CrashType: Motorcycle vs Car/Front to Right Side Impact with Secondary Lay-Down Event. (on-scene investigation/on-scene photographs)
Crash:
This is a two-vehicle crash involving moderate injuries to the rider that occurred during daylight hours in June 2011 at 1410 hrs. In Southern California. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was 72 degrees F. The roadway was made of asphalt which was dry, well-worn and polished, but in good condition. The wind was a mild cross breeze from left to right for the riders direction of travel. The crash occurred in the middle of a three-leg intersection that had no signal control devices. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of residential structures. The roadway in question at the crash scene consists of four thru lanes, two in each direction; one right turn only lane and a bike lane for the direction of the motorcycle. In the opposite direction there is a left turn lane leading to the intersection and a merging lane leaving the intersection for cross traffic from the third leg of the intersection. There are only painted dividers in the roadway that are tapered and rounded for traffic turns, but reach a width of approximately 3?. The roadway runs in a north/south orientation and is straight in the crash area. There is a concrete curb, sidewalk and over-head street lights on the NB side of the road, which is the direction of travel for the Case Vehicle. The other side of the road has fencing covered with greenery and trees, and a soft shoulder. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. The side street is made of asphalt and in very good condition. It has raised concrete curbs and no sidewalks. It leads to a gated residential community with a guard shack. 
OV1 was a 2008 Harley Davidson Ultra CLA cruiser motorcycle that was being operated by a 48 year old Caucasian male, (70 in., 185 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing a full face helmet with a clear shield and no other motorcycle related protective clothing. The operator of Case Vehicle was proceeding NB at approximately 30 mph in a posted 50 mph zone with very heavy traffic due to construction further ahead with a lane closure. The operator was either riding in the bike lane passing slower vehicles or went straight from the right turn only lane when the collision occurred. The rider then impacted the Other Vehicle in the right side passenger front door. The rider then was fully ejected from the motorcycle, but landed next to it in the roadway at their FRP?s. The Other Vehicle was a 2010 Cadillac DTS, four door sedan, grey in color driven by a 66 year old Caucasian female, (67 in., 155 lbs.). Other driver was driving SB and making a left turn to return home. She was driving between five to ten mph. as she was making her turning movement.
RiderInj: The 48 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a broken leg and wrist (unknown which wrist) and was hospitalized for three days. There was no evidence of impairment and no tests were given.
Human: The 48 yr. old rider was driving at a speed which was too fast for the conditions and in an improper lane to enter the intersection.
Vehicle: The case vehicle involved was found to have a pre-crash non-functional R/T signal, and a loose side stand, but still meets SAE requirements. The post-crash investigation of the vehicle showed that the tires were good and the overall pre-crash mechanical condition was good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This motorcycle crash involved a laydown event in response to an encroaching Other (Non-Contacted) Vehicle. The case motorcycle was laid-down onto the left side plane resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the rider.
MV1: 1996 Harley Davidson Road King (touring) motorcycle 1138cc, black in color
OV1: 2007 Nissan Frontier (pick-up truck), red in color
Crash: This single vehicle motorcycle ?lay down? crash occurred within a four-leg intersection in July 2011 at 0730 hours in Southern California. The weather was cloudy, the temperature was 73.0 degrees F and it was calm with no prevailing winds. The roadway surface was of an asphalt composition, was dry and, in good condition. The intersection is controlled by posted multi-phase street lights for all four directions of travel. The east/west portion of the roadway surface consists of two lanes for each direction of travel and designated left turn lanes. These lanes are undivided and separated only by a set of painted solid double yellow lines. Both sides of the roadway contain designated bike lanes as well as raised concrete curbs and sidewalks. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The north/south portion of the roadway consists of two lanes for each direction of travel as well as designated left turn lane. There are also designated bike lanes with raised concrete curbs and sidewalks on both sides of the roadway. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The case vehicle was a 1996 Harley Davidson Road motorcycle that was being operated by a 60 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was wearing a DOT approved helmet at the time of the crash. The Other Vehicle (OV1) was being operated by a 50 year old female Caucasian who sustained no injuries or damage to her vehicle.The motorcycle rider was traveling eastbound in the #1 lane at a speed of about 40-45 mph approaching the intersection. The Other Vehicle (OV1) was stopped at the intersection, first position, in the northbound #1 lane. As the motorcycle and rider continued the approach to the intersection, facing a green light, OV1 moved forward into the intersection at a speed of about 2-3 mph. The motorcycle rider reacted to the incursion of OV1 by braking and sliding out, laying his bike down on the left side. The rider stayed with the motorcycle as it continued to slide into the intersection. Other driver of OV1 stopped her vehicle in the intersection avoiding contact with the motorcycle.
RiderInj: The rider of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions to his arms, hands and, legs. The rider was treated at the scene and subsequently transported to a local hospital for treatment.
Human: The 50 year old female operator of OV1 failed to remain stopped for a red light when she moved her vehicle into the intersection.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor left side damage as a result of impacting with the roadway surface however, appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition. The other vehicle (OV1) sustained no damage.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs Fixed Object with Secondary Lay-Down Event. (on-scene investigation/on-scene photographs)
Crash:
This is a single vehicle crash involving moderate injuries to the rider that occurred during daylight in July 2011 at 0730 hours in Southern California. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was approximately 62 degrees F.	The roadway was made of asphalt which was dry, well-worn and polished, but in good condition. There was no wind. The crash occurred on a straight portion of roadway with a significant downhill grade for the direction of travel for Case Vehicle in the middle of a three leg intersection that had no signal control devices. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of residential structures. The roadway in question at the crash scene consists of four thru lanes, two in each direction; one right turn only lane and a bike lane for the direction of the motorcycle. In the opposite direction there is a left turn lane leading to the intersection and a merging lane leaving the intersection for cross traffic from the third leg of the intersection. There are only painted dividers in the roadway that are tapered and rounded for traffic turns, but reach a width of approximately 3?. The roadway runs in a north/south orientation and is straight in the crash area. There is a concrete curb, sidewalk and over-head street lights on the NB side of the road, which is the direction of travel for the Case Vehicle. The other side of the road has fencing covered with greenery and trees, and a soft shoulder. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. The side street is made of asphalt and in very good condition. It has raised concrete curbs and no sidewalks. It leads to a gated residential community with a guard shack. Crash Situation Case Vehicle was a 2008 Harley Davidson Ultra CLA cruiser motorcycle that was being operated by a 48 year old Caucasian male, (70 in., 185 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing a full face helmet with a clear shield and no other motorcycle related protective clothing. The operator of Case Vehicle was proceeding NB at approximately 30 mph in a posted 50 mph zone with very heavy traffic due to construction further ahead with a lane closure. The operator was either riding in the bike lane passing slower vehicles or went straight from the right turn only lane when the collision occurred. The rider then impacted the Other Vehicle in the right side passenger front door. The rider then was fully ejected from the motorcycle, but landed next to it in the roadway at their FRP?s.
 The Other Vehicle was a 2010 Cadillac DTS, four door sedan, grey in color driven by a 66 year old Caucasian female, (67 in., 155 lbs.). Other driver was driving SB and making a left turn to return home. She was driving between five to ten mph. as she was making her turning movement.
RiderInj: The 48 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a broken leg and wrist and was hospitalized for three days. There was no evidence of impairment and no tests were given.
Human: The 48 yr. old rider was driving at a speed which was too fast for the conditions and in an improper lane to enter the intersection.
Vehicle: The case vehicle involved was found to have a pre-crash non-functional R/T signal, and a loose side stand, but still meets SAE requirements. The post-crash investigation of the vehicle showed that the tires were good and the overall pre-crash mechanical condition was good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs Fixed Object with Secondary Lay-Down Event. (on-scene investigation/on-scene photographs)
Crash:
This is a single motorcycle crash with two fatalities occurring in July 2011 at 0130 hrs. in Southern California. It was dark, the weather was overcast, and the temperature was approximately 57 degrees F. The asphalt roadway was dry at the time. It was well worn and polished, but in good repair. The wind was light.

The crash occurred at the entrance to a three-leg intersection that had no signal control devices. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of residential structures on the riders? right and a fenced in field to the left. The roadway in question at the crash scene runs in an east/west configuration and consists of
four through lanes, two in each direction. In the opposite direction there is a left turn lane leading to the intersection which has a raised concrete divider both on the lanes left side and at its terminus, protecting the lane from on-coming traffic. The roadway has a right curve prior to the first harmful event, and then
curves left before going straight. The roadway has concrete curbs on both sides, and a sidewalk on the Case Vehicles? right. There are overhead street lights that were functioning properly. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

The side street is made of asphalt and in good condition. It has raised concrete curbs and no sidewalks.

Case Vehicle was a 2001 Honda CBR900, predominately yellow in color. It was being operated by a 22 yr. old Hispanic male (5? 07?/185) and had a 31 yr. old female Caucasian (5?01?/127) passenger. Both were wearing full-face helmets that appear to not have been strapped.

Case vehicle was proceeding in a WB direction at a very high rate of speed, (80-90 mph) when it failed to negotiate a right curve and sideswiped the center divider. Case vehicle then moved laterally and sharply to the right, striking the right curb. Case vehicle then continued WB while making prolong contact with the curb, and fully ejected both the rider and passenger. The Case vehicle made a glancing contact with a 24? diameter wooden utility pole, and then continued in a WB direction for another 300? before coming to its FRP.

When both occupants of the Case vehicle were ejected, they tumbled/slid on the sidewalk and then impacted into the utility pole. After which, they were deflected a few feet to the right and into a block wall and utility vent pipe where they came to rest.
RiderInj: Both the rider and passenger sustained fatal injuries. The rider was pronounced dead at the scene. The passenger was taken to a trauma center where she died during surgery. Both were impaired from alcohol consumption according to the coroner?s report.
Human: The 22 yr. old rider was driving while impaired and at a speed which was too fast for the roadway configuration.
Vehicle: The case vehicle involved was found to have extensive post-crash damage. It did appear to have been well maintained prior to the crash. The tires and brake pads looked to be near new. The post-crash investigation of the vehicle showed that the overall pre-crash mechanical condition was good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle (pick-up truck) sideswipe type traffic collision, resulting in minor injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
MV1: 1996 Yamaha Virago motorcycle (Black & White in color)
Crash:
This is a motorcycle vs. vehicle (pick-up truck) traffic collision involving minor injuries to the rider that occurred during daylight in July 2011 at 0910 hours in Southern California. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was 68 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was found to be dry, well-worn and polished, but in good condition. There was little to no measurable wind direction at the time of the collision and, the skies were clear.

The crash occurred on a multiple lane roadway in proximity of a signal control intersection. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of state owned land and commercial districts. The area is also surrounded by tall vegetation such as trees. The roadway at the crash scene is a major north south arterial feeding commercial districts and allows access to a state highway. There are two lanes dedicated to northbound traffic and two lanes for southbound traffic. Theses lanes of traffic are separated by a 6 inch raised concrete and asphalt median approximately 12 feet 6 inches in width. Southbound traffic is afforded a designated right turn only lane for access to the state highway. Northbound traffic is afforded access to the state highway by a single lane on-ramp at an uncontrolled offset intersection. The roadway is illuminated by overhead street lights. The speed limit in this area is 30 mph.

Case Vehicle was a 1996 Yamaha Virago motorcycle that was being operated by a 32 year old Caucasian male. The rider was wearing DOT approved motorcycle helmet and, protective upper body armored clothing at the time of the collision. The MC rider of Case Vehicle was travelling northbound on the inside #1 lane at approximately 25-30 mph in a posted 30 mph zone with moderate traffic. The other vehicle (OV) was travelling in the same direction, at approximately the same speed in the #2 lane, adjacent to the case vehicle.

As the motorcycle continued northbound approaching the state highway on-ramp, the other vehicle suddenly initiated a lane change movement form the #2 to the #1 lane. The motorcycle rider was caught completely unaware of the other vehicles sudden lane change and did not initiate any kind of collision avoidance maneuver. The lane change caused the motorcycle to impact the other vehicle along the right rear quarter panel with the entire left side of the
 
bike. The motorcycle and rider remained in contact with the other vehicle until such time the rider was ejected and the motorcycle dropped onto the roadway surface landing on the rider. The other vehicle continued in a forward motion and continued turning onto the state highway on-ramp. The driver of the other vehicle eventually pulled over and stopped a short distance away.
RiderInj: The 32 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of a head trauma, neck sprain, numerous abrasions to both hands, the left thigh and leg. Both the left knee and foot sustained sprain type injuries as well. The rider was treated at the scene and subsequently transported to a local hospital for treatment. The motorcycle rider showed no apparent signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The 22 year old male Hispanic driver of the other vehicle had been preoccupied with attempting to interpret a GPS device, failed to stop for a red light prior to the precipitating event, made an unsafe lane change while attempting to access the state highway on ramp when cutting off the motorcycle and causing the collision.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor left and right side damage however, appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs Car/Front to Left Side Impact, with Secondary Lay-Down Event.
Crash:
This is a two-vehicle crash involving severe injuries to the rider that occurred during night hours in August 2011 at 2142 hrs. in Southern California. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was 66 degrees F. The roadway was made of asphalt which was dry, well-worn and polished, but in good condition. The wind was a mild cross breeze from left to right for the riders direction of travel.

The crash occurred in the Southbound #4 lane approximately 316 feet North of an East-West signal controlled intersection. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of commercial structures. The roadway consists of two right turn lanes, four thru lanes and two left turn lanes on the Southbound side, for the direction of the motorcycle. In the opposite direction there are three thru lanes and one merging lane leading from the intersection and a merging lane leaving the freeway. There is a raised concrete and brick center median that is approximately 11? wide, narrowing to approximately 4? at the intersection. The roadway runs in a north/south orientation and is straight in the crash area. There is a concrete curb, sidewalk and over-head street lights on the SB side of the road, which is the direction of travel for Vehicle # 1. The other side of the road has a concrete curb, sidewalk and overhead street lights. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

The side street is made of asphalt and in very good condition. It has raised concrete curbs, sidewalks, raised center median and overhead street lights. Both streets are non-freeway principal thoroughfares.

Vehicle #1 is a 2009 Honda CBR 1000RR sport motorcycle that was being operated by a 50 year old Caucasian male, (67 in., 155 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing an unknown style of helmet and unknown clothing.

The operator of the Vehicle #1 was proceeding SB at approximately 45 mph in a posted 45 mph zone with heavy traffic. The operator was riding in the number three lane, passing slower vehicles in the number four lane, in order to change lanes to the left turn lanes. The rider crossed in front of the Other Vehicle, and was struck in the left rear quarter. The motorcycle slid left side down, approximately 163? south, to its FRP in the number two lane. It is unknown where the rider came to rest.
 
The Other Vehicle was a 2004 Chevrolet Caviler, sedan, silver in color driven by a 24 year old female, (64 in., 183 lbs.). Other driver was driving SB proceeding straight in the number 4 lane. She was driving approximately 45 mph.
RiderInj: The 50 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a broken left rib and punctured/collapsed left lung and was hospitalized for an unknown number of days. There was no evidence of impairment and no tests were given at the scene.
Human: The 50 yr. old rider was driving at a speed which was too fast for the conditions and in an improper lane to enter the left turn lane.
Vehicle: The case vehicle involved was found to have a pre-crash front tire with excessive wear. The post-crash investigation of the vehicle showed that the tires were under inflated, but the overall mechanical condition was good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: Single Motorcycle Lay-Down Event
Crash:
This is a single motorcycle lay-down event causing moderate injuries to the rider that occurred in August 2011 at 1220 hrs. in Southern California. It was daytime and the weather was clear. The temperature was approximately 75? F. The asphalt roadway was dry at the time. It was well worn and polished, but in good repair. The wind was light.

The crash occurred at a four-leg intersection that had signal control devices. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of commercial businesses on the riders? right and residential area to the left. The roadway at the crash scene runs in an east/west configuration and consists of three thru lanes, with dedicated left and right turn lanes. The roadway has a raised center divider. In the opposite direction there are four thru lanes reducing to three. There are two left turn lanes leading to the intersection. The direction of travel for Vehicle 1 has a slight downgrade and is straight. The roadway has concrete curbs and sidewalks on both sides as well as overhead street lights. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.
Vehicle 1 was a 1978 Suzuki GS 1000, red in color. It was being operated by a 64 yr. old White male (6?02?, 200 lbs.) who was wearing an open face motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield.

Vehicle 1 was proceeding eastbound slowing/stopping for a red light. When the light turned green, he started to proceed, however his front brake was locked and he was unable to power through it and fell to his right on the roadway, causing injuries to himself. The rider said that the brake fluid was very old and caused the brakes to malfunction. The rider was fully ejected at the area of the first harmful event. Both the rider and motorcycle POI/POR coincide.
RiderInj: The rider had visible injuries and was treated at the scene and taken to the hospital. He sustained a complex peri-orbital fracture of the of the right cheek area, lacerations above his right eye and to his right foot/big toe. He also sustained an abrasion to his right knee. There was no evidence of impairment and no tests were given.
Human: The 64 yr. old rider has a long riding history; however, has very little experience in dealing with mechanical failures. In this case, he failed to activate the clutch to prevent the crash. He also failed to properly maintain his vehicle.
Vehicle: The case vehicle involved was found to have minor post- crash damage. The tires and brake pads looked to be in good condition. The post- crash investigation of the vehicle showed that the overall pre-crash mechanical condition was good. What was not visible was the condition of the old brake fluid that had been changed. The mechanic said that it was in poor condition and probably caused the brakes to seize.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Car sideswipe with Non-Contact OV involved
Crash:
This is a two-vehicle crash with a non-contact vehicle that fled the scene. The rider sustained major injuries. The crash occurred during daylight hours in July 2011 at 1625 hrs. in Southern California. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was 76 degrees F. The roadway was made of asphalt that was dry, well-travelled and polished, but otherwise in good condition. The wind was a light cross breeze from left to right for the riders direction of travel.

The crash occurred in the mid-block between signal controlled intersections which were far away in either direction. The surrounding area is comprised of a fenced oil field on the riders? right and a beach with the Pacific Ocean on the left. There is no on street parking in either direction. On the right side of the road is a dirt pathway with medium size shrubbery. There is a parking strip separated from the roadway on the ocean side of the road. The roadway at the crash scene consists of four thru lanes, two in each direction with a safety/bike lane. There is a raised center median that is approximately 15? wide. Concrete curbs as well as the center median are 8? tall. The roadway in this location runs primarily in an east/west orientation. The posted speed limit is 60 mph.
Case Vehicle was a 2003 Harley Davidson Super Glide custom cruiser motorcycle that was being operated by a 46 year old Caucasian male, (6? 3?, 180 lbs.) who was wearing a full coverage open face helmet with a visor and no face shield. It is unknown what other protective clothing/gear he may have been wearing. The rider refused to participate in the study.

The operator of Case Vehicle was proceeding WB at approximately 60 mph in moderate to heavy traffic in the #1 (outside curb lane) when the Non-Contact OV- 1 began passing vehicles on the right side in the bike lane. When this vehicle attempted to return to the #1 lane, he did not see the M/C and nearly ran into it.
This was the precipitating event for the ensuing crash events. The rider swerved to his left in a collision avoidance maneuver, leaving his lane and entering the
#2 lane (inside) and struck OV-2 causing him to lose control of the M/C and go down. The M/C slid on its? left side, high side forward to its? FRP. The rider was fully ejected and slid/tumbled to his FRP not too far from the M/C. OV -2 left skid marks after contact with the M/C and swerved to its? left, coming to rest on the center median. The driver of the Non-Contact (OV-1) vehicle fled the scene without stopping.
RiderInj: The 46 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a torn anus, fractures to his left pelvic region and dislocation; left hand; left side ribs; and numerous abrasions. The rider was hospitalized for an unknown amount of days. There was no evidence of impairment and no tests were given.
Human: The 21 yr. old driver of the Non-Contact OV was under the influence of alcohol and driving at a high rate of speed and in an unsafe manner.
Vehicle: The case vehicle involved sustained major damage, mostly to the left side. The post-crash investigation of the vehicle showed that the tires were good and the overall pre-crash mechanical condition was good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. utility truck, left side and rear end impact collision with a secondary lay down event.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle crash event that occurred in Southern California in August 2011in the early evening. The weather was clear with a temperature of 73 degrees F and there were no prevailing winds. The roadway surface was of an asphalt composition and was in good repair. There are no significant grade or crown issues with the roadway surface.

The crash occurred in the northbound number one lane of a multiple lane, major arterial highway. The posted speed limit on this roadway is 45 mph and there were no traffic control devices in proximity to the crash event. The roadway surface has four lanes designated for northbound traffic, four lanes for southbound traffic and they are separated by a 3 foot 6 inch wide raised concrete median. The west side of the roadway has a raised concrete curb and sidewalks bordered by multiple family unit apartment complexes. The east side of the roadway has a dirt and gravel shoulder that is approximately 6 feet in width adjacent to a construction site.

MC1 was being operated by a 61 year old male rider. There was also a female passenger seated behind him. There is currently no data regarding helmet information due in part to both the rider and passenger?s refusal to participate with the research.
MC1 was northbound at an approximate speed of 10 mph with the presence of heavy traffic on the roadway. This was due in part to a previous traffic accident further north of the rider?s location.

The rider had initially moved from a designated left turn lane, changing lanes to the right, into the adjacent northbound number one lane prior to the crash event.
 
The rider was accelerating at the time however, failed to see the traffic stopped in front of him. The rider attempted a collision avoidance maneuver by braking and attempting to swerve to the left however impacted the left rear section of the camper shell, left rear quarter panel and bumper of OV1 as it was stopped in traffic.

OV1 was being operated by a 48 year old female driver. She had been travelling northbound in the number one lane and came to a full and complete stop prior to the crash event. There were no passengers in the vehicle and the driver did not sustain any injuries.
RiderInj: The rider of MC1 sustained a laceration to his right shoulder, right hand, and a complaint of pain to his neck. The passenger of MC1 sustained a laceration to her right arm. There was no evidence of alcohol and/or drug impairment on either the rider or passenger.
ODriverInj: The operator of the other vehicle (OV1) was uninjured and there was no issue with drug or alcohol impairment.
Human: The rider of MC1 was travelling too fast for the present traffic conditions on the roadway at the time of the crash event.
Vehicle: Other than the damage sustained, both vehicles had been in satisfactory operating condition at the time of the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Other Vehicle with Secondary Lay-Down Event. (on-scene investigation/on-scene photographs)
Crash:
This is a motorcycle vs. other vehicle broadside crash causing minor injuries to the rider that occurred on August 2011 at 1420 hrs. in Southern California. It was daytime and the weather was clear. The temperature was approximately 78? F. The asphalt roadway was dry at the time. It was well worn and polished, but in good repair. The wind was light.

The crash occurred at a three-leg intersection that had no signal control devices. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of residential structures (mobile home park) on the riders? right, and a fenced in field to the left. The roadway at the crash scene runs in an east/west configuration and consists of one lane in each direction and a left turn lane in the opposite direction of the rider. The roadway has a painted divider consisting of double yellow lines. The entrance/exit of the mobile home park, which is more like a private drive, is controlled by a stop sign and a painted limit line. It is a gated community with a guard shack. The roadway is straight and level. The roadway has concrete curbs on both sides, and a sidewalk on Vehicle 1?s right. There are overhead street lights on the riders? right side only. There is a dirt path on the riders? left side of the road. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

The side street is made of asphalt and in good condition. It has raised concrete curbs, sidewalks, and a curb height center divider/planter which is set back from the prolongation of the south curb line.
Vehicle 1 is a 1985 Yamaha 1100CL, blue in color. It was being operated by a 56 yr. old Asian male (70?, 165 lbs.) who was wearing a full face motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield.

Vehicle 1 was proceeding eastbound at the posted speed limit when the Other Vehicle proceeded to make a left turn in front of him at a nominal speed. The rider swerved slightly to the left and then braked, leaving approximately 17? of rear wheel locked skid. Vehicle 1 then impacted the left side of the other vehicle and then contacted the ground. The rider was fully ejected at the area of the first harmful event. Both the rider and motorcycle POI/POR coincide.
RiderInj:
The rider complained of pain at the scene. He refused medical attention. He later went to the hospital on his own. He
 
sustained bilateral broken toes, bilateral abrasions/contusions to his knees and ankles.
Human:
The 56 yr. old rider was driving at the posted speed limit, but made the wrong evasive actions and poorly applied them. For the Other Vehicle
driver, poor traffic scan was a factor.
Vehicle: The case vehicle involved was found to have moderate post- crash damage, which included a 7.9? reduction in wheelbase. The tires and brake pads looked to be in good condition. The post-crash investigation of the vehicle showed that the overall pre-crash mechanical condition was good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Fixed Object with Lay-Down Event.
Crash:
This is a single motorcycle crash with minor injuries to the rider that occurred during daylight hours in August 2011 at 1919 hours in Southern California. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was 75 degrees F. The roadway was made of asphalt that was dry, well-worn and polished, but in good condition. The wind was a mild cross breeze from left to right for the riders direction of travel.

The crash occurred mid-block well between signal controlled intersections. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of residential structures. The roadway runs in an east/west configuration, consists of four thru lanes, two in each direction; a bike lane, and a safety lane in the direction the M/C was travelling. The roadway has an 8? raised concrete curb that makes up a 14? wide center divider that is planted with trees and bushes. The roadway in the eastbound direction has a left curve for the rider?s direction of travel. There are concrete curbs, sidewalks, and over-head street lights on the both sides of the road.
There are several large bushes and trees adjacent to the sidewalk on the rider?s right side. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

Vehicle 1 was a 1990 Harley Davidson Heritage motorcycle that was being operated by a 21 year old Hispanic male, (72 in., 180 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing a full face helmet with a clear shield and no other motorcycle related protective clothing.

Vehicle 1 was proceeding EB at approximately 45+ mph in a posted 40 mph zone. As the rider entered the left curve of the road, he realized that his speed was too great for him to negotiate the turn and applied his brakes, locking the rear. The bike started to slide out with the rear brake locked, and the rider released the brakes in an attempt to straighten out and regain control. He then impacted into the curb. The bike then scrapped the curb continuously for some distance until the rider was fully ejected at which point the M/C continued to its FRP in the safety lane.
RiderInj: The 21 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained abrasions to his right leg and wrist. He was taken to a hospital where he was treated and released. There was no evidence of impairment and no tests were given.
Human: The 21 yr. old rider was driving at a speed that was too fast for the conditions and the curvature in the road.
Vehicle: The case vehicle involved was found to have no pre-crash conditions. The post-crash investigation of the vehicle showed that the tires were good and the overall pre-crash mechanical condition was good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. automobile (OV1), front to left side impact collision with a secondary lay down event.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle crash event that occurred in Southern California in August 2011 at 1927 hours. The weather was clear with a temperature of 78.1 degrees F and a mild tailwind for MC1. The roadway surface was of an asphalt composition and was in good repair. There are no significant grade or crown issues with the roadway surface.

The crash occurred in the southbound number one lane of a multiple lane, connector roadway. The posted speed limit on this roadway is 40 mph and there were no traffic control devices in proximity to the crash event. The roadway surface has three lanes designated for northbound traffic, three lanes for southbound traffic and they are separated by a painted 10 foot wide two-way left turn lane. Both sides of the roadway have raised concrete curbs and sidewalks bordered by commercial and retail businesses.

MC1 was being operated by a 19 year old male rider. There was also a 24 year old male passenger seated behind him. There is currently no data regarding helmet for the male passenger due to his refusal to participate with the research.

MC1 was southbound accelerating from a standing stop in the #2 lane of traffic to an approximate speed of 40 mph with the presence of light to moderate traffic on the roadway.

OV1 was being operated by a 93 year old male driver. There was a female passenger present in the vehicle. Prior to the crash event the driver of OV1 was exiting a private driveway of a commercial shopping complex. The driver moved his vehicle onto the roadway crossing the southbound lanes of traffic attempting to negotiate a left turn movement into the northbound lanes of traffic.
 
The driver of OV1 had initially waited for traffic to clear before proceeding onto the roadway however failed to notice MC1 due in part to periodic traffic volume prior to the crash event.

The rider of MC1 was accelerating at the time and initially detected the presence of OV1 crossing his lane of travel. The rider attempted to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver by applying his brakes, downshifting and swerving left. The rider swerved left from the #2 southbound lane into the #1 lane as OV1 continued crossing from his right to left at a slow rate of speed. The rider of MC1 impacted OV1 at the left front quarter panel and driver side door at the A- pillar. The rider maintained his position on the bike until such time when the bike collapsed left side down onto the roadway surface. The passenger of MC1 was ejected off the right side and impacted the roadway surface. Both rider and passenger came to rest within six feet of the area of impact.
RiderInj: The rider of MC1 sustained a laceration to his right ankle and abrasions to his right arm.. The passenger of MC1 sustained abrasions to both his elbows. There was no evidence of alcohol and/or drug impairment on either the rider or passenger.
ODriverInj: The operator and passenger of OV1 was uninjured and there were no issues with drug or alcohol impairment.
Human: The 19 year old operator of MC1 was unlicensed and lacked the experience to operate a motorcycle in an emergency situation. The 93 year old driver of OV1 failed to perceive the presence of MC1 approaching his location.
Vehicle: Other than the damage sustained, both vehicles had been in satisfactory operating condition at the time of the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. SUV / Front to Side Impact with Fatal Injuries.
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in September 2011 at 2224 hours in Southern California. It was dark and the weather was partly cloudy, the temperature was 65 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry at the time and was noted to be travel worn.

The crash occurred on a lightly traveled North/South local street that consists of one southbound travel lane, one northbound travel lane, with a northbound left turn lane at crash location. The roadway is bordered on the west side by 8? raised curbing and sidewalks, the east side is bordered by 8? raised curbing. The asphalt roadway surface is level at the crash location and the posted speed limit is 35 mph.

Vehicle 1 was a 2011 Suzuki GSXR 750 (750cc) Sport/Race replica motorcycle that was being operated by a 23 year old Caucasian male (72 in., 195 lbs.) who was wearing a full face helmet with a smoke colored plastic visor. The operator of Vehicle 1 (Suzuki GSXR) was proceeding southbound in lane 1 (curb lane) at an estimated speed of approximately 45 mph, doing a wheelie.

Vehicle 2 was a 2006 Honda Element was being operated by a 28 year-old Caucasian female (65 in., 125 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing the available three- point manual lap and shoulder restraint. The 28 year-old female entered the northbound left turn lane, slowing with left turn signal on prior to making a left turn. The driver of Vehicle 2 (Honda Element) turned left with the intention of entering a driveway. She initially traversed the southbound travel lane without detecting Vehicle 1 (Suzuki GSXR) due to the high angle of vehicle 1?s headlight and was struck by vehicle 1 on the right side.

Vehicle 1 (Suzuki GSXR) came down on both wheels, then flipped over onto to its top and slid rear first (right side) impacting vehicle 2 (Honda Element) at an acute impact angle on the right side doors and breaking the right side rear wheel. Both vehicles engaged in a ?sideslap? as the right side of the rear wheel, exhaust and foot pegs of the motorcycle rips into the sheet metal of the right B pillar, rear door panel and rear wheel of Vehicle 2 (Honda Element). The motorcycle and the Honda separated as the motorcycle lays down on its left side plane. The motorcycle spins and slides to its FRP. The rider of the motorcycle was ejected as the motorcycle flips onto its top plane causing the rider to be vaulted forward head first onto the pavement, where he slides feet first on his
 
back to his FRP. The rider came to rest on the northbound roadway facing north-east and the bike came to rest listing on its left side and facing east at its final rest position. Vehicle 2 (Honda Element) came to rest in center of the driveway and was facing north. The rider was unresponsive at the scene and was transported to a hospital where he succumbed to his injuries.
RiderInj: The deceased 23 year old male operator of the motorcycle had a BAC of .07 and sustained the following (AIS-3) injuries: a diffuse cerebral edema, vascular injury with peri-renal hematoma, splenic rupture, left lung laceration and bilateral pulmonary contusions. He also sustained Diffuse bilateral subarachnoid hemorrhage, multiple fracture (AIS-2) injuries. Minor abrasions, contusions, a forehead laceration and avulsion of the left #3 and 4 fingers (AIS-1) injuries. The operator of Vehicle 2 was uninjured in the crash but had a BAC of .05 at the crash scene.
Human: Both the 23 year old male rider of vehicle 1 (Suzuki GSXR) and the 28 year old female driver of vehicle 2 (Honda Element) were impaired by alcohol. The rider of vehicle 1 (Suzuki GSXR) was performing an unsafe act ?wheelie? reducing the ability of the driver of vehicle 2 (Honda Element) to see the motorcycle before starting her left turn.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were free of defects and determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: Motorcycle Lay-Down Event.
Crash:
This is a single-motorcycle crash with minor injuries to the rider that occurred during daylight hours in September 2011 at 1103 hrs. in Southern California. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was 68 degrees F. The roadway was made of asphalt that was dry, well-worn and polished, but in good condition. The wind was a mild tail wind.

The crash occurred at a T-type intersection with no signal controls. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of residential structures. The roadway runs in a north/south configuration and consists of three thru lanes in each direction, and a bike lane. The roadway has an 8? raised concrete curb on either side with concrete sidewalks. There is also an 8? raised concrete curb/center divider with trees and grass that is 14? wide. The roadway is straight. The crash occurred on the concrete gutter way adjoining the two streets. The gutter way had standing water in it and a slimy substance similar to algae or fine dirt which made it very slippery. A resident came out and told me that the water is present most of the time due to poor drainage slope and that the water usually comes from the sprinkler systems. There are street lights on both sides of the road. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

Vehicle 1 was a 2007 Lance Milan 150 cc step though that was being operated by a 60 year old White male, (5? 10?, 170 lbs.), who was wearing a full coverage helmet with a clear shield and no other motorcycle related protective clothing.

The operator of Vehicle 1 was proceeding NB and had slowed to approximately 5 mph in a posted 45 mph zone, to make a right turn. As the rider entered the gutter way with the standing water, he lost friction contact with the roadway surface and the motorcycle slid out from under him on its right side, low side forward. The rider was fully ejected and slid next to the vehicle until they reached their FRP?s, which was side by side. The rider stated that he never let go of the left hand grip.
RiderInj: The 60 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor abrasions/contusions to his hand and torso right side. He was treated at the scene and released. He later went to a hospital and was diagnosed with minor soft tissue damage. There was no evidence of impairment and no tests were given.
Human: The 60 yr. old rider was driving at a speed which safe for the turn, but his lack of experience caused him to not identify the potential hazard of making a turn in standing water.
Vehicle: The case vehicle involved was found to have no pre-crash conditions. The post-crash investigation of the vehicle showed that the tires were good and the overall pre-crash mechanical condition was good.
Environmental: The standing water and slimy substance in the gutter way were definite environmental factors linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Deer
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred on a morning in September 2011 at 0609 hours in Southern California. It was dark at the time and the roadway was not lighted. The temperature was 51 degrees F and it was overcast at the time with no precipitation. The winds were calm and the asphalt roadway surface was dry at the time with minor surface cracking.

The crash occurred on an un-divided two-lane, State Highway, in a rural wilderness area. The area of the crash is composed of one westbound travel lane and one eastbound travel lane. There is a 2? 9? center lane divider that has solid yellow (no passing) lines with a rumble strip in the center. There is a paved and dirt shoulder with brush and trees bordering the north roadside and a dirt shoulder mountain slope on the south roadside. There are no traffic controls at this area and the posted speed limit is 55 mph.

Vehicle 1 was a 2008 Black Suzuki C-90 Boulevard cruiser motorcycle, being operated by a 47 year old female (63 in., 192 lbs.) who was wearing a full face helmet with a clear face shield at the time of the crash. The operator of Vehicle 1 was proceeding westbound immediately adjacent to the painted center line at an estimated speed of approximately 55 mph. The rider had just negotiated a left curve in the roadway and was entering a straight
section of the roadway, when a deer crossed the road from right to left from the brush adjacent to the road. The rider reported that she had no time to avoid a collision. She struck the deer with the left side of the front fender and the left crash bar and fairing. The motorcycle subsequently laid-down on its left side, sliding approximately 107? to its final rest, approximately 2? 6? south of the north lane line.
The rider was ejected from the bike and came to rest in the westbound travel lane just west of impact location. The rider was subsequently transported to a local hospital where she was admitted for her injuries.
RiderInj: The 47 year old female operator of the motorcycle lost consciousness for an indeterminate length of time, regaining consciousness at the scene. She also sustained abrasions to her left elbow, left hand, right knee and a hematoma to right lower leg.
Human: The motorcycle operator was operating the vehicle at a speed that was prudent, but had insufficient time to react to the deer crossing in front of her.
Vehicle: There were no vehicular factors that contributed to the crash causation.
Environmental: There were trees and brush adjacent to both sides of roadway that may have contributed to the crash causation factors.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) broadside type crash resulting in major injuries to the rider. There were no passengers with the rider of the motorcycle
MV1: 2009 Yamaha Royal Star Classic (Touring) 1063cc, red in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle broadside type crash that occurred in Southern California in September 2011 at 1337 hours. The weather was partly cloudy with a temperature of 71.6 degrees F. There was a light tailwind for the motorcyclist. The roadway surface travelled by the other vehicle was of an asphalt composition and was in good repair. The roadway surface travelled by the motorcycle was of a concrete composition and, it too was found to be in good repair.

The crash occurred on a four leg, multiple lane, minor arterial roadway surface, with three lanes in each direction. There are also designated left turn lanes for all four directions of travel. The intersection is also controlled by multi-phased overhead signal lights. The surrounding area is compromised by commercial/retail businesses. West of the intersection is a raised center divider and the roadway surface is bordered by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks. The posted speed limit is 35 mph for east and westbound traffic.

The case vehicle was a 2009 Yamaha Royal Star Classic touring type motorcycle that was being operated by a 48 year old female Caucasian. The rider was wearing a full face FMVSS-218 rated DOT approved motorcycle helmet with a clear plastic face shield.

Prior to the crash event both vehicles were approaching perpendicular to each other. MC1 was southbound in the #1 through lane of traffic on a State Highway Off-ramp.

The rider was positioned on the left side of the lane adjacent to her friend; another rider. Both were at a standing stop for a red light. Upon receiving a green
 
light the both riders proceeded forward into the intersection. The rider of the case vehicle (MC1) followed behind her friend.

The other vehicle (OV1) was approaching the intersection westbound in the #1 lane through lane and entered the intersection against a red light. The rider of MC1 told me during her interview that she never saw the other vehicle approaching and that her view had been blocked by other vehicles adjacent to her. The other vehicle driver attempted to swerve left in an apparent collision avoidance maneuver however the rider of MC1 struck OV1 along the right front quarter panel. The rider was ejected of the motorcycle onto the hood, striking the windshield and eventually falling onto the roadway surface. The motorcycle collapsed onto the roadway surface, left side down and slid to its final resting place west of the intersection.
RiderInj: The 48 year old female rider sustained major injuries consisting of multiple fractures to her ribs and a punctured lung. She also sustained numerous contusions on her extremities, groin and the left side of her torso. The rider was treated at the scene and subsequently transported to a local hospital. At the time of the crash the rider was wearing a motorcycle oriented jacket, gloves and, boots which likely reduced or prevented any further injuries. When contacted by law enforcement officials, there were no apparent issues with drug or alcohol with the rider.
ODriverInj: The operator of the other vehicle (OV1) was uninjured and there was no issue with drug or alcohol impairment.
Human: The driver of the other vehicle failed to perceive the dangers of entering the intersection against a red phased signal light.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate left side damage as a result of the collision. The other vehicle (OV1) sustained moderate right side damage to the door, quarter panel and, windshield.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash.

CrashType: This was a vehicle vs. motorcycle vs. other vehicle (pick-up truck) rear-end type traffic collision, resulting in minor injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a three vehicle rear-end crash in which the stopped motorcycle was rear-ended and pushed into a pick-up truck causing the rider to sustain minor injuries. The crash occurred during daylight in September 2011 at 1829 hours in Southern California. The weather was cloudy and the approximate temperature was 59.9 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was found to be dry, well-worn and polished, but in good condition. There was a slight breeze at approximately 6.9 mph from NW.

The crash occurred on a multiple lane roadway (four lanes in each direction) mid-block between signal controlled intersections. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of commercial/retail establishments. There is small greenery on either side of the road which is bordered by concrete curbs and an 8? sidewalk. There is a raised, curb height center divider that is made of concrete and filled with stamped concrete. The roadway is configured in a north/south direction and is a non-freeway major arterial. There are overhead street lights on both sides of the road. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

Case Vehicle was a 1992 Honda Goldwing touring motorcycle that was being operated by a 56 year old Caucasian male. The rider was wearing SNELL85/DOT approved open face motorcycle helmet with no face shield and a leather jacket/boots at the time of the collision.

All vehicles in this crash were driving in the same direction and lane. The MC rider of Case Vehicle was travelling northbound on the outside #1 lane and had just come to a stop for other traffic that was attempting to make a right turn into a commercial driveway. It was then that he was rear-ended by Other Vehicle #1 and pushed forward into Other Vehicle #2. The motorcycle yawed to the right after making contact with Vehicle #2, pinching the riders? right knee between the M/C and Vehicle #2. The M/C then fell on its left side, with the riders left leg trapped between it and the ground. Other Vehicle #2 was also stopped for the other traffic ahead of it. The M/C sustained minor damage to the front fender and rear luggage bags. There was pre-existing damage to the right side mirror, not related to this crash.
RiderInj: The 56 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions and contusions to his legs, left foot toes, and left arm. He was treated at the scene, and then taken to a hospital where he was treated and released. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: Neither OV driver sustained any injuries and showed no apparent signs of impairment.
Human:
The unlicensed 25 year old female Hispanic driver of the other vehicle had been preoccupied with her children in the back seat of her, and did
not realize that traffic in front of her had stopped. She applied her brakes in an attempt to stop, however, still crashed into Vehicle #1. This driver refused to be interviewed.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor front and rear damage, along with both sides. The windshield was broken also. The front tire was noted to be bald with no tread showing. The rear tire was legally bald with only 2/32? of tread. The tires however, had no contributing effect on the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a vehicle vs. motorcycle rear-end collision resulting in moderate injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a two-vehicle rear-end crash that occurred in Southern California in October 2011 during daylight at 1355 hours. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was 86 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt which was found to be dry, well-worn and polished, with some surface cracking present, but in good condition. There was a light wind coming from the riders? left.

The crash occurred on a multiple lane roadway (two lanes in each direction) that runs in an east/west orientation. The intersection where the crash occurred has no signal controls. There are dedicated left turn lanes in both directions. Alongside the roadway to the riders? right side is a raised divider separating this road from a residential frontage road. The surrounding area is comprised of single-family residences. There is small greenery on the right (north) side of the road in the 8? wide divider. The left side of the roadway has a sidewalk and a sound wall. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

Case Vehicle was a 1976 Honda CB 550 cruising type motorcycle that had been modified to look like a sport/racing style bike. The motorcycle was being operated by a 31 yr. old male Asian rider. The rider was wearing an open face, no shield, full coverage, FMVSS 218 approved motorcycle helmet with non- prescription sunglasses at the time of the collision. No other riding gear was being worn.

The vehicles involved were driving in the same direction in the same lane. The MC rider of Case Vehicle was travelling westbound on the outside #1 lane at a constant speed. The OV was behind him and gaining on him. The M/C then began slowing to make a right turn to go home. The OV had rapidly accelerated and did not notice that the M/C was slowing for a turn. OV driver slammed on his brakes, leaving approximately 166? of locked rear wheel skid before going over a curb and then knocking down a concrete light pole. OV impacted the motorcycle approximately 83? into his skid. There were no evasive maneuvers by the rider. The motorcycle was struck from the rear by the OV?s right front. The rider rode the car a short distance before falling onto the roadway to his FRP. The motorcycle was engaged with the OV, being pushed to its? FRP. The motorcycle left scrape marks on the road and curb. The motorcycle was sliding on its? left side, low side first. The motorcycle sustained major damage on all sides. The gas tank, side covers, seat, and fenders were all separated from the bike. The
 
headlight was destroyed and not located. There was no reduction in wheelbase on the motorcycle.
RiderInj: Rider Injuries and/or Impairment: The 31 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained moderate injuries consisting of several fractures to his left arm/hand. He was treated at the scene, and then taken to a hospital where he was treated and released.
ODriverInj: OV driver sustained no injuries and showed no apparent signs of impairment.
Human: The 21 year old male Hispanic driver of the OV was driving in an unsafe manner at a high rate of speed for the location.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major damage to all sides. Major components were broken off. The pre-crash condition of the M/C appeared to be good with the exception of a little rust on the chain. We were not able to examine the OV.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle vs. other vehicle (OV1) (2004 Honda Accord) side swipe impact type traffic collision, with a secondary side swipe impact of other vehicle (OV2) (Unknown year/make/model red semi-tractor/trailer) event that caused the motorcycle to impact the ground minor to moderate left and right side damage with injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
MV1: 2009 Harley Davidson XR 1200 motorcycle 1202cc (orange in color).
Crash:
This is a motorcycle vs. vehicle vs. vehicle involving several side swipe impacts with a subsequent lay down event. The rider sustained serious injuries and
the crash occurred in October 2011 at 1630 hours in Southern California. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was 89.1 degrees F. There was little to no measurable wind direction at the time of the collision and, the skies were clear.

The roadway was constructed of a concrete material that was found to be dry, well-worn and polished, but in good condition. The roadway in question is a multiple (8) lane freeway east/west corridor. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of commercial/residential districts. The area is also surrounded by sparse vegetation such as trees and secondary growth. There is a slight left curvature in the roadway with an approximate radius of 1,251 feet.

The crash events occurred in the number 3 and number 2 lanes of the westbound travel lanes. There are no traffic control devices regulating traffic other than a designated ?High Occupancy? section of two lanes on the left side of the westbound corridor. There are five designated westbound lanes with an average lane width of approximately (12) feet in width bordered on the right by a (10) foot wide safety lane adjacent to the shoulder. The area of the crash scene is approximately 1200 feet east of the next available off ramp allowing access to local surface streets.

The posted speed limit of both east and westbound traffic is 65 mph. The diagram provided for this case does not show the eastbound lanes of traffic. The presence of this section of the freeway did not contribute to the cause or outcome of the crash investigated.


The case vehicle was a 2009 Harley Davidson motorcycle that was being operated by a 44 year old Asian female. The rider was wearing a DOT approved motorcycle helmet and, protective upper body armored clothing at the time of the collision. She was not, however, wearing any protective lower body
 
clothing (light material business slacks) or gloves.

The MC rider of the case vehicle was travelling westbound in the number 3 lane of the freeway at a speed of approximately 65 mph. The other vehicle (OV1) was described as a blue Honda Accord and was travelling in the same direction in the number 4 westbound lane at an increased speed of about 75 mph approaching the motorcycle rider from behind and to her left side. The second other vehicle (OV2) was also travelling in the same direction in the westbound number 2 lane at a speed of about 65 mph and was either adjacent to or slightly in front of and to the right of the motorcycle rider. The second other vehicle (OV2) was described by witnesses at the scene as a red semi-tractor trailer commercial vehicle. There was no further information available on this vehicle.

As the motorcycle continued westbound, the rider suddenly observed the presence of OV1 making a sudden lane change into her lane and impacting the left side of herself and the motorcycle. The resulting impact caused the right side view mirror of OV1 to become displaced and minor damage occurred to the right front and rear doors. The OV1 continued westbound in the number 3 lane and fled the scene, failing to stop and identify or render aid to the motorcyclist.

The motorcycle rider was caught completely unaware even stating she never saw it coming. She initiated braking and swerved to the right in an attempt to avoid any further contact with the other vehicle (OV1). However, after the first other vehicle impacted with the motorcyclist, the riders ?collision avoidance?, action placed in the westbound number 2 lane at a position adjacent to the second other vehicle (OV2). During my interview with the motorcycle rider, she thought to the best of her knowledge that there was little to no contact with the second other vehicle (OV2) and, an inspection of the right side of her motorcycle revealed no visible contact damage. She did however say that her body may have contacted the truck and, at this point, she went down losing control of the bike and tumbled down the roadway surface for a distance of about 40 feet. Witnesses at the scene verified to law enforcement that there was some type of contact between the motorcyclist and the second other vehicle (OV2) and that the vehicle continued westbound failing to stop and render aid. The motorcycle rider was aided at the scene and escorted to the side of the roadway prior to the arrival of emergency service personnel. The motorcycle which had slid left side down, came to rest in the westbound number 2 lane, facing west about 40 feet ahead of the riders point of rest (POR). Those that stopped to render aid had also moved the motorcycle to the side of the roadway.
RiderInj: The 44 year old female operator of the motorcycle sustained minor/moderate injuries consisting of abrasions to both unprotected hands and wrists. There were abrasions to the outer portion of the upper and lower left thigh and leg, as well as the region of the left buttocks. She also sustained bruising to the left side of the rib cage. The rider was treated at the scene by emergency service personnel and was subsequently transported to a local hospital for treatment. She was admitted to the hospital for about three days for treatment of her injuries.
ODriverInj: The 29 year male Caucasian driver of the first other vehicle (OV1) was later identified during a law enforcement follow-up investigation. He apparently had sustained no injuries as a result of the crash and, denied any involvement. However, the damage to his vehicle was consistent with the crash scenario and statements made to law enforcement regarding the dynamics of the impact between the motorcycle and the first other vehicle (OV1). There was no information available on the identity of the driver of the second other vehicle (OV2). It is likely that based on the size of the second other vehicle and the minimal contact with the motorcyclist that he or she might not have even realized there was contact between the two-vehicles.
Human:
The 29 year old male Caucasian driver of the first other vehicle (OV1) had been driving at a speed inconsistent and greater than the regular flow of traffic. He also failed to see the motorcyclist ahead and to the right of him during the negotiation of his lane change from the number 4 lane into the number 2 westbound lanes of traffic.

The 44 year old Asian female motorcycle rider was travelling a known route from her place of employment. She was driving at a speed consistent with the regular flow of traffic at the time of the collision. Although her initial ?collision avoidance? maneuver was consistent with attempting to escape from the first other vehicle (OV1), she failed to perceive and properly react to the presence of the second other vehicle (OV2).

The driver of the second other vehicle (OV2) had been travelling at a speed consistent with the regular flow of traffic, staying within the number 2 lane and, made no apparent contribution to the cause of the crash.
Vehicle: The 2009 Harley Davidson motorcycle sustained minor left side damage however, appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle vs. other vehicle (heavy construction truck) rear end impact type traffic collision, with a secondary lay down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the ground causing minor right side damage and injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
MV1: 2006 Honda Shadow VT 600 motorcycle 583cc (red in color)
Crash:
This is a motorcycle vs. vehicle (heavy construction truck) rear end type traffic collision involving minor injuries to the rider that occurred during daylight in
October 2011 at 0827 hours in Southern California. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was 66.0 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in good condition. There was little to no measurable wind direction at the time of the collision and, the skies were clear.

The crash occurred on a single lane freeway off ramp of a major north/south freeway corridor. The off-ramp and surrounding area is currently under construction to widen the existing off-ramp from the freeway up to adjoining surface streets. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of state owned land and commercial/residential districts. The area is also surrounded by sparse vegetation such as surrounding trees and secondary growth.

The roadway in question at the crash scene is a single northbound exit ramp accessing a major multi-phased signal controlled east west boulevard that services the area. The off ramp lane is approximately 12 feet wide bordered on both sides by concrete K-rails (Jersey Rails) and a temporary construction site for trucks and equipment. The K-Rails have also been fitted with 24 inch tall plywood panels. There is an access lane of approximately 12 feet in width
allowing construction vehicles access to the off ramp as well.

Due to the presence of on-going roadway construction, there has been a temporary posted speed limit for off ramp traffic set at 25 mph. There is also a posted traffic advisory warning motorists using this off ramp of the presence of exiting construction vehicles.

The case vehicle was a 2006 Honda Shadow VT600 motorcycle that was being operated by a 39 year-old Caucasian male. The rider was wearing a DOT approved motorcycle helmet and protective upper body armored clothing at the time of the collision.
 
The MC rider of the case vehicle was travelling northbound exiting the freeway at approximately 50 mph in proximity of the construction site with the posted 25 mph advisory. The other vehicle (OV) was travelling in the same direction having just exited the adjoin construction site on to the off ramp, accelerating to a speed of approximately 20-30 mph.

As the motorcycle continued northbound the rider suddenly observed the presence of the construction truck ahead of him travelling at a lessor speed than his approach. The motorcycle rider initiated braking and down shifting in an attempt to reduce his speed as he approach the other vehicle. The rider also noticed the presence of loose dirt material in the roadway, however, his application of the rear brake caused the motorcycle to begin a low side rear tire slide out to the right. The motorcycle initiated a counterclockwise yaw and continued approaching the other vehicle as the right side of the motorcycle impacted the rear bumper. The rider estimated that at the point of impact he had reduced his speed to about 25 mph. During the impact the other vehicle continued in a forward motion and the motorcycle fell on to its right side; the rider staying with the bike.

The driver of the other vehicle had felt the impact and noticed the motorcycle and rider on the ground, he stopped his vehicle and assisted the motorcycle rider. The driver of the other vehicle had advised officers at the scene that he had checked the lane prior to pulling out, saw a tractor trailer rig far enough back and thought it safe to enter the off ramp.
RiderInj: The 32 year-old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of a medial malleolus fracture to the right ankle, contusions to the upper and lower right leg and well as the left buttocks. The rider sustained no apparent internal injuries. The rider was treated at the scene by emergency service personnel and subsequently transported to a local hospital for treatment. The motorcycle rider showed no apparent signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 32 year-old Hispanic driver of the other vehicle, who was currently working his assigned duties, sustained no injuries and showed no apparent signs of impairment.
Human:
The 32 year-old male Hispanic driver of the other vehicle had failed to see the approaching motorcyclist while exiting the construction area (precipitating event). When he moved out on to the off ramp although accelerating, he was travelling at a reduced speed and failed to yield to the approaching motorcyclist.

The 39 year-old male Caucasian motorcycle rider was travelling a known route to his place of employment. The roadway construction had been present for some time as was the various posted traffic advisories for said construction. The rider had exited the freeway on to the off ramp at an excessive rate of speed (50 mph) off throttle. When faced with having to commit to a sudden reduction in speed and possible collision avoidance maneuver, slid out on the dirt contaminated roadway (poor surface appraisal).
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor right side damage however, appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing critical injuries.
MV1: 2010 Sanyang Lance (step through style) scooter, 124cc (tan in color).
OV1: 2008 Toyota Scion tC 4 door sedan (dark blue in color)
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury traffic collision. The collision occurred during dusk in October 2011 at 1803 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1816 hours. The weather report for 1753 hours showed clear skies, with SW winds at 5.8 mph and, an ambient temperature of 69.1 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface for the motorcycle (MC1) was an uphill grade of 2.9 degrees. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.

The collision occurred on a (right) curved uphill grade local surface street with an overall travel-way width of 62 feet. The street although curved, runs primarily east to west with two lanes dedicated for eastbound and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic. There is a designated ?left turn? lane to regulate westbound traffic into a multiple family residential apartment complex. The location of the crash scene was at the entrance was at the entrance of this complex and is unregulated by any traffic signs or signals.

The main entrance of this complex allows for ingress and egress of all vehicular traffic and has an overall width of 51 feet. The 20 foot entrance and exit lanes are separated by an 11 foot wide (6?) raised concrete median. The speed limit in this area is 30 mph. The eastbound uphill grade is 2.9 degrees which drops to
2.7 degrees near the crash scene and beyond. The roadway crown was a consistent 0.9 degrees approaching and at the crash scene. There were no super- elevation issues with this roadway.
The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted double yellow line lane markers. West of the crash scene the lanes are separated by the painted median a width of 10 feet. This median coincides with the left turn lane east of the intersection. The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2010 Sanyang Lance (step through style) 124cc scooter being operated by a 53 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was
 
travelling eastbound in the designated #2 eastbound lane of the multi-lane surface street approaching the entrance of the complex.
The other vehicle (OV1), operated by a 21 year old male Hispanic driver was approaching westbound in the left turn lane and initiating a left turn movement into the complex. The other vehicle was on downhill grade (2.7 degrees) with a left curvature roadway surface. The driver kept a constant speed of 20-25 mph while making the left turn movement however, failed to notice the rider and scooter (MC1) approaching in the #2 lane.
The rider and scooter collided with the left front portion of the bumper area of the other vehicle (OV1) causing the scooter to collapse onto the right side. The rider vaulted off the scooter and onto the roadway surface about 32 feet east of the area of impact.
The scooter was captured under the left front portion of the other vehicle (OV1) and pushed a distance of about 45 feet to its final resting place. The driver and, passenger of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained no injuries. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 53 year old male white operator of the scooter (MC1) sustained critical injuries as a result of the collision. He was wearing an open face motorcycle style helmet with a bubble face shield that was ejected off the rider's head during the crash event. The helmet strap was in good condition and may have not been fastened properly or, at all.
Human:
The 53 year old male white operator of the scooter (MC1) failed to comprehend the hazards of approaching vehicles at intersections.
The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) claimed that the sun was in his view creating a visual obstruction and failed to perceive, comprehend or, react to the presence of the approaching scooter while making his left turn movement.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained total front, left and right side damage as a result of impacting with the other vehicle (OV1).
The other vehicle (OV1) sustained moderate left front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: Sunset for the area was 1816 hours for this date and the collision was reported as occurring at 1803 hours. No other environmental factors were present at the time of the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. car, front to side impact configuration resulting in minor injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
OV1: Ford Focus, Silver. No further information.
Crash:
This is a two-vehicle near head-on crash that occurred in Southern California in October 2011 during darkness at 2042 hours. The weather was overcast and the approximate temperature was 64 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of concrete in the intersection where the crash occurred. The roadway leading to the intersection was constructed of an asphalt material. The concrete was in good repair, which was found to be dry, well-worn and polished. There was no wind. It was dark at the time and overhead street lights were on.

The crash occurred on a multiple lane roadway (three lanes in each direction) with dedicated left/U-turn lanes in three directions. In the NB direction, the inside left/U-turn lane was coned off. The intersection is controlled by overhead signals. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of commercial/retail establishments, and an amusement park.
