There is small greenery on either side of the road which is bordered by concrete curbs and 8? sidewalks. The roadway is configured in a north/south direction and is a local road. The posted speed limit is 35 mph.

The case vehicle was a 2006 Yamaha R6S racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 22 year old Caucasian male. The rider was wearing a full face FMVSS 218/SnellM2005 rated motorcycle helmet with a gray face shield at the time of the collision. It is unknown if the face shield was in the up or down position.

The vehicles involved were initially driving in opposite directions. The MC rider of Case Vehicle was travelling southbound on the outside #1 left turn lane and had been stopped for a red light. He then proceeded forward with a green light and was accelerating through his turn when OV ran a red light in the north bound direction #3 (inside) lane. The rider saw the OV coming at him and attempted to swerve to the left, but could not avoid the impact. The front of the OV impacted the front right area of the motorcycle. The motorcycle fell and was pushed a short distance before coming to rest in the #2 (inside) left/U-turn lane. The OV/driver then backed off of the M/C and fled the scene. The intersection has protected left turn lanes with a leading green arrow. There were no skid marks from either vehicle. The M/C came to rest on its? left side close to the point of impact. The M/C sustained minor damage to the front end and both sides.
 
There was no reduction in wheelbase. The bike was still ridable. The M/C had pre-existing damage from other events.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of soft tissue damage, (contusions/swelling) to both lower extremities, groin, and right arm. He sought no medical treatment. The rider was wearing M/C oriented jacket/gloves which likely reduced his injuries. The M/C clothing had some retro-reflective material that should have made him more visible. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: OV driver fled the scene. It is unlikely that the driver sustained any injuries. It is unknown about his/her impairment
Human: The unknown OV driver caused the crash and was either distracted, impaired, or both.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor front end damage, along with both sides. The pre-crash condition of the M/C appeared to be very good mechanically, however, there was a good amount of pre-crash damage that was mostly minor in nature.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This is a single motorcycle lay-down event. There was no passenger.
Crash:
This is a single M/C Lay-Down that occurred in Southern California in October 2011 during daylight at 1005 hours. The weather was clear. The approximate temperature was 59 degrees F with a slight breeze blowing SSW at 4.6 mph. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was found to be dry, well-worn and polished, but in good condition.

The crash occurred on an unmarked residential street in a hilly area. The street is a nearly constant set of switchback S-turns. The surrounding area is comprised of single-family residences. There is greenery on either side of the road which is bordered by concrete curbs and a 5? sidewalk. The roadway is configured in a northeasterly/southwesterly direction at the crash site. The posted speed limit is 25 mph.

Case Vehicle was a 2006 Kawasaki Ninja 500r racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 39 year old Caucasian male, (6?01?, 185). The rider was wearing full-faced helmet with integral chin bar and a clear face shield. The helmet met Snell M2000 qualifications.

The MC rider of Case Vehicle was travelling up-hill in a northeasterly direction on the right half of the roadway, at a constant speed. The rider stated that he was following a pick-up truck that had moved to the left side of the road. The rider said that he went to pass the truck on the right, when the truck made a right turn into a driveway in front of him. The rider said that he braked, swerved to the right, and then laid the M/C down on its right side. There was no evidence of
the other vehicle, only the riders? statements. The Case Vehicle left approximately 19? of front tire skip scuff, along with some small gouges. The rider rode the M/C to its? FRP. The M/C sustained minor damage to the right side. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 39 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of a sprain to his left shoulder and right knee, as well as a minor abrasion/contusion to his right knee. He refused treatment at the scene. He later went to a walk in clinic where he was treated and released. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: There is no evidence of an OV involvement.
Human: The 39 year old male Caucasian rider of Case Vehicle did not appear to be distracted by any obvious sources. He appeared to be in a hurry and tried to unsafely pass on the right.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor right side damage. There was pre-existing damage from a previous owner. The pre-crash condition of the M/C showed that there was other damage not related to this crash, but the overall condition appeared to be good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle, front to side impact configuration with a secondary law-down event. The rider sustained major injuries.
Crash:
This is a two-vehicle front to side crash that occurred in Southern California in October 2011 during darkness at 0602 hours. The weather was clear and the approximate temperature was 62.1 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, with some patches of bitumen repair, but in otherwise good condition. There was no wind. The roadway was illuminated with overhead street lights that were on.

The crash occurred on a multiple lane roadway (two lanes in each direction with a continuous two-way left turn center lane) mid-block between signal controlled intersections. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of commercial/retail establishments. There is small greenery on either side of the road which is bordered by concrete curbs and a 5? sidewalk. The roadway is configured in a north/south direction and is a local road. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

The case vehicle was a 2007 Yamaha Road Star cruising motorcycle that was being operated by a 56 year old Caucasian male. The rider was wearing a half shell partial coverage helmet with unknown safety ratings at the time of the collision. The helmet was retained on the riders? head to the completion of the crash events.

The involved vehicles were driving in opposite directions. The rider of M/C-1 was travelling southbound on the outside #1 lane at a constant speed. There was another vehicle (non-contacted) to his left in the inside #2 lane. OV-1 was northbound and preparing to make a left turn into a mall driveway from the two way left turn lane. OV-1 had just entered this lane and never stopped or slowed. There are no signal controls. OV-1 made his left turn in front of on-coming traffic, causing the vehicle that was next to M/C-1 to swerve left around OV-1. M/C-1 braked, leaving approximately 46? of rear tire locked skid prior to impacting the
right rear door of OV-1 (first harmful event). OV-1 was spun in a clockwise direction and came to rest in the driveway area. M/C-1 came to rest on its? right side at the point of impact, (second harmful event). The rider was fully ejected from the M/C and flew over the trunk of OV-1, landing approximately 12? 6? from the POI. The vehicle that was next to M/C-1 was not involved in the crash and determined not to be a causal factor. The M/C sustained major damage to the front end and both sides. The reduction in wheelbase was at a minimum, 18?. The forks were completely destroyed and there was no way to accurately measure
 
the reduction. Cooling fins on the engine were broken off, as well as both footboards. The left side down tube of the frame was deformed and bent. The crash was captured on security video from a liquor store on the east side of the street. The time stamp on the video shows OV-1 entering the frame from the left at 06:01:56.
RiderInj: The 56 year old male operator (6? 00?, 180 lbs.) of the motorcycle sustained major injuries consisting of a compound fracture to his right leg, a fracture to his left shoulder (NFS), an avulsion to his right ankle and foot. He was treated at the scene, and then taken to a hospital where he was admitted. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 74 year old male Caucasian OV driver (5? 11?, 195 lbs.) sustained no injuries and showed no apparent signs of impairment.
Human: The driver of the other vehicle did not appear to be distracted by any obvious sources. He appeared to be in a hurry and tried to beat on- coming traffic. This is based on watching the video of the crash. The other vehicle driver was cooperative at first, but then refused to continue.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major front end damage, along with both sides. The front rim had pieces broken and the tire was flat as a result of the crash. The M/C sustained a maximum reduction in wheel base which was not accurately measurable due the post-crash condition. The pre-crash condition of the M/C appeared to be very good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Car / Rear-end Impact with Secondary Lay-Down Event
MV1: 2010 Honda Elite150, 108cc Step Through Motor Scooter
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in October 2010 at 1220 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the temperature was 71 F. The weather was clear with no precipitation.

The crash occurred on a ten (10) lane divided Interstate Highway that consists of five (5) southbound travel lanes and five (5) northbound travel lanes and a concrete jersey barrier is present that separates the roadways. The posted speed limit for this roadway is 65 mph and there are no traffic controls present and the asphalt roadway surface was dry at the time.
Vehicle 1 was a 2010 Honda Elite 150, 108cc Step Through Motor Scooter. That was being operated by a 57 year old Caucasian male, who was wearing a full face helmet, with a clear face shield, at the time of the crash. The operator of Vehicle 1 was proceeding in a northerly direction in the right hand lane No. 1 at an estimated speed of approximately 20 mph. Traffic was heavy at the time of the crash. Vehicle 2 was a 1997 Honda Civic Four-Door Sedan that was being operated by a 35 year old Caucasian male (75 in. / 285 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder
restraint. The driver of Vehicle 2 was proceeding in a northerly direction in the right hand lane No. 1 at an estimated speed of approximately 20-25 mph. The driver of Vehicle 2 made a sudden stop due to vehicles in front of him stopping suddenly. The driver of Vehicle 1 did not sufficiently detect the stopped traffic and the front wheel of Vehicle 1 impacted the center rear bumper of Vehicle 2 in a rear-end type impact. The Honda (Vehicle 1) rotated counterclockwise and low-side impacted the asphalt surface with the left side, sliding forward and to the right approximately 17 ft., where it came to rest on the asphalt shoulder
and facing East. Vehicle 2 stayed stopped in lane No. 1. The rider of Vehicle 1 vaulted onto the rear window and trunk of Vehicle 2, then rolled off the trunk, coming to rest at the right rear of Vehicle 2.
RiderInj:
The 57 year old operator of the motor scooter, sustained an open fracture of the left Clavicle (AIS-2) and hematoma's to left
ribs (AIS-1). Based on the medical and police report, the driver of Vehicle 1 was not under the influence of alcohol or drugs at the time. The rider was admitted for surgery and released two (2) days later.
Human: The motorscooter operator was operating the bike in an unsafe manner by following to close to the vehicle in front of him in heavy traffic. Traffic was frequently slowing and stopping and the motorscooter rider did not allow ample space to slow or stop his vehicle.
Vehicle: Neither of the crash involved vehicles were determined to be defective.
Environmental: There were no related environmental conditions that contributed to the crash causation.

CrashType: This single vehicle crash involved a motorcycle that impacted a curb, w-beam guardrail and impacted a secondary curb before laying down onto its right side, off road. The motorcycle rider sustained fatal injuries as a result of this collision. There was a passenger seated to the rear of the rider who sustained minor injuries as a result of this collision.
Crash:
This crash involved a motorcycle that impacted a curb, w-beam guardrail before being redirected back onto the roadway and impacted a secondary curb
before departing the roadway and laying down onto its right side plane. The rider was fatally injured and the passenger sustained minor injuries. The collision occurred during hours of darkness in October 2011 at 0209 hours in Southern California. The weather was clear and the temperature was 44.1 degrees F as of 0154 hours. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was found to be dry, well-worn and polished, but in good condition. The wind
direction and speed were listed as ?calm? at the time of the collision and, the skies were clear.

The crash occurred on a two lane residential street with one (13 foot wide) lane dedicated for northbound traffic as well as a (20 foot wide) southbound lane. The surrounding area on the eastside of this street is occupied by open property and single family residential dwellings. The west side of the street is bordered by state land which drops off significantly towards a major north south freeway corridor. The area is also surrounded by sparse vegetation such as surrounding low lying shrubs.

The roadway speed limit for a residential area in this state is 25 mph. The west side of the street is bordered by a steel guardrail barrier supported by wooden posts. The east side of the roadway has only a six inch high raised concrete curb with an uphill slope of residential property. As for the northbound direction of the case motorcycle, there is a significant 8.5 degree uphill grade that gradually drops off to a 2.1 degree uphill grade as the street angles to the right to an east/west configuration near the crash scene.
Beyond the crash scene at the east/west juncture of the roadway is a residential cul de sac style cross street of approximately 36 feet in width. 
The Case Vehicle was being operated by a 23 year old male. The rider was not wearing any type of helmet or protective head gear.
 
The MC rider of the Case Vehicle was travelling northbound on the residential street at a high rate of speed. The MC Rider for crossed from the northbound lane into the southbound lane, failing to negotiate the right curve (R-211 feet) of the roadway and collided with the curb and adjacent w-beam guardrail located on the west roadside.

As the motorcycle impacted the w-beam guardrail the MC Rider and passenger were ejected off the motorcycle and on to the roadway. The motorcycle continued in a northeast direction riding the guardrail until it was redirected back into the roadway impacting the east curb and riding into an uphill embankment where it collapsed onto the right side.

At the time and within proximity of the crash scene, there were no other vehicles, pedestrians or, animals that may have caused or contributed anything to this event.
RiderInj: The 23 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained fatal injuries the most serious of which was a lacerated renal artery and detached right kidney. The rider also sustained numerous abrasions and contusions however, no apparent head injuries. The rider was treated at the scene by emergency service personnel and subsequently transported to a local hospital where he succumbed to his injuries. Subsequent autopsy results showed a blood alcohol level at .14 BAC.
Human: The 23 year old male operator of the motorcycle was driving while significantly impaired and at a high rate of speed unsafe for the roadway. Although the passenger appeared to be a local resident of the area, the male operator may have also been unfamiliar with the roadway configuration and environment.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor left side damage however, appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle lay-down event with a secondary OV contact event. There was no passenger.
MV1: 2000 Harley Davidson Soft tail Fat Boy (1449cc)
Crash:
This is a NC, M/C lay-down event, and the motorcycle initiated a low-side slide impacting OV-2 with its? tires on the right side plane of OV-2 that occurred in Southern California on November 2011 during hours of darkness at 1757 hrs. The weather was clear and the wind was calm. The approximate temperature was 62.1 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The area was illuminated by overhead street lights and they were on at the time.

The crash occurred at a T-type intersection on a multi-lane road, (two lanes each direction) that had dedicated left turn lanes in both directions and a raised center median. The roadway is an East/West configuration. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The cross street is a two lane roadway, (one in each direction) that is controlled by a stop sign and has no lane markings. This roadway is located on the south side of the intersection. There are no signal controls. The surrounding area is comprised of multi-story apartment buildings on all sides. On-street parking is allowed. There is greenery on either side of the road which is bordered by concrete curbs and a 12? sidewalk. The posted speed limit is 25 mph.

Case Vehicle was a 2000 Harley Davidson Soft-tail Fat Boy cruising type motorcycle that was being operated by a 23 year old Caucasian male, (6?02?, 330). The rider was wearing full-faced helmet with integral chin bar and a clear face shield. The helmet met FMVSS-218 qualifications.

The MC rider of Case Vehicle was travelling westbound in the #1 (outside) curb lane at approximately 40 mph. He said he was to the left side of the lane because there had been some parked cars a short distance back. The rider said that he saw the OV2 in the opposing left turn lane and that it was stopped. The rider said that another vehicle, OV1, came out from the side street on the left and made a left turn in front of OV2. The rider said that OV2 then started to make its? left U- turn behind OV1 and almost rear-ended OV1 and came to a stop. OV1 completed its? left turn and continued westbound. The rider said that the OV1 stopped partially blocking both westbound lanes. The rider said that he braked while trying to swerve left when the front tire locked up and he went down on the left side, low side first. The rider said he was fully ejected from the M/C somewhere in the middle of the intersection and that his bike continued
 
sliding and hit OV2 in the right side front area. OV2 driver said that she was attempting to make a U-turn to go home when another vehicle came from her right and made a left turn in front of her. She said she stopped to avoid OV1 and then saw the motorcycle. OV2 driver said that she remained stopped because the M/C was already on the ground. Case vehicle left approximately 41? of rear tire mark and 3? of front tire mark and 51? of scrapes prior to the AOI with OV2. The M/C sustained damage mostly to the left side. The right mirror was damaged, possibly when it made contact with OV2. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 23 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained moderate injuries consisting of a fractured right wrist, bilateral knee abrasions, and a left elbow abrasion. He was treated at the scene, and then taken to a hospital where he was treated and released. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: Neither OV driver was injured. There was no sign of impairment for OV2. It is unknown about OV1.
Human: The 23 year old male Caucasian rider of Case Vehicle did not appear to be distracted by any obvious sources. He was an inexperienced M/C rider who was taught by his father how to ride. Both OV drivers appeared to be in a hurry and pre-occupied.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor left side damage. The pre-crash condition of the M/C showed that there was no other damage not related to this crash, but the overall condition appeared to be fair.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This is a frontal (MC) to side (OV) impact event with secondary lay down event. There was no passenger.
Crash:
This is a frontal to left side impact with a secondary lay down that occurred in Southern California in November 2011 at 1910 hrs. The weather was clear and the wind was calm. The approximate temperature was 59.8 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was found to be dry, worn and polished, but otherwise in good condition. The area was illuminated by overhead street lights that were on.

The crash occurred at a four leg type intersection on a multi-lane road, (three lanes each direction) that had dedicated left turn lanes in both directions and a painted center median. The roadway is an east/west configuration. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The cross street is a two lane roadway, (one in each direction) that is controlled by a stop sign and has lane markings. On the south side of the intersection, there is significant uphill grade for OV1. The north side is an entrance to a mobile home park. There are no lane markings, but there is a raised planter box/divider. There is a stop sign for exiting traffic. There are no signal controls. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial/retail west of the intersection and residential east of it. There is no on-street parking. There are some trees on either side of the road which is bordered by concrete curbs and a 9? sidewalk on the riders? side of the road. At the time we were on-scene, there was construction taking place which included lane closures and electronic reader board signs. The P.A.R. indicates that there was no construction on- going at the time of the crash. The police were asked if any of these items were in the roadway at the time of the crash and the officer that took the report replied, ?No. It was off the road.? During the OV driver interview, the driver said that there were construction materials in the roadway at the time of the crash. The construction material may have been in the area near the roadside, but not actually in the road. It would appear that the OV driver was mistaken.

Case Vehicle was a 2006 Motofino NST step-through scooter type motorcycle that was being operated by a 20 year old Caucasian male, (6?00?, 195 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown type helmet.

The rider of Case Vehicle was travelling eastbound in the #3 (inside) lane at approximately 40-45 mph. The rider told the police he had no memory of the accident. The rider refused to participate with the study. The driver of OV-1 was westbound and making a left turn from a stop sign. He stated that he saw no vehicles coming when he made his turn. The rider was fully ejected from the M/C and vaulted into the left side of OV-1 causing major injuries. The front end of
 
the M/C collapsed and had maximum reduction in wheelbase as a result of impacting OV-1. The M/C landed on its? left side plane. Its FRP is within six feet of the AOI. OV-1 stopped a short distance after impact in the middle of the intersection. Neither vehicle involved left any tire marks. The M/C sustained major damage to the front end.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained major injuries consisting of multiple fractures to his face; a broken left hand and right wrist; a pelvic fracture; lacerated spleen, and a concussion. He was treated at the scene, and then taken to a hospital where he was admitted. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The OV driver was not injured and showed no signs of impairment.
Human: The 30 year old male Asian driver (5?07?, 145 lbs.) of OV-1 failed to see the M/C approaching the intersection. The rider of the M/C had no motorcycle endorsement for his license. Based on that and his age, the rider probably had limited riding experience.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major front end damage with a maximum reduction in wheelbase that included penetration to the floorboard area. The pre-crash condition of the M/C showed that there was no other damage not related to this crash, but the overall condition appeared to be fair. OV-1 sustained minor damage; however, due to the location of the damage, it was not drivable.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. vehicle head-on crash resulting in major injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a two-vehicle head-on crash that occurred in Southern California in November 2011 during darkness at 0015 hours. The weather was cloudy with impending rain and the approximate temperature was 51 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was found to be dry, worn and polished, with some surface cracking present, but in good condition. There was a light wind coming from the riders? left. The roadway was illuminated with overhead street lights that were on.

The crash occurred on a multiple lane roadway (three lanes in each direction with a raised center median that was landscaped with grass, trees, and bushes) just south of the T type signal controlled intersection. The surrounding area is comprised of single family residences, a high school, and a commercial/retail center. There is small greenery on either side of the road which is bordered by concrete curbs and sidewalks. The roadway is configured in a north-east/south- west direction south of the intersection and in a north/south direction north of the intersection and is a minor arterial road. The roadway has a 665? left curve for the riders? direction of travel. The posted speed limit is 50 mph.

Case Vehicle was a 1999 Ducati racing type motorcycle that was newly purchased by the 23 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a SNELL M2010/FVMSS approved motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield at the time of the collision.

The vehicles involved were driving in opposite directions in the same lane. The MC rider of Case Vehicle was travelling northbound on the inside #3 lane on the wrong side of the road at a constant speed. The OV was southbound in the same lane. The M/C was navigating the left curve in the road for his direction of travel. The OV was following the right curve. The actual speed of either vehicle is unknown. A witness stated that he was behind OV-1 and he estimated their speed at between 35-40 mph. There was no evidence of any evasive maneuvers by the rider. There were no evasive actions by the driver of the OV prior to impact. After impact she braked and swerved. The rider rode directly into the left front of the OV. The OV driver braked hard but left no skids due to ABS. The rider rode the car a short distance before falling onto the roadway and his FRP. The motorcycle was engaged with the OV causing a great deal of penetration before dislodging and landing in the landscaped center median. The motorcycle left some scrapes marks on the curb. There were some gouges in the dirt, but
 
they were washed away in the heavy rain that arrived a short time after the accident. The motorcycle was sliding on its? left side, high side first. It came to rest in that position facing northwesterly after hitting a tree. The motorcycle sustained major damage to the front end and left side. The fairing, gas tank, side covers, seat, and rear fender were all separated from the bike. The headlights were destroyed and not located. There was a maximum reduction in wheelbase on the motorcycle.
RiderInj: The 33 year old male (5? 08?, 175 lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained major injuries consisting of unspecified head trauma, unspecified internal injuries, and a traumatic amputation of an unknown foot. He was treated at the scene, and then taken to a hospital where he was admitted. The motorcycle rider had a BAC of .13 % according to the police report.
ODriverInj: The 34 year old Asian female (5? 05?, 121 lbs.) OV driver sustained no injuries and showed no apparent signs of impairment.
Human: The 33 year old male driver of the motorcycle had a suspended license and was heavily intoxicated and riding on the wrong side of the road.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major front end damage, along with both sides and major components that were broken off. The front rim had pieces broken and the tire was flat as a result of the crash. There was maximum wheelbase reduction. The pre-crash condition of the M/C appeared to be very good.
Environmental: The roadway has a blind horizontal curve that could be a contributing factor to the crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Van / Front to Side Impact with Secondary Lay-Down Event.
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in November 2011 at 1714 hours in Southern California. It was dark and the weather was clear, the temperature was 69 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and was noted to be travel worn, but in good repair.

The crash occurred on a busy North/South principal road that consists of four lanes in each direction with dedicated northbound left turn lanes. The roadway is located in a business district, bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The roadway is level at the crash location and the posted speed limit is 40 mph.
Vehicle 1 (MC-1), is a 2004 Yamaha V-Star 1100 (1063cc) cruiser style motorcycle, operated by a 51 year old Caucasian male (70 in., 190 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing a helmet, but type is unknown. The rider of MC-1 was proceeding southbound between lanes # 2 & 3 at an estimated speed of approximately 35 mph.

Vehicle 2 (OV-1), is a 2002 Chevrolet 1500 panel van, operated by a 47 year-old Hispanic male (65 in., 160 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraint. The driver of OV-1 was northbound in the left turn lane stopped at the limit line. The left turn arrow turned green and he started his left turn and suddenly saw vehicle 1 southbound in front of him and he didn?t have time to brake.

The front of OV-1 (Chevrolet Van) impacts the left front side of MC-1 (Yamaha V-Star) at an acute impact angle. OV-1?s front bumper pushed MC-1 onto its right side and rode up onto the left side of MC-1 and its rider. The motorcycle rider?s right leg was pinned between the motorcycle and the ground, and his left leg was severed below the knee by OV-1.
RiderInj: The 51 year old male rider of MC-1 sustained the following injuries: Left leg amputation below the knee, distal fracture of the left femur, collapsed left lung and puncture wounds to the left side of his hip and torso. The rider was negative for alcohol and drugs. The driver of OV-1 was uninjured in the crash.
Human: The 51 year old male rider of MC-1 failed to yield the right of way to the operator of OV-1. The operator of OV-1 was traveling at a prudent speed and there were no human factors attributable to him with regards to the crash causal factors.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were free of defects and determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. vehicle side-swipe Hit & Run type crash resulting in minor injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a two-vehicle sideswipe Hit & Run crash with injuries that occurred in Southern California in December 2011 at 1930 hours. The weather was clear with no wind. The approximate temperature was 57 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in good condition. The roadway was illuminated with overhead street lights that were on.

The crash occurred on a multiple lane roadway (two lanes in each direction with a continuous two-way left turn lane) just north of a T type intersection. There are no signal controls for this intersection, only a stop sign that regulates WB traffic from the side street. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial/retail businesses on the right side of the road and a multi-story office building on the left. There are tall trees on the left side of the roadway. The roadway is bordered by concrete curbs and sidewalks. The roadway is configured in a north/south direction and is a minor arterial road. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

Case Vehicle was a 2009 Yamaha R6 sport/racing type motorcycle that was purchased by the 21 year old male Hispanic rider. The rider was wearing an unknown model full face helmet with unknown safety ratings at the time of the crash. Other than a helmet, the rider was wearing no M/C protective apparel.

The vehicles involved were driving in the same direction in adjacent lanes at about the same speed. There was a municipal bus at a bus stop in the #1 (curb lane) that OV-1 was also in. The Other Vehicle (OV-1) made a lane change to the left into the motorcycle, causing him to go down on his left side. The OV-1 then fled the scene without stopping. The M/C left approximately 8? of locked front wheel tire marks before the bike went down. The M/C left scrape marks after the AOI to its? FRP. There was no evidence of any evasive maneuvers by the rider other than braking. The M/C impacted the OV-1 in the left rear area. The motorcycle was sliding on its? left side, high side first. The motorcycle sustained minor damage to the right front of the fairing and the left side. There was no reduction in wheelbase on the motorcycle.
RiderInj: The 21 year old Hispanic male (6? 04?, 180lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of an unknown type fracture to his left wrist, abrasions to his right leg, and a sprain to his left wrist and ankle. He was treated at a hospital and released.
ODriverInj: It is unknown whether the OV-1 driver sustained any injuries, but it is unlikely. OV-1 driver fled the scene with OV-1.
Human: The unknown driver of the OV-1 made an unsafe driving act that caused the crash. The 21 year old male Hispanic rider of the motorcycle had little if any time to react to the OV-1.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor damage to the fairing and left side. There was minor pre-existing damage to the lower right side and exhaust pipe of the M/C. The pre-crash condition of the M/C appeared to be very good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle (pick-up truck), side to right front impact collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface and a raised concrete curb line. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained fatal injuries as a result of multiple impacts with the roadway surface, sidewalk, utility pole and tree. There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the collision.
MV1: 2009 Yamaha YZF R6 (Sport type) motorcycle, 599cc (orange in color).
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle (OV1) left side to right front impact type traffic collision resulting in fatal injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight in December 2011 at 1353 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, no wind, and an ambient temperature of 65.8 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.

The collision occurred on a straight multiple lane surface street with an overall travel-way width of 92 feet. This is a major north/south arterial surface street with three lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and three lanes for southbound traffic. In the area of the collision scene there are designated left turn lanes for both north and southbound traffic to access the commercial businesses on both sides of the street. Both the east and west sides of the street are occupied by commercial retail businesses and restaurants. South of the crash site, on the west side of the street, is a tract of residential single family homes bordered by a six foot high cinder block wall.

At the location of the crash site there were no traffic control devices to regulate the flow of traffic in the area. Both north and southbound lanes of traffic have posted speed limit signs regulating the speed of traffic to 40 mph. The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by a raised concrete and brick median approximately 8 inches in height and 4 foot wide. The street is also bordered on both sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks approximately 8 foot in width. The nearest major intersection is approximately 626 feet north of the crash site and is regulated by multi-phased traffic
signals. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.

There are driveways on both the east and west side of the street that allow ingress and egress of traffic to the businesses located on private property. The driveway on the east side is designed for north and southbound traffic with a raised divider separating the two lanes. Each of these lanes measure 24 feet in width and the surface area is of an asphalt composition. There is a posted ?STOP? sign regulating the northbound traffic out of this commercial site.
 
The driveway on the west side also allows ingress and egress of traffic into the commercial site however, is only a single lane of 39 feet in width.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2009 Yamaha YZF-R6 (Sport Bike style) motorcycle being operated by a 25 year old male Hispanic rider. The rider was wearing a full face (FMVSS 218 US DOT approved) motorcycle helmet, manufactured by HJC, Model Paradox CS-R1.
The rider was travelling southbound in the #3 lane of the multi-lane surface street approaching the intersection of the north and south entrances of the commercial businesses at a high rate of speed. As the rider continued southbound he moved from the #3 lane to the #2 lane due to a mid-sized SUV type vehicle stopped in the southbound #3 lane ahead of him. This vehicle had stopped due to the fact that the westbound other vehicle (OV1) had partially blocked the #3 southbound lane as it was traversing the lanes.

The other vehicle (OV1) was a 1982 Chevrolet Silverado C10  ton standard bed pick-up truck being operated by a 20 year old male Hispanic driver. There was a cruiser style motorcycle secured and being transported in the bed of the truck at the time of the collision.
The driver of (OV1) had exited the commercial complex along the east side of the multi-lane surface street in a northbound direction.
The driver (OV1) had successfully traversed the northbound lanes of traffic and moved into the center median area of the intersection. The driver noticed a vehicle in the southbound in the left turn lane and made eye contact with the driver as he passed in front of the vehicle. The driver (OV1) was moving forward at a reduced speed (about 5 mph) at this time and took one more look northbound, to check for any approaching traffic. Once he thought it was clear to continue forward (westbound) he accelerated his vehicle and began traversing the southbound lanes of the multi-lane surface street blocking the path of a midsized SUV in the southbound #3 lane.

As the other vehicle (OV1) moved forward the driver heard what he thought was either a motorcycle exhaust or skidding and suddenly saw the rider of a motorcycle (MC1) ?flying? in front of the hood of his truck. The driver continued across the intersection, entered the commercial complex on the west side of the roadway and parked his truck. The other driver saw the motorcyclist lying in the roadway and the motorcycle (MC1) further down the street, south of the crash scene.

Based on the damage sustained it appeared as though the motorcycle (MC1) had struck the right front portion of the front bumper of the other vehicle (OV1) passing along the front of the truck (right to left) ejecting the rider, falling right side down and continued sliding south along the west curb line for a distance of approximately 408 feet.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 25 year old male Hispanic operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained fatal injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were predominately in the area of the head and torso with multiple internal injuries. On the attached ?Injury Form? there were 30 entries recorded identifying injuries sustained by the rider. Of those recorded on the AIS 2005 Severity column, two were listed as category 6 and, six were listed as category 5 traumatic injuries. The Coroner?s report also indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
ODriverInj: The 20 year old male driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. There were no apparent objective symptoms of alcohol intoxication however, he did admit to having taken his prescription dose of Prozac.
Human: The 25 year old male operator of the motorcycle (MC1) was driving at a high rate of speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway. The 20 year old male driver of the other vehicle (OV1) failed to yield to approaching traffic while exiting a private driveway.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor right side damage however, appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition.
The other vehicle (OV1) sustained minimal damage to the right front portion of the front bumper otherwise, was in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle VS. other vehicle, left rear side impact with secondary lay-down event resulting in minor injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This was a two-vehicle sideswipe crash that occurred in Southern California in December 2011 at 1800 hrs. It was dark and the area was lit with overhead luminaries. The weather was cloudy and there the wind was calm. The approximate temperature was 61 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of asphalt which was dry, worn and polished, but in good condition.

The crash occurred mid-block between two four leg intersections on a multiple lane roadway (three lanes in each direction with a raised landscaped center median). The surrounding area is comprised of commercial/retail businesses. There are medium sized trees in the center divider. The roadway is bordered by concrete curbs and sidewalks. The roadway is configured in an east/west direction and is a minor arterial road. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2010 Kawasaki Ninja EX-250R (248 cc?s) sport/racing type motorcycle that was purchased by the 23 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was wearing a Snell M2010 rated motorcycle helmet with a clear colored face shield. The rider was also wearing upper/lower motorcycle apparel.

The vehicles involved were driving in the same direction in adjacent lanes. M/C-1 had split lanes through stopped traffic at the previous intersection. He had split between the #3 (inside) lane and the #2 (middle) lane to get up to the limit line. In doing this, he thought he hit a car mirror on his left side. When the light phased green, the rider said that he ?accelerated rapidly? so the he could pull over to the side of the road or into a parking lot. He started off from the left side of lane #2 and moved over to the right side of the same lane. He then wanted to make a lane change to the right #1 (outside) lane. He used his signal and looked in his mirror, but stated that he didn?t do a ?head check? and did not see OV-1 passing him in the right lane. He then lane changed into OV-1, lost control and crashed, falling down high side first. The MC rider said that he was going about 25 mph. The rider was fully ejected and tumbled/rolled to his FRP.

His only injury was a fracture to his right clavicle. There were no visible tire marks or scrapes at the time we were at the scene. There was no reduction in wheelbase on the motorcycle.
RiderInj: The 23 year old male (6?04?, 140 lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of a fracture to his right clavicle. He was treated at a local hospital and released the same day.
ODriverInj: The 22 year old Black female (5? 04?, 147 lbs.) OV driver was not injured and showed no signs of impairment.
Human: The rider of M/C-1 was pre-occupied with getting to the side of the road to check for damage to his M/C after thinking he hit another vehicle, and made an unsafe lane change which caused the crash. The driver of OV-1 was contacted by phone and refused to participate.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor damage to the right side. There was some previous damage on both sides that was minor and not related to this crash. The pre-crash condition of the M/C was very good. We were unable to inspect OV-1.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle lay-down event with a secondary rear-end impact with another vehicle resulting in minor injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a two-vehicle rear-end crash that occurred in Southern California in December 2011 at 1558 hours. The weather was cloudy with a light wind. The approximate temperature was 60 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of asphalt which was dry, worn and polished, but in good condition. We were On- Scene. Both vehicles had already been moved from their FRP.

The crash occurred on a multiple lane roadway (three lanes in each direction with a continuous two-way left turn lane that becomes a dedicated left turn lane) just south of a four leg type intersection. There are signal controls for this intersection. The surrounding area is comprised of multi-story apartment buildings on both sides of the road south of the intersection. The layout changes to commercial/retail businesses on the north side of the intersection. There are tall trees on the left side of the roadway. The roadway is bordered by concrete curbs and sidewalks. The roadway is configured in a north/south direction and is a minor arterial road. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

M/C-1 was a 1997 Kawasaki Ninja ZX9R (899 cc?s) sport/racing type motorcycle that was purchased by the 26 year old male Hispanic rider. The rider was wearing a FMVSS 218/Snell M2005 rated motorcycle helmet with a dark colored face shield. Other than a helmet, the rider was wearing no M/C protective apparel.

The vehicles involved were driving in the same direction in adjacent lanes. OV-1 was stopped for a red light in the #3 (inside) lane. MC-1 was rapidly approaching the intersection in the #2 (middle) lane. The MC rider said that he was going between 50-60 mph and his throttle was stuck. He said he applied his brakes to slow the bike down and lost control when he hit a ?Bot-Dot.? The M/C then slid on its? left side, low side first, crossing over into the #3 lane and impacting the left rear of OV-1 causing minor damage and a flat tire to OV-1. The rider was fully ejected and tumbled/rolled to his FRP. The M/C left approximately 99? of combined scrapes from First Harmful Event to FRP. There were no tire marks. Evidence of the scrapes in the middle of the #2 lane discounts the riders? version of hitting a bot-dot and losing control. There was no reduction in wheelbase on the motorcycle.
RiderInj: The 26 year old male (6? 0?, 180 lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of multiple abrasions to his legs, hip, and both arms. He refused any medical attention at the scene. He stated that he would seek medical attention later if needed.
ODriverInj: The 32 year old female (5? 2?, 150 lbs.) OV driver was not injured and showed no signs of impairment.
Human: The unlicensed, inexperienced rider of MC1 was riding in an unsafe manner that would likely cause a crash.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor to moderate damage to the fairing and left side, as well as to the right side where the MC impacted OV1. There was minor pre-existing damage to many areas of the MC. The throttle return did not work. The entire mechanism was stiff and difficult to use.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a single vehicle (motorcycle) lay-down event (low side left) that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface and, ejected the rider causing non-life threatening injuries.
MV1: 2006 Honda Shadow VLX (cruiser style) motorcycle, 583cc (silver in color)
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. roadway surface traffic collision. The collision occurred during the hours of dusk in December 2011 at 1701 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1650 hours. The weather report showed clear skies, with winds out of the SW at 3.5 mph and, an ambient temperature of 62.1 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface was level, of asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.

The collision occurred on a straight at grade intersection multiple lane surface street, with an overall travel-way width of 90 feet. This is a minor arterial surface street with three lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and three lanes for southbound traffic. There are dedicated left turn lanes to regulate the flow of traffic as well as a posted speed limit of 40 mph. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. There were no significant roadway grade or,
crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site. At the location of the crash site the intersection is controlled in all four directions by multi-phase traffic control signals. The north side of the street is occupied by commercial and retail businesses as well as the south side of the street. The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted double yellow line lane markers. The intersection is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. There are also painted 12 foot wide pedestrian crosswalks decorated with roadway tiles at all four corners
of the intersection.
The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2006 Honda Shadow VLX (cruiser style) motorcycle being operated by a 67 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was travelling southbound in the designated #1 left turn lane of the multi-lane surface street entering the intersection. The motorcycle rider initiated his left turn movement in order to continue eastbound from the intersection. The rider advised law enforcement officials that during this time his speed was about 5 mph however, as he passed over the first (inside) painted crosswalk line marker he lost control of his motorcycle. The rider claimed that the rear tire ?slipped?
from under the bike causing him to fall left side down onto the roadway surface. When law enforcement officials arrived at the scene, the motorcycle had been moved off the roadway surface and was located parked and upright on the southeast corner of the intersection.
 
The left side rider foot peg and, the left rear turn signal had been sheared off as a result of the bike striking the roadway surface only. The left side view mirror had been damaged as well. Upon inspection of the ?area of impact? and ?final resting place?, I could find no other items or fixed objects that the bike could have come into contact with.

During the law enforcement investigation of this crash, a witness claimed a vehicle in front of the motorcycle (MC1) suddenly slowed at the end of the turning movement in order to turn into a service station located near the southeast corner of the intersection. The witness told police the motorcycle rider had to brake suddenly to prevent striking the vehicle and, that was the proximate cause of the collision. However, the rider did not impart this information to police when interviewed. There has been no other information available on the vehicle in question. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 67 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were predominately a broken left leg. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
Human: The 67 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) had made an unsafe turning movement while making his left turn movement and, may have been following too close to present traffic on the roadway.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. ground with subsequent bike lay-down (right side)
MV1: 1994 Yamaha FZR 1000 (1003 CC) Sport bike, black in color
Crash:
This Single non-fatal motorcycle crash/lay-down occurred in January 2012 at 1642 hours in Southern California. It was daylight, not bright and the roadway was lighted by the overhead luminaries. Traffic volume was moderate. The temperature was 67 degrees F and it was partly cloudy with no precipitation, the winds were light and asphalt roadway surface was dry.

The crash occurred on an undivided three-lane East/West straight roadway with a dedicated left turn lane in each direction with adjacent curbing and sidewalks. The area of the crash occurred in a commercial business area. The asphalt/bituminous roadway surface was in good repair. The posted speed limit is 35 mph.

Vehicle 1 (MC 1) was a black 1994 Yamaha FZR 1000 (1003 CC) Sport bike that was being operated by a 50 year old Black male (6 ft. 4 in., 235 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing a full face helmet with a clear face shield. The operator of Vehicle 1 (MC 1) was proceeding eastbound in the left turn lane, at approximately 40 mph. slowing to make a left turn at a four-leg intersection.   The operator of (MC 1) failed to slow enough to safely negotiate the turn with a grossly under inflated rear tire, causing the rear tire to slide out to the right.  The operator pulled in the clutch and grabbed the front brake, causing the motorcycle handlebars to rotate violently counter clockwise and causing the motorcycle to do a high-side lay-down on the right side. The rider was ejected
from the motorcycle and the rider POR was within 6 ft. of the POI.
RiderInj: The 50 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a left wrist sprain, contusions to the left side of his chest, right upper back, palms of both hands and abrasions to the back of both hands and inner left lower leg.
Human: The operator was unlicensed to operate the crash involved motorcycle. He failed to check the tire pressures before starting his trip. This coupled with his skills deficiency, led to the unsafe act of making the left turn at a higher speed than was prudent to the conditions and his inappropriate control operations.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicle (MC 1) determined to have a grossly underinflated rear tire greater than 40% underinflated with no tread visible, a front tire underinflated by more than 16% with 1/32 of visible tread. The lack of rear tire tread depth and grossly underinflated rear tire contributed to motorcycles initial low-side slide.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle (pick-up truck), front to side impact collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained a broken right leg and abrasions to his right elbow as a result of the front of the other vehicle (OV1) impacting with the right side of the motorcycle (MC1). There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the collision.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle (OV1) right side to front impact type traffic collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred during the hours of darkness in December 2011 at 1806 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1824 hours showed coastal fog, winds out of the south at 3.5 mph and, an ambient temperature of 51.8 degrees F. Visibility at ground level had been reduced to 0.5 miles. The roadway surface was level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred on a right curve multiple lane surface street of 740 feet in length with an overall travel-way width of 85 feet. This is an east/west surface street with two lanes dedicated for eastbound traffic and two lanes for westbound traffic. The posted speed limit for east/west traffic is 40 mph.
The radius of the roadway curvature was measured by using a 100? chord and was found to be approximately 894 feet on the approach to the intersection where the crash occurred. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The area of the collision scene is an at-grade intersection with designated left turn lanes for both east and westbound traffic to access the north/south residential street on either side. The north side of the street is occupied by residential multiple family dwellings. The south side of the street is occupied by a city government complex as well as residential homes.

At the location of the crash site there were no east/west traffic control devices to regulate the flow of traffic in the area. Both north and southbound lanes of traffic have posted ?STOP? signs regulating traffic. The posted speed limit for north/south traffic is 25 mph.
The opposing lanes of traffic west of the intersection are separated by a raised concrete median approximately 8 inches in height and 4 foot wide. The street is also bordered on both sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.
 
There are designated bicycle lanes on both the north and south side of the street. There is a designated right turn only lane designed to allow eastbound traffic to turn south from the intersection. This lane is marked with white lane paint and segregated from the rest of eastbound traffic. There is also a painted median with a designated pedestrian crosswalk. On the east side of the intersection the east/west lanes of traffic are separated only by a painted solid double yellow line lane marker.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 1994 Kawasaki Vulcan (touring type) motorcycle being operated by a 23 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was travelling eastbound in the #2 lane of the multi-lane surface street approaching the intersection.
The other vehicle (OV1) was a 1995 Toyota Tacoma standard bed pick-up truck being operated by a 24 year old male Pacific Islander driver. The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) had been travelling northbound and stopped at the marked limit line prior to entering the intersection.

The driver (OV1) looked to his left; checking for any approaching eastbound traffic then moved into the intersection at a speed of 5 to 10 mph. The driver said as he moved into the intersection he looked to his right checking for any approaching westbound traffic. As he thought it was clear the driver continued forward in his vehicle traversing the eastbound lanes of the multi-lane surface street when his vehicle struck the motorcycle (MC1).
At some point the resulting impact caused the motorcycle to become engaged with the other vehicle (OV1) and pushed approximately 36 feet from the area of impact where it fell on to the right side.
Based on the location of the damage sustained it appears as though the motorcycle (MC1) had been struck on the right side by the front portion of the other vehicle (OV1).
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 23 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were predominately a broken right leg and abrasions to the right elbow. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
ODriverInj: The 24 year old male driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. The police report also indicated that there were no apparent objective symptoms of alcohol or drug intoxication as well.
Human:
The 23 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) was driving at a speed considered safe for the present traffic on the roadway.
The 24 year old male driver of the other vehicle (OV1) failed to yield to approaching traffic while entering the intersection from another local surface street.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained major right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
 
The other vehicle (OV1) sustained major front end damage otherwise, was in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) pick-up truck front to side impact with a secondary side to side impact involving another vehicle (OV2) causing the motorcycle rider to be ejected off the bike and sustaining injuries to his back, neck and left side. The third and final event involved the motorcycle impacting with the roadway surface. There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the collision.
MV1: 2010 Aprilia RSV4R, (sport, race replica) motorcycle, 999.6 cc (white in color).
Crash:
This was a multiple impact motorcycle vs. other vehicle (OV1) vs. other vehicle (OV2) type traffic collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight in January 2012 at 0821 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 0855 hours showed overcast, calm winds and, an ambient temperature of 52.3 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unrestricted for 10 miles. The roadway surface was level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred on a straight multiple lane north south state highway with an overall travel-way width of 107 feet. This surface street has three lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and four lanes for southbound traffic. There is a marked 8 foot wide bicycle lane on the north side of the roadway and also a marked ?fog line? on the south side of the roadway. The posted speed limit for both north and southbound traffic is 50 mph.

The area of the crash site is about 140 feet north of an ?at grade? intersection controlled by multi-phase signal devices for all four directions of travel. There
are designated left turn lanes for all approaching traffic as well as designated right turn only lanes. The north side of the street is occupied by state protected wetlands. The south side of the street is occupied by a state owned public beach with parking.
At the location of the crash site traffic had been stopped for a southbound red light. Traffic was backed up to the area of the crash site.
The opposing lanes of traffic on this highway are separated by two sets of painted solid double yellow lines approximately 4 feet wide. The street is also bordered on both sides by a soft sandy shoulder. On the four corners of the intersection there is raised concrete curbing with concrete sidewalks. There are marked pedestrian crosswalks on the north, east and, west sides of the intersection.
There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site. There were no super- elevation issues with this roadway.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2010 Aprilia RSV4R (sport, race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 40 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was travelling southbound at about 15 to 20 mph splitting traffic between the #1 and #2 lanes.
 
The other vehicle (OV1) was a 1996 Chevrolet 3500 flatbed utility truck being operated by a 52 year old male Caucasian driver. The driver of other vehicle (OV1) was stopped southbound in the #1 lane behind traffic.

The other vehicle (OV2) was a 1996 Chevrolet 2500 pick-up truck being operated by a 60 year old male Caucasian driver. The driver of other vehicle (OV2) was stopped southbound in the #2 lane behind traffic and, slightly ahead and adjacent to the other vehicle (OV1).

While sitting in traffic the driver of (OV1) heard something to the rear of his vehicle and was concerned that something may have fallen off the bed of the truck. He decided to check it out. As he exited his vehicle, he swung the driver side door open at the same time the motorcycle (MC1) and rider were in the process of passing. However, as the driver did this, the motorcycle impacted with the door causing the motorcycle to veer to the left impacting the right rear portion and, right side of the Chevy pick-up (OV2) ejecting the rider.

The resulting impact between the motorcycle (MC1) and the Chevy pick-up (OV2) caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface and slide back into the #1 lane. The rider remained on the roadway surface in proximity to the first impact site with (OV1).

At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event. Although in proximity of a signal controlled intersection, the intersection and signal controls played no significant role in this event other than traffic being stopped for a red light.
RiderInj: The 40 year old male white rider of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were predominately complaints of pain to the back, neck and left side. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
ODriverInj: The 52 year old male driver of the Chevy 3500 flatbed utility truck (OV1) sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. The police report also indicated that there were no apparent objective symptoms of alcohol or drug intoxication.
Human:
The 40 year old male white rider of the motorcycle (MC1) was driving at a speed considered safe for the present traffic on the roadway however, may have been taking an unnecessary risk in splitting traffic.
The 52 year old male driver of other vehicle (OV1) failed to check for approaching traffic prior to opening the driver side door. The actions of the 60 year old male driver of other vehicle (OV2) contributed nothing to the cause of the crash.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained moderate left and right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
The other vehicle (OV1) sustained major damage to the driver?s side door otherwise, was in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
The other vehicle (OV2) sustained minor right rear (taillight assembly) and side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Light Truck / Front to Rear Impact with Secondary Lay-Down Event.
MV1: 2007 Yamaha R1 998cc sport, race replica style motorcycle
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred on 01/11/2012, a Wednesday evening at 2014 hours in Southern California. It was dark and the weather was clear, the temperature was 59 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and was noted to be travel worn.

The crash occurred on a busy East/West multiple lane surface street, which consists of two lanes in each direction, with dedicated left turn lanes. The roadway is located in a business district, bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The roadway has a downhill grade of the eastbound lanes of 4% at the location of the precipitating event and levels off to 1.2% downhill grade in the area of the crash. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.
Vehicle 1 (MC-1), is a 2007 Yamaha R1 998cc sport, race replica style motorcycle that was being operated by a 28 year-old Caucasian male (76 in., 235 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full-face motorcycle helmet, without a visible safety rating. The operator of MC-1 was proceeding eastbound in lane #1 at a high rate of speed.

Vehicle 2 (OV-1), is a 1987 Ford Ranger light truck which was being operated by a 38 year-old Hispanic male (68 in., 180 lbs.). The driver was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraint. OV-1 was eastbound in the #1 lane stopped behind two other vehicles at a red signal.

The rider of MC-1 saw the stopped traffic at the intersection and applied the rear brake, causing a locked rear tire skid of approximately 295 feet. The motorcycle drifted into the #2 lane, and then swerved back into the #1 lane before striking the right rear bumper and taillight of OV-1 with the left side of MC-1 and the rider?s left leg. The rider of MC-1 was launched from the motorcycle onto the asphalt roadway, and slid to his final rest position (FRP) adjacent to the South curb of the eastbound lanes. The motorcycle sustained major damage to the left side from the collision with OV-1 and the right side from impacting the asphalt roadway, and sliding to its FRP adjacent to the South curb of the eastbound lanes.
RiderInj: The 28 year-old male operator of the MC-1 sustained a compound fracture of the left leg/knee and showed objective symptoms of alcohol intoxication. The operator of OV-1 was uninjured in the crash.
Human: The 28 year-old male rider ofMC-1 was riding with a BAC of .076% tested a half hour after the crash, and at an excessive speed, contributing to his failure to see stopped traffic ahead. The driver of OV-1 was stopped in traffic, and contributed nothing to the cause or outcome of this crash.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. Other Vehicle; right to left side impact configuration with a secondary right side lay-down event that resulted in minor injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This two-vehicle, right to side impact crash occurred in Southern California in January 2012 at 1830 hours. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with no wind. The approximate temperature was 60.1 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of asphalt that was dry, but in good condition.

The crash occurred at a T-type intersection on a residential roadway that is hilly with an up-grade for the vehicles direction of travel, and has a series of switchback curves. Some of these curves create a blind curve, especially if the speed limit is not adhered to. The roadway has one lane in each direction with a painted double yellow line that terminates at each intersection. The two lane roadway leading to the intersection is curved to the right (R=386.2 ft.) and has a positive 8% grade. There is a stop sign for the intersecting side street only. The surrounding area is comprised of single family residences. On the riders? left, the homes are at grade. On the riders? right is a landscaped up-hill slope with homes above. There are trees and other greenery on both sides of the roadway. The roadway is bordered by concrete curbs and sidewalks. The roadway is configured in an east/west direction and is a local road. The posted speed limit is 25 mph.

M/C-1 was a 2004 Suzuki SV1000s (966 cc?s) sport/racing type motorcycle that was borrowed by the 24 year old male Caucasian rider with owner?s permission. The rider was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings. It is unknown what, if any, safety gear the rider was wearing.

The vehicles involved were driving in the same direction in the same lane until the M/C attempted to pass OV-1 on the left, but still in lane one. At the time the M/C was passing on the left, OV-1 started to make a left turn onto the side street. The rider of M/C-1 swerved to the left and locked his rear brake leaving approximately 19? 10? of skid, then impacted the left front side of OV-1 with his right side/exhaust, muffler region and subsequently went down. The M/C slid
 
to its FRP on its? right side, high side forward. The rider was fully ejected and landed at an unknown location. Both vehicles were moved prior to the police arriving. Their locations were not reported and neither operator participated for an interview. There was no reduction in wheelbase for the motorcycle.
RiderInj: The 24 year old male (5? 10?, 155 lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions to his right elbow and both knees. He was taken to a hospital, treated and released.
ODriverInj: The 20 year old male (5? 09?, 155 lbs.) OV driver was not injured and showed no signs of impairment.
Human:
The rider of M/C-1 had an expired license (unknown if it has an endorsement for M/C) and was riding in an unsafe manner that would likely
cause a crash. The rider also used improper avoidance techniques.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor damage to the fairing and right side, as a result of impacting OV-1 and the ground. There was minor pre- existing damage to other areas of the MC. The overall pre-crash condition of the M/C appeared to be good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: SUV vs. rear of Motorcycle, vs. rear of Light Truck.
MV1: 2006 Black, Harley Davidson Softtail, 1442cc Cruiser style motorcycle.
Crash:
This three vehicle crash occurred in February 2012 at 0752 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the weather was partly cloudy, the temperature was 50.7 degrees F and the winds were light. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and travel worn.

The crash occurred on a busy North/South, multiple lane surface street, which consists of three lanes in each direction, with dedicated left turn lanes. The roadway is located in a business district, bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The roadway is straight and level at area of the crash. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

Vehicle 1 (MC-1), a 2006 Black, Harley Davidson Softtail, 1442cc Cruiser style motorcycle was being ridden by a 51 year-old Caucasian male (6
ft. 4 in., 230 lbs.). The rider was wearing a motorcycle helmet, type and style unknown. The rider of MC-1 was northbound, stopped in lane #2 behind Vehicle 3 (OV-2) a 1997 White, Ford Explorer, which was being driven by a 54 year-old Hispanic male (5 ft. 6 in., 180 lbs.), waiting for the traffic signal to turn green. The driver and passenger of OV-2 were reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

Vehicle 2 (OV-1), a 1994 White, Toyota Land Cruiser, driven by a 43 year-old male (5 ft. 11 in., 220 lbs.) who was reported to have a brace on his right leg. The driver was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraint. OV-1 was northbound in the #2 lane approaching the level, four- way, at grade intersection. The driver of OV-1 saw the stopped traffic at the intersection and attempted to move his right foot to the brake pedal, but was unable to get his foot completely off the accelerator, causing OV-1 to accelerate into MC-1, which in turn pushed MC-1 into OV-2. OV-1 continued to push MC-
1?s front, then left side into and up the back bumper and hatch of OV-2, pinning the riders left leg between the motorcycle and OV-2. The rider of MC-1 jumped from the motorcycle onto the asphalt roadway where he collapsed at his final rest position (FRP) in the #1 lane. The motorcycle sustained major damage to
the rear and right side from the collision with OV-1 and the front and left side from the collision with OV-2.
RiderInj: The 51 year-old male operator of MC-1 sustained abrasions to his arms and legs, and reported pain to his head, neck and chest.
ODriverInj: The operators of OV-1 & OV-2 were uninjured in the crash.
Human: The 43 year-old male driver of OV-1 was driving with a metal brace on his right leg, making it extremely difficult to properly operate the gas and brake pedal, contributing to his failure to stop. The rider of MC-1 and the driver of OV-2 were stopped in traffic, and contributed nothing to the cause or outcome of this crash.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle, left side impact with secondary lay-down event resulting in moderate injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a motorcycle (M/C-1) into Other Vehicle (OV-1) left side impact that occurred in Southern California in January 2012 at 1702 hours. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with no wind.
