The approximate temperature was 60.1 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of asphalt which was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition.

The crash occurred mid-block between signal controlled intersections at a private driveway to a business. The roadway is configured in an east/west direction. The roadway has two lanes in the westbound direction and three lanes in the eastbound direction. There is a two-way left turn lane in the center of the roadway. The surrounding area is comprised of industrial/commercial to the right and commercial businesses to the left. There are trees and other greenery on both sides of the roadway. The roadway is bordered by concrete curbs and sidewalks. The roadway is a minor arterial and the speed limit is 45 mph.

M/C-1 was a 1984 BMW K100rs (987 cc?s) sport touring type motorcycle that was owned by the 56 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was wearing a FMVSS 218/Snell M90 rated motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield.    Other than a helmet, the rider was wearing an armored jacket, motorcycle style gloves, and boots.

M/C-1 was westbound in the #1 (outside) lane after making a right turn from a nearby side street. There was at least one slow moving vehicle in front of him that he wanted to pass. When M/C-1 made its? right turn to go west, there was another vehicle at that intersection that was making a left turn to also go west. They both made their turns at the same time and stayed in their proper lanes. It was at this time that M/C-1 wanted to pass the slower moving vehicle in the
 
#1 lane. He signaled, made a head check over his left shoulder while accelerating and changed lanes into the #2 (inside) lane. He was passing the vehicle in the #1 lane at about 30 mph. The motorcycle rider traversed the skip-dash lane lines during his passing maneuver and entered lane #2, just prior to the
collision. He was looking forward and accelerating when OV-1 came into the roadway from a driveway on the right side. Neither the M/C rider nor the OV driver could see each other because of the vehicle that was being passed in the #1 lane. The OV pulled out directly in front of the M/C who had no time to react and hit the left side of the OV, then fell to the roadway surface. Neither the rider nor the OV driver made any evasive maneuvers. There were no tire marks from either vehicle. There were only a couple of small scrapes in the roadway where the M/C hit the ground. The M/C landed on its? left side plane in an unknown configuration and close to the AOI. The same is true for the rider. There was an approximate 5.7? reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 56 year old Caucasian male (5? 11?, 195 lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained moderate injuries consisting of fractured right acetabulum, a minor laceration to the bridge of his nose cause by the sunglasses he was wearing, a minor abrasion to his right elbow, and bi- lateral muscle strains to his neck. He was admitted to a hospital for three days.
ODriverInj: The 55 year old female Caucasian (5? 06?, 150 lbs.) OV driver was not injured and showed no signs of impairment.
Human: Both the M/C rider and the OV driver had a perception failure due to a temporary moving visual obstruction (other vehicles in the roadway). The OV driver also had a decision failure by pulling out in front of on-coming traffic.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major damage to the front end, fairing and left side, as a result of impacting OV-1 and the ground. The front rim was deformed in two areas. The damage appears to have been caused by the M/C impacting the lower frame of the OV causing the reduction in wheelbase and forcing the front tire/wheel into the M/C frame/engine resulting in a second deformation of the rim. There was minor pre-existing damage to other areas of the MC. The overall pre-crash condition of the M/C appeared to be good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) rear-end type injury traffic collision, with a secondary lay-down event. The motorcycle rider sustained non-life threatening injuries and was treated and released at the scene.
MV1: 2004 Harley Davidson FXSTI Soft tail (cruiser style) motorcycle, 1449cc (black in color)
Crash:
This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) minor injury traffic collision occurring during the daylight hours in February 2012 at 1134 hours in Southern California. The weather report for this region showed partly light rain, with winds out of the SW at 10.4 mph and, an ambient temperature of 57.2 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface was level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred on a straight multiple lane arterial surface street with an at-grade four leg intersection. The intersection is controlled by multi-phase traffic control signals with three lanes dedicated for westbound traffic and three lanes for eastbound traffic. The opposing lanes are separated by a 4 foot wide raised concrete median. There are two designated left turn lanes for westbound to southbound traffic as well as two designated left turn lanes for eastbound to northbound traffic. Each side of the street also contains designated bike lanes and the overall travel-way width of this street is 100 feet. There are commercial and retail shopping centers in all four quadrants.

There is a posted speed limit of 45 mph for both east and westbound traffic. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2004 Harley Davidson (cruiser style) motorcycle being operated by a 53 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider had been travelling westbound in the designated #3 lane of the multi-lane surface street and was stopped at the limit line for a red phased traffic light. The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) was also travelling westbound in the #3 lane at a reduced speed of 10-15 mph approaching (MC1) from behind.
As the rider was waiting for the light to phase he saw the adjacent left turn lane traffic had received a fresh green arrow to proceed. The rider then checked his side view mirrors and saw that the other vehicle (OV1) began to gain in speed not stopping. The motorcycle (MC1) was struck from behind by the other vehicle (OV1) causing the rider to be ejected off the rear portion of the bike. The bike was pushed forward a distance of 15 feet and collapsed onto its left side.
 
The motorcycle sustained damage to the rear fender which had been pushed into the rear tire. The left side of the motorcycle sustained minor damage to the left side once it collapsed onto the roadway surface. While inspecting the scene there was a 9 inch long scrape on the roadway surface near the motorcycles final resting place (FRP) and no evidence of skid marks from either vehicle. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 53 year old male Caucasian rider sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were a neck sprain (whiplash) and a contusion to the right leg from striking the motorcycle engine air cleaner and, roadway surface. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system. The rider was treated and released at the scene.
Human:
The 44 year old female Caucasian driver of the Chevrolet Tahoe (OV1) had been traveling at a speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway. The driver may have been distracted as well by the movement of the left turn lane traffic directly to the left of her lane of travel.
The male rider of the motorcycle (MC1) was stopped in traffic at the time of the crash and subsequently did not contribute to the cause or outcome of the event.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor rear and left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision. The other vehicle (OV1) sustained minor damage to the front bumper however, was in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle, right side impact with secondary lay-down event resulting in moderate injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a motorcycle (M/C-1) into Other Vehicle (OV-1) frontal to right side impact that occurred in Southern California in February 2012 at 1612 hours. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with a light wind from the West. The approximate temperature was 75.9 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was dry, and in poor condition, (ripples, pot holes, bitumen repair, and exposed/unused train tracks).

The crash occurred at a private driveway to a business mid-block between T-type intersections that were controlled by stop signs for cross traffic. The roadway is configured in an east/west direction. The roadway has one lane in each direction with no centerline markings. The roadway is 45? wide and has a 29? offset just east of the crash site. The offset east of the crash site is horizontally lower. The surrounding area is comprised of industrial/commercial on both sides of the road. There are trees and other greenery on both sides of the roadway. The roadway is intermittently bordered by concrete curbs. There is some on-street parking allowed on both sides of the road. There are no sidewalks. The roadway is a local road and the speed limit is 25 mph.

M/C-1 was a 2006 Honda CRB 600rr (599 cc?s) sport/race replica type motorcycle that was owned by the 25 year old male Hispanic rider. The rider was wearing a FMVSS 218/Snell M2005 rated motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield. Other than a helmet, the rider was wearing a leather armored jacket and gloves.

M/C-1 was westbound in the #1 (outside/only) lane after entering the road from a nearby driveway. A witness said that the M/C and he nearly crashed when the M/C entered the road and that the M/C was going very fast. The OV was going eastbound #1 (outside/only) and making a left turn into a driveway.
According to statements, neither operator saw each other prior to impact. The rider thought that the car was pulling out from a driveway between parkedcars. Neither operator made any evasive moves. The M/C impacted the right side of the OV in the passenger door area and caused major damage to both vehicles. The rider was fully ejected and impacted the top of the door/roof line area causing damage to the helmet as well as fracturing his nose. The rider was wearing non-prescription sun glasses which may have been partially responsible for his fractured nose. The face shield to the helmet was broken off. The
rider was momentarily stuck under his M/C. There were no tire marks from either vehicle. There were no scrape marks in the road from the M/C. The M/C landed on its? right side plane facing south and close to the AOI. The same is true for the rider. There was a minor reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 25 year old Hispanic male (5? 07?, 165 lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained moderate injuries consisting of: avulsion fractures involving the spinous process of the C2, C3, and C4 vertebrae; open nasal fractures; open fracture to his left femur; blunt trauma to his chest and abdomen, and lacerations/ contusions. He was admitted to a hospital for five days.
ODriverInj: The 58 year old female Hispanic (5? 01?, 140 lbs.) OV driver complained of pain to her left knee, but refused treatment. She showed no signs of impairment. The OV driver refused to participate for an interview.
Human: Both the M/C rider and the OV driver had a perception failure most likely from not paying attention. Excessive speed on the part of M/C-1 was a contributing factor. The OV-1 driver made a decision error in making her left turn in front of on-coming traffic.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major damage to the front end, fairing and both sides, as a result of impacting OV-1 and the ground. There was a minor reduction in wheelbase which is surprising due to the type of impact and speed involved. The overall pre-crash condition of the M/C appeared to be good.
Environmental: The roadway off-set may have been a contributing factor to the crash.

CrashType: This was a single vehicle motorcycle (MC1) vs. roadway surface injury traffic collision, causing non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider.
MV1: 2009 Harley Davidson Electra Glide (Touring style) motorcycle, 1584 cc (black in color)
Crash:
This was a single vehicle motorcycle lay down event occurring during the daylight hours in January 2012 at 0835 hours in Southern California. The weather report for this region showed clear skies, with winds out of the east at 3.5 mph and, an ambient temperature of 57.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface was level, of a concrete composition that appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.

The collision occurred on a right curved westbound multiple lane arterial local freeway corridor (refer to CSAT image) in proximity of an interchange of two intersecting freeway corridors.

The posted speed limit is 65 mph for both freeways. It was illegal as well as unsafe to park on this freeway to obtain information regarding: super-elevation issues with this freeway surface. However, driving through this area I could find no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.

At the location of the crash site there are no traffic control signs, signals or, fixtures to regulate the flow of traffic other than speed limit and directional signs. The diagram will not illustrate the opposing lanes of the freeway because they did not contribute to the cause or outcome of this crash.
The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2009 Harley Davidson Electra Glide (touring style) motorcycle being operated by a 50 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was travelling westbound in the designated #1 lane of the multi-lane freeway corridor.
The motorcycle rider was accelerating his bike to a speed of between 35 and 40 mph and, and at the time was setting up to ?split? traffic between the
#1 and # 2 lanes. The rider continued to say that before he could do this a vehicle made a lane change moving from left to right from the #2 lane into the #1 lane directly in front of him. He could not provide any information as to the make and model of the vehicle, no contact between vehicles was made and, it was not listed on the police report.
 
The motorcycle rider told me in his own words that he applied both brakes and down shifted however, ?grabbed? too much front brake. He said he felt his only option was to lay the bike down (low side left) and not ?high side? it to the right. The rider continued to say the bike went down and he hit the ground striking his head and was knocked unconscious. The rider said when he came to, he was on a Paramedic?s stretcher and his motorcycle was parked on the shoulder.
RiderInj: The 50 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were predominately a temporary loss of consciousness (NFS) and numerous superficial non-infected abrasions to his forehead, left eye brow and, the bridge of his nose. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system. It has been recorded that the rider was wearing a ?novelty? style helmet at the time of the crash. This helmet is not DOT approved.
Human: The 50 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) had been traveling at a speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway and, may have been following too close as well. The rider also told me he was preoccupied with the fact that he was running late for work.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision. Other than the presence of vehicles on the freeway there was no indication of the presence of pedestrians or animals within proximity of the crash site.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a single vehicle (motorcycle) vs. fixed object (concrete curb) impact including a lay-down event (high side right) and secondary impact with another fixed object (concrete curb) resulting in the rider being ejected and sustaining serious injuries.
MV1: 2005 Yamaha V Star Classic (cruiser style) motorcycle, 1063cc, blue in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. (multiple) fixed objects (8? raised concrete curbs) and lay down event injury crash. The collision occurred during the hours of darkness in March 2012 at 2010 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1751 hours. The weather report showed clear skies, with calm winds and, an ambient temperature of 63.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface was a progressive positive grade from 0.2% grade in the area of the precipitating event to 4.0% at the motorcycles final resting place. The roadway surface was of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred on a straight uphill grade multiple lane minor arterial surface street, with an overall travel-way width of 84 feet. This is a minor arterial surface street with three lanes dedicated for westbound traffic and three lanes for eastbound traffic. There is a multi-phase signal controlled intersection (in proximity to AOI#1) that regulates the flow of north and southbound traffic from a residential area on the north to a public Park & Ride lot on the south. There are dedicated ?left turn? lanes to regulate the flow of traffic as well as a posted speed limit of 35 mph for east/west traffic. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.

At the location of the secondary crash site (AOI#2) there is a freeway on ramp of approximately 30 feet in width that grants access for westbound traffic to transition onto the northbound lanes of an interstate/freeway mainline. There are no signs or signals to regulate traffic onto this on ramp from the street.

The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted solid double yellow line lane markers. The intersection is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2005 Yamaha V Star Classic (cruiser style) motorcycle being operated by a 55 year old male Hispanic rider. The rider was travelling westbound in the designated #1 lane of the multi-lane surface street entering a signal controlled intersection prior to the crash sequence.
In my conversation with the motorcycle rider he told me he was travelling a known route of travel to a meeting at his local church. He went on to tell me thatas he was driving westbound he turned his attention to a market located on the northeast corner of the intersection; he contemplated stopping in. The rider stated his speed was about 30-40 mph and there were no vehicles or anything that he could remember that would have caused him to redirect his vehicle on the roadway. The rider said he had no recollection of the crash events and, in his words: ?one minute I?m riding, the next minute I?m in the hospital!?

While inspecting the crash scene, I discovered scuff marks along the top of the curb face located on the northwest corner of the signal controlled intersection. These scuff marks appeared to coincide with scratch marks discovered on the front underside of the right foot board of the crash motorcycle. There was also damage to the underside mounting brackets for the footboard.
There were also scratch marks to the face of the exhaust pipes mounted on the right side of the bike.
The major damage to the gas tank along the top and right side coincided with the impact to the second curb face at the entrance to the freeway. What was evident at this location was the discovery of glass material, still at the scene, that matched the glass material used on the speedometer face (mounted on top of the tank) which was severely damaged.

The damage to this location of the crash motorcycle appears to suggest a high side right front collapse of the bike simultaneously onto the roadway surface and curb face.

During my scene investigation I walked the approximate 155 feet from the first area of impact to the final resting place of the motorcycle and could find no visible scratches or scuffs between the two locations suggesting a high speed wobble was created after the first harmful event that led to a high side right collapse of the motorcycle at the second harmful event.

The rider was ejected off and to the right of the second impact area however there was no indication in the police report or the riders statements as to exactly where other than inside the boundaries of the on ramp. The diagram illustrates a location for the rider as a result of the discovery of a plastic colored eye glass lens that matched the description of what the rider was wearing. This lens was discovered on the raised concrete divider in proximity to the motorcycle and possibly close to where the rider had landed.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj:
The 55 year old male Hispanic operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained serious injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were
predominately a fractured (broken) right ankle with four broken toes (excluding the big toe). He also sustained abrasions to the right side of his head near the temple, the outside of the right thigh, both right and left knees, and the left hand. He sustained a neck sprain and an apparent loss of consciousness. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
Human: The 55 year old male Hispanic operator of the motorcycle (MC1) was travelling at an unsafe speed on the roadway and, directing his attention away (to the right) caused his motorcycle to drift enough to the right was enough to cause a sideswipe type impact of the curb face thus starting the crash sequence.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained major damage to the area of the top right side of the gas tank and handlebar assembly and, moderate damage along the right side. Other than the damage sustained the motorcycle appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this multiple series of crash events.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Non-fixed Object.
Crash:
This single vehicle crash occurred in March 2012 at 1001 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the weather was overcast, the temperature was 64 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and was noted to be travel worn.

The crash occurred on a lightly traveled, two way residential North/South, surface street. The roadway is bordered by single family homes, raised curbing and sidewalks. The roadway has a grade of .2% at the location of the precipitating event and a crown of 2.7%. The posted speed limit is 25 mph and has a gentle curve to the left.

Vehicle 1 (MC-1), a 1998 Yamaha YZ 250cc off-road motorcycle, operated by a 29 year-old Caucasian male (67 in., 175 lbs.). The rider of MC-1 was proceeding northbound at approximately 44 mph, with a 21 year-old Caucasian female (no further details) passenger, directly behind him. Neither the rider or passenger was wearing a helmet and there were no passenger foot pegs.

The rider of MC-1 saw that he wouldn?t be able to negotiate the left hand curve ahead due to his high rate of speed. He applied both brakes, causing a rear wheel locked skid of approximately 106? 7?. The skid terminated at the Point of Impact (POI), where the lower right side of MC-1?s engine, impacted the lower left corner of the roll-off bin, causing severe damage to the right side of the engine. The rider and passenger of MC-1 were launched to the left, from the motorcycle onto the asphalt roadway, as the motorcycle pivoted around the corner of the bin to the left and slid to its final rest position (FRP) adjacent to the West side of the roll-off bin. The FRP of MC-1 was 8? 1? North and 3? 7? West of the POI. The rider FRP was 16? North and 11? 9? West of the POI and the FRP of the passenger was 9? 6? North and 13? 2? West of the POI.
RiderInj: The 29 year-old male rider of MC-1 sustained a compound fracture of the right leg, the 21 year-old female passenger of MC-1 sustained abrasions to the right knee with complaint of pain to the right leg.
Human: The 29 year-old male rider of MC-1 was riding a non-street legal motorcycle, at an excessive speed, with a passenger, on a motorcycle made for a single rider.  This caused a critical balance issue, which contributed to the cause of this crash. Neither the rider nor passenger was wearing a helmet. This was not a causal factor.
Vehicle: It was determined that MC-1had a grossly underinflated rear tire and an under-inflated front tire, these factors were crash causal factors. It was also determined that the muffler had been removed; this factor was not a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) lay-down event with a secondary side impact vs. other vehicle (OV1) resulting in fatal injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a motorcycle (MC1) into Other Vehicle (OV1) front to left side impact that occurred in Southern California in March 2012 at 0951 hours. The weather was clear with a moderate wind that was gusting and variable but predominately from the SSW. The approximate temperature was 60 degrees F. The roadway
was constructed of asphalt which was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition.

The crash occurred mid-block between signal controlled intersections. The roadway is configured in a north/south direction. The roadway has two lanes (one in each direction) with on-street parallel parking on the rider?s right and angled parking on the rider?s left. The roadway is divided with a double solid yellow painted line. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial businesses to the right and a railway easement with fencing on the left. There are trees and other greenery on both sides of the roadway. The roadway is bordered by concrete curbs and sidewalks. The roadway is a minor arterial and the speed limit is 40 mph.

MC1 was a 2007 Kawasaki ZX 10r Ninja (998 cc) sport/racing type motorcycle that was owned by the 30 year old male Caucasian rider?s father. The rider was wearing a full face helmet with integral chin bar and clear face shield. The face shield broke off during the crash and was found lying in the parking area northwest of the crash. The coroner would not allow access to the helmet. It is unknown what the color is or the safety ratings. The rider was wearing a leather jacket, motorcycle style gloves, and over the ankle sport hiking shoes.

MC1 was northbound in the #1 lane approaching traffic that was stopped. A witness in one of the stopped vehicles said that the rider weaved from side to side as he approached in what he thought was an attempt to see how to get around the stopped traffic. The rider suddenly accelerated and crossed over the
 
double yellow lines and began passing the vehicles on the wrong side of the road. At the head of the stopped vehicles was a car that was waiting to make a legal left turn into the angled parking area. This vehicle (OV1), began its? left turn at about the same time as the MC was passing the stopped traffic. The MC rider veered slightly to the right before losing control and capsizing due to a ?flopping wobble? per [name] on the MC?s left side plane and then impacted OV1 on the left side near the rear tire. OV1 was pushed in a CCW rotation approximately 1.5 feet and the MC was wedged under the OV. The rider was also pinned under the OV. Witnesses and others jacked up the OV1 to extricate the rider and the MC from under the car before emergency personnel arrived. The rider was under the OV head first. Both vehicles were in their proper orientation for their FRP?s. The MC was moved approximately 5? south of its? original FRP per the police. The OV1 driver made no pre-impact evasive maneuvers. There was a maximum reduction in wheelbase in which the front tire impacted the engine area. Accurate measurements could not be taken due to the severely damaged MC front end.
RiderInj: The 30 year old Caucasian male (6? 00?, 170 lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained fatal injuries consisting of numerous cranial/facial fractures, brain lacerations with trauma and swelling, bi-lateral rib fractures, bilateral lung hematomas, lacerated spleen, two fractured vertebrae, and numerous abrasions/contusions. The rider had no evidence of alcohol in his system, but did test positive for THC (Cannabis).
ODriverInj: The 68 year old female Caucasian (5? 02?, 128 lbs.) OV driver was not injured and showed no signs of impairment.
Human: Both the MC rider and the OV driver had a perception failure due to a temporary moving visual obstruction (large truck between the two in the roadway). The MC rider also had a decision failure by riding on the wrong side of the road to illegally pass other vehicles at a high rate of speed.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major damage to the front end, fairing, gas tank deformation, and both sides, as a result of impacting OV1 and the ground. The damage appears to have been caused by the MC impacting the lower frame of OV1 causing the reduction in wheelbase and breaking the forks. It is unknown if there was any pre-existing damage to the MC. The overall pre-crash condition of the MC appeared to be good. The MC was equipped with many aftermarket high performance items. Both tires showed worn tire material buildup on the outer edges from hard and fast turns with a very low lean angle as would be done on a race track.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing serious injuries.
MV1: 1991 Suzuki GSXR Sport Race replica motorcycle 599cc (red in color) Other Vehicle (OV1):
OV1: 2002 Acura TL S series automobile (blue in color)
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury traffic collision. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight in March 2012 at 1005 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 0953 hours showed clear skies, with winds out of the east at 11.8 mph, wind gusts of up to 17.3 mph and, an ambient temperature of 69.1 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface for the motorcycle (MC1) was an uphill grade of 7.8%. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition.

The collision occurred on a (left) curved uphill grade local surface street with an overall travel-way width of 38 feet. The street although curved, runs primarily east to west with one lane dedicated for eastbound and one lane dedicated for westbound traffic. There are no designated traffic control devices to regulate
the east/west traffic lanes. The location of the crash scene was at an at-grade T-style intersection with one posted stop sign regulating northbound traffic.

The intersecting local surface street has an overall travel-way width of 33 feet. The speed limit for east/west traffic in this area is 35 mph. The intersecting local street speed limit is 25 mph. The eastbound uphill grade at the intersection is 3.6%. The roadway crown on approach to the crash scene is 1.4% however at the crash scene it measured 3.6%. There were no apparent super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted solid double yellow line lane marker. The intersecting local surface street lanes (for north & southbound traffic) are also separated by a painted solid double yellow lane marker. Besides the posted stop sign, there is also a white painter designator prior to the limit line indicating the word ?STOP?.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 1991 Suzuki GSXR (sport race replica) 599cc motorcycle being operated by a (20) year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was travelling eastbound in the #1eastbound lane of the two lane local surface street approaching the T-intersection on an uphill grade.
 The other vehicle (OV1) was approaching northbound in the #1 lane of the intersecting local surface street. The operator of the other vehicle (OV1) had initially stopped at the limit line prior to entering the intersection to make a left turn onto the westbound lane of traffic. The driver initiated a left turn movement by entering the intersection however the driver saw the motorcycle (MC1) approaching at a high rate of speed. The driver of OV1 immediately applied the brakes
and attempted to place the vehicle in reverse to back out of the way, to no avail. As the rider crested the grade and observed the other vehicle (OV1) stopped in the intersection, he applied his brakes and attempted to downshift. The rider said the rear of his bike started to slide out to the right at the moment he collided with the left front portion of the bumper area of the other vehicle (OV1) causing him to be vaulted over the front hood of the vehicle and on to the roadway surface (about 18 feet) near the FRP of his motorcycle. The now rider-less motorcycle (MC1) continued in front of the other vehicle (OV1) collapsing left side down on to the roadway surface until it came to rest a distance of approximately 30 feet from the area of impact.
The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained a complaint of pain however refused any medical treatment.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The (20) year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained a fracture to his right hand a contusion to his left forearm, abrasions to both knees, left hand and, right elbow. The rider was transport from the scene to a local hospital where he was treated and released the same day. The rider was wearing a DOT approved full face motorcycle helmet that sustained minor scrapping type damage.
Human:
The (20) year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) was travelling at a speed unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway and failed to comprehend the hazards of vehicles at intersections.
The (41) year old female driver of the other vehicle (OV1) failed perceive the presence of approaching traffic while making a left turn movement.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained moderate right front contact damage with the other vehicle (OV1) and minor left side damage as a result of impacting with the roadway surface.
The other vehicle (OV1) sustained moderate left front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Semi-truck
OV1: Unknown year, Semi-Truck w/trailer (dirt/gravel hauler type).
Crash:
This multi-vehicle motorcycle crash occurred in March 2012 at 2203 hours in Southern California. The temperature was 55 degrees F and it was partly cloudy with no precipitation. The winds were calm and the asphalt/concrete roadway surface was dry and travel worn.

The crash occurred Southbound on a level, north/south state highway with four normal and one High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes in both directions. The southbound highway curves left, with a radius of 1251 feet, a cord of 100 feet, a middle ordinate of 1 foot, superelevation of 3.0 % and a horizontal curve length of 1659 feet. The posted speed limit is 65 mph.
Vehicle 1 (MC-1) is a 2009 Yamaha, 599 cc, R6, with unknown miles on the odometer, was being operated by a 30 year old black male (5 ft. 10 in., 173 lbs.) who was wearing a (DOT/Snell 2000) approved full face helmet at the time of the crash. Vehicle 2 (OV-1) is an unknown year, Semi-Truck w/trailer (dirt/gravel hauler type), driver unknown, who fled the scene without stopping. Both vehicles were proceeding south. The rider of MC-1 was proceeding at an estimated speed of 90 mph, and was observed moving from lane to lane passing other vehicles, just prior to the precipitating event; MC-1 was in lane # 3 entering the left curve, approaching OV-1 on the left side. MC-1 drifted right toward OV-1, the rider attempted to apply the brakes, just prior to impacting the left side of OV-1?s trailer #2. The rider was launched forward and to the right between OV-1?s trailers in line with the left side tires, sliding forward approximately five (5) feet, before being run over by OV-1. There is evidence on the roadway surface that points to the rider and MC-1 being struck by multiple vehicles each, after the end of the crash sequence. The ?Point of Impact? (POI) of MC-1 and rider with the side of OV-1was approximately 255 feet north of the south road edge of the east/west overpass and approximately 4 feet 4 inches east of the north/south station line, which is anchored on the south road edge of the east/west overpass and the lane line dividing the #1 and #2 lanes. The first ?Final Rest Position? (FRP) of MC-1 was approximately 231 feet north of the south road edge of the east/west overpass and approximately 12 feet 4 inches east of the north/south station line. The first ?Final Rest Position? (FRP) of the rider was approximately 178 feet north of the south road edge of the east/west overpass and approximately 10 feet 9 inches east of the north/south station line. The debris field stretches south approximately 720 feet to the ?Final Resting Position? (FRP) of MC-1. The FRP of MC-1 is approximately 461 feet south of the south curb line and 64 feet east of the north/south station line.
RiderInj: The 30 year old male rider of the motorcycle died at the scene, due to multiple blunt force traumas. The highest AIS severity code in each of the three most severely injured areas are: Partial abdominal transection (511000.6), crushed calvarium (150408.4) and left arm amputation (711001.4). The ?Injury Severity Score? (ISS) #157 of the Rider/Occupant Injury Form totals 68. The rider was not under the influence of alcohol or drugs at the time of the crash.
Human: The rider was newly licensed to operate a motorcycle and had limited riding experience. The rider failed to negotiate the left curve, due to his excessively high rate of speed and riding experience.
Vehicle: There were no pre-existing vehicle condition that contributed to the accident.
Environmental: There were no contributing environmental factors.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) lay down event (left side plane, low side forward) with a secondary non-horizontal impact into the rear of the Other Vehicle (OV1) which was slowing/stopping. The crash resulted in minor injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a motorcycle (MC1) lay down event in which MC1 over braked and capsized onto its? left side plane, low side forward and then impacted the rear center of OV1. The crash occurred on a freeway in Southern California in January 2012 at 1749 hours. It was daylight, near dusk and no overhead lighting. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy and the wind was calm. The approximate temperature was 60.1 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material which was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition.

The crash occurred on a southbound freeway just before an on-ramp merging area. There are three lanes of travel where the crash occurred, not including the on-ramp lane to the west which is separated by a white painted gore point. The roadway has a north/south designation; however, in the area of the crash it runs northwest/southeast. The roadway has a positive barrier separating the other side of the freeway. The roadway consisting of the three lanes of travel is 60 feet wide. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial/retail and multi-story office buildings. There are some trees and other greenery on both sides of the roadway. The roadway is intermittently bordered by concrete curbs, but mostly has an asphalt shoulder. There are no sidewalks. The speed limit is 65 mph.

MC1 was a 2003 Honda CRB 600 F4i (599 cc) sport/race replica type motorcycle that was owned by the 30 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a FMVSS 218 rated motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield. The rider was also wearing an armored nylon jacket and gloves.

MC1 was southbound in the #1 lane (inside) going straight. Traffic was moderate to heavy. He was travelling at about 20-25 mph. The #2 lane (middle) was going slower. As MC1 continued, OV1 made a quick lane change without signaling into the rider?s lane and then slowed/stopped in front of MC1. The rider
 
veered left and braked hard, causing him to lose control and capsize onto the left side plane, low side forward and going into a CCW yaw. The rider was fully ejected. His FRP was within six feet of the MC and its? FRP. After capsizing, the un-manned MC was sliding on its? own, and impacted the rear of OV1 causing minor damage. The rider said that when he was ejected, he landed on his left elbow, which caused the injury to his clavicle. He said that his riding gear protected him from further injury. The rider said that there was no contact with his helmet during the crash sequence. He did not have the helmet in his possession at the time of the interview. We were unable to locate any tire marks or gouges on the roadway due to the type of road, (freeway) and the late notification. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 30 year old male (6? 00?/195 lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of dislocation/subluxation of the clavicle near his left shoulder. He was treated at a local hospital and released.
ODriverInj: The 23 year old male (5? 09?/190 lbs.) OV driver had no injuries and showed no signs of impairment.
Human: The MC rider may have been traveling slightly faster than what could be deemed safe for the prevailing traffic conditions and on the wrong side of his lane of travel lacking compensation. The OV driver had a perception failure of not seeing the M/C approaching before making a lane change in front of it. The OV1 driver made a decision error in making his lane change in front of on-coming traffic.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained moderate damage to the front end, fairing and left side, as a result of capsizing and then impacting OV1. The overall pre-crash condition of the MC appeared to be good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors contributing to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing non-life threatening injuries.
OV1: 2001 Toyota Corolla automobile (dark blue in color)
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury traffic collision. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight in March 2012 at 1614 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1900 hours. The weather report for 1553 hours showed clear skies, with WSW winds at 6.9 mph and an ambient temperature of 69.1 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface for the motorcycle (MC1) was level with a 6.7% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition that appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an at-grade intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 64 feet. The roadway is straight and runs east to west with two lanes dedicated for eastbound and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic. There are no designated left turn lanes to regulate either east or westbound traffic onto the intersecting residential street at this intersection.

This intersecting local street has an overall travel-way of 37 feet on the north side of the intersection and, 40 feet on the south side of the intersection. The intersection is controlled in all four directions by posted traffic signals.
The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted double yellow line lane markers. The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 35 mph.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 1999 Suzuki DS400 (349cc) dual purpose on-road off ?road motorcycle being operated by a 22 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was travelling at a speed of about 35 mph, eastbound in the designated #1 eastbound lane of the minor arterial surface street approaching the signal controlled intersection. The light for his direction of travel had been green during his approach.
The other vehicle (OV1) was a 2001 Toyota Corolla automobile being operated by a 69 year old female Hispanic. OV1was approaching westbound in the designated #2 lane, and the driver had initially stopped for approaching eastbound traffic while waiting to make a left turn to proceed southbound. When the driver of OV1 presumed it safe to proceed, she accelerated her vehicle and initiated a left turn movement through the intersection. The driver kept a
 
constant speed while making the left turn movement however, failed to notice the rider and motorcycle (MC1) approaching in the #1 lane.
The rider collided with the right front quarter panel and bumper area of the other vehicle (OV1) causing the motorcycle to collapse onto the left side. The rider was subsequently vaulted off the motorcycle onto the front engine hood of OV1 and eventually rolled off on to the roadway surface about 20 feet east of the area of impact.

The motorcycle slid to a stop at its final resting place about 17 feet away from the initial area of impact. The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained no injuries.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj:
The 22 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were
that of numerous abrasions and contusions to the upper & lower extremities. The rider was treated and released at a local hospital. The rider was wearing an full face DOT approved motorcycle style helmet.
Human:
The 22 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of the other vehicle (OV1) to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver.
The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) made an unsafe decision to turn having failed to perceive or, comprehend the presence of approaching traffic while making her left turn movement.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor left side damage as a result of impacting with the right front portion of other vehicle (OV1). The other vehicle (OV1) sustained moderate right front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. SUV / Front to Side Impact.
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in March 2012 at 1826 hours in Southern California. The sun was setting and the weather was partly cloudy, the temperature was 59 degrees F and the winds were 10.4 mph, WNW with sunset at 1859. The asphalt roadway surface was dry at the time and was noted to be travel worn.

The crash occurred at a T type intersection, on a moderately traveled east/west local street that consists of one travel lane in each direction, with a connecting north/south street intersection from the south. The roadway is bordered on the south side by a 7? wide bike lane, 8? raised curbing and sidewalks, the north side is bordered by a 15? wide shoulder and 8? raised curbing. The eastbound asphalt roadway surface has a 1.3% downhill grade with a 1.3% uphill westbound grade. The east/west crown is 2.5%. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

Vehicle 1 (MC-1), is a 1959 Harley Davidson FLH (1200cc) Cruiser motorcycle that was being operated by a 53 year old Caucasian male (74 in., 220 lbs.) who was wearing a Bieffe half style helmet manufactured in October 1992. The rider of MC-1 was proceeding eastbound at approximately 45 mph, with a 10 year old Caucasian female who was wearing a Bell adult large size Drifter helmet, sitting on the fender, directly behind him. There were no foot pegs for the female passenger.

Vehicle 2 (OV-1), was a 2007 Chevrolet Equinox was being operated by a 65 year old Caucasian male (78 in., 210 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraint. The driver of OV-1 was proceeding westbound at approximately 7 mph, turning left at the T
intersection. OV-1 crossed into the eastbound lane and was struck by MC-1 in front of the right front wheel. The rear of MC-1 pivoted left coming to rest on top of the rider, the MC-1 passenger was launched approximately 30 ft. NE, landing on her back on the westbound outside lane line. OV-1 came to rest approximately 15 ft. SW, from the point of impact.
RiderInj:
The 53 year old male operator of MC-1sustained the following injuries: Bleeding on the brain, pelvic fracture, right arm fracture 
 and right leg fracture. The 10 year old female passenger of MC-1 sustained a fractured left wrist. The driver of OV-1 was uninjured. Blood was drawn from the driver of OV-1and the rider of MC-1for BAC testing. Neither party was under the influence of drugs or alcohol.
Human: OV-1?s failure to see MC-1 and not yielding the right of way, was determined to be a contributing factor of this crash.
Vehicle: MC-1 has a rider controlled headlight; there is no evidence of the headlight being switched on. OV-1 was determined to be free of defects.
Environmental: The inclination of the setting sun and dark background behind MC-1 were contributing factors of this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (M/C-1) lay down event (right side plane, high side forward) involving a Non-Contact Other Vehicle (NC-OV). The crash resulted in minor injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a motorcycle (MC1) lay down event in which MC1 over braked and capsized onto its right side plane, high side forward. The crash occurred on a major arterial in Southern California in February 2012 at 1020 hours. It was daylight and the weather was cloudy/partly cloudy. There was no wind. The approximate temperature was 65.5 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition.

The crash occurred mid-block on a roadway that is configured in a north/south direction and has eight through lanes of travel (four in each direction). There are raised curbs on both sides of the roadway and sidewalks. There is an 8? raised concrete center divider that is 8? wide. On the riders right side there are trees, grass and a commercial center. On the riders left is a mobile home park with a block wall and then a commercial center with some roadside greenery. The roadway is 118? wide. The speed limit is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 1991 Yamaha XJ 600 (599cc) sport/race replica type motorcycle that was owned by the 45 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was wearing a FMVSS 218 and Snell M2005 rated motorcycle helmet with a gray/smoke face shield. The rider was also wearing an armored nylon jacket and gloves.

MC1 was southbound legally lane splitting stopped traffic in the #3 and #4 (outside curb lane) lanes. He was going between 8-10 mph and weaving between the vehicles. NC-OV was in the #3 lane and attempted to make a lane change to the right into the #4 (outside) lane. There was a gap between a bus and a truck. The NC-OV could only partially complete the lane change because traffic was not moving at the time. NC-OV was now stopped blocking MC1?s path. The rider veered to the right and braked hard to avoid hitting NC-OV as well as the stopped bus that he was now headed for. The rider over applied his front brake, locking the wheel and causing the motorcycle forks to turn to the right lock and go down on its? right side plane. MC1 landed on the rider causing injuries to his
 
lower extremities. He said that his upper riding gear protected him from additional injury. We were unable to locate any tire marks or gouges on the roadway due to the late notification. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 45 year old Asian male (5? 10?/195 lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained moderate injuries consisting of a distal fracture to his right fibula, ruptured ligaments to his right ankle, a sprain to his right knee, and torn ligaments to his left hand/wrist area. He was treated at a local hospital and released.
ODriverInj: The 23 year old male Asian (5? 09?/130 lbs.) OV driver had no injuries and showed no signs of impairment. The NC-OV driver never responded to calls or letters.
Human: MC1 rider was legally splitting lanes which is inherently dangerous. He made the only evasive actions that he could; however, they were not properly executed (braking). The OV driver had a perception failure of not seeing the MC approaching before making a lane change in front of it.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor damage to the right side, as a result of capsizing and impacting the paved roadway surface. The overall pre- crash condition of MC1 appeared to be fair. The OV was not impacted by MC1.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors contributing to this crash.

CrashType: Sedan turning left vs. Motorcycle.
MV1: 2008 Kawasaki Ninja ZX-1400C, 1352 cc, sport/race replica motorcycle.
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in March 2012 at 1504 hours in Southern California. It was light and the weather was clear, the temperature was 69 degrees F and the winds were light. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and was noted to be travel worn.

The crash occurred on a busy North/South, multiple lane street, which consists of two lanes in each direction, with dedicated left turn lanes, that are permissive controlled only signals. The roadway is located in a residential district, bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The roadway is straight and level at area of the crash. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

Vehicle 1 (MC1), is a 2008 Black, Kawasaki Ninja ZX-1400C, 1352 cc, sport/race replica style motorcycle, ridden by a 50 year old Black male
who is, 6ft. 4in. And 230 lbs. The rider was wearing a full face motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield. Vehicle 2 (OV1), is a 1986 gray Toyota Corolla, driven by a 61 year old White male who is, 6ft. And 180 lbs. The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.
The rider of MC1 was northbound, at approximately 55 mph., in lane #1 approaching the intersection with a green traffic signal. The rider of MC1 saw OV1 stop in his travel path and applied his brakes, causing a rear wheel locked skid of approximately 40ft., he started to lose control, let off then reapplied the brakes.
The rider lost control of MC1, causing the motorcycle to high-side onto its right side, sliding nose first approximately 201ft. North into the southbound left turn lane. The rider slid into the right rear fender of OV1, coming to rest approximately 16ft. North of OV1. OV1 was southbound making a left turn at the intersection, when he had to stop in the intersection because of a vehicle northbound turning right, in his travel path. He stated that he didn?t see MC1 but felt an impact to the right rear fender of his vehicle.
RiderInj:
Rider Injuries and Impairment: The 50 year-old black male rider of MC1sustained the following injuries, as related by medical records and rider. Bilateral pneumothorax, bilateral pneumomediastinum, bilateral pulmonary lacerations & hematoma, left adrenal hematoma, left 5-10 rib fractures, bilateral
scapula fractures, left 2-5 lumbar TP fractures, multiple ligament tears of the left knee, contusions to the left upper arm, abrasions to the right lower back and left buttocks.
ODriverInj: The operator of OV1 was not injured.
Human: The 61 year-old male driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1. The 50 year-old rider of MC1 was riding at an excessive speed in a school zone and failed to take proper evasive action to avoid the accident. These contributed to the cause and outcome of this crash.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: The permissive only traffic signal contributed to the crash causation.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle lay-down event. There was no passenger.
Crash:
This is a NC, M/C initiated lay-down event in which the M/C went down in a low-side slide on its? left side plane that occurred in Southern California in March 2012 during hours of darkness at 2105 hours. The weather was clear and the wind was calm. The approximate temperature was 66.9 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The area was illuminated by overhead street lights
that were on.

The crash occurred just east of a four way type intersection on a multi-lane road, (three lanes each direction with a diminishing fourth lane) that had dedicated left and right turn lanes in both directions and a raised center median. The roadway is an East/West designation, however runs in a north-east, south-west configuration. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. The cross street is a four lane roadway, (two in each direction with dedicated left turn lanes). All directions are controlled by multi-phase signal devices that were working properly. The left turn lanes are protected only. The surrounding area is comprised
of single family residences. There is greenery on either side of the road which is bordered by concrete curbs and a 5? sidewalk. Behind the trees and shrubbery is a block sound wall. The posted speed limit is 50 mph.

Case Vehicle was a 2007 Yamaha XVS 1100 cruising type motorcycle that was being operated by a 30 year old Caucasian male, (6?02?, 200 lbs.). The rider was wearing full-faced helmet with integral chin bar and a tinted face shield. The helmet met FMVSS-218 and Snell M qualifications.

The MC rider of Case Vehicle was travelling eastbound in the #1 (outside) curb lane at approximately 50 mph. The rider said that he saw OV1 entering the intersection from his right front without stopping for its red light as he approached the intersection with a green light. The rider said that OV1 made a wide right turn and went out to the #4 lane of four lanes. The rider said that he made a lane departure to his left (two lanes) as well as hard braking and down
 
shifting. The rider said that he started to lose control, so he released the brakes and thought about swerving back to the right because OV1 was still going to the left. The rider however, never changed directions, re-applied the brakes, and ultimately lost control when the rear tire slid out from under him in a CCW
rotation. The M/C went down on its? left side plane, low side first. The Non-Contact OV1 fled the scene. The rider said that he left about ten feet of locked rear tire skid before losing control and going down. If there were any tire marks left by the M/C, they were not visible when we were at the scene (late notification). We did find about four feet of marks/scrapes that we can attribute to the M/C. The rider said that the M/C slid about 25 feet before coming to rest. There was no visible evidence of this. The rider said that he was fully ejected and ended up about ten feet away from his M/C and closer to the AOI. He stated that both
he and the M/C came to rest on the lane line dividing the #3 and #4 lanes. The M/C sustained minor damage to the left side. There was no reduction in wheelbase. Many of the entries on the Helmet Testing Evaluation Form are coded as unknown, (per the manual where the helmet is the source of information) with notations below indicating what they would be otherwise per the rider. This is because the rider never provided the helmet to us for evaluation.
RiderInj: The 30 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of a fractured right thumb, bilateral contusions to his knees, and a skin contusion to his posterior hip area. He went to a medical facility on his own and was treated and released. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The NC-OV driver was not injured and fled the scene. Impairment is unknown.
Human: The 30 year old male Caucasian rider of Case Vehicle did not appear to be distracted by any obvious sources. He should have been in a lane further to his left since he was not ready to make a right turn. His initial avoidance decision was correct. His application was poorly executed. The driver of the NC-OV failed to stop for a red light and failed to stay to the right lane while making a right turn.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor left side damage. The pre-crash condition of the M/C showed that there was no other damage not related to this crash, but the overall condition appeared to be good.
Environmental: Lack of longer distance visibility due to a block wall and greenery are a contributing factor to crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (raised concrete median), left side to front impact crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the median surface vegetation, concrete breakaway style light pole, and the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained fatal injuries as a result of multiple impacts with the light pole, environmental objects (trees, vegetation) and the roadway surface. There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the crash and, there were no witnesses who came forward with information for law enforcement.
MV1: 2004 Harley Davidson Ultra Classic (touring style) motorcycle (1449cc).
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. multiple fixed objects left side and front impact type traffic collision resulting in fatal injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred during the hours of darkness in April 2012 at 2009 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, a WSW wind direction at 4.6 mph, and an ambient temperature of 62.1 degrees F. Sunset was at 1912 hours on this day. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 3.1% downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a straight, multiple lane surface street with an overall travel-way width of 78 feet. This is a minor east/west arterial surface street with two lanes dedicated for eastbound traffic and two lanes for westbound traffic. East of the crash site there is a designated left turn lane allowing east bound traffic access northbound onto a 43 foot wide surface street. This street allows access to a single family housing residential tract. The east and west bound lanes of this street are divided by a 6? high raised concrete median with low lying vegetation.

The width of this median varies from 4 feet wide at the location of the designated left turn lane, to 14 feet wide. There is a concrete breakaway style street light and palm trees inside the median at the crash site.
At the location of the crash site there were no traffic control devices to regulate the flow of traffic in the area other than posted 45 mph speed limit signs for both east & westbound traffic. The residential cross street east of the crash site has a posted STOP sign for southbound traffic accessing either east or west bound directions on the minor arterial surface street. Both the north and south sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs, concrete sidewalks and, a high angle environmental dirt bank with both low lying bushes and taller tree type vegetation.
The street is also designed to allow bicycle access with designated (8? wide) lanes along both the north and southbound sides. Parking on both sides of the street is prohibited.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2004 Harley Davidson Ultra Classic (Touring style) motorcycle being operated by a 44 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider
 
was wearing a novelty style non-DOT approved half shell helmet with a single snap nylon chin strap. The helmet sustained catastrophic fracturing and was reduced to pieces as illustrated in the photo series.
The rider was travelling westbound in the #2 lane of the multi-lane surface street having passed through the residential T-intersection cross street prior to the crash event. As the rider continued westbound the motorcycle came in contact with the raised concrete median divider (left side of lane #2). The motorcycle continued westbound riding up and onto the top of the median impacting with the utility pole and tumbling through the vegetation. The motorcycle continued tumbling/sliding until it collapsed back onto the surface street about 162 feet west of the first area of impact.
The rider appeared to have impacted with the utility pole causing major head and upper chest trauma. The rider was ejected and subsequently came to rest in the westbound #2 lane about 116 feet west of the first area of impact. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj:
The 44 year old male Caucasian rider of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained multiple blunt force traumatic fatal injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were predominately in the area of the head and torso with multiple internal injuries. On the attached Injury Form there were (57) entries recorded identifying injuries sustained by the rider. Of those recorded on the AIS 2008 Severity column, (2) were listed as Category 6 traumatic injuries including an Atlanto-Occipital Dislocation: Orthopedic decapitation. There was also a transverse separation of the brain stem. There were (6) Category 5 traumatic
injuries. The Coroner?s report also indicated that there was the presence of alcohol (.24 BAC) in his system. There was no apparent presence of medications or drugs.
Human:
The 44 year old male Caucasian rider of the motorcycle (MC1) was driving at a high rate of speed that was unsafe and, with a blood/alcohol concentration of
.24 BAC.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained total damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. During the inspection of this motorcycle the engine was started and ran satisfactorily.
There were no other vehicles involved.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Scooter vs. Asphalt roadway surface.
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred in March 2012 at 2228 hours in Southern California. It was night and the roadway was lighted by overhead luminaries (street lights). The temperature was 57 degrees F and it was partly cloudy with no precipitation and the winds were southwest at approximately 3.4 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry with ruts, spalling, surface cracking, potholes, bitumen repair and overbanding/tar snakes.

The crash occurred on an East/West four-lane principal city street with a 14? double yellow line painted divider, in a commercial/business area. The street has two (2) through travel lanes and a dedicated left turn median in both directions. There is a westbound uphill grade of 1.8 % with a 0.7 % crown. There are no traffic controls at this area and the posted speed limit is 45 mph.
Vehicle 1 (MC-1) a 2010 Puma, 149.6cc, Rocky 150 Scooter, was being operated by a 39 year old Hispanic male (6 ft. 1 in., 225 lbs.) who was wearing a full face flip-up helmet with a clear face shield at the time of the crash. The rider was proceeding westbound along the right hand painted line in lane 2, at an estimated speed of approximately 47 mph. Due to the darkness and poor overhead lighting, the rider was unable to see a surface crack/rut in front of him. The rider stated that the scooter started shaking up and down violently and before he could consider his options, he saw the front wheel/fender disappear under the scooter. MC-1 laid-down on its left side then slid approximately 91? to its Point of Rest (POR), adjacent to the right side painted line of lane 1. The rider was ejected from MC-1 and tumbled/slid approximately 41? to his POR on the left double yellow painted line on the left of lane 1. The rider was subsequently transported to a local hospital where he was treated for his injuries and released.
RiderInj: The 39 year old male rider of the scooter sustained minor abrasions to his: Left shoulder, left knee, left posterior 3rd and 4th fingers and bilateral anterior hands; minor contusions and strains to his: neck, left shoulder and left hand;  and a minor puncture to his left posterior elbow. The rider was not under the influence of alcohol or drugs at the time of the crash.
Human: The rider was operating MC-1 at speed that was prudent.
Vehicle: The failure of the steering stem between the lower steering head bearing and the top of the triple tree is a major factor that contributed to the crash causation.
Environmental: The poor condition of the roadway surface (ruts, spalling, surface cracking, potholes, temporary bitumen repair and overbanding/tar snakes) is a major factor that contributed to the crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (M/C-1) vs. Other Vehicle (OV) front-left to right rear side impact with a secondary lay-down event resulting in minor injuries to the rider. There was no passenger with the rider of the motorcycle.
Crash:
This is a motorcycle (M/C-1) frontal impact into the right rear side of the OV, followed by a lay-down event that occurred in Southern California on April 2012 at 1520 hours. The weather was overcast with a moderate wind from the SSW. The approximate temperature was 61 degrees F. The roadway was constructed of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, with some minor latitudinal and longitudinal cracking, but in otherwise good condition.

The crash occurred mid-block between two three-way intersections, one of which is signal controlled. The uncontrolled intersection is a freeway on/off ramp. The roadway is configured in a north/south direction. The roadway has two lanes in each direction with a two way left turn center lane. There is no on street parking. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial businesses on either side of the roadway. There are trees and other greenery on both sides of the roadway. The roadway is bordered by concrete curbs and sidewalks. The roadway is a freeway frontage road and the speed limit is 35 mph.

M/C-1 was 2001 Harley Davidson Soft-tail Springer (1449 cc) cruiser style motorcycle that was owned by the 54 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was wearing a FMVSS 218 rated half police style motorcycle helmet with non-prescription sunglasses. Other than a helmet, the rider was wearing a leather jacket, motorcycle style gloves, and over the ankle motorcycle style heavy boots.

M/C-1 was in the southbound #1 (curb) lane at a constant speed of about 35 mph. The OV was going in the same direction in the #2 (inside) lane and was about 90 feet ahead of the M/C. The OV driver was unfamiliar with the area and wanted to pull into a gas station. She thought she was in the right lane and started to make a right turn into a driveway. She then realized that the driveway was an exit only driveway and that there were two-vehicles attempting to exit. She then started to proceed further down the road when she felt an impact and thought that one of the exiting vehicles had hit her. The motorcyclist was riding to
 
the left side of his lane when the OV turned in front of him. He swerved to his right and applied his brakes, locking his rear wheel. The M/C went into a slight CW yaw, and then impacted the OV on its? left rear side near the rear tire with the left front side of the front wheel. The M/C went down on its? right side plane and came to rest within six feet of the AOI. The rider was fully ejected and vaulted above ride height and flew over the rear of the OV landing in the street and sustaining minor injuries. The riders? FRP is estimated to be about 20? from the AOI based on the interview statements. The M/C left approximately 45? of rear wheel locked skid prior to impact. There was a reduction of wheelbase of approximately 1.4?. The OV driver was from out of state and did not respond to letters or telephone calls.
RiderInj: The 54 year old Caucasian male (5? 11?, 190 lbs.) operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of a dislocated clavicle and contusions to his upper back. He was treated at the scene and then went on his own to a medical facility where he was treated and released. There were no signs of impairment.
ODriverInj: The 36 year old female (5? 09?, 254 lbs.) OV driver was not injured and showed no signs of impairment.
Human: The OV driver had a perception failure and was possibly somewhat distracted by not being familiar with the area. The OV driver made a decision error by making a right turn from the wrong lane. The M/C rider had a reaction failure by poor application of crash avoidance maneuvers which included excessive rear braking and turning right instead of left.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor visible damage to the front end, fairing, and right side, as a result of impacting the OV and the ground. We were told that the M/C had frame damage was being ?totaled? by the insurance company. There was one minor pre-existing piece of damage which was chipped paint on the rear fender lip. The overall pre-crash condition of the M/C appeared to be good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. ground (asphalt surface)
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred in March 2012 at 1820 hours (dusk) in Southern California. The temperature was 60 degrees F and it was partly cloudy with no precipitation. The winds were 11.5 mph out of the southwest and the asphalt roadway surface was dry travel worn.

The crash occurred on an East/West six-lane principal city street with a 4? raised divider, planted with trees and shrubs, in a commercial/business area. The street has three (3) through travel lanes and a two (2) left turn lanes and one (1) right turn lane in both directions. The grade is 0.3 % with a 3.1 % crown. Traffic is controlled by upright and overhanging traffic signals and the posted speed limit is 45 mph.

Vehicle 1 (MC-1) is a 2011 Kawasaki, 599 cc, ZX-6R Ninja, with 3000 miles on the odometer, was being operated by a 22 year old white male (5 ft. 8 in., 170 lbs.) who was wearing a full face helmet with a reflective face shield at the time of the crash. The rider was proceeding eastbound with another rider in lane 3, at an estimated speed of approximately 35 mph. The rider was observed approaching intersections and at the last moment before crossing the limit line he would apply his front brake, causing the back of the bike to pop up into the air (a stoppie). He was performing a stoppie, braked too hard, causing
the motorcycle to flip over forwards, landing on top of rider.  MC-1 Point of Impact (POI) and Final Resting Position (FRP) coincide; approximately 35? 1? north of the south curb line and 42? 11? west of the west curb line. MC-1 was moved onto South sidewalk prior to Orange County Sheriff?s department arrival. The rider was subsequently transported to a local hospital where he was treated for his injuries and released.
RiderInj:
The 22 year old male rider of the motorcycle sustained a comminuted olecranon fracture of the left ulna, a left shoulder
fracture Not further specified (NFS) and a fracture of the left clavicle NFS; minor abrasions to his left knee; and a minor contusion of the left. The rider was not under the influence of alcohol or drugs at the time of the crash.
Human: The rider was operating MC-1 at speed that was prudent, but was taking risks and performing unsafe acts (stoppie).
Vehicle: There were no pre-existing vehicle condition that contributed to the accident.
Environmental: There were contributing environmental factors.

CrashType: This is an out of control motorcycle lay-down event. There was no passenger.
Crash:
This is a single MC ran wide off road event fully ejecting the rider after which the MC continued its forward vertical movement striking other objects on the roadside before landing on its left side plane and stopping at its FRP. The crash occurred in Southern California in April 2012 during hours of darkness at 2336 hours. The weather was clear and the wind was calm. The approximate temperature was 53 degrees F. The roadway surface was asphalt material that was dry, fairly new and in good condition. The area was illuminated by overhead street lights that were on.

The crash occurred mid-block in a high density, single family residential gated community in which the roadway is curved. The roadways are two-way with no markings. On-street parking is allowed on one side of the street (riders? right) that has a four foot wide sidewalk, some greenery and a block wall. The other side has short sections of red curbing between driveways which are very close together and no sidewalk. There are small patches of greenery/trees. The roadway is an East/West designation, however runs in a north-east, south-west configuration. There is no posted speed limit; however the prima fascia speed limit of 25 mph would apply.
