Case Vehicle was a 2012 Yamaha FZ 6R 600 sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 20 year old Caucasian male, (5? 11?/185 lbs.). The rider was wearing full-faced helmet with integral chin bar with a clear face shield and a motorcycle oriented leather jacket. The helmet met FMVSS-218 and Snell M2010 qualifications. The helmet was still on his head at the crash scene.

The rider of the MC had just purchased the MC earlier in the day. He had gone to a friend?s house to show it off. The MC rider was facing east in the #1 lane and was stopped talking with friends. He then rapidly accelerated, raising the front tire off the ground and lost control. The tire marks indicate that the bike was making a wide turn to the right. He crossed the non-marked centerline and rode into a curb, striking it with the left front of the front tire. The rider was
dragging at least one foot. The MC mounted the curb and continued in an easterly direction across a driveway, paralleling a car garage door. Both the MC and
 
the rider made contact with the garage door. The rider brushed against the garage door with his jacket and helmet leaving color transfer. The rider then impacted the garage door frame support head first causing fatal injuries, and was fully ejected. The rider and the bike continued in an easterly direction before coming to their FRP?s. The MC impacted a tree on its? right side while still in an upright position. The MC continued in an easterly direction and impacted a neighboring garage wall. The MC fell onto its? left side plane on top of the rider. The MC was found upright with its left side stand in the down position by emergency personnel. One of the witnesses said that he had raised the MC off of his friend. The MC sustained major damage to the front and left side. The forks, fairing, headlight assembly and left side covers were broken. The front tire was pushed back into the engine. There was a maximum reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained fatal injuries consisting of massive blunt trauma to the head causing a fracture of the vault and base of the skull along with laceration, contusion, and hemorrhage of the brain. He was pronounced deceased at the scene by paramedics. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle. The autopsy revealed no alcohol or drugs in his system.
ODriverInj: There was no OV involved.
Human: The 20 year old male Caucasian rider of the MC may have been distracted by showing off to a friend. He had purchased the MC only a few hours earlier. The rider had completed the entry-level rider safety course and had obtained his motorcycle license the same day. The rider was very inexperienced and a definite situation incompatibility was present with such a powerful MC.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major front and left side damage. The pre-crash condition of the M/C was new.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (raised concrete curb), front to right side impact crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact a concrete pedestrian sidewalk and surface vegetation. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained fatal injuries as a result of multiple impacts with the sidewalk surface area and, a fixed steel pole. The pole had an electronic traffic (digitally displayed) speed advisory panel mounted to it. The purpose of this speed advisory was to show drivers their approaching speed southbound while entering into a school zone. There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2006 Honda CRF250XL, off-road style motorcycle (250cc) Black
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. multiple fixed objects front and right side impact type traffic collision resulting in fatal injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred during daylight hours in April /2012 at 1215 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, a SW wind direction at 8.1 mph, and an ambient temperature of 69.1 degrees F. Sunset was at 1925 hours on this day. The roadway surface was found to be dry, asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 6.6 % downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a southbound right curve, multiple lane surface street with an overall travel-way width of 61 feet. This is a north/south residential street with two lanes dedicated for northbound traffic. There are two designated lanes for southbound traffic however, the outside #1 lane is set aside as a bike lane and is 11 feet wide.

The north and southbound lanes of this street are divided by a painted solid double yellow set of stripes spaced 12 feet apart. The width of this median varies from 12 feet wide to one set of double yellow lines at the location of the designated left turn lane.
South of the crash site there is a designated left turn lane allowing southbound traffic access westbound onto a 40 foot wide (T-Intersection) residential surface street. This street allows access to a single family housing residential tract. The residential cross street south of the crash site has a posted STOP sign for eastbound traffic accessing either north or southbound lanes on the multiple lane surface street.
At the location of the crash site there were no traffic control devices to regulate the flow of traffic in the area other than a posted electronic speed advisory sign. The speed limit on this street is 35 mph for both directions of travel. Both the east and west sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs and, concrete sidewalks. There is a high angle environmental dirt bank with both low lying bushes and taller tree type vegetation on the west side of the street.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2006 Honda CRF250XL (off-road style) motorcycle being operated by a 20 year old male Hispanic rider. The motorcycle was not
 
set up for street legal operation. The rider was not wearing a helmet during his operation of the motorcycle or at the time of the crash event.
The rider was travelling southbound in the #1 bike lane of the multi-lane surface street approaching the residential T-intersection cross street prior to the crash event. Reports from Law Enforcement officials indicated that the rider had apparently made one pass by the speed advisory sign to check hi speed and was in the process of a second pass when the crash occurred.

As the rider continued southbound the rider came into the curve too fast and applied rear braking. This resulted in approximately 91 feet of visible rear skid marks on the roadway surface. The rider swerved to the right toward the roadway edge with the motorcycle making contact with the raised concrete curb. The motorcycle continued a short distance on the curb face eventually jumping the curb and collapsing onto the concrete sidewalk. The motorcycle continued tumbling/sliding until it collapsed back onto the surface street about 87 feet south of the first area of impact.

The rider was ejected and subsequently came to rest adjacent to the steel sign pole about 51 feet south of the first area of impact. The rider appeared to have impacted first with the concrete sidewalk then the metal sign pole causing major head and upper chest trauma. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male Hispanic rider of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained fatal injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were predominately in the area of the head and torso with multiple internal injuries. On the attached Injury Form there were (25) entries recorded identifying injuries sustained by the rider. Of those recorded on the AIS 2005 Severity column, (1) was listed as a category 6 untreatable injury and, (1) was listed as category 4 injury. The Coroner?s report indicated there was no evidence of alcohol or drugs present.
Human: The 20 year old male Hispanic rider of the motorcycle (MC1) was driving at a high rate of speed that was unsafe for the type of motorcycle operated and the roadway. The rider was not wearing a helmet at the time of the crash which contributed to the traumatic injuries sustained.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minimal to minor right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. Damage was limited to minor scuffing of both metal and plastic components of the motorcycle.
There were no other vehicles involved.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Sedan turning left vs. Motorcycle.
MV1: 1982 Honda Goldwing Interstate 1100, 1084 cc, touring motorcycle.
Crash:
This was a three vehicle crash that involved an initial front to front impact configuration with a secondary sideslap and subsequent front to front impact between vehicle 2 (OV-1) and vehicle 3 (OV-2). The crash occurred on a April 2012 at 2023 hours in Southern California. It was dark and the weather was clear, the temperature was between 64 and 66 degrees F and the winds were light. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and noted
to be travel worn and lit by overhead streetlights.

The crash took place within the confines of a four-leg intersection. The north leg of the intersection consists of one southbound left turn only travel lane, a combination straight through or left turn travel lane and two northbound travel lanes. A raised, curbed center divider separates or delineates the north and southbound travel lanes and the posted speed limit is 40 mph. The south leg of the intersection consists of north and southbound travel lanes that are delineated by solid, double yellow (no passing) centerlines and the posted speed limit is 25 mph. The east/west roadway consists of multiple through travel lanes and designated turn lanes. There are traffic controls present and all traffic controls were functioning correctly, the north/south controls are permissive controlled only signals. The intersection is located in a commercial/residential area, bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The north/south roadway is straight and has a 3.2% northbound uphill grade.

Vehicle 1 (MC-1), is an orange colored, 1982 Honda Goldwing Interstate, 1084 cc, touring motorcycle,  ridden by a 58 year old male who is, 5 ft. 11 in. and 228 lbs. The rider was wearing a full-face motorcycle helmet with a grey or smoked colored face shield. Vehicle 2 (OV-1), is a blue colored, 1994 Toyota Corolla, driven by a 44 year old Hispanic male who is, 5 ft. 1 in. and 180 lbs. Vehicle 3 (OV-2), is a silver colored, 2006 Chevrolet Colorado truck, driven
by a 55 year old white male who is, 5 ft. 10 in. and 180 lbs. The drivers of OV-1 and OV-2 were reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.
 
The rider of the case motorcycle was traveling northbound, in lane No. 1 at a r4ider estimated speed of 25 mph and the overhead traffic signal was in the green signal phase. The Toyota Corolla (OV-1) was southbound and stopped in lane No. 2 (designated through traffic and left turn lane) and the driver was waiting to initiate a left turn sequence. When the overhead traffic signal changed from the green phase to the yellow phase, the driver of OV-1 initiated his left turn sequence and crossed directly in front of the case motorcycle?s path of travel. The rider of the motorcycle detected the encroaching Other Vehicle and only had time to apply a moderate braking input. The front of the Honda Goldwing impacted the front, right bumper region and corner of the Toyota Corolla (OV-1) in a front-to-front, obtuse angle impact configuration. The initial frontal impact resulted in a dual, frontal air bag deployment with the 1994
Toyota Corolla (OV-1). The rider was ejected and launched over the front hood region of OV-1 and landed an unknown distance north of the original, first POI. The case motorcycle initiated a rapid clockwise rotation and the left corner of the rear luggage/cargo carrier rack impacted the right rear door panel of OV-1.
The motorcycle fell onto its left side plane and came to rest.
RiderInj: The 58 year-old male rider of MC-1sustained the following injuries, as related by medical records: Ruptured spleen, small pneumothorax, small hemothorax, left side rib fractures (ribs 6-10), left femur bruise, bilateral leg abrasions and a swollen left ankle with deformation. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 19.
ODriverInj:
The 44 year old Hispanic male driver of OV-1, refused medical treatment but sustained the following injuries, likely due to his engagement with the deploying drivers frontal air bag. Small laceration adjacent to left side of the left eye, ruptured blood vessel in the left eye and a bruise to the left bicep. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 2.

The driver of OV-2 was not injured and there was no drug or alcohol involvement.
Human: The 44 year-old male driver of OV-1 failed to yield the right of way to MC-1.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: The permissive only traffic signal contributed to the crash causation.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle (MC1) vs. motorcycle (OV1) left front to right side impact, with a secondary lay-down event. MC1 had a passenger.
Crash:
This is a M/C (MC1) vs. M/C (OV1) left frontal to right side impact with a secondary lay-down event for both M/C?s. Both riders and one passenger were fully ejected and sustained minor to moderate injuries. The FRP for both MCs is at the AOI. The riders/passenger landed within six feet of the AIO. Both M/C?s landed on their left side plane facing in a westerly direction. The crash occurred in Southern California in April 2012 during hours of daylight at 1254 hours.
The weather was overcast with a moderate wind from the south. The approximate temperature was 62.6 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, fairly new, and in good condition.

The crash occurred at a four leg, not skewed, signal controlled intersection. The intersecting roadways are straight. The primary roadway is in a north/south configuration and has six through lanes (three in each direction) with a dedicated protected only left turn lane in both directions, and a curb high raised center median. The cross street has two lanes in each direction with a dedicated permissive left turn lane and no raised divider. The surrounding area is comprised of single family residences. There are sidewalks and block walls with greenery on either side of the roadway. There is no on-street parking. The posted speed limit is 50 mph.

Case Vehicle was a 2006 Yamaha YZF R6 600 sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 24 year old male, (5? 07?/175 lbs.) with a 27 year old female passenger, (5? 05?/120 lbs.). Both were wearing full-faced helmets with integral chin bar and face shields. The rider?s helmet met FMVSS-218 and Snell M2005 qualifications and had a dark smoke colored face shield. The passengers helmet met FMVSS-218 and Snell M2000 qualifications and had a clear face shield.

MC1 was southbound in the #3 (outside) lane of three lanes. He was part of approximately 30 MC?s that were riding together. MC1 was towards the front of the
 
group. The group was riding in a staggered formation. The rider of the MC1 was to the right side of his lane. As they approached the intersection, the signal began to phase from green to yellow. OV1 was ahead of MC1 and accelerated to try and beat the signal. The rider of MC1 did the same thing when suddenly OV1 braked and turned right coming to a stop in the intersection, just beyond the crosswalk, blocking their lane. The rider of MC1 braked and veered to the right in an unsuccessful attempt to avoid colliding with OV1. MC1 impacted OV1 with the left front and side to the right side of OV1. The left hand grip broke off and the left side was damaged including the gas tank. Both MC?s fell over onto to their left side planes. The rider of MC1 broke his left ulna and radius bones at impact. He stated that he remembered jumping off his MC before the bike fell over. He stated that he landed to the left side (south of) of OV1, along with his passenger and the other rider. The rider said that when he landed in the street, he landed on his left elbow which caused an acromioclavical dislocation to his
left shoulder area. The rider said that when he braked, he thought that he may have left about 7? of rear wheel locked skid prior to impact. No skids or gouges were visible at the scene during inspection. The rider had aftermarket heavy duty crash bars on his MC because he also does stunts with the bike. There was
some pre-existing damage to MC1 which had been painted over, mostly to the top of the gas tank. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 24 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of a distal fracture of the left ulna and radius; an acromioclavical dislocation, and several abrasions. He was treated at the scene, and then transported to a hospital where he was admitted. The passenger was taken to a hospital where she was treated and released for her minor injuries consisting of abrasions and contusions. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The 24 year old male rider of MC1 may have been distracted by trying to keep up with OV1 even though there were several riders in the group behind him. The rider is experienced, but made a poor decision to attempt to keep up with the rider on OV1. The rider of OV1 had a decision failure to try and make the signal, then another one in his attempt to stop, causing the accident.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor damage to the left side. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle (MC) vs. Other Vehicle (OV-1) left front to right rear impact with a secondary impact to a curb, then a lay-down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC vs. Other Vehicle rear-end event followed by a secondary impact with a curb, followed by an out of control lay-down event. The rider was fully ejected and sustained moderate injuries. The initial impact occurred in the street. The MC then impacted and mounted the curb, sliding on its? right side to its? FRP, located on the sidewalk. The MC was facing in a northwesterly orientation at its? FRP. The rider landed at an unknown location not far from the MC, but greater than six feet. The crash occurred in Southern California in May 2012 during hours of daylight at 1812 hours. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the southwest. The approximate temperature was 73 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition.

The crash occurred mid-block between signal controlled intersections in a commercial/retail area. The roadway is a principle arterial that is in a north/south configuration and has four through lanes with a curb high raised center divider that has greenery and trees. There are sidewalks and greenery on either side of the roadway. There is no on-street parking. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

The Case Vehicle was a 2006 Honda CBR600 sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 26 year old Hispanic male, (5? 06?, 205 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face helmet with a clear visor. The helmet also has a built in darker visor that is adjustable and slides within the helmet shell. The helmet also has an articulated chin bar. The helmet rating standards are unknown. It was not made available to us for inspection.

The case MC was northbound legally splitting lanes (between the #1 and #2 lanes), but at a speed that could be considered unsafe. Traffic was very heavy and moving slowly due to the red signal ahead. He was moving in a straight line between vehicles splitting the lanes at about 15-20 mph. when OV-1 made a lane
 
change to the right and blocked his path. MC impacted the right rear of OV-1 and then veered to the right, impacting the curb. The rider lost control and was ejected. The MC then continued its? forward progress sliding on its? right side approximately 45? north of the impact with the curb (2nd harmful event). The MC was sliding high side forward and slightly rotating in a CCW manner on the 8? wide sidewalk before coming to its? FRP. The motorcycle appears that it was in a northwesterly orientation at its? FRP, based on the evidence of the scrapes on the sidewalk and the motorcycle. The rider landed on the sidewalk at an unknown location between the crash event #2 and the motorcycles FRP. The motorcycle sustained damage to the left front from impacting OV-1 (1st harmful event). The MC sustained additional deformation to the right side of the front rim from impact with the curb(2nd harmful event) and subsequent damage to the right side due to sliding on its? right side plane(3rd harmful event). The rider of MC sustained moderate injuries. There was no evidence of any skid from the MC on the roadway or the tires. There was pre-existing damage to MC, mostly on the left side, that had been poorly repaired with some type of tape. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 26 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a compound distal fracture of his right tibia and a fracture to his right ankle (NOS). He was treated at the scene, and then transported to a hospital where he underwent surgery and was admitted for three days. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV-1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The 26 year old male Hispanic rider of Case Vehicle was lane splitting at a speed that was unsafe for prevailing traffic conditions. Even though lane splitting is legal, it is inherently dangerous. The driver of OV-1 had a perception failure of not seeing MC before making the lane change. The driver of OV-1 did not participate, so it is unknown if there were any other human factors that may have contributed to the crash.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained moderate damage to the both sides. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was fair with visible repaired pre- existing damage to the left side. The tires showed a buildup of worn rubber on the outer edges, indicating hard riding with high speed turns at a low lean angle. We were unable to inspect OV-1.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV2) multiple impact, rear-end type injury traffic collision, with a secondary lay-down event. The motorcycle rider sustained non-life threatening injuries and was treated and released at a local hospital emergency room.
MV1: 2006 Big Dog K-9 (chopper style) motorcycle, 1917cc (red in color)
Crash:
This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV2) minor injury traffic collision occurring during the daylight hours in May 2012 at 0726 hours in Southern California. The weather report for this region showed haze with no measurable wind and an ambient temperature of 64.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface was level, of asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
The crash occurred mid-block on a straight multiple lane at-grade arterial surface street, 212 feet south of a four leg signal controlled intersection. There are three lanes dedicated for northbound traffic as well as three lanes for southbound traffic. There is a dedicated left turn lane on the northbound side of the street for traffic approaching the aforementioned intersection.

The opposing lanes are separated by a 4 foot wide raised concrete median. There are no designated bike lanes and, the overall travel-way width of this street is 84 feet. The west side of the street is occupied by a public school and park. The east side of the street is occupied by residential single family homes.

There is a posted speed limit of 40 mph for both north and southbound traffic. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2006 Big Dog K-9 model (chopper style) motorcycle being operated by a 56 year old male Hispanic rider. The rider had been travelling southbound in the designated #3 lane of the multi-lane surface street and had just stopped for traffic in front of him. The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) was also travelling southbound in the #3 lane at a speed of 35-40 mph approaching (MC1) from behind.
 
The other driver (MVD1) said she was travelling behind the motorcycle (MC1) at about one car length and both their speeds were consistent. The other driver said she decided to change lanes to the right (#3 lane to #2 lane) turning her attention toward the #2 lane to check for any vehicles. The driver said when she turned her attention back to traffic in front of her she suddenly realized the traffic in her lane had come to a complete stop. The other driver said she had no time to react and subsequently struck the rear of the motorcycle (MC1). The motorcycle rider said he checked his side view mirrors and saw that the other vehicle (OV1) approach from behind and strike the rear of his bike. When the motorcycle (MC1) was struck from behind by the other vehicle (OV1), the resulting impact pushed the motorcycle into the right rear bumper area of another vehicle (OV2) which had been stopped for traffic as well.

The motorcycle sustained damage to the rear tire and fender however the resulting front impact into the other vehicle (OV2) caused major damage to the front forks, suspension and, a significant 24 inch reduction in the wheel base. The right side of the motorcycle sustained minor damage when it collapsed onto the roadway surface. The left side of the motorcycle sustained damage as a result of OV1 riding up and onto its side during the crash event. While inspecting the scene there was a 8 foot long scrape on the roadway surface near the motorcycles final resting place (FRP) and no evidence of skid marks from either vehicle.

At the time of the collision traffic conditions were heavy with other vehicles in proximity of the crash scene. Upon further inspection of the scene, I could not locate the presence of any pre-impact or post impact skid marks from any of the vehicles involved. There were no pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 56 year old male Hispanic rider sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system. The rider was treated and released at a local hospital emergency room.
Human:
The 30 year old female Hispanic driver of the Nissan Maxima (OV1) had been traveling at a speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway. The driver by her own admission was distracted as well by her scanning of the adjacent #2 lane prior to the crash event.

The male rider of the motorcycle (MC1) was stopped in traffic at the time of the crash and subsequently did not contribute to the cause or outcome of the event.
The other vehicle (OV2) was stopped in traffic as well and did not contribute to the cause of the crash event.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor rear, minor right side and, major front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating
condition prior to the crash event.

The other vehicle (OV1) sustained major front end damage however, was in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
 
The other vehicle (OV2) sustained moderate right rear damage however, was in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle (M/C-1) vs. Other Vehicle (OV-1) left front to right front side impact with a secondary impact to a curb, then a lay-down event. M/C1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This is an M/C vs. Other Vehicle left front to right front side impact event in which the rider was fully ejected. The MC subsequently impacted the north curbing and then tumbled down an embankment, impacting a combination block wall/wrought iron fence at its? FRP. The rider was fully ejected during the first harmful event and sustained moderate injuries. The initial impact occurred within the confines of a four-leg intersection. The M/C then impacted and
mounted the north roadside curbing. The motorcycle then slid on its? left side plane and tumbled to its? FRP. At its? final rest position, the M/C was facing in a northeasterly orientation, on its? left side plane. The rider landed in the street approximately nineteen feet west and fifteen feet north of the first harmful event and was adjacent to the north curb. The crash occurred in Southern California on June 2012 during the late morning at 1130 hours. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with a moderate wind from the southwest. The approximate temperature was 66.9 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition.
 
The crash occurred just west of a four-way intersection that had posted stop signs for north/south local roadway. The surrounding area is composed of residential single family residences, churches, and commercial/retail businesses. The east/west roadway is a minor arterial east of the intersection and becomes a principle arterial at the crash site, west of the intersection. The east leg of the east/west roadway consists of two through westbound lanes and a designated left turn lane. There are three through travel lanes for the west leg of the intersection. The east/west roadway has a raised, curbed, center divider that has greenery and trees on the riders? approach to the crash scene. The north/south local side street consists of an undivided, two-lane roadway that is controlled by posted stop signs. There are sidewalks and greenery on either side of the north/south roadway. There is no on-street parking. The posted speed limit for the east/west roadway is 50 mph. and 35 mph for the north/south cross street.

The Case Vehicle was a 2007 Kawasaki ZX6R Ninja 600 sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 35 year old Caucasian male, (5? 10?; 175 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full-face helmet with integral chin bar and a clear face shield. It is rated to conform to FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell M2005 standards.

The case motorcycle was westbound in the #2 (inside) lane. Traffic was moderate and moving at posted speed limits. The Other Vehicle (2006 Toyota Prius) was northbound from the stop sign, making a left turn to go westbound. The Other Vehicle driver thought the roadway was clear when she initiated her left turn. The view of on-coming traffic, in the westbound lanes is partially obscured by the trees and greenery located in the center divider, just east of her position. As the driver of the Other Vehicle initiated her left turn into the westbound #3 (inside) lane, she continued to merge to the middle lane in preparation to continue over to the #1 (curb) lane so that she could make a right turn at the next intersection which is close proximity to the crash location.

The rider detected the OV making its left turn, so he began veering to the right, in an attempt to avoid it. As the OV kept merging to the right, so did the rider. He was unable to avoid impacting OV-1 and the first impact event occurred just west of the intersection in the #2 (middle) lane. The left front of the case motorcycle impacted the right front side of the OV. The rider was fully ejected and flew over the hood of the OV, landing in the street. The M/C continued in a northwesterly direction and impacted the curb (crash event #2), causing the M.C to tumble/cartwheel (crash event #3) over the sidewalk, and down a landscaped embankment. The case motorcycle impacted a combination block/wrought iron wall at the bottom of the embankment (crash event #4) where it came to rest on its? right side and facing easterly. The M/C proceeded approximately +72? 10? with an offset of approximately +40? 07? from the first harmful event.

According to the driver of OV-1, she stopped in the roadway at the first point of impact, and then drove her car to the side of the road. The rider of M/C-1 sustained moderate injuries. There was no evidence of any skid from the M/C on the roadway or the tires. There were some minor scratches at the curb impact (2nd harmful event). There was no reduction in wheelbase of the motorcycle.
RiderInj: : The 35 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a minor concussion w/o loss of consciousness, a strain to his right shoulder, and several abrasions and contusions. He was treated at the scene, and then transported to a hospital where he was treated and released. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: Other Vehicle Driver Injuries and/or Impairment: The driver of OV-1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The driver of OV-1 had a perception failure of not seeing M/C-1 before making the left turn and a decision failure for the subsequent lane change into the riders? path. The rider had a reaction failure. He only casually veered to the right and never applied his brakes.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major damage to the front, left side, and rear. The right side sustained very little damage. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was good. We were unable to inspect OV-1, but reportedly had minor damage to the right front side and was driven from the scene..
Environmental: The curvature of the roadway with limited sight distance which is also obscured by the foliage in the center divider, along with a high speed limit could be contributing causation factors in this case.

CrashType: Bus turning left vs. Motorcycle.
MV1: 1999 Custom Harley Davidson, 1340 cc, Chopper motorcycle.
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred In March 2012 at 1908 hours in Southern California. It was dark, lit by overhead luminaries. The weather was clear, the temperature was 57 degrees F and the winds were light, blowing in a southwesterly direction. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and was noted to be travel worn.

The crash occurred on a busy East/West, multiple lane street, which consists of two lanes in each direction, with dedicated left turn lanes, that are protected- only LT signal phasing with leading green signals. The roadway is located in a commercial/residential district, bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The roadway is straight and level at area of the crash. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

MC-1 is a 1999 black Custom Harley Davidson, 1340 cc, Chopper motorcycle, ridden by a 49 year old male who is, 6 ft. and 200 lbs. The rider was wearing a partial/ half coverage motorcycle helmet without a face shield. The rider was operating MC-1 without a valid operator?s license or insurance
and it is probable that there was drug involvement. OV-1 is a 2001 NABI 40? Transit Bus, model 415, driven by a 49 year old male who is, 5 ft. 6 in. and 185 lbs. The driver of OV-1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints. The rider of MC-1 was westbound, at approximately
18 mph, in lane #1 approaching the intersection with a red traffic signal. The rider of MC-1 took no evasive action as he rode into the path of OV-1, which was proceeding east, in the left turn lane of the east/west street, making a left turn on a green signal, at approximately 5 mph into the northbound #1 lane of the north/south street. The driver of OV-1 stopped at the point of impact (POI), which was approximately 22 ft. west of the east curb line of the north/south street and 6 ft. south of the north curb line of the east/west street. MC-1 Came to rest approximately 6 ft. north of the POI and the rider of MC-1 was ejected and came to rest approximately 24 ft. north of the POI.
RiderInj: The 49 year-old male rider of MC-1has an Injury Severity Score (ISS) of 17, from the following injuries, as related by the rider. Fractures to C1 through T1, fractured left ankle and lacerations to the anus and inner left leg.
ODriverInj: The operator of OV-1 was not injured.
Human: The 49 year-old male rider of MC-1 failed to yield the right of way to OV-1 was operating MC-1 without a valid license or insurance, with probable drug involvement. These contributed to the cause and outcome of this crash.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: The permissive only traffic signal contributed to the crash causation.

CrashType: This is a single motorcycle fall down event causing injuries to the rider. There was no passenger.
MV1: 2001 Big Dog Pro Sport cruiser style M/C (1750cc)
Crash:
This is a single M/C crash in which the M/C was attempting to avoid rear-ending another vehicle that had stopped in front of him. The M/C rider was successful in the collision avoidance and came to a complete stop, however, lost his footing and the M/C fell over on its? left side plane, landing on the riders? left leg and the raised divider causing injuries. The AOI and FRP are the same. The crash occurred in Southern California In June 2012 during daylight at 1550 hours. The weather was partly cloudy and the wind was moderate out of the SSW which was a tailwind for the rider. The approximate temperature was 66.9 degrees F. The roadway surface was of asphalt material that was dry, fairly new and in good condition.

The crash occurred in a 230? long left turn lane approximately 59? south of the intersection in a single family residential area. The roadway has four through lanes (two in each direction) and a left turn lane for the rider?s direction. There is a bike lane on the opposite side of the road. On street parking is allowed on the riders? side of the road, however, per the rider, there were no cars parked there. On the riders? right side is a large open park like area with homes just beyond. The intersection near the crash site is a T type intersection that is controlled by electronic multi-phase signal control devices. The roadway in the area where the crash occurred is straight. There are a lot of greenery/trees on either side of the road with concrete sidewalks. The roadway is a North/South designation. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. and is a minor arterial.

Case Vehicle was a 2001 Big Dog Pro Sport cruiser type motorcycle that was being operated by a 42 year old Caucasian male, (5? 11?, 230 lbs.). The rider was wearing an open face full coverage M/C helmet with a clear face shield. The helmet met FMVSS-218 qualifications.

The rider was returning home and had entered the left turn lane and came to a complete, controlled stop. He was about the fourth or fifth vehicle back in his lane. There was a large truck type vehicle in front of him. The rider could see the left turn signal, which was red. The signal phased to green and traffic in all lanes for the riders? direction of travel began to proceed forward. When the truck in front of the rider had started to move forward, so did the rider. All of a
 
sudden, the truck came to a stop. The rider could not see why the truck stopped. The rider was afraid of crashing into the truck, so he swerved to his left (correct decision because of traffic moving in lanes to his right) and braked. The rider said he locked the rear tire and skidded approximately 5? in a CCW rotation before coming to a stop. There were no visible tire marks in the roadway when we examined the scene. The rider said that he ?aimed? the M/C to an area between the truck and the raised center divider. The rider was successful in coming to a complete and controlled stop without hitting anything. He then put his left foot down to stabilize the M/C. The rider either didn?t realize how close he was to the divider or misjudged the distance. His foot landed on the outside top edge of the curb high divider and slipped down to the asphalt roadway, causing him to lose his balance. The M/C fell over onto its? left side plane, landing on the divider and the riders? left lower leg, breaking his tibia and fibula. There was minor damage to the M/C consisting of scrapes. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 42 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained injuries consisting of a fractured tibia and fibula at their distal ends; severed/torn tendons in the area of the fractures; and a contusion. He was taken to a medical facility where he was treated and released. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: There was no OV involved.
Human: The 42 year old male Caucasian rider of Case Vehicle was initially following too close and/or travelling at a speed that was slightly unsafe for conditions which include a large truck in front of him that he could not see around (mobile view obstruction).
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor left side damage consisting of small scratches. The pre-crash condition of the M/C was very good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a step through scooter w/sidecar (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury traffic collision that caused the motorcycle rider to be ejected and, impact the roadway surface causing non-life threatening injuries.
MV1: 2012 Genuine Stella scooter, 150cc with a Cozy India sidecar (green in color)
Crash:
This was a step through scooter with sidecar vs. other vehicle injury traffic collision. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight in June 2012 at 1055 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 2006 hours. The weather report for 1052 hours showed clear skies, with SW winds at 10.4 mph and, an ambient temperature of 70.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface for the motorcycle (MC1) was level with a 1.8% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? intersection of a local surface street with an overall travel-way width of 54 feet. The roadway curves to the right and runs north to south with two lanes dedicated for northbound and one lane dedicated for southbound traffic.

The number one northbound lane is designated right turn only at the intersection and the #2 lane is designated for left turn and straight through traffic.
The intersecting local street has an overall travel-way of 53 feet on both the east and westbound sides of the intersection. There are two lanes dedicated for eastbound traffic, with a designated left turn lane for east to northbound traffic at the intersection. There are three lanes designated for left turn, straight through and right turn only traffic on the east side of the intersection. On the west side of the intersection there is only one designated lane of travel. The intersection is controlled in all four directions by posted traffic signals with leading green arrows.
The opposing lanes of north and southbound traffic are separated by a 10 foot wide painted median strip bordered by painted solid double yellow lines. The east and westbound opposing lanes of traffic are separated by a single painted solid double yellow line. The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for both east/west and north/south directions of travel is 35 mph.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2012 Genuine Stella step through style scooter (150cc) with an aftermarket sidecar mounted on the right side. It was being operated by a 24 year old female Hispanic rider. The rider was travelling at a speed of about 10 mph, northbound in the designated #2 lane of the local surface street approaching the signal controlled intersection. The light for her direction of travel had phased to green during her approach.
 
The other vehicle (OV1) was a 2011 Jeep Wrangler automobile being operated by a 38 year old female Caucasian driver. OV1 was approaching the intersection eastbound, west of the intersection in the designated #2 lane. Both the MC rider and witnesses at the scene indicated that both east and westbound traffic had red lights at the time OV1 crossed into the intersection.
The driver of OV1 kept a constant speed and observed MC1 moving into the intersection from her right however she maintained a constant speed but felt an impact near the right rear quarter panel of her vehicle. The driver then pulled off to the side of the road on the east side of the intersection to return and render aid to the rider. The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained no injuries.

The MC rider attempted to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver by braking and swerving to the left of OV1 however collided with the right rear quarter panel. The resulting impact caused the rider to be ejected off the front of the scooter. The rider was subsequently vaulted off the motorcycle onto the roadway surface about 20 feet north of the area of impact.

The scooter remained on all wheels in the intersection however was moved off the roadway by one of the witnesses who remained at the scene. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 24 year old female Hispanic operator of the scooter (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were that of abrasions to both elbows and a laceration to the back of her right ankle. The rider was treated and released at a local hospital. The rider was wearing a 3/4 face DOT approved Bell style motorcycle style helmet. The rider claimed that there was scraping to the rear area of her helmet from contact with the roadway surface; the helmet was not available for inspection.
Human:
The female operator of the other vehicle (OV1) made an unsafe decision to continue into and through an intersection having failed to act on a visual traffic advisory (red light). The other driver failed to perceive the presence of approaching cross traffic while traversing the intersection.
The 24 year old female Hispanic operator of the scooter (MC1) failed to perceive the inherent dangers in entering an intersection at or during a signal phase sequence and could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of the other vehicle (OV1) to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver.
Vehicle:
The scooter and sidecar (MC1) sustained moderate front end damage as a result of impacting with the right rear portion of other vehicle (OV1). Vehicle Factor (continued):
The other vehicle (OV1) sustained minor damage to the right rear quarter panel however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. asphalt roadway
MV1: 2002 Honda CB900 F2 919 (901 CC) Sport bike, black in color
Crash:
This Single non-fatal motorcycle crash/ lay-down occurred in June 2012 at 2147 hours in Southern California. It was night and the roadway was lighted by the overhead luminaries. Traffic volume was light. The temperature was 63 degrees F and it was partly cloudy with no precipitation, the winds were light and asphalt roadway surface was dry.

The crash occurred on an undivided two-lane curving roadway of approximately 68 degrees, (direction of travel being North to West) with adjacent curbing, sidewalks and overhead lights. The area of the crash occurred in a commercial business area. The asphalt/bituminous roadway surface was travel worn. The posted speed limit is 15 mph.
Vehicle 1 (MC 1) was a black, 2002 Honda CB900 F2 919 (901 CC) Sport bike that was being ridden by a 32 year-old white male (6?, 180 lbs.) who was wearing a full face helmet with a smoke tinted face shield. The rider of MC 1 was traveling northbound, approaching the left hand curve, with a 15 mph posted limit, at approximately 52 mph. The rider stated that his ?previous experience indicated 30 mph was acceptable?, to make the turn. The rider braked hard to lower his speed to 30 mph as he started into the left curve, causing a high speed wobble with approximately 15? of rear wheel locked skid and the front wheel/handlebars to turn all the way to the right, this caused the motorcycle to lay down on the left side, ejecting the rider, who slid and impacted the north curb face. The motorcycle slid NNW, nose first into the north curb and continued to slide west along the curb, coming back up-right and mounting the
north curb, striking a 3? high 18? diameter metal vent cover painted yellow, coming to rest on the north side of the sidewalk, northwest of the vent. The rider POR was within 6? of the motorcycle POR. The rider stated that ?he was in a hurry to meet friends.?
RiderInj: The 32 year-old male rider of MC-1 has an Injury Severity Score (ISS) of 11, from the following injuries: Bilateral, superior and inferior pubic rami fractures w/sacroiliac joint widening, a zone III sacral fracture, left rib fracture, bruised genitalia and abrasions to his upper and lower extremities.
Human: The rider of the crash involved motorcycle was, pre-occupied and rushing to meet friends, failed to slow to a safe speed to negotiate the curve. The unsafe act and pre-occupation were deemed to be contributing factors in this crash.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: Motorcycle Lay-Down Event.
Crash:
This is a single motorcycle crash with minor injuries that occurred during daylight hours in June 2012 at 1115 hrs. in Southern California. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy and the approximate temperature was 70 degrees F. The roadway was made of asphalt which was dry, worn and polished, but in good condition. The wind was light and variable.

The crash occurred at a four leg, not skewed type intersection of a public street and two mall driveways with signal controls. The surrounding area is comprised mostly of commercial buildings. The public roadway runs in an east/west configuration and consists of two thru lanes in each direction with bike lanes, and dedicated left turn lanes. The driveway that the rider was exiting has a wide entrance lane, a left turn/straight lane, and a right turn only lane. The roadway has an 8? raised concrete curb on either side with concrete sidewalks and a painted divider. The public roadway has an 8? raised concrete curb/center divider that is 2? wide. The roadway is straight. The crash occurred in the middle of the intersection. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.
MC1 was a 1981 Honda CM 400cc conventional MC without modifications that was being operated by a 31 year old male (6? 02?, 180 lbs.) who was wearing a full coverage open face helmet with no shield or visor, and no other motorcycle related protective clothing.

The operator of MC1 was proceeding NB exiting the mall and crossing the public street with a green light. He said he was going about 5 mph and accelerating while in first gear. As the rider entered the intersection, another vehicle was entering the intersection from the mall from across, going in the opposite direction. The other vehicle turned on its? left turn signal which startled the rider. He said he thought that the other vehicle was going to turn left in front of him. He said he got scared and panic braked by ?grabbing? his front brake, locking the front wheel and causing him to lose control. He said he went down on his right side, causing minor injuries and minor damage to the MC. The rider said that he stayed with the MC to their FRP?s. He said that the MC hit the ground and stopped.
RiderInj: The 31 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a minor puncture/avulsion to the left chin area, and several abrasions to his extremities. He was treated at the scene and released. He later went to a friend who works in the medical field for additional treatment. There was no evidence of impairment and no tests were given.
Human: The 31 yr. old rider had only been riding for four months, has had no formal training, and was very inexperienced. He over-reacted to a potential threat and did not know how to recover before crashing.
Vehicle: The case vehicle involved was found to have low tire pressure which may have contributed to the crash. The post-crash investigation of the vehicle showed that the tires were good and the overall pre-crash mechanical condition was fair.
Environmental: The roadway consists of several surfaces and grades that could be contributory to the crash. MC1s path started with a 5% downgrade on decorative brick which transitions to a concrete drainage defile with painted stripes, to crossing a crowned roadway.

CrashType: This motorcycle crash involved a laydown event in response to an encroaching Other (Non-Contacted) Vehicle. The case motorcycle was laid-down onto it?s left side plane and impacted roadside curbing in a secondary event. The rider sustained non-life threatening injuries.
MV1: 2008 Kawasaki 249cc (sport race, replica style) motorcycle, green in color.
Crash:
This motorcycle laydown even involved an encroaching Other Vehicle that was non-contacted. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight in June 2012 at 1645 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 2008 hours. The Weather Underground report for 1553 hours showed partly cloudy skies, with WSW winds at 8.1 mph and, an ambient temperature of 72.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface for the motorcycle (MC1) presented an uphill grade of 3.7% with a 1.5% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an at-grade intersection of a local surface street with an overall travel-way width of 62 feet. The north/south running roadway has a right curve facing southbound traffic on approach to the intersection. There are two lanes dedicated for southbound and three lanes dedicated for northbound traffic. There is a designated left turn lane for northbound traffic approaching a signal controlled intersection north of the crash scene. There is also a dedicated southbound left turn lane at the intersection of the crash scene.
Environmental and Crash Specifics (continued):
The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted double yellow line lane markers. The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and grass & low shrub parkways. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 45 mph.
The intersecting local street has an overall travel-way of 30 feet on the west side of the intersection and, 40 feet on the east side of the intersection. The intersection is controlled in two directions by (east/west) posted stop signs. There is a public park & ride parking area west of the intersection. East of the intersection, the local street leads to a semi-rural residential area.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2008 Kawasaki Ninja (249cc) sport race replica motorcycle being operated by a 20 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was travelling at a speed of about 35 to 45 mph, southbound in the designated #2 southbound lane of the local surface street approaching the intersection. The rider would have the right-of-way at this intersection because there are no posted signal devices regulating either north or southbound lanes of traffic.
The other vehicle (OV1) was a 2008 Toyota Sienna automobile being operated by a 77 year old male Caucasian driver. OV1 was approaching the intersection eastbound and, the driver had initially stopped for the posted stop sign regulating his direction of travel. The other driver moved his vehicle partially into the
 
intersection to check traffic to his left; there was vegetation partially blocking his view. The other driver then looked to his right and proceeded into the intersection. The driver kept a constant speed however, failed to notice the rider and motorcycle (MC1) to his left, approaching in the #2 lane as his attention was drawn to the possible traffic to his right.
The rider noticed the sudden movement of OV1 moving into and across his lane of travel at a proximate distance (30-40 feet by his statement) causing him to negotiate a (left lane departure) collision avoidance maneuver. There was no contact between MC1 and OV1 during the crash event. The resulting movement of the motorcycle caused the rider to lose control and the motorcycle collapsed (low-side left) onto the roadway surface. The rider remained with the bike as
it slid through the intersection however, was ejected off when the bike hit a raised concrete curb surface near the southeast corner of the intersection. Both the bike and rider came to rest on a grassy parkway surface along the southeast area of the intersection.

The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained no injuries or damage to his vehicle.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were that of sprained right ankle. The rider was treated and released at a local hospital. The rider was wearing a full face DOT approved motorcycle style helmet including armored upper body clothing, armored gloves and motorcycle boots.
Human:
The 22 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of the other vehicle (OV1) to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver. The rider lost control of the motorcycle causing it to collapse onto the roadway surface.
The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) made an unsafe decision having failed to perceive or, comprehend the presence of approaching traffic while making her left turn movement.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor left side damage as a result of impacting with the roadway surface and raised concrete curb. The other vehicle (OV1) sustained no damage.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. asphalt roadway
MV1: 2006 Harley Davidson Heritage Softtail (1442 CC) Cruiser bike, black in color
Crash:
This single non-fatal motorcycle crash occurred in June 2012 at 1530 hours in Southern California. Traffic volume was heavy. The temperature was 71 degrees F and it was partly cloudy with no precipitation, the winds were 9.2 mph out of the SW and the asphalt roadway surface was dry.

The crash occurred in a rural area, on an undivided two-lane North/South, straight roadway, with asphalt bicycle lanes, that were being used for parking. The asphalt/bituminous roadway surface was travel worn with tar snakes. The posted speed limit is 50 mph.
MC1 was a black, 2006 Harley Davidson Heritage Softtail (1442 CC) Cruiser style bike, that was being ridden by a 60 year-old white male (5 ft. 9 in., 180 lbs.) who was wearing an open face half helmet with visor. The rider of MC1 was traveling northbound at approximately 25 mph, with parked vehicles on both sides of the road, approaching stopped traffic. The rider stated that the car ahead of him stopped abruptly and started to back up, he down shifted and braked hard. The rider lost control during braking, causing the bike to crash low side, left side down. The motorcycle slid NNW, nose first for an unknown distance, causing minor abrasions to the lower portion of the front crash bar, engine case and saddle bag. The rider and motorcycle point of rests (PORs) are unknown due to being moved prior to law enforcement arrival.
RiderInj: The 60 year-old male rider of MC1 has an Injury Severity Score (ISS) of 14, from the following injuries: left (4-11) rib fractures, left comminuted and distal clavicle fractures and a hematoma to the left chest wall.
Human: The rider of the crash involved motorcycle was distracted looking for a place to park. He over braked, losing control, which caused the laydown.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle (MC1) vs. two Other Vehicles (OV1, OV2), frontal right to left rear and frontal left to right side impacts with a lay down event to a paved roadway surface. M/C-1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC vs. two Other Vehicles in which the MC was attempting to split lanes and rear-ended OV1 at which time the rider was partially ejected. The MC then impacted OV2 on its right side and the rider was fully ejected and landed on the paved roadway. The MC continued its forward motion causing damage to OV2, and then fell to the ground sliding on its right side plane, high side first to its FRP. The roadway has three lanes in each direction with a raised center divider. In the direction of the MC, there is a fourth lane that is a freeway on-ramp lane. It is separated from the other lanes by painted solid white lines that form a gore point. The crash occurred approximately 294? east of the nearest intersection. Only OV2 was at its FRP when the police arrived. The orientation of the MC at its FRP was on its right side and facing westbound according to the police report diagram. The rider said he landed somewhere near the MC, but then got up and walked to the side of the road. The crash occurred in Southern California in June 2012 during hours of daylight at 1015 hours. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with no wind. The approximate temperature was 70 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway runs in an east/west configuration and has a slight right curve in the area of impacts. The surrounding area is a combination of residential single family residences and a golf course on both sides. The roadway is a minor arterial. The roadway has a curb high raised center divider that has greenery and trees. There are sidewalks and greenery on either side of the roadway. There is no on-street parking. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2006 Yamaha FZ6 sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 22 year old male, (5?11?/155 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face helmet with a gray/smoke colored face shield. It is rated to conform to FMVSS 218 and UN/ECE-22-05 standards.

MC1 was westbound in the #2 (middle) lane. Traffic was moderate to heavy and moving slow at the crash site. There is a signal controlled intersection west of
 
the crash site that had just phased to green and traffic was just starting to proceed forward. The driver of OV1 was slowly driving westbound in the #2 lane and not familiar with the area. He was looking for a freeway on-ramp and did not know which side of the road it was on. He was in the middle lane so that he could make a lane change to either side of the road to access the on-ramp when he found it. The on-ramp was on his right and was stacked full of cars. He was unable to make a double lane change, so he continued to go straight when the crash occurred. He was slightly ahead of but next to OV2 which was in the left lane when he was hit from behind by MC1 in the left rear corner. OV1 stopped as soon as he could and remained in his lane for several minutes before moving his vehicle to the right side of the road. After impacting OV1, MC1 veered to the left and impacted OV2 on the right side. The rider was fully ejected and landed in the left lane near the lane line. She said that she saw the rider?s helmet go flying through the air and land in the street in front of her vehicle. The rider of MC1 said that the helmet was retained in place to the completion of the crash. The driver of OV2 said she could see the rider lying in the street through her mirrors. The rider said that he stayed with the MC to its FRP. The driver of OV2 said that she stopped and remained in her lane until the authorities arrived.
She said that the MC came to rest about 20? in front of her vehicle. The driver of OV2 said that the rider had been going the speed limit, if not faster prior to the crash and was weaving in and out of traffic and lane splitting, using all lanes to pass vehicles. It appears that the MC rider was attempting to split the lane between OV1 and OV2 and misjudged the space between those vehicles and their speeds. This combined with his speed relative to other traffic and the lackof braking on the part of the rider caused him to crash.The rider of MC1 sustained moderate injuries. There was no evidence of any skid from the MC on the roadway or the tires. There were some minor scratches at AOI #2. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male operator of MC1 sustained a fractured hand, a fractured patella, several minor lacerations, and abrasions. He was treated at the scene and taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: Neither driver of the OV?s showed any signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a comprehension failure of not realizing how rapidly he was approaching slower moving vehicles, and a decision failure for not braking. He was also riding in a manner that was unsafe. The driver of OV1 was distracted and unfamiliar with the area, but had no causational factors to the crash.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained moderate to major damage to the front, and both sides, but mostly to the right side. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was good. OV1 sustained moderate damage to the left rear corner. OV2 sustained minor damage to the right side from both the rider and MC1.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors considered to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. asphalt roadway
MV1: 2009 Buell XB9SX Lightning (984 CC) Sport/race replica, black in color
Crash:
This two-vehicle (non-contact), non-fatal motorcycle crash/ lay-down occurred in June 2012 at 1903 hours in Southern California. Traffic volume was light. The temperature was 71 degrees F and it was clear with no precipitation, The winds were 9.2 mph out of the SW and the asphalt roadway surface was dry.

The crash occurred on an undivided four-lane East/West, straight roadway, with concrete curbs and sidewalks. The area of the crash occurred in a residential area. The asphalt/bituminous roadway surface was in good repair. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

Vehicle 1 (MC1) was a black, 2009 Buell XB9SX Lightning (984 CC) Sport/race replica, that was being ridden by a 29 year-old white male (5? 9?, 155 lbs.) who was wearing an full-face helmet with a smoke colored visor. MC1 was traveling westbound in the #1 lane; at approximately 45 mph. Vehicle 2 (Non-Contact), (OV1) was a gray, 2011 Honda CRV, being driven by a 49 year-old Hispanic female (5? 2?, 130 lbs.) and was traveling eastbound in the #1 lane; making a left turn into a driveway. The rider of MC1 saw OV1 making the left turn; applied heavy braking, locking up his front brake and leaving 31? of skid. This caused MC1 to low side on its right side and slide for approximately 110?, coming to rest in the #1 lane, adjacent to the right side lane line. The rider?s final
rest position (FRP) is unknown do to his moving to the north side of the road prior to law enforcement arrival. Rider has no memory of his FRP.
RiderInj: The 29 year-old male rider of MC1 has an Injury Severity Score (ISS) of 5, from the following injuries: Left clavicle and wrist fractures and right knee abrasions.
Human: The driver of OV1 was distracted by her passenger and outside pedestrian.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle (MC) vs. Other Vehicle (OV1) frontal to left side impact with a secondary lay-down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC vs. Other Vehicle frontal to left side impact event in which the rider was fully ejected, followed by a secondary laydown even. The 1st harmful event and the FRP are within six feet of each other. The rider was fully ejected during the first harmful event and sustained minor injuries. Both vehicles were at their FRP?s when the police arrived. The MC went down on its? right side after impact and was facing in a southeasterly direction. The OV was facing in a north/northwest direction. The crash occurred in Southern California July of 2012 during hours of daylight at 1245 hrs. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the west. The approximate temperature was 76 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition.

The crash occurred in the middle of a four-way, not-skewed intersection that had posted stop signs for the cross street where the OV came from. The street that the MC was riding on is in an east/west configuration and has no traffic control devices or stop signs. The cross street is in a north/south configuration and has stop signs for both directions. There are painted limit lines and the word STOP that are very faded. There are no lane lines or dividers. Both roadways are local streets. The area has a couple of residential lots, but is comprised mostly of commercial/industrial businesses. The posted speed limit is 25 mph.
There are sidewalks and some greenery on either side of the roadway.
The Case Vehicle was a 2006 Honda Shadow 750 cruiser type motorcycle that was being operated by a 31 year old male, (6? 01?; 180 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown type/style helmet with unknown ratings/standards.

The MC was eastbound in the #1 lane. Traffic was light. OV1 was northbound from the stop sign making a left turn to go westbound. The driver of the OV thought the roadway was clear when he made his left turn. When the driver of the OV noticed the MC coming towards him, he stopped, not knowing what else to do.
 
The view of on-coming traffic in the eastbound lanes is partially obscured at the limit line for NB traffic by legally parked vehicles and the trees and greenery on the corner lot on the SW corner. When the rider saw that OV1 had stopped in his pathway, he braked and locked the rear tire in an attempt to avoid
colliding with it. The MC left 56? 09? of rear tire lock skid prior to impact. The MC impacted the left side of OV1 (1st harmful event) at the forward portion of the drivers? door. The MC then rotated in a CW direction, side-slapping the OV and then fell onto its? right side plane. The gas tank was ruptured and torn. A large piece of the left side of the gas tank was removed through the crash events. The rider was fully ejected and landed on the paved roadway surface (2nd harmful event). There was no visible evidence when we examined the scene on this late report. The officer who authored the report calculated that the MC was speeding. He used a very high coefficient of friction of .75 in his slide to stop speed calculations for the MC. This calculation puts the MC at 35.7 mph per the report. I used a more modest average of .6, and the MC speed drops to 31.7 mph. The rider of M/C-1 sustained minor injuries. There was an approximate 1.5? reduction in the wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 31 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained facial and unknown extremity lacerations along with complaint of pain to his back and hip. He was treated at the scene, and then transported to a hospital where he was treated and released. If the lacerations were to lower extremities, they could have been caused by the torn gas tank. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV-1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human:
The driver of OV1 had a perception failure of not seeing the MC before making the left turn and a decision failure for the subsequent stopping in the middle of the intersection. The rider stated that if the OV had continued its? path of travel, he would have cleared the intersection and there would have been no accident. The rider was potentially exceeding the speed limit by less than 10 mph and had a reaction failure of poor avoidance maneuvers by
applying only the rear brake.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major damage to the front and left side. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was good. We were unable to inspect OV1, but it reportedly had minor damage to the left side and was driven from the scene.
Environmental: There were visual obstructions (trees, parked vehicles) that could have been contributory to the accident.

CrashType:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (raised concrete median), left side to front impact crash causing the motorcycle to cross into opposing lanes of the highway. The motorcycle departed the roadway surface and there was a secondary lay-down event with environmental objects (sandy shoulder & low lying
ice plant type vegetation). The motorcycle rider sustained non-life threatening injuries. There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2010 Harley Davidson Wide Glide (cruiser style) motorcycle (1584cc) black & yellow in color.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object left side and front impact type traffic collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred during the hours of darkness in July 2012 at 0027 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, a southerly wind direction at 4.6 mph, and an ambient temperature of 63.3 degrees F. Sunset was at 2006 hours on this day. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 1.0% downhill grade in the area of the crash site.

The collision occurred on a right curve, multiple lane roadway surface with an overall travel-way width of 76 feet. This is a major north/south arterial designated state highway with two lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and two lanes for southbound traffic. On the east side of the roadway and crash site are protected coastal wetlands. The west side of the roadway is a designated public state beach area. The east and westbound lanes of this street are divided by a 5? high raised concrete median approximately 11 feet in width with an asphalt surface.

At the location of the crash site there are no traffic control devices to regulate the flow of traffic in the area other than posted 55 mph speed limit signs for both north and southbound traffic. There are no intersecting streets on either the east or west side of the roadway in proximity of the crash site. Both the north and south sides of this street are bordered by level loose sand & low lying vegetation. There are no concrete sidewalks or curbing on either side of the roadway. On the west side of the shoulder area is a 4 foot high wood and chain link beach fence. There is no overhead illumination for either north or south bound traffic along this area of the highway.

The street is also designed to allow bicycle access with designated (7? wide) lanes along both the north and southbound sides. Parking on both sides of the street is prohibited.
 
The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2010 Harley Davidson Wide Glide (cruiser style) motorcycle being operated by a 37 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was wearing a motorcycle helmet of unknown make or model. The rider was, for the most part, uncooperative with law enforcement officials at the scene and, had claimed the crash occurred as a result of a former female acquaintance forcing him off the roadway.
However, this statement was disputed by at least two eye witness accounts of the rider driving at a high rate of speed prior to the crash and, the lack of any vehicles in proximity to the motorcycle.

The rider was travelling northbound in the #2 lane of the multi-lane surface street at a rate of speed. As the rider continued northbound the rider failed to navigate the right curve design of the roadway and subsequently impacted with the raised concrete median divider (left side of lane #2). The motorcycle continued northbound riding up and onto the top of the median surface for a distance of just over 100 feet.
The motorcycle continued in a northbound direction, leaving the raised median and continued tumbling/sliding into the opposing southbound lanes of traffic until it collapsed onto the loose sandy shoulder surface of the southbound side of the roadway approximately 563 feet north of the initial area of impact.

At some point the rider appeared to have impacted with the roadway surface based on witness accounts only. When contacted by law enforcement officials, the rider displayed objective symptoms of alcohol intoxication however, was not detained or arrested for driving under the influence. The rider was subsequently transported to a local hospital for treatment.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 37 year old male Caucasian rider of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. These injuries were limited to abrasions to both hands and trauma to the chest area. The rider also displayed objective symptoms of alcohol intoxication.
Human: The 37 year old male Caucasian rider of the motorcycle (MC1) was driving at a high rate of speed that was unsafe and had been drinking prior to the crash.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained major front end, left & right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
There were no other vehicles involved.
