Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Motorhome turning left.
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in July 2012 at 2043 hours in Southern California. It was dark, the weather was overcast, the temperature was 62.6 degrees F and the winds were 8.1 mph out of the south. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, travel worn, and lit by overhead streetlights.

The crash occurred at a busy T intersection. The east/west speed limit is 60 mph, the eastbound lanes consist of two through lanes and a right turn lane. Westbound lanes consist of a left turn lane and two through lanes. The northbound lanes consist of two left turn lanes and a right turn lane. There are traffic controls present and all traffic controls were functioning correctly. The intersection is located adjacent to a beach park to the south and wetlands to the
north, bordered by asphalt shoulders. The east/west roadway is straight with a west to east uphill grade of 0.4%. The north/south roadway is level and curves to the west.

Vehicle 1 (MC1), is a red, 2006 Kawasaki EX 650 (649 cc) sport motorcycle, ridden by a 27 year old white male who was, 5 ft. 6 in. tall and weighed 123 lbs. The rider was wearing a full face motorcycle helmet with a partially tinted face shield. Vehicle 2 (OV1), is a 1983 Fleetwood/Southwind motorhome, gold in color, driven by a 53 year old white male who was, 6 ft. 1 in. tall and weighed 210 lbs. The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available manual lap restraints.

The rider of MC1 was eastbound, at an unknown rate of speed, between the right turn lane and the # 2 lane passing stopped traffic, approaching the intersection with a red traffic signal. OV1 entered the intersection from the northbound #2 left turn lane on a green traffic signal. MC1 failed to stop for the red traffic signal, entering the intersection and struck OV1 in left rear corner and rear bumper. MC1 went down on its right side sliding nose first to its Final Rest Position (FRP) approximately 22 ft. 6in. East of the Point of Impact (POI). The rider was entangled with MC1 and his FRP was the same as MC1. The riders helmet was retained in place to completion of the accident, then it was removed by responding paramedics, who cut off the retention strap.
RiderInj: The 27 year-old male rider of MC1had a BAC of .16 and sustained a severe head injury with a loss of consciousness of 6 hours, as related by the police report.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured and there was no drug or alcohol involvement.
Human: The 27 year-old male rider of MC1, was under the influence of alcohol, and failed to yield the right of way to OV1, by failing to stop for the red traffic signal.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There were no environmental related factors.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle (Case Motorcycle/MC1) vs. motorcycle (OV1) rear-end type collision. Both MCs went down onto the roadway surface and fully ejected the riders. Neither MC had a passenger. This case will coincide with case 0112.
OV1: 2012 Lance Havana Classic step through scooter (125 cc)
Crash:
This MC vs. MC (OV1), rear-end collision occurred on a non-freeway principle arterial multi-lane roadway. The roadway has two lanes in either direction. On- street parallel metered parking is allowed on both sides of the street. There is a 6? raised center divider with palm trees spaced at approximate 40? intervals along with other greenery. The divider is 12? wide. On the riders? right side is a large public pay parking lot. On the riders? left is a large hotel/resort. There are no intersections or signal controls near the crash site. The crash occurred in July 2012 at 1429 hours in Southern California. The weather was partly cloudy with a moderate wind out of the SSW at 10.4 mph. The approximate temperature was 74.7 degrees F. The roadway surface was of asphalt composition, worn and polished, dry, and in good condition. The roadway was measured to have a +0.4% uphill grade and a +2.5% crown in the area of the crash. The roadway is designated as a north/south direction, however in the crash area, it has an east/west orientation and is straight. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

The case vehicle was a 2012 Honda CBR 250 (sport/replica style, 249 cc) ridden by a 23 year old Caucasian male (6? 04?/195 lbs.) wearing a full face helmet with integral chin bar and clear face shield rated to FMVSS 218 and Snell M2005 standards. OV1 was a 2013 Lance Havana Classic step through scooter (125 cc) ridden by a 58 year old Caucasian female (5? 08?/148 lbs.) wearing an open face helmet with a clear bubble face shield rated to FMVSS 218 standards. The rider of the Case MC was wearing a pair of gloves. No other apparel was worn by either rider.

The crash occurred in the #1 (inside) lane. The riders in this crash are related; mother and her adult son. Both were initially riding in the #2 right lane, side by side, with the OV1 to the left side of the lane. OV1 made a lane change to the inside lane. When the rider of the Case MC noticed the lane change, he followed. Both were traveling between 25-35 mph. Traffic was very heavy. The rider of OV1 had to make a quick stop after changing lanes. The rider of the Case MC was not paying attention by looking around at the scenery. When he looked forward and saw that traffic was stopped in front of him, he applied his brakes in an effort to avoid a collision. He was unable to stop in time and impacted the rear of OV1 causing it to launch forward. Both he and the rider of OV1 were fully
 
ejected from their MCs. The rider of OV1 was ejected off to the right. The rider of the MC was vaulted over the handlebars. The MC landed on its left side. The OV appears to have flip-flopped, initially landing on its left side and then rolling over onto its right side plane to its FRP. Both riders landed on the roadway surface and sustained minor to moderate injuries. There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals, or environmental conditions that contributed to the crash.
RiderInj: The 24 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained fractures to his T3 and T4 vertebrae, a hip fracture, a contusion, and a laceration. The rider was taken to a medical facility where he was treated and released. The rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj:
The rider of the OV sustained a fracture to her right humerus bone and a contusion to her right shoulder. She was taken to a medical facility where she was treated and released. She showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit the safe operation of
her vehicle.
Human: The rider of the Case Vehicle had a comprehension and reaction failure along with being distracted. He was pre-occupied and diverted is attention from the roadway. He was not paying attention to his position in traffic in relation to other vehicles on the road. This combined with his speed relative to other traffic and the lack of experience caused the crash. He had a reaction failure by applying his brakes too late. The combination of these aspects makes his driving an unsafe act likely to cause an accident. The rider of the OV had no contribution to the crash.
Vehicle: The MC sustained minor damage to the front and left side. The pre-crash condition of the MC was new. The OV sustained minor damage to the rear and both sides. The pre-crash condition was new.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors considered to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType:
This was a motorcycle vs. motorcycle (scooter) front to rear impact crash event causing the motorcycle to collapse right side down onto the roadway surface of the highway. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the scooter on to the roadway surface and rider sustained non-life threatening injuries. There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the crash.
This case will coincide with DSI case 0111.
MV1: 2013 Lance Havana Classic (step through) style scooter (125cc) black in color
OV1: 2012 Honda CBR250 (sport race replica) style motorcycle, (250cc) black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. motorcycle front to rear impact type crash event resulting in non-life threatening injuries to both motorcycle riders. The crash occurred during the hours of daylight in July 2012 at 1429 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed partly cloudy skies, winds out of the SSW @
10.4 mph, and an ambient temperature of 74.7 degrees F. Sunset was at 2003 hours on this day. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured +0.4% uphill grade and, a +2.5% crown in the area of the crash site.
The crash occurred on a straight, multi-lane, roadway, with an overall travel-way width of 86 feet. This is a major east/west arterial designated State Highway with two lanes dedicated for eastbound traffic and two lanes for westbound traffic. On the south side of the roadway and crash site, is a public parking facility.

The north side of the roadway is a commercial high rise hotel complex. The east and westbound lanes of this roadway are divided by a 6? high raised concrete median approximately 12 feet in width with palm trees spaced at 40 foot intervals.
At the location of the crash site there are no traffic control devices to regulate the flow of traffic in the area other than posted 45 mph speed limit signs for both east and westbound traffic. There are no intersecting streets on either the north or south side of the roadway in proximity of the crash site. Both the north and south sides of this street are bordered by 8 inch raised concrete curbs and sidewalks. There are overhead street lights on both the north and south bound sides of the highway.
The street is also designed to allow public (metered) parking access with designated stalls along both the north and southbound sides. Refer to the attached diagram.
 
The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2013 Lance Havana Classic (step through style) scooter being operated by a 58 year old female Caucasian rider. The rider was wearing a black HCI open face style motorcycle helmet; FMVSS218 (US DOT) approved. The helmet was retained on the riders head during the crash event and sustained no significant damage.

The rider was travelling eastbound in the #1 lane of the multi-lane surface street at 15 to 20 mph. The reduced speed was due in part to heavy traffic. As the rider continued eastbound she made a left lane change from the #1 lane to the adjacent #2 lane. Once she had negotiated this lane change she had to come to a sudden stop due to the traffic in front of her having come to a stop.

The other vehicle (OV1) a 2012 Honda CBR250 (sport race replica style) motorcycle, was being operated by a 23 year old male Caucasian who was traveling eastbound in the #1 lane to the rear and right side of MC1 at a speed of 25-35 mph. Both riders in this matter are related to each other (mother and son). The rider decided to change lanes as well, moving to the left in and behind the scooter (MC1). The rider of the other vehicle (OV1) claimed at the time he had been distracted by the local scenery and misjudged his speed and proximity to the scooter.

When the rider finally turned his attention back to the traffic in front of him, he immediately pulled in his clutch and attempted to apply both front and rear brake however, he could not stop in time and subsequently struck the rear of the scooter (MC1) causing the rider of the scooter to be ejected off the bike and onto the roadway surface. The rider of the other vehicle (OV1) was ejected over the top front of his motorcycle and onto the roadway surface as well. Both vehicles collapsed left side down onto the roadway surface.

There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 58 year old female Caucasian rider of the scooter (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were a proximal fracture of the Humerus bone of the right arm as well as a contusion to the right shoulder. The rider sustained no other soft tissue damage or internal injuries.
ODriverInj:
The 23 year male Caucasian rider of the motorcycle (OV1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were a fractured hip and fractures to both the T3 and T4 vertebrae.
Both riders were subsequently transported to a local hospital and, were treated and released.
Human:
The 58 year old female Caucasian rider of the scooter (MC1) was stopped in traffic and contributed nothing to the cause or outcome of this crash event.
 
The 23 year old male Caucasian rider of the motorcycle (OV1) was driving at a speed unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway as well as too close to the scooter in front of him. His lack of experience to these types of situations also contributed to the cause and outcome of this crash event.
Vehicle: The scooter (MC1) sustained minor rear and right side damage as a result of this crash however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. The motorcycle (OV1) sustained minor front and right side damage as a result of this crash event however, appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition. There were no other vehicles involved.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Sedan turning left
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred In July 2012 at 1606 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the weather was partly cloudy; the temperature was approximately 72 degrees F. and the winds were moderate, out of the SSW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, travel worn and the traffic was moderate.

The crash occurred on a moderately busy east/west street in a commercial area, the roadway was bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks, with three through lanes in each direction and an eastbound left turn lane. The east/west speed limit is 45 mph. There are no traffic controls present. The roadway is straight with a grade of 1.0%.
MC1, is a 2011 Triumph Bonneville T100, 865 cc, black and white in color, ridden by a 40 year old male (6 ft. and 180 lbs). The rider was wearing an open face motorcycle helmet with a clear wraparound face shield. OV1 is a 2011 Lexus CT200H, gray in color, which was driven by a 33 year old female (5 ft. 8 in. and 140 lbs). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling westbound at approximately 40 mph, in lane #2, approaching the commercial driveway on the north side of the street. OV1 was stopped at the exit of the driveway, waiting to make a left turn, heading eastbound. As MC1 approached the driveway, OV1 started crossing the westbound lanes; the
rider of MC1 applied front brake only, causing a left low side slide out. MC1 and rider struck the left front and side of OV1. The rider?s Point of Rest (POR) was approximately 6 ft. east of the Point of Impact (POI); MC1?s POR was approximately 23 ft. southwest of the POI, OV1 rolled on its wheels to its POR approximately 42 ft. northeast of POI in the # 1 lane of the eastbound lanes.
RiderInj:
The 40 year-old male rider of MC1died as a result of multiple blunt force injuries, his ISS score was 50. The following injuries were sustained: Lacerated right ventricle wall, bilateral lung contusions, laceration of the right lobe of the liver, fractured thyroid cartilage, laceration of right kidney, lacerated spleen, bilateral rib fractures, lacerations of the right adrenal gland, contusions of the diaphragm, subarachnoid brain hemorrhage,
 
fractured sternum, fractured hyoid bone, right tib/fib fractures and multiple external lacerations, abrasions and contusions

The 33 year-old female driver of OV1 sustained a laceration to the right forearm and minor abrasions and contusions from the three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints and airbags. Her ISS score was 1.

There was no alcohol involvement.
Human: The 33 year-old female driver of OV1 looked but did not see MC1 and failed to yield the right of way to MC1. The rider of MC1 failed to use proper braking techniques, by only applying front brake only.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors involved with this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) vs. Other Vehicle (OV1) frontal to front right side impact with secondary lay down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC frontal impact to the front right side of OV1 that was making a right turn from the wrong lane in front of MC1. The crash occurred on a minor arterial at a four-leg, not skewed intersection. There are four through lanes, two in each direction with dedicated left turn lanes and bicycle lanes. The intersection is controlled by electronic multi-phase signals that were working properly. The left turn lanes had a trailing green arrow when traffic activated the signal. The roadway is an east/west orientation. After impact, MC1 landed on its left side plane, front end forward and slid in a southeasterly direction to its FRP and was in an unknown orientation. The rider was fully ejected after impact and landed at an unknown location in the roadway. MC1 was eastbound in
the #2 lane. There are conflicting statements in the police report as to which lane OV1 was in. The driver and one witness said that OV1 was in the #2 lane. The rider said that OV1 was in the #1 lane. One witness was uncertain which lane OV1 was in. Based on how the accident occurred, it is very likely that OV1 was in the eastbound #1 lane. OV1 was eastbound and suddenly made a right turn to go south when the accident occurred. The driver of OV1 admitted to the police that he was distracted by his GPS system. He lives out of state and was in a rental car, indicating that he is probably not very familiar with the area. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial/retail businesses. No on-street parking is allowed. The crash took place in the #2 right lane. The crash occurred
in Southern California in July 2012 at 2119 hours. It was dark with street lights on. The weather was clear with a light variable wind. The approximate temperature was 64 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has a 1.8% upgrade at the crash site with a 3.7% crown. Both sides of the roadway have 8? concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2000 Harley Davidson Fat Boy cruising type motorcycle that was being operated by a 41 year old Caucasian male, (5?10?/200 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown ratings.

MC1 was eastbound in the #2 (right) lane at about the posted speed limit. Traffic was moderate. The rider said that OV1 was in the left lane and ahead of him, when suddenly, OV1 made a right turn in front of him without signaling. The rider said that he braked, and tried to steer right, but could not avoid colliding with OV1. The driver of OV1, a 21 year old male Caucasian (5? 10?/170 lbs.) said that he was looking at his GPS unit for directions when he realized that he needed
 
to turn right to go home. He said he was in the #2 lane. He said that when he made his right turn, he was hit on the right side. Neither vehicle left any pre- impact tire marks in the roadway. Based on the lane widths, vehicle speeds, and crash dynamics, it is unrealistic to believe that OV1 was in the same lane as MC1 making a right turn and causing the crash. When looking at where the First Harmful event (POI) is plotted by the police, it appears that OV1 was originally in the left lane and then made its right turn. The police found the driver of OV1 at fault for the crash for making an unsafe turning movement. The left side of the front forks, near the axle bolts, broke as a result of the impact with OV1, but there was no reduction in wheelbase. Both the tank and cap were fully retained on MC1. The gas tank sustained minor damage.
RiderInj: The 41 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a fractured right ankle, fractured left foot with two fractured toes (NFS), three fractured ribs on his left side, both shoulders were fractured (NFS), and a left hand fracture with two fractured fingers (NFS). This information was gathered from the rider?s wife. He was treated at the scene, and then transported to a hospital where he was hospitalized for an unknown number of days. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV-1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The 21 year old male Caucasian operator of OV1 distracted and made a decision error. The rider of MC1 was alert and not distracted.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained moderate damage to the front end and minor damage to the left side. There was minor damage at the end of the right side tail pipe. It is the only unrelated damage to the right side and may have been pre-existing. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was very good, like new. It is not equipped with ABS brakes. The OV was in very good condition prior to the crash. It sustained major damage to the right side starting at the middle of the front door and going forward to the front bumper. The right front axle was broken.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. non-fixed object (chair) spilled from another vehicle (OV1), front end impact with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider stayed with the bike in a low side left impact with the roadway surface. The rider sustained non-life threatening injuries (abrasions) to his right elbow and knee as well as his right thigh and buttocks. There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the collision.
MV1: 2008 Triumph Thruxton, (Sport race, replica type) motorcycle, 865cc, silver in color.
OV1: 2007 Toyota Tacoma (small sized) pick-up truck, white in color, transporting an unsecured chair in the utility bed.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. non-fixed object (chair) front end impact collision, resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the rider. The object was an unsecured item being transported by another vehicle (OV1). The collision occurred during the hours of daylight in July 2012 at 1038 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1055 hours showed mostly cloudy skies, winds out of the SSW at 9.2 mph and, an ambient temperature of 70.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was 10.0 miles. The roadway surface was dry, level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.

The collision occurred at an at-grade intersection of two straight multiple lane surface streets. The north/south surface street is a principal arterial with three lanes dedicated for north and three lanes dedicated for southbound traffic. There are also (leading signal) dedicated left turn lanes for north to westbound traffic and, south to eastbound traffic. There are no designated right turn lanes or bike lanes for either north or southbound traffic. The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by an 8 inch tall and ten foot wide raised concrete and brick median. The posted speed limit is 45 mph for both directions of travel.

The east/west surface street is a minor arterial with two lanes dedicated for east and two lanes for westbound traffic. There are (leading signal) designated left turn lanes for west to southbound traffic and, east to northbound traffic. There are no designated right turn lanes however, there are dedicated bike lanes for both directions of travel east and west of the intersection. The opposing lanes are separated by a painted solid double yellow line. The posted speed limit for east/west traffic is 40 mph.

Both streets are regulated by multi-phase overhead traffic signals. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site, as well as any super-elevation issues.
 
There are business and commercial complexes open to public access in all four quadrants surrounding this intersection.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2008 Triumph Thruxton (Sport race, replica type) motorcycle being operated by a 41 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider had initially been stopped for traffic in the designated left turn lane for north to westbound traffic at the intersection. The rider was waiting behind another utility truck which was not involved in the crash event.

The other vehicle (OV1) was a 2007 Toyota Tacoma standard bed pick-up truck being operated by a 17 year old male Caucasian juvenile. The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) was travelling southbound and setting up to turn right.

When the rider received a green light he moved forward into the intersection and maintained an approximate speed of 15 mph (22 fps) through the intersection. At about the same time, the other vehicle driver (OV1) initiated his right turn movement at a high rate of speed.

As the rider approached the westbound lanes of the cross street, the other vehicle (OV1) was slightly ahead of him and continuing at a high rate of speed. The rider suddenly observed a metal and plastic constructed chair spill out of the rear utility bed of OV1.

When I interviewed the rider he seemed to think the chair spilled out of OV1 and first bounced off the vehicle in front of him however it ended up directly in front of him. The rider went on to tell me the chair landed on the back upright with the seat portion facing up.
The rider said as the front of his motorcycle impacted with the chair, the front wheel became entangled and he effectively lost any ability to steer or use his front brake. The rider tried to steer and use his brake however, to no avail and simply rode it out until the motorcycle collapsed onto the roadway surface in a low side left impact. The rider stayed with the motorcycle as it slid up to and stopped near the north curb line of the westbound portion of the roadway.

There was no contact between the motorcycle (MC1) and the other vehicle (OV1); only the spilled cargo (chair) from the rear utility bed of OV1.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 41 year old male Caucasian operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were abrasions to the right elbow, knee, thigh and, buttocks. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
ODriverInj: The 17 year old male juvenile driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. The police report also indicated that there were no apparent objective symptoms of alcohol or drug intoxication as well.
Human:
The 41 year old male white operator of the motorcycle (MC1) was driving at a speed considered safe for the present traffic on the roadway.
The 17 year old male juvenile driver of the other vehicle (OV1) was operating his vehicle at a high rate of speed without due caution for the unsecured cargo in the back of the truck.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision. The other vehicle (OV1) sustained no damage as a result of the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This is a motorcycle (MC) vs. Other Vehicle (OV1) frontal to left side impact with a second lay-down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC vs. Other Vehicle frontal to left side impact event in which the rider was fully ejected, followed by a secondary laydown event. The rider was fully ejected during the first harmful event and sustained major injuries. The MC went down on its right side after impact and was facing in a northwesterly direction. The crash occurred in Southern California in July 2012 during hours of daylight at 0700 hours. The weather was clear with no wind. The approximate temperature was 59 degrees F. The roadway surface was concrete, which was dry, worn and polished. It has several transverse tar snake repairs for cracks
but was in otherwise good condition.

The crash occurred mid-block on a two lane roadway that is separated by a double solid yellow line. Each lane is 11? wide. There are bike lanes on either side of the road. On the right side of the road is a 5? dirt shoulder. There are utility poles and some trees. At the right edge of the dirt shoulder there is an approximate 20? drop down to railroad tracks. There is no guardrail or fence. Beyond the railroad tracks is a park with soccer fields. On the left side of the road is a chain link type fence and no shoulder. There is an approximate 15? easement full of tall weeds and then a freeway wall. There are no curbs. The roadway at the crash scene is curved to the left and has a slight upgrade for the MC?s direction of travel. The roadway runs in a north/south configuration. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. There is no on-street parking in the area of the crash.

The Case Vehicle was a 1994 Suzuki DR350 enduro type MC with knobby type tires that was being operated by a 59 year old Caucasian male, (5? 08?/180 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face helmet with an integral chin bar and clear face shield. It is rated to conform to FMVSS218 and Snell M2000 standards.

The MC was southbound in the #1 lane. Traffic was light. OV1 was southbound ahead of the MC. The MC was riding with a friend in a single file style formation and was the lead bike. The OV driver was not familiar with the area; was lost; and was exceeding the speed limit. When she realized that she had missed the
 
side street that she was supposed to turn onto, she slowed and moved to the right edge of the roadway. She checked for traffic in her mirrors and saw a MC that was far enough away that she felt she had enough time and room to make a left U-turn. The MC that she saw was the friend of the Case MC. The Case MC was much closer and possibly in her blind spot. As the Case MC rider saw the OV pull over to the right and slow down, he saw its brake lights and let off on his throttle, slowing from approximately 40 mph to about 35 mph. He also moved from the center of the lane to the left side of the lane, but never applied his brakes. The OV made a left turn in front of the case MC and was blocking the roadway. The rider said that he thinks he may have steered left a little, but did no other avoidance maneuvers. He said that his natural reaction was to do what he does when riding in the dirt and about to hit something, which is to stand up on the foot pegs to help absorb the shock. The rider said he remembers impacting the OV near the leading edge of the driver?s door and then flying over the roof of the OV and landing in the street to an unknown distance from the 1st harmful event. The MC proceeded down the road approximately 88? 09? in an unknown dynamics, landing on its right side plane facing in a northwestern direction against the chain link fence. There was an 8.25? reduction in the wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 59 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a pleural effusion to his right lung, a lacerated iliac artery on his right leg, two fractures to his pelvis, three fractured cervical vertebrae, six fractured ribs on his right side, three contused ribs on his left side, a distal fracture of his radius, and several abrasions and contusions. He was hospitalized for five days. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was lost and distracted. She showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The driver of OV1 had a perception failure of not seeing the MC before making the left U-turn and a decision failure for making the illegal U-turn. The rider had a reaction failure of poor avoidance maneuvers.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major damage to the front and minor to moderate damage on both sides. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was good. We were unable to inspect OV1, but it reportedly had moderate damage to the left side and was towed from the scene
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the accident.

CrashType: This was a motor scooter (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) front end to left side, side-slap type impact, injury traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing serious injuries.
MV1: 2008 Lance Model GS-R (Step Through style) scooter (black in color)
OV1: 2008 BMW 335i sedan type automobile (white in color)
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury traffic collision. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight in July 2012 at 1100 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1053 hours showed hazy skies, with variable winds not exceeding 4.6 mph and, an ambient temperature of 69.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The collision occurred at an at grade multi-lane signal controlled intersection.
The roadway surface for the motorcycle (MC1) was an uphill grade of 2.8%. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. The roadway for the motorcycle was a multi-lane local surface street with an overall travel way width of 77 feet. There are two lanes designated for westbound and two lanes designated for eastbound traffic. On a westbound approach to the intersection there are designated left turn, right turn & through traffic and, right turn only lanes. The signal controls have a demand sequence protected leading green left turn arrow for westbound traffic as well as eastbound traffic.

The east and westbound traffic lanes are divided by a raised concrete & brick median that is four feet in width. West of the intersection the opposing lanes are divided by a series of painted solid double yellow lines spaced approximately 4 feet apart. The speed limit for this street is 40 mph.
The intersecting surface street is a multi-lane major arterial roadway with an overall travel-way width of 102 feet. This roadway has three lanes designated for northbound and three lanes designated for southbound traffic. On a southbound approach to the intersection there are two designated left turn lanes to move traffic eastbound on a protected leading green arrow. There is also the same protected leading green arrow for north to westbound traffic.

On the north side of the intersection the opposing lanes of traffic are separated by a raised concrete & brick median that is two feet in width. There are also dedicated bike lanes on both sides of the street. South of the intersection the lanes are separated by the same raised concrete & brick median however, it is four feet in width. The speed limit for this street is 50 mph.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2008 Lance GS-R (step through style) scooter, (150cc) being operated by a (27) year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was travelling westbound at a speed of approximately 40 mph in the #2 westbound lane of traffic approaching the intersection on a slight 2.8% uphill grade.
 
The other vehicle (OV1) was stopped in traffic, southbound (first position) in the #3 lane at the intersection of the major arterial. There were also additional vehicles stopped adjacent to OV1 to the left in the designated left turn lane and, the #2 through lane of traffic.
When the westbound signal cycles through its phase sequence from green, yellow to, red, there is a slight phase delay and, then the southbound lanes receive a leading protected green arrow as well as a solid green light for the through lanes of traffic.

Upon receiving a solid green light the driver of (OV1) proceeded into the intersection from a standing stop. The driver did not see the motorcycle (MC1) approaching at a high rate of speed from her left. The driver of (OV1) only heard the sound of a horn and then the sudden impact of the motorcycle striking the left side of her vehicle and, the rider vaulting over the engine hood. (OV1) had moved a distance of approximately 86 feet into the intersection when struck by (MC1).

The front end of the motorcycle (scooter) MC1 struck the left side of the other vehicle in the area of the driver side door side slapped with the right side continuing along the left front quarter panel of (OV1). MC1 separated from (OV1) collapsing onto the roadway surface, left side down to its final resting place approximately 51 feet southwest of the area of impact.

The rider of (MC1) was ejected of the scooter upon impacting with (OV1) and initially impacted with the roadway surface in the adjacent #2 lane in front of approaching southbound traffic. The rider however, continued to tumble and/or roll to an area adjacent to the southwest corner of the intersection, coming to rest approximately 46 feet southwest of the area of impact.

The driver of (OV1) had no time or inclination to conduct a collision avoidance maneuver and simply came to a stop near the southwest corner of the intersection.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj:
The (27) year old male Caucasian rider of the scooter (MC1) sustained a fracture to his right elbow and numerous broken ribs. Due to his lack of cooperation
with the police investigation and our research, little else is known regarding the extent of his injuries.
ODriverInj: The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained a complaint of pain to her left shoulder, hip and, leg however refused any medical treatment.
Human: The (27) year old male Caucasian operator of the scooter (MC1) was travelling at a speed unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway and failed to stop for a red phase signal while approaching the intersection. The operator of the scooter (MC1) made an unsafe decision to continue into the intersection against approaching cross traffic.The (55) year old female driver of the other vehicle (OV1) was unable to react in time to avoid the collision. There was no contributory negligence on her part.
Vehicle:
The Lance scooter (MC1) sustained total catastrophic front end and right side contact damage with the other vehicle (OV1) as well as left side damage when impacting with the roadway surface.
The other vehicle (OV1) sustained moderate left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. SUV turning left.
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in July 2012 at 1914 hours in Southern California. It was dusk and the weather was clear; the temperature was between 73 and 70 degrees F and the winds were light. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, travel worn and lit by overhead streetlights.

The crash occurred at a moderately busy four-leg intersection. The east/west speed limit is 50 mph, the eastbound lanes consist of two left turn lanes and three through lanes. Westbound lanes consist of a left turn lane and three through lanes. There are traffic controls present and all traffic controls were functioning correctly. The intersection is located in a commercial area, bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The east/west roadway is straight with a west to east downhill grade of 4.1% to 2.9%. The north/south roadway is straight and has a 4.2% northbound uphill grade.
Vehicle 1 (MC1), is a 2005 Harley Davidson, 20C-XL1200C, 1200 cc, Modified Chopper, green in color, ridden by a 25 year old white male who
is, 5 ft. 10 in. and 220 lbs. The rider was wearing a full face motorcycle helmet with a smoke colored face shield. Vehicle 2 (OV1) is a 2012 Lexus RX300, (gold in color) that was driven by a 64 year old white male who is, 5 ft. 7 in. and 190 lbs. The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

The rider of MC1 was westbound, at approximately 55 mph, in lane #1 approaching the intersection. OV1 was stopped in the eastbound #1 left turn lane, waiting to make a left turn. As the rider of MC1 approached the intersection he looked down at his GPS, when he looked back up, he saw the traffic signal had changed to red and that OV1 was turning across his path and applied his brakes. The driver of OV1 started his left turn with a green traffic signal, saw MC1 going through the intersection without stopping for the red traffic signal and braked to a stop in front of MC1. MC1 was unable to stop before striking the right
front bumper. MC1 and OV1, Point of Impact (POI) and Point of Rest (POR) are the same. The rider was launched from MC1 and his POR was approximately 20 ft. from the POI.
RiderInj: The 25 year-old male rider of MC1sustained the following injuries: Contusions to the left arm, an abrasion to the left knee and bilateral contusions to the lower legs. His ISS score is 1.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured and there was no drug or alcohol involvement.
Human: The 25 year-old male rider of MC1 was distracted by his GPS and failed to yield the right of way to OV1.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors involved with this crash.

CrashType: This is a three vehicle rear-end type collision. Other Vehicle-1 (OV1) impacted the back of the Motorcycle (MC) causing it to go down on its? right side plane and fully ejecting the rider who impacted the rear of Other Vehicle-2 (OV2). MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC vs. two Other Vehicles in which the MC was rear-ended by OV1 and the rider was fully ejected and impacted OV2. All three vehicles were in the same lane and travelling in the same direction. OV2 was stopped for a red light. MC was slowing to stop when he was hit from behind. The driver of OV1 was distracted and not paying attention. When he realized that traffic was stopped or slowing in front of him, he applied his brakes in an attempt to avoid the collision, but was unsuccessful. The crash occurred 180? south of an intersection. The crash occurred in Southern California in July 2012 during hours of daylight at 1737 hours. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with a moderate wind from the west. The approximate temperature was 79.0 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition.

The crash occurred on a seven lane roadway on the approach to a signal controlled intersection. The roadway runs in a north/south configuration and is straight. The surrounding area is a combination of single family residences, a college and commercial businesses. The roadway is a minor arterial. The north/south travel lanes are delineated by a solid double yellow (no passing) centerline. There are sidewalks and greenery on either side of the roadway. There is no on-street parking permitted and the posted speed limit is 45 mph.

The Case Vehicle was a 2006 Kawasaki Ninja sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 44 year old Caucasian male, (6? 2?; 185 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face helmet with an integral chin bar and a clear face shield. It is rated to conform to FMVSS218 and an unknown Snell standard. The rider provided us with photographs of his helmet which did not include the inside labels.
 
MC was northbound in the #3 (left-inside) lane. Traffic was moderate to heavy and stopped or stopping for a red light just north of the crash site. The driver of OV-1 was driving northbound in the #1 lane immediately behind the MC and was distracted. He did not realize that the MC was slowing to a stop in front of him. When he did notice, he applied his brakes in an attempt to avoid hitting the MC. The rider was not familiar with the area. He was looking for a freeway on- ramp and did not know which side of the road it was on. He never saw OV1 behind him. OV1 rear-ended the MC (1st harmful event) and pushed it forward, fully ejecting the rider. The rider rose above ride height and flew into the rear of OV2, which was stopped (2nd harmful event). The rider then landed on the paved roadway surface. The MC slid on its right side, front end first to its? FRP. The rider had no memory of the crash following the first harmful event. Both OV drivers refused to participate. I spoke with both drivers on the phone. The driver of OV2 said that the bike never made contact with her vehicle, only the rider. She insisted that there was only a scuff mark on her vehicle that washed off. There was no damage to OV2. There were no tire marks from either OV. There was one tire mark from the MC after the 1st harmful event before the MC went down. This was possibly caused by the front tire as the forks turned to lock after impact. The rider said that he did not brake. The driver of OV1 told the police that he ?diverted his attention from the roadway? but did not say what his attention was diverted to. This combined with his speed relative to other traffic and the lack of sufficient time for braking on the part of the driver of OV1 caused the crash.


The rider of the MC sustained minor injuries. There were some minor scratches where the MC went down. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 44 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained multiple contusions (no abrasions, per the interview, even though the police report listed one abrasion) to his left side and extremities. His injuries were drastically lessened or prevented because of his safety apparel. He was taken to a medical facility where he was treated and released. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: Neither driver of the OV?s showed any signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The driver of OV1 had a perception failure. He was pre-occupied and diverted is attention from the roadway. He was not paying attention to his position in traffic in relation to other vehicles on the road. He then had a reaction failure by applying his brakes too late. The combination of both these aspects makes his driving an unsafe act likely to cause an accident. None of the operators had any impairment.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained moderate to major damage to the rear, and right side. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was good. OV-1 sustained minor damage to the front left per the police report. OV-2 sustained no damage per the driver on the phone. Neither vehicle was able to be inspected.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors considered to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile turning left.
MV1: 2007 Kawasaki, ZX600J, 599 cc, sport/race replica, black in color
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in July 2012 at 1851 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the weather was partly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 70 degrees F and the winds were light. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, with surface cracking, spalling and cutout sections of new asphalt.

The crash occurred at a busy four-leg intersection. The speed limit is 45 mph, the eastbound lanes consist of two left turn lanes, two through lanes and a through/right turn lane. Westbound lanes consist of two left turn lanes, three through lanes and a right turn lane. There are traffic controls present and all traffic controls were functioning correctly. The intersection is located in a commercial area, bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The east/west roadway is straight with a west to east downhill grade of 0.7% to 0.2%.

Vehicle 1 (MC1), is a 2007 Kawasaki, ZX600J, 599 cc, sport/race replica, black in color, ridden by a 56 year old white male who is 6 ft. 2 in. tall and weighs 190 lbs. The rider was wearing an unknown style of helmet. Vehicle 2 (OV1), is a 1997 Mercedes-Benz, S500, silver in color, driven by a 67 year old Asian male who is 5ft. 5in. Tall and weighs 150 lbs. The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

The rider of MC1 was eastbound, at approximately 45 mph, in lane #2 approaching the intersection with a green traffic signal. OV1 was stopped in the westbound #2 left turn lane, waiting to make a left turn. The eastbound traffic had a full phase green tri-light and the westbound traffic had a red phase tri- light and red arrow. OV1 made a left turn against the red phase tri-light and red arrow, across the path of MC1. The rider of MC1 applied the front brake only, causing a front wheel locked skid, approximately 27? until impacting the right rear wheel of OV1. Area of impact was 28 ft. north of the south curb line of the east/west street and 32 ft. east of the west curb line of the north/south street.
RiderInj: The 56 year-old male rider of MC1sustained the following injuries, as related by the rider: Abrasions to the left shoulder, contusion to the palm of the right hand, and a laceration to the left knee. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1.
Human: The 67 year-old male driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1. The 56 year-old male rider of MC1?s decision to only apply the front brake, causing a locked front wheel skid. This reduced his ability to safely maneuver, causing the motorcycle to veer right into the rear of OV1.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: No crash causal factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC) vs. Other Vehicle (OV1) frontal right to front impact with secondary lay down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC right frontal impact to the front of OV1 that was making a left turn in front of the MC. The crash occurred on a non-freeway minor arterial at a three-leg, not skewed driveway type intersection. There is one lane in each direction divided by a double yellow line. There is a combination bike lane/parking strip that is 10? wide on the northbound side, along with a varying dirt shoulder that is 1?-3? wide with intermittent asphalt curbing. There is also an approximate 5? high elevated parking lot where OV1 came from that has an unimproved dirt face edge. The southbound side has a 9? paved bike lane and a varying 3?-5? dirt shoulder and a chain link fence. The roadway has a north/south orientation. The MC landed on its left side plane after impact, high side forward and slid in a northwesterly direction. The MC slid across paved roadway surface to the dirt shoulder on the west side of the roadway, striking the chain link fence. The MC then rebounded back onto the roadway to its FRP. The rider was fully ejected and landed at an unknown location in the roadway after the First Harmful event. He had already been removed by the paramedics and taken to the hospital when the police arrived. The police report did not document the riders FRP. The OV was making a left turn from a private driveway on the rider?s right. After impact, the OV drove to the shoulder and parked.
There is a bar on the rider?s right and rural fields on the left. Parallel parking is allowed on both sides of the roadway. It is unknown if any vehicles were parked at the time of the crash. The OV came from an elevated parking area. The approach to the roadway has the side view blocked on both sides due to the ground elevation. Once at the driveway entrance/exit, there is a clear view of the roadway in both directions. The crash took place in the northbound lane near the center line. The crash occurred in Southern California in August 2012 during hours of daylight at 1820 hours. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the southwest. The approximate temperature was 77 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has a 3.7% upgrade and a 1.7% crown on the northbound side at the crash site. The posted speed limit is 50 mph.

The Case Vehicle was a 2012 Honda CBR 250 sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 27 year old male, (5?11?/165 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown ratings. It is unknown if he had any other safety apparel.
 
The case MC was northbound at an unknown speed. Traffic was light to moderate. The rider saw the OV in the driveway. The rider said that all of a sudden the OV entered the roadway and that he barely had time to swerve left in an attempt to avoid hitting the OV. He said that he struck the OV and was fully ejected. There were no pre-impact skid marks from either vehicle. There was no evidence of skidding on any of the tires for both vehicles. The driver of the OV drove to the right edge of the roadway and parked. The OV driver had just left the bar. He was subsequently arrested by the police for felony DUI. Based on the police interview of the rider, it would appear that he was attentive and looking forward while riding.
RiderInj: The 27 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained what was described as a partial amputation of the right foot at the ankle. He also sustained numerous lacerations and abrasions. He was treated at the scene, and then transported to a hospital where he was admitted and underwent surgery. His length of stay at the hospital is unknown. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV-1 showed obvious signs of intoxication and was arrested. He was not injured.
Human: The 69 year old male operator of the OV was impaired and had a perception failure. The rider of the MC was alert and not distracted, but did not have adequate time to react to the OV?s movement.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major damage to the right side from impacting the OV and substantial damage to the left side from sliding on the roadway. There was no reduction in the wheelbase. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was very good, like new. It is not equipped with ABS brakes. The OV sustained minor damage to the center-front and across to the right front fender/head light area. The damage is visible from the hood line to the lower bumper area. Its pre-crash condition was good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (roadway surface) with the rear portion of the motorcycle impacting the roadway, after a failed attempt at negotiating a wheel stand (wheelie). The right side of motorcycle collapsed onto the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider and passenger were ejected off the bike and sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of impacting with the roadway surface. There were no other vehicles involved and, the rider was subsequently arrested for driving under the influence.
MV1: 2006 Suzuki GSXR, sport race replica style motorcycle (1000cc) blue in color.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object rear-end impact type traffic collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to both the rider and passenger. The collision occurred during the hours of darkness in August 2012 at 2330 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, a SSW wind direction at 4.6 mph, and an ambient temperature of +68.0 degrees F. Sunset was at 1950 hours on this day. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 2.3 % downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a eastbound, straight, multiple lane surface street with an overall travel-way width of 110 feet. This is an east/west minor arterial surface street with three lanes dedicated for eastbound and three lanes for westbound traffic. There are no designated bike lanes for either direction of travel at the crash site or at the intersection.

The east and westbound lanes of this street are divided by a 2 foot wide concrete and brick raised median. West of the crash site is a four way intersection with multi-phase traffic signals to regulate traffic in all directions. The area in proximity of the crash site is bordered by multiple unit residential structures located along the northeast corner and a commercial shopping center open to public access at the southeast corner. West of the intersection on both the north and south sides of the street is undeveloped land.
At the location of the crash site there were no traffic control devices to regulate the flow of traffic in the area. The speed limit on this street is 45 mph for both directions of travel. Both the north and south sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs and, concrete sidewalks.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2006 Suzuki GSXR 1000cc (sport race replica style) motorcycle being operated by a 41 year old male Caucasian rider. The passenger seated behind the rider was a 32 year old female Caucasian. Both the rider and passenger were wearing motorcycle helmets or at the time of the crash event. It is unknown what make, model or, color the helmets were.
The rider was travelling eastbound in the #1 lane of the multi-lane surface street and was initially stopped for a red phase light west of the intersection. Reports from witnesses at the scene were hearing the motorcycle take off at a high rate of speed soon after receiving a green phase light.
 
As the rider continued eastbound through the intersection he attempted to negotiate a front wheel stand (wheelie). As the rider attempted the ?wheelie? the bike continued in an upward motion to a point the caused the passenger to be ejected off the rear and, the rear fender assembly to impact with the roadway surface. The rider lost control and either leapt off the bike or was ejected himself. Evidence of first contact with the roadway surface spanned a distance of no less than 76 feet.

Prior to the arrival of law enforcement officials both the rider and passenger had moved off the roadway to a safe area along the southeast corner of the intersection. It is unknown where the occupants ended up with respect to the final resting point of the motorcycle. The rider, who was intoxicated, freely admitted to his inexperience operating a motorcycle with a passenger.
RiderInj: The 41 year old male Caucasian rider of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were predominately lacerations and abrasions to both his hands, arms and legs. The 32 year old female Caucasian passenger sustained an abrasion to her left knee and, apparently was unconsciousness for a period not exceeding 30 seconds. The passenger refused any medical treatment at the scene. Medical records regarding the rider are currently unavailable.
Human: The 41 year old male Caucasian rider of the motorcycle (MC1) was operating a vehicle while under the influence of an intoxicant (alcohol), driving at a high rate of speed, transporting a passenger and, attempting an otherwise illegal wheel stand beyond his ability to maintain control of the vehicle. The rider was subsequently arrested at the scene for driving under the influence of an intoxicant.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained moderate damage to the rear fender, seat & stoplight/taillight assembly and right side however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
There were no ?other vehicles? involved.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. fixed object.
Crash:
This single vehicle fatal motorcycle crash occurred in August 2012 at 1252 hours in Southern California. It was bright daylight, the temperature was approximately 99 degrees F., the sky was clear and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry.

The crash occurred in a commercial area. The eastbound side has a 27 ft. 3 in. lane, a 6 ft. raised dirt shoulder with a metal fence, the westbound side has a 24 ft. 3 in. lane, a 9 ft. concrete sidewalk. The lanes are divided by a solid double yellow stripe. There is a left hand curve leading to the crash scene, which is 115 ft. 10 in. in length with a radius of 119.03 ft. There are no traffic controls at this area and the posted speed limit is 40 mph.

MC1, a 2008 Suzuki, GSXR 750, 749 cc, was being operated by a 41 year old male (5 ft. 7 in., 190 lbs.) who was wearing a DOT/Snell approved helmet at the time of the crash. The rider was proceeding eastbound at approximately 65 mph, popped a wheelie, crossed over the center stripe as he
entered the curve. He braked and skidded 145 ft. 3 in., striking the south curb. The rider stayed with MC1 as it rode up onto the shoulder, continued eastbound against the fence approximately 82 ft. 3 in., before striking a breakaway signpost. The riders helmet shows damage on the right side from scraping along the fence and damage to the left front from the breakaway pole, the rider came to rest, face down on the shoulder facing west, while MC1 came to rest on its right side on the curb, facing north. The final rest positions are within 6 ft. of the signpost.
RiderInj: The 41 year old male rider of the MC1 died at the hospital after 62 days, with an AIS score of 4, as a result of injuries listed in the police report and coroners statement: Severe head fracture Not Further Specified (NFS), multiple blunt traumatic injuries (NFS), bleeding from the head and face (NFS), possible broken bones (NFS) and loss of consciousness (NFS).
Human: The rider was operating MC1 at an unsafe speed and a reckless manner.
Vehicle: There are no motorcycle crash causal factors.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC) right side lay-down event with a secondary rear end impact to the Other Vehicle. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC lay down event in which the rider lost control by locking the front tire and washing out while braking (1st harmful event) in an attempt to avoid rear-ending the OV which was stopped for a red light. The crash occurred at a four-leg, not skewed intersection. There are five through lanes and dedicated left turn lanes for three of the four legs. The fourth leg is a driveway to a small shopping center. The roadway has a north/south dedication, however, at the crash site; the roadway has an east/west orientation. The MC slid on its right side plane, front end forward, and impacted the center rear of the OV (2nd harmful event), pushing it forward approximately 5?. The rider was fully ejected when the MC went down. The MC landed on his right leg, causing his injuries. The rider landed about half way (approximately 6?) from the 1st harmful event (out of control lay down) and the 2nd harmful event (MC impacting OV). All events occurred in the #2 middle lane. The MC was facing in a southeasterly orientation at its FRP. The crash occurred in Southern California in August 2012 during hours of daylight at 1810 hours. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the south. The approximate temperature was 79 degrees F. The sun was low in the horizon and behind both operators, but had not set. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has a 6.1% downgrade at the crash site.

The crash occurred just prior to the intersection. On the rider?s right side of the intersection, is the fourth leg of the intersection (driveway) leading to the commercial complex. There are commercial/retail businesses on either side of the roadway. It has four through lanes prior to the crash site and expands to five lanes after at the crash site. There are eight lanes on the opposite side of the intersection. The roadway is divided by painted double yellow lines. There are sidewalks, limited greenery, and street lights on either side of the roadway. There is on-street parking on both sides of the road. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

The Case Vehicle was a 2009 Harley Davidson Road King Classic cruising type motorcycle that was being operated by a 57 year old Caucasian male, (5? 10?/190 lbs.). The rider was wearing an open face helmet with no face shield. The helmet is rated to FMVSS 218/DOT standards.
 
The case MC was southbound in the #2 lane at about the posted speed limit. Traffic was moderate. The rider said that he was attentive and not distracted when he noticed that he was approaching the intersection with a red light and a car stopped in his lane. He panic braked. He applied too much front brake, locking the front tire, causing the forks to turn and the bike to go down. The driver of the OV admitted that he stopped quickly because he was not paying attention. The OV, however, was stopped at the time of the crash. The driver of the OV took some photos of the crash scene which are in the case file. Based on the OV driver?s photos, the MC left approximately 12? of scrapes from the 1st harmful event to its FRP at the 2nd harmful event. It is unknown if the MC rotated lightly in a CW rotation during the slide (1st harmful event) or after impacting the OV (2nd harmful event). Based on the damage to the front fender and the scrapes in the photograph, it appears that the MC may have done both. The MC was sliding on its right side plane, front end forward, and being protected by the crash bars that were installed both to the front and rear. The sliding damage was minimal and only to the crash bars on the right side. The damage to the front fender and left side of the MC was from impacting the OV. There was no evidence of any skid from the MC on the roadway or the tires. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 57 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a comminuted fracture of the tibia and fibula. He was treated at the scene, and then transported to a hospital where he was admitted for seven days. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV-1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The 57 year old male rider of the Case Vehicle was not paying attention/distracted while operating the MC at or near the speed limit and realized too late that the signal ahead of him was red and that traffic was stopped. The driver of the OV was also somewhat distracted, but was able to make a safe and legal stop prior to the crash and had no contribution to the crash.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor damage to both sides and the front fender. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was very good, like new. It is not equipped with ABS brakes, which the rider said would have probably helped prevent the crash. The OV was in very good condition prior to the crash and sustained only minor scratches to the lower center portion of the rear bumper.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash. Contributing Factors Form 105

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. roadway surface including a secondary impact with another vehicle (OV1). The crash event caused the motorcycle rider to be ejected impacting with (OV1) causing fatal injuries.
MV1: 2010 Harley Davidson (conventional) XL883N ?Iron Sportster?, black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle fatal traffic collision. The collision occurred in August 2012 at 1205 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1153 hours showed mostly cloudy skies, with winds out of the southwest at 9.2 mph, and, an ambient temperature of 77.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The motorcyclist was traveling on a roadway surface with an uphill grade of 4.2%. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

The collision occurred on a (left) curved uphill grade local surface street with an overall travel-way width of 65 feet. The street although curved, runs primarily north to south with two lanes dedicated for eastbound and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic. The opposing lanes are separated by a painted median strip of two solid double yellow lines. There are no designated traffic control devices to regulate the east/west traffic lanes. The location of the crash scene
was at an at grade T-style intersection with one posted stop sign regulating northbound traffic.

The intersecting local surface street has an overall travel-way width of 40 feet. The speed limit for the local street is 25 mph. The eastbound downhill grade at the intersection is 3.2%. The roadway crown on approach to the crash scene is 0.1% on a left curve approach. There were no apparent super-elevation
issues with this roadway.

The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted solid double yellow line lane marker. Besides the posted stop sign, there is also a white painter designator prior to the limit line indicating the word STOP.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2010 Harley Davidson (conventional) 883cc motorcycle being operated by a (29) year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was travelling eastbound in the #2 eastbound lane of the two lane local surface street approaching the T-intersection on the uphill grade.
 
The other vehicle (OV1); a 2010 Acura TSX coupe (automobile) was being operated by a (30) year old male Hispanic. The other driver (MVD) was approaching northbound in the #1 lane of the intersecting local surface street. The driver had initially stopped at the limit line prior to entering the intersection. The driver then moved his vehicle into the intersection to get a better view of cross traffic due to the presence of a large four wheel drive truck that had slowed to make a right turn from the eastbound #2 lane at the intersection. The motorcyclist had been behind this truck and moved around the truck to the left to pass. When the driver of OV1 moved into the intersection he saw the motorcycle (MC1) approaching however did not have time to avoid the collision.

The motorcyclist attempted to avoid contact with OV1 however, lost control of the motorcycle causing it to collapse (right side down) onto the roadway
surface. The rider was ejected off the bike and both he and the motorcycle slid and/or tumbled into the left side of OV1. The motorcycle struck the left side of the front bumper and the rider struck the left side of OV1 at the driver side door.
The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained no injuries as a result of the collision.
Other than the presence of the truck turning right, causing a temporary visual obstruction, there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj:
The (29) year old male Caucasian operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained blunt force trauma to the head, thoracic and abdominal areas of his body. The rider was transported from the scene to a local hospital where he succumbed to his injuries. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
The rider was wearing an FMVSS 218 (US DOT) approved full face motorcycle helmet that sustained minor abrasive damage.
Human:
The (29) year old male Caucasian operator of the motorcycle (MC1) was travelling at a speed safe for the present traffic on the roadway however failed to perceive the hazards of vehicles at intersections.
The (30) year old male Hispanic driver of the other vehicle (OV1) failed perceive the presence of approaching traffic while entering the intersection.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained major front end damage with the other vehicle (OV1) and minor right side damage as a result of impacting with the roadway surface.
The other vehicle (OV1) sustained moderate left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. SUV (Non-Contact) vs. asphalt roadway
MV1: 1986 Honda Shadow VT700 (694 CC) Cruiser bike, black in color
OV1: 1995 Chevrolet Blazer (Non-Contact, Minor Driver), red in color
Crash:
This Single non-fatal motorcycle crash/ lay-down occurred on Friday, 08/17/2012 at 1605 hours in Southern California. Traffic volume was light. The temperature was 84 degrees F and it was clear with no precipitation, the winds were 12.7 mph out of the South and the asphalt roadway surface was dry.

The crash occurred on an undivided two-lane East/west, asphalt roadway, with a sold double yellow center line and a slight right hand curve. The area of the crash occurred in a residential area, with single family homes on the south side and a park on the north. The asphalt/bituminous roadway surface was travel worn with surface cracking. The posted speed limit is 25 mph.

Vehicle 1 (MC 1) was a black, 1986 Honda Shadow VT700 (694 CC) Cruiser style bike, that was being ridden by a 73 year-old white male (5? 10?, 150 lbs.) who was wearing a full face motorcycle helmet with a clear shield. The rider of MC 1 was westbound at approximately 25 mph, with parked vehicles on both sides of the road. Vehicle 2 (OV-1) a 1995 Chevrolet Blazer (Non-Contact, Minor Driver), red in color, was parallel parked along the right curb ahead of MC-1. OV-1 began to pull out into traffic, then stopped. The rider of MC-1 moved towards the center line, when OV-1, suddenly pulled out across both lanes.
The rider lost control during braking, causing the bike to low side, left side down. The motorcycle left approximately 18 feet of tire mark and approximately 10 feet of gouge marks, coming to rest facing north across the center line, 302 west of the west curb line of the north/south street. There were minor abrasions to the left highway peg on the front crash bar, air cleaner and saddle bag. The rider?s POR was within 6 feet of MC1s POR.
RiderInj: The 73 year-old white male rider of MC-1 has an ?Injury Severity Score? (ISS) of 2, from the following injuries: Left (#7) rib fracture, neck strain, multiple abrasions and contusions to the left side of his body.
Human: The minor driver of OV-1, failed to look for oncoming traffic prior to pulling across both lanes. The rider of MC-1 failed to properly executer his evasive action.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to be linked to the crash causation.

CrashType:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (roadway surface) injury collision. The rider had over applied the use of his front and rear brakes causing him to lose control of the motorcycle. The motorcycle subsequently collapsed with the right side impacting the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of impacting with the roadway surface, curb and, sidewalk area adjacent to his lane of travel.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians or, animals involved in this event.
MV1: 2012 Suzuki Boulevard Classic (Cruiser style) motorcycle, (805cc) dark red
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (roadway surface) right side impact type traffic collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the rider. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight on Friday in August 2012 at 1851 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, a south tailwind at 8.1 mph, and an ambient temperature of +86.0 degrees F. Sunset was at 1937 hours on this day.
The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 0.8 % downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a northbound, right curved, multiple lane local surface street with an overall travel-way width of 90 feet. This is a north/south local surface street with two lanes dedicated for north and two lanes for southbound traffic. There are no designated bike lanes for either direction of travel and parking adjacent to both sides of this street is prohibited.

The traffic lanes of this street are divided by a 29 foot wide, raised concrete median, containing low lying surface vegetation and trees. This median tapers off at the intersection on the north side. On the south side the median tapers off into a 85 foot long two foot wide raised divider to facilitate two designated left turn lanes. North of the crash site is a T-shaped intersection with multi-phase traffic signals to regulate traffic in all directions. The area in proximity of the
crash site is bordered by a large public amusement park along the east side and, commercial & public parking along the west side.
The location of the crash site was approximately 91 feet south of the intersection as the rider was approaching. The intersection is controlled by overhead traffic signals with leading protected green arrows and a designated pedestrian crosswalk along the north side of the intersection. The posted speed limit on this street is 35 mph for both directions of travel. Both the north and south sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs, low lying surface vegetation, palm trees and, concrete sidewalks.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2012 Suzuki Boulevard Classic (Cruiser style) motorcycle being operated by a 31 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was wearing an HJC Model CL Max 2 FMVSS 218 DOT approved full face motorcycle helmet at the time of the crash event.
The rider was travelling northbound in the #1 lane of the local surface street at an estimated speed of approximately 44 mph and, was approaching the T-
 
intersection in light traffic.

As the rider continued northbound towards the intersection he noticed the traffic signal, for his direction of travel begin to go through a phase sequence from green, yellow to red. At first the rider told me he thought he might have enough time to get through the intersection however, at the last moment opted not to and grabbed his front brake. The rider told me the front brake locked up and he lost control of the motorcycle and collapsed in a low side right impact with the roadway surface.
