When I inspected the scene I discovered what appeared to be a one foot long skid patch followed up by approximately 39 feet of locked rear wheel skid. The rider was ejected off the motorcycle as it collapsed on to the roadway surface, sliding and tumbling a distance of approximately 61 feet. The motorcycle continue to slide parallel to the roadway edge until it came to rest just inside the boundaries of the intersection a distance of approximately 75 feet from the initial area of impact.
RiderInj: The 31 year old male Caucasian rider of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were for the most part superficial abrasions and contusions to his shoulder, thorax region, both arms, right side hip & thigh, left hand and, left knee. The rider was transported to a local hospital and, was treated & released.
Human: The 31 year old male Caucasian rider of the motorcycle (MC1) admitted that he was new to motorcycling and had limited (3 months) experience. The rider was operating a newly purchased motorcycle; his first. Although traffic was light and played no role in the crash event, his speed on approach to the intersection with a phasing signal, was unsafe.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. fixed object (wall w/guard rail), DUI involvement.
Crash:
This single, fatal motorcycle crash occurred on Monday in September 2012 at 1835 hours in Southern California. It was dark and the roadway was lighted by overhead luminaries (street lights). The temperature was approximately 77 degrees F., it was partly cloudy with no precipitation and the winds were south-southwest at approximately 9.2 mph. The concrete roadway surface was dry.

The crash occurred in a residential area, made up of single family homes, on a three-lane eastbound transition to a state highway, with 12 ft. lanes a 4 ft. shoulder on the north side and a 10 shoulder on the south. At the edge of the shoulders are 3 ft. concrete walls with metal top rails. The lanes are divided by painted white dashed stripes, a solid yellow stripe on the north side and a solid white stripe on the south. There are no traffic controls at this area and the posted speed limit is 45 mph.

Vehicle 1 (MC1) a 2010 Harley Davidson, 1803 cc, Fat Boy, was being operated by a 27 year old male (5 ft. 7 in., 170 lbs.) who was wearing a DOT approved helmet at the time of the crash. The rider was proceeding eastbound in the # 2 lane, at an estimated speed of approximately 85 mph. Due to the drugs/alcohol in his system and his high rate of speed, MC1 lost control, hitting the north wall at an angle of approximately a 50 deg. Angle vaulting the rider above ride height, over the wall and down a 20 ft. embankment covered in ice plant. MC1 came to rest in the #2 lane on its right side.
RiderInj: The 27 year old male rider of the MC1 died at the scene, with an AIS score of 45, as a result of: incomplete transection of the thoracic aorta, subdural/subarachnoid hemorrhages, bilateral contusional hemorrhages, laceration of the inferior vena cava/heart, multiple lacerations of the liver, laceration of the spleen, fractures of the right orbital plate & ethmoid bone, fractured sternum, bilateral 1-7 rib fractures and multiple abrasions to the exterior skin. The rider was under the influence of drugs and alcohol at the time of the crash.
Human: The rider was operating MC1 at an unsafe speed, while under the influence of drugs and alcohol.
Vehicle: There are no motorcycle crash causal factors.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC) high side lay-down event in collision avoidance with a Non-Contact Other Vehicle. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a single MC high side lay down event in which the rider lost control while braking (1st harmful event) in a collision avoidance maneuver with Non- Contact OV1. MC1 had just completed negotiating a left curve when NC-OV1 either failed to stop for a posted stop sign or failed to yield from the stop sign violating MC1?s right of way. The crash occurred in Southern California in September 2012 during daylight at 1715 hours. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with a moderate wind from the southwest. The approximate temperature was 84 degrees F. The roadway is made of an asphalt material and was dry, worn and polished, but in good repair. The speed limit is not posted, but has a prima fascia speed limit of 25 mph. for the residential neighborhood. There are sidewalks on both side of the road. On the riders right side is some greenery consisting of the landscaped front yards. On the riders left is a block wall. The MC was traveling in a northerly direction. The crash occurred at a T-intersection in a residential area. The roadway has one lane in each direction, each of which is 18? wide. On-street parallel parking is allowed on both sides of the roadway and vehicles were parked on both sides per the rider. The roadway is divided by a combination of skip-dash and solid double yellow painted lines at the crash scene. The intersecting street is the same size as the crash street and has a
posted stop sign for approaching traffic and a cross walk. This street would be on the rider?s left. The northern side of the intersection also has a cross walk. The roadway has an 8.1% downgrade for the MC?s direction of travel. There is another T-intersection 94? north of the crash intersection. There are solid double yellow lane lines between the two intersections. The roadway has a north/south dedication, however, at the crash site; the roadway has a northwest/southeast orientation. A single rear tire friction mark was found prior to any scratches/gouges with no overlapping.

MC1 was a 2006 Honda CBR 600 F4i (599cc) sport/race replica type motorcycle that was being operated by a 23 year old male, (5? 08?/170 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face MC helmet with an integral chin bar and a clear face shield. The rider is not required to wear any type of corrective lenses, and was not wearing any type of eye protection other than the face shield. The helmet is rated to FMVSS 218/DOT and Snell M2010 standards.

The MC was northbound in the #1 lane at a stated 30 mph and in 3rd gear. The rider lives in this neighborhood and drives/rides this road on a daily basis. As
 
the rider approached the intersection, he began braking in response to a perceived hazard. The rider reported that NC-OV1 was entering the intersection from his left and cut him off. This was not substantiated by the police and was not listed as a causal factor in their report. There is no other obvious reason that the rider would lock up his brakes. The police did look for and locate a resident in the neighborhood that owns a black Honda Element and verified that it was not in the area at the time of the crash. The rider said that he applied his rear brake, causing it to lock and skid. He said that he released the rear brake and re- applied it, ending up with the same result. He said that the MC went into a CCR to approximately 90 degrees to his left. At that time the MC rear tire caught the roadway surface and flipped, high side forward, fully ejecting the rider and landing on his right leg causing injuries. The rider said that he then separated from the MC and slid mostly on his back and backpack to his FRP near the right curb. The MC then slid on its right side plane to its FRP in the middle of the roadway. The MC was moved prior to arrival of the police. Traffic was light. The rider said that he was attentive and not distracted. He panic braked twice. He said that after locking the rear tire up the second time, he decided to just ?ride it out.? Other than being on its right side, the orientation of the MC at its FRP is unknown. There was no evidence of the rider leaving two separate skids. A single 43 foot rear tire mark was found. The rider was willing to participate, however, he needed time to recuperate and the MC was in his garage. This was a Late Report.
RiderInj: The 23 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a multiple comminuted fractures to his right femur and some minor abrasions. He was treated at the scene and then transported to a hospital, where he was admitted for two days. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: Non-Contact driver fled the scene. Any impairment is unknown.
Human: : The 23 year old male rider of the MC1 was riding at a speed that was at or near the prima fascia and had a reaction failure in applying his rear brake.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor damage to the right side. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was very good. It is not equipped with ABS brakes. There was no reduction in wheelbase. NC-OV1 fled the scene. There was no damage as a result of this crash. Its mechanical condition is unknown.
Environmental: Limited visibility from block walls and houses on the corners of the intersection may have been a contributing factor.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (roadway surface) low-side left lay down event including a secondary impact with another vehicle (OV1). The rider had lost control of the motorcycle in reaction to the other vehicle pulling away from the curb and the driver attempting a U-Turn type movement. The motorcycle subsequently collapsed with the left side impacting the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of impacting with the roadway surface.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (roadway surface) low-side left impact type traffic collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the rider. The collision occurred on Friday in September 2012 at 1520 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed partly cloudy skies, a southwest crosswind at 9.2 mph, and an ambient temperature of +100.9 degrees F. Sunset was at 1900 hours on this day.

The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 5.8 % downhill grade in the area of the crash site.

The collision occurred on a southbound, left curved, two lane local surface street with an overall travel-way width of 38.2 feet. This is a north/south local surface street with one lane dedicated for north and one lane for southbound traffic.

There are no designated bike lanes for either direction of travel and parking adjacent to both sides of this street is allowed with a designated 8? 6? wide parallel parking lane.

The traffic lanes of this street are divided by a painted double yellow colored lane line. The area in proximity of the crash site is bordered by a public park along the west side and, residential single family homes on the east side.
The location of the crash site was approximately 340 feet south of the nearest local street T-intersection. The intersection is controlled by posted stop signs. The posted speed limit on this street is 25 mph for both directions of travel. Both the north and south sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs, 6? wide parkways with low lying surface vegetation (grass) and, concrete sidewalks.
 
The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2011 Yamaha Zuma (125cc) scooter being operated by a 62 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was wearing an unknown make/model motorcycle helmet at the time of the crash event.
The rider was travelling southbound at approximately 25 mph in the designated #1 lane of the local surface street at an estimated speed of approximately 25 mph and, was approaching the location of numerous parked vehicles along his right.
As the rider continued southbound he noticed a vehicle pull out and away from the designated parallel parking area. The vehicle turned perpendicular across the southbound lane of travel. The rider told law enforcement officials that he had no time to react and subsequently lost control of the scooter. The scooter collapsed in a low side left impact with the roadway surface. The rider was thrown off his scooter onto the roadway surface. The scooter continued to slide a distance of about 16 feet until it impacted with the left rear fender of the other vehicle.
Other than the physical damage to the scooter there was little evidence at the scene to indicate its contact area with the roadway surface other than an 18 inch long scrape mark in proximity of the area of impact.
RiderInj: The 62 year old male Caucasian rider of the scooter (MC1) sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were for the most part superficial abrasions to his shoulders, arms, hands, knees and, legs. The rider was transported to a local hospital and, was treated & released.
Human:
The 62 year old male Caucasian rider was operating a newly purchased scooter and had insufficient time to initiate a safe collision avoidance maneuver.
The 38 year old Asian driver of the other vehicle saw the rider coming as he pulled away from the parking area thinking that he had sufficient time to negotiate a U-turn type movement. The driver realized as he pulled out that he had blocked the rider?s path and attempted to accelerate forward however his proximity to the scooter caused the rider to lose control and crash the bike.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained minor left and right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. The other vehicle (OV1) sustained minor damage to the left rear fender.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. ground (8 in. raised concrete center median)
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred on Monday in September 2012 at 2245 hours in Southern California. The temperature was 69 degrees F and it was clear with no precipitation. The winds were calm and the asphalt roadway surface was dry and travel worn.

The crash occurred on an East/West, right hand uphill curved, six-lane principal city street with an 8? raised brick and concrete divider, planted with trees and shrubs, in a single family home, residential area. The street has three (3) through travel lanes and a left turn lane in both directions. The grade is 3.7 % with a
2.14 % crown. The radius of the curve is 1503?, the chord is 100?, the middle ordinate is 10?, and the length is 657?. Traffic is controlled by upright and overhanging traffic signals. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

Vehicle 1 (MC1) is a 2004 Honda, CBR 600RR, 599cc, Sport Motorcycle, with 10,300 miles on the odometer, was being operated by a 27 year old white male (5 ft. 11 in., 165 lbs.) who was wearing a full face helmet with a smoke colored face shield at the time of the crash. The rider was eastbound, stopped in the #2 through lane, waiting for the signal to phase green, when he felt an epileptic seizure coming on. Witnesses observed him riding erratically before he stopped at the signal. After pulling away from the intersection, MC1 veered left striking the 8? raised center median, approximately 140 ft. east of the beginning of the median, where the rider fell off and slid forward on his left side for 22 ft. before coming to rest face down. MC1 continued along the curb for approximately 87 ft. before falling and rotating counter clockwise onto its left side.
The rider was subsequently transported to a local hospital where he was treated for his injuries and released.
RiderInj: The 27 year old male rider of the motorcycle had an epileptic seizure and sustained abrasions from his left shoulder to just above his wrist and minor abrasions to his left knee. The rider had taken anti-seizure drugs prior to the crash and had smoked marijuana in the previous 24 hours
Human:
The rider continued to ride MC1 after experiencing the onset of an epileptic seizure, and was smoking marijuana while taking Carbanazepine 
to control his seizures.
Vehicle: There were no pre-existing vehicle condition that contributed to the accident.
Environmental: There were no contributing environmental factors.

CrashType: Other Vehicle (OV1) frontal left side vs. Motorcycle (MC1) rear right side impact causing the MC1 to lose control and slide into Other Vehicle 2 (OV2) before coming to rest. The crash caused minor injuries to the rider. OV1 fled the scene. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a three vehicle hit and run crash. It occurred on a major non-freeway arterial that is close to the freeway and next to an urban high school and a senior living complex. The roadway has a north/south designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway has a northwest/southeast orientation. The roadway in the southbound lanes reduces from two lanes to one and has a left curve. The number one (left lane) is eliminated and forced to merge right with the number two lane. The crash occurred approximately 600? south of the intersection, and beyond the merge markings in the only lane that is marked. This single lane was measured at 18? wide. There are bike lanes and concrete sidewalks on both sides of the roadway. There is a painted divider made up of double yellow lines that is 14? wide. The northbound side has two lanes that open up to four lanes at the intersection. No on-street parking is allowed on either side of the roadway. The asphalt roadway was travel worn and polished, but in very good condition with no evidence of any repair work or the need for any. The crash occurred in Southern California in September 2012 at 1300 hrs. with clear skies and a moderate wind from the north. The approximate temperature was 85 degrees F. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The roadway has a 2.2% downgrade and 0.0% crown for the MC1 at the crash site

The Case Vehicle was a 2004 Yamaha V-Star cruising type motorcycle that was being operated by a 69 year old Caucasian male, (6?00?/210 lbs.). The rider was wearing a partial coverage helmet with a visor and prescription sunglasses. The helmet is rated to FMVSS 218 (US-DOT) standards.

MC1 was southbound in the #1 (left) lane at about 20-30 mph. and slowing by reducing the throttle. His lane was diminishing and he needed to merge to the right. Traffic was heavy with stop and go movement. The rider said that he was passing vehicles on the left and never saw any movement from the vehicle that hit him (OV1). In the police report, he told the police that he saw OV1 starting to turn into his area of travel and that he attempted to swerve left. He said that OV1 impacted the right rear side of the MC (1st Harmful Event), causing damage to the saddle bag and forcing the MC into an out of control CW rotation. The
 
MC high sided and fully ejected the rider, vaulting him above ride height and over the handlebars, breaking the windscreen, then sliding on the paved roadway surface (2nd Harmful Event). The MC slid on its left side plane, high side forward, and impacted OV2 (3rd Harmful Event) to the front left side before coming to rest in the center divider area. The rider sustained contusions to his chest and right thigh, probably as he was ejected from the MC and struck the windscreen and handlebars. He also sustained abrasions from impacting and sliding on the paved roadway surface. The rider slid in the prone position causing abrasions to his elbows and knees. OV1 fled the scene. There was not enough information regarding OV1 for the police to attempt any follow-up. This was a Late Report (19 days). We were unable to reach the rider for several more days. When we inspected the scene, there was no visible evidence. The police report did not record any of the physical evidence. The rider provided some crash scene photos that were included with the report. They show the MC at its? FRP, however there is no good reference point for actual placement. The photos also show an estimated 30? scrape mark from the MC leading to its FRP. A portion of the mark is covered by OV2 that moved to the center divider after the crash. The police report only gives an estimated AOI and makes no mention of the scrape or FRP. There was no reduction in wheelbase for the MC.
RiderInj: The 69 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained contusions and abrasions to his chest, abdomen, elbows, and knees. He was treated at the scene, and then went to a walk in clinic later for additional treatment. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The status of the driver of OV1 is unknown because he/she fled the scene. Based on the dynamics of the crash itself, it is assumed that this driver sustained no injuries. The driver of OV2 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The unknown driver of OV1 was attempting to make an unsafe lane turning maneuver to try and pass vehicles on the left and did not see the MC. The MC rider should have merged into the traffic lane instead of continuing to pass vehicles on the left in the wide lane at the speed he was going
Vehicle:
The motorcycle sustained minor damage to the front fender, windscreen, and both sides. The MC had already been repaired prior to our inspection. The rider provided photos of the damaged MC and still had some of the damaged parts. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was very good. It is not equipped with ABS brakes.OV1 fled the scene and was not inspected.

OV2 was not inspected because the driver never responded. In the photos provided by the MC rider, OV2 appears to be in good condition. Damage to OV2 is not visible.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Asphalt roadway.
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred on Tuesday in September 2012 at 0956 hours in Southern California. The temperature was 73 degrees F and it was clear with no precipitation. The winds were variable at 3.2 mph and the asphalt roadway surface was dry and in good repair.

The crash occurred on an undivided North/South, city street, which is the top of a tee intersection bordered by 8 in. raised concrete curbs, in a residential apartment area. The street is level, with a 4.9 % crown with one 20 ft. wide travel lane in each direction separated by a yellow dashed center line. The posted speed limit is 35 mph and there are no traffic controls.
MC1 is a 2004 Yamaha YZFR6, 599cc, Sport Motorcycle, with 28,078 miles on the odometer, was being operated by a 21 year old Hispanic male (5 ft. 9 in., 190 lbs.) who was wearing a full face helmet with a smoke colored face shield at the time of the crash. OV1 (a non-contact vehicle) is a 2006 Nissan Murano, being operated by a 45 year old Hispanic female (5 ft. 4 in., 150 lbs.) who was wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder
restraint. MC1 was behind OV1 approaching the east/west intersection on the right, both vehicles were southbound. OV1 was positioned to the right of the travel lane, slowing as it approached the intersection, and there was no indication that her turn signals were being used. MC1 attempted to pass OV1 to the left, believing she was going to turn right at the intersection. As MC1 came adjacent with the rear of OV1, OV1 started making a left turn into a private driveway into an apartment complex. MC1 attempted to avoid hitting OV1 by swerving to the left and braking. This caused the handlebars to rotate clockwise, hitting the right side of the gas tank, breaking the right hand throttle/grip off and causing the motorcycle to low slide out onto its left side 7? north of the north curb line and 18? west of the east curb line. There was no contact with OV1. The driver of OV1, completed her left turn into the parking lot and stopped, and she was told by a witness of MC1 and its rider.
RiderInj: The 21 year old male rider of the motorcycle sustained bilateral anterior contusions to the palms of both hands, an abrasion to his right knee, a laceration to his left knee and a contusion to the top of his right foot.
Human: The rider of MC1 didn?t allow enough distance between MC1 and OV1. This coupled with a higher speed than was prudent for conditions, caused the rider of MC1 to apply excessive braking, which caused a low side laydown. The driver of OV1 failed to signal for her left turn and wasn?t adjacent to the center lane line.
Vehicle: There were no pre-existing vehicle condition that contributed to the accident.
Environmental: There were no contributing environmental factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) out of control high speed lay-down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a single MC lay down event in which the rider lost control after landing from a stated 60 mph. wheelie. The crash occurred in September 2012 at 0951 hours on an east/west five lane roadway, 145? west of a four-leg, non-skewed intersection that has posted stop signs for the north/south cross street. The rider was traveling at approximately 246 degrees from North in a westbound direction. The weather was partly cloudy with no wind. The temperature was approximately 76 degrees F. The roadway is a local road that is heavily traveled and bisects a single family residential area. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The asphalt roadway was dry, worn and polished with cracks and raised ridges, and in overall poor condition in the crash area. The defects run longitudinal and transverse and are present in all lanes of travel. The roadway prior to and after the crash area is in better condition. The roadway is straight and level with a 3.5% crown at the crash site. There are sidewalks, trees, and block walls on both sides of the roadway. There is no on-street parking allowed. The rider was wearing a full face MC helmet. The only other safety apparel worn was a pair of armored gloves. The rider stated that when he landed his front tire back onto the roadway, it hit one of the raised ridges in the roadway causing the MC to go into high speed wobble that he referred to as a ?tank slapper? in which the handlebars violently swing back and forth to their maximum turning radius. The rider could not estimate how long this event lasted before the MC flipped over and fully ejected him.

The Case Vehicle was a 2000 Honda CBR 600 F4 sport/racing style motorcycle that was being operated by a 20 year old male, (5? 11?/170 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face with integral chin bar with a gray/smoke tinted face shield. The helmet is rated to FMVSS 218/DOT and Snell M2010 standards.

The case MC was westbound in the #2 (inside) lane at about the posted speed limit in second gear. Traffic was light to moderate. The rider said that he was attentive and not distracted. He then decided to rapidly accelerate and raise the front tire off the ground. In doing so, he said that he attained the speed of approximately 60 mph. when he began to red line on the RPMs. He then had to slow down and put the front tire back onto the roadway. In doing so, the front tire landed on a ridge in the roadway which caused the MC to lose control (first harmful event). The ridge that was located at the marked area of impact in the police report runs transverse and is about one inch in height. The MC flipped and tumbled down the roadway in an unknown dynamic. The MC had damage to
 
all sides, including the top/seat area. Prior to the crash while the MC was in the high speed wobble, the rider said that he tried to accelerate again and raise the front tire off the ground in an attempt to regain control. When the MC flipped, the rider was fully ejected and slid mostly on his back. He was wearing a back pack with a change of clothes inside. The back pack was destroyed from sliding on the roadway surface, but protected the rider from sustaining some injuries. The laceration that the rider sustained on his chin was possibly caused by the windscreen as the rider was ejected. The rider told the police that there was a vehicle in front of him that had slowed down. He applied his front brake, causing it to lock and he lost control and crashed. One scrape was located at the scene. It was about 18? long. It was found in the painted center divider area and was very faint. I could not determine whether or not it was made from the crash MC based on its location, which was approximately 15? west of the first harmful event. There were no other supporting scrapes/gouges to help in determining the path of the MC after falling onto the roadway. The scrape was photographed, but not included in the diagram. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a minor laceration to his chin, and minor abrasions to his elbows, the left hip/buttocks area, and right knee. He was treated at the scene, and then transported to a hospital where he was treated and released. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: There was no OV involved.
Human: The 20 year old male rider of the MC1 had a decision failure by choosing to ride in an unsafe and aggressive manner. He had a reaction failure due to his speed.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major damage to all sides, including the seat. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was fair. It is not equipped with ABS brakes, which most likely would not have helped prevent the crash. The exhaust system was an after-market type that is a high performance style with excessive noise. It had been modified to make even more noise by drilling out internal parts and making more vents for the exhaust to escape (see photos # MC023 and MC027).
Environmental: The poor condition of the roadway could be a contributing factor based only on the riders statements as to how the crash occurred. In a normal riding manner, the roadway would most likely not cause a crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC) vs. Other Vehicle (OV1) frontal right to left rear impact with secondary lay down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC right-frontal impact to the left rear corner of OV1 that was stopped for another vehicle ahead. The non-contacted vehicle was making a right turn into a driveway. The crash occurred on a non-freeway principal arterial just west of a three-leg, not skewed driveway type intersection. There are five through lanes; two in each direction with a continuous two-way left turn center lane. The roadway has an east/west dedication with a slight left curve at the crash site. The MC was headed east with an approximate 44 degrees compass heading. The rider stated he was going about 20 mph and in 3rd gear and was about to down-shift when suddenly traffic in front of him stopped. The rider made unsuccessful collision avoidance maneuvers. After impact, the MC landed on its
left side plane, front tire forward in an easterly direction and impacted OV1. The rider was fully ejected when the MC went to the ground. The rider said that he jumped off the MC then tumbled/rolled approximately 20? and landed on his feet like a gymnast. The rider also said that he never hit the OV and that the
crash was a low side wash-out due too excessive braking and the recently paved roadway surface that was slick with oil from the asphalt mixture. The surrounding area is commercial/retail on both sides of the road. The crash took place in the #2 (right) lane. The crash occurred in Southern California in September 2012 during hours of daylight at 1420 hours. The weather was clear with a light wind from the SSW giving the rider a slight tailwind. The approximate temperature was 70 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry and recently paved. The roadway has a 0.8% upgrade and a 1.9% crown at the crash site. Both sides of the roadway have 5? concrete sidewalks, trees, and street light poles. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

The Case Vehicle was a 2005 Buell sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 50 year old male, (5?03?/120 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face motorcycle helmet with an integral chin bar and clear face shield. The helmet is rated to FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell M2010 standards. The rider was also wearing MC style glove and boots.

The case MC was eastbound in the #2 (right) lane at about 30 mph. and in 3rd gear. Traffic was heavy, but moving. The rider saw that the signal ahead was
 
green and that overall, the traffic was flowing. He did not see the vehicle one ahead of the OV that was being driven by a 44 year old female (5?04?/125 lbs.) that was slowing to make a right turn into a driveway which caused traffic to stop. The rider said he applied too much front brake, causing the wheel to lock up and start to skid. He said that he released the front brake before losing control and then applied the rear brake, with the same result. He released the rear brake and decided to attempt to split lanes to avoid rear-ending the OV. The rider said that another vehicle that was in the #1 lane had drifted a little to the right, closing the gap for him to be able to lane split. It appears that the rider used poor braking techniques (locking the brakes) and due to the fresh, oily asphalt he lost control in his attempt to swerve and lane split and impacted the left rear of OV1 with the right handlebar, causing MC1 to go down. After impact, the rider jumped/was ejected off the MC and rolled/tumbled to his feet. This was a Late Report (7 days). There was no physical evidence at the crash site when the police where there per the police report. We found no evidence when we inspected the scene. There was no reduction in wheelbase.
RiderInj: The 50 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions and contusions to his arms, left shoulder/back area, and his left hip. He was treated at the scene, and then transported to a hospital where he was treated and released. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The 50 year old male operator of the MC was driving too fast for the prevailing traffic/road conditions. He then had a reaction failure. The rider of the MC was otherwise alert and not distracted.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor damage to the left side from impacting and sliding on the roadway. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was very good. The MC is not equipped with ABS brakes. The OV was not inspected due to lack of response from the OV driver. Damage is listed as minor in the police report. Its pre-crash condition is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing critical injuries.
MV1: 1984 Honda CB700sc Nighthawk conventional street bike (697cc), black in color
OV1: 2009 Volkswagen Tiguan (SAV) automobile, white in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury traffic collision. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight on Wednesday in September 2012 at 0626 hours in Southern California. Sunrise was at 0643 hours. The weather report for 0653 hours indicated overcast skies, with a calm wind and, an ambient temperature of 68.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface for the motorcycle MC1 was level with a 4.7% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an at-grade intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 68 feet. The roadway is straight and runs east to west with two lanes dedicated for eastbound and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic. There are designated left turn lanes to regulate both east and westbound traffic onto the intersecting commercial/residential street at this intersection.

This intersecting local street has an overall travel-way of 66 feet on the north side of the intersection and, 73 feet on the south side of the intersection. The intersection is controlled in all four directions by posted traffic signals.
The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted double yellow line lane markers. The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 1984 Honda CB700sc Nighthawk (697cc) conventional street motorcycle being operated by a 27 year old male rider. The rider was travelling at a speed of about 40 mph, westbound in the designated #1 westbound lane of the minor arterial surface street approaching the signal controlled intersection. The light for his direction of travel had been green during his approach.
OV1 was a 2009 Volkswagen Tiguan (SAV) automobile being operated by a 63 year old female. OV1was approaching eastbound in the designated left turn lane, and the driver had initially stopped for approaching westbound traffic while waiting to make a left turn to proceed northbound. When the driver of OV1 presumed it safe to proceed, she accelerated her vehicle and initiated a left turn movement through the intersection. The driver kept a constant speed while
 
making the left turn movement however, failed to notice the rider and motorcycle MC1 approaching in the #1 lane.
The rider collided with the center front portion of OV1 causing the motorcycle to collapse onto the right side. The rider was subsequently ejected off the motorcycle across the front left portion of the engine hood. The rider vaulted off OV1 a distance of approximately 61 feet impacting with the roadway surface. He continued across the roadway surface impacting with a raised concrete curb and sidewalk over a distance of 24 feet coming to rest on the sidewalk.

The motorcycle slid to a stop at its final resting place about 44 feet away toward the northwest corner of the intersection. The other vehicle OV1 rolled to a stop approximately 26 feet north of the area of impact. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 27 year old male operator of MC1 sustained critical injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were that of a broken back, collapsed lung and broken legs. The rider was immediately removed from the scene to a local hospital for treatment. There is no further information available on the extent of injuries.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries.
Human:
The rider of MC1 could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of OV1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver.
The driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision to turn having failed to perceive the presence of the approaching motorcycle while making her left turn movement.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained total damage as a result of impacting with the center front portion of OV1.
OV1 sustained moderate front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile turning left.
MV1: 2006 Suzuki, SV650, 649 cc, sport/race replica, white in color
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in September 2012 on a Friday morning at 0920 hours in Southern California. It was light and the weather was partly cloudy, the temperature was between 74 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn and the traffic was light.

The crash occurred at a busy four-leg skewed intersection/interchange. The speed limit is 35 mph, the northbound off-ramp lanes consist of one left turn lane and two right turn lanes. Eastbound lanes consist of one on-ramp left turn lane and two through lanes. Westbound lanes consist of three through lanes and one on-ramp right turn lane. There are traffic controls present and all traffic controls were functioning correctly. The intersection is located in a commercial area, bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The northbound off-ramp is straight and has a downgrade of 3.1% and a crown of 2.75%, The eastbound roadway has a 73 ft. right curve with a 209 ft. radius and has an uphill grade of 1% and a crown of 2.1%.
Vehicle 1 (MC1), is a 2006 Suzuki, SV650, 649 cc, sport/race replica, white in color, ridden by a 28 year old Hispanic/American Indian male who is 5 ft. 11 in. and 194 lbs. The rider was wearing a full facial coverage, integral chin bar and face shield style of helmet. Vehicle 2 (OV1), is a 2003 Infinity, G35, black in color, driven by a 49 year old white male who is 6 ft. 1 in. and 250 lbs. The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling northbound at approximately 25 mph in the left turn-through lane, intending to turn left at the intersection. Before he made his turn, the traffic signal phased red. OV1 was stopped in the eastbound left turn lane waiting to make a left turn. The eastbound traffic had a full phase green tri-light and the westbound traffic had a red phase tri-light and red arrow. OV1 made a left turn on the green phase arrow across the path of MC1. MC1 struck the right front bumper of OV1. Area of impact was 17 ft. 8 in. southeast of the north curb line of the east/west street, and 21 ft. 1 in. southwest of the west curb line of the northbound onramp.
RiderInj: The 28 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injury, as related by traffic collision report: Left lower leg avulsion. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was one. he 49 year-old driver of OV1 sustained the following
Human: The 28 year-old male rider of MC1 failed to yield the right of way to OV1.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: : The setback of OV1?s left turn lane combined with the vehicles in the eastbound through lanes contributed to blocking OV1 driver?s view of MC1.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing fatal injuries.
MV1: 2012 Yamaha YZF R6 (sport race replica), 600cc, blue in color
OV1: 2003 Buick Century (4 door sedan) automobile, silver in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle fatal traffic collision. The collision occurred on Sunday in September 2012 at 0846 hours in Southern California. Sunrise was at 0649 hours. The weather report for 0646 hours showed clear skies, with calm wind conditions and, an ambient temperature of 75.9 degrees F. Visibility was 10.0 miles and at ground level it was clear and unobstructed in all directions. On approach to the intersection the roadway surface for the motorcycle (MC1) had a 1.0% downhill grade with a 5.0% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an at-grade intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 80 feet. The roadway is straight and runs east to west with three lanes dedicated for eastbound and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic. There is a designated two-way left turn lane to regulate both east and westbound traffic onto the intersecting commercial/industrial driveway entrances at this intersection.

On the north side of the intersection is a 29 foot wide entry and exit for a commercial/industrial center used for weekend religious services. There are no traffic control devices along the north or south side of the intersection. On the south side of the intersection is a 40 foot wide commercial/industrial driveway with no regulatory traffic controls.

East of the intersection the opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted double yellow line lane marker. Wes of the intersection there are also painted double yellow lines forming a 10 foot wide median between opposing lanes. The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 40 mph.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2012 Yamaha YZF R6 (600cc) sport race replica motorcycle being operated by a 25 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was travelling at an estimated speed of approximately 40/50 mph, westbound in the designated #1 westbound lane of the arterial surface street approaching the
 
intersection.

The other vehicle (OV1) was a 2003 Buick Century automobile (4 door sedan) being operated by an 87 year old female Caucasian. The other vehicle (OV1) was approaching eastbound in the designated two way left turn lane. The driver had been moving slowly forward waiting to make a left turn to proceed northbound into the driveway of the complex. The driver of the other vehicle had seen the approach of the motorcycle (MC1) in the #2 lane however felt she had sufficient time to make her left turn movement. The other driver accelerated her vehicle and initiated a left turn movement into the intersection. The driver accelerated to an approximate speed of 12 mph while making the left turn movement however, failed to notice the rider of the motorcycle (MC1) initiating a right lane departure from the #2 lane to the #3 lane.

The rider attempted to brake however struck the right side of the other vehicle at the front passenger door. The motorcycle collapsed onto the roadway surface right side down. The rider was subsequently ejected off the motorcycle. The rider vaulted onto the engine hood of OV1 and subsequently rolled or was launched off the vehicle impacting with the roadway surface inside the driveway area a distance of 23 feet 6 inches. The other vehicle continued its forward movement into the complex until it came to rest after hitting a pole some 74 feet from the initial crash site.

The motorcycle came to rest within 6 feet of the initial area of impact. The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) (the sole occupant) remained in her vehicle until law enforcement officials arrived at the scene.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj:
The 25 year old male Caucasian operator of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained fatal injuries as a result of the collision. The rider was immediately removed from
the scene to a local hospital for treatment however was pronounced dead on arrival. The 87 year old female driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained no injuries.
Human:
The 25 year old male Caucasian operator of the motorcycle (MC1) could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of the other vehicle (OV1) to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver.
The 87 year old female Caucasian driver of the other vehicle (OV1) made an unsafe decision having failed to perceive the proximity of the approaching motorcycle while making her left turn movement.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle (MC1) sustained major front end damage as a result of impacting with the right side portion of other vehicle (OV1).
The other vehicle (OV1) sustained major right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Scooter turning left vs. Automobile.
MV1: 2007 Yamaha, C3, 49 cc, scooter, gray in color
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred on Monday in October 2012, at 1550 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the weather was clear; the temperature was 90 degrees F and the winds were light and variable. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, travel worn and the traffic was light.

The crash occurred in a commercial area, on an east/west undivided state highway with 2 lanes in each direction, that was bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The speed limit is 35 mph. The westbound lanes are straight with a downgrade of 4.6 % and a crown of 8.9 %.

Vehicle 1 (MC1), is a 2007 Yamaha, C3, 49 cc, scooter, gray in color, ridden by a 58 year old Hispanic male who is 5 ft. 7 in. and 185 lbs. The rider was wearing a full facial coverage, integral chin bar style of helmet, without a face shield. Vehicle 2 (OV1) is a 2002 Toyota Tundra (green in color), driven by a 58 year old white male who is 5 ft. 10 in. and 195 lbs. The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling southbound and had pulled out of a commercial driveway making a left turn to go eastbound, as he started to cross the westbound lanes; he stopped and put both feet on the ground, straddling the painted lane line of the #1 and 2 lanes. OV1 was westbound in the #1 lane at approximately 35 mph, when MC1 stopped in front of him. The driver of OV1 braked and swerved to the left, striking MC1 in the left front fork area with the front right side
bumper. This caused MC1 to spin clockwise and land on its right side approximately 6 ft. 7 in. west and 4 ft. 2 in. north of the Point of Impact (POI). The rider of MC1 was launched westbound approximately 11ft. 4 in. from the POI. Area of impact was 344 ft. east of the east curb line of the north/south street and 19 ft. south of the north curb line of the east/west state highway.
RiderInj: The 58 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained a laceration to his nose and right forearm. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 2.
Human: The 58 year-old male rider of MC1 failed to yield the right of way to OV1.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) Hit & Run injury traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider on to the roadway causing critical injuries. The driver of OV1 fled the scene after the crash.
MV1: 2008 Harley Davidson Sportster (cruiser) 1200cc, dark red in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle hit & run injury traffic collision. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight on Wednesday, October 2012 at 1637 hours in Southern California. Sunrise was at 1649 hours. The weather report for 0653 hours showed scattered clouds, with SW winds at 6.9 mph and, an ambient temperature of 75.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. On approach to the intersection the roadway surface for the motorcycle (MC1) had a 3.9% downhill grade with a 4.7% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 96 feet. The roadway is straight and runs east to west with three lanes dedicated for eastbound and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic.
There are designated ?left turn? lanes to regulate both east and westbound traffic onto the intersecting commercial/industrial streets at this intersection.
On the north side of the intersection is a 57 foot wide entry and exit for a commercial shopping center. The only traffic control device along the north side of the intersection is a posted stop sign for traffic leaving the complex onto the public roadway. On the south side of the intersection is a 60 foot wide industrial street with a posted stop sign for northbound traffic. Other than the two aforementioned stop signs, this intersection is uncontrolled.
East of the intersection the opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted double yellow line lane marker. West of the intersection there are also painted double yellow lines forming a 10 foot wide median between opposing lanes. The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2008 Harley Davidson Sportster (1200cc) cruiser style street motorcycle being operated by a 29 year old female rider. The rider was travelling at a speed of approximately 40 mph, westbound in the designated #3 lane of the minor arterial surface street approaching the uncontrolled intersection.
OV1 was a 2002 Lexus RX300 (SAV) automobile being operated by a 75 year old male driver. OV1was approaching eastbound in the designated left turn lane, and the driver had initially stopped in second position behind another vehicle (Witness #3) waiting to make the same left turn movement. Westbound traffic east of the intersection was congested and stopped in both the #1 and #2 lanes however, the #3 westbound lane was clear for vehicular travel. The driver
 
ahead of OV1 had moved into the intersection and began to cross in front of the stopped westbound traffic in the #1 & #2 lanes however, stopped prior to crossing the westbound #3 lane. The driver of OV1 suddenly became impatient and moved out from behind the other vehicle, turning inside the other vehicles turning radius to proceed through the intersection and towards the shopping center parking lot. The driver of OV1 continued to accelerate across the westbound lanes failing to notice the approach of MC1 in the westbound #3 lane. As OV1 crossed into the #3 lane, the front end of OV1 was stuck by MC1.
There appeared to be no evidence of pre or post impact skid marks from either vehicle.
Both MC1 and the rider collided with the center front portion of OV1 causing the motorcycle to collapse right side down.
The rider was subsequently ejected off the motorcycle and vaulted an approximate distance of 37 feet onto the roadway surface until coming to rest adjacent to the north raised concrete curb.
MC1 continued in a northwesterly direction sliding across the roadway surface up over the concrete sidewalk and onto a raised grassy area. MC1 had moved an approximate distance of 45 feet before coming to rest. The driver of OV1 initially pulled over and proceeded to make contact with the rider. He apologized to her, went back to his vehicle and left the area. The driver of OV1 was subsequently apprehended by law enforcement officials.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 29 year old female rider of MC1 sustained critical injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were a severely injured left leg which was subsequently amputated during surgery and undisclosed upper torso trauma. The rider was immediately removed from the scene to a local hospital for admission and treatment. There was no evidence of alcohol and/or drug use.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. There was no evidence of alcohol and/or drug use.
Human: The 29 year old female operator of MC1 could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of OV1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver. The 75 year old male driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision to move his vehicle into the intersection having failed to perceive the presence of MC1 and made an unsafe decision to turn left across the intersection prior to the crash.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage as a result of impacting with the center front portion of OV1 and the roadway surface however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1sustained minor front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC) vs. Other Vehicle (OV1) frontal to front right side impact with secondary lay down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC frontal impact to the front right side of OV1 that was making a left or U-turn in front of the MC. The crash occurred on a non-freeway principle arterial at a three-leg, not skewed driveway type intersection. There are five through lanes, two in each direction with a two-way left turn center lane. At the crash site, the OV had a dedicated left turn lane for its direction of travel that breaks up the continuous two way center lane. The roadway has a north/south dedication, however, at the crash site, the roadway has a northwest/southeast orientation. The MC rotated slightly in a CCW direction after impact and landed on its right side plane, high side forward and in a northwesterly direction. The rider was fully ejected and flew above ride height to the curb area on the
right side of the roadway, coming to rest approximately 14? away from the First Harmful event. The OV was making either a left turn or a U-turn when the crash occurred. After impact, the OV continued in a U-turn manner and went up the curb and hit a roadside no parking sign before coming to rest. The OV was partially on the sidewalk and in the street. On the rider?s right is commercial buildings and motels. On the left, there is a railroad easement and a public
beach. Parallel on-street parking is allowed on the left side of the roadway. The crash took place in the #2 right lane. The crash occurred in Southern California in October 2012 during hours of daylight at 1545 hours. The weather was clear with a light wind from the southwest. The approximate temperature was 76 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has a 1.0% upgrade at the crash site. Both sides of the roadway have 8? concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit is 45 mph

The Case Vehicle was a 2007 Harley Davidson Road King Classic cruising type motorcycle that was being operated by a 28 year old Caucasian male, (6?00?/190 lbs.). The rider was not wearing motorcycle oriented protective apparel. He was wearing heavy work type boots. His half helmet is rated to FMVSS-218 (US DOT) standards.

MC1 was northbound in the #1 (left) lane at about the posted speed limit. Traffic was moderate. The rider saw the OV enter the left turn lane in the opposite direction and felt that it was going to do something. He let off on the throttle and changed lanes to the right. As he approached OV1, it suddenly turned in front
 
of him. He panic braked, locking the front tire. He said he released the brakes and re-applied them leaving approximately 16? of front wheel locked skid (per the police report) before impacting OV1 on the right front side. The front forks of the MC went rearward and made contact with the frame/engine causing a reduction in wheelbase of approximately 9.5?. MC1 slid a short distance on its right side plane, high side first. While the MC was on its right side, some fuel leaked from the gas cap. Both the tank and cap were fully retained on the MC. The gas tank sustained very minor damage as a result of the impact. The fuel seeped out from the gas cap area and peeled the paint. Two of the three witnesses thought that the driver of OV1 was attempting to flee the scene. The rider said that he remembers being on the sidewalk area near the edge of the driveway being attended to by paramedics. The rider was unsure if he lost consciousness. The rider said he was attentive and not distracted while riding. He was focused on his riding, looking forward, and not suffering from any ailments.
RiderInj: The 28 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained a right side pubic rami fracture, a proximal fracture of the right humerus, and a concussion. He was treated at the scene, and then transported to a hospital where he was admitted for 9 days. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The 72 year old female Caucasian operator of the OV had a perception failure per the police report. She did not respond to requests for an interview. The rider of the MC was alert and not distracted.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained major damage to the front end and minor damage to the right side. The pre-crash condition of the motorcycle was very good, like new. It is not equipped with ABS brakes. We were unable to inspect OV1. Its condition prior to and after the crash is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle OV1, rear end crash with a lay-down event prior to impact. The motorcycle rider sustained fatal injuries as a result of impacting the right rear portion of OV1. OV1 had been stopped on the roadway (facing westbound in the eastbound lane) prior to the crash due to the presence of a previous crash that had blocked traffic in both directions. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2004 Suzuki GSXR 750cc (sport race replica), blue & white
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle rear impact crash resulting in fatal injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Saturday in October 2012 at 1218 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed mostly cloudy skies, a SW wind direction at 5.8 mph, and an ambient temperature of +78.1 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured -3.3 % downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on an undivided left curve two lane rural highway with an overall travel-way width of 28 feet. The east and westbound lanes each have a common width of 10 feet. There are no designated bike lanes in the area however there is a designated safety lane along the eastbound side of the highway approximately 8 feet wide. Along the west side of the highway is a painted white lane or fog line with no available safety area. The area of the left curve travelled by MC1 had a super elevation of +2.34 feet.

The east and westbound lanes of the highway are separated by one set of painted solid double yellow lane stripes spaced 12 inches apart. There are no adjoining cross streets in the area. There is however, traffic turn outs provided for slower moving vehicles both east and west of the location of the crash site.


At the location of the crash site there were no traffic control devices to regulate the flow of traffic. The speed limit on this street is 55 mph for both directions of travel. Both the east and west sides of the highway are bordered by a composition of soft dirt and gravel shoulders. Along the eastbound side of the highway is a large nearly vertical earth & rock cliff face rising above the roadway surface in excess of 40 to 50 feet.

Along the westbound side of the highway upon approach to the crash site is nearly vertical earth & rock embankment approximately 30 feet in height. At the crash site there is a guardrail style traffic barricade extending parallel alongside the roadway a length of approximately 50 feet. This barricade is followed up by a 4 foot tall concrete wall that extends several hundred feet along the contour of the roadway surface. Beyond this concrete wall is a significant (100 foot)drop off into a ravine.
The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2004 Suzuki GSXR 750cc (sport race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 29 year old male black rider. The rider was wearing a helmet during his operation of the motorcycle at the time of the crash event however it was unavailable for inspection. The make and model is unknown.

The rider was travelling westbound on the highway at a high rate of speed prior to the crash event. Reports from Law Enforcement officials indicated that the rider had been riding with another motorcyclist when the crash occurred. In fact, the other motorcyclist also crashed however sustained minor injuries when impacting with the guardrail and wall.

As the rider continued westbound into the left curve there was limited visibility due to the curvature of this section of the highway. As the rider rounded the curve he came upon the stopped traffic occupying both the east and westbound lanes directly in front of him. The rider attempted a lane departure to the left entering the eastbound lane of the highway. The motorcycle collapsed onto the roadway surface right side down. Both the rider and motorcycle stayed together until impacting with the right rear surface area of the other vehicle (OV1). After impacting with OV1 the motorcycle rotated off the vehicle coming to rest along the south side of the highway. The location of the rider was within 6 feet of the area of impact with OV1.

The rider appeared to have been caught between the motorcycle gas tank and the other vehicle upon impact. The resulting impact was sufficient to cause fatal injuries in the thoracic area of the rider?s body. At the time of the collision law enforcement and state highway employees were working another traffic collision ahead of this collision. There was a significant highway obstruction with stopped vehicles occupying the westbound lanes of the highway. Both east and westbound lanes had been shut down at the time.
RiderInj: The 29 year old male rider of the motorcycle (MC1) sustained fatal injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were predominately in the area of the head and thoracic region of the body with multiple internal injuries. On the attached Injury Form there were (10) entries recorded identifying injuries sustained by the rider. The Coroner?s report indicated ante-mortem blood/alcohol levels at .10.
Human: The 29 year old male rider of the motorcycle (MC1) was driving at a high rate of speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained moderate front and right side damage. The gas tank sustained major crush damage along the top surface however, the motorcycle appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motor scooter vs. Light truck turning left.
MV1: 2008 Zhong, Milan 150 SSR, 149 cc, step-through scooter, blue in color
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in October 2012 on a Tuesday afternoon at 1635 hours in Southern California. It was light and the weather was clear, the temperature was approximately 80 degrees F and the winds were light and variable. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn and the traffic was moderate.

The crash occurred at a T-intersection. The north/south roadway forms the top of the T and has a speed limit of 45 mph, there are 2 travel lanes in each direction divided by a 10 ft. wide painted median with a southbound left turn lane for the east/west roadway. The east side is bordered by apartments and the west side is bordered by railroad tracks. The east/west roadway is undivided with 1 travel lane in each direction, is east of the north/south street, and forms the base of the T. The south side is bordered by apartments and the north side is bordered by commercial buildings. There are no traffic controls present on the north/south roadway; there is a stop sign for westbound traffic, and it was clearly visible. The north/south roadway is straight and has a
northbound grade of 0.7% and a crown of 2.8%, the westbound roadway has a 101 ft. right hand curve with a 369 ft. radius and has an downhill grade of 1% and a crown of 2.7%.

MC1 is a 2008 Zhong Milan 150 SSR 149 cc step-through scooter, ridden by a 48 year old male, (5 ft. 8 in. and 160 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full facial coverage, integral chin bar and face shield style of helmet. OV1 is a 2004 Toyota Tacoma, driven by a 59 year old male (6 ft. 1 in. and 250 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

The rider of MC1 was traveling northbound, at approximately 45 mph, in #1 lane, slightly behind a vehicle in the #2 lane making a right turn at the intersection. OV1 was stopped at the limit line of the westbound lane, waiting to make a left turn. The driver of OV1 saw the vehicle slow to make the right turn at the intersection, thought northbound traffic was clear, looked for southbound traffic, then proceeded to make his left turn. As OV1 crossed into the #1 northbound lane, it was struck in the left front wheel/fender by MC1. The vehicle turning right at the intersection, may have blocked OV1?s view of MC1. Area of impact was approximately 44 ft. 6 in. east of the west curb line of the north/south roadway and approximately 19 ft. 6 in. north of the south curb line of the east/west roadway.
RiderInj: The 48 year-old male rider of MC1 died after 5 days of hospitalization. The injury information was taken from the certificate of death and the police report: cardiopulmonary arrest, anoxic brain injury, cervical spine injury, back and chest injury. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 999.
Human: The 59 year-old male driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: OV1?s view of MC1 may have been blocked by the vehicle turning right at the intersection from the northbound #2 lane as he started his left turn across the north/south roadway.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. bicycle broadside type crash event with a secondary lay down of the motorcycle onto the roadway surface as well as the bicyclist. The crash resulted in serious injuries to both parties involved.
Crash:
This motorcycle crash event involved a bicyclist exiting a designated Bike Lane. The collision occurred on Saturday at 1129 hours in October 2012 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1805 hours. The Weather Underground report for 1153 hours showed clear skies, with SW winds at 4.6 mph and, an ambient temperature of 82.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface for MC1 presented an downhill grade of 6.4% with a 9.8% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished with numerous parallel and perpendicular "tar snakes? but, was otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a +5.25 foot super elevation present with this portion of the roadway.
The collision occurred at an at-grade T-intersection of a rural highway with an overall travel-way width of 42 feet. The north/south running roadway has a right curve facing southbound traffic on approach to the intersection. There is one lane dedicated for southbound and one lane dedicated for northbound traffic.
There is a designated Bike Lane adjacent to the northbound lane 10 feet in width. There is also another designated Bike Lane adjacent to the southbound lane 8 foot in width.
The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted double yellow line lane markers. The roadway is also bordered on both sides by earth & rock soft shoulders. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 55 mph.
The intersecting local street has an overall travel-way of 30 feet on the west side of the intersection and, 37 feet on the east side of the intersection. The intersection is controlled only by a STOP marking in the westbound lane prior to the stop line. There are no other traffic controls or designated turn lanes at this intersection.

MC1 was a 2008 Suzuki DR650 SE dual purpose on/off road motorcycle (644cc) being operated by a 48 year old male. The rider was travelling southbound at a speed of about 50 to 55 mph, of the local street approaching the intersection.
The bicyclist; a 50 year old male was riding a Santa Cruz ?Tall Boy? style touring bicycle. The bicyclist was riding southbound in the designated Bike Lane adjacent to the southbound lane of traffic that MC1 was travelling. As the bicyclist approached the T-intersection, he initiated a left turn type movement from the Bike Lane crossing the southbound lane in front of MC1. The bicyclist apparently made no effort to check for approaching traffic as he crossed the highway.
 
The motorcycle rider attempted to wave off the bicyclist but with no success.
MC1 struck the bicycle in a broadside type impact at the location of the rear wheel. The resulting impact ejected both the motorcyclist and the bicyclist on to the roadway surface. Both vehicles collapsed on to the roadway as well. MC1 came to rest approximately 198? south of the area of impact right side down. The bicycle had been moved off the roadway prior to emergency service arrival.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 46 year old male rider of MC1 sustained serious injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries included but were not limited to a subdural hematoma, OIS III lacerated spleen and a numerous fractured bones. The rider was treated at the scene and admitted for extended hospitalization. The rider had no recollection of the crash events when questioned by law enforcement investigators.
ODriverInj: The 50 year old bicyclist sustained serious injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries included but were not limited to a subarachnoid hemorrhage, pulmonary contusion and a lacerated spleen. The bicyclist was treated at the scene and admitted for extended hospitalization. The bicyclist had no recollection of the crash events when question by law enforcement investigators.
Human:
The 46 year old rider of MC1 had insufficient time in order to conduct a collision avoidance maneuver do to his proximity to the bicyclist.
The 50 year old male bicyclist failed to yield the right of way to MC1 while negotiating a left turn movement across the southbound lane of the roadway.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor front end and right side damage as a result of impacting with the bicycle and roadway surface otherwise it was in satisfactory operating condition.
OV1 (bicycle) sustained left side damage.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. fixed object (concrete lamp post), DUI involvement.
MV1: 2013 Harley Davidson, 1201 cc, Sportster Forty Eight.
Crash:
This fatal motorcycle crash occurred on Wednesday in October 2012 at 2055 hours in Southern California. It was dark and the roadway was lighted by overhead street lights. The temperature was 57.9 degrees F; it was partly cloudy with no precipitation and the winds calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry with surface cracking and ridges.

The crash occurred on a north/south residential street made up of single family homes with numerous adult/child pedestrians. There is one 22 ft. lane in each direction, divided by painted double yellow stripes, the downhill southbound grade is 2.9% and the crown is 0.5%. There are no traffic controls at this area
and the posted speed limit is 30 mph.
 MC1 a, 2013 Harley Davidson 1201 cc Sportster Forty Eight, was being operated by a 28 year old male (6 ft. 2 in., 160 lbs.) who was wearing a DOT approved open face helmet without face shield at the time of the crash. The rider was proceeding southbound at an estimated speed of approximately 60 mph. Due to the drugs/alcohol in his system and his high rate of speed, MC1 failed to negotiate the left hand turn, hitting the west curb face at approximately a 10 deg. angle. MC1 continued south along the curb face for approximately 40 ft., at which time the rider struck a cement light pole, which pulled him from MC1. ?Riderless?, MC1 continued south, angling into the northbound lane for approximately 208 ft. before striking OV1 which was a 2007 Nissan Titan light truck. OV1 was being operated by a 21 year old male (5 ft. 8 in., 165 lbs.) who was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints. MC1 impacted OV1 on the front left and left side and came to rest approximately 72 ft. farther south between the north/south lanes. The rider came to rest in the southbound lane approximately 41 ft; oriented in a southerly direction.
RiderInj: The 28 year old male rider of the MC1 succumbed to his injuries at the hospital, with an AIS score of 14, as a result of: Open fractures to the right femur, right proximal humerus and right ankle, closed fractures to the pelvis, right ulna/radius and right 2nd metacarpal, multiple liver and kidney lacerations, descending colon laceration, retro peritoneum hemorrhage and multiple lacerations/contusions to the exterior skin. The rider was under the influence of drugs and alcohol at the time of the crash
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was uninjured.
Human: The rider was operating MC1 at an unsafe speed while under the influence of drugs and alcohol.
Vehicle: There are no motorcycle crash causal factors.
Environmental: At night the southbound sudden downgrade combined with the left turn at its beginning, was an environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC) vs. two Other Vehicles (OV1 and OV2) left side sideswipe to right side sideswipe to lay-down event with fuel spill and fire. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC left side-swipe impact to the right side of OV1 that was drifting to its right while MC1 was lane splitting between OV1 and OV2. When OV1 hit MC1, the rider lost control and went down. MC1 then got caught under the left rear wheels of OV2. The gas tank had a failure causing the fuel to leak out. As the MC1 was being crushed and dragged on its right side plane, front end forward, sparks ignited the fuel causing a fire that completely destroyed MC1 and damaged OV2. The First Harmful event occurred on a non-freeway principle arterial at an estimated 220 feet south of a four-leg, not skewed intersection. Traffic was flowing slowly at the time. According to the rider, traffic was moving along at about 15 mph. He stated he was lane-splitting at 25-30 mph. The driver of OV1 stated she never saw MC1 until after she pulled over and stopped. She thought that she had been hit by OV2. There are six through lanes, three in each
direction with a curb high raised center median. The roadway runs in a north/south orientation.
