The rider of MC1 said that he was fully ejected and landed in the roadway behind the MC and was able to avoid being run over by OV2. Both MC1 and OV2 stopped in the northbound #2 lane where the fire occurred. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial businesses on both side of the roadway. No on-street parking is allowed. The First Harmful event took place in the #1 lane. The crash occurred in Southern California in October 2012 at 1922 hours. It was dark and the area was lit by overhead street lights. The weather
was cloudy/partly cloudy with a light wind from the south-southwest. The approximate temperature was 65 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has is flat and level (0.3 % upgrade) and a 4.8 % crown at the crash site. Both sides of the roadway have 9? concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2009 Suzuki GSXR sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 19 year old male, (5? 01?; 215 lbs.). The rider was wearing a Shoei full face helmet with a clear face shield. The helmet is rated to FMVSS 218 (DOT) and Snell M2010 standards.

MC1 was northbound legally lane-splitting between the #1 (left) lane and the #2 (middle) lane. Traffic was heavy but flowing at a stated speed of 10-15 mph.
 
The rider was traveling at a stated speed of 25-30 mph. which could be considered an unsafe speed for conditions. The driver of OV1 drifted to her right as MC1 was starting to pass on the right. The rider stated that he had no warning that OV1 was coming into his shared space. When OV1 hit MC1, the rider said that
he immediately lost control and went down. The MC landed on its right side plane and then was run over by OV2 which stopped on MC1. The front forks were separated from the rest of the MC. The gas tank on MC1 was crushed and leaked all of its fuel which then caught fire. MC1 was melted down to a worthless heap. The rider sustained minor injuries. The drivers of OV1 and OV2 never responded to calls/letters. Attempts to locate OV2 which was a rental vehicle were unsuccessful. We inspected what was left of MC1. We were unable to rotate the rear tire due to severe damage. We were unable to locate any evidence of skidding on either tire. There was no evidence on the roadway of any tire marks from any of the vehicles involved. There were 12? of gouges and scrapes leading up to the MC FRP. There was a burn mark in the roadway at the FRP. This was a Late Report.
RiderInj: The 19 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of a dislocated left shoulder which reset itself at the crash scene, and minor abrasions to his left elbow and knee. He refused any medical treatment at the scene. He went to his private physician the next day for additional care. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: Neither driver of the OV?s showed any signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: Since the driver of OV1 did not participate, it is unknown if the 29 year old female (5? 01?/135 lbs.) operator of OV1 was distracted. She stated that she never saw MC1. She had a perception failure. The rider of MC1 was legally lane splitting, but in a manner that could be deemed unsafe because of his speed (up to three times the traffic flow speed) as compared to surrounding traffic and the narrowness of the roadway/traffic lanes. There are no known or suspected failures for the driver of OV2, a 31 year old Hispanic male (5? 07?/170 lbs.).
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained unknown damage (probably very minor) as a result of the First Harmful event. The MC would have sustained minor to moderate damage from the 2nd Harmful (falling onto the roadway). The MC sustained total loss damage from the 3rd Harmful event of being run over and catching on fire. The MC became a total loss a result of the fire. The pre-crash condition is unknown, but stated to be good by the rider. MC1 is not equipped with ABS brakes. OV1 was not inspected; its condition prior to and after the crash is unknown. Damage from contact with the MC would have most likely been minor in nature. OV2 was not inspected. OV1 was equipped with ABS braking, however, neither vehicle would have benefitted from ABS braking in this crash. The condition OV2 prior to or after the crash or how it is equipped is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (roadway surface) low-side right lay down event including a secondary impact with a parked vehicle (OV1). Prior to this crash event the rider had been involved in a minor collision with two other vehicles and was leaving the scene by fleeing up a cross street. During his evasive actions the rider lost control of the motorcycle which collapsed onto the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained critical injuries as a result of impacting with the roadway surface and the parked vehicle.
MV1: 2007 Harley Davidson FLHR Road King (cruiser) 1584cc, black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (roadway surface) low-side left impact type traffic collision resulting in critical injuries to the rider. The collision occurred on Sunday in November 2012 at 1453 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed partly cloudy skies, a west crosswind @ 3.5 mph, and an ambient temperature of +64.9 degrees F. Sunset was at 1651 hours on this day.
The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 1.5 % uphill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a southbound left curved, two lane local residential street with an overall travel-way width of 36 feet. The street runs north & south with no physical or painted lane dividers.
Environmental and Crash Specifics (continued):
There are no designated bike lanes for either direction of travel and parking adjacent to both sides of this street is allowed. Both sides of the street are occupied by single family residential homes.
The location of the crash site was approximately 166 feet south of the nearest local street T-intersection. The intersection is controlled by a posted stop sign for eastbound traffic. The speed limit on this street is 25 mph for both directions of travel. Both the north and south sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs, 5 foot wide concrete sidewalks.

MC1 was a 2007 Harley Davidson FLHR Road King (cruiser style) motorcycle being operated by a 50 year old male Caucasian rider. The rider was wearing an unknown make/model non-DOT approved half shell novelty helmet at the time of the crash event.
The rider was travelling southbound on the local surface street at an estimated speed of approximately 38 mph and, was approaching the location of numerous parked vehicles along his right.
 
As the rider continued southbound he lost control of his motorcycle. There was evidence of locked rear wheel skid marks approximately 44 feet in length prior to the collapse of the motorcycle.
Both motorcycle and rider slid or tumbled southbound impacting with parked OV1. From the initial area of impact with the roadway surface the motorcycle continued a distance of about 31 feet. The rider slid or tumbled from the initial area of impact to his final resting place; a distance of about 36 feet.
RiderInj: The 50 year old male rider of MC1 sustained serious injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were to his head, ribs and wrist. The rider was admitted to a local hospital for treatment. A pre-surgery scan of the rider?s blood indicated a .24 blood alcohol concentration.
Human: The rider was operating his motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol and, attempting to evade a prior crash event.
Vehicle: MC1sustained moderate right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. OV1 sustained minor damage to the left side and was in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile turning left.
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in November 2012 on a Friday at 1645 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the weather was overcast, the temperature was 68 degrees F and the winds were light and vehicle 1 (MC1) had a left crosswind. The asphalt roadway surface
was dry, noted to be travel worn with surface cracking, spalling and potholes. The traffic was light.

The crash occurred at a T-intersection. The top of the tee runs north/south, has a speed limit of 45 mph and there are no traffic controls. There are two through lanes in each direction and two left turn lanes northbound and the road is divided by a double yellow painted line. The grade is a 3.2 % downhill for southbound travel with a 3.1 % crown. The base of the tee is on the west side, has a speed limit of 25 mph, runs east/west and has a functioning stop sign with limit line. There is a single lane in each direction, undivided with an eastbound uphill grade of 4.7 % and a crown of 5 %.
 MC1, is a 2003 Suzuki, GSXR 750, 749 cc, sport/race replica, ridden by a 25 year old white male (5 ft. 11 in. and 200 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full facial coverage, integral chin bar and face shield style of helmet. OV1 is a 1999 Ford, Taurus, driven by a 29 year old Hispanic male (5 ft. 6 in. and 165 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

The rider of MC1 was southbound, stopped between the #1 and #2 lanes at a traffic signal, after the signal phased green, he proceeded south in the #1 lane. OV1 was stopped at the eastbound limit line, waiting to make a left turn. The driver of OV1 stated that he saw MC1 at approximately 65 ft. north of the intersection and thought he had enough time to make his left turn. OV1 made a left turn across the path of MC1, causing MC1 to strike the left side of OV1. Area of impact was 20 ft. east of the west curb line of the north/south street and 7 ft. north of the south curb line of the east/west street.
RiderInj: The 25 year-old male rider of MC1 was transported by ambulance to an area hospital/admitted for 10 days and sustained an Injury Severity Score (ISS) of 14, from the following injuries: Superior cerebral cortex hemorrhage, cerebral contusion, bilateral pulmonary contusions, bilateral pneumothoraxes, hemopneumothorax, fractured sternum, right 9th rib and left 4th rib fractures, fractures to C-6 through T-7 left transverseprocesses, left periorbital contusion and contusions to his left side.
Human: The 29 year-old unlicensed male driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1.
Vehicle: MC1 had insufficient tread on both tires with significant cupping, however, there was insufficient time/distance for MC1 to make a controlled stop.
Environmental: There are no environmental contributing factors.

CrashType: This was a multiple vehicle crash event involving a motorcycle (MC1) with another vehicle (OV1) in a side-swipe type impact. This resulted in MC1 impacting with a raised concrete divider ejecting the rider. Both MC1 and the rider travelled into the opposing lanes of traffic and impacted head on with another vehicle (OV2). The rider sustained fatal injuries as a result of impacting with OV2.
MV1: 2007 Suzuki GSXR750 (sport race replica) motorcycle (749cc), green
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle vs. roadway surface vs. another vehicle multiple impact collision resulting in fatal injuries to the rider. The drivers of OV1 and OV2 were not injured. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight on Monday in November 2012 at 1230 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, WSW wind direction at 4.6 mph, and an ambient temperature of +68.0 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 1.2% downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a straight north/south multiple lane surface street with an overall travel-way width of 81 feet. There are three lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and three lanes for southbound traffic.

This portion of the roadway is in proximity to a freeway overpass and allows for ingress and egress to the freeway. On the east side of the roadway and crash site is a designated freeway on ramp and the outlying area is commercial businesses. On the west side of the roadway there is a designated freeway off ramp regulated by at least two posted stop signs. The north and southbound lanes of this street are divided by an 8 inch high raised concrete median approximately 3 feet in width with an asphalt surface.
At the location of the crash site there are no traffic control devices to regulate the flow of north/south traffic in the area other than posted 40 mph speed limit signs. The only intersecting streets are the on and off ramps for eastbound freeway traffic to enter or exit the roadway. Both the east and west sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs sidewalks. There are no designated ?bike lanes? in the area of the crash site. South of the crash site is a signal controlled four-way intersection.

MC1 was a 2007 Suzuki GSXR 750 (sport race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 23 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an EXO Scorpion full facemotorcycle helmet that was DOT and UN/ECE-22-05 rated and approved. The helmet weighed 56 ounces and had a manufacturing date of 11/2011.
The rider had been traveling southbound in the #1 lane of the multi-lane surface street. A witness traveling in the same direction put the speed of MC1 at about 35 mph. As the rider crested the freeway overpass the driver of OV1 had already exited the freeway and was stopped waiting to merge onto the surface street. The driver told police that he waited for traffic to clear before proceeding southbound and did not see the motorcyclist. The driver proceeded to make a right turn movement onto the street, swinging wide to enter the #1 lane when he felt an impact on the left side of his vehicle. The driver stated that he saw MC1 and the rider pass his vehicle on the left and impact the raised center median that separates the north and southbound lanes of traffic. The driver continued southbound to the next intersection and pulled off the roadway.
After the impact with OV1, both MC1 and the rider crossed over the center median into the opposing northbound #1 lane of traffic. At this same time OV2 was traveling northbound in the #1 lane having passed through the intersection (south of the crash scene) on an existing green light.

Witnesses traveling in the same direction as OV2 substantiated that the light was green however, could not provide a speed for OV2 at the time of the collision. Once MC1 and the rider struck and crossed over the center median, the rider was ejected on to the roadway surface. MC1 continued southbound in
the #1 lane (adjacent to the center median) until it impacted the left side of OV2. At the same moment, the rider was struck (head on) by OV2. The driver of OV2 did not see the motorcycle or rider in time to negotiate any type of collision avoidance maneuver. Upon impact the driver of OV2 applied her brakes and swerved to the right, stopping straddling the northbound #1 and #2 lanes.
MC1 continued a short distance in a southbound direction, eventually collapsing onto the roadway surface right side down, facing southbound in the northbound #1 lane. Having impacted the lower front portion of OV2 the rider was pushed back a distance of about 20 feet and also came to rest in the center portion of the northbound #1 lane. The multiple impact crash event was stabilized at this time with witnesses stopping to render aid and wait for law enforcement.
There were no more vehicles, pedestrians, or animals that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 23 year old male rider of MC1 sustained critical life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. He was transported from the scene of the crash to a local emergency hospital facility where he succumbed to his injuries within two hours. The more serious injuries likely to have caused his death were to the head and thoracic areas of the body.
ODriverInj: The drivers of OV1 and OV2 sustained no injuries as a result of this crash.
Human: The 23 year old male rider of MC1 was driving at a speed considered safe for the present traffic on the roadway and there was no indication of the presence of alcohol or drugs in his system, postmortem.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major left front damage as well as minor damage to the right side otherwise appeared to be have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 sustained minor left side damage as a result of the impact with MC1 otherwise appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition.
OV2 sustained minor front and left side damage as a result of the multiple impacts of MC1 and the rider otherwise appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile.
MV1: 1999 Harley Davidson, XLH 883, 883 cc, Custom sportster
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in November 2012 on a Wednesday evening at 1722 hours in Southern California. It was dark and the weather was clear, the temperature was approximately 61 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, with moderate traffic.

The crash occurred at a four way intersection, in a commercial area. The north/south roadway has 2 lanes each way, a dedicated left turn lane, and no traffic controls. The speed limit is 35 mph, there is a 2.7 % downhill southbound grade, a 3.2 % crown and a left curve 430 ft. long, with a radius of 501.25 ft., a 100 ft. cord, and a 2 ft. 6 in. middle ordinate, that ends 93 ft. 7 in. before the point of impact (POI). On the west side there is an east/west undivided, one lane each way street, with an eastbound, downhill grade of 1.3% and a 2.3% crown. There is a functional and visible stop sign for eastbound traffic. On the east side there is an undivided, one lane each way commercial driveway with a functional and visible stop sign with limit line, for westbound traffic. The intersection is located in a commercial area, bordered by raised curbing, grass, trees and sidewalks.
Vehicle 1 (MC1), is a 1999 Harley Davidson, XLH 883, 883 cc, Custom sportster, ridden by a 28 year old white male (6 ft. 1 in. and 179 lbs). The rider was wearing a full facial coverage, integral chin bar style of helmet. Vehicle 2 (OV1), is a 1989 Honda Accord LX, driven by a 72 year old white male (6 ft. 1 in. and 170 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

The rider of MC1 was traveling southbound at approximately 35 mph in the # 2 lane approaching the intersection. OV1 was stopped on the west side of the intersection in the eastbound lane, waiting to cross the north/south street into a commercial driveway on the east side of the intersection. The driver of OV1 looked to the left, then the right, then started across the north/south street into the path of MC1. MC1 struck the left driver?s door of OV1 and was dragged to
its point of rest (POR). POI was 93 ft. 7 in. south and 13 ft. 1 in. east of the reference point (RP). The POR of MC1 and the rider was 9 ft. 5 in. north and 23 ft. 11 in. east of the POI. There is no POR for OV1, which was moved prior to police arrival.
RiderInj: The 28 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries, as related by traffic collision report: Bilateral abrasions of the forearms. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was one (1). The 72 year-old driver of OV1 sustained the following injuries, as related by traffic collision report: Minor laceration above the left eye and a minor laceration of the left ear. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was one (1).
Human: The 72 year-old male driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: This was a scooter (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) pick-up truck front to side impact with a secondary lay down event with the (scooter) impacting the roadway surface. The rider was ejected off the scooter and sustained non-life threatening injuries. There were no passengers on the scooter at the time of the collision.
MV1: 2005 Panon model STC50QT-8 scooter (50cc), black in color.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) broadside type collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred during the hours of dusk on Friday in December 2012 at 1715 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1654 hours showed hazy conditions, calm winds and, an ambient temperature of 61.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unrestricted for 6 miles. The roadway surface for both vehicles has a -1.8% downhill grade. The roadway surface is of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred on a right curve multiple lane north/south arterial State Highway with an overall travel-way width of 68 feet. There are two lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and two lanes for southbound traffic. There is a marked 9 foot wide safety lane on the east side of the roadway. The south bound side of the roadway is uninvolved in this crash event. The posted speed limit for northbound traffic is 35 mph.

The area of the crash site is approximately 379 feet south of an at-grade intersection controlled by multi-phase signal devices for all four directions of travel. There are designated left turn lanes for all approaching traffic as well as designated right turn only lanes. The west side of the street is a state owned public beach park. The east side of the street is occupied by a commercial shopping center open to public access.
At the location of the crash site traffic had been slowing for a northbound red light. Traffic had been backed up to the area of the crash site.
The uninvolved southbound lanes of traffic on this highway are separated by two sets of painted solid double yellow lines approximately 10 feet wide. There also concrete ?K? rails (aka Jersey rails) physically separating the opposing lanes along with impact barrels and a raised concrete median. Along the east side of the street are raised asphalt and concrete curbs with concrete sidewalks.
There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site. There were no super- elevation issues with this roadway.
 
MC1 was a 2005 Panon 50cc scooter being operated by a 45 year old male rider. The rider was travelling northbound in the #2 lane at a speed of approximately 25 mph before moving into the adjacent safety lane.
OV1 was a 2004 Nissan Altima sedan being operated by a 44 year old male driver. The driver of OV1 was traveling at a speed of approximately 15 mph slowing with traffic northbound in the #2 lane. There were three passengers in his vehicle.
As the driver of OV1 was moving forward in traffic, he decided to change lanes to the right for the purpose of pulling of the highway into a gas station up ahead. The road opens up to a third lane ahead and there is sufficient room to move a vehicle to the right. He maintained his speed of approximately 15 mph.
The rider of MC1 noticing the backed up traffic moved from the #2 lane into the safety lane portion of the roadway to the right and adjacent to the #2 lane. The rider maintained his speed of approximately 25 mph.

As the rider continued northbound, OV1 suddenly crossed in front of him. The rider told me during our interview that he had no time to initiate any type of collision avoidance maneuver other than braking. MC1 struck the right side of OV1 at the front passenger door. The resulting impact caused MC1 to careen off the roadway onto the shoulder collapsing on the left side. The rider was ejected off the scooter during the impact with OV1 and tumbled onto a driveway entrance to the shopping center about 83 feet from the initial area of impact.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event. Although in proximity of a signal controlled intersection, the intersection and signal controls played no significant role in this event other than traffic being stopped for a red light.
RiderInj: The 45 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were abrasions and contusions along the most serious to the back of his head. This was due in part to his helmet coming off his head during the crash event. The rider freely admitted to having not strapped the helmet properly prior to operating his scooter. The police report indicated the presence of alcohol intoxication however, this was only documented as an associated factor and no further investigation was conducted.
ODriverInj: The 44 year old male driver of OV1 and his passengers sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. The police report also indicated that there were no apparent objective symptoms of alcohol or drug intoxication.
Human:
The 45 year old male rider of MC1 had been driving at a speed greater than the present traffic on the roadway, started to pass the line of traffic on the right and, may have been adversely influenced by his alcohol consumption.
The 44 year old male driver OV1 failed to check for approaching traffic prior to exiting his lane of travel.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained total damage as a result of the collision with OV1 and impacting the roadway surface.
OV1 sustained minor right side damage to the passenger side front door otherwise, was in satisfactory operating condition and driven from the scene.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. fixed object (Ground), DUI involvement.
Crash:
This single vehicle motorcycle crash occurred in January 2013 at 2120 hours in Southern California. It was dark and the roadway was lighted by overhead street lights. The temperature was approximately 50 degrees F., the weather was clear and calm and the asphalt roadway surface was dry.
The crash occurred at an intersection, in a commercial/business area. The north/south street is undivided, has three southbound lanes; the northbound lanes consist of a left turn lane, a through lane and a right turn lane. The east side of the intersection is undivided, with three through lanes and one through/right turn lane eastbound and two left turn, three through lanes and a right turn lane westbound. The north and west sides of the intersection did not play a role in this accident. All traffic controls were functioning properly, and the posted speed limit is 45 mph.

Vehicle 1 (MC1), a 2007 Honda Rebel 234 cc cruiser style motorcycle, was being operated by a 52 year old male (5 ft. 3 in./ 140 lbs.) who was wearing a helmet and eye protection. The rider was proceeding northbound in the right turn lane, at an estimated speed of approximately 22 mph. Due to the drugs/alcohol in his system, the rider of MC1 lost control while making the right turn and low-sided onto its right side, striking the roadway. The final rest position for both rider and MC1 was approximately 31 ft. east of the point of impact. There is a black, half/partial coverage helmet strapped to the left frame behind the left side cover, it is unknown if this is the helmet worn by the rider of MC1.
RiderInj: The 52 year old male rider of the MC1, has an AIS score of 1, as a result of: Bilateral hand abrasions, right knee abrasions and a swollen right knee. The rider had a BAC of 0.31 at the time of the crash.
Human: The rider was operating MC1 while under the influence of drugs/alcohol.
Vehicle: The motorcycle tires were grossly underinflated at the time of the crash.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) vs. Other Vehicle (OV1) rear end type impact with secondary lay-down event. MC had no passenger.
OV1: 2009 Ford F-150 Super Crew light truck
Crash:
This is a MC frontal impact to the rear end of OV1 that entered the roadway from a private driveway (shopping center) making a left turn and failing to yield to on-coming traffic. MC1 was eastbound in the #1 lane. The crash occurred at a T type intersection (driveway) on a non-freeway minor arterial approximately 548 feet south of a four-leg, not skewed intersection. Traffic was light and flowing at the time. According to the rider, he was the only vehicle moving in his direction. He was going approximately 35 mph. There are two through lanes in each direction with a dedicated left turn lane in the rider?s direction of travel. Each direction also has a bike lane. There is a curb high raised center median with bushes and trees. There are no signal controls. The roadway runs in a north/south orientation and has a right curve for the rider. The length of roadway curvature was measured to be 890 feet. The rider of MC1 said that he was fully ejected and landed in the roadway and was unconscious. He had no memory of where he landed. The driver of OV1 said that he felt an impact from behind, but did not stop. He drove to the side of the road and parked. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial businesses on the rider?s left side of the roadway and single family residences on his right. No on-street parking is allowed. The First Harmful event took place in the #1 lane as the rider was slowing because the OV was entering his pathway. The crash occurred in Southern California in January 2013 at 1745 hours. It was dark and the area was lit by overhead street lights. The weather was clear with no wind. The approximate temperature was 55 degrees F. The roadway surface was of an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has a 4.8% crown and a 4.2% downgrade for the rider at the crash site. Both sides of the roadway have 8? concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit is 45 mph

MC1 was a 2001 Yamaha FZ-1 sport/racing type motorcycle with modifications that was being operated by a 23 year old Caucasian male, (5?09?/175 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face helmet with integral chin bar and a clear face shield. The helmet is rated to FMVSS 218 (DOT) and Snell M2010 standards. It sustained minor pot marks from the rider laying his head onto the roadway after the crash. During the interview, the rider stated that he had a valid license which was also endorsed for motorcycles. The police report shows it as expired.
 
MC1 was southbound in the #1 (left) lane when OV1 entered the roadway from the shopping center driveway on the riders left. Traffic was light. The rider had been stopped at the previous intersection and was going about 35 mph. He said he saw OV1 enter the roadway making a left turn form the driveway. He began to slow by letting off the throttle. He said he was expecting the OV to cross over into the right lane. The rider said that the OV stopped partially blocking both lanes. The rider said that he had no time to react and hit the OV in the rear. He said that he woke up in an ambulance. The MC landed on its left side plane.
MC1 sustained a maximum reduction in wheelbase. The front tire was pushed backwards into the radiator and exhaust pipes causing damage. The forks broke and a static measurement was not possible. OV1 sustained minor damage to the tailgate and hitch receiver. The rider sustained minor injuries in this crash.
No tire marks were located at the scene. No evidence of a skid was located on either tire. One gouge from MC1 was located at the first harmful event. This was a Late Report.
RiderInj: The 23 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of an abrasion to his right cheek below the eye, a contusion to his right groin, and a mild concussion with no loss of consciousness. He was treated at the scene and then taken to a hospital where he was admitted for two days. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The driver of OV1 did not participate. It is unknown if the 42 year old male (6? 01?/200 lbs.) operator of OV1 was distracted. Per the police report, he stated that he saw MC1 coming and still continued with his left turn. The driver of OV1 made a decision error. The rider of MC1 also saw OV1 making his left turn and failed to slow or change lanes. This would be a reaction failure.
Vehicle:
The motorcycle sustained major damage as a result of the First Harmful event. We were unable to obtain a measurement for the reduction in wheelbase because of the damage. The MC had several modifications that were cosmetic in nature and had no effect to how the MC operated. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good. OV1 was in near new condition prior to the crash. Damage from contact with the MC was minor consisting of two dents in the tailgate and scratches to the hitch receiver.
MC1 did not have ABS brakes.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: SUV making U-turn vs. Motorcycle.
MV1: 2012 Ducati Monster 1100 EVO, 1078 cc, touring motorcycle.
Crash:
This was a three vehicle crash that involved an initial front to left side impact configuration with a secondary high-side laydown and subsequent vault of rider into the rear of vehicle 3 (OV2). The crash occurred on a Wednesday afternoon in January 2013 at 1535 hours in Southern California. It was light and the weather was clear, the temperature was 71 degrees F and the winds were light and variable. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and noted to be travel worn with surface cracking, spalling and minor ruts.

The crash took place within the confines of a four-leg intersection. The north/south legs of the intersection consist of one left turn travel lane and two through travel lanes in each direction, the posted speed limit is 40 mph. The north/south legs of the intersection consist of north and southbound travel lanes that are delineated by solid, double yellow (no passing) centerlines and the posted speed limit is 40 mph. The east/west roadway consists of two through travel lanes each way and designated turn lanes. The west leg of the intersection is delineated by solid, double yellow centerlines, and the leg is delineated by a 8
in. raised concrete and 4 ft. wide asphalt median. There are permissive controlled only traffic controls present and all traffic controls were functioning correctly. The intersection is located in a commercial area, bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks. The east/west roadway is straight with a 0.1% uphill eastbound grade and a 4.0% crown.
Vehicle 1 (MC1), is a 2012 Ducati Monster 1100 EVO, 1078 cc, touring motorcycle, ridden by a 35 year old male who is, 6 ft. 2 in. and 205 lbs. The rider was wearing a full face motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield. Vehicle 2 (OV1) is a maroon colored, 2006 Ford (Eddie Bauer edition) Explorer, driven by a 45 year old female who is 5 ft. 7 in. and 135 lbs. Vehicle 3 (OV2) is a silver colored, 2007 Ford Escape Hybrid, driven by a 55 year old male who is 5 ft. 5 in. and 165 lbs. The drivers of OV1 and OV2 were reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

The rider of the MC1 was traveling eastbound, in lane # 2 at an estimated speed of 40 mph, with a vehicle slightly ahead in the #1 lane, with a green traffic
 
signal phasing yellow. OV2 after making a U-turn from the westbound turn lane, on a green signal, was stopped in the #2 lane just beyond the east leg crosswalk waiting to make a right turn into a commercial driveway, which was blocked by other vehicles, already in the driveway. OV1 was westbound in the left turn lane, partially in the intersection, waiting to make a U-turn into the eastbound #2 lane, when the signal phased yellow. With the yellow phasing of the signals, the witness vehicle stopped at the limit line, MC1 continued into the intersection angling left to go around OV2 and OV1 started making its U-turn. OV- 1 initiated its U-turn and struck MC1on the left side, approximately 11 ft. from the east crosswalk, between the # 1 and 2 travel lanes, continuing into the crosswalk before stopping.  MC1 disengaged from OV1, high sided onto its right side and slid under the rear of OV2, the rider of MC1 was launched into the back of OV2, and bounced off, coming to rest approximately 8 ft. west of MC1 in the crosswalk. The rider of the motorcycle detected the encroaching OV1 with insufficient time to react. The left engine guard of MC1 was caught in the bumper of OV1, tearing a piece off when they separated.
RiderInj: The 35 year-old male rider of MC1sustained the following injuries, as related by the police report: Laceration to the liver and left kidney, not further specified (NFS). Multiple right side rib fractures NFS, left foot fracture NFS. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 13.
ODriverInj: The 55 year-old male driver of OV-2 was transported to the hospital with complaint of pain, NFS. There was no drug or alcohol involvement.
Human: The 45 year-old female driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1. The rider of MC1 had a decision failure by not stopping as the signal phased yellow.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: The permissive only traffic signal contributed to the crash causation.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) frontal vs. Other Vehicle (OV1) right side rear type impact with secondary lay-down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC frontal impact to the right rear side of OV1 that made a left turn in front of MC1 on a public roadway. The area is a T-type intersection, not skewed, with no signal controls, involving a driveway to a shopping center. MC1 was southbound in the right #3 lane at an unknown speed when OV1 made a left turn from the dedicated left turn lane on the northbound side of the road. The roadway is a non-freeway principle arterial that has a total of six through lanes
(three in each direction) and bike lanes in both directions. There are nine foot wide concrete sidewalks on either side of the roadway. It has a curb high center median that is landscaped. North of the left turn lane area is a merging lane for traffic exiting the parking lot. The roadway surface was dry and is made of an asphalt composition that was worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The crash occurred in Southern California on January 2013 at 1620 hours. It was dusk. The roadway runs in a north/south orientation and has a left curve for the rider. The length of curve is 763? and the radius is 1374.08?. At the crash site the crown is 2.5% and the upgrade is 1.4% for the rider. The weather was clear with a light wind from the southwest. The ambient temperature was 74 degrees F. MC1 came to rest in the area of the southeast corner on its left side plane. OV1 was moved prior to the police arrival. The rider was treated at the scene, and then transported to a local hospital where he was admitted for two days. On the rider?s right is commercial businesses. On the riders left is a church and a post office that are below the grade of the roadway. No on-street parking is allowed. The posted speed limit is 50 mph.

MC1 was a 2011 Honda PCX 125 scooter that was being operated by 57 year old male, (5?11?/175 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown style of helmet. The condition of the helmet prior to and after the crash is unknown.

MC1 was southbound in the #3 (right) lane when OV1 made a left turn in front of him from the dedicated left turn lane on the northbound side of the road. The 61 year old male (6?00?/200 lbs.) operator of OV1 said in the police report that he never saw MC1. There were no pre or post tire marks from either vehicle involved in the crash. Some marks were found on the right side of the front tire from MC1. They appear to have been caused when MC1 impacted OV1. The rear tire of MC1 was legally bald (lack of tread). OV1?s FRP is unknown because it was moved prior to police arrival. The damage to OV1 is listed as moderate;
 
however, it was driven away. According to the police report, the damage to OV1 is to the right rear side. As noted on the diagram, the police report measurements for MC1?s FRP and the author?s depiction of it in the report are in conflict with MC1?s orientation. It appears that MC1 landed on its left side plane and spun in a CCW to its FRP after impacting OV1. The rider?s FRP is not known.
RiderInj: The 57 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of a fractured left ankle and bilateral abrasions to his knees. He was treated at the scene and then taken to a hospital where he was admitted for two days. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The driver of OV1 did not participate. It is unknown if he was distracted by his passenger who is the registered owner of OV1 or some other thing. He stated that he never saw MC1. He had a perception failure. It is unknown if the rider had contribution to the crash.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate damage to the front end as a result of impacting OV1. It sustained minor damage as a result of impacting the paved roadway surface and sliding upon it. There was no reduction in wheelbase. MC1 has a combined braking system, but no ABS. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be near new.

OV1 was not inspected. The police report states that the damage was moderate to the right side rear of OV1 and was driven away. The pre-crash and post- crash condition of OV1 is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors determined to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) crash with a secondary collapse of the motorcycle on to the roadway surface. The crash event caused the motorcycle rider to be ejected impacting with the roadway surface causing minor injuries.
MV1: 2008 Yamaha WR250 (dual purpose) 249cc, blue in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle minor injury traffic collision. The collision occurred on Sunday in January 2013 at 1612 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1558 hours showed clear skies, with winds out of the southwest at 11.5 mph, and, an ambient temperature of 57.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The motorcyclist had just turned right off a minor arterial surface street, southbound onto a residential local street where the crash event occurred. The local street has a downhill grade of 0.7%. The posted speed limit is 25 mph.
The collision occurred on a straight residential local surface street with an overall travel way width of 40 feet. The street runs north and south with one lane dedicated for northbound and one lane dedicated for southbound traffic. These lanes are separated by painted solid double yellow lines. There are no designated traffic control devices to regulate traffic other than the posted speed limit signs and a stop sign for northbound traffic approaching the T- intersection. The location of the crash scene was on the residential local street, away from the intersection.

OV1 had initially been parked along the west side of the local street, facing southboun
MC1 was a 2008 Yamaha (dual purpose) 249cc motorcycle (blue) being operated by a (40) year old male rider. The rider had completed a right turn movement off the minor arterial surface street and began to proceed southbound on the residential local street with the intent to return home.
OV1was a 2006 Toyota Prius automobile (black) being operated by a (34) year old female. As MC1 rounded the corner onto the local street, the driver of OV1 pulled away from the curb and initiated a U-turn type movement with the intent to proceed north.
The motorcyclist attempted to avoid OV1 by braking and steering his motorcycle to the left towards the northbound lane. The rider was unable to avoidcontact with OV1 and struck the left front quarter panel and bumper area just in front of the left front tire. Upon contact with OV1 the rider was ejected off the motorcycle and it collapsed (right side down) onto the roadway surface. MC1 slid about 14 feet from the point of impact and the rider came to rest about 19 feet from the point of rest.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj:
The rider of MC1 sustained a broken left wrist and a minor laceration to his right knee. The rider was transported from the scene to a local hospital where he was treated and released for his injuries. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
The rider was wearing an FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell M2010 rated full face motorcycle helmet that sustained minor abrasive damage.
ODriverInj: The driver of the other vehicle (OV1) sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 40 year old male operator of MC1 was off throttle and travelling at a speed safe for the present traffic on the roadway. He did however fail to perceive OV1 pulling away from the curb area of the street.
The 34 year old female Hispanic driver of OV1 failed perceive the presence of approaching traffic when she decided to turn from her position on the roadway.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor right side damage as a result of colliding with OV1 and the roadway surface otherwise, was in satisfactory operating condition. OV1sustained minor left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Van
MV1: 2006 Honda, VLX Shadow, 599 cc, cruiser motorcycle
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in January 2013 at 1038 hours in Southern California. It was daylight, overcast, the temperature was approximately 61 degrees F and the winds were light and variable. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, in good condition and there was moderate traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial area on a busy east/west undivided state highway. The roadway has 2 lanes each way with a dedicated left turn lane and no traffic controls. The speed limit is 40 mph. The roadway was level with a 3.6 % crown. The Reference Point (RP) is a fire hydrant setback 2 ft. on the north sidewalk adjacent to a commercial driveway.
MC1 is a 2006 Honda VLX Shadow, 599 cc, cruiser motorcycle ridden by a 37 year old male (5 ft. 7 in. and 215 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full facial coverage, integral chin bar style of helmet. OV1 is a 2003 Ford Econoline van driven by a 70 year old male (6 ft. 3 in. and 245 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling westbound at approximately 40 mph in the # 1 lane; OV1 was also traveling westbound at approximately 45 mph in the # 2 lane and was passing MC1. The driver of OV1 stated that he turned backwards to deal with his 3 dogs and granddaughter in the back seat. He turned forward when he heard metal on metal noises and saw that he had veered left across the # 1 and the common left turn lane and into the eastbound # 1 lane. He pulled back into the left turn lane, looked into his left mirror and saw a motorcycle rider lying in the road behind him. He then stopped in the left turn lane. The Point of Impact POI is 67 ft. east and 23 ft. south of the RP. The right footpeg of MC1 punctured the left rear tire of OV1 and was torn off by the tire. The rider was pulled off the motorcycle when his right foot was pinned between the motorcycle and OV1?s tire. He slid on his back approximately 100 ft., coming to rest in the right turn lane, west of the POI. MC1 went down on its left side and slid southwest to its Final Rest Position adjacent to the south curb, 30 ft. 4 in. west and 38 ft. 3 in. south of the RP. MC1 deposited approximately 124 ft., of gouges and paint transfer on the roadway.
RiderInj: The 37 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries, as related by medical records: Fractures of the 2nd and 3rd metatarsals of the right foot, abrasions to multiple areas of the body, strain to the cervical and lumbar spine. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 6
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was uninjured.
Human: The 70 year-old male driver of OV1 was distracted by his passenger and animals. This caused him to veer into the side of MC1.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) lay-down event followed by left side impact with OV1. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC lay-down event while trying to avoid a collision with OV1 that was making a legal left turn in front of MC1. The crash occurred at a ?T? type, not skewed intersection with a through street and a cul-de-sac on which the rider resides. Both streets are posted at 25 mph. and are non-freeway local or collector streets. Traffic was light. The cul-de-sac is an unmarked two lane roadway that runs in an east/west direction. The collector road runs in a north/south direction and has two through lanes (one in each direction) and a dedicated left turn lane on the northbound side. Both roadways are straight. Block walls, trees, and two story apartment buildings are permanent visual obstructions. Both roadways have standard 8? curbs with greenery and sidewalks, except for the east side of the northbound road. It has a curb and greenery which hides a concrete barrier that supports a metal fence along a railway easement. There is no sidewalk. The only signal control is a stop sign for eastbound traffic. The rider had just left his residence and was traveling eastbound at a high rate of speed. After seeing OV1, the rider said that he locked both brakes and lost control, causing the MC to wash out and land on its right side plane. The MC deposited 23 feet of front wheel skid before falling onto the roadway. The MC then slid another 87 feet before impacting the left side of OV1. OV1 had been northbound on the collector road and was making a left turn onto the cul-de-sac. The rider was fully ejected. He said that it was street sweeping day and that there were no parked cars on either side of the roadway. He also said that the sweeper has just been on the street and that it was damp and dusty. The crash occurred in Southern California in January 2013 at 1507 hours. It was daylight and the weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with a moderate wind from the south. The temperature was 57 degrees F. The roadway surface was an asphalt material that was dry, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition.
The rider?s roadway has a 0.5% crown and a 1.5% up-grade that elevates to a 4.3% up-grade at the crash site. The roadway for OV1 has a 0.8% crown and a 0.5% up-grade.

MC1 was a 2004 Honda sport/racing type motorcycle with modifications that was being operated by a 20 year old male, (5?07?/142 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face helmet with integral chin bar and a gray/smoke face shield. The helmet is rated to FMVSS 218 (DOT) and ECE-22-05 standards. It sustained a minor abrasion on the right side of the chin bar.
 
MC1 was eastbound in the #1 lane when OV1 entered the intersection to make its left turn. Due to the buildings and block wall, cross traffic cannot be seen from mid-block until they are in the intersection. At the point where the tire marks start, OV1 would not be visible unless he had already entered the intersection. The rider over-braked and lost control then slid into OV1. MC1 was equipped with heavy duty aftermarket crash bars and engine guards (sliders) that are made of nylon which prevented additional damage. When MC1 went down, it left very little evidence on the roadway. When MC1 impacted OV1 with the front end, the forks collapsed rearward. The front tire impacted the radiator and exhaust causing damage. Both damaged parts appeared to still be operational. When we inspected MC1, the rider had already dismantled most of the damaged parts. He still had possession of the damaged parts.
Photographs were taken of these parts. The front forks are bent, and one is broken. Even though the front sliders and crash bars were removed, the crash bars and rear sliders still were able to provide directional information of MC1?s path. The rider said that OV1 was ?cutting the corner? and that the driver veered to the right and straightened out when he saw him coming. The rider said that he had no time to react and hit the OV in the left side. He said that he woke up in an ambulance. The MC landed on its left side plane and slid to its FRP. MC1 sustained a maximum reduction in wheelbase. The front tire was pushed backwards into the radiator and exhaust pipes causing damage. The forks were broke and removed from the MC by the rider. A static measurement was not possible. OV1 sustained minor damage to the left side somewhere near the trailing edge of the front wheel housing and then the driver?s door. The impact caused to side airbags to deploy. The rider sustained minor injuries in this crash. The driver of OV1 complained of pain to his head, neck, and left side of his torso. One gouge from MC1 was located at the first harmful event. This was a Late Report.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions to both knees and a sprained left wrist. He sought his own medical attention sometime after the crash. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The male driver (6? 04?/210 lbs.) of OV1 showed no signs of impairment. He had a complaint of pain and was taken to a local hospital.
Human: The rider of MC1 was going too fast and was distracted with something on the side of the road. He then over-braked and lost control. He slid approximately 86? until he crashed into OV1. Even though the driver of OV1 did not participate, it does not appear that there were any human factors attributable to him.
Vehicle: The motorcycle sustained minor damage as a result of the First Harmful event (falling onto a paved roadway surface). The MC then sustained moderate damage to the front end when it impacted OV1. We were unable to obtain a measurement for the reduction in wheelbase because the forks had been removed from the MC. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good. OV1 was not inspected. Per the police report, the damage was listed as moderate; however, it was driven to the operator?s residence down the street and parked. Its pre and post-crash condition is unknown.
Environmental: Two story buildings, a block wall, and trees obscure viewing the intersecting streets until one is at or within the intersection.

CrashType:
This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1), side to right front impact collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained non-life threatening injuries. There were no passengers on this motorcycle
at the time of the collision.
MV1: 2007 Yamaha YZF R1 Sport/race replica motorcycle, 998cc (red)
Crash:
This was a side impact crash event resulting in minor injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred during the morning hours of Wednesday in February 2013 at 0555 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed mostly cloudy skies, SE winds at 5.8 mph, and an ambient temperature of
+54.0 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. Sunrise was at 0646 hours this day.
The collision occurred on a straight multiple lane principal arterial roadway surface with an overall travel-way width of 102 feet. The roadway runs east/west with three lanes dedicated for eastbound traffic and three lanes for westbound traffic. The crash occurred entirely within the eastbound lanes of traffic. The eastbound left turn lane is segregated from the through lanes of traffic by a painted median.
Environmental and Crash Specifics (continued):
In the area of the collision scene there is a designated left turn lane for eastbound to northbound traffic. Both the east and west sides of the street are occupied by commercial retail businesses and restaurants.
East of the crash site is a multi-phase signal controlled intersection regulating traffic in all four directions. At the location of the crash site eastbound traffic was stopped for a red phased signal light. The posted speed limit for both east and westbound traffic is 50 mph. The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by a raised concrete and brick median approximately 8 inches in height and 4 foot wide. The street is also bordered on both sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks approximately 9 feet in width. There is a +2.4% uphill grade and +3.9% crown in the area of the crash site, otherwise there are no other issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.
MC1 was a 2007 Yamaha YZF-R1 sport/race replica motorcycle being operated by a 22 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a full face (FMVSS 218 US DOT Snell M2010 approved) motorcycle helmet, manufactured by EXO, Model 400.
 
The rider was travelling eastbound in the #1 lane approaching the intersection at a speed of approximately 35 mph. The rider had positioned his motorcycle on the right side of the lane with the intention of splitting traffic between the #1 and # 2 lanes. The rider told me he saw about 4 vehicles stopped in the #1 lane and as many as a dozen stopped in the #2 lane. It was his intent to move to the front of the traffic at the intersection.
OV1 was a 2012 Toyota Camry sedan type automobile being operated by a 23 year old male driver. OV1 was stopped in the eastbound #2 lane along with other vehicles in this lane.
The driver of OV1 decided to exit the #1 lane and move his vehicle into the adjacent #2 lane. The driver told law enforcement officials that he looked in his rear view mirror and over his left shoulder prior to making the lane change.
As OV1 moved into the #2 the driver felt an impact alongside the rear passenger and front driver side doors. The driver saw MC1 and the rider collapse onto the roadway surface and immediately pulled in behind them.

The rider of MC1 told me he had only enough time to apply the brakes to his motorcycle before striking the left side of OV1. He went on to tell me the resulting impact caused the motorcycle to collapse, right side down towards the painted median separating the #1 lane and the left turn lane about 26 feet from the area of impact. The rider was ejected off and just in front of the final resting place of the motorcycle.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were in the area of the scalp and face as a result of the movement of the rider?s helmet. His other injuries were abrasions and contusions to both knees. There was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
ODriverInj: The 23 year old male driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. There were no apparent objective symptoms of alcohol intoxication.
Human: The 23 year old male driver of OV1 failed to perceive the presence of the motorcycle while changing lanes. The 22 year old male rider of MC1 lacked the understanding of the inherent risks of lane splitting.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate right side and front end damage however, appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition.The other vehicle (OV1) sustained minor left side damage was in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) left rear side swipe impact with OV1 followed by a left side lay-down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC (left side swipe impact) vs. OV (right side swipe impact) followed by a secondary lay-down. The crash occurred 70? east of a four-way, not skewed, signal controlled intersection. The intersection/signal controls played no role in crash causation. The roadway is a minor arterial and has four through lanes (two in each direction) with raised center dividers that are landscaped with trees and bushes. Each direction has a dedicated left turn lane at the
intersection. Both directions have a bike lane. The roadside has a concrete sidewalk, block wall, and chain link fence on the rider?s right. There is a concrete sidewalk and a landscaped up-slope on the left side. The roadway has a 1% downgrade with a left curve for both vehicles? direction of travel. None of these potential view obstructions had any effect on the crash because both MC1 and OV1 were going in the same direction and in the same lane. The roadway has an East/West designation but has a northeasterly orientation at the crash site. The roadway is of an asphalt composition. It had some minor surface cracking and on area of bituminous repair, but was in otherwise in good condition. The roadway bisects a single family residential area and has a posted speed limit of 40 mph. Traffic was light to moderate. The crash occurred 70? east of the intersection in February of 2013 at 1633 hours in Southern California. The weather was clear with a temperature of 62 degrees F. There was a light wind from the SSW giving the rider a right crosswind. From the First Harmful event (MC1 into OV1), MC1 traveled in an upright orientation approximately 38? before falling on its left side plane and sliding front end forward approximately 76? until it impacted the south curb. At that point, MC1 partially righted itself and was scraping the curb with the right side and slid approximately another 43? to its FRP. It was found leaning against the curb on its right side. The rider was located at an unknown location in the eastbound bike lane next to the curb. OV1 had been moved prior to the arrival of emergency personnel.

MC1 was a 2010 Victory Cross Country touring type motorcycle that was being operated by a 65 year old male, (5?10?/180 lbs.). The rider was wearing a half type, partial coverage helmet with no face shield. The helmet had a snap on visor that was broken off and lost during the crash. The helmet is rated with FMVSS 218 (US DOT) standards. The helmet sustained a few minor abrasions to the front and both sides. The rider was wearing prescription sunglasses that stayed on his face through the entire crash sequence and sustained no damage.
 
Both MC1 and OV1 were eastbound in the #1 left lane. OV1 was ahead of MC1. There was a van ahead of OV1 in the #2 right lane. Both OV1 and the van entered this roadway by making a right turn from the intersecting street prior to the crash location. The van stayed in the #2 lane, while OV1 went wide and out into
the #1 lane. Per the police report, there was a skateboarder going east on the south sidewalk. The skateboarder crashed on the sidewalk and fell forward. While falling forward, he lost control of his skateboard and pushed it backwards into the street. The driver of the van saw the skateboard rolling into the street and did not want to run it over so he came to a stop. The 80 year old driver of OV1 (5?06?/148 lbs.) saw the van stop, but didn?t know why. The van blocked her view of the skateboarder. She slowed and stopped, afraid that someone was running into the street. The rider only saw the two-vehicles stopped in the lanes. He slowed and decided to ride between the two-vehicles since he saw no other room to go around them. He stated that the van was stopped at an angle, putting the front of the van closer to OV1. The rider attempted to stay close to OV1 in fear that he would hit the van. As he did so, his oversized rear crash bars caught the right rear of OV1. The rider stated that he was slammed up against the side of OV1 and then ejected. He stated that his MC continued sliding down the street while he slid/tumbled to the curb. The rider ended up at an unknown location near the south curb. He was on his back, with his feet
near the south curb. There were no pre-impact skids or tire marks from either vehicle. The rear tire of MC1 showed evidence of rubbing against the curb while rotating.
RiderInj: The 65 year old male operator of the motorcycle sustained major injuries consisting of a left lung hemopneumothorax, lacerated spleen, a fractured clavicle, and 4 fractured left ribs. He was admitted to a local hospital for 12-13 days. The motorcycle rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The female driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The rider of MC1 made a decision error by not slowing down more when he saw traffic ahead of him stopped or stopping. This limited his choice of avoidance techniques when he needed them. It does not appear that there were any human factors attributable to the driver of OV1.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor damage as a result of the First Harmful event (impacting OV1). MC1 then sustained moderate damage to the left and right sides including the faring and left saddle bag that was ripped off as a result of the crash. MC1 then slid down the street impacting and riding the curb to its FRP. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good to near new There was no reduction in wheelbase. OV1 was not inspected. Per the police report, the damage was listed as minor and was driven away. Its pre- and post-crash condition is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors attributed to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) rear-end type injury traffic collision, causing non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider.
MV1: 2009 Harley Davidson FLHX Street Glide Cruiser 1688cc (black)
Crash:
This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) injury traffic collision occurring during on Saturday in February 2013 at 1555 hours in Southern California. The weather report for this region showed clear skies, with winds out of the SSW at 13.8 mph and, an ambient temperature of 59.5 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface was level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred at the location of a four way multi-phase signal controlled intersection on a straight, multiple lane minor arterial surface street. The street has an overall travel-way width of 101feet. There are a total of six lanes dedicated for vehicular traffic; three for northbound and three southbound
traffic. There are designated left turn lanes for north to westbound and south to eastbound traffic at the intersection. There are also designated ?Bike Lanes? on the east and west side of the roadway, approximately 7 feet in width.
The cross street east of the roadway is a residential area of single family units. The cross street west of the roadway leads into a single family housing development.
There is a posted speed limit of 50 mph for both directions of travel. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.
The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by a four foot wide raised concrete median containing low lying vegetation.
The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2009 Harley Davidson FLHX Street Glide cruiser style motorcycle being operated by a 59 year old male. The rider was wearing a DOT approved Shoei RF1100 full face motorcycle helmet. Prior to my interview the rider claimed he had since disposed of the helmet soon after the crash.
OV1 was a 2000 Ford F350 pick-up truck being operated by a 51 year old female with two passengers on board. OV1 was initially stopped northbound for a red phased light at the intersection in the designated left turn only lane.
The rider was travelling southbound in the designated #3 lane of the multi-lane surface street approaching the intersection on an existing green light. The rider had been travelling at an approximate speed of 45 mph.
 
The driver of OV1 decided (during the red phase) to move her vehicle into the intersection against the opposing traffic and initiate a U-turn type movement to her left with the intent to proceed southbound.
As MC1 entered the intersection, the rider applied his brakes (front & rear ABS) in an attempt to avoid hitting OV1 however struck the right side of the rear bumper causing the rider to fall to the roadway surface and the motorcycle to collapse left side down.
MC1 sustained moderate front end damage to the bumper and fairing as well as minor scraping along the left side from striking the roadway surface. OV1 sustained minor damage to the rear bumper.
While inspecting the ?area of impact? and ?final resting place?, there was a small scrape on the roadway surface and no evidence of skid marks. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj:
The 59 year old rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries were a broken lower left arm, a fracture of the T5 vertebra, contusions to both hands and abrasions to the right knee. He was admitted to a local hospital for treatment of his injuries. The police report
indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
ODriverInj: The driver and passengers of OV1 sustained no injuries.
Human: The 51 year old female driver of OV1 had made an unsafe decision to initiate a U-turn type movement against a red phased light.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
Other than the reported minor damage to OV1 there is no further information available at this time although, the vehicle was driven from the scene after the
crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Light truck turning left.
OV1: 1991 Toyota, Deluxe extra cab light truck
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in February 2013, a Wednesday morning at 0739 hours in Southern California. It was daylight, the weather was clear, the temperature was approximately 58 degrees F and the winds were light. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, in good condition and there was moderate traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial area, on a busy, east west undivided state highway. The roadway has 2 lanes each way with a dedicated left turn lane,
and no traffic controls. The speed limit is 40 mph. There is a 1.3 % uphill eastbound grade and a 3.5 % crown. The Reference Point (RP) is a fire hydrant setback 2 ft. on the north sidewalk.
Vehicle 1 (MC1), is a 1973 Honda, CB500 four, 498 cc, motorcycle, ridden by a 26 year old white male (6 ft. 1 in. and 165 lbs). The rider was wearing a full facial coverage, integral chin bar style of helmet. Vehicle 2 (OV1), is a 1991 Toyota, Deluxe extra cab light truck, driven by a 23 year old white male (5 ft. 10 in. and 155 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

The rider of MC1 was traveling eastbound at approximately 35 mph in the # 1 lane, saw OV 1 enter the turn lane and started slowing, OV 1 entered the common left turn lane, from the westbound # 1 lane, slowed in preparation of making a left turn into a commercial driveway. The driver of OV1 stated that he didn?t see the motorcycle, then started across the eastbound lanes, glimpsed movement to his right and stopped in the #1 eastbound lane. The rider of MC 1 saw OV 1 start a left turn and applied his brakes, applying more rear brake than front. This caused the rear brake to lockup leaving 41 ft. 6 in. of rear tire skid before impacting OV 1 in the front bumper, grill and left headlight assembly. The rider of MC 1 was launched over the hood of OV 1 and came to rest approximately 33 ft. 7 in. east of the Point of Impact (POI), on his back with his feet towards MC 1. MC 1 came to rest on its left side facing south,
approximately 7 ft. 8 in. east and 2 ft. 7in. South of the POI. OV 1 was pushed or was moved approximately 3 ft. backward from the POI. The POI was 20 ft. east and 55 ft. 5 in. south of RP
RiderInj: The 26 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries, as related by medical records and interview: Right distal radius fracture, right ulnar styloid fracture, bilateral abrasions of the lower legs, minor left knee laceration and contusions to the right shoulder and foot. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was five (5).
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was uninjured.
Human: The 23 year-old male driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1. The 26 year-old male rider of MC 1 stated that he had a lower skill level due to minimal riding, this was reflected in his choice of, and application of his avoidance actions.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) right frontal impact to OV1 left side, followed by a capsize event and right side sliding impact into OV2 right rear area. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC right front impact with side-slap into OV1 left side driver?s door area, after which MC1 went down on its right side plane and slid forward into the right rear area of OV2 which was stopped. The rider was fully ejected after the First Harmful event and slid/skidded to his Final Resting Place (FRP). The crash occurred mid-block between two ?T? type intersections. The roadway has four through lanes (two in each direction), bike lanes, and a curb high raised center divider that is landscaped with trees and greenery. The roadway runs in a North/South orientation and is bordered by concrete sidewalks. All vehicles involved were traveling southbound. There is an urban park on the right side of the roadway and a commercial/retail center on the left. The intersection behind the crash scene has a stop sign for the side street and leads into a residential area. The intersection ahead of the crash scene is controlled by multiphase traffic signals and is an entrance/exit for a commercial complex. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, was worn and polished, but
otherwise in good condition. The roadway is a major non-freeway arterial. The roadway has a 1.2% downgrade in the southbound direction and is straight. The roadway has a posted speed limit of 45 mph. There is no on-street parking. Traffic was moderate. The crash occurred in February 2013 at 1509 hours. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the WSW giving the rider a right crosswind. The temperature was 76 degrees F.

MC1 was 2002 Honda CBR 600 F4i sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 20 year old male (5?6?/140 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings. The pre- and post-crash condition of the helmet is unknown.

MC1 was southbound in the #1 (left) lane at a minimum speed of 38 mph. He was riding in the middle of the lane. He saw OV1 enter his roadway ahead of him from the side street and proceed straight in the #2 (right) lane. The rider stated that the signal ahead was red so he had backed off the throttle and was slowing. OV1 suddenly made a sharp lane change into the rider?s lane. The rider applied his brakes leaving approximately 43? of rear tire skid according to the
 
police report. He was unable to avoid crashing into OV1. He impacted OV1 somewhere on the left side, near the driver?s door. He then lost control and was fully ejected off the MC. The rider impacted the right side of OV1, then the ground. He then slid/skidded across lanes into the left turn lane to his FRP next to the center divider. MC1 continued sliding on its? right side plane, front end forward for approximately 78? until it impacted OV2 that was stopped for a red signal in the left turn lane. MC1 impacted the right rear area of OV2. OV1 stopped in the #1 lane. OV2 never moved from its stopped position. The 86 year old female driver (5?01?/128 lbs.) of OV1 said that she never saw MC1. The 61 year old female driver (5?06?/130 lbs.) driver of OV2 had no idea what had happened. She said she felt something slam into the back of her car. She got out and found MC1 wedged under the right rear of her vehicle. During the inspection of the scene, we could only see 27? of the police report documented 43? of skid from MC1. This was a five day old report.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries consisting of pneumothorax, lung contusion, five fractured ribs, a scapula fracture, an avulsion of a toenail, and abrasions. He was admitted to a local hospital for an unknown number of days. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit her ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 86 year old female driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured. The 61 year old female driver of OV2 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The driver of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 prior to making her lane change. There is no obvious failure on the part of the rider.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage as a result of the First Harmful event (impacting OV1), then sliding on its right side plane and impacting OV2. The rear tire pressure at the time of inspection, which was 7 days after the crash, was found to be 8 psi. It is unknown if there was a small air leak as a result of the crash.
