There were no obvious signs of damage that would account for the air pressure loss. It is possible that the air pressure was below recommended psi at the time of the crash. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good. There was no reduction in wheelbase.

OV1 was not inspected. Per the police report, the damage was listed as minor and was driven away. OV2 was not inspected either. Per the police report, the damage was listed as moderate, which included a flat right rear tire. The vehicle was towed from the scene. Its pre and post-crash condition is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors attributed to this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) frontal impact with OV1 left side followed by a right side lay-down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC (frontal impact) vs. OV (left side impact) followed by a secondary lay-down. The crash occurred in the intersection of a four-way, not skewed, signal controlled intersection. Both roadways are major non-freeway arterials. The MC1 roadway has six through lanes (three in each direction with two dedicated left turn lanes) and is an east/west orientation. The intersecting roadway has eight through lanes (four in each direction and two dedicated left turn lanes)
and is in a north/south orientation. Both have curb high raised center dividers that are landscaped with bushes. Both directions of MC1?s roadway has a bike lane. Both roadsides have concrete sidewalks. Both roadways are straight and level and made of an asphalt composition, that is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. Both roadways have commercial/retail features on either side. The posted speed limits are 45 mph. Traffic was heavy, but moving. The crash occurred in March 2013 at 1238 hours. The weather was clear with a temperature of 63 degrees F. There was a light wind from the SSW giving the rider a right crosswind. Both the rider and MC1 came to rest at the POI. The rider, MC1, and OV1 were all moved prior to our arrival and their FRPs were not listed in the police report.

MC1 was 2011 Tomas Sprint ST motorcycle with pedals that was being operated by a 17 year old female (5?4?/150 lbs.). The rider was wearing an open face full coverage helmet with a clear face shield. The helmet is rated for FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell 2005 standards. It sustained very minor abrasions to the back side and a broken vent.

MC1 was eastbound in the #3 right lane, after exiting the bike lane upon approaching the intersection. The rider stated she was going approximately 30 mph and was behind a red pick-up truck. She said that the signal was changing and she thought that the truck was going to continue on through the intersection. When the truck stopped for the changing light, she swerved to the left into the next lane and went around the truck and continued into the intersection. She stated that the light was ?yellow.? In the police report, there are several witnesses that state the light was red. When the rider saw OV1 going northbound through the intersection, she began to brake in an attempt to avoid a collision. She stated that she was unable to stop without impacting OV1. She said she hit OV1 in the driver?s side front door at a speed of between 10-15 mph. and fell to the ground. She said that MC1 was on its right side and next to her. She couldnot recall whether or not OV1 stopped at the POI or parked nearby.
RiderInj: The 17 year old female operator of the MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions, contusions, and one minor laceration. She was treated at a local hospital and released. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit her ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 40 year old male driver (5?09?/150 lbs.) of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The rider of MC1 made a decision error in attempting to enter and cross the intersection against a red light. Even though the driver of OV1 did not participate, it does not appear that there were any human factors attributable to him.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor damage (bent front fender and scuff on right fork leg) as a result of the First Harmful event (impacting OV1). MC1 then sustained additional minor damage (scrapes to right pedal and breaking off rear basket) to the right side after falling on its? right side plane. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as new (MC1 didn?t have a license plate yet). There was no reduction in wheelbase.

OV1 was not inspected. Per the police report, the damage was listed as minor and was driven away. Its pre and post-crash condition is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors attributed to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) front end to left side injury crash with a secondary impact of MC1 with the roadway surface The crash caused the motorcycle rider to be ejected onto the roadway and causing serious injuries.
MV1: 2007 Harley Davidson Buell XB9SX (sport race replica) 983cc, silver in color
OV1: 2003 Nissan Frontier (utility pick up), red in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event. The collision occurred on Wednesday in March 2013 at 1900 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1854 hours showed mostly cloudy skies, with WSW winds at 6.9 mph, and, an ambient temperature of 57.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The motorcyclist was traveling on a multiple lane roadway with grade of +1.2%. The roadway is of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit for north and southbound traffic is 35 mph.
The collision occurred on the northbound left curved portion of the street with an overall travel-way width of 26 feet. The street has two lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and two lanes dedicated for southbound traffic including a continuous left turn lane designated for southbound traffic. The opposing lanes are separated by a painted median strip of two solid double yellow lines. There are no designated traffic control devices to regulate traffic at the crash site.
There is a signal controlled intersection about 125 feet south of the crash site.

Across from the area of the crash site is a 21 foot wide local street intersecting on the south side of the roadway. The local street has a posted stop sign regulating eastbound traffic approaching the intersection. This cross street is uninvolved to this crash event.

MC1 was a 2007 Harley Davidson Buell (sport race replica) 983cc motorcycle being operated by a 26 year old male rider. MC1 was traveling northbound in the #1 lane of the multi-lane minor arterial having just passed through the signal controlled intersection south of the impending crash site.
OV1 was a 2003 Nissan Frontier (utility pick up), that was being operated by a 44 year old male. The driver was in the process of entering the roadway from a private driveway, turning left to proceed southbound. The driver of OV1 moved across the northbound #2 and #1 lanes and was in the process of entering the southbound portion of the roadway. The rider of MC1 was approaching at a speed of about 35 to 40 mph when OV1 crossed from right to left into his lane of travel.
 
The motorcyclist attempted to avoid contact with OV1 however impacted the truck along the left rear quarter panel causing it to collapse (left side down) onto the roadway surface. The rider was ejected off the bike and both he and the motorcycle slid and/or tumbled onto the roadway surface.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 26 year old male operator of MC1 sustained a concussion (NFS), bilateral Pneumothorax, lacerated Spleen, ruptured stomach and, a fractured femur. There was mention of a traumatic brain jury with no further information available. The rider was transported from the scene to a local hospital for treatment. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision.
Human:
The 26 year old male operator of MC1 was traveling at a speed safe for the present traffic on the roadway. The rider was in possession of a valid operator?s license which was also endorsed for the operation of motorcycles.
The 44 year old male driver of OV1 failed to perceive the presence of approaching traffic while entering the intersection.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front end damage with OV1 and minor left side damage as a result of impacting with the roadway surface. Despite the damage sustained MC1 appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
OV1 sustained moderate left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile.
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in March 2013, a Tuesday evening at 1948 hours in Southern California. It was dark and the weather was mostly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 57 degrees F. and the winds were WSW at approximately 5.8 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, with moderate traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial area, approximately 162 ft. west of a 4 way intersection, on an east/west roadway divided by a raised center median. The west roadway has 4 through lanes and the east roadway has 4 through lanes and 2 left turn lanes; the left turn lanes have leading green signals. The speed limit is 40 mph. The roadway was bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks.
Vehicle 1 (MC1) is a 1986 Honda Elite CH80, 79.7 cc scooter, ridden by a 29 year old male (6 ft. 1 in. and 195 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make/model helmet. Vehicle 2 (OV1) is a 2004 Kia Spectra, driven by a 19 year old female (5 ft. 6 in. and 135 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

The rider of MC1 was traveling eastbound at approximately 26 mph in the # 1 lane slowing, approaching the intersection with a red phased signal. OV1 was stopped in the # 2 left turn lane waiting for the green phased signal. When the left turn signal phased green, the driver of OV1 waited for the vehicles ahead to start their left turn, then merged right into the # 1 through lane into the path of MC1. MC1 had insufficient time to avoid OV1 and struck the right rear door and rear fender of OV1. MC1 then hit the roadway on its right side and slid to its point of rest (POR). The point of impact (POI) was 161 ft. 7 in. west of the intersections west curb line and 39 ft. 2 in. north of the east/west roadways south curb line. The POR of MC1 was 25 ft. 7 in. east and 8 ft. 6 in. south of the POI. The POI/POR for OV1 are the same.
RiderInj: The 29 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries, as related during the partial interview: 3 right side rib fractures, shattered right patella and right knee ligament damage. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 13.
ODriverInj: The 19 year-old female driver of OV1 was not injured
Human: The 19 year-old female driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) left side capsize in collision avoidance with OV1. MC1 slid under and into OV1. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC left side lay-down event from over braking and losing control in a collision avoidance maneuver followed by a secondary impact with OV1. MC1 was traveling at a high rate of speed and negotiating a left curve on a motorcycle with a non-functional rear brake. OV1 had slowed to make a right turn onto a driveway. The other lanes were full of vehicles and the MC could not go around. The rider was fully ejected upon losing control and slid/skidded into the middle lanes. His Final Resting Place (FRP) is not known because he got up and walked to the curb/sidewalk area. The crash occurred just prior to the entrance of the driveway. The roadway is major non-freeway arterial. The roadway has eight through lanes (four in each direction with a curb high raised center divider which is landscaped with trees and bushes) with bike lanes and is an east/west orientation. There are concrete sidewalks on both sides of the roadway. The roadway has a 5.6% upgrade at the crash site. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has commercial/retail features on either side. The roadway has a posted speed limit of 45 mph. Traffic was heavy, but moving. The crash occurred in March 2013 at 1325 hours. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with a temperature of 64 degrees F. There was a light wind from the SW giving the rider a right crosswind.

MC1 was 2005 Yamaha YZF-R6 sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 18 year old male (5?10?/140 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face helmet with a clear face shield. The helmet is rated for FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and ECE-22-05
standards. It sustained minor abrasions to the sides and back.

MC1 was eastbound in the #4 right lane and was racing a co-worker on another motorcycle to get home. He stated that he had been stopped at the prior signal and had rapidly accelerated to approximately 80 mph. He had gained on the pack of vehicles ahead saw that the lanes were full. Then he noticed that
the truck in from of him was slowing/stopping. He did a ?head check? to see if there was room to go around the truck and stated that there wasn?t. He said that he had only one option to avoid a crash and that was to brake. He said that he had recently purchased MC1 as a used motorcycle and that the rear brake was
 
not working. He locked up his front brake, leaving approximately 18? of skid before capsizing onto the left side plane of MC1. MC1 then slid for approximately 45? before impacting OV1. MC1?s FRP was at the impact point with OV1. OV1 rolled forward approximately 5? before coming to its FRP. Both of the vehicles had to be towed. The rider was fully ejected and skid/slid into the middle lanes of traffic. MC1 slid in a high side forward configuration and went under OV1 and impacted the rear differential, breaking the differential cover. OV1 is a full size four door pick-up that had been ?lifted? and had over-sized tires. Its height was substantially higher than factory elevations. The modifications on OV1 had nothing to do with crash causation, however, because of its modifications; there was less damage than what would have otherwise been caused by this crash. The 35 year old male driver (5?05?/130 lbs.) of OV1 was looking forward into his turn and was aware of what was in front of him. He did not respond to calls or letters for an interview.
RiderInj: The 18 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions and contusions to both his upper and lower extremities. He was treated at a local hospital and released. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 35 year old male driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The rider of MC1 made a decision error in riding at almost double the posted speed limit and a reaction failure in braking, along with a pre- existing mechanical condition that he was fully aware of (non-functional rear brake). Even though the driver of OV1 did not participate, it does not appear that there were any human factors attributable to him.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage. The damage was caused by sliding on its left side plane and then impacting OV1. The entire fairing was broken off, along with the headlight assembly and instrument cluster. The gas tank was damaged from sliding under and impacting OV1. Some of the damage could possibly be attributed to the handlebars impacting the trailer hitch and ball unit from OV1. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as fair to good. There was no reduction in wheelbase.

OV1 sustained only a broken differential gear cover. Its pre and post-crash condition would be labeled as good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors attributed to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (raised concrete curb and sidewalk), right side impact crash causing the motorcycle to collapse onto the roadway surface and tumble side to side. The motorcycle rider sustained non-life threatening injuries. There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2007 Suzuki GSXR, (sport race replica) motorcycle, (599cc), black in color.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object right side impact type traffic collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred during the hours of darkness on Thursday, March 2013 at 1935 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, with winds out of the west at 4.6 mph, and an ambient temperature of +59.0 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured uphill grade of 3.2% in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a multiple lane roadway with a 420 foot left curve and 1250 overall radius. There is an overall eastbound travel-way width of 38 feet. This is a principal east/west arterial roadway with two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic and three lanes for eastbound traffic. The east and westbound lanes are divided by a 14 foot wide painted (solid double yellow lines) median. On the north side of the roadway and crash site is rural countryside with a downhill slope of low lying vegetation. The south side of the roadway is an uphill embankment with low lying vegetation and park like environment adjacent to a single family residential area.

At the location of the crash site there are no traffic control devices to regulate the flow of traffic in the area other than posted 55 mph speed limit signs for both east and westbound traffic. There are no intersecting streets on either the north or south side of the roadway in proximity of the crash site. Both the north and south sides of the roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and five foot wide concrete sidewalks. There is no overhead illumination for either north or southbound traffic along this area of the highway.
The street is designed without designated bicycle access along both the north and southbound sides. Parking on both sides of the street is prohibited.
MC1 was a 2007 Suzuki GSXR (sport race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 27 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a motorcycle helmet of unknown make or model that remained secure on the rider during the crash event.
The rider was travelling eastbound in the #2 lane of the street at a high rate of speed. By the rider?s own admission he estimated his speed at 70 mph. As the rider continued eastbound into the curve, he was afraid his speed was too fast and attempted to slow down by braking. The rider did not use the front brake
 
out of concern he would dump the bike on to the roadway surface. The rider was trying to use the rear brake when the bike drifted right, from the #2 lane to the #3 lane.
The bike continued drifting and struck the raised concrete curb face along the south side of the street. The bike and rider continued along the curb face for about 103 feet until the bike collapsed left side down and the rider was ejected onto the adjacent concrete sidewalk. The motorcycle continued eastbound another 229 feet until coming to rest in the # 3 lane. The rider slid for a distance of about 77 feet until coming to rest on the sidewalk.
When contacted by law enforcement officials, the rider displayed no objective symptoms of drug/alcohol intoxication and was transported to a local hospital for treatment.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 27 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. These injuries were abrasions to both of his hands and a complaint of pain to his back. This was verified by witnesses at the scene.
Human: The 27 year old male rider was unfamiliar with MC1 and was driving at a high rate of speed that was unsafe for his level of experience.
Vehicle: The motorcycle (MC1) sustained moderate left side and minor right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. There were no other vehicles involved.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Van.
MV1: 2008 San Yang, SYM HD200, 171 cc, scooter
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in March 2013, at 1209 hours in Southern California. It was daylight, the weather was clear, the temperature was approximately 69 degrees F. and the winds were SSW at approximately 4.6 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, with light traffic.

The crash occurred at a driveway in a commercial/business area. The east/west roadway is undivided, and has two through lanes and a left turn lane for both directions; there are no traffic signals and the speed limit is 40 mph. The roadway was bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks,
MC1 is a 2008 San Yang SYM HD200, 171 cc, scooter, ridden by a 36 year old male (6 ft. and 180 lbs.). The rider was wearing a DOT open face helmet with a bubble type face shield. OV1 is a 2000 Dodge Caravan driven by a 49 year old male (5 ft. 4 in. and 130 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

The rider of MC1 was traveling westbound at approximately 20 mph on right side of the # 2 lane slowing to make a right turn into the driveway. The rider of
MC1 saw OV1 behind him on his left approximately 2-3 ft.  OV1 was traveling westbound at approximately 22 mph on left side of the # 2 lane slowing to make a right turn into the driveway; the driver was distracted, looking for a dentist office and did not see MC1. MC1 and OV1 attempted to make a right turn into the driveway at the same time. The right front fender and wheel of OV1 struck MC1 on the left front area. MC1 had insufficient time to avoid OV1. MC1 then hit the roadway on its left side and slid to its point of rest (POR). The point of impact (POI) was 34 ft. 9 in. west and 1 ft. 6 in. north of the fire hydrant Reference Point. The POR of MC1 was within 6 ft. of the POI. OV1 stopped in the north parking lot.
RiderInj: The 36 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries, as related on the police report: Left knee and Left lower leg abrasions. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was one (1).
ODriverInj: The 49 year-old male driver of OV1 was not injured.
Human: The 49 year-old male driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1. The 36 year-old male rider of MC1 used improper lane positioning prior to making the right turn.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) frontal impact to left side of OV1 followed by a right side plane CW rotating event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC frontal followed by a right side plane lay-down event after impacting the left side of OV1. The roadway is a principal arterial, non-freeway that bisects a single family residential area. It has three lanes of travel in each direction, bike lanes, and dedicated left turn lanes, separated by curb high raised and landscaped center dividers. The crash occurred at a four-way, not skewed type intersection that has no signal controls. There are stop signs for the intersecting side streets. No parking allowed on either side of the street. The roadway has a north/south orientation. The roadway is straight and level with a 0.5% grade and a 0.4% crown in the southbound direction. The roadway is 105? wide and has concrete curbs. The roadside has 8? sidewalks adjacent to the curb. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The intersecting side street runs in an east/west orientation and is a local road with painted double yellow lines. It is straight and level with a 0.4% grade and a 3.1% crown. On-street parallel parking is allowed on both sides of the street. There are concrete curbs and adjacent nine foot sidewalks. On the same side of the street as OV1 are apartments. On the opposite side are single family residences. The posted speed limit is 25 mph. Buildings and shrubbery creates permanent visual obstructions on the approach to the intersection for both directions of travel. The limit line for eastbound traffic is set back 8? from the prolongation of the west curb line. Both roadways have poles/trees on the roadside. OV1 was attempting to go straight across the intersection when the crash occurred. Traffic conditions were moderate. The rider was fully ejected and sustained fatal injuries. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. There were no pre-impact tire marks from either vehicle involved. There are post impact tire marks from OV1. The crash occurred in March 2013 in Southern California at 1009 hours. The weather was partly cloudy with a temperature of 61 degrees F. The winds were light and variable.

MC1 was 2010 Special Construction cruiser type motorcycle that was being operated by a 66 year old male, (5?10?/190 lbs.). Special Construction vehicles are not manufactured by formally recognized manufacturers. The vehicles are ?piece-mealed? together with new or used parts from a variety of suppliers. Refer to footnote section cited from the California Vehicle Code (CVC)1. The rider was wearing a HJC half style helmet with FVMSS 218 (US DOT) safety ratings and weighed 29.15 ounces. The helmet has a model name of ?Evolution.? It sustained minor to moderate damage with visible cracking around the entire ABS shell.
 
The helmet was fitted with an aftermarket bicycle style plastic ?D? slot quick release. There was no obvious sign of a failure on the part of the strap or plastic connector. The double ?D? rings were still attached. The helmet was retained on the rider?s head through to completion of the crash sequence. The rider was wearing prescription sunglasses.

MC1 was southbound in the # 3 (right curb) lane at about the speed limit of 45 mph. when OV1 pulled out from the stop sign and attempted to go straight across the intersection. The 66 year old female driver (5?03?/115 lbs.) of OV1 said that she had been stopped waiting for traffic to clear before attempting to go through the intersection. She stated that she never saw MC1. The rider made no obvious collision avoidance maneuvers and broadsided OV1 in the area of
the left rear tire/wheel. MC1 then side-slapped OV1 with its right side and then fell on its right side plane. As a result of the impact, the front tire/wheel of MC1 separated from the vehicle. The front forks also collapsed and broke. There was a maximum reduction in wheelbase at the time of the crash. With the front tire/wheel missing and the broken forks, a static measurement of reduction was not possible. The rider was fully ejected and sustained fatal injuries. His orientation at FRP is unknown. OV1 went into a CCW rear end rotation and came to rest in the middle of the intersection facing northwest. MC1 was down on its right side plane and went into a CW rotation. Its FRP was approximately 31? south of the POI and was also in a northwesterly orientation. The rider?s FRP
was approximately 50? southwest of the POI. Eastbound traffic can clearly see a vehicle at the limit line of the cross street for well over 200?. Both MC1 and OV1 were towed to a police impound yard for additional inspections.
RiderInj: The 66 year old male operator of MC1 sustained fatal injuries consisting of a massive pelvic fracture; bilateral hemothorax; liver laceration; 8 fractured ribs; mesenteric, liver parenchyma, retro-peritoneal, and bladder hemorrhages; numerous lacerations, abrasions, and contusions. The rider?s autopsy showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 66 year old female driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The driver of OV1 had a perception error in not seeing MC1 approaching. There were no human errors on the part of the rider.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front end and right as a result of impacting OV1 and sliding on the roadway. The damage consisted of a totally collapsed front end with the front wheel broken off. Numerous scratches, scrapes, and dents on the entire right side. The left side leather saddle bag and spare helmet were torn off. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good.

OV1 sustained moderate to major damage involving the entire left rear quarter panel, C-pillar, a broken left rear wheel axel, broken left side windows, and left side air bag deployments. The pre-crash condition of OV1 would be labeled as very good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors attributed to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (raised concrete curb), left center front head on impact crash with a secondary lay-down event. The motorcycle also impacted a raised concrete sidewalk, surface vegetation coming to rest in an asphalt parking lot. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained fatal injuries as a result of multiple impacts with the ground and environmental objects (tree and surface, vegetation). A passenger was riding on the motorcycle at the time of the crash and, sustained critical injuries as a result of being ejected onto the ground.
MV1: 1979 Yamaha XS1100SF (cruiser style) 1101cc black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object head-on impact crash event resulting in fatal injuries to the motorcycle rider and, critical injuries to the passenger. The collision occurred on Sunday in March 2013 at 2037 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, ESE wind direction @ 3.5 mph, and an ambient temperature of +66.9 degrees F. Sunset was at 1908 hours. The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. There were no roadway crown or grade issues with this portion of the roadway.
The collision occurred on a straight portion of a curved, multiple lane surface street with an overall travel-way width of 76 feet. This is a principal north/south arterial with two lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and two lanes for southbound traffic. The roadway design is an ?S? curve at the location of a four way signal controlled intersection. The intersection and the signals controlling traffic did not contribute to the crash causation however the curvature was
present as a factor.

MC1 was traveling northbound in the #2 lane approaching the intersection into a left curve. As MC1 passed through the intersection it moved into a right curve portion of the roadway. The posted speed limit for north and southbound traffic is 45 mph. The area of the crash site is bordered by a commercial business park along the west side and residential single family homes along the east side.
The street is also designed to allow bicycle access with designated (8? wide) lanes along the east side and (6? wide) along the west side. Parking on both sides of the street is prohibited.
Both the north and south sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs, and concrete sidewalks. The west side of the environment adjacent to the street is bordered by trees and surface vegetation (grass lawns).
MC1 was a 1979 Yamaha XS1100SF (Touring style) motorcycle being operated by a 42 year old male rider. There was also a 55 year old female passenger seated directly behind the rider. The rider was wearing a ?novelty? style non-DOT approved half shell helmet with a double ?D? ring nylon chin strap. The passenger was also wearing a non-DOT approved half shell as well. Both helmets were ejected from rider and passenger during the crash event.
The rider was travelling northbound in the #2 lane of the multi-lane surface street having passed through the four way intersection prior to the crash event. As the rider continued northbound, negotiating through the ?S? curve MC1 went wide to the left, crossing into the southbound lanes striking the raised concrete curb on the west side of the street. The motorcycle moved along the face of the curb a short distance, eventually jumped the curb and collapsed tumbling end over end onto the concrete sidewalk and surface vegetation. MC1 came to rest inside a parking area about 119 feet north of the initial area of impact with the curb. Both the rider and the passenger were ejected as a result of the impact of MC1 with the curb face. The rider rolled or tumbled until he struck a tree
about 55 feet northwest of the area of impact. The passenger rolled or tumbled into the parking area until coming to rest about 131 feet northwest of the area of impact.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, passenger conduct, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event. The traffic signals at the intersection were functioning properly and there were no apparent issues with the offset ?S? curve design.
RiderInj:
The 42 year old male rider of MC1 sustained multiple blunt force traumatic fatal injuries of the head and thoracic areas of the body. The Coroner?s report also indicated that there was a postmortem presence of alcohol (0.31 BAC) in his system. There was no apparent presence of medications or drugs.
The 55 female passenger sustained critical injuries as a result of the crash. She was transported from the scene and, admitted to the hospital for eight days. The injuries sustained were numerous fractures to the left side of the rib cage, left scapula and multiple fractures of the T4 through T12 thoracic vertebra.
Human: The 42 year old male rider of MC1 was driving at a high rate of speed that was unsafe and, with a blood/alcohol concentration of 0.31 BAC. The 55 year old female passenger claimed she did nothing in the way of distracting the rider at the time of the crash.
Vehicle: MC1sustained total damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. There were no other vehicles either parked or in transit that contributed to the cause or outcome of the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. fixed object (Curb)
MV1: 2005 Yamaha YZF R6, 599 cc, Sport motorcycle
Crash:
This single vehicle motorcycle crash occurred in March 2013 at 2203 hours in Southern California. It was dark and the roadway was lighted by overhead street lights. The temperature was approximately 56 degrees F., the weather was clear and the winds were WSW at approximately 2.3 mph and the asphalt roadway surface was dry.

The crash occurred at an intersection, in a commercial/business area. The north/south street is separated by a 4 ft. wide concrete divider, has four southbound through lanes, two right hand and two left turn lanes; the northbound lanes consist of three through lanes, two left turn lanes and a right turn lane. The west side of the intersection is separated by a 4 ft. wide concrete divider, with three through lanes, two left hand and two right hand turn lanes eastbound and three westbound through lanes. The east side of the intersection is separated by a 4 ft. wide concrete divider, three through lanes westbound, two through, two left turn and one right turn lane eastbound. The north and east sides of the intersection did not play a role in this accident. All traffic controls were functioning properly, and the posted speed limits were 45 mph north/south and 40 mph east/west.

MC1, a 2005 Yamaha YZF R6 599 cc Sport style motorcycle, was being operated by a 23 year old female (5 ft. 2 in./ 131 lbs.) who was wearing an EXO-400 full face Dot and Snell M2010 helmet. MC1 was proceeding northbound in the number one left turn lane, at approximately 40 mph. Due to the inexperience of the rider; she failed to brake for the left turn, ran wide and struck the north curb. MC1 traveled approximately 36 ft. west of the west curb-line, where MC1 high sided to the right. The rider was thrown approximately 10 ft. north of the point of impact onto the sidewalk/grass area. MC1 continued 67 ft. west along the curb, coming to rest on its right side.
RiderInj: The 23 year old female rider of MC1 has an AIS score of 9, as a result of: Left scapula fracture, left 4 & 5th rib fractures and left leg abrasions.
Human: The 23 year old female riders lack of experience and skill were major crash causal factors in this crash.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors related to MC1.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) frontal impact to right side of OV1 followed by a left side plane lay down event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC frontal impact followed by a left side plane lay-down event after impacting the area between the right front wheel-well/fender and the leading edge of the right front door area of OV1. The roadway is a principal arterial, non-freeway road in a residential area. It has three lanes of travel in each direction separated by a curb high raised center median that is landscaped with trees and shrubbery. On-street parallel parking is allowed only on the south side of the roadway (rider?s right). The roadway has an east/west dedication; however, it runs in a northeast/southwest orientation at the crash site. The roadway bisects single family residences (mobile home park) on the left and town homes on the right. The roadway is offset west of the crash site and has an
?S? curve. The length of the ?S? curve was measured to be 388?. The ?S? curve is first a right turn and ends with a left turn. The crash occurred at approximately 200? east of the last curve. The offset was measured at 30?. The roadway is 99? wide and has concrete curbs and 7? concrete sidewalks. The crash occurred
mid-block at a driveway type intersection, not skewed, with no signal controls. There are dedicated left turn lanes for both east and westbound traffic. The landscaped center divider along with the 30? offset creates a permanent visual obstruction for westbound traffic in the left turn lane as well as eastbound traffic in all lanes. MC1 was traveling at an unknown speed. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The 28 year old male driver (6?03?/285 lbs.) of OV1 was in the westbound left turn lane, starting his left turn. After the crash occurred, the driver of OV1 moved his vehicle to the side of the roadway south of the intersection. Traffic conditions were moderate to heavy. The rider was fully ejected and sustained major injuries. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The crash occurred in April 2013 in Southern California at 1711 hrs. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with a temperature of 65 degrees F. There was a moderate wind from the south. MC1 was towed.

MC1 was a 2012 Yamaha YZF R6 sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 30 year old male (6? 00?/175 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face helmet with a gray/smoke tinted face shield. The helmet is rated for FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and ECE 22-05 standards. It sustained major fractures in the chin bar area and abrasions. It was retained on the rider?s head to the completion of the crash events. The rider was also wearing a motorcycle oriented heavy leather jacket and gloves.
 
MC1 was eastbound in the #1 lane at an unknown speed, but presumed to be excessive based on statements from witnesses and the damage to both vehicles. The driver of OV1 said that when eastbound traffic cleared, he started making his left turn when he saw a jogger headed westbound on the south side sidewalk who was about ready continue across the street. There was also a stopped vehicle at the northbound stop sign with its left turn signal on. The driver of OV1 then slowed, nearly stopping, at which time he looked back for on-coming eastbound traffic. He stated that he saw MC1 and was almost simultaneously impacted by MC1. The driver of OV1 said that he then drove to the southwest corner and parked his truck, then ran back into the street to check on the rider. The rider was non-responsive. MC1 was approximately 10? north of the POI on its left side plane facing southeast. The rider was
approximately 10? southwest of MC1. The front tire was flat from the impact which broke the front rim. The forks were also broken. The gas tank has a dent on the right side that appears to have been made by the handlebars after the initial impact caused the forks turn to the right. The right side of the handlebars impacted the gas tank, breaking the throttle/hand grip off. MC1 was found to be in 3rd gear. There were no pre-impact tire marks from either vehicle. The post- crash tire marks made by OV1 were made as he drove to park after rolling though fluids, not as a result of the crash. OV1 sustained moderate damage to the right side and roof. MC1 was towed. OV1 was allowed to be driven home.
RiderInj: The 30 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries consisting of spinal fractures to C5, C6, and C7; brain hemorrhage-NFS, a collapsed lung, a right femur fracture, and a left tibia fracture. He was admitted to a local hospital for an unknown number of days. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 28 year old male driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The rider of MC1 made a decision error in riding too fast for the roadway with its offset, and limited distance viewing due to permanent view obstructions consisting of trees and bushes in the center divider.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front end as a result of impacting OV1. There was additional minor damage to the right side after a side- slap occurred. There was very minor damage to the left side of MC1 consisting of scratches after MC1 fell onto its? left side plane. The windshield was broken, probably when the rider was ejected and flew over the handlebars. There was evidence that the front tire made contact with the radiator. A static measurement for the reduction in wheelbase was not possible because the front tire and fork assembly were broken. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as new or near new.

OV1 sustained moderate to major damage to the right side starting at the right front fender and moving through the door and rear cab area, then ending a short distance beyond the forward corner of the truck bed. The roof line was dented. The metal running board step was also severely deformed. Only the right side mirror had been replaced when OV1 was inspected. Its pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.
Environmental:
The roadway design is a major contributing factor in crash causation. The 30? offset creates permanent view obstructions for both directions of travel involving a westbound left turning vehicle. The full array of trees and shrubbery planted in the center divider may help out as a traffic
 
barrier and with beautification, but also creates a permanent visual obstruction. The maximum distance with a clear view is approximately 200? for the #3 lane and approximately 100? for the #1 lane.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) frontal impact to left side of OV1 followed by a left side plane capsize event. OV1 then rolled into OV2 which was parked on the opposite side of the street. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC frontal impact followed by a left side plane lay-down event after impacting the left front door area of OV1. OV1 had a secondary frontal impact with OV2 to the left rear side. OV2 was legally parked across the street. The roadway is a local road in a residential area. It has one lane of travel in each direction separated by double yellow painted lines. There is a parking lane on each side of the roadway, separated by a solid white painted line. The roadway has a north/south dedication; however it runs in a northwest/southeast orientation at the crash site. On the riders right is single family residences. On his left is a park. The roadway has a slight right curve for the rider?s direction and has a -1.3% grade. The roadway is a total of 38? wide and has concrete curbs. The roadside has a seven foot grass strip and five foot sidewalks. The crash occurred mid-block between two ?T? type intersections. There are no permanent visual obstructions for either party involved in the crash. MC1 was traveling at or close to the posted speed limit of 25 mph. OV1 was pulled over to the right curb and appeared to be parked. Traffic conditions were light.  The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The crash occurred in April 2013 in Southern California at 0955 hrs. The weather was clear with a temperature of 61 degrees F. There was a light wind from the WNW giving the rider a mostly headwind.

MC1 was 2007 Honda Gold Wing touring type motorcycle that was being operated by a 70 year old male, (6? 01?/220 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face helmet with a clear face shield. The helmet is rated for FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell M2005
standards. It sustained minor abrasions to the right front, right side, and back. It was retained on the riders? head to the completion of the crash events.

MC1 was northbound in the #1 lane at about the speed limit when OV1 pulled out from the right curb and started making a left hand U-turn. The rider stated that he saw the OV start to slowly move as he was approaching, so he veered to the left side of his lane. He stated that he thought the OV driver saw him and
 
would pull out behind him after he passed. The rider said that he didn?t remember braking or slowing as he approached the OV, only changing his position in
the lane. As the rider came in close proximity to OV1, it pulled out in front of him, making a left U-turn. Approximately 8? of front wheel skid was located at the crash site from MC1. The tire mark starts east of the center line and ends on the center line. When the police arrived, all vehicles were at their final resting places (FRPs). MC1 was a little over 7? away from the point of impact (POI) when located at its FRP. MC1 was in the middle of the roadway on its? left side plane facing in a northwesterly direction. OV1 was blocking the southbound lane in a westerly direction and in contact with OV2 which was legally parked in the southbound parking lane facing south. The rider was located at an unknown location along the south curb line. The rider stated that he remembered hearing
a ?thud? on his helmet, but doesn?t remember hitting anything other than the ground. When OV1 was inspected, it was in a repair facility and had already been partially dismantled. The left front quarter panel, drivers? door, and seat had been removed from the vehicle. They were still at the facility and inspected. The windshield had been removed and thrown in the trash. The manager of the repair facility said that the windshield had a ?large body dent and was shattered.? The hood of OV1 was in-place and showed that it had been knocked out of alignment. The left side air bags in the drivers? compartment had
deployed. There was a small amount of scuffing to the left front bumper area where OV1 impacted OV2. OV2 was never inspected. Both MC1 and OV1 had to be towed.
RiderInj: The 70 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of a fractured humorous, a minor laceration to his lower lip, several contusions to his legs, and a dis-located right thumb. One very large contusion was on his inner left thigh. It was most likely caused by the gas tank. He was admitted to a local hospital for four days. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 46 year old female driver (5? 03?/105 lbs.) of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human:
The rider of MC1 made a decision error in assuming that the driver of OV1 saw him approaching and would wait for him to pass. Other than that, there were no human errors on the part of the rider.

The driver of OV1 who did not participate had at least a perception error.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front end as a result of impacting OV1. There was additional minor damage to the right side after a side- slap occurred. There was very minor damage to the left side of MC1 consisting of scratches to the crash bars after MC1 fell onto its? left side plane. The windshield was broken, probably when the rider was ejected and flew over the handlebars. There was a measured reduction in wheelbase of 1.5?. The pre- crash condition would be labeled as very good.

OV1 sustained what appeared to be moderate damage to the drivers? door and left front quarter panel as a result of the impact with MC1 which caused the left side airbags to deploy. The lower frame below the door also had a bend in it. The front windshield was broken by the rider when he was ejected and flew over the handlebars and impacted it. Its pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors attributed to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) right front to left side injury crash with a secondary impact (MC1) with the roadway surface. The crash caused the motorcycle rider and passenger to be ejected onto the roadway causing minor injuries.
MV1: 2009 Suzuki GSXR sport race replica (999cc) black
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event. The collision occurred on a Sunday in April 2013 at 1009 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 0954 hours with overcast skies, variable winds at 3.5 mph and, an ambient temperature of 60.1 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The motorcyclist was traveling on a two lane local road with grade of +0.8%. The roadway is of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit for north and southbound traffic is 45 mph.
The collision occurred on the southbound portion of the street with an overall travel-way width of 34 feet. The street has one lane dedicated for northbound traffic and one lane dedicated for southbound traffic separated by one set of painted double yellow lines dividing the opposing lanes. The opposing lanes are separated by a painted median strip of two solid double yellow lines. There are designated ?Bike Lanes? on both sides of the roadway approximately 5 feet wide.

There are no designated traffic control devices to regulate traffic at the crash site.
At the scene of the crash site is a 34 foot wide private driveway intersecting the south side of the roadway. The driveway has a posted stop sign regulating eastbound traffic approaching the intersection. The driveway leads to a commercial winery open to public access. OV1 was turning into this driveway at the time of the crash.

MC1 was a 2009 Suzuki GSXR (sport race replica) 999cc motorcycle being operated by a 29 year old male rider. There was also an 18 year old female passenger aboard, seated directly behind the rider. MC1 was traveling northbound in the #1 lane of the two lane local road approaching the commercial driveway intersection. The rider was traveling at a speed of approximately 50 mph (73.5 fps).
OV1 was a 2006 Honda Accord (automobile) that was being operated by a 29 year old male. The driver was also traveling northbound at a reduced speed of 25 mph and slowing. The driver was intending to turn left into the driveway and had signaled his intention to do so. However, the rider of MC1 had moved into the southbound lane in order to pass OV1.
 
The driver of OV1 initiated the left turn at an estimated speed of 10 mph, crossing into the southbound lane of the road. The rider of MC1 was a distance of approximately 50-60 feet behind OV1 when he noticed OV1 making his left turn.
The rider had insufficient time to avoid contact with OV1 due to the proximity of both vehicles . MC1 struck OV1 on the left side near the rear driver side door. This caused both he rider and the passenger to be ejected and the bike to collapse right side down.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 29 year old male operator of MC1 sustained a complaint of pain to his leg and refused any treatment at the scene. However, the passenger of MC1 sustained abrasions to her abdomen, both knees, and a complaint of pain to her back and shoulder. She was treated at the scene and later transported to a local hospital for treatment. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision.
Human: The 29 year old male operator of MC1 was traveling at a speed unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway and was attempting to pass OV1 on the left. The rider was in not possession of a valid operator?s license.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate right front damage and, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. OV1 sustained moderate left side damage and, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Asphalt roadway in avoidance of other accident
Crash:
This was a three vehicle crash that involved an initial OV to OV crash with MC high siding on the asphalt roadway in a failed avoidance maneuver; there was no OV/MC contact. The crash occurred on a Saturday afternoon in April 2013 at 1630 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the weather was clear, the temperature was 74 degrees F and the winds were SW at approximately 7 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and noted to be travel worn with surface cracking.

The crash took place at a commercial driveway related T-junction. The north/south straight roadway has raised curbing and sidewalks, is divided by a 26 ft. wide, raised concrete median and there are three through lanes and a bicycle lane in each direction. Going southbound there is a 1.1% > grade and a 4.0% crown, a right turn lane at the crash involved driveway and a bus turnout approximately 121 ft. north. There are no traffic controls and the posted speed limit is 55 mph. The ?Reference Point? (RP) is a fire hydrant approximately 78 ft. north of the south facing curb-line of the driveway and approximately 2 ft. west of the east facing curb-line.
MC1 is a 2001 Kawasaki ZRX 1200R, (1164 cc) Sport/Race replica motorcycle, ridden by a 50 year old male who is 6 ft. 1 in. and 210 lbs. The rider was wearing a DOT/Snell 2010 full face motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield. OV1 is a gold colored 2000 Toyota Camry, driven by a 68 year old female who is 5 ft. 6 in. and 120 lbs. OV2 is a black colored 2007 Toyota Corolla, driven by a 30 year old female who is 5 ft. 6 in. and 150 lbs. The drivers of OV1 and OV2 were reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling southbound in lane # 2 at an estimated speed of 45 mph, with OV1 ahead in the # 2 lane and OV2 in lane # 3 in OV1?s blind spot. The driver of OV1 attempted to make a right turn into the driveway from lane # 2; OV2 braked but hit OV1 in the right rear side and pushed OV1 into the right turn lane and driveway, OV2 hit the curb face. The ?Area of Impact? (AOI) of OV1 & OV2 was approximately 38 ft. along the station line and 12 east. The rider of MC1 braked
 
and attempted to swerve to the left, leaving approximately 52 ft. of skid overall. He lost control and high-sided onto the right side. The AOI of MC1 was approximately 54 ft. along the station line and 27 feet east of it. Both MC1 and the rider slid to their final rest positions in lane #2 approximately 67 ft. south of the RP.
RiderInj:
The 50 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries: Right posterior 3-6 rib fractures, right scapula fracture, left humeral head fracture, right pneumothorax, abrasions to the right shoulder, left posterior hand and bilaterally to the elbows. The Injury Severity Score (ISS)
was 14.
There was no drug or alcohol involvement.
Human: The 68 year-old female driver of OV1failed to yield the right of way to OV2 by making a right turn from lane #2, causing an accident with OV2. The rider of MC1 failed to keep a safe following distance and lost control trying to avoid the accident between OV1 and OV2.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) right frontal impact to frontal center impact to OV1 followed by a right side plane capsize event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC right frontal impact followed by a right side plane lay-down event after impacting the center front of OV1. The roadway is a principal arterial, non- freeway that bisects a single family residential area on the rider's right and a large church facility on the left. It has three lanes of travel in each direction separated by curb high raised and landscaped center divider. The crash occurred at a ?T? type intersection that has no signal controls. There is a stop sign for the intersecting side street. The opposite direction of travel for the rider has a dedicated left turn lane. There is no parking allowed on either side of the
street. The roadway has an east/west dedication; however it runs in a northeast/southwest orientation at the crash site. The roadway has a left curve for the rider?s direction with a radius of 1251?. The roadway has a 5.1% upgrade and a 5% crown in the eastbound direction. The roadway is a total of 87? wide and has concrete curbs. The roadside has 5' sidewalks adjacent to the curb prior to the crash location and across the street. After the intersection, the sidewalk on
the south side is wavy and has landscaping in the areas where the sidewalk separates from the curb. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The intersecting side street runs in a north/south orientation and is a local road with no markings. It has a 5.3% downgrade and a 1.9% crown. There are curbs and landscaped shoulders. The posted speed limit is 25 mph. There are no permanent visual obstructions in the eastbound direction or from the limit line forward to the prolongation of the south curb line for OV1. OV1 was attempting to make a left turn across the intersection when the crash occurred. Traffic conditions were moderate. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. There were no pre or post-impact tire marks located that could be attributed to either involved vehicle. The crash occurred in April 2013 at 1040 hours. The weather was clear with a temperature of 66 degrees F. There was a light wind from the south giving the rider a mostly right crosswind.

MC1 was 2005 Honda ST1300 sport/touring type motorcycle that was being operated by a 45 year old male, (6? 04?/275 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety features or ratings. The helmet was not inspected.

MC1 was eastbound in the # 2 lane at about the speed limit of 40 mph. when OV1 pulled out from the stop sign and attempted to make a left turn. The rider
 
stated that he saw OV1 stopped and the next thing he knew, he was hit on his right side and went down. He made no evasive maneuvers. The 51 year old female (5? 09?/140 lbs.) driver of OV1 said that she never saw MC1. Neither involved party participated for an interview. After the crash occurred, the rider slid/skidded approximately 99' to his Final Resting Place (FRP). He was in the area of the #1 and #2 eastbound lanes. MC1 slid on its right side plane, rotating in a CCW rotation for approximately 160'. Its FRP was in the #1 lane facing westbound. OV1 was moved and parked after the crash. Its FRP is unknown. There are no permanent visual obstructions for either party. Eastbound traffic can clearly see a vehicle at the limit line of the cross street for well over 200'. If a vehicle at the stop sign rolls forward of the stop limit line, they become more visible. Since the rider could see OV1, there is no doubt that there were no mobile obstructions either. MC1 was towed and OV1 was driven away.
RiderInj: The 45 year old male operator of MC1 sustained one minor injury listed on police report consisting of an abrasion to the left wrist. He had numerous complaints of pain. He was taken to a local hospital, treated and released. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 51 year old female driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment and was not injured.
Human: The driver of OV1 had a perception error in not seeing MC1 approaching. There were no human errors on the part of the rider.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate damage to the right side as a result of impacting OV1 and sliding on the roadway. The damage consisted of numerous scratches and scrapes along the faring, windshield, seat, and exhaust pipe. The plastic covered engine guard protected MC1 from much more damage. The
right side mirror and saddle bag were broken off. The only damage on the left side of MC1 was a missing mirror housing, which was possibly knocked off by the rider when he was ejected. The mirror is still intact on the MC. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good.

OV1 was not inspected. The extent of damage to the front end is unknown. OV1 was listed in the police report as being driven away after the crash. The pre- crash condition of OV1 is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors attributed to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) side swipe type crash event causing a secondary low side left collapse of the motorcycle on to the roadway surface and subsequent impact with a fixed object (raised concrete curb & sidewalk). The motorcycle rider was ejected off MC1 however, came to rest within six feet of the final resting place. The rider sustained non-life threatening injuries that did not require transportation to a medical facility for treatment.
MV1: 2007 Honda CBR 600rr (sport race replica) motorcycle, 599cc, silver
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event on Tuesday in April 2013 at 1325 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed scattered clouds, with variable winds @ 5.8 mph, and an ambient temperature of +66.9 degrees F. Sunset was at 1931 hours on this day.
The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 12.0 % downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a right curved, two lane local residential street with an overall travel-way width of 36 feet. The street runs east & west with no physical or painted lane dividers.

There are no designated bike lanes for either direction of travel and parking adjacent to both sides of this street is allowed. Both the north and south sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs, and a 5 foot wide concrete sidewalk along the north side of the street.
The north side of the street is occupied by single family residential homes. The south side of the street has a raised concrete curb, no sidewalk and, an uphill embankment leading to other single family residences.
The location of the crash site was approximately 102 feet west of the nearest local street T-intersection. The intersection has no posted or marked traffic control signs, signals or advisories. The posted speed limit on this street is 25 mph for both directions of travel.

MC1 was a 2007 Honda CBR 600rr (sport race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 39 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a Shoei (unknown model) DOT approved and Snell M2005 (USA) rated full face motorcycle helmet at the time of the crash event.
The rider was travelling eastbound on the downhill portion of the local surface street at an estimated speed of approximately 35 mph. The rider was in a right turn movement on the street approaching a T-intersection. There were parked vehicles immediately adjacent and to the right of his position. There was an
 
obstruction to his view of traffic on this street due to the presence of trees and shrubs along the north side of the street. The measured radius of the street is 222 feet with an overall 229 length of curve in the area of the crash site.
As the rider continued eastbound he came in visual contact with OV1 which was traveling westbound (uphill) at an approximate speed of 5 mph. The distance between the two-vehicles was no greater than 100 feet.
The rider was concerned that OV1 was occupying a portion of his side of the street and in reaction to this moved his motorcycle towards the left side of the street in with the intent of passing along the right side of OV1.

However, the driver of OV1 (a 17 year old female); reacting to the presence of MC1 approaching directly at her, moved her vehicle towards the right side of the street. MC1 impacted OV1 along the left driver side door of OV1 causing the rider to lose control. MC1 collapsed on to the roadway (left side down) surface sliding about 30 feet until both bike and rider came to rest on the concrete sidewalk along the north side of the street.
RiderInj: The 39 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were for the most part superficial lacerations, abrasions and contusions to his left shoulder, right elbow, left hand, both knees and, left leg.
ODriverInj: The rider was transported to his home by the driver of OV1 and did not go to the hospital. The driver of OV1 was not injured.
Human: The 39 year old male rider made an incorrect decision to drive on the wrong side of the street in an attempt to pass OV1.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. OV1 sustained minor damage to the left side and, appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Sedan
MV1: 1992 Honda Night Hawk, CB750, 747 cc, conventional street motorcycle
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in May 2013 at 0655 hours in Southern California. It was daylight, the weather was clear, the temperature was approximately 61 degrees F and the winds were WSW at approximately 3.5 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, with moderate traffic.

The crash occurred at a T intersection in a residential/apartments area. The north/south roadway has three through lanes and a bicycle lane in both
direction, the lanes are divided by a raised concrete center median. On the southbound side there is a left turn lane for eastbound traffic and just south of the intersection there is a left turn merge lane. The speed limit is 50 mph. The east/west roadway has two westbound lanes that are dedicated turning lanes for north/south traffic one eastbound travel lane. The east/west lanes are divided by a raised concrete median with foliage. There is a stop sign for the westbound roadway and the speed limit is 10 mph. The roadways are bordered by raised curbing and sidewalks.
MC1 is a 1992 Honda Night Hawk CB750 (747 cc) conventional street motorcycle ridden by a 33 year old male (5 ft. 6 in. and 165 lbs.). The rider was wearing a Scorpian (DOT/Snell) full face helmet with clear face shield. OV1 is a 2008 Lexus IS 250 driven by a 38 year old female (5 ft. 3 in. and 145 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling northbound at approximately 41 mph in the # 3 lane. The rider of MC1 saw OV1 start to make a left turn at the intersection applied his
brakes and skidded 82 ft. 9 in. where he was struck in the right side by OV1. OV1 was traveling westbound, making a left turn at approximately 14 mph and had traveled approximately 35 ft. 3 in., before striking the right side of MC1 head-on. MC1 was pushed onto its left side by OV1 approximately 30 ft. to their final rest positions (FRP). The area of impact (AOI) was 37 ft. 7 in. south and 16 ft. 9 in. west of the fire hydrant reference point. MC1 and OV1 remained engaged to final rest.
RiderInj:
The 33 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries, as related in the medical records: a pubic symphysis
 
diastasis with SI injury, right acetabular fracture, left L4 transverse process fracture, left medial tibial plateau fracture, left ACL & MCL tear, complete right meniscus tear, right mesenteric contusion, left elbow abrasion, right knee contusion, right lower leg laceration and a left knee laceration. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was (14).
ODriverInj: The 38 year-old female driver of OV1 was not injured.
Human: The 38 year-old female driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1. The 33 year-old male rider of MC1 made an assumption that OV1 driver saw him and would yield the right of way.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: The absence of traffic signals at this intersection is a crash causal factor.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1), rear end crash. The motorcycle rider sustained major injuries as a result of impacting the rear portion of OV1. OV1 was an emergency vehicle (ambulance) and was not responding to a call for service. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash
OV1: 2009 Freightliner M-Line walk-in van (ambulance) red and white (GVWR 21,880)
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle rear impact crash event resulting in major injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Saturday, May 2013 at 2209 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed overcast skies, a south wind direction @ 5.8 mph, and an ambient temperature of
+59.9 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a 0.5 % uphill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred in the westbound lanes of a straight undivided four lane minor arterial roadway with an overall travel-way width of 63 feet. The east and westbound lanes are separated by a painted set of solid double yellow lines. There are designated bike lanes on both sides of the roadway.
There is a signal controlled intersection east of the crash site that both OV1 and MC1 had passed through just prior to the crash event.

MC1 was a 2001 Harley Davidson FXSTD Soft tail (cruiser) motorcycle being operated by a 38 year old male. The rider was wearing a non-DOT approved novelty helmet during his operation of the motorcycle and at the time of the crash event. Photographs of the helmet were taken at the scene.
The rider was traveling westbound in the #1 lane at a high rate of speed prior to the crash event. As the rider continued westbound through a signal controlled intersection, OV1 was directly ahead also traveling westbound in the # 1 lane.
OV1 was a 2009 Freightliner M-line (walk in style) van. OV1 was being operated by a 26 year old male. OV1 was equipped as a functioning ambulance for the local fire department. OV1 and the two crew members were not responding to a call for service at the time of the crash. Prior to the crash event the driver of OV1 had slowed down while passing through the intersection and through a slight depression in the roadway surface. At the moment of the crash event, the driver felt an impact to the rear portion of the vehicle, continued forward and observed MC1 and the rider (on the roadway) to the rear. The driver called in the crash and immediately returned to the crash site to render aid to the rider.

The rider of MC1 had failed to slow down or stay far enough behind the emergency vehicle (300 feet required by law) and struck the rear of OV1. The resulting impact caused the rider to impact with his motorcycle, the rear portion of the ambulance and the roadway surface.
 
MC1 had become entangled with the rear step board of the ambulance and appeared to have rotated clockwise until it became detached and remained in an upright position (facing eastbound) upon conclusion of the crash sequence.
RiderInj: The 38 year old male rider of MC1 sustained a major penetrating type injury to the front of his head and unspecified spinal injuries as a result of the collision. The rider was transported to a local area hospital for treatment. A pre-screening of the rider?s blood alcohol level showed his BAC at that time as .28.
ODriverInj: Neither the driver or crew members of OV1 sustained any injuries as a result of the crash.
Human: The 38 year old rider of MC1 was driving at a high rate of speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway and while under the influence of an intoxicant.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained major front end damage as a result of the crash however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 sustained minor damage to the rear step board and cargo doors and was otherwise in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) frontal impact to left side impact to OV1 followed by a right side plane capsize event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC frontal impact followed by a right side plane lay-down event after impacting the left side of OV1. The roadway is a collector roadway in a single family residential area. Both MC1 and OV1 were going in the same direction. On the rider?s right is an up-slope that has trees and ground cover. On the left are road level homes with trees and block walls. The roadway has one 20? lane of travel in each direction divided by a painted double yellow line and is a collector road. The crash occurred at a ?T? type intersection that has no signal controls. There is a stop sign for the intersecting side street which is on the rider?s left.
Parking is allowed on either side of the street; however, there were no parked cars. The roadway has a north/south dedication but is in a slight northwest orientation at the crash site. The roadway has a left curve for the rider?s direction with a radius of 1001?. The length of curve is 485?. The roadway has a 7.3% upgrade and a 1.1% crown. There are concrete curbs and 5? sidewalks on both sides of the roadway. The posted speed limit is 30 mph. The intersecting side street runs in an east/west orientation and is a local road with painted double yellow lines on the approach to the limit line for the posted stop sign. The posted speed limit is 25 mph.  There were no permanent or temporary visual obstructions. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. There were no pre or post-impact tire marks located. The crash occurred in Southern California in April of 2013 at 1040 hrs. The weather was clear with a temperature of 73 degrees F. There was a light wind from the east giving the rider a mostly right crosswind. OV1 was attempting to make a left U-turn across the intersection from the right edge of the roadway across the path of MC1 when the crash occurred. Traffic conditions were light. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. The bicyclist was also fully ejected and sustained injuries.

MC1 was 2009 Kawasaki EX250 Ninja sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 20 year old male (5? 05?/140 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face style helmet with integral chin bar and a clear face shield. It has FMVSS 218 (US DOT) safety ratings. The helmet sustained minor abrasions, mostly to the
right side area. MC1 was northbound in the # 1 lane at about the speed limit of 30 mph. and approaching the ?T? intersection. OV1 was being ridden by a 30 year old female (5?/04?/120 lbs.) and was ahead of MC1 riding along the right edge of the roadway. The exact model/style of OV1 is unknown. There are about 8 listed in Trek?s web page with the same name. They are high end sport/competitive style bicycles. As MC1 was nearing the intersection, he saw a vehicle approaching the stop sign on the side street. He said he focused his attention briefly on that car to make sure it stopped for the stop sign, which it did. The rider did not
 
remember slowing down at all. The rider stated that when he looked forward again, the bicycle was directly in front of him making a left turn across the intersection. He said that he had no time to react and hit the bicyclist broadside. Both the rider and the cyclist were fully ejected. The cyclist flew across the front of MC1 and fell to the left side in the roadway. The rider of MC1 was ejected to the right side of his MC when it went down a few feet past the point of impact. The rider slid/skidded to his final resting place (FRP). MC1 went down on its right side plane and slid front end forward to its FRP. The rider stated that he remembered ending up on his back near the curb and about 10? uphill from his MC. He stated that the bicycle was somewhere in the middle of the road.
Neither MC1 nor OV1 was towed. The operator of OV1 did not agree to an interview.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions and contusions to his upper and lower extremities. He was wearing an armored leather jacket and gloves for the upper body and regular denim jeans for the lower body. The protective upper body apparel minimized the rider?s injuries; however, after seeing the apparel, those injuries should have been prevented. The rider refused medical treatment and did not seek any at a later date. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
