ODriverInj: The 30 year old female bicyclist sustained what appear to be minor injuries according to the police accident report. It listed abrasions and contusions to the left side of the head and left leg. The bicyclist was wearing a bicycle helmet of an unknown style. She was taken to a local hospital. The rider of OV1 showed no signs of impairment.
Human: The rider of OV1 had a perception error in not seeing MC1 approaching prior making the left U-turn in front of MC1. There were no human errors on the part of the rider.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate damage to the front end (headlight/faring/faring frame) as a result of impacting OV1 and right side damage from sliding on the roadway. The damage consisted of a broken headlight lens, broken turn signal on the right side, bent faring frame and handlebars. There were numerous scratches and scrapes along the faring, windshield, and exhaust pipe. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good.

OV1 was not inspected. The extent of damage to the bicycle is unknown. OV1 was listed in the police report as being ?taken away? after the crash. The pre- crash condition of OV1 is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors attributed to this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) left frontal impact with a fixed object followed by a right side plane capsize event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a single MC left frontal impact with a curb high concrete raised roadway median that is landscaped with trees and bushes. After impacting the median, MC1 then went onto its right side plane scraping against the curbed median and the roadway. MC1 slid, tumbled, and rotated for over 200? before coming to its final rest. The roadway is a principal arterial, non-freeway that bisects a single family residential area. It has two lanes of travel in each direction, bike lanes, and a dedicated left turn lane for the opposite direction of travel, separated by curb high raised and landscaped center divider. The crash occurred mid- block, north of a ?T? type intersection that has no signal controls. The intersecting side street has a stop sign. The intersection had no part in crash causation. The rider had just navigated a left curve prior to the intersection and was approaching a right curve when he ran off the road to the left. At this point the roadway is straight. There is no parking allowed on either side of the street. The roadway has a north/south dedication; however, at the crash site, the roadway runs in a northwest/southeast orientation. The roadway is straight and level at the crash site with a -1.1% grade and a 5.9% crown in the northbound direction. The roadway is a total of 93? wide, has concrete curbs, and 5? sidewalks adjacent to the curb. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The roadway is of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway was wet from sprinkler run-off. There were no permanent or temporary visual obstructions that could be contributory to this crash. Traffic conditions were light. The roadway was lit by overhead spot illumination street lights that are located both in the center median and the right side of the road. The crash occurred in May 2013 at 0320 hrs. The weather was clear with a temperature of 61 degrees F. There was a light wind from the south. The rider was fully ejected and sustained moderate injuries. There were no pre-impact tire marks from  MC1
MC1 was 2004 Honda CBR 600RR sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 29 year old male, (6?00?/165 lbs.). The rider was wearing a full face helmet with integral chin bar and an unknown color face shield and an unknown style of glasses. The helmet is rated to meet FVMSS 218 (US DOT) safety
ratings and weighed 43.85 ounces. It sustained minor to moderate damage. MC1 was northbound in the # 2 (right curb) lane traveling at about 55 mph, (based on slide to stop calculations), exceeding the speed limit of 45 mph. He was passing a vehicle that was in the #1 lane. The roadway surface was wet from sprinkler run-off. The wet roadway surface is noted in the police accident report (PAR), but it does not specify how much of the roadway surface was wet, or if water was flowing heavily from the sprinkler system. Both the rider and the witness who was in the vehicle being passed said that the rider went into a wobble and lost control. MC1 veered to the left in front of the vehicle and hit the center median, breaking the front rim and deflating the tire. The front tire was found to be bald (no tread) during the
 
inspection. This could be contributory to the loss of control on the wet roadway surface. After hitting the median, the rider and MC1 continued in a northerly direction following the west side of the median. MC1 was on its right side plane, front end forward. The top portion of MC1 was dragging in the landscaped median, damaging bushes and parts of the irrigation system. It appeared by the width of the damage, the rider may have been still attached in some way to MC1. When MC1 broke free of the median, it slid/tumbled in an unknown orientation across the southbound lanes until it impacted the west side curb and came to its FRP. The driver of the vehicle that MC1 passed made a U-turn at the first available location and stated that when he was approaching MC1, the rider was coming out from the bushes beyond the west sidewalk. The rider?s FRP is unknown. The rider never responded for an interview. The rider made no obvious collision avoidance maneuvers and stated to the police that he hit some water, went into a wobble and lost control. At some unknown point, the rider was fully ejected and sustained moderate
injuries. According to the PAR, MC1 was facing in a southerly direction on its left side. The PAR also states that MC1 sustained major damage to the left side. When MC1 was inspected after the crash, there was very little damage noted on the left side. All the damage was located on the right side and top. Based on the conflicting information between the PAR and the inspection, it is believed that MC1 was actually on its right side plane at the FRP. The rider was subsequently arrested for DUI after the crash. His BAC is unknown.
RiderInj: The 29 year old male operator of MC1 sustained a left upper arm fracture listed as a ?shoulder fracture? in the PAR, a laceration to his left thumb, and numerous abrasions with no locations given. The rider was displaying obvious signs of intoxication, including red and watery eyes, and the odor of an alcoholic beverage from his person. A DUI investigation was conducted and the rider was arrested. He was taken to a local hospital, treated and released to the custody of the police.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a perception error in not seeing the wet roadway surface. This may have been in part due to his intoxication.
Vehicle: Prior to the crash, MC1 appeared to be in fair condition. The front tire had no measurable tread. This may have been a contributing factor in the loss of control on the wet roadway. MC1 sustained major damage to the front rim, right side, and top as a result of impacting the median and sliding approximately 200? before impacting the west curb. There were some minor scrapes on the lower left side which probable came from when MC1 mounted the center median at the First Harmful Event. The front forks were fractured and evidence of a minor contact with the forward engine area. The front wheel axle appears to be broken as well. The static wheelbase measurement showed a 1? reduction.
Environmental: The wet roadway surface from the median irrigation system is an environmental factor attributed to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing serious injuries.
MV1: 1981 Honda CM400E conventional street bike (395cc), black in color
OV1: 2000 Chevrolet Silverado utility pick-up truck, gold in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury traffic collision. The collision occurred on Thursday May 2013 at 1734 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1954 hours. The weather report indicated clear skies, with WSW winds at 9.2 mph. and an ambient temperature of 73.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface for MC1 was level with a 2.1% crown. The roadway surface was dry, found to be of an asphalt composition worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 62 feet. The roadway is straight and runs east to west with two lanes dedicated for eastbound and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic. There are designated left turn lanes to regulate both east and westbound traffic onto the intersecting commercial/residential street at this intersection.
This intersecting local street has an overall travel-way of 64 feet and south of the intersection. The intersection is controlled in all four directions by posted traffic signals.
The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted double yellow line lane markers. The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 35 mph.

MC1 was a 1981 Honda CM400E (395cc) conventional street motorcycle being operated by a 21 year old male. The rider was travelling eastbound, stopped in the left turn lane, waiting to proceed northbound. The light for his direction of travel was green and there is no exclusive left turn arrow.
OV1 was a 2000 Chevrolet Silverado (Utility pick-up truck) being operated by a 66 year old male. OV1was approaching the intersection westbound in the #1 through lane at a speed of about 30 mph. As OV1 continued westbound the rider of MC1 moved from the left turn lane into the intersection and began to cross the #1 lane directly into the path of OV1.
The rider of MC1 continued his left turn movement and OV1 collided with the right front portion of the motorcycle head on. MC1 was pushed back about 17 feet and collapsed onto the roadway surface left side down ejecting the rider within six feet of the final resting place. The rider was unable to initiate any type of collision avoidance maneuver.
 
Prior to law enforcements arrival OV1 had been moved from its initial final resting place to an area west of the intersection alongside the north curb.
RiderInj: The 21year old male rider sustained severe right lower leg injury as a result of the collision. The rider was immediately removed from the scene to a local hospital for treatment by a ?Life Flight? helicopter transport. There is no further information available on the extent of injuries.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries.
Human:
The rider of MC1 could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of OV1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver.
The driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision to continue into the intersection failing to perceive the presence of the approaching motorcycle making a left turn.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front end damage as a result of impacting with the center front portion of OV1.
OV1 sustained moderate front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Mini Van.
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred on a Saturday afternoon in May 2013 at 1450 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the weather was clear, the temperature was approximately 69 degrees F. and the winds were SSW at approximately 4.6 mph. The asphalt roadway
surface was dry, noted to be travel worn and there was heavy traffic. The Reference point (RP) is a fiber optic cable pole that is 33 ft. 7 in. south and 110 ft. 6 in. west of the point of impact (POI).

The crash occurred on a straight, southeast/northwest state highway. The asphalt roadway has a 5 ft. 8 in. asphalt shoulder on the south side with a K-rail wall separating a pedestrian/bicycle path and a railroad right of way. The north side has a 7 ft. asphalt shoulder with a K-rail wall separating a 60? uphill wilderness slope. White painted fog lines separate the shoulders from the travel lanes. There is a single 10 ft. wide travel lane in each direction divided by a 4 ft. wide, double yellow line painted center median. There are no traffic controls and the posted speed limit is 50 mph. On the north side of the roadway, at the crash site, there is a paved drainage opening in the K-rail wall that is 92 ft. wide and 25 ft. deep.

MC1 is a 2008 Yamaha YZF R6 (599cc), Sport/Race replica motorcycle, ridden by a 21 year old male of unknown height and weight. The rider was wearing an unknown style/make of helmet, as stated in the police report. OV1 is a 2006 Kia Sedona, driven by a 57 year old female (5 ft. 5 in. and 160 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling southeast at approximately 21 mph in the center median, passing vehicles. OV1 was traveling southeast ahead of MC1, made a U-turn across the center median and stopped blocking the center median and both travel lanes. MC1 had insufficient time to avoid OV1 and struck OV1 in the left driver?s door at the A pillar. The back of MC1 then pivoted, striking the front fender of OV1, then slid on its left side approximately 12 ft. north and 2 ft. east of the POI to its final rest position (FRP) straddling the white painted fog line facing south. The rider of MC1 vaulted over the front of OV1 approximately 20 ft., then slid/tumbled approximately 15 ft. to his FRP, which is approximately 12 ft. north and 27 ft. 7 in. east of the POI.
RiderInj: The 21 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries, as related on the police report: Lung contusion, not further specified (NFS), liver laceration NFS, scrape on right calf/ankle NFS, front and back road rash NFS and concussive behavior noted. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 14.
ODriverInj: The 57 year-old female driver of OV1 was not injured.
Human: The 57 year-old female driver of OV1 turned across the painted center median and blocked the path of OV1. The 21 year-old male rider of MC1 used improper lane positioning to pass eastbound traffic.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) rear impact by OV1 followed by a right side plane capsize event. MC had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC rear impact followed by a right side plane lay-down event. The roadway is a non-freeway major arterial. Both MC1 and OV1 were going in the same direction. The rider had just exited a small commercial complex and was approaching an area that has a golf course on either side of the roadway. As OV1 approached the crash site, the vehicle had gone over a freeway bridge crossing and was passing the commercial complex that MC1 was exiting. The roadway has an east/west designation, however; at the crash site it runs in a northeast orientation. The roadway has three through lanes in each direction and is
divided by a curb high raised divider that is landscaped with trees and shrubbery. At the crash scene, there is a break in the divider with a left turn pocket for the opposite side of the roadway to enter the commercial complex. There are no signal controls. At the time of the crash, it was dark. The area is illuminated with overhead street lights approximately 100? apart and other ambient lighting. No on-street parking is allowed. The roadway has an east/west dedication but is in a northeast orientation at the crash site. The roadway has a left curve for both operators direction with a radius of 1250.5?. The length of curve is 790?. The roadway has a 3.8% downgrade and a 0.8% crown. There are concrete curbs and a 6? sidewalk on the right side of the roadway. There is no sidewalk on the opposite side. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The intersecting driveway has a 4.6% upgrade for the rider and a 0.0% crown. There is a posted stop sign and a ?Right Turn Only? sign for traffic exiting the commercial complex. There is no posted speed limit on the private property complex. There are no permanent visual obstructions from the area of the stop sign. Since the driver of OV1 stated that she could see MC1 approach the street as well as enter the street, it appears that there were no temporary visual obstructions either. Traffic conditions were light. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. The driver of OV1 was not injured. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. There were no pre or post-impact tire marks located when the crash site was inspected 48 hrs. after the crash occurred. The police accident report (PAR) however lists skid marks from OV1. There were discrepancies in the PAR regarding the skid marks also. The PAR indicates that the skid marks extend over 60? beyond OV1?s FRP. Attempts to resolve the discrepancies with the reporting police agency were unsuccessful. OV1 is listed as having ABS brakes according to Edmunds web site.
It is unknown if the braking system was in proper working order. The crash occurred in Southern California in May of 2013 at 2148 hrs. The weather was clear with a temperature of 60 degrees F. There was a light wind from the SSE. Neither party participated for an interview. OV1 was not inspected.
 
MC1 was 2008 Yamaha FZ6-S2 (600cc) sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by an 18 year old male, (5? 02?/140 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings. The helmet was in an unknown condition prior to or after the crash.

MC1 was exiting a private driveway from a commercial complex and making a right turn onto the roadway. It is unknown if the rider stopped at the stop sign prior to entering the roadway. As the rider was entering the roadway, he quickly went across all three lanes of travel out to the #1 lane. OV1 was being operated by a 30 year old female (5?08?/130 lbs.) eastbound in the #1 lane at an unknown speed, but presumed to be at or below the posted speed limit based on physical evidence consisting of skid marks and the minor damage to the vehicle. The driver of OV1 said she saw MC1 entering the roadway from the driveway at which time it ?quickly shot across the lanes of traffic? into her lane. She made no mention of the rider using a turn signal. She stated that she
?slammed? on her brakes in an effort to avoid hitting MC1 who was now directly in front of her. The rider stated he saw no cars approaching, so he entered the roadway into the curb lane and then signaled to make lane changes to the left. He stated that once he entered the left lane, he was hit from behind and ejected from his motorcycle. MC1 showed evidence of landing on its right side plane and sliding high side forward with some rotation as well as being on the left side plane sliding front end first. It is unknown if the left side damage was pre-existing or as a result of this crash. The rider slid/skidded to his FRP. MC1 was towed. OV1 was driven away.
RiderInj: The 18 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries according to the PAR consisting of a fractured left wrist, and abrasions to his lower back and both knees. It is unknown what if any protective safety apparel the rider was wearing that either might have prevented some of the injuries, or reduced the ones he sustained. The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle. The rider did not grant an interview.
ODriverInj: The 30 year old female driver of OV1 was not injured. The driver of OV1 showed no signs of impairment. The driver of OV1 did not grant an interview.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a perception error in not seeing OV1 approaching prior to entering the roadway and a decision error to go wide with his right turn onto the roadway. According to the PAR, the rider had only a permit to ride a MC, not a license. He was in violation of the restrictions on the permit by riding at night. Because the rider only had a permit, his riding experience level may have a contributory part in the crash. There were no human errors on the part of the driver of OV1.
Vehicle:
MC1 had damage to all sides. It is unknown if some of the damage may have been pre-existing, especially on the left side. MC1 sustained moderate to major damage based on the inspection. The rear tire was flat as a result of the impact from OV1. The rear wheel was damaged beyond repair
which caused the tire to go flat (photo MC031). The rear of MC1 was off center (photo MC042). The front end, (headlight/faring/faring frame) was broken off as a result of impacting the ground. MC1 had right side damage from sliding on the roadway. The front tire had no measurable tread depth and steel belting was visible (legally bald; photo MC03). The rear tire had only 1/32nd of an inch of measurable tread depth and the wear bars were showing (also legally bald; photo MC043). There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as fair to poor.
 
OV1 was not inspected. The extent of damage is unknown. OV1 was listed in the police report as being ?driven away? after the crash. The pre-crash condition of OV1 is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors attributed to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1), rear end crash event with a secondary lay down impact of the motorcycle and roadway surface. The motorcycle rider sustained serious injuries as a result of impacting the roadway and adjacent concrete sidewalk. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2006 Kawasaki ZX6R Ninja (sport race replica) 599cc, black in color
OV1: 2001 Chevrolet Blazer (sport utility vehicle) gray in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle rear impact crash event resulting in serious injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Thursday, May 2013 at 1906 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed partly cloudy skies, a SSW wind direction @ 10.4 mph, and an ambient temperature of
+66.9 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a 2.6 % downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred in the northbound #3 lane of a left curve divided six lane non-freeway arterial roadway with an overall travel-way width of 102 feet. The north and southbound lanes are divided by a 14 foot wide painted set of solid double yellow lines. There are designated 8 foot wide bike lanes on both sides of the roadway. The southbound portion of this roadway was uninvolved in the crash event. The posted speed limit is 45 mph for both north and southbound traffic.
There is a signal controlled intersection south of the crash site that both OV1 and MC1 had passed through just prior to the crash event and it is uninvolved as well.
MC1 was a 2006 Kawasaki ZX6R (sport race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 23 year old male. The rider was traveling northbound in the #3 lane at a high rate of speed (60 mph) prior to the crash event. As the rider continued northbound OV1 was directly ahead also traveling northbound in the #3 lane. The rider was looking to change into the #2 lane and looked to see if it was clear. When he looked back forward, he saw OV1?s brake lights come on. The rider admitted he was only about two car lengths off the rear bumper of OV1 and had no time to conduct a collision avoidance maneuver so he simply applied both front and rear brakes.
OV1 was a 2001 Chevrolet Blazer (sport utility vehicle) being operated by a 53 year old female. OV1 was northbound in the #3 lane at an approximate speed of 55 mph. At the moment of the crash event, the driver felt an impact to the rear portion of her vehicle and thought she had blown a tire however continued forward and observed MC1 and the rider (on the roadway).
 
MC1 had impacted the rear bumper of OV1 causing the motorcycle to collapse right side down onto the roadway surface ejecting the rider. The rider impacted the roadway surface tumbled and slid about 62 feet before coming to rest in the middle of lane #3. MC1 continued down the roadway another 150 feet along the curb line until coming to rest.
RiderInj: The 23 year old male rider of MC1 sustained abrasive burn type injuries (2d & 3d degree) to his back, arms, and legs as a result of sliding along the roadway. He also dislocated a bone in his right ankle. The rider was transported to a local area hospital for treatment. There was no evidence of alcohol or drugs present in his system.
ODriverInj: The 53 year old driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of this crash event.
Human: The 38 year old rider of MC1 was driving at a high rate of speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway. The 53 year old driver of OV1 did not contribute anything to the cause or outcome of the crash event.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained major front end and right side damage as a result of the crash however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 sustained minor damage to the rear bumper otherwise was in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
MV1: 2007 Harley Davidson XL1200C Sportster (1199 cc) Custom Cruiser
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred on a Saturday morning in June 2013, at 0955 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the weather was mostly cloudy; the temperature was approximately 70 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn and there was moderate traffic. The Reference Point is a fire hydrant; that is 57 ft. 4 in. northeast and 2 ft. 6 in. west of the point of impact.
The crash occurred on a straight, east/west, two-way roadway with a continuous left-turn lane and a ?T? intersection on the south side of the roadway. There is a westbound uphill grade of 5.5% and a crown of 3.3%. East/west there are two through lanes in each direction an eastbound right turn lane and a continuous center turn lane with double yellow painted lane lines to both sides. The north/south roadway is a single lane each way with a stop sign for the northbound lane, divided by a concrete planter that is 3 ft. 4 in. wide by 17 ft. 4 in. long set-back 2 ft. from the crosswalk. The north/south roadway played no role in this accident.
MC1 is a 2007 Harley Davidson XL1200C Sportster (1199 cc) custom cruiser motorcycle, ridden by a 43 year old male (5 ft. 7 in. and 165 lbs.). The rider was wearing a black HJC full face helmet with a clear face shield. OV1 is a 2012 Audi A3 driven by a 17 year old male (5 ft. 8 in. and 165 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

OV1 was traveling west stopped in the left turn lane at the ?T? intersection waiting for a break in the oncoming traffic in order to make a left turn. MC1 was traveling west in the number 1 lane approaching the ?T? intersection planning to make a left turn at the intersection. MC1 moved into the left turn lane, then the rider realized that OV1 was stopped in front of him and attempted to pass OV1on the right. MC1 sideswiped OV1 along OV1?s right side, caught the rider?s left foot peg and shifter on the right front tire/wheel before high-siding on its right side, coming to rest approximately 7 ft. west and 3 ft. north in front of OV1.
RiderInj: The 41 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries taken from the police report; Injury to his mouth NFS, left foot abrasion, cuts and scratches on his arms and legs. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1.
ODriverInj: The 17 year-old male driver of OV1 was not injured.
Human: The 41 year-old male rider of MC1 failed to perceive OV1 was stopped ahead when he entered the left turn lane and failed to properly execute his evasive swerve to pass OV1 on the right.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) losing control in collision avoidance with secondary non-horizontal impact to the right front of OV1. MC1 had a passenger who sustained fatal injuries.
Crash:
MC1 lost control while braking heavily with both brakes in collision avoidance with OV1 who was making a left turn at a four way off-set intersection with signal controls. All legs of the intersection are straight and level. The east leg of the intersection is off-set to the south. The north/south roadway is a 6 lane principal arterial, non-freeway. It has intermittent raised center dividers that are landscaped with trees and bushes. The raised dividers terminate approximately 150? in either direction from the intersection. MC1 was headed in a southbound direction. There is an uncontrolled left turn lane in the area where the raised divider ends. The area between the left turn lane and the intersection is a painted divider. In the northbound direction there is a dedicated left turn lane with protected/permissive signal that works on demand. The roadway is divided by double yellow painted lines. The intersecting cross streets have no dedicated turn lanes. All the roadways have concrete curbs. On the rider?s right, there is a sidewalk and a block wall. There are a few trees and streetlights. This side of the roadway is a single family residential area. On the left side of the roadway there is a sidewalk and numerous trees adjacent to an urban wilderness park. No parking is allowed on either side of the street. The roadway has a north/south dedication and is in that orientation at the crash site. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. There are no permanent visual obstructions. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, and has several surface cracks, but in otherwise good condition. There were two pre-impact tire marks located from MC1. The crash occurred in Southern
California in June of 2013 at 2038 hrs. The weather was partly cloudy with a temperature of 64 degrees F. There was a moderate wind from the south. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. Both the rider and passenger were fully ejected. The rider sustained moderate injuries. The passenger?s injuries were
fatal.

MC1 was a cruiser type motorcycle that was being operated by a 24 year old male (6?00?/195 lbs.). The rider said that he had just picked up his girlfriend and was southbound in the #2 lane (middle) when he saw OV1 in the northbound left turn lane, so he merged over to the #1 (inside) lane. He stated that he backed off the throttle. When he was about 40? from the intersection, the rider stated that OV1 stopped, blocking his path. He said that he braked, downshifted, and
 
tried to veer left. He thought about intentionally laying MC1 down, but lost control and went down on the left side plane of MC1 in the street before impacting OV1. Both he and his passenger were fully ejected. The rider was wearing a newer Bell full face style helmet with a clear face shield, an internal drop down sunglass shield, and integral chin bar. The helmet has unknown safety ratings. All the labels had been removed. The passenger was wearing an open face helmet with a visor and no face shield. It had labels indicating that it met FMVSS 218 (US DOT) safety ratings.

The intersection has multi-phase signals. The northbound left turn lane has protected/permissive phasing. At the time of the crash, the signal was on permissive phasing. The driver of OV1 said he never saw MC1 when he was making his left turn. The driver of OV1 was displaying obvious signs of alcohol intoxication and was later arrested. The rider of MC1 stated that there was a pack of vehicles ahead of him that passed OV1 at about the time OV1 was entering the left turn lane. MC1 then slid front end forward into the front right of OV1. It is unknown at what point in the crash sequence that they were ejected. Both the rider?s and passenger?s FRPs are listed in the police accident report as being between 20?-25? from the second harmful event. The rider stated that he was actually much further away and had made his way back to where his girlfriend was. After impacting OV1, MC1 came to rest on its left side plane facing east. OV1 rolled approximately 8? before coming to rest in a northwesterly orientation. Both vehicles were towed. Both the rider and passenger were taken to a hospital. The rider was admitted for three days. The passenger was pronounced deceased.
RiderInj:
The 24 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of bilateral ankle fractures, a fractured right heel, three fractures to his right tibia, and several abrasions. The rider was not wearing any protective gear. The rider of MC1 submitted to a blood test which had negative results for alcohol. There was a positive reading for cannabis (THC), however, due to the fact that this substance can be detected up to 30 days after use, no action was taken. At the time of the crash, the rider showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.

The 25 year old female passenger (5?05?/161 lbs.) sustained fatal injuries consisting of a fracture of the atlanto-occipital joint with a partial transection of the spinal cord, subdural and subarachnoid hemorrhages of the brain, intraventricular hemorrhage of the brain, bi-lateral contusional hemothorax to the lungs, liver tear, a massive fracture of the pelvis and both tibias.
ODriverInj: The 69 year old male (5?07?/160 lbs.) driver of OV1 was not injured. He had a BAC of .13% and was arrested for DUI.
Human: The driver of OV1 was under the influence of alcohol while driving and had a perception failure while turning left in front of MC1. The rider of MC1 did not have time to adequately react and panic braked, locking both wheels and losing control.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage mostly to the front end. There was a maximum reduction in wheelbase in which the front tire was pushed backwards into the frame/engine area. The static measurement of approximately 54? revealed a reduction in wheelbase of 5.8?. The forks twisted and were jammed into a left turn position. The aftermarket handlebars were so distorted, that a sweep measurement was impossible. MC1 was equipped with an aftermarket ?sissy? bar that had no padding. It was of the bolt on variety that has open bolt eyelets. The sissy bar came off during the crash. MC1 was also
 equipped with a suction cup pillion pad for the passenger. This type of seat is illegal in California. This seat had no contribution to crash causation or passenger injury. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be labeled as good.

OV1 sustained moderate damage to the right front and side. Part of the steering/suspension was broken and the tire was flat. There was additional minor damage on the right side. There was damage to the left rear corner that was pre-existing. The pre-crash condition of OV1 would be considered very good.
Environmental: There are no environmental factors considered to be a factor in crash causation.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) right front to left side injury crash with a secondary impact (MC1) with the roadway surface. The crash caused the motorcycle rider to be ejected onto the roadway causing serious injuries.
MV1: 2005 Kawasaki Ninja 500R sport race replica (498cc) black
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event. The collision occurred on Thursday at 1417 hours during June 2013 in Southern California. The weather report for 1358 hours showed clear skies, SSW winds at 6.9 mph, and, an ambient temperature of 77.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The motorcyclist was traveling on a two lane principal arterial road with grade of +0.2%. The roadway is of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit for north and southbound traffic is 40 mph. The collision occurred on the eastbound portion of the street with an overall travel-way width of 33 feet. The street has two lanes dedicated for eastbound traffic and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic separated by a 4.6 foot wide raised asphalt and concrete median dividing the opposing lanes. The opposing lanes are also separated by a painted two way left turn lane that is 16 feet wide. There are no designated ?Bike Lanes? on either side of the roadway.
There is a signal controlled intersection 235 feet west of the crash site. On the day of the crash there were road crews conducting surface repairs to the eastbound #2 lane. This same work was also being conducted east of the intersection and crash site. To facility traffic, the eastbound #2 lane had been cordoned off with traffic cones and signs regulating all eastbound traffic into the eastbound #1 lane.
Approximately 185 feet east of the intersection is a fast food restaurant driveway for traffic exiting the parking lot onto the roadway. There are no less than three regulatory traffic signs for vehicles exiting the 35 foot wide driveway that was occupied by OV1.
These three signs consist of a directional ?One Way?, ?Right Turn Only? and an international style ?No U-turn? sign.

MC1 was a 2005 Kawasaki Ninja (sport race replica) 498cc motorcycle being operated by a 22 year old male rider. MC1 was traveling eastbound in the #1lane approaching the driveway intersection. The rider was traveling at a speed of approximately 35-40 mph.
OV1 was a 2006 Audi S4 (station wagon) that was being operated by a 54 year old male. The driver was exiting the driveway traveling northbound crossing the eastbound #2 lane into the #1 lane. The driver was intending to circumvent the raised traffic barrier and make a U-turn type movement so he could proceed westbound.
The driver of OV1 initiated a right turn out of the driveway into the #2 lane, then proceeded to turn left crossing the #1 lane into the two-way left turn just eastof the median barrier. The rider of MC1 was approaching at a speed of about 35-40 mph when he noticed OV1 making the turn.
The rider attempted to avoid colliding with OV1 by applying both front and rear brakes however had insufficient time to avoid contact with OV1 due to the proximity of both vehicles. MC1 struck OV1 on the left side near the rear driver side door. This caused the rider to be ejected and the bike to collapse left side down.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male operator of MC1 sustained a unspecified broken wrist injury to his right hand and numerous abrasions to his body. The rider was treated at the scene and later transported to a local hospital for treatment. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision.
Human:
The 54 year old male driver of OV1 had failed to obey the numerous regulatory restrictions for the movement of his vehicle and failed to yield the right of way to MC1.
The 22 year old rider of MC1 was operating his vehicle at a reasonable speed for the present traffic conditions however was unable to avoid colliding with OV1
Vehicle: MC1 sustained major right front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. OV1 sustained moderate left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event. Although there was the presence of road work (resurfacing) the areas affected were well east and west of the crash site.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred on a Thursday afternoon in May 2013 at 1655 hours in Southern California. It was daylight and the weather was clear, the temperature was approximately 73 degrees F. and the winds were W at approximately 5 mph. The asphalt roadway surface
was dry, noted to be travel worn and there was moderate traffic. The Reference point is a fire hydrant; that is 192 ft. west and 50 ft. 1 in. south of the point of impact.

The crash occurred on a straight, east/west divided roadway (no median barrier), east of a 4 way, signal controlled intersection with an eastbound downhill grade of 3.9%. West of the intersection there are three 12 ft. through lanes in each direction, with one eastbound left and one right turn lanes. East of the intersection; there are three through lanes in each direction, with a westbound right turn lane and two left turn lanes. The northbound roadway is undivided with two southbound lanes and a northbound combination left turn/ straight through lane and a right turn lane, with a 6% northbound downhill grade. The southbound roadway plays no part in this accident.
MC1 is a 2013 Honda Shadow Phantom (745 cc), cruiser motorcycle, ridden by a 22 year old male (6 ft. 1 in. and 145 lbs.). The rider was
wearing a black HJC full face helmet with a clear face shield. OV1 is a 2009 Ford Fusion driven by a 91 year old male (5 ft. 9 in. and 180 lbs.). It is unknown if the driver of OV1 was wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling east at approximately 43 mph in the number 1 lane approaching the intersection on a green signal. OV1 was traveling north in the right turn lane approaching the intersection on a red signal. OV1 made a right turn against the red signal as MC1 entered the intersection and proceeded to move
from the number 3 to the number 1 lane without pause. MC1 braked and tried to move left away from OV1, but MC1?s front tire was hit by OV1. MC1 high-sided onto its left side and slid approximately 9 ft. to its area of rest. The riders left leg was caught under MC1. The driver of OV1 didn?t stop, but later told police that he didn?t see the motorcycle and wasn?t aware that he had caused an accident. The rider of MC1 didn?t have a valid motorcycle endorsement or
operator?s permit authorizing the operation of MC1. The driver of OV1 was driving on an expired license.
RiderInj: The 22 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries related during the interview: Minor laceration to the left outer leg at the knee, contusion of the left knee, abrasions to the left shoulder blade and left arm. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1.
ODriverInj: The 91 year-old male driver of OV1 was not injured.
Human: The 91 year-old male driver of OV1 failed to yield the right of way to MC1, by making a right turn on a red signal and crossing 3 lanes of traffic into the path of MC1.
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: There are no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) lost control braking lay-down event with secondary non-horizontal impact into OV1 which was parked. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a single MC losing control while braking in collision avoidance with a parked vehicle. The crash occurred on a straight portion of a collector roadway in a single family residential area. MC1 was going westbound. OV1 was legally parked facing WB on the same side of the street. Both sides of the roadway have low rounded curbs. On the rider?s right, there is no sidewalk. On the left side of the roadway there is a 4? sidewalk. The roadway has one 20? lane of travel in each direction divided by a painted double yellow line. The crash occurred west of a ?T? type intersection that has no signal controls and is approximately
mid-point through a left curve that the rider had been negotiating. There is a stop sign for the intersecting side street which is on the rider?s right. Parking is allowed on either side of the street. The roadway has an east/west dedication and is in that orientation at the crash site. The roadway has several curves, both left and right, as it winds through the neighborhood. The rider had been negotiating a left curve that has a radius of 243? and a total length of 188?. The roadway has a 7.4% upgrade and a 4.1% crown. The posted speed limit is 35 mph. There are permanent visual obstructions consisting buildings and block walls along with the curvatures of the roadway. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. There are two large rectangular patches of bituminous repair at the crash site. They are smooth with the rest of the roadway surface and had no part in crash causation. No pre-impact tire marks were visible at the time of the scene inspection which took place 3 days after the crash; however, a rear tire mark/skid was documented in the Police Accident Report. MC1 had very low tire pressure which could have been responsible for faint tire marks that dissipated rapidly
on this heavily traveled roadway. The crash occurred in Southern California in June 2013 at 1614 hrs. The weather was partly cloudy with a temperature of 70 degrees F. There was a moderate wind from the WSW. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries.

MC1 was 2002 Honda CBR 600 F4i sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 41 year old male (5? 09?/157 lbs.). The rider told the police that he was on his way home from work and had no memory of the crash. He was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings.

MC1 was westbound in the # 1 lane at about the speed limit of 35 mph. and had just completed negotiating a left curve. For unknown reasons, the rider began
 
heavy braking with his rear brake, lost control and crashed. The tires had very low air pressure upon inspection 3 days after the crash (17 psi front/08 psi rear). There was no obvious or visible reason for the low psi. The low tire pressure would cause a lack of control, especially while negotiating a curve at 35 mph. It would cause the MC to go wide through the turn and hinder handling and braking. It appears that the rider did go wide right though the left curve and was unable to safely recover to the middle of his lane. He began to brake heavily, lost control, and high-sided on the MC?s right side plane. The rider was fully ejected and skidded/slid on the roadway causing abrasions to his hands. He then slid into a 4x3x4? decorative rock mailbox which was adjacent to the right curb, and came to rest in the flowers/bushes. It is unknown whether the impact with the roadway surface or the rock mailbox caused the riders additional injuries, or a combination of both. MC1 continued skidding/sliding on its right side plane, rotating slightly in a CCW direction until it impacted the left rear corner of OV1. MC1 then rotated 180 degrees from its original direction and came to rest middle of the roadway, near OV1. According to the PAR, MC1 left approximately 25? of rear tire lock skid marks. MC1 skidded/slid approximately 63? to its FRP, including impacting OV1 near the end of the slide. MC1 was towed and the rider taken to a hospital. OV1 was left parked at the scene.
RiderInj: The 41 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of traumatic brain injury (NFS), a fractured clavicle, and abrasions to both hands. It is unknown what if any protective gear the rider was wearing. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 made a decision failure in riding a MC that was not properly maintained. He was also riding too fast based on the condition of the MC.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate damage mostly to the right side as a result of impacting the roadway and sliding, as well as impacting OV1. The low tire pressures, combined with too much speed, are primary crash causation factors. MC1 had evidence of at least one prior crash in which it was down on the left side. The fairing was held together near the top with a plastic ?zip? tie. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as fair to good.

OV1 was not inspected. The extent of damage is listed in the PAR as minor to the left rear corner. The pre-crash condition of OV1 is unknown.
Environmental: The numerous switch-back type turns, a severe grade, and a high speed limit for the roadway are all considered contributing factors to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1), front to side impact collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained non-life threatening injuries. There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the collision.
MV1: 1997 Harley Davidson FLSTS Springer Heritage (cruiser) 1338cc, white Other Vehicle (OV1):
Crash:
This was a front to side impact crash event resulting in minor injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred at 1814 hours on Wednesday, June 2013 in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, WSW winds at 5.8 mph, and an ambient temperature of +54.0 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. Sunrise was at 0646 hours and Sunset at 2007 hours.
The collision occurred on a straight two lane local street with an overall travel-way width of 36 feet. The roadway runs north and south with one lane dedicated for each direction of travel. The opposing lanes on this street are separated by one set of painted solid double yellow lines and there are no
designated turn lanes present in the area of the crash site. The crash precipitated within the southbound lane of traffic. The east side of the street is occupied by commercial businesses and the west side is a local railroad easement for both north and southbound commercial rail service. The street is bordered on both sides by raised concrete curbs. The east side of the street does not allow for the parallel parking of vehicles and there is a 5 foot wide public sidewalk available for pedestrians. The west side of the street has a 9 foot wide set-back for parallel parking and there are no
sidewalks available. There is a +0.2% grade for southbound traffic and +3.4% crown in the area of the crash site. There are no other issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.

MC1 was a 1997 Harley Davidson FLSTS (cruiser) motorcycle being operated by a 62 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a motorcycle helmet of unknown make model or rating.
The rider was travelling southbound approaching OV1 at an unknown rate of speed. The rider had positioned his motorcycle near the center portion of the roadway with the intent of passing OV1 on the left. OV1 was travelling at a lessor speed and the rider proceeded to initiate his passing movement.
OV1 was a 2006 Saturn automobile being operated by a 48 year old female driver. The driver of OV1 was slowing down for the purpose of negotiating a U-Turn type movement from her present southbound direction to northbound.
 
The driver of OV1 decided to facilitate her U-turn movement in proximity to a 38 foot wide driveway along the west side of the street in case she needed more turning area. She also swung wide to the right side of the roadway to give herself more room.
As OV1 moved left crossing over the double yellow lines the rider of MC1 had moved out of the southbound lane to an area just inside the northbound lane adjacent to the double yellow lane lines. The driver of OV1 did not see MC1 and the rider prior to impact and the motorcycle subsequently struck the left side of
OV1 near the left rear quarter panel.
The rider of MC1 had insufficient time in order to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver. During an inspection of the crash scene there was no evidence of front or rear tire braking from MC1, only scrape marks where it had collapsed onto the roadway surface. The resulting impact caused the motorcycle to collapse left side down. The rider fell off of his motorcycle and onto the roadway surface.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 62 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were abrasions to both elbows. During the police investigation officers noticed the presence of alcohol on the rider. While at the hospital the rider was arrested for driving under the influence. A sample of his blood was taken about 1hour and 30 minutes after the accident. Results indicated a .11 BAC at the time of the blood draw.
ODriverInj: The 48 year old female driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. There were no apparent objective symptoms of alcohol intoxication.
Human:
The 62 year old male rider of MC1 was operating a vehicle on a public roadway while under the influence of an intoxicant. Furthermore he was initiating an unsafe passing movement to the left of OV1.
The 48 year old female driver of OV1 contributed to the crash event by initiating an unsafe U-turn movement in proximity to approaching traffic.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor front end and right side damage to the area of the front fender. The right front brake handle was also broken. MC1 appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained minor left side damage was in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred on a Saturday afternoon in June 2013 at 1055 hours in Southern California. It was daylight with scattered clouds, the temperature was approximately 71 degrees F. and the winds were SSW at approximately 13 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred at a 4 way signal controlled intersection on a straight, north/south road that has a 4.0% positive grade in the direction of travel. There are 2 north/south through lanes, with a northbound left turn lane; southbound has a left and right turn lanes. Westbound is a residential road without lane markings that is 24 ft. wide with brick walls at the edge of the travel surface and a 5.1% negative grade in the direction of travel. Where the roads intersect the grade increases to a negative 12.0%. The west side of the intersection wasn?t involved with this crash.
MC1 is a 2002 Harley Davidson FXDX (1449cc) motorcycle with high rise handlebars, ridden by a 23 year old male (6 ft. and 185 lbs.) without
an M1 endorsement. The rider was wearing a Bell Arrow full face helmet with a smoked colored face shield. OV1 is a 2003 Honda Accord driven by a 51 year old male (5 ft. 10 in. and 208 lbs.). The driver and passengers of OV1 were reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling northwest at approximately 43 mph in the #2 lane approaching the intersection with a green signal displayed. The rider looked over his shoulder at the motorcycle behind him, when he turned back he saw the signal had phased to red. OV1 was stopped at the westbound limit line waiting to make a left turn. When the signal phased green the driver pulled slowly forward through the gutter-dip where the roads meet into the #2 lane. The rider of MC1 braked, lost control and capsized onto the right side. This caused MC1 to slide approximately 25 ft. on its right side into the left front wheel/bumper of OV1. The rider slid into the left passenger door. MC1?s point of impact (POI) was approximately 12 ft. north of the south curb line of the westbound road and 8 ft. west of the east curb line of the northbound road. The rider impacted the left passenger door approximately 6 ft. 2 in. east of MC1?s POI. The POI locations and final rest positions were the same.
RiderInj: The 23 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related during the rider interview: minor laceration of the left forearm, left shoulder abrasion and a contusion to the right hip. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1.
ODriverInj: The 51 year-old male driver of OV1 was not injured.
Human: The 23 year-old male rider of MC1 was operating MC1 without an M1 endorsement or any formal training, failed to perceive the phasing signal due to inattention.
Vehicle: MC1 was modified with 12 in. narrow risers that made it harder to control the movements of MC1.
Environmental: The eastbound roads negative 12.0% grade combined with the 8.3% crown of the northbound road causes vehicles to transit this dip at extremely low speed.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) lost control while riding with the front tire up in the air (wheelie). MC1 lost control and fell onto its left side plane. MC1 had a passenger who fell off before MC1 crashed.
Crash:
This is a single MC losing control while operating with the front tire up in the air (wheelie). MC1 had a passenger. Both the rider and passenger were fully ejected and sustained injures. The crash occurred on a straight roadway that is a non-freeway principal arterial at intersection with another non-freeway principal arterial. The roadway bisects a public beach on the left and wetlands preserve on the right. The roadway has a north/south designation; however, at the crash site, it has a northwest/southeast orientation. MC1 was going northbound. There is no on-street parking on either side of the roadway. Curbs and sidewalks are only present at the intersection area of the roadway. Both sides of the roadway have sandy edges. The roadway has double solid yellow lines as a divider. The crash occurred 33? west of the west curb line of the four-way, non-skewed type intersection that has signal controls. The rider had been stopped for a red light just prior to the crash. Upon receiving the green light, the rider rapidly accelerated, raising the front tire off the ground. The rider rode in this manner until he lost control and crashed just north of the intersection. The roadway has a 0.4% upgrade and a 0.5% crown. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. There were no permanent or temporary visual obstructions that would be contributory to the crash. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. There were no pre or post-impact tire marks. The front tire lost all tire pressure during the crash. MC1 had very low tire pressure (14 psi) in the rear tire the next day when it was inspected which could have been contributory to the crash. The rider has a deformed right arm and hand which is withered and has limited mobility and control which is also contributory. The crash occurred in Southern California in June of 2013 at 1739 hrs. The weather was clear with a temperature of 78 degrees F. There was a moderate wind from the SW. Traffic conditions were moderate.

MC1 was 2005 Yamaha YZF-R1 sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 47 year old male (6? 00?/170 lbs.) with a 50 year old female (5?05?/170 lbs.) passenger. Neither the rider nor passenger is quoted in the police report. Witnesses told the police that the rider rapidly accelerated when the light phased to green which raised the front tire off the ground, after which, he lost control and crashed. Both the rider and passenger were wearing full- face helmets with integral chin bars and face shields. The rider?s helmet has a FMVSS 218 (US DOT) safety rating and a gray/smoke tinted face shield. It sustained minor abrasions. The passenger?s helmet has both a FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell M2005 safety rating. The face shield was reflective/mirror finish.
 It also sustained minor abrasions.
MC1 was northbound in the #2 (middle) lane stopped for a red light. When the light phased to green, he rapidly accelerated, raising the front tire off the ground and rode in this manner until he lost control and crashed just north of the intersection. The passenger fell off MC1 somewhere in the middle of the intersection. The front tire lost all air pressure. The front rim sustained a large dent/deformation which broke the bead of the tire and allowed the air to escape. The damage to the rim was caused when the front tire landed back onto the roadway surface. Although the tire pressure in the front tire is unknown, it was probably very low. A properly inflated tire would not have allowed the rim to sustain the type of damage that occurred a result of landing from a wheelie. The rear tire had very low pressure which could be contributory to the crash. The rider stated he had checked the tire pressure before riding that day. There were no visible signs of a leak in the rear tire. The rider also stated that there was another vehicle in the lane to his right that was making a lane change into him. The rider said that he was even with the front door of the other vehicle. In reaction to this, the rider stated that he veered to the left and intentionally braked hard and skidded with his rear brake and laid MC1 down on its left side to avoid a collision with that car. The rider said that because of his deformed hand, he never uses the front brake. Neither the police report nor the witness makes mention of another vehicle or skid. The rider stated that his FRP was next to MC1 which is unknown, but was north of the intersection on its left side plane facing in a northerly direction. The passenger said that she fell off MC1 somewhere in the middle if the intersection. Both sustained abrasions to their extremities. Both the rider and passenger were treated at the scene by paramedics and refused to be taken to a hospital. They both went to a walk-in clinic the next day for additional treatment. MC1 was towed.
RiderInj: The 47 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions to his right knee and left calf. The rider has a physical impairment to his right arm and hand. He has limited function to both. This would be contributory to the lack of throttle control. The passenger sustained a fracture of her tail bone, bi-lateral abrasions to her knees, an abrasion to her left elbow, and bi-lateral contusions to her inner thighs. Both were wearing tank tops and shorts. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle. The passenger showed no signs of impairment that would interfere with the rider?s safe operation of MC1.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a reaction failure in responding to the raise front tire. MC1 was also not properly maintained. .
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate damage to the front rim and left side as a result of impacting the roadway and sliding. The low tire pressure could be contributory to the crash. MC1 had evidence of what appeared to be several crashes prior to this crash. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as fair.
Environmental: There were no environmental determined to be contributory.

CrashType: Motorcycle (MC1) frontal impact to right side of OV1. MC1 subsequently caught fire and was destroyed. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a crash in which MC1 broadsided OV1 who was making a left turn at an intersection. After the crash, a fuel line leak ignited MC1 and it was completely destroyed by fire. The crash occurred at a four-way, not skewed intersection with signal controls. The roadway is a principal arterial, non-freeway. It has two through lanes in each direction, with dedicated left turn lanes. The roadway also has bike lanes and dedicated right turn lanes. The roadway is straight and level. It has a north/south dedication, but is a northwest/southeast orientation at the crash site. The roadway has curb high center dividers that are landscaped with trees and bushes. The roadway is bordered by concrete curbs. There is a sidewalk on both sides of the roadway; however, the north side sidewalk meanders back and forth away from the roadway and has grass/greenery in between. In the northbound direction, north of the intersection, there is no sidewalk. All sides of the roadway have single family residential homes. No on-street parking is allowed. The roadway is straight and level with a -0.7% downgrade and a 2.0% crown. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. There are no permanent visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway does have some surface cracking and tar snake repairs in the intersection area of the crash. No pre-impact tire marks were visible from either vehicle. MC1?s FRP was clearly visible due to the burn mark in the roadway. The crash occurred in Southern California in July 2013 at 0858 hrs. The weather was overcast with a temperature of 69 degrees F. The wind was calm. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries.

MC1 was 2005 Suzuki SV1000 sport/racing type motorcycle that was being operated by a 23 year old male (5? 07?/140 lbs.). The rider said that he was on his to work from home. He was wearing a full face Icon helmet with integral chin bar and a reflective/mirror face shield. The helmet had labeling for FMVSS 218 (DOT) and ECE 22-05 safety ratings. The helmet was retained on the rider?s head to the completion of the crash.
 
The rider of MC1 stated that he was northbound in the # 2 lane at a speed of 50-55 mph. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. He said that he was on his way to work and not in any particular hurry. The 18 year old male (5?11?/150 lbs.) driver of OV1 never responded and was not interviewed. The driver of OV1 told the police that he was making a left turn on a green arrow and that there were no pedestrians. Witnesses stated that there was a pedestrian crossing with the green light/walk signal, which is why OV1 stopped. As MC1 was approaching the intersection, he stated that he saw OV1 in the southbound left turn lane starting to make its left turn. The rider stated that he then changed lanes from the #1 lane to the #2 lane, anticipating that OV1 would stop before he reached the intersection. The rider stated that OV1 continued with the left turn, then stopped in the middle of the intersection, blocking his path. The rider said that when OV1 stopped, he had no time to react at that point. He stated however that he was able to let off the throttle, honk his horn, and swerve to the right. The driver of OV1 and witnesses put MC1 in the #2 lane, never in the #1 lane. MC1 then impacted OV1 on the right front side. The rider was fully ejected, vaulted above ride height and impacted the windshield, then fell to the roadway. The fuel tank was deformed by both the rider and the impact with OV1. It appears that the deformation allowed a gap in the fuel cap filler area. Gasoline then leaked out and ignited, burning MC1 into a mostly melted mass. The right front axle of OV1 was broken. Both vehicles were towed. There were no tire marks from either vehicle. The air pressure in either of MC1?s tires at the time of the crash or after is unknown because they were deflated during the fire. The front tire/rim was separated from MC1. The hub of the front tire was separated from the rest of the rim. What was left of the rear tire that was visible and not charred showed no evidence of braking. The rider was unconscious for an unknown short period of time. He stated that he remembers waking up and seeing MC1 on fire. Witnesses and/or bystanders took photos on their cell phones of the crash scene and forwarded them to the rider, who in turn provided them to the team. The roadway surface has a burn scar where MC1 was. The rider landed in between MC1 and OV1. MC1 appears to have an FRP near the POI. It was on its left side plane and had rotated approximately 90 degrees in a CCW rotation facing in a westerly direction. OV1 rolled forward and came to rest a short distance from the POI and was facing in an easterly direction. The intersection is controlled by overhead electronic multi-phase signals with leading protected only left turns. It was determined by the police that OV1 violated the red arrow signal. The rider of MC1 was taken and admitted to a hospital for 8 days.
RiderInj: The 23 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries consisting of a pelvic ring fracture, pneumothorax, unknown number of rib fractures on the left side, a closed distal radial/ulnar fracture of the right arm, an open comminuted fracture of the radius on the left arm, a laceration and abrasions. The rider was wearing upper protective apparel only and it had no effect on injury prevention. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would otherwise inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured and showed no signs of impairment.
Human: The driver of OV1 made a decision failure making a left turn against a red arrow. The rider had a reaction failure in not braking and/or swerving and anticipating that the OV would clear the intersection.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage as a result of impacting OV1 and the ensuing fire that resulted from the crash. There was a maximum reduction in wheelbase that is unknown. The front tire impacted the radiator and exhaust pipes before breaking. The front tire/wheel assembly was broken from the front forks/axle, and the forks were broken. A static measurement of the wheelbase was not possible. The pre-crash condition of MC1 is unknown.
 
OV1 sustained moderate damage to the right front and axle. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors found to be contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (roadway surface) with the rear portion of the motorcycle impacting the roadway, after a failed attempt at negotiating a wheel stand (wheelie). The left side of motorcycle collapsed onto the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of impacting with the roadway surface. There were no passengers on the motorcycle or other vehicles involved.
MV1: 2012 Triumph Daytona 675R sport race replica style motorcycle (675cc) white
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (roadway surface) type traffic collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the rider. The collision occurred on Wednesday, July 2013 at 1616 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed overcast skies, a SSW wind direction @ 5.8 mph, and an ambient temperature of +71.8 degrees F. Sunset was at 2007 hours.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? four way intersection controlled by multi-phase signal lights. The north/south lanes have an overall travel way width of 82 feet. The intersecting east/west lanes also have an overall travel way width of 82 feet. Both streets have two lanes serving each direction of travel and
would be considered minor arterial roadways. There are marked 8 foot wide bike lanes for both directions of travel. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The east and westbound lanes of this intersection
were uninvolved in this crash event.

On the north side of the intersection the opposing lanes are separated by a four foot wide painted median. On the south side of the intersection the opposing lanes are separated by a four foot wide raised concrete median containing lowing lying surface vegetation. Along the northeast and northwest portions of the intersection there are commercial shopping centers. On both sides of the south portion of the intersection are single family residential areas.
The posted speed limit for north and southbound traffic is 45 mph. Both the north and south sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks.

MC1 was a white 2012 Triumph Daytona 675R (sport race replica style) motorcycle being operated by a 20 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an unknown make/model motorcycle helmet at the time of the crash. There were no passengers on the motorcycle.
The rider was travelling southbound in the #2 lane of the multi-lane surface street and was initially stopped for a red phase light north of the intersection. A witness at the scene advised law enforcement officials of seeing and hearing the motorcycle take off at a high rate of speed across the intersection with the front wheel off the ground. The motorcycle then collapsed onto the roadway surface on the south side of the intersection.
As the rider started off southbound through the intersection he attempted to negotiate a front wheel stand (wheelie). As the rider attempted the ?wheelie?
 
the bike continued in an upward motion until it collapsed just outside the plain of the intersection having travelled an approximate distance of 103 feet. The rear portion of MC1 struck the roadway surface and, the rear tire caught the left foot of the rider causing injury to his ankle. The rider lost control and either leapt off the bike or was ejected himself. When questioned about the ?wheelie? maneuver, the rider would only say that he accidentally let the clutch completely out causing the front tire to come off the ground.
MC1 collapsed left side down rupturing the transmission case, causing a fluid spill. The motorcycle continued to slide another 98 feet until it came to rest in the southbound #2 lane facing east.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were a dislocated ankle and distal fracture of the left fibula. There were no apparent surface abrasions or internal injuries sustained. There were no objective symptoms of alcohol intoxication or drug use.
Human: The 20 year old male rider of MC1 made a decision to conduct a ?wheelie? style maneuver and subsequently lost control of his motorcycle, causing an injury to his left ankle and moderate damage to the left side and rear of the motorcycle.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate left side damage to the transmission case, engine guard and damage to the rear fender and exhaust pipe. MC1 appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
There were no ?other vehicles? involved.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in July 2013 at 1831 hours in Southern California. It was daylight, the temperature was approximately 78 degrees F., and the winds were approximately 5.8 mph out of the WSW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, and there was moderate traffic.

The crash occurred at a ?T? intersection, on a busy East/West residential road that curves to the left, has a 3.5% positive westbound grade, a 5.4% crown, and
a speed limit of 35 mph. There is a single lane in each direction and an open center turn lane. The base of the ?T? is an undivided North/South residential road that is controlled by a stop sign with a limit line. There is a southbound downhill 0.9% grade and a -2.2% eastbound crown.
MC1 is a 2012 Honda NC700X (670cc) Sport-touring motorcycle ridden by a 28 year old male (6 ft. 2 in. and 140 lbs.). The rider was wearing a DOT approved, IV2, 936-MBK modular helmet with a clear face shield. OV1 is a 2008 Ford Escape driven by a 33 year old female (5 ft. 7 in. and 130 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling west at approximately 35 mph approaching the intersection. OV1 was southbound stopped to make an eastbound left turn. As MC1 approached the intersection, the rider saw OV1 pull up and stop at the limit line and believed that the driver saw him and he could continue. OV1 started a
left turn in front of MC1, causing the rider to brake, using only the rear brake and leaving 28 ft. of skid. MC1 started to yaw counter clockwise, so the rider let off the brake. This induced 33 ft. of wobble up to the point of impact. MC1impacted OV1 at approximately 24 mph. OV1 continued eastbound and then turned right at the next cross street before stopping at her final rest position (FRP). MC1 pivoted counterclockwise falling on its right side approximately 4 ft. from the point of impact (POI). The rider of MC1 fell within 8 ft. of the POI
RiderInj:
The 28 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the emergency room record: bilateral pubic ramus inferior/superior fracture, non-displaced fracture of the left proximal fibula, left wrist tendon tear, left elbow bone bruise, left upper arm abrasions, left knee
abrasions, left #5 phalange abrasions, bilateral inner thigh contusions and genital contusions
ODriverInj: The 33 year-old female driver of OV1 was not injured. There was no drug or alcohol involvement.
Human: The 33 year-old female driver of OV1 failed to perceive MC1 prior to making her unsafe left turn. The 28 year-old rider of MC1 made an incorrect decision in his avoidance action which contributed to the accident.
Vehicle: There were no crash causation factors related to MC1 and OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) rear-end type injury traffic collision, causing non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider.
MV1: 2008 Yamaha YZF R6 599cc (sport race replica) motorcycle black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle minor injury rear end traffic collision occurring on Saturday July 2013 at 1955 hours in Southern California. The weather report for this region showed clear skies, with winds out of the south at 6.9 mph and, an ambient temperature of 66.6 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions.
The collision occurred on a straight north/south two lane local surface street with a posted speed limit of 30 mph for both directions of travel. The roadway surface was level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
