MC1 was a 2013 Zero ZF 8.5 conventional style motorcycle utilizing a 420 amp electric propulsion system. MC1 was being operated by a 60 year old male. The rider was traveling eastbound in the #1 lane at a speed of about 25 mph prior to the crash event. As the rider was approaching the intersection he was about to enter the left turn lane when a black SUV (possibly a Chevy Tahoe-OV1) made a sudden lane change ahead of him. OV1 had also been in the eastbound #1 lane at a reduced speed and had signaled for the lane change prior to merging over into the	entrance of the left turn lane. The rider estimated his distance from the SUV as about 6 feet when he applied his rear brake in an attempt to slowdown however when he applied his front brake it caused the bike to stall and collapse ?high side left? onto the roadway. There was no contact between the two-vehicles
OV1 continued into the left turn lane and stopped ahead at the intersection (about 200 feet) and continued making a left turn northbound into a residential area. The driver was only described as a female who appeared to be aware of the circumstances of the crash but failed to remain at the scene.
 
MC1 had impacted the roadway surface left side down causing minor damage to the side covers and components.	The rider was ejected off the bike impacting the roadway surface and came to rest in the middle of lane #1 near the motorcycle. When I inspected the center median I could find no evidence of contact damage from MC1.
RiderInj: The 60 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of impacting	the roadway surface. The injuries included an open fracture of the left clavicle, an abrasion to the left forearm as well as a contusion to the left side of the thigh. The rider was transported to a local area hospital for treatment and released later the same day. There was no evidence of alcohol or drugs present in his system.
Human:
The 60 year old rider of MC1 appears to have been driving to close to OV1 and overreacted upon having to slow down.
The driver of OV1 may have been pre-occupied and not paying attention to traffic behind her prior to making her lane change.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor left side damage as a result of the crash however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 sustained no damage as a result of this crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
MV1: 2011 Kawasaki Ninja EX250J (649 cc) sport, race replica
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in December 2013 at 1755 hours in Southern California.	It was dark with overhead street lighting.	The weather was overcast, the temperature was approximately 58 degrees F and the winds were S at approximately 4 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, with light traffic.

The crash occurred at a T driveway intersection, on a straight undivided north/south commercial road. The roadway has two through lanes in both directions. The speed limit is 35 mph. The roadway is bordered by raised curbing, sidewalks and commercial buildings on the east side and raised curbing and a chain- link fence on the west side. The Reference Point (RP) was a light pole 56 ft. north of the north driveway curb-line and 2 ft. west of the west curb-line of the north/south roadway.
MC1 is a 2011 Kawasaki Ninja EX250J (649 cc) sport, race replica motorcycle ridden by a 21 year old male (5 ft. 4 in. and 160 lbs.). he rider was wearing a Shoei RF-500 (DOT/Snell) full face helmet with dark tinted face shield.	OV1 is a 2011 Hyundai Sonata driven by a 27 year old female (5 ft. 7 in. and 128 lbs.). The driver was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was northbound in the #1 lane approximately 6 ft. behind a minivan in the #2 lane approaching the T intersection at approximately 30 mph.	OV1 was westbound stopped at the limit line waiting to make a left turn heading south.	The minivan started to make a right turn at the intersection, the driver of OV1 believed she had enough time to make her left turn and started across the northbound lanes.	OV1?s view of MC1 was blocked by the minivan; the driver stated she never saw MC1.	MC1 saw OV1 start her turn and applied both brakes, but had insufficient time to stop and was struck by OV1 on the right side.
Area of Impact was 79 ft. 6 in. south and 28 ft. 6 in. east of RP.	MC1 high-sided onto its left side and slid to its Final Rest Position (FRP) 51 ft. south and 10 ft.
east of RP.	The rider of MC1 was ejected and landed face down at his FRP approximately 65 ft. south and 21 ft. east of RP.	OV1 was driven back into the parking lot on the north/east side, FRP unknown.
RiderInj: The 21 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries, as related during the interview: a contusion to the right ankle and abrasions to the right knee and lower leg. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was (1).
ODriverInj: The 27 year-old female driver of OV1 was not injured
Human: The 27 year-old female driver of OV1 made an assumption about northbound traffic when the minivan started to turn right and failed to look for other traffic before pulling across the northbound lanes
Vehicle: The crash involved vehicles were in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash, and were determined not to be a crash causal factor.
Environmental: A vehicle preparing to turn right from the #2 lane at the intersection blocked OV driver?s view of MC1.

CrashType: Single motorcycle riding in right turn only lane making a right turn on a borrowed MC, leans too low grounding the footboard which causes the MC to crash on its right side plane. The rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway major arterial at an at-grade four-way, not skewed type intersection with signal controls that were working properly. The roadway has an east/west designation but is in a southwest/northeast orientation at the crash site. The roadway the rider was exiting has 2 through lanes in each direction, dedicated left and right turn lanes, and a curb high raised divider with low ground cover.	The roadside has dirt shoulders and up- slopes. There are no sidewalks until the rider makes the turn. The area beyond the up-slopes is graded and new single family homes are being built. No on-
street parking is allowed. The posted speed limit is 55 mph. The roadway that the rider was turning onto is also a non-freeway major arterial roadway that has 3 through lanes and dedicated left and right turning lanes. There is a combination of meandering sidewalks, ground cover, and trees on either roadside. Both roadways are straight in the area of the intersection. As the rider was making his turn, he was leaving a roadway with a +2.4% crown and a 6.2% downgrade. MC1 was westbound to northbound when the crash occurred. The right footboard grounded out due to the low clearance and lean angle. MC1 went onto its right side plane, sliding front end first. The rider was fully ejected. At no time did the rider apply the brakes. There are no permanent visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, and is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition.
The crash occurred in Southern California in December of 2013 at 1150 hrs.	The weather was clear with a temperature of 75 degrees F. There was no wind. Traffic conditions were moderate. MC1 had no reduction in wheelbase. MC1 was taken to the registered owner?s house a short distance away.

MC1 was a 1999 Kawasaki Vulcan Drifter 1500 cruising type motorcycle with some modifications, including front crash bars, windscreen, footboards, and leather saddle bags. MC1 is owned by the brother of the rider. The rider was a male (5? 09?/230 lbs.). His age is unknown. He was wearing a full face helmet with unknown safety ratings. The helmet had a mirrored face shield. The helmet was retained on the rider's head to the end of the crash event. Per the owner of MC1, the rider?s helmet only had small pit marks on the back portion from when the rider laid his head onto the roadway surface after the crash. The helmet was not inspected.
 
The rider stated that he was visiting his brother and they had gone for a ride. He stated that they were just a few blocks away from returning home when the crash took place. The rider stated that he borrowed the crash bike from his brother. He said that he is used to riding sport type bikes with high clearance and that MC1 was a cruiser with footboards and low clearance. The rider stated that as he was making his right turn, the footboard hit the roadway causing MC1 to go down and ejecting him. The rider stated that he was going ?slow? while making the turn. The rider stated that he sustained several injuries which are
listed below. The rider then stated that he did not want to continue the interview or participate in the research. While inspecting MC1, the owner/brother stated that he and his brother had gone for a ride and were returning home when the rider crashed. Based on the brother?s statement, the ride they took was approximately 50 miles round trip. The owner stated that the brother is ?very heavy? and that his weight may have contributed to the crash by reducing the suspension and lowering the clearance. He also stated that the rider was wearing a full face helmet with a mirrored shield, and that there was no ?real damage? to the helmet as a result of the crash. He also said that the rider was wearing a T-shirt, shorts, and tennis shoes. The owner stated that the two of them were riding in single file type formation and that he was in the lead and did not actually see the crash. There were no visible scrapes when the scene was inspected. There is no mention of any scrapes in the police accident report. MC1 was moved prior to police arrival and its FRP is unknown. The rider was treated at the scene and taken to a local hospital. It is unknown if he was admitted or released.
RiderInj: The male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of 2 fractured ribs, a fractured right clavicle and scapula, along with numerous abrasions-not further specified. Had the rider been wearing heavier clothing, or protective apparel, some of the injuries may have been prevented. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would affect his ability to operate a vehicle.
ODriverInj: There was no Other Vehicle involved.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a comprehension error in regards to riding habits/styles on different MCs.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor damage consisting of scrapes to the front crash bar, windshield, auxiliary headlight, exhaust pipe, and leather saddle bag. MC1 was still ridable. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were contributory to this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Roadway in crash avoidance
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in December 2013 at 1536 hrs. in Southern California.	It was daylight, clear, the temperature was approximately 73 degrees F and the winds were approximately 8 mph from the west. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn with surface cracking and tar snakes. There was moderate traffic.

The crash occurred at a 4 way intersection, on the eastbound side of an east/west roadway with single family houses on the south side and commercial businesses on the north side.
There are 3 travel lanes in each direction with 2 eastbound and 1 westbound left turn lanes. The roadway is divided by a 5 ft. wide center median. The north/south roadway has no bearing on the crash. There are multi-phased traffic signals.

MC1 is a 2002 Kawasaki ZX6R (636cc) motorcycle ridden by a 20 year old male (6 ft. 1 in. and 200 lbs.).	The rider was wearing an unknown make and model of helmet. OV1 was an unknown white 4 door sedan.

MC1 was eastbound in the #2 lane, slowing as the rider approached the intersection, intending to continue east through the intersection.	OV1 was eastbound in the #1 lane ahead of MC1.	The signal phased green and traffic accelerated. As OV1 approached the east side of the intersection it changed
lanes, moving into the #2 lane in front of MC1.	MC1 swerved right and braked, in avoidance of OV1.	The rider of MC1 over braked, lost control and MC1 high- sided onto its left side, throwing the rider over the handlebars to the ground.	MC1 and rider slid an unknown distance to their respective Points of Rest
(PORs).
RiderInj: The 20	year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report:	right arm fracture NFS, left wrist fracture NFS, separated right shoulder NFS and minor abrasion and lacerations NFS.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 5. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: OV1 driver?s failure to perceive the presence of MC1 is a major contributing causal factor.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) front end to left front impact injury crash causing a secondary impact of MC1with the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider sustained an injury during the initial impact and was subsequently ejected onto the roadway surface causing additional injuries.
Crash:
This was another vehicle vs. motorcycle injury crash event. The collision occurred on Saturday December 2013 @ 1602 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1558 hours showed clear skies, wind direction from the south at 8.1 mph, and an ambient temperature of 63.7 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The motorcyclist was traveling on a straight two lane local (residential) street with grade of +4.3% on approach to an at-grade intersection. The roadway was 40 feet in width, with no lane markings and is of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit for east and westbound traffic is 25 mph.
The collision occurred on a straight at-grade offset (skewed) intersection with a minor arterial roadway. This roadway is has two through lanes dedicated for north and southbound traffic as well as designated 7 foot wide bicycle lanes on both the east and west sides of the street. The opposing lanes of travel are separated by a 10 foot wide painted two-way left turn lane.
The overall travel way width of this street is 64 feet. The posted speed limit for both north and southbound traffic is 40 mph.
On the east side of the street is another local street that allows for east and westbound traffic ingress and egress into a commercial complex. This street has one lane for each direction of travel and is 40 feet wide overall with a speed limit of 25 mph. The lanes are separated by a painted double yellow. This street was uninvolved during the crash event.
At the intersection there are no traffic signals or devices for either north or southbound traffic other than the posted speed regulation. For the adjoining local streets there are posted ?Stop? signs regulating traffic onto the minor arterial street.
MC1 was a 2012 Harley Davidson ?Iron 883? Sportster motorcycle being operated by a 33 year old male rider. MC1 was traveling eastbound in the #1 lane of the local (residential) street approaching the intersection. The rider was slowing and did stop for the posted stop sign prior to entering the intersection.
OV1 was a 2011 Honda Civic automobile that was being operated by a 23 year old male. The driver was traveling southbound in the #1 lane of the minor arterial street approaching the intersection at an approximate speed of 31mph.
The rider of MC1 had looked to his left and then to his right prior to entering the intersection. He noticed a vehicle stopped in the two-way left turn lane facing
 
northbound waiting to turn on to his street. The rider was waived on by the other driver to proceed. The rider also noticed a red Hummer SUV traveling southbound in the #2 lane slowing to turn right on to his street. The rider presumed that either one of these vehicles did not pose a threat so he proceeded eastbound into the intersection initiating a left turn to proceed northbound on the minor arterial street.
The rider had moved a distance of about 32 feet crossing the southbound lanes of the minor arterial street when MC1 was struck on the left front by OV1. OV1 had been southbound in the #1 lane at a speed of about 31 mph. The driver of OV1 had no time to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver. The collision caused the rear tire of MC1 to ride up on to the front hood of OV1 by evidence of tire scrub. The rider was thrown on to the hood and windshield. Both the motorcycle and rider rolled off the front of OV1 collapsing onto the roadway surface. MC1 had been moved a distance of approximately 56 feet from the initial area of impact. The rider was a distance of about 32 feet from the area of impact.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 33 year old male rider of MC1 sustained a distal fracture of both the Tibia and Fibula of the left lower leg as well as fractures to the C6 and C7 cervical vertebra. There was also a compressed fracture of the T3 thoracic disc as well as abrasions to both hands and his left shoulder. There were no apparent internal injuries. The rider was treated at the scene and later transported to a local hospital and admitted for a period of two days. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement. The rider was wearing a non-compliant ?novelty? helmet.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 33 year old rider of MC1 was operating his vehicle while fatigued after a day at work and had failed to yield to OV1 while entering the minor arterial roadway. The rider was unable to initiate any collision avoidance maneuvers.
The 23 year old male driver of OV1 was traveling at a reasonable speed for the traffic environment and was unable to react in sufficient time to the presence of MC1 intruding into his lane of travel.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate left front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. OV1 sustained moderate front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Fatal; Motorcycle vs. Fixed Objects
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred in January 2014 at 0238 hours in Southern California.	It was night with spot illumination, clear skies, the temperature was approximately 41 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition.

The crash occurred at a T intersection, in a residential area on a predominately north/south left curving, principal arterial roadway. South of the intersection, there are 3 through lanes and a bike lane in each direction, divided by a 15 ft. wide planted center median. The curve is 716 ft. in length with a radius of 1254 ft. The base of the T is on the east side of the intersection and has a bike lane and 2 travel lanes going east, 2 left turn lanes and a right turn lane going west.
MC1 is a 2007 Suzuki GSXR 750 (749cc) motorcycle ridden by a 29 year old male (5 ft. 11 in. and 170 lbs.). The rider was wearing an HJC; IS-16 full face helmet with a clear face shield.	MC1 was traveling northwest, negotiating the left hand curve at approximately 95 mph while under the influence of drugs and alcohol.	 MC1 may have attempted to pass a vehicle and as he returned into the #2 lane, continued to ride towards the right curb.	MC1 left approximately 149 ft. of rear wheel skid before striking the curb face. It continued along the curb face for approximately 17 ft. more, where the right side struck a 3 ft. high, 2 ft. in diameter steel vent cover.	MC1 fell onto the roadway on its right side approximately 36 ft. farther then slid approximately 95 ft. in the north/south crosswalk. This put MC1 and the rider approximately 20 ft. from the north/east curb of the east/west roadway, where MC1 continued straight while the rider angled to the right striking the curb approximately 6 ft. south of MC1.	MC1 struck the curb rear wheel first, splitting the tire and fracturing the right side of the rim.  MC1 crossed the 8 ft. wide sidewalk and struck the 8 in. high planter curb then vaulted approximately 8 ft. farther, where it struck a 10 ft. x 6 ft. metal sign.	MC1 broke apart with the engine falling to the ground at the Point Of Impact (POI) with the sign.	The rear wheel and part of the rear frame came to rest approximately 35 ft. west of the POI with the sign.	The fuel tank came to rest approximately 110 ft. north of the POI with the sign.	The front wheel/handle bars came to rest approximately 10 ft. east of the POI with the sign.
The rider struck the curb head first, causing the helmet to be ejected from the rider, coming to rest approximately 36 ft. east against the planter curb.  The rider continued across the sidewalk striking the planter curb and vaulting approximately 25 ft. northeast into a tree at a height of 5-6 ft.	The riders Final Rest Position was approximately 6 ft. southwest of the POI with the tree.

All measurements were taken using a north/south station line, with station (0, 0) approximately 28 ft. west of the western edge of the north/south crosswalk
 
and approximately 29 ft. north of the north edge of the east/west crosswalk.
RiderInj: The 29 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the coroner?s report:	transected cerebellar peduncle, cerebrum split in half, multiple skull and facial fractures, right femur fracture, pubic fracture, right metatarsal fractures, left humerus fracture, bilateral tibia and fibula fractures, laceration of the spleen, right eye avulsion, laceration & contusion of the tongue; extensive lacerations, abrasions and contusions of the external skin. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 75. Alcohol and Hallucinogens were a factor in this crash.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a BAC of .22, had Hallucinogens in his system and was riding at a high rate of speed.
Vehicle: The front tire of MC1 was grossly underinflated, greater than 40% below recommended pressure post-crash, with minimal tread. This was contributory to this crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType:
Motorcyclist riding in moderate to heavy fog while under the influence of alcohol is distracted by an alleged road rage vehicle and rear ends OV1 who is stopped for a red light. MC1 then careens left into OV2, side-swiping it before falling onto the roadway. The rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries.
MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway major arterial at an at-grade T-type intersection with signal controls that were working properly. The roadway has a north/south designation, but is in a slight northwest/southeast orientation at the crash site. The roadway has 3 through lanes in each direction, and dedicated left turn lanes on the rider?s side of the road. The roadway has a 2? wide, curb high raised divider in the area of the crash. The roadside on the right has a 5? dirt path and a chain link fence with open wilderness space beyond. On the left is an 8? concrete sidewalk, then grass and trees along with an industrial area.	No on-street parking is allowed. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. The roadway is straight and level with a negative 0.7% downgrade and a
+1.2% crown for the rider.	The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished and has some surface cracking, but is otherwise in good repair. The intersecting roadway was on the rider's left. The roadway surface was wet due to moderate to heavy fog. Visibility varied, but was at least 1/10th of a mile at the time of the crash. The rider gave two different versions as to how the crash took place. In the first version, the rider stated that he was in the #1 (left) lane approaching stopped traffic at the red signal. He attempted to split lanes to get up ahead of the Ovs. The rider stated that he hit a raised marker (?Botts? dot) and lost control, causing him to impact the left rear of OV1. He then careened left and impacted the right side of OV2. In the second version, which is in the police accident report, the rider stated that another vehicle was following him after he cut it off. The rider stated that he was not paying attention and that when he looked up, he saw the other vehicles stopped and ran into them. Both Ovs were the lead vehicles in their lanes of travel. MC1 then fell onto its right side plane in the middle of the crosswalk area. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. There are no permanent visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The fog may be contributory, as well as the wet roadway surface. The crash occurred in Southern California in
January of 2014 at 0747 hrs. The weather was foggy with a light breeze from the SSW. The temperature was 49 degrees F. Traffic conditions were heavy, but flowing. MC1 had no reduction in wheelbase. MC1 was towed.
 
MC1 was a 2006 Harley Davidson Dyna Superglide FXDI cruising type motorcycle with some minor modifications including a windscreen and nylon saddle bags. The rider was a 39 year old male (5? 10?/180 lbs.). He was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings. The helmet was retained on the rider's head to the end of the crash event per the police. The helmet went with the rider to the hospital.

The rider stated that he wasn?t paying attention because a car that he cut off earlier was following him. He stated that when he looked up, he saw the Ovs stopped and he hit them. Some friends of the rider showed up at the scene before the police did and loaded MC1 up onto a flatbed semi-trailer. OV1 and OV2 stayed at their POI/POR. MC1 impacted OV1 to the left rear area then careened left going in between OV1 and OV2. MC1 then side swiped OV2 near the leading edge area of the right rear door. MC1 continued moving forward between the two Ovs, and then landed on its right side plane in the crosswalk area. Both OV drivers stated that they were stopped for a red light when they were hit by MC1. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. He was also arrested for
DUI, and other charges. MC1 had markings indicating membership in a motorcycle ?club?. The rider was also carrying a loaded firearm. OV1 was in the #1 lane and OV2 was in the #2 left turn only lane. There were no involved vehicles in the #1 left turn only lane. The rider was treated at the scene and taken to a local hospital. It is unknown if he was admitted or released.
RiderInj: The 39 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of a compound fracture to one of his femurs (NFS). The rider of MC1 showed signs of impairment that would affect his ability to operate a motor vehicle. He was arrested after being medically cleared. A blood test was given at 1001 hrs. The results came back positive for Morphine, Hydromorphone, Amphetamine, Methamphetamine, and THCA (cannabis).
ODriverInj: There were no injuries or impairment noted by either of the two OV drivers.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a comprehension error as well as being under the influence of an alcoholic beverage. The rider may have also been riding too fast for the prevailing conditions.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor damage consisting of a broken windshield, rear brake pedal and right side foot peg, and several scrapes to both sides of the bike from the multiple impacts. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as fair.
Environmental: The weather could be considered contributory to this crash. Moderate to heavy fog limited visibility and made the roadway surface wet.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) left front to left front impact crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface. The rider was ejected onto the roadway and sustained minor injuries.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle traffic collision resulting in injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Wednesday, January 2014 at 0641 hours in Southern California. Sunrise was at 0659 hours. The weather report for 0653 hours indicated clear skies, with a calm wind condition, and an ambient temperature of 45.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface for MC1 had a 1.5% uphill grade with a 6.6% crown. The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? off-set (skewed) intersection of a principal arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 69 feet. The speed limit is posted 40 mph for both north and southbound traffic. The roadway is straight and runs east to west with two lanes dedicated for eastbound and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic.	There are designated left turn lanes to regulate both east and westbound traffic onto the intersecting retail/commercial areas at this intersection
The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by painted solid double yellow line lane markers. The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. The east and westbound lanes of the principal arterial street are regulated by traffic control signals without exclusive left turn signals.
The intersecting streets have an overall travel-way of 40 feet on the north side of the intersection and, 40 feet on the south side of the intersection. The north and southbound lanes of these streets are regulated by the same type of traffic signals without exclusive left turn arrows. The speed limit for the local streets is 25 mph.
MC1 was a 1999 Harley Davidson XL1200C cruiser style motorcycle being operated by a 20 year old male rider.	The rider was travelling at a speed of about 40 mph, eastbound in the designated #1 lane of the principal arterial street approaching the intersection. There were moderate traffic conditions at the time of the crash event.
OV1 was a 2012 Chevrolet Cruze automobile being operated by a 68 year old female. OV1was approaching the intersection westbound in the designated left
 
turn lane slowing and stopping for an intended left turn movement into the southbound lane of the intersecting local street.
When the driver of OV1 presumed it safe to proceed, she slowly began a left turn movement through the intersection. As the driver continued the turn she failed to notice MC1 approaching the intersection in the eastbound #1 lane.
The rider attempted to avoid the collision by moving towards the eastbound #2 lane however, collided with the left front portion of OV1 causing the motorcycle to collapse left side down onto the roadway surface and slide (approximately 30 feet) up and onto the wheelchair access ramp on the southeast corner of the intersection. The rider was ejected and vaulted off the motorcycle across the left front portion of the engine hood. The rider vaulted/slid a distance of approximately 52? 6? feet impacting with the roadway surface and coming to rest adjacent to the south curb line of the principal arterial.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, or animals that caused or contributed to the event. Other than the position of OV2 to the initial crash event, the driver of OV2 did not contribute anything to the cause or outcome.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of the crash. The injuries were visible abrasions to his lower back, both knees and his lower left leg. He also suffered a sprain to his left ankle.	The rider was treated at the scene and taken to a local hospital where he was released the same day. He was wearing a Shoei Qwest full face motorcycle helmet FMVSS 218 (US DOT)/Snell 2010 rated. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The drivers of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of this crash. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision to turn having failed to notice the presence of MC1 while making her left turn movement.
The rider of MC1 was driving at a safe speed for the current traffic on the roadway however, chose an unsafe collision avoidance maneuver at the time of the crash.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate front end and left side damage as a result of impacting OV1 and the roadway surface. MC1 appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained moderate left front damage. OV1 appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental conditions that contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in January 2014 at 0814 in Southern California.	It was daylight and overcast.	The temperature was approximately 50 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred at a four-leg intersection in a commercial area.	The north/south roadway is divided by a painted double yellow stripe and has 2 through lanes and a dedicated left turn lane in each direction. The speed limit is 35 mph and the southbound grade is -0.7 % and a crown +4.1%.	There are no traffic controls for the north/south roadway. The east/west roadway has a single lane in each direction divided by a painted double yellow stripe, a speed limit of 25 mph. Traffic is controlled by stop signs. The Reference Point (RP) is a fire hydrant; that is 2 ft. south of the south curb-line and 14 ft. 8 in. west of the west curb- line.
MC1 is a 2005 Kawasaki Concourse (997cc) motorcycle ridden by a 51 year old male (5 ft. 8 in. and 150 lbs.) rider. The rider was wearing a HJC RKT-201 full-face helmet. OV1 is a 2003 Chevrolet Tahoe driven by a 37 year old female (5 ft. 2 in. and 140 lbs.).	It is unknown if the driver of OV1 was wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling southbound at approximately 35 mph in the #1 lane approaching the intersection. OV1 was traveling eastbound from the limit line making
a left turn to the northbound lanes.	As MC1 neared the intersection, OV1 started her left turn in front of MC1, OV1 stopped, blocking the southbound #1 lane. The rider of MC1 applied both front and rear brakes; applying more front brake.	This caused MC1?s front brake to lock-up and the rear of MC1 to pivot clockwise, the rider steered left as he released the brakes; this caused MC1 to high-side onto its right side at Area of Impact #1 (AOI-1) and slide into the left
rear of OV1, AOI-2.	MC1 then slid to its Final Rest Position (FRP). The rider was launched from MC1 and slid to his FRP.	AOI-1 is 72 ft. north and 38 ft. 2 in. east of RP, AOI-2 is; 22 ft. north and 29 ft. east of RP.	MC1 FRP is unknown. MC1 moved prior to police arrival and Rider has no memory of MC1?s FRP.	The approximate rider FRP is 60 ft. north and 28 ft. east of RP.
RiderInj: The 51 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related during the interview: contusion of the left palm, abrasion to the back of the left hand and a minor laceration with stiches on the left knee.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to give MC1 the right of way and blocked MC1?s lane of travel.	The rider of MC1 failed to avoid the accident due to improper braking technique.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 and unable to determine OV1?s crash causal status, unable to view OV1.
Environmental: Per the driver of OV1, a vehicle proceeding northbound caused her to stop and block the southbound lanes of travel.

CrashType: Non-Contact OV1 makes left turn in front of MC1 negotiating a left curve.	MC1 over-brakes and loses control. MC1 slides then impacts a curb, flips, and continues sliding to its FRP.	The rider is fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway minor arterial at an at-grade T-type intersection with no signal controls. The roadway has a north/south designation, but is in a northeast/southwest orientation at the crash site. The roadway has 2 through lanes in each direction. There is a 10? wide raised center median with trees and shrubbery on the rider?s left while approaching the intersection. The opposite direction has a dedicated left turn lane with double yellow painted lines. There are meandering sidewalks on both sides of the roadway. On the rider?s side of the roadway the sidewalk is 7? 06? wide. On the other side it is 8?.
Where the sidewalk does not meet the curb, there is grass filling in the gaps.	Beyond the roadside greenery is a block wall separating the single family residences. No on-street parking is allowed. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The roadway is curved left for the rider?s direction. The length of curve is 902?. 261? of that curve is prior to the crash. The roadway has a 2.1% crown and a 3.2% downgrade.	The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished and has some surface cracking, but is otherwise in good repair. The intersecting roadway is on the rider?s right and has a stop sign. The lane line is a combination of paint with raised markers over the paint. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. There are no permanent visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in February of 2014 at 1950 hrs.	The weather was clear with a light breeze from the NE. The temperature was 50 degrees F. Traffic conditions were light. MC1 had no reduction in wheelbase. MC1 was towed. NC-OV1 fled the scene.
MC1 was a 2006 Kawasaki ZX-6R Ninja sport/racing type motorcycle with some minor modifications including front turn signals, the removal of the passenger foot pegs and rear plastic fender. The rider was a 37 year old male (5? 09?/128 lbs.). He was wearing a full face helmet with a clear face shield. The helmet had no safety rating markings; however, a check on the manufacturer web site indicates that all their helmets are ECE 22-05 rated. The helmet was retained on the rider?s head to the end of the crash event.
 
The rider stated that he was traveling northbound in the #2 lane at approximately 50-55 mph when NC-OV1 made a left turn in front of him. There were two independent witnesses who stated the same story. The driver of NC-OV1 never stopped prior to turning. The driver did stop blocking the #1 lane. The rider stated he braked and started to skid, then swerved to the right in an attempt to avoid NC-OV1. He lost control and went down, sliding across the intersection and into the curb. No pre-impact tire friction marks were visible when the scene was inspected. None were noted in the police accident report. The police accident report only documented the impact of MC1 into the curb as a POI. There is a slight crest in the roadway; however it would not be considered a contributory factor as a permanent view obstruction. Visibility is over 300?. At 50 mph (rider?s statement), over 4 seconds would lapse prior to any impact allowing either party to react normally to prevent a crash. The rider said that he was fully ejected.

When MC1 was inspected the morning after the crash, both tires were found to have extremely low (below 40% recommended) air pressure. This could be a contributing factor to the crash when combined with the speed, turning, and heavy braking. MC1 sustained major damage from impacting the curb. This impact fractured the engine case on the right side and caused the fairing to fragment off MC1. It appears that MC1 went down first on its left side and then flipped after impacting the curb. Both sides had significant damage. It appears that MC1 slid on one side first, then flipped after impacting the curb.	The damage from sliding on its left side was mostly cosmetic, consisting of scratches to the side covers, clutch lever, and handlebar. The frame had one small dent where the left side handle bar impacted it just below the gas tank. There appeared to be some minor pre-existing damage on MC1. According to the rider, MC1 had been re-painted and the only visible pre-existing damage was to the right handlebar.
RiderInj: The 37 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions and contusions to his knees, hip, buttocks, arms, and hands. He was taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released. The rider of MC1 showed signs of impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of NC-OV1 fled the scene. Any impairment is unknown.
Human: The driver of NC-OV1 had either a perception or decision failure. The rider had a reaction failure in over-braking which caused him to go down.
Vehicle: MC1 had very low tire pressure (below 40% recommended) in both tires which would contribute to poor handling and probably contributed to the crash. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as fair.
Environmental: There were no environmental conditions that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing non-life threatening injuries.
MV1: 2013 Harley Davidson FLSTN Soft Tail (conventional style) 1688cc, black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle head on type traffic collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Tuesday, February 2014 at 1655 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1656 hours indicated clear skies, with Southwest winds and an ambient temperature of 57.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions.
The roadway surface for MC1 had a -2.1% uphill grade with a 5.8% crown. The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. The collision occurred at an ?at grade?
T-intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 83 feet. The roadway runs east and westbound with two lanes dedicated for eastbound and three lanes dedicated for westbound traffic. The east and westbound through lanes are separated by a painted 11 foot wide two way left turn lane open to both directions of travel. The roadway is curved with a radius of 626 feet and an overall length of curve of 500 feet.
There are no traffic signals or devices to regulate both east and westbound traffic into the intersecting public driveway. The 30 foot wide driveway allows access into the parking area of a local commercial/retail shopping center.
The east and westbound lanes of the minor arterial street are not regulated by any posted or marked traffic control devices other than the post 35 mph speed limit signs.	There is no posted speed regulation for the intersecting driveway into the local shopping center.
The minor arterial roadway is also bordered on the both sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. There are no unusual surface features and both sides of the street are occupied by commercial/retail businesses.

The rider of MC1 was westbound in the #1 lane, negotiating a right curve approaching the intersection. The driver of OV1 was stopped facing eastbound in the two-way left turn lane waiting to turn into an adjacent shopping center.
MC1 was a 2013 Harley Davidson FLSTN Soft Tail (conventional style) motorcycle being operated by a 24 year old male rider. The rider was negotiating a right curve travelling at a speed of about 25 mph westbound in the #1 lane of the minor arterial surface street approaching the intersection. There were no other vehicles in the area other than OV1.
 
OV1 was a 2002 Honda Accord (automobile) being operated by a 67 year old female. OV1was approaching the intersection eastbound in the two way left turn lane and had stopped prior to an intended left turn movement into the shopping center parking lot. The driver of OV1 stopped prior to her turn, and said she intruded into the westbound #1 lane about 2 feet when the crash occurred. As the driver crossed the westbound #1 lane she felt a sudden impact to the front of her vehicle and did not move her vehicle until the police arrived. The driver claimed she had looked prior to entering and saw no approaching traffic.

The rider of MC1 did not see OV1 cross into his lane until he was struck on the left side by the front of OV1. The rider told police he vaulted over the handlebars of his motorcycle, tucked his shoulder, and rolled twice onto the roadway surface coming to rest in the westbound #2 lane approximately 43 feet 7 inches
west of the area of impact. The rider of MC1 had no time to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver. MC1 had collapsed right side down and came to rest in the westbound #2 lane approximately 22 feet 9 inches west of the area of impact.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, or animals that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj:
The 24 year old rider of MC1 sustained a fractured Femur to his left leg	as well as an abrasion to his right shoulder. He was treated at the scene and
subsequently transported to a local hospital where he was admitted for treatment. The rider of MC1 had no objective symptoms of drug and/or alcohol use at the time of the crash.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries and there was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human: The rider of MC1 could not sufficiently react in time due to the proximity and position of OV1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver. The driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision to turn having failed to notice the presence of MC1 while making her left turn movement.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major left side damage as a result of impacting the left front corner of OV1 however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained moderate left front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental conditions that contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Heavy truck w/trailer
OV1: 1997 Peterbilt dump truck w/end dump trailer
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in February 2014 at approximately 1650 hours in Southern California.	It was dusk, clear, the temperature was approximately 65 degrees F and the winds were light out of the south. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred at a ?T? intersection in a commercial area. The northbound side of the roadway has 4 through lanes and is divided by an 8 in. raised center median that is 16 ft. wide with trees and shrubs planted in the center. The southbound side of the roadway has 4 through lanes and 1 left turn lane and is divided by an 8 in. raised center median that is 16 ft. wide. There is a speed limit of 45 mph, the northbound grade is -0.3 % and the crown +0.4%.	There are no traffic controls for the north/south roadway.	The east/west roadway is undivided, has a single lane in each direction, intersects the north/south roadway on the east side and has a speed limit of 25 mph.		There is a stop sign and limit line for westbound traffic.	A north/south station line was established along the east curb-line of the southern center median, which is approximately 43 ft. west of the east curb with 0 at the north curb-line of the center median, which is approximately 2 ft. south of the south curb-line of the east/west roadway.
MC1 is a 1992 Harley Davidson FXLR (1337cc) motorcycle ridden by a 27 year old male (5 ft. 8 in. and 180 lbs.). The rider was wearing a Simpson, street bandit full-face helmet. OV1 is a 1997 Peterbilt end-dump, dump truck w/end-dump trailer, which has an overall length of approximately 52 ft., driven by a 63 year old male (5 ft. 6 in. and 170 lbs.). It is unknown if the driver of OV1 was wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling northbound, approximately 45 mph in the #1 lane approaching the intersection. OV1 was traveling southbound in the left turn pocket, making a left turn to the eastbound lane.	When MC1 was approximately 100 ft. from the intersection, OV1 started his left turn in front of MC1 without slowing or stopping, the trailer of OV1 blocked the northbound #1 lane.	The rider of MC1 applied both front and rear brakes and attempted to go behind OV1 until he saw the trailer behind OV1.	MC1 struck the right rear wheel of the rear trailer.	The Point of Impact (POI) was at station 13 ft. 9 in. north and 10 ft. east.	The driver of OV1 reported seeing the crash in his rearview mirror and stopped OV1 along the south curb-line of the east/west roadway with the right rear trailer
 
wheel at station 5 ft. 5 in. north and 62 ft. 10 in. east; this was also the riders Point of Rest (POR).	The rider was launched forward, over the handlebars, through the front fairing and came to rest with his upper body draped over the fender, with his lower body hanging straight down.

The front wheel assembly with suspension attached, sheared off from the triple tree and came to rest at station 25 ft. 9 in. north and 3 ft. 8 in. east.	The main portion of MC1 came to rest at station 19 ft. 9 in. north and 5 ft. 8 in. east.
RiderInj: The 27 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the hospital medical record and during the interview: comminuted left distal femoral diaphysis fracture, right triquentral carpal bone fracture, right 2nd metacarpal base fracture, right transquetral axial carpal dislocation, right metacarpophalangeal joint dislocation/subluxation, right upper lobe pulmonary contusion, left soft tissue contusion anterior of the iliac bone, 10 X 15cm avulsion of left knee w/exposed knee joint and minor abrasions.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 17.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured during this crash. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to give MC1 the right of way and blocked MC1?s lane of travel.	The rider of MC1 made the assumption that the driver of OV1 saw his approach.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors.
Environmental: Trees and Shrubs in center median may have blocked OV1 drivers view of MC1.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. multiple fixed objects (raised concrete curb, median and roadway surface), left center side impact crash, collapsing onto the grass top soil and roadway surface. The motorcycle impacted a curb which was part of a 15 foot wide raised concrete median with trees and low lying surface vegetation (grass top soil). The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained fatal injuries as a result of multiple impacts with the ground and environmental objects (surface vegetation and tree). There were no passengers on the motorcycle
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. multiple fixed objects, side impact crash event resulting in fatal injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Tuesday, February 2014 at 2104 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, calm wind conditions, and an ambient temperature of +59.0 degrees F. Sunset was at 1735 hours. The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. There were no roadway crown or grade issues with this portion of the roadway.
The collision occurred on a right curve portion of a multiple lane surface street with an approximate radius of 940 feet. The overall length of the curve in this area was 1056 feet. The overall travel-way width of the roadway is 72 feet. This is a	north/south collector with two lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and two lanes for southbound traffic. The southbound portion of this roadway is uninvolved in the crash event. The roadway design is a ?right curve? with a 15 foot wide raised concrete median separating the north and southbound lanes of traffic.
The street is also designed with 6 foot wide bicycle lanes along the east and west side of the roadway. Parking on both sides of the street is prohibited. The posted speed limit for both directions is 45 mph.
North of the intersection is a 58 foot wide residential T-intersection regulated by one posted stop sign for eastbound traffic entering the collector roadway. There are no other regulatory traffic control devices in the area. Both the east and west sides of this roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs, concrete sidewalks parklands and single family residential homes.
MC1 was a 1990 Honda VTR250R (conventional style) motorcycle being operated by a 22 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a full face DOT/ECE-2205 approved motorcycle helmet with a double ?D? ring nylon chin strap (mfg. date: 9-2012). Other than a missing face shield the helmet sustained only minor surface abrasions and was retained in place during throughout the crash event.
There was no evidence to suggest whether or not the rider was in the #1 or #2 northbound lanes prior to the crash. There was no evidence of any pre-impact skids up to the point where it was evident MC1 struck the median curb. As the rider continued northbound MC1 went wide to the left, striking the raised concrete median curb bordering the northbound #1 lane.	The motorcycle moved along the face of the curb a distance of approximately 79 feet, jumping the
 
curb and collapsing onto the grass top soil of the median and eventually onto the roadway surface.	The rider was ejected onto the grassy area of the median and impacted with a pine tree that was positioned in the center of the median. This tree was approximately 12 feet in height with a diameter of about 8 inches. MC1 slid or tumbled off the raised median continuing across the roadway surface (left side down) for another 93 feet before coming to rest in the northbound #1 lane.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event. There were no apparent roadway design issues at or near the location of the crash site.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male rider of MC1 sustained multiple blunt force traumatic fatal injuries of the head and thoracic areas of the body.	The Coroner?s toxicology report indicated that there was a postmortem presence of cannabis in his system.
Human: The 22 year old male rider of MC1 was driving at a speed safe for the area however, failed to perceive the (right) curvature in the roadway causing the motorcycle to drift left striking the raised concrete median. The rider was licensed but not endorsed for the operation of motorcycles.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcyclist stopped while waiting to make a left turn at an uncontrolled intersection with no left turn lane is rear-ended by OV1. The impact causes MC1 to be launched forward 31? and fully ejects the rider who sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway minor arterial at an at-grade four-way, non-skewed type intersection. The intersection had no signal controls or dedicated left turn lanes. The roadway has a north/south designation and is in that orientation at the crash site. The roadway has 2 through lanes in each direction and is divided by solid double yellow painted lines. The roadway has single family residences on both sides. Both roadsides have a strip of grass adjacent to the curb and then a 4? concrete sidewalk. On-street parking is allowed. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The roadway is straight and has a substantial downgrade of 5.4%. The crown is 4.7%. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but is otherwise in good repair. The intersecting roadway has no lane lines and is controlled by stop signs. Visibility was clear and unrestricted from the crest of the roadway to the crash site. This distance is approximately 300?. The area is lit with overhead street lights that were illuminated. MC1 was stopped when impacted from behind by OV1. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. There are no permanent visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in February of 2014 at 1834 hrs. The weather was clear with a light breeze from the SSE.	The temperature was 59 degrees F. Traffic conditions were light. MC1 had no reduction in wheelbase. MC1 was towed
MC1 was a 2005 Honda CBR 600 RR sport/racing type motorcycle with some minor modifications including hand grips and tinting the windscreen. The 25 year old male (5? 10?/175 lbs.) rider was northbound and stopped in the left lane waiting to make a left turn. He had his turn signal on. MC1 was equipped with ?always on? technology. He was wearing a full face style helmet with integral chin bar and dark flip down visor. The helmet had unknown safety ratings. The helmet was retained on the rider's head to the end of the crash event per the police. The helmet went with the rider to the hospital.

The rider stated that he was waiting for traffic to clear in the southbound direction so that he could make a left turn when he was hit from behind. He stated that the impact fully ejected him forward off MC1. He wasn?t sure where he landed or how he got to where he was when the police arrived. The 33 year old
 
male driver (5? 11?/160 lbs) stated that he was northbound in the #1 lane going about 30 mph and was conversing with his passenger over electronic directions to get back home. He stated that he was not paying attention to traffic around him and collided with an unknown vehicle to the front of him. When he looked forward, he saw MC1 and had no idea where it came from. The left front of OV1 impacted the rear of MC1. The impact broke the rear rim and flattened the rear tire of MC1. A portion of the broken rear rim jammed into the rear swing arm, causing the rear tire to not be able to rotate. MC1 was pushed forward approximately 31? before going down on its left side plane. The non-rotating rear tire left a long curved tire friction mark as MC1 was pushed forward by OV1. OV1 had left approximately 26? of right front locked wheel skid. Approximately 9? of this skid was pre-impact. The left front tire of OV1 left approximately 11? of locked wheel skid, which starts post impact. OV1 is not equipped with ABS brakes. Both MC1 and OV1 went into a CCW rotation. MC1 rotated approximately 90 degrees. OV1 rotated approximately 10 degrees. Both vehicles sustained minor damage as a result of the impact. MC1 was not ridable because of the rear tire/rim and was towed. OV1 was driven away. The rider was treated at the scene and taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released.
RiderInj: The 25 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of contusions the back of the knees. The rider of MC1 showed no signs of impairment that would affect his ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries and displayed no signs of impairment that would affect his ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The driver of OV1 had a perception error as well as being distracted with a passenger and an electronic mapping device.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor damage consisting of a broken rear rim which caused the tire to go flat. MC1 also had some minor scrapes on the left side plane. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.
OV1 sustained minor damage consisting of scrapes to the frontal left bumper and a dent in the hood.
Environmental: The crest in the roadway is a permanent view obstruction on the approach to the crash site however; it is far enough back from the crash site that at the posted speed limit there is sufficient distance to safely stop if needed.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing non-life threatening injuries.
MV1: 2014 Victory Cross Country 8-Ball (Touring) 1731cc, black in color
OV1: 2007 Toyota Tundra Pick-up truck, black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) injury crash event. The collision occurred on, Monday February 2014 at 0849 hours in Southern California. Sunrise was at 0636 hours. The weather report for 0845 hours showed mostly cloudy skies, with	winds out of the south at 5.8 mph and, an ambient temperature of 62.6 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed. The collision occurred at an ?at grade? intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 95 feet. The off-ramp intersects at a slight offset angle and the intersection is controlled by overhead multi- phase traffic control signals. The roadway surface for MC1 is straight and level with a +1.8% crown.
The minor arterial roadway runs east to west with two lanes dedicated for eastbound and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic. There are two designated ?left turn? lanes to regulate eastbound traffic onto the northbound interstate freeway on-ramp. The opposing lanes of traffic west of the intersection are separated by a painted double yellow line.
East of the intersection the opposing lanes are separated by a 12 foot wide raised concrete median with grass topsoil. The posted speed limit in this area is 40 mph.
The intersecting roadway for OV1 is a one-way single lane interstate freeway off ramp approximately 18 feet in width. The off-ramp is straight with a +2.8% uphill grade approaching the intersection and a +4.2% crown. There is no posted speed limit for the off-ramp. Both the east/west minor arterial and the off ramp were found to be of an asphalt composition that appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with either roadway.
The intersection where the crash event occurred is primarily in a commercial district of multi-story office buildings and commercial property. The minor arterial street is bordered by raised concrete sidewalks and there are no designated ?Bike Lanes? available. The off-ramp has no sidewalks or, bicycle lanes available and is bordered on both sides by concrete and river stone ground cover.
MC1 was a 2014 Victory Cross Country 8-Ball touring style (1731cc) motorcycle	being operated by a 59 year old male.	The rider was travelling at an unknown speed in the eastbound #2 lane of the minor arterial surface street approaching the signal controlled intersection. The light for his direction of travel had
recently phased to red prior to his entry into the intersection.
 
OV1 was a 2007 Toyota Tundra pick-up truck being operated by a 52 year old male. OV1was approaching the intersection northbound having just exited the freeway. The driver of OV1 said there was one vehicle in front of him that had entered the intersection on a green light and he followed into the intersection some distance behind this vehicle.
As the driver of OV1 entered the intersection, MC1 crossed in front of his truck. The driver had no time to stop and struck the right side of MC1. The contact between the two-vehicles caused MC1 to collapse onto the roadway surface left side down, sliding into the eastbound #1 lane. The rider was ejected off the bike and came to rest about 10? 6? from MC1. When interviewed the rider had no recollection of impacting with OV1 and there was no evidence of pre-impact
skid marks on the roadway from MC1. A witness following MC1on his own motorcycle saw the rider enter the intersection on a red light and felt as though he may have been distracted at the time.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 59 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were that of blunt force head and abdominal trauma, mesenteric injury as well as a scalp hematoma and abrasion. The rider was treated at the scene, transported to a local hospital and admitted for treatment. There was no indication of alcohol and/or drug involvement. The rider was wearing a full face motorcycle style helmet.
ODriverInj: The 52 year old male driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. There was no indication of alcohol and/or drug involvement.
Human:
The 59 year old male rider of MC1 made an incorrect decision to continue into the intersection against a red phase signal light.
The 52 year old male driver of OV1 entered the intersection on a green phase light and had no time to avoid colliding with MC1. The driver of OV1 did not contribute to the cause of the crash event.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate right side damage as a result of being impacted by OV1. There was also minor left side damage as a result of the collapse onto the roadway surface.
OV1 sustained moderate right front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in February 2014 at approximately 1751 in Southern California. It was dusk, not bright.
The temperature was approximately 65 degrees F and the winds were approximately 4 mph out of the southwest. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was heavy traffic.

The crash occurred at a four-leg intersection in a residential area, comprised of single family homes.			The north/south roadway has 2 through lanes and dedicated left and right turn lanes divided by an 8 in. wide raised concrete divider in each direction.		The east/west roadway is divided by a painted double yellow stripe and has 2 through lanes a dedicated left turn lane and bicycle lanes in each direction.	The speed limit is 45 mph.	The westbound grade is 0.7 % and a crown 7.5%.	The traffic controls for the east/west roadway are left turn demand dependent.				The Reference Point (RP) is a telephone pole; that is 3 ft. 10 in. east of the north/east curb-line of the north/south roadway and 38 ft. south of the north/east curb-line of the east/west roadway.
MC1 is a 2004 Honda CBR1000RR (998cc) motorcycle ridden by a 22 year old male (5 ft. 11 in. and 220 lbs.) The rider was wearing an extra- large AGV, K3 full-face helmet. OV1 is a 2013 Mercedes Benz GLK350 driven by a 33 year old female (5 ft. 6 in. and 124 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling westbound at approximately 41 mph, alternating between the # 1 and 2 lanes.	As MC1 approached the intersection MC1 veered into the # 2 lane and attempted to follow a blue, full-sized pickup truck through the intersection, after the signal had phased red.	MC1 braked hard leaving approximately 23 ft. of front wheel skid and approximately 70 ft. of rear wheel skid.	OV1 was eastbound in the left turn lane. OV1 entered the intersection and stopped for westbound traffic to clear before completing the left turn.	The signal phased red and OV1 started turning left, but stopped for the pickup truck to
pass in the # 2 lane. The driver of OV1 heard MC1?s engine and observed MC1approaching the intersection prior to MC1 moving into lane # 2 and believed MC1 would stop for the red signal. OV1 again started to complete the left turn and was struck by MC1 in the right side at the ?B? pillar as OV1 crossed lane # 2. The Area of Impact was approximately 48 ft. south and 22 ft. west from the RP.
 
There was approximately a 7 in. intrusion into the passenger side of OV1 overlapping into both front and rear passenger doors from the front of MC1. The front of MC1 was almost completely destroyed from the gas tank forward.	The front forks were broken from the frame and were being held on by wires. The  panel, front fairings, front headlight housing and key housing were completely destroyed.	The front tire was flat and coming off the broken rim which was collapsed approximately 4 in. The front half of the gas tank was broken off.

The rear of MC1 pivoted clockwise and MC1 came to rest on its right side facing east. The Point of Rest (POR) of the rear wheel was approximately 49 ft. south and 28 ft. west and the front wheel approximately 49 ft. south and 22 ft. west of RP. OV1 rolled forward on its wheels and came to its POR facing north; the right front wheel was approximately 6 ft. south and 2 ft. west and the right rear wheel 15 ft. south and 5 ft. west of RP.

The rider was launched from MC1 into the intersection approximately 30 ft. He came to rest with his head pointing north and his feet pointing south. His helmet was retained in place and was removed by emergency personnel. The POR of his head and feet was approximately 60 and 65 ft. south and 50 ft. west of the RP.
RiderInj:
The 22 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries taken from the medical examiner?s report:	a complete transection of brainstem, aortic tear, ventricle tear, near complete transection of the spleen, posterior bilateral rib fractures, a 7 cm. laceration of the liver, left orbital fracture, right tibia fracture, lateral laceration of the spleen, anterior right lung contusion, a right occipital fracture, sternum fracture, left radius
fracture, right ulna fracture and multiple abrasions and contusions of outer skin surface. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 75.
ODriverInj: The 33 year-old female driver of OV1 sustained the following injuries as related during the interview: seatbelt contusions to left shoulder and waist, multiple minor lacerations to the upper back from flying glass, a laceration to the right elbow from flying glass and lower back strain from the seatbelt.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The rider of MC1 failed to avoid the crash due to his failure to yield the right-of-way for a red phased traffic signal.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for crash involved vehicles.
Environmental: There were no crash causal factors relating to the environment.

CrashType: Motorcyclist swerves left into two-way center lane to avoid Non-Contact OV1 in front of him that is also swerving. MC1 over-brakes and loses control, going down on right side plane. Rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway minor arterial, mid-block between two T-type intersections that have no signal controls. The roadway has two lanes in each direction with a center two-way left turn lane. The roadway has an east/west designation however; it is in a slight southeast/northwest orientation at the crash site. The roadway has a motel and businesses on the rider?s right and small apartment complexes on the left. Both roadsides have a strip of grass adjacent to the curb and then a 5? concrete sidewalk. There are trees and light poles on both sides of the roadway. On-street parking is allowed. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The roadway is straight and level with a +0.1% grade and a +4.7% crown. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but is otherwise in good repair. Visibility was clear and unrestricted. MC1 was proceeding straight in the left lane when traffic slowed in front of him.
Multiple vehicles began changing lanes to the left to go around traffic that had slowed/stopped for a vehicle that was making a right turn into a driveway. MC1 swerved left to avoid NC-OV1. MC1 over braked and went down on its right side plane in the two-way left turn lane. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. There were no permanent or mobile visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern
California in February of 2014 at 1155 hrs.	The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with a light variable breeze. The temperature was 70 degrees F. Traffic conditions were moderate. MC1 had no reduction in wheelbase. MC1 was towed.
MC1 was a 2006 Yamaha V-Star 1100 Classic cruising type motorcycle with no modifications. The 65 year old male (6? 00?/190 lbs.) rider was eastbound in the #1 left lane proceeding with the flow of traffic. NC-OV1 was directly ahead of MC1. NC-OV1 quickly merged to the left in a collision avoidance maneuver because another vehicle that was slightly ahead of it and in the #2 right lane did the same thing to go around other vehicles that has slowed or stopped for a vehicle that was turning right into a driveway. MC1 also merged to the left and began braking. Witnesses stated that MC1 appeared to be wobbling and the rider lost control. In the police accident report, there was some speculation that the rider may have intentionally laid MC1 down as a collision avoidance maneuver. There were no pre-impact tire marks from MC1. MC1 and NC-OV1 never made contact. MC1 went down on its right side plane, low side first. It
 
skidded/slid 32? and rotated in a CW rotation before coming to its FRP in the two-way left turn lane. The rider was fully ejected and landed in the area of the #1 and two-way left turn lane line, southeast of MC1. Witnesses stated that the rider was tumbling head over heels. The investigator stated that the rider had some type of heart problem and that he took an unknown barbiturate prescription. While inspecting the helmet, it appears that the first impact to the helmet was in the front upper portion. This would cause the head to be forced rearward and is consistent with the cervical injuries that the rider sustained. MC1 was equipped with ?always on? technology. The rider was wearing a partial coverage helmet with double ?D? rings and strap. The helmet was retained on the riders head to the completion of the crash. The helmet was cut off at the scene by paramedics. The helmet had labels indicating it met FVMSS218 (US-DOT) safety ratings. The helmet had no face shield. The rider was wearing prescription clear glasses. During the inspection of MC1, no skid patches were found on the tires. The air pressure in both tires was low. The front tire had only 19 psi. The rear tire was at 25 psi. MC1 sustained minor damage.	The pre-crash movement of MC1, NC-OV1 and the other vehicle were caught on a security video camera. NC-OV1 remained at the scene, but the other vehicle that set the crash into motion did not.
RiderInj: The 65 year old male operator of MC1 sustained fractures to the C1, and C2 vertebrae leaving him paralyzed from the chin down. He also had visible abrasions to his hands. The rider tested positive for Cannabis and barbiturates at the hospital. It is unknown what level of influence the rider may have been under at the time of the crash that may have impaired his ability to safely operate a motor vehicle. An autopsy was not done. The investigating officer stated that the rider was somehow able to communicate with medical personnel that he did not want to continue live in his present condition which required a ventilator. The ventilator was removed after a "Do Not Resuscitate" was completed. The rider passed away 3 days after the crash.
ODriverInj: The driver of NC-OV1 remained at the scene. She sustained no injuries. She displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit her ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a reaction error and over-braked, causing MC1 to go down.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor damage consisting of a broken right turn signal and some scratches to the fender, exhaust pipes, and the underside of the right footboard which was jammed upward into the rear brake arm and neither were functional. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.
NC-OV1 had no damage and no mechanical problems.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors found to be contributory in this crash.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) broadside type impact causing the rider to be ejected off the motorcycle and on to the roadway surface. MC1 continued rolling until impacting with a concrete curb line and sidewalk area until it collapsed right side down off the roadway. The rider (MCR) suffered minor non-life threatening injuries.
Crash:
This was OV1 vs. MC1 front end to right front broadside type impact collision resulting in minor injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred	on Tuesday, February 2014 at 0846 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 0858 hours showed mostly cloudy skies, winds out of the north at 3.5 mph and, an ambient temperature of 59.4 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was 10.0 miles. The roadway surface was level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The collision occurred on a left straight multi-lane, minor arterial roadway with an overall travel-way width of 64feet. There is a -1.3% (eastbound) grade and, a +6.3 crown. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. This is an east/west surface street with two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic and two lanes for eastbound traffic. The east and westbound lanes are separated by a 10 foot wide painted two-way left turn lane. There is a designated left turn lane for westbound to southbound traffic onto a local street. There are no traffic signals at this intersection. The posted speed limit for east/west traffic is 40 mph.
The area of the collision scene is an ?at grade? T-intersection bordered by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks. There are multiple family apartment buildings along the north side of the minor arterial street at the intersection. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site. There are no designated bicycle lanes or pedestrian crosswalks in the area of the crash site.
The intersecting local street connects with the minor arterial on the south side of the roadway and is approximately 40 feet in width.
