There is one lane for northbound traffic and one for southbound traffic. Both lanes are 20 feet in width. This street serves a school/church and residential area. There is one traffic regulation (posted stop sign) for northbound traffic. The speed limit is 25 mph.
MC1 was a 1999 Suzuki GSF R1200 (sport touring) motorcycle being operated by a 23 year old male rider.	The rider was travelling eastbound in the #2 lane of the multi-lane surface street approaching the intersection.
OV1 was a 2000 Toyota Camry automobile being operated by a 85 year old male driver. The driver of OV1 had been traveling northbound on the local street and had stopped at the marked limit line prior to entering the intersection.
 
The driver of OV1 looked to his right checking for any approaching westbound traffic however, did not look to his right. The driver then moved his vehicle across the stop line and stopped prior to entering the intersection. The driver accelerated into the intersection initiating a left turn movement. As he was crossing
the westbound lanes his passenger said ?watch out?! The driver turned his attention to his left to see MC1 approaching in the westbound #1 lane and stopped his vehicle. OV1 had traveled about 60 feet. The driver saw the rider lay his motorcycle down in an attempt to avoid colliding with his vehicle. The motorcycle collapsed onto the roadway surface left side down sliding into the left side of OV1 near the front portion of the driver side door. MC1 glanced off OV1 coming to rest in the #2 westbound lane left side down facing west. The rider fell off the motorcycle prior to impacting with OV1.
The rider of MC1 said that prior to the crash event he was traveling at a speed of about 30 mph in the eastbound #1 lane. The rider saw a panel truck starting to make a U-turn type movement from east to west from the two-way left turn lane. The rider decided to change lanes into the #2 lane prior to passing the truck.
As the rider entered the eastbound #2 lane he saw OV1 pull across the stop line and stop partially inside his lane.
The driver of OV1 then proceeded into the intersection. When the ride saw OV1 pull across his lane of travel his first instinct was to apply both brakes and steer his bike to the left in an attempt to go around the front of OV1. As the rider passed in front of OV1 he impacted with the front of the vehicle and was ejected off the bike. The rider vaulted and tumbled on to the roadway surface coming to rest in the eastbound lanes of traffic.	MC1 rolled across the intersection until impacting with the raised concrete curb line on the north side of the roadway. When MC1 impacted with the curb it tumbled across a concrete sidewalk coming to rest right side down in an adjacent planter. Both rider and motorcycle came to rest, parallel with each other east of the initial area of impact.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were abrasions to the right thigh both knees and a sprained right ankle. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
ODriverInj: The driver was injured as a result of the collision. The police report also indicated that there were no apparent objective symptoms of alcohol or drug intoxication as well.
Human:
The 23 year old male rider of MC1 was driving at a speed considered safe for the present traffic on the roadway.
The 85 year old male driver of OV1 failed to yield to approaching traffic while entering the intersection from another local surface street.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate right front and left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision. OV1 sustained minor front end damage otherwise, was in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in March 2014 at 1831 hours in Southern California.	It was dusk, partly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 61 degrees F and the winds were approximately 8 mph out of the SSW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was moderate traffic.

The crash occurred at a four-leg intersection in a commercial/state beach area. The east/west state highway is divided by a raised concrete divider. The westbound side has a dedicated left turn lane, 2 through lanes and a dedicated right turn lane. The eastbound side has 2 dedicated left turn lanes and 3 through lanes. There is a speed limit of 45 mph and the grade is 0.0 % and a crown 3.0 %. There are multi-phased leading left turn green signals.

The Area of Impact (AOI) was 39 ft. south of the north curb-line and 52 ft. west of the east curb-line.
MC1 is a 2006 Honda CBR600F (599cc) motorcycle ridden by a 32 year old male (6 ft. 3 in. and 200 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make and model motorcycle helmet. OV1 is a 2004 Volkswagen Passat driven by a 49 year old male (5 ft. 5 in. and 140 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling westbound, stopped at the limit line beside the left side of the #2 lane. OV1 was traveling eastbound behind another vehicle in the #2 left turn lane slowing to make a left turn to the northbound lanes. The vehicle in front of OV1 made a left turn as the signal phased from yellow to red.  OV1 continued making its left turn after the signal had phased red. MC1 quickly accelerated after the westbound signal phased green, realized that OV1 had failed to stop and attempted to brake and steer left behind OV1. MC1 left 22 ft. of rear wheel skid before striking OV1 in the area of the right rear wheel.

The Final Rest Position (POI) of MC1, the rider and OV1 is unknown due to being moved prior to police arrival.
RiderInj: The 32 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: abrasions to the right wrist and left knee. He also had a complaint of pain to the left ankle. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to give MC1 the right of way and blocked MC1?s lane of travel. The rider of MC1 failed to react in time to prevent this accident.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 and unable to determine OV1?s crash causal status, unable to view OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: OV1 makes left turn in front MC1 at protected/permissive signal controlled intersection. No evidence of avoidance on the roadway by either operator. MC1 had a frontal impact to the right side of OV1. The roadway surface was wet from rain. Rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway minor arterial, at an at-grade signal controlled 4-way, not skewed intersection. The roadway has two lanes in each direction with bike lanes. Each direction has a dedicated left turn lane that is protective/permissive. On the approach to the intersection for MC1, there is an 11? wide painted divider. On the approach to the intersection for OV1 is an 11? wide painted divider. The roadway has an east/west designation, however; it is in a slight southeast/northwest orientation at the crash site. The roadway has single family residences on both sides. On the rider?s right, the residences are medium density and for ?active seniors?. The complex is gated.	The north side of the roadway has a 6? concrete sidewalk, along with some trees and shrubbery in front of a block wall. The south side of the roadway has a 7? concrete sidewalk and a block wall. There are trees and light poles on both sides of the roadway. No on-street parking is allowed. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The roadway is straight and level with a +0.8% grade and a +1.0 crown. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, with some surface cracking and large patches of repair in the area, but in otherwise good condition. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was cloudy with light scattered rain. The roadway surface was wet. There was a moderate wind from the west. MC1 was proceeding straight in the left lane when OV1 made a left turn in front of it. There was no evidence of braking by either operator. A small braking patch was located on the front tire of MC1 during the inspection. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. There were no permanent or mobile visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in March of 2014 at 1916 hrs. The temperature was 61 degrees F. Traffic conditions were moderate. MC1 had an approximate 4.6? reduction in wheelbase. MC1 was towed. OV1 was driven home.
MC1 was a 2004Suzuki SV 650 S sport/race type motorcycle with modifications. The 30 year old male (5? 11?/200 lbs.) rider was westbound in the #1 left lane. He was wearing a full face helmet with integrated chin bar and clear face shield. The helmet had labeling indicating that it met FMVSS 218 (US DOT) safety
 
ratings. The rider was wearing a denim jacket and jeans, low cut running shoes, and armored nylon mesh full fingered gloves. He was returning home from the store. He had a small amount of cargo in a backpack. He said that the store is about one mile from his home. The crash occurred one block from the rider?s home. OV1 was stopped in the eastbound left turn only lane, headed home. In the police accident report, both operators stated that they either had a green arrow (OV1) or a green light (MC1). The report does not name either party at fault. The rider stated that he was able to brake a little and thought that he drifted left when he saw OV1 beginning its turn, but made no overt turning movement. The rider also stated that he had no idea where he landed in the street, but thought it was in the eastbound left turn lane. MC1 was lying in the middle of the street according to the rider. There was one witness to the crash, but she did not see the signal. The witness stated that she saw OV1 make a left turn and that MC1 hit OV1. She saw the rider vaulted over the trunk on OV1. The rider stated that he was traveling at about 45 mph. Based on the location of the POI, it does not appear that MC1 made any evasive turning maneuvers prior to the crash. There was no mention in the police accident report in regards to any FRPs. During the inspection of MC1, a small skid patch was found on the front tire.
The air pressure in both tires was low. The front tire had 21 psi. The rear tire was at 22 psi. MC1 sustained major damage.
RiderInj: The 30 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries listed as a laceration to the right knee, an abrasion to the left elbow, and contusions to the lower right leg, right foot, and left buttocks.. He was treated at a local hospital and released.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. She displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit her ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
Human: It is unknown whether the operator of OV1 had a perception or decision error in making the left turn in front of MC1, or if the rider had a decision error in failing to stop for a red light.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front end. The reduction in wheelbase caused the front tire to impact the engine area and damage the forward exhaust pipe. The rest of the damage was mostly on the right side and consisted of a broken off foot peg/rear brake unit, and numerous scratches. There was a dent to the gas tank that appears to have been caused by the handlebars. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.
OV1 was not inspected.
Environmental: The cloudy, rainy weather which caused the roadway surface to become wet may have been a contributing factor.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) front end to left front impact injury crash event causing a secondary impact of MC1 with the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider sustained a non-life threatening injury.
MV1: 2013 BMW S1000 RR (sport, race replica) motorcycle, white in color
Crash:
This was another vehicle vs. motorcycle injury crash event. The collision occurred on Thursday, March 2014 @ 0759 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 0758 hours showed cloudy skies, with calm winds and an ambient temperature of 52.3 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The collision occurred on a straight section of a north/south multi-lane principal arterial roadway north of a four way signal controlled intersection. There are three designated though lanes of travel for both north and southbound traffic. These lanes are separated by a painted solid double yellow line lane divider. There is also a designated ?Bike Lane? on both sides of the roadway. There is a single designated left turn lane for southbound traffic approaching the intersection. The edges of the roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks. The overall travel way of the southbound lanes is 46 feet and the speed limit for both directions of travel is posted at 45 mph.
The environment of the crash scene is bordered by commercial/retail shopping along the west side and a community college campus parking facility on the east side.
MC1 was a 2013 BMW S1000 RR (sport, race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 38 year old male rider. The rider had exited a commercial shopping area and was traveling eastbound crossing the southbound lanes of traffic in order to enter the left turn lane. Southbound traffic had come to a stop for a red light at the intersection and the rider was slowly maneuvering between stopped vehicles in the #3, #2 and #1 lanes in order to access the left turn lane.
OV1 was a 2012 Volkswagen automobile that was being operated by a 30 year old male. The driver was traveling southbound in the designated left turn lane approaching the intersection. As the rider of MC1 entered the left turn lane he was attempting to turn right to position his motorcycle into the lane. The driver of OV1 did not see the rider or motorcycle when it entered his lane and he could not stop in time to avoid a collision. The front of OV1 struck the left side of MC1 causing it to collapse on to the roadway surface and ejecting the rider.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj:
The 38 year old male rider of MC1 sustained a fracture to his right ankle with no further explanation of the injury. There were no apparent internal injuries.
 The rider was treated at the scene and later transported to a local hospital where he was treated and released. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 38 year old rider of MC1 was operating his vehicle while attempting to cross a principal arterial roadway. The rider failed to or ignored the presence of approaching southbound traffic to his left while maneuvering between vehicles.
The 30 year old male driver of OV1 was traveling at a reasonable speed for the traffic environment and was unable to react in sufficient time to the presence of MC1 crossing into his lane of travel.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate left front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. MC1 was towed from the scene.
OV1 sustained front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 was driven from the scene.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. roadway surface vs. other vehicle (OV1), minor injury crash event. The rider lost control of his motorcycle causing it to collapse low side right onto the roadway surface and sliding into the rear portion of OV1. The rider was ejected off the motorcycle and sustained non-life threatening injuries.
MV1: 1996 Yamaha XJ600S Diversion (conventional style) 598cc, black in color
OV1: 2011 Hyundai Tucson (automobile derivative SAV) green in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. roadway surface vs. other vehicle minor injury crash event. The collision occurred on Wednesday, April 2014 at 1440 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, a WNW wind direction @ 11.5 mph, and an ambient temperature of +66.9 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a 0.7 % downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred in the southbound #1 lane of a right curve divided multiple lane minor arterial roadway with an overall travel-way width of 43 feet. The north and southbound lanes are separated by a 4 foot wide raised concrete median with no median barrier. There are 5 foot wide designated bike lanes on both sides of the roadway.
There is a multi-phasic signal controlled intersection south of the crash site that both OV1 and MC1 were approaching just prior to the crash event. 
MC1 was a 1996 Yamaha XJ600S (conventional style) motorcycle being operated by a 20 year old male. The rider was wearing an unknown make/model full face motorcycle helmet at the time of the crash event. Photographs of the helmet were taken at the scene.
The rider was traveling southbound in the #1 lane prior to the crash event. The rider was traveling at a speed of at least 15-20 mph when he approached OV1. OV1 was directly ahead slowing in the #1 lane and the rider had intended to move around the right side of the vehicle to continue southbound.
OV1 was a 2011 Hyundai Tucson ?sport activity vehicle?. OV1 was being operated by a 76 year old female. There was also a female juvenile riding in the vehicle as well. OV1 was southbound in the #1 lane slowing and the driver was attempting to move left into a designated left turn lane prior to the crash event.
The passenger asked the driver to take her to a fast food restaurant located across the street on the northbound side of the street. The driver had intended to enter the left turn lane, proceed to the intersection and make a U-turn. The driver decided to stop her vehicle while in the #1 lane to wait for a spot to enter the left turn lane. Traffic ahead of OV1 had already started moving ahead on a fresh green light at the intersection.
The rider of MC1 initially saw OV1 slowing and intended to pass the vehicle on the right. The right drew his attention away from OV1 to conduct a lane check of
 
the southbound #2 lane. When he looked back towards OV1 he suddenly realized that OV1 had come to a complete stop in the lane. The rider attempted to apply both front and rear brakes however, lost control of the motorcycle causing it to collapse low side right onto the roadway surface. The rider was thrown onto the roadway and both he and his motorcycle continued sliding until the bike impacted with the rear of OV1.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male rider of MC1 sustained a minor non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The rider refused any treatment at the scene. The injuries sustained were abrasions to the right forearm, right knee and, right foot.
ODriverInj: The driver and passenger of OV1 were uninjured.
Human:
The 76 year old driver of OV1 failed to comprehend the danger of impeding traffic in her lane of travel while stopping to change lanes.
The rider of MC1 was found not to be in possession of a valid motorcycle license and had only recently purchased the motorcycle. The rider had limited experience to or exposure to circumstances such as vehicles stopped in traffic.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate right side damage as a result of the crash however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 sustained minimal damage to the rear bumper and was otherwise in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: OV1 impacts MC1 to the right rear side as MC1 makes a right turn from the wrong lane into a commercial driveway. There was no evidence of avoidance by either operator. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway major arterial, at an at-grade, signal controlled, 4-way, not skewed intersection. The roadway has three lanes in each direction with bike lanes. Each direction has a dedicated left turn lane that is protective only. The roadway has a 4? wide curb high raised center divider. The roadway has an east/west designation however, it is in a slight southwest/northeast orientation at the crash site. The roadway has a retail commercial complex on the rider?s right and single family residences on the left. The north side of the roadway has a 9? concrete sidewalk, along with some trees and street light posts. No on-street parking is allowed. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The roadway is straight with a slight downgrade of -2.7% grade and a
+5.6% crown. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, with some surface cracking and large patches of repair in the area, but in otherwise good condition. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The area was lit by overhead street lights that were functioning properly. The weather was partly cloudy. There was a slight wind from the southeast. Both vehicles were stopped for a red light. MC1 was in the #1 left lane and OV1 was in the #2 middle lane. When the signal phased to green, MC1 began its right turn in front of OV1 and was impacted. There was no evidence braking by either operator. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. There were no permanent or mobile visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in April of 2014 at 2214 hrs. The temperature was 63 degrees F. Traffic conditions were light. There was no reduction in wheelbase. MC1 was towed. OV1 was driven home.
MC1 was a 2012 Yamaha R6 sport/race type motorcycle with no modifications. The 25 year old male (6?00?/190 lbs.) rider was westbound in the #2 middle lane approaching an intersection. He was wearing a full face helmet with integrated chin bar and mirrored face shield. The helmet had labeling indicating that it met FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell M2005 safety ratings. The helmet sustained minor damage as a result of the crash. The cracked face shield occurred after the crash when the rider dropped the helmet. The rider was wearing a Kevlar long sleeved shirt, jeans, hi-top style tennis shoes, and armored nylon mesh full fingered gloves. The rider stated that he was following friends that were in a car ahead of him going to the store. The rider stated that he had never been on
 
this road or neighborhood before. The rider stated that he was in the #3 right lane, had down shifted to first gear, was going approximately 10-15 mph and was making a right turn when he was impacted from behind. He stated that he never saw the OV behind him. The rider stated that he came to rest in the crosswalk on the far side of the intersection and that his bike was a short distance beyond him in the right lane.	The driver of OV1 stated that she was westbound behind MC1 who appeared to be following an SUV. She stated that the SUV was changing lane from the right lane over to the left lane and back and that MC1 was following. She stated that all three came to a stop for a red light. She stated that MC1 was to her left in the #1 lane, she was in the #2 lane, and that the SUV was to her right in the #3 lane. The SUV made a right turn into the parking lot while the light was still red. When the light phased to green, MC1 suddenly made a right turn in front of her and she hit him. She stated the MC1 impacted here left front area and then both the bike and the rider impacted the right front and hood area of her car. The rider was then ejected. The driver of OV1 said that she had no idea that MC1 was going to turn in front of her and that she braked after impact. According to the driver of OV1, the occupants of the SUV came running to the crash scene and said they would wait for the police to arrive which caused the other witnesses to leave. According to the driver of OV1, the occupants of the SUV turned out to be friends of the rider and gave vague statements as to how the crash occurred. When OV1 was inspected, some minor repairs had been completed. Based on the damage that was still present, the evidence supports the driver of OV1?s version of what took place. After the impact with OV1, MC1 went down on its left side plane, high side first and slid into the curb at the northwest corner. MC1 then rotated in a clockwise direction and slid to its FRP, west of the intersection. OV1 was moved prior to the arrival of the police and parked. When the scene was initially inspected two days after the crash, the only evidence that could be located was where MC1 impacted the curb.
There was no construction at or near the crash site. Scene photos had to be re-taken weeks later after the interviews and police report were found to be contradictory. There were no pre or post-impact tire marks from either vehicle. MC1 had slightly low air pressure in the front tire when it was inspected. This had no contribution to the crash. The police accident report shows that the first harmful event took place in the westbound #2 (middle) lane. The police report does not name either party at fault. MC1 sustained major damage and was towed. OV1 was driven away.
RiderInj: The 25 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of fractures to his right thumb and two toes on the right foot as well as numerous abrasions and contusions. He was treated at the scene and refused to go to a hospital. He later went to a walk in clinic who determined that he needed more medical attention than they could provide. He then went to a hospital.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. She displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit her ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a decision failure in making a right turn from the wrong lane.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the rear end and left side. There is a moderate dent to the left side of the gas tank which appears to be from an impact with the curb. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.

OV1 sustained minor damage to the left front, right front, and hood as a result of the impacts with MC1 and the rider. The pre-crash condition of OV1 would be considered good.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were considered to be contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) left front to right side impact crash event causing a secondary impact of MC1 with the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected onto the roadway surface sustaining serious injuries. The other driver (OVD) failed to stop and subsequently drove away from the scene prior to law enforcement or emergency service arrival.
MV1: 2007 Suzuki Bergman 400 (step through style) 400cc, silver in color
OV1: Unknown year Toyota Celica (automobile, maroon in color
Crash:
This was another vehicle vs. motorcycle injury crash event. The collision occurred on Saturday April 2014 @ 1045 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1046 hours showed mostly cloudy skies, wind direction from the west at 4.6 mph, and an ambient temperature of 68.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. Both the motorcyclist and the other driver were traveling in the westbound #3 lane of a straight six lane principal arterial roadway with a downhill grade of -4.4%. The roadway was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The overall travel width of this roadway is 98 feet and the posted speed limit for east and westbound traffic is 40 mph.
The collision occurred on a straight section of the roadway just west of a signal controlled intersection.	This roadway is has three through lanes dedicated for east and three lanes for westbound through traffic and there are no designated ?Bike? lanes. The opposing lanes of travel are separated by a 4 foot wide raised concrete median with no barrier.
On the north side of the street is a retail/commercial complex open to public access.	On the south side of the street are residential single family homes. The intersection east of the crash site is controlled by electronic multi-phase traffic signals and will also accommodate pedestrian traffic with painted crosswalks. Both MC1 and OV1 had passed through this intersection prior to the crash and it is not factored into the crash event.
MC1 was a 2007 Suzuki Bergman 400 (step through style) scooter being operated by a 64 year old male rider. MC1 was traveling westbound in the #3 lane of the principal arterial roadway.
OV1 was an unknown year Toyota model Celica automobile, maroon in color being operated by a female with black hair.	The driver was traveling westbound in the #3 lane of the principal arterial roadway some distance behind MC1.
The rider of MC1 had looked ahead towards the traffic in front of him and noticed the vehicles coming to a stop. The rider applied his brakes and began to slow down when he felt an impact to the rear of his bike. The rider continued braking however lost control of his bike and it collapsed onto the roadway surface right side down. The impact also caused the rider to be ejected onto the roadway surface sustaining serious injuries to his right knee and right shoulder. MC1
 
continued another 50 feet until coming to its point of rest.
The driver of OV1 failed to stop after the crash and subsequently drove away prior to the arrival of law enforcement and emergency service personnel. There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 64 year old male rider of MC1 sustained a fracture to his right knee cap and a laceration to his right shoulder. He was treated at the scene and transported to a local hospital for treatment. The rider also complained of pain along the entire right side of his body. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: It is unknown if the driver of OV1 sustained any injuries as a result of this crash event.
Human: The 64 year old rider of MC1 was operating his vehicle with reasonable safety although having to suddenly slow down for traffic in front of him. The driver of OV1 failed to notice the change in the speed and flow of traffic and could not stop in time to avoid colliding with MC1.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate left front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. OV1 sustained an unknown amount of left front damage as a result of this crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Ground
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred in April 2014 at 1403 hours in Southern California.	It was daylight with scattered clouds, the temperature was approximately 66 degrees F and the winds were approximately 12 mph, gusting to approximately 20 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn with tar snakes.

The crash occurred on a rural, undivided, 2 lane roadway at the exit of a right hand curve. MC1?s direction of travel was predominately northwest; the road has a -3.2% northwest grade, a crown of 5.0% and a superelevation of approximately 5.0%. The lanes are 12 ft. wide and there is a painted center median that s 13 ft. wide. The curve is 957 ft. in length, with a radius of 834 ft., measured with a 100 ft. chord whose middle ordinate of 16 in.
MC1 is a modified, 1982 Kawasaki KZ750 CSR (745cc) motorcycle ridden by a 54 year old male (5 ft. 11 in. and 195 lbs.). The rider was wearing a Bilt, full face helmet, model # BLH17/992.	MC1 was traveling northwest, negotiating the right hand curve, when the front of the rear fender came loose and
was dragged under the rear tire.	This caused MC1 to fall onto the roadway and slide north across the opening of the right turn lane to the shoulder.	The rider of MC1 lost consciousness during the crash, but regained consciousness on the way to the hospital.	All measurements were taken using a roll-a-tape, from a Reference Point (RP) which is a utility junction box, approximately 361 ft. southeast of the east curb-line of the intersection and 8 ft. northeast of the north
curb-line.	Area of Impact was approximately 65 ft. southeast and 27 ft. southwest of RP, the Area of Rest was approximately 43 ft. southeast and 12 ft. southwest of RP.
RiderInj: The 50 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related in the rider interview:	right clavicle fracture, right #2 rib fracture, left index finger fracture and bilateral abrasions to the toes.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 6. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: There were no human crash causation factors.
Vehicle: There was mechanical failure to MC1 which contributed to this crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: MC1 in #1 lane is passing OV1 (tractor/trailer rig) which is in the #2 lane as it starts making a left turn. No evidence of avoidance by either operator. MC1 had a right side rear impact to the left front bumper of OV1. Rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway major arterial, at an at-grade signal controlled 4-way, not skewed intersection. The roadway is undergoing major renovations including underground utilities and widening. The roadway construction is present for several blocks. The roadway is a one-way road and has three through lanes with a bike lane. There are no dedicated left or right turn lanes. The intersecting roadway is a two way street with one lane in each direction. The intersection is controlled by overhead signals that were functioning properly. On-street parallel parking is allowed on both sides of each roadway. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial businesses. Both roadsides have concrete sidewalks of varying widths. The #1 left lane for both vehicles direction of travel is currently 22? wide to allow for on-street parking and left turns onto the cross street. Part of the construction is widening that lane an additional 10? to allow for some additional on-street parking and driveways. The old curb line at the south-west corner is still present and has a functioning signal pole. The posted speed limit is 35 mph. There are no reduced speed limit signs posted for the construction zone. The roadway is straight with a +3.7% grade and a +6.6% crown. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, and has numerous bituminous repair sections from underground infrastructure being replaced. The loose material on the roadway surface is kept at minimum and had no contribution to the crash. Visibility
was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear and the wind was calm. MC1 was proceeding straight in the #1 left lane. OV1 was going in the same direction in the #2 lane and was making a left turn. There was no evidence braking by either operator. The rider impacted the left side of the front bumper of OV1 and was fully ejected. The rider sustained serious injuries. There were no permanent or mobile visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in April of 2014 at 0725 hrs. The temperature was 60 degrees F. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. MC1 was towed. OV1 was driven away.
MC1 was a 2009 Kawasaki LE 650A dual purpose type motorcycle with modifications. The 30 year old male (5? 10?/185 lbs.) rider was northbound in the #1 left lane. He was wearing a full face helmet with integrated chin bar and clear face shield. The helmet had labeling indicating that it met FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and
 
Snell M2005 safety ratings. The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. The rider was wearing an armored nylon mesh protective jacket, jeans, full fingered armored gloves, and casual work shoes. The rider stated that he normally takes a different route to work, however, he wanted to put air into his tires and knew of a location that does not charge on this road. The rider stated that he was going approximately 45-50 mph in the left lane and was riding to the right side of the lane. He said that he did see the truck. The rider did not recall seeing the turn signal on the truck. The rider stated that as he was passing the truck, it suddenly came into his lane. The rider stated that he thought about steering left, but didn?t think he had time to react and do so. The rider stated that he had no time to react and try to avoid the truck. The rider remembered lying on the sidewalk after the crash. The driver of OV1 was attempting to make a left turn from the #2 lane because of the length of his vehicle. In the police accident report, he states that he saw that the left lane was partially coned off. He stated that he slowed, put on his left turn signal and his emergency flashers. There are two video clips regarding the crash. The first one is about one block south of where the crash occurred and shows both vehicles several seconds apart. The second video is taken from west of the crash intersection. It shows OV1 starting to make its left turn from the #2 lane as MC1 is passing in the #1 lane, along with the impact. The light was green for northbound traffic. There was no evidence of skidding on the roadway or on the tires of MC1. The air pressure in the front tire was slightly low, however not enough to be considered contributory to the crash. MC1 sustained major damage and was towed. OV1 was driven from the scene.
RiderInj: The 30 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries listed as a comminuted compound fracture to his lower right leg-ankle area, a compound fracture to the right foot, along with vascular and muscular injuries in both areas; a major laceration/degloving to his upper right thigh, and abrasions to left upper arm and elbow. He was admitted to a local hospital for 25 days. His right foot/lower leg was amputated below the knee. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
Human: It is unknown whether the operator of OV1 had a perception or decision error in making the left turn in front of MC1, or if the rider had a perception or decision failure while attempting to pass OV1.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the rear end and left side. There was an approximate 6.2? reduction in wheelbase which came from the rear end being pushed forward when the rear suspension was broken. This caused severe frame and or structural damage. When MC1 was on its left side plane, the reflectors, turn signals, foot peg, and shifter were broken. The muffler and side mirror were damaged on the right side from impacting OV1. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good.
OV1 sustained a bent fender on the left side as a result of the crash.
Environmental: Although the roadway is undergoing a major renovation, the construction was not contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (raised concrete curb face) head-on type impact including a secondary impact with a four foot tall hedge row just off the roadway. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of impacting with the hedge row.
MV1: 1990 Kawasaki EX500R Ninja (conventional) 498cc, black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (raised concrete curb face) head-on type impact type crash event resulting in minor injuries to the rider. The collision occurred Thursday, May 2014 at 0106 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, calm winds, and an ambient temperature of +71.1 degrees F. Sunrise was at 0602 hours on this day.
The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 6.2% downhill grade with a +6.6% crown in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a westbound left curve approaching a ?Y? type intersection of adjoining local streets. The two lane local (residential) street has an overall travel way width of 38 feet. The street has no physical median or painted lane dividers.	The street, the intersecting local streets and the intersection are uncontrolled. There are no posted speed limit signs, strop signs or, marked crosswalks. Both the north and south sides of the local street are bordered by raised concrete curbs and 5 foot wide concrete sidewalks.

There are no designated bike lanes for either direction of travel and parking adjacent to both sides of this street is allowed. Both sides of the street are occupied by single family residential homes.
MC1 was a 1990 Kawasaki EX500R (conventional style) motorcycle being operated by a 33 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a white Arai Quantum E model full face motorcycle helmet which was found to be DOT and Snell 95 approved.
The rider was travelling westbound on the local street at an estimated speed of approximately 30-35 mph (downhill) as he was approaching the ?Y? intersection of the two other adjoining local streets.
As the rider continued westbound he applied his rear brakes possibly concerned about his approach speed to the intersection. There was evidence of locked rear wheel skid marks approximately 65 feet in length prior to the motorcycle impacting with the curb face.
The motorcycle skidded into and through the intersection until impacting with the northwest curb face.	From the initial area of impact the motorcycle continued up and onto the raised concrete sidewalk impacting a 4 foot tall hedge row and collapsing right side down on the sidewalk having traveled	a distance of about 10 feet. The rider was ejected off the bike and into the hedge row from the initial area of impact to his final resting place about the same
 
distance as the bike.
RiderInj: The 33 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non specified superficial abrasions to his body as a result of the collision. The injuries were non-life threatening and the rider was not treated at the scene or transported to a hospital for treatment. There was no evidence of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human: MCR was attempting to evade a police.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor front and right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: OV1 is making a left turn in front of MC1. The front left of OV1 impacts MC1 to the left side. MC1 goes down on its right side, impacting the curb, and then impacts the rear of parked OV2. No evidence of avoidance by either operator. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a local road at an at-grade ?T? type intersection with no signal control devices for any direction. On-street parallel parking is allowed on both sides of each roadway. The surrounding area is comprised of industrial/commercial businesses. Both roadsides have grass ground cover and no
sidewalks. The roadway is an undivided two lane road with lanes that are 22? wide and separated by painted double yellow lines. The posted speed limit is 30 mph. The roadway is straight with a -1.1% grade for the rider?s direction of travel and a +3.4% crown. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was partly cloudy and the wind was light from
the south-east. MC1 was proceeding straight when OV1 turned left in front of it. There was no evidence braking by either operator. The rider was fully ejected after POI #3 and sustained injuries. After going down on its right side plane, MC1 impacted the curb on the northeast corner, then slid and impacted a parked vehicle, trapping the rider under it. There were no permanent or mobile visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in May of 2014 at 1605 hrs. The temperature was 94 degrees F. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the southwest. Traffic conditions were light. MC1 had no reduction in wheelbase. MC1 was towed. OV1 was driven away. The rider was hospitalized. The crash was captured on security video.
MC1 was a 2003 Suzuki GSX R750 sport/racing type motorcycle with modifications. The 30 year old male (6? 02?/240 lbs.) rider was northbound in the #1 lane. He was wearing a full face helmet with integrated chin bar and clear face shield. The helmet had labeling indicating that it met FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and ECE 22- 05 safety ratings. The helmet sustained minor abrasions. The rider was wearing a T-shirt, denim jeans, and low top tennis shoes. He had just left work and was on his way home. He had a small amount of cargo in a backpack that he was wearing.	The crash occurred one block from the rider?s work. The rider stated that he was second gear going between 35-40 mph. OV1 was southbound and made a left turn in front of MC1. The driver stated in the police accident report that
 
he was going approximately 15 mph. The rider stated that the driver of OV1 was looking to his right as he was turning. After the crash, OV1 stopped in the intersection. The crash was captured on security video from a business on the northeast corner. The rider stated that as he was approaching the intersection, he saw OV1 ?drifting? to the right. As he got closer to the intersection, the rider stated that he could see the driver of OV1 looking away to his right and not stopping. He stated that he backed off the throttle, then braked and tried to swerve to the right in an attempt to avoid the crash. The rider stated that he was aware of an air bubble in his front brake lines which caused the front brakes to not work as effectively as they should. He was not sure if they even engaged when he used them. He said he also applied his rear brake and thought that he locked it up because he felt that he was sliding/skidding. A tire mark was located during the scene inspection. It appears to be from the front tire and is post impact. After being struck by OV1, MC1 went down on its right side plane and slid front end forward, impacting the curb. MC1 then continued in a northwesterly direction and rotating counter-clockwise and slid into and under OV2 which was parked. The rider was still on MC1 and pinned under OV2. People in the area that heard the crash came out to assist the rider and moved MC1.
Both tires on MC1 had low air pressure, but not enough to be contributory to the crash. During the inspection of MC1, no skid patches were found on the tires. The driver of OV1 stated that he never saw or heard MC1 until he hit him.
RiderInj: The 30 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries listed as a compound fracture to his left leg near the knee and another fracture near the left ankle. He also had abrasions and contusions, mostly to his extremities. He was admitted to a local hospital for 24 days.	He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to safely operate a motor vehicle. OV2 was parked and had no occupants.
Human: The driver of OV1 had a perception failure by looking away while driving. The rider had a minor decision failure in going over the speed limit.
Vehicle:
MC1 had a brake system issue which the rider described as air in the brake lines. He stated that he was aware of the problem but had not yet fixed it. MC1 sustained minor damage to the left side from the impact with OV1 and minor to moderate damage on the right side from skidding on the roadway surface. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be considered good.
OV1 sustained minor damage to the left front. It was driven away.

OV2 sustained minor damage to the right rear. It was left parked at the scene. OV2 was drivable.
Environmental: There were no environmental conditions that were considered to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) right front to left side impact with a secondary low-side left lay down event onto the roadway surface. The rider (MCR) sustained non-life threatening injuries and refused treatment at the scene. The other driver (OVD) was uninjured.
MV1: 2007 Kawasaki ZX14 (sport race, replica) 1352cc, black in color
OV1: 2007 Jeep Compass SUV (automobile derivative) red in color
Crash:
This was MC1 vs. OV1 in a broadside type impact type crash event resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the rider. There was a secondary low side left impact of MC1 impacting with the roadway surface. The collision occurred on Tuesday, May 2014 at 1550 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed partly cloudy skies, a WSW crosswind @ 12.7 mph, with periodic gusting winds of up to 20.7 mph and an ambient temperature of +68.0 degrees F. Sunset was at 1951 hours on this day.
The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a measured 3.6 % uphill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a northbound, right curve two lane local surface street with an overall travel-way width of 40 feet. This is a north/south local surface street with one lane dedicated for northbound and one lane for southbound traffic.

There are no designated bike lanes for either direction of travel and parking adjacent to both sides of this street is allowed in designated areas on both sides of the street. OV1 was legally parked along the east side of the roadway facing north prior to the crash event.
The traffic lanes of this street are divided by a painted set of solid double yellow colored lane lines. The area in proximity of the crash site is bordered by single family residential homes on the east side and multiple family dwellings (apartments) along the west side of the street.
The location of the crash site was approximately 170? south of the nearest local street T-intersection. The intersection for north and southbound traffic is uncontrolled and was not involved in this crash event.	The posted speed limit for both north and southbound traffic is 35 mph however, is also regulated by posted ?School Zone? signs limiting the maximum speed to 25 mph while children are present in the area. Both the east and west sides of this street are bordered by raised concrete curbs, and 5 foot wide concrete sidewalks. The environment adjacent to the east side of the roadway consists of an uphill geography with low lying surface vegetation. The west side geography is level with trees and low lying surface vegetation.
MC1 was a 2007 Kawasaki ZX14 (1352cc) sport race, replica motorcycle being operated by a 47 year old male rider. The rider was wearing DOT approved full
 
face Shoei motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield. The helmet was unaffected by the crash event.
The rider was travelling northbound in the designated #1 lane of the local surface street at an estimated speed of approximately 30 mph and was approaching the location of parked vehicles along his right, including OV1.
As the rider continued northbound he noticed a red 2007 Jeep Compass SUV (OV1) pull out and away from the designated parallel parking area. OV1 began to turn across the northbound lane of travel moving an approximate distance of 21 feet from its parked position. The rider reacted by applying his brakes periodically creating at least two gaps in the skid pattern over a distance of about 57 feet. The cumulative measured visible skid pattern was about 43 feet 9 inches in total length. The rider also attempted to steer to his left in a collision avoidance maneuver however the right front portion of MC1 struck the left side of OV1 at the driver side door. MC1 collapsed in a low side left impact with the roadway surface.
The rider was wedged between both vehicles. OV1 remained at the area of impact and MC1 was within 6 feet of the area of impact as well.
RiderInj: The 47 year old male rider of MC1 sustained serious injuries as a result of the collision.	The rider initially refused medical treatment at the scene however ha later admitted himself for treatment. The rider discovered he had sustained a fractured right Scapula, eight fractured ribs and had punctured his right lung.
Human:
The 47 year old male rider of MC1 was operating at a speed within the posted speed limits of the roadway however, had insufficient time to initiate a safe collision avoidance maneuver.
The 29 year old driver of OV1 pulled away from the parking area thinking that he had sufficient time to negotiate a safe entry into the northbound lane. The movement of OV1 effectively blocked the northbound lane of travel.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate right front and minor left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. OV1 sustained moderate left side damage and was subsequently driven away from the scene.
Environmental:
The roadway surface in the area of the crash site has a 626 foot radius in a right curve configuration with a 3.6% uphill grade over an overall 847 foot horizontal curve. The north and southbound lanes of travel are 20 feet in width with the	parallel parking allowed and a posted speed limit of 35 mph. When the OVD moved about 21 feet from his legally parked position along the east side of the street MC1 was approaching at an approximate speed of 30 mph/44 fps, 132 feet behind the position of OV1. Visibility due to roadway curvature, uphill grade, visibility limitations from parked vehicles and the allowed
maximum speed of 35 mph may have compromised the rider?s safe travel.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Pickup Truck
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in May 2014 at 2025 hrs in Southern California.	It was night with overhead spot lighting, partly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 65 degrees F and the winds were approximately 7 mph from the southwest. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn with surface cracking, and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial area, on a north/south 4 lane roadway, at a 4 way intersection.	There are no traffic controls for the north/south roadway; the # 1 lanes are 10 ft. wide and the #2 lanes are 17 ft. wide.	The	roadway is divided by a painted double yellow stripe.	The east/west roadway has vertical stop signs and the word stop painted on the ground behind a white painted limit line.	The speed limit is 35 mph, the southbound grade is -4.0% and the crown is 8.0%.
MC1 is a 1979 Vespa Piaggio P125X (123cc) scooter, ridden by a 47 year old male (5 ft. 8 in. and 156 lbs.). The rider was wearing an AGV RP60 open-face helmet.	OV1 is a 2003 Chevrolet C1500 driven by a 28 year old male (5 ft. 7 in. and 155 lbs.). The driver and passengers of OV1 were reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was traveling southbound in the #1 lane approaching the intersection at approximately 35 mph.	OV1 was eastbound stopped at the limit line intending to make a left turn heading north. The driver of OV1 believed it was clear of traffic and started his left turn, then saw MC1 just before MC1 impacted the left
side of OV1 just ahead of the ?B? pillar.	OV1 traveled forward approximately 6 ft. before stopping at its Final Rest Position (FRP). MC1 rebounded and fell on its right-side on top of the rider, facing north in the #1 lane. There were no visible skid marks on the roadway or on MC1?s tires.	 The Point of Impact (POI) was approximately 20 ft. east of the west curb-line and 18 ft. south of the north curb-line. MC1?s FRP was approximately 8 in. north and 1.2 ft. west of the POI. Injuries and Impairment: The 47 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on police report:	Injuries Not Further Specified (NFS) major brain injury, fractured neck, right femur fracture and multiple facial fractures.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 10.	Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.	The 28 year-old male driver and the passengers of OV1 were not injured.
RiderInj: The 47 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on police report:	Injuries Not Further Specified (NFS) major brain injury, fractured neck, right femur fracture and multiple facial fractures.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 10.	Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
ODriverInj: The 28 year-old male driver and the passengers of OV1 were not injured.
Human: OV1 driver?s failure to perceive the presence of MC1 is a major contributing causal factor. MC1 rider?s failure to perceive the presence of OV1 is a probable contributing factor.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: MC1 in right turn lane goes straight attempting to pass a large truck in the #1 lane which is making a right turn. MC1 brakes, and then has frontal impact to OV1 right side. MC1 goes down on right side plane. Both rider and passenger are caught up under OV1 and seriously injured.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway major rural arterial, involving an at-grade T-type intersection. There are no signal control devices involved. The roadway has one through lane in each direction with a bicycle/emergency lane on the right edge. The roadway is divided by solid double yellow painted lines except at the intersection where the roadway widens. There is a dedicated right turn only lane in the direction of the rider. Between the #1 lane and the right turn only lane is a bicycle lane. In the opposite direction, there is a dedicated left turn lane. No on-street parking is allowed on either side of the roadway. The roadway is designated as a north/south direction however; in the area of the crash it has a northwest/southeast orientation. The surrounding area is comprised of a small community of single family residences on the right which are barely visible from road. On the left is open wilderness. There are no sidewalks and only a dirt shoulder in some areas. The posted speed limit is 55 mph. The roadway is straight in the area of the crash. The roadway has a +3.2% grade and a +5.0% crown. There is a super elevation of 5% with the rider?s lane on the low side. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the southwest. There was evidence braking by MC1. Brake marks from MC1 are pre-impact. There are no pre or post-impact brake marks from OV1. What appears to be skid marks from the right side of OV1 are actually body drag marks from one of the victims. The rider and passenger of MC1 were fully ejected and sustained serious injuries.
There were no permanent or mobile visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in May of 2014 at 1035 hrs. The temperature was +71 degrees F. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. Both vehicles were towed.
MC1 was a 2008 Harley Davidson Softail Springer (1584cc) cruiser with minor modifications. The 40 year old male (5? 08?/145 lbs.) rider and 33 year old female passenger (no description) were wearing an unknown style helmets with unknown safety ratings. It is unknown if the helmets remained in place to the
 
completion of the crash events. The rider was wearing unknown type of clothing. The passenger was wearing a leather jacket and tennis shoes. The rider stated that he and his passenger were on their way to eat. He stated that they had changed their minds as to which restaurant they were going to, so he was going to turn around at the intersection. He pulled into the right turn only lane and accelerated instead of slowing down. He proceeded to attempt pass OV1 and go straight from the right turn only lane. There was a witness vehicle that was behind OV1 and ahead of MC1. OV1 signaled and merged into the right turn only lane to go to the residential neighborhood. The rider of MC1 applied his brakes, locking the rear. MC1 left 58? of rear tire skid before impacting the right rear side of OV1. MC1 side-slapped OV1 and both the rider and passenger were fully ejected. Both were caught under OV1 and dragged to their FRP. According to the driver of OV1, the passenger was under the right front tire and the rider was under the vehicle. He stated that he backed OV1 off of the passenger, and then called for help. Witnesses stated that OV1 was a large public utilities service truck and going slower than the posted speed limit. He stated that MC1 swerved several times from side to side in what he thought was the rider looking for a place to pass OV1. The witness also stated that when MC1 entered the right turn lane, he accelerated to pass him and the large truck. OV1 was making its right turn while mostly still in the #1 lane, near the end of the bike lane. The driver of OV1 stated that he was unfamiliar with the area and the street that he was turning onto. Both MC1 and OV1 were towed from the scene.
RiderInj:
The 40 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate to major injuries listed as a grade 3 spleen injury, a pneumothorax to the left lung, multiple rib fractures, and a fracture of the left tibia. The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.

The 34 year old female passenger sustained severe injuries and was placed into a drug induced coma. Some of her injuries were listed as multiple rib fractures, bilateral scapula fractures, a fracture of the pelvis, left leg and foot, and numerous abrasions. She was still hospitalized at the writing of this report, which is 35 days after the crash.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
Human:
The rider of MC1 had a decision failure in attempting to unsafely pass on the right in a right turn only lane.

The driver of OV1 had a perception error in not seeing or hearing MC1 passing on the right. The driver of OV1 also made a right turn from the wrong lane, which was contributory to the accident.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage. The front suspension was damaged from impacting OV1. The left side sustained denting to gas tank and a broken transmission case from side slapping OV1. MC1 then went down on its right side plane and sustained additional damage. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good.

OV1 sustained minor damage to the right side, forward of the rear tires.
Environmental: There are no environmental factors that are considered to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) front end to right side impact minor injury crash event causing a secondary impact of MC1 with the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider sustained non-life threatening injuries.
MV1: 2007 Honda VT600CD VLX Shadow Deluxe (modified chopper) black in color
Crash:
This was OV1 vs. MC1 broadside type minor injury crash event. The collision occurred on Friday, May 2014 @ 1910 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1853 hours showed clear skies, with WNW winds @ 6.9 mph and, an ambient temperature of 79.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The collision occurred on a straight section of a north/south multi-lane principal (non-freeway) arterial roadway north of a four way signal controlled intersection. There are three designated though lanes of travel for both north and southbound traffic. These lanes are separated by a 4 foot wide raised concrete center median. There is also a designated left turn lane for southbound to eastbound traffic north of the intersection. This left turn lane is separated by an 8 foot wide painted median from the southbound through lanes.
There are no designated ?bike lanes? on either side of the roadway.	The edges of the roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks. The overall travel way of the southbound lanes is 61 feet and the speed limit for both directions of travel is posted at 45 mph.
The environment of the crash scene is bordered by commercial/retail shopping centers along both the east and west side of the roadway.
MC1 was a 2007 Honda VLX Shadow (modified chopper) style motorcycle that was being operated by a 27 year old male. The rider was wearing a DOT approved partial coverage motorcycle helmet of unknown make or model. The helmet did not sustain any damage as a result of the crash. The rider was traveling southbound on principal arterial roadway and was lane splitting between the #1 and # 2 through lanes of travel.	As the rider continued southbound the driver of OV1 was exiting the retail shopping center parking lot located on the west side of the street. Traffic was heavy at the time and the rider did not notice OV1 crossing the southbound lanes between stopped vehicles in front of him. As he continued southbound OV1 moved into his path of travel and impacted with the right side of MC1. The subsequent impact caused MC1 to collapse onto the roadway surface ejecting the rider.
OV1 was a 2014 Honda Accord (automobile) being operated by a 54 year old female. The driver had exited a retail/commercial shopping area and was traveling eastbound crossing the southbound lanes of traffic in order to enter the left turn lane. Southbound traffic had come to a stop for a red light at the
intersection the driver was slowly maneuvering between stopped vehicles in the #3, #2 and #1 lanes in order to access the left turn lane.	As the driver crossed from the #2 to #1 lanes, her vehicle struck the right side of MC1.
 
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 27 year old male rider of MC1 sustained compound fractures to both the Tibia and Fibula of the right leg. He also sustained a fracture to his right ankle with no further explanation of the injury. There were no apparent internal injuries. The rider was treated at the scene and later transported to a local hospital where he was admitted for a period of seven days. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement. Access to a medical ?discharge summary? was refused.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 27 year old rider of MC1 was operating his motorcycle while attempting to split lanes in heavy traffic southbound on a principal arterial roadway. The rider failed to or ignored the presence of an approaching vehicle attempting to enter the roadway and cross over into the designated left turn lane.
The 54 year old female driver of OV1 failed to notice the presence of an approaching vehicle (MC1) while crossing the southbound lanes of travel.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate left front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. MC1 was towed from the scene.
OV1 sustained front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 was driven from the scene.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType:
This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. fixed object (roadway surface) with a secondary impact involving MC1sliding into and impacting a portable sign trailer. The rider had failed in his attempt at negotiating a wheel stand (wheelie).
The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of impacting the roadway surface. There were no passengers on the motorcycle or other vehicles involved.
MV1: 2008 Suzuki GSXR 1000 sport race replica style motorcycle (999cc) blue in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. fixed object (roadway surface) type crash event with a secondary impact resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the rider. The collision occurred on Friday, June 2014 at 1529 hours in Southern California. Visibility at ground level was clear and unrestricted for all directions of travel.
The weather report showed clear skies, a SW wind direction @ 12.7 mph with no gusting winds, and an ambient temperature of +71.8 degrees F. Sunset was at 2002 hours.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? straight, multiple lane principal (non-freeway) arterial roadway that ?T? intersects with a 40 foot wide local street. The four southbound lanes have overall travel way width of 56 feet. The local street has two lanes; one for west and one for eastbound traffic and has an overall travel way width of 40 feet. There is one posted ?Stop? sign regulating eastbound traffic at the intersection. The local street is not involved in this crash event other than its proximity to the crash scene. The north and southbound lanes are divided by a series of raised concrete dividers. The northbound lanes of the roadway are not involved with the crash event.
There are no designated bike lanes on either the principal arterial roadway or the local street. The west side of the roadway is bordered by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit for north and southbound traffic is 45 mph.
MC1 was a blue Suzuki GSXR 1000 (sport race replica style) motorcycle being operated by a 39 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an unknown make/model motorcycle helmet at the time of the crash. There were no passengers on the motorcycle.
The rider was travelling southbound in the #2 lane of the multi-lane principal arterial roadway. The rider had initially started from a signal controlled intersection north of the crash scene. Witnesses at the scene indicated that the rider began his ?wheelie? once he crossed through the intersection and held the maneuver while nearing the T-intersection where he eventually lost control and crashed; a distance of nearly 700 feet.	Further information provided to law enforcement was that the rider was traveling at a speed somewhere between 45 and 60 mph. At the same time the rider was approaching the T- intersection there was a public school bus starting to cross the southbound lanes from a designated left turn lane at the T-intersection. The driver of the bus
 
saw MC1 approaching while performing the ?wheelie? and stopped prior crossing the lanes of travel.
The rider of MC1 swerved to the right, possibly in reaction to the presence of the school bus causing the bike to collapse left side down. The rider was ejected onto the roadway surface while MC1 slid further eventually impacting a mobile electronic traffic sign board. The sign board had been placed in the southbound #4 lane at about 0900 hours this day. The sign was set up to divert traffic from the #4 lane into the #3 lane for roadwork being conducted further south of its location.
RiderInj: The 39 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were a broken right arm, head laceration and left hip abrasion. The rider was treated at the scene and subsequently transported to a local hospital for treatment. There were no objective symptoms of alcohol intoxication or drug use.
Human: The 20 year old male rider of MC1 made a decision to conduct a ?wheelie? style maneuver and subsequently lost control of his motorcycle, causing injuries and damage to both his motorcycle and the sign trailer. The rider was operating his motorcycle while his driver?s license was currently under suspension.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front end and moderate left side damage as a result of impacting with the roadway surface and the sign board trailer.	MC1 appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
There were no ?other vehicles? involved.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in May 2014 at 2320 hours in Southern California.	It was dark, without illumination, partly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 65 degrees F and the winds were approximately 3-4 mph out of the SSW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred on a predominately north/south oriented state highway adjacent to a commercial driveway, in a commercial/state beach area.	The northbound roadway has a 14 ft. lane adjacent to the east curb and a 10 ft. lane adjacent to a two way center turn lane.	The southbound roadway has 9 ft. wide parallel parking stalls adjacent to the west curb a 15 ft. lane, a 10 ft. lane and a dedicated left turn lane.	There is a speed limit of 45 mph and the northbound grade is 0.5 % with a 6.1 % crown. There are no traffic controls.	The Reference Point (RP) is a concrete bridge pillar, which is 34 ft. south of the south driveway curb-line and 12 ft. east of the east curb-line.	The following measurements are taken from this RP.
MC1 is a 2003 Suzuki DR650SE (644cc) dual sport motorcycle ridden by a 31 year old male (5 ft. 9 in. and 195 lbs.). The rider was wearing a Fly Racing, Trekker full-face helmet. OV1 is a 1998 Pontiac Firebird driven by a 24 year old male (6 ft. and 155 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

Both MC1 and OV1 were traveling northbound in the #1 lane approaching the driveway.
OV1 was ahead of MC1, slowing to approximately 15 mph and moving into the #2 lane.	MC1 was traveling at approximately 65 mph overtaking OV1; the rider believed OV1 was going to turn into the driveway ahead, instead, OV1 started a U-turn, crossing the northbound lanes and into the two-way turn lane, where the driver stopped just before impact.	MC1 braked and attempted to swerve to the left, slowing to approximately 33 mph before impacting the left front
fender/bumper of OV1.	The area of impact (AOI) was approximately 17 ft. north and 27 ft. west of the RP.	MC1 slid to its Area of Rest (AOR) approximately 85 ft. north and 51 ft. west of the RP.	The rider of MC1 was launched over the hood of OV1 and his AOR was approximately 45 ft. west of the AOI.	OV1 turned back slightly to the right and the AOR of its right front and right rear wheels were at approximately 26 ft. north and 23 ft. west and 18 ft. north and 19 ft. west of the
RP.
RiderInj: The 31 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related during the interview and on the medical report: multiple 4 in. lacerations to the right knee, right lower leg abrasions and contusions to the right side from the hip to the ankle.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to give MC1 the right of way and blocked MC1?s lane of travel. The rider of MC1 failed to react in time to prevent this accident.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 and unable to determine OV1?s crash causal status, unable to view OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: MC1 in #2 lane is riding with approximately 20 other scooters and is in the last position. OV1 is stopped ahead in the #2 lane. The other riders go around OV1. MC1 gains on OV1 faster than expected while conducting head check. Rider over-brakes and loses control, going down on left side plane, and then impacting OV1 to the left rear. There was no evidence of skids from braking avoidance by the rider. Rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway major arterial, involving an at-grade driveway type intersection. There are no signal control devices involved. The roadway has two through lanes in each direction and a two way left turn lane in the middle. The crash occurred on the approach to a signal controlled intersection; however, the intersection had no part in the crash. No on-street parking is allowed on either side of the roadway. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial businesses. Both roadsides have concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit is 35 mph. The roadway has a left curve for the rider?s direction of travel. The roadway has a +1.2% grade and a +6.3% crown. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a light wind from the west. MC1 was negotiating the left curve and preparing to pass OV1 who was stopped in her lane. There was no evidence of braking by either operator. The rider of MC1 was fully ejected before MC1 impacted the left rear bumper of OV1. The rider sustained moderate to serious injuries. There were no permanent or mobile visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in June of 2014 at 1225 hrs. The temperature was +71 degrees F. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. MC1 was retained by friends. OV1 was driven away.
MC1 was a 1987 Honda Helix 250 (244cc) scooter with modifications. The 37 year old female (5? 04?/120 lbs.) rider was wearing a full face helmet with integrated chin bar and clear face shield. The helmet had labeling indicating that it met FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell M2005 safety ratings. The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. The rider was wearing an armored leather protective jacket with the armor inserts removed, jeans, full fingered leather gloves, and tall boots that were not motorcycle oriented. None of the clothing was retro-reflective. The rider is required to wear prescription glasses while operating a motor vehicle. She was wearing prescription sunglasses with a gray tint.
