The rider stated that she was part of a club
 
ride involving approximately 20 other riders. One of the riders had run out of gas and they had just been stopped in a nearby parking lot about 2 blocks south of the crash.	The rider stated that she was in the ?sweep? position, which is to the rear of the pack. She stated that she was going between 20-30 mph when she saw all the other riders ahead of her going around OV1 which was either stopped or slowing. The rider stated that she made a head check to make sure the left lane was clear. When she looked forward again, OV1 was much closer than she anticipated. She over-braked and lost control. MC1 went down, low side first and slid into the left rear of OV1. The rider stated that as soon as MC1 went down, she pushed off of it and landed in the street. She had no idea where she was in relation to MC1 or OV1. The driver of OV1 stated that she recalled seeing the group of scooters exiting a driveway behind her as she approached the driveway of a restaurant that was going to. The drive-thru traffic was backed out into the street. The driver stated that she had been stopped for approximately 30 seconds when she felt something (MC1) impact her vehicle. She exited her car and found the rider lying in the roadway and MC1 under her car. There was no evidence of skidding on the roadway or on the tires of MC1. MC1 had been routinely serviced the week before and no problems were discovered. The rider stated that she only checked the air pressure in her tires today. MC1 sustained minor damage and was left in the possession of one of the riders in the group. OV1 was driven from the scene.
RiderInj: The 37 year old female operator of MC1 sustained moderate to major injuries listed pneumothorax to the left lung, fractures to her left clavicle, scapula and tibia. She also sustained a contusion to her front left shoulder area and an abrasion to her left knee. She was admitted to a local hospital for seven days. She displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. She displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit her ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a reaction failure in over-braking and losing control while conducting collision avoidance maneuvers. The rider has never taken any formal training and was not licensed for motorcycles.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained mostly minor cosmetic damage. The front sustained the worst damage from impacting OV1. The front fairing area was broken. The scooter was still ridable. Most of the damage appeared to be cosmetic in nature, involving the plastic body components. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.
OV1 sustained minor damage to the left rear bumper and was driven away.
Environmental: There are no environmental factors that are considered to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Fixed Object (Roadway)
Crash:
This single vehicle motorcycle crash occurred in June 2014 at 1655 hours in Southern California.	It was daylight, partly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 60 degrees F and the winds were light out of the SW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was moderate traffic.

The crash occurred on a right hand curved divided roadway. The north/south aligned roadway is divided by a 14 ft. wide, exposed dirt center median with 8 in. raised concrete curbs.	There are 2 lanes in each direction, the speed limit of 35 mph and the grade is a northbound grade of +4.6 % and a crown of +4.2 %. The curve is 1069 ft. in length with a radius of 782 ft. and a superelevation of -9.0%.
MC1 is a 2012 Yamaha YZF-R6 (599cc) motorcycle ridden by a 27 year old male (6 ft. and 175 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make and model motorcycle helmet.	MC1 was traveling northbound, negotiating a right hand curve, in the #1 lane at approximately 60 mph.	The rider failed to negotiate the curve and struck the center divider, Point of Impact (POI) #1 MC1 continued along the curb face before falling on its left side in the center
median, POI #2.		It then slid until striking a round u-shaped 4 in. high hay bag used for drainage control, POI #3 MC1 then tumbled and slid to its Final Rest Position (FRP).	The rider?s FRP is unknown.	The measurements were taken using an east/west station-line with a fire hydrant as the Reference Point (RP).	The RP was approximately 485 ft. north of the north curb line of the east/west roadway and approximately 7 ft. east of the east curb line of the north/south
roadway.	POI #1 was approximately 38 ft. west and 4 ft. south of the RP.	POI #2 was approximately 38 ft. west of the RP.	POI #3 was approximately 49 ft. west and 35 ft. north of the RP.	MC1 came to rest on its right side facing east with its front wheel approximately 39 ft. west and 111 ft. north of the RP and the rear wheel approximately 43 ft. west and 110 ft. north of the RP.
RiderInj: The 27 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: abrasions to the right wrist and left knee.	He also had a complaint of pain to the left ankle. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The rider of MC1 failed to negotiate the curve (reason unknown).
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. SUV
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in June 2014 at 1244 hours in Southern California.	There was bright sunlight with scattered clouds, the temperature was approximately 75 degrees F and the winds were approximately 7 mph out of the SW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was moderate traffic.

The crash occurred in a residential area, on a predominately east/west oriented roadway, at a T intersection. There are 2 lanes in each direction divided by a center turn lane. The outside lanes are 17 ft. wide and the inside lanes and center turn lane are 10 ft. wide. The eastbound grade is -1.3%, the crown is 6.3% and there are no traffic controls.	The north/south roadway is on the south side; it is undivided, with a 20 ft. lane in each direction and a stop sign with limit line for the northbound traffic.	All measurements were taken from the north/south curb prolongation of the east curb face and the east/west curb prolongation of the south curb face.
MC1 is a 2003 Harley Davidson FLST C/I (1449cc) cruiser style motorcycle ridden by a 25 year old male (5 ft. 10 in. and 150 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make and model of helmet. OV1 is a 2001 Chevrolet Suburban driven by a 41 year old female (5 ft. 5 in. and 130 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was eastbound in the #1 lane at approximately 40 mph approaching the intersection when the rider observed OV1 approaching westbound in the center turn lane.	OV1 started making a U-turn in front of MC1. The rider of MC1 applied the brakes hard, leaving 52 feet of skid and causing the rear end to wobble. MC1 crossed into the #2 lane but was unable to avoid OV1 as it crossed in front into the #1 lane. MC1 impacted with the right rear corner and right rear quarter of OV1. The area of impact was approximately 15 ft. north of the south curb and 66 ft. east of the east curb line.	The final rest positions are unknown.
RiderInj: The 25 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: abrasions to the left shoulder, elbow and knee. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to give MC1 the right of way and blocked MC1?s lane of travel. The rider of MC1 had insufficient time to react to prevent this accident.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 and unable to determine OV1?s crash causal status, unable to view OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: MC1 in #1 lane is following friends in OV1. All parties had been drinking. OV1 was coming to a stop for a signal that was phasing to red. The rider of MC1 noticed too late and was unable to attempt avoiding impacting the rear of OV1. No evidence of braking avoidance by the rider. Rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway major arterial, at an at-grade, four-way, not skewed intersection. The intersection is controlled by overhead signal control devices that were functioning properly. The roadway has three through lanes in each direction, and designated left and right turn only lanes. The roadway is divided by painted double yellow lines. The crash occurred on the approach to the intersection as the signal was phasing to red. No on-street parking is allowed on either side of the roadway. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial businesses on the rider?s right and apartments on the left. The roadway has a left curve on the approach to the intersection. The curvature has no causation involvement in the crash, as the roadway straightens prior to the intersection. Both roadsides have meandering concrete sidewalks and grass. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. The roadway has a -4.3% grade and a 2.7% crown. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the south-southwest. The roadway that the crash occurred on has an east/west designation. At the crash site, the roadway is in a southwest/northeast orientation. There was no evidence braking by either operator. The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and vaulted above ride height after impacting the right rear bumper of OV1. The rider landed in the middle of the intersection. The rider sustained moderate injuries. There were no permanent or mobile visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in June of 2014 at 1310 hrs. The temperature was +78 degrees F. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. Both vehicles were towed.

MC1 was a 2014 Harley Davidson Softail Breakout (1688cc) cruiser type motorcycle. The 22 year old male (5?11?/165 lbs.) rider was wearing unknown clothing and an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings. It is unknown if the helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. The rider was operating MC1 because the owner, who was a passenger in OV1, had too much alcohol to drink at lunch. Since the riding of MC1 was spontaneous on the part of the rider, and he does not own MC1, it is doubtful that any protective gear other than a helmet was worn. The rider had been drinking also, as had the
 
operator of OV1 and the other passenger. The rider had no license. Both vehicles had left a nearby restaurant/bar and were on their way to MC1 owner?s residence to drop of MC1.They had driven approximately 5 miles of the 8 mile trip when the crash occurred. The 21 year old male (5?11?/165 lbs.) operator of OV1was slowing/stopping for a red light when he was impacted in the right rear by MC1. He stated that he was ?not completely stopped? when the crash occurred and did not know his actual or estimated speed. The rider also did not know how fast he was going. Based on calculations of distance traveled post impact, MC1?s estimated speed at time of impact was 37 mph. As OV1 was stopping, the left handlebar impacted the right rear of the trunk lid, causing MC1 to turn into OV1. The foot peg and shifter impacted the lower portions of OV1, including the right rear tire/wheel, causing a chunk of the wheel to be broken off and a large slice in the tire, which caused a total loss of air pressure. OV1 sustained additional damage as MC1 side-slapped OV1 before going down on its
right side plane and sliding to a stop in the north end of the intersection. The rider had been removed from the scene by paramedics before the police arrived. The rider admitted to having consumed ?one? beer an hour and a half earlier while eating lunch with his friends. The rider has no license issued to him. The operator of OV1 has a license that is suspended/revoked for a prior DUI arrest. The operator of OV1 was given a field sobriety test and a portable alcohol screening device (PAS) test which produced results of 0.06% BAC. He was deemed not to be under the influence of alcohol. There was no evidence of skidding on the roadway or on the tires of either vehicle.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries listed as an open fracture to the left tibia and numerous abrasions. He was taken to a local hospital and treated. It is unknown if he was admitted, and if so, for how many days. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. He displayed signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to safely operate a motor vehicle. He was tested and released.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a perception failure in not realizing until too late that OV1 was stopping for the changing signal. The rider stated that he ?did not have time? to react. The rider has no license for any vehicle.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front end and both sides. The damage to the front suspension and left side were from impacting and side- slapping OV1. The damage on the right side was from sliding on the roadway surface. The pre-crash condition would be labeled near new.

OV1 sustained minor damage to the left rear trunk lid and bumper from the initial impact, and then additional damage along the right side as MC1 side- slapped OV1 before separating.
Environmental: There are no environmental factors that are considered to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. multiple fixed objects (raised concrete curb, sidewalk, grass ground cover and a tree), right center side impact crash event. MC1 struck a raised concrete curb and collapsed onto the concrete sidewalk. Both the rider and MC1 impacted with a tree. The motorcycle rider sustained fatal injuries as a result of this crash event. There were no passengers on the motorcycle.
MV1: 2002 Suzuki SV650 (conventional) motorcycle (645cc), black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. multiple fixed objects, right center impact crash event resulting in fatal injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Friday, June 2014 at 1732 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, with SSW wind conditions at 9.2 mph. The ambient temperature was +75.9 degrees F and sunset was at 2008 hours. Visibility was clear and unrestricted for 10.0 miles. The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. The rider was negotiating a left curve on an 8.5% downhill grade prior to crash event.
The collision occurred on a left curve portion of a multiple lane surface street with an approximate radius of 376 feet. The overall length of the curve in this area was 214 feet. The overall travel way width of the roadway is 67 feet. This is a north/south minor arterial street with two lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and two lanes for southbound traffic. The southbound portion of this roadway is uninvolved in the crash event. The roadway design is a ?left curve? with a 10 foot wide painted median (solid double yellow lines) separating the north and southbound lanes of traffic.
There are no bicycle lanes on either side of the roadway and parking is prohibited. The posted speed limit for both directions, through the curve is 25 mph. Other than the posted speed limit signs and the posted traffic advisory signs for the curve, there are no other regulatory traffic control devices in the area. Both the east and west sides of this roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs,	and sidewalks east side of the street has a commercial building and the west side of the street has single family residential homes above on an elevated slope.

MC1 was a 2002 Suzuki SV650 (conventional style) motorcycle being operated by a 47 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a full face modular motorcycle helmet with a double ?D? ring nylon chinstrap which appeared to have a loose fit. The helmet was equipped with a face shield the helmet sustained only minor surface abrasions. The helmet was not on the rider at the when several persons ran to render aid. The helmet had apparently come off the rider during the crash event. The helmet was not available for inspection, information taken from police report.
The rider was traveling northbound in the #2 lane prior to the crash. There was no evidence of any pre-impact skid marks leading up to the point where the front tire of MC1 struck the curb face along the east side of the roadway. MC1 continued northbound along curb line for about 13 feet before jumping the curb
 
onto the concrete sidewalk.	MC1 collapsed onto the sidewalk right side down sliding a distance of about 50 feet until it slid the last 15 feet across a grass top soil parkway. MC1 finally came to rest when striking a tree in the parkway. The rider was ejected onto the sidewalk area and rolled or tumbled until impacting with the same tree as MC1. The tree, a Eucalyptus, was approximately 15 feet in height with a diameter of about 12 inches. The rider came to rest in the same area as MC1 laying face up parallel with the position of MC1.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event. There were no apparent roadway design issues at or near the location of the crash site. The MCR had been moved from the grassy knoll (FRP) out to the concrete sidewalk area when several people responded to render first aid/CPR.
RiderInj: The rider sustained severe blunt force fatal injuries to the head. The injuries included were a lacerated brain stem and basal skull fracture as well as a lacerated liver. The Coroner?s toxicology report indicated that there was a postmortem brain blood alcohol level of 0.16 however, no presence of drugs.
Human: The 22 year old male rider of MC1 was driving at a speed unsafe for the portion of the roadway posted at 25 mph and failed to perceive the (left) curvature in the roadway causing the motorcycle to drift to the right striking the raised concrete curb.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate front and right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: MC1 is southbound in the #2 lane when OV1 enters the roadway from private property making a left turn across six lane of traffic. MC1 veers to the right, over brakes, and high sides on MC1?s left side plane. MC1 then impacts OV1 to right rear side. Rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway major arterial, at an at-grade, four-way, not skewed, driveway type intersection. There are no signal controls. The roadway has three through lanes in each direction, and designated left turn only lanes. The roadway is divided by a curb high center divider that is 4? wide. There are trees and bushes on the north side divider. The crash occurred just south of the intersection. No on-street parking is allowed on either side of the roadway. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial businesses. Both roadsides have 12? wide concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The roadway has a 6.7% crown and a -2.1% grade. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, has some surface cracking, but in otherwise good repair. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a light wind from the south. There was no evidence braking by OV1. MC1 left several feet of front wheel locked skid before high siding and impacting the roadway surface. The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and skid/slid to his FRP. The rider sustained minor injuries. There were no permanent or mobile visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in July of 2014 at 1307 hrs. The temperature was +80 degrees F. Traffic conditions were light to moderate.
Both vehicles were towed. 
MC1 was a 2005 Honda CBR 600 RR (599cc) sport/racing type motorcycle. The 19 year old male (6?00?/180 lbs.) rider was wearing a full face helmet with integral chin bar that had safety ratings for FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell 2010. The rider also wore an armored leather jacket, thin cotton pants, low top athletic shoes, and full fingered leather gloves. The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. The rider had been stopped at a red light a block away. When the light phased to green, he accelerated to approximately 50 mph. The rider was in the #2 lane ahead of all other traffic. The rider stated that he saw the OV exiting the east side driveway and crossing the lanes of traffic. The rider stated that once entering the roadway, the OV never stopped. The OV completed its left turn and was slowly proceeding southbound in the #1 lane. The rider saw the brake lights come on and the OV began changing lanes to
 
the right. The rider backed off on the throttle and changed lanes to the right. The OV then continued changing lanes to the right and was nearly perpendicular to the roadway and trying to enter another driveway on the west side of the roadway. The rider stated that he over-braked and lost control when the OV blocked his lane. The rider stated that he knew he locked the front brake and should have released it and re-applied it, but didn?t. He said that MC1 high sided and went down on its left side plane, then skidded/slid into OV1. The rider stated that he skidded across the roadway to about the middle of the driveway that the OV drove into and was near the lane line for the #3 and #2 lanes. The 19 year old male driver (5?08?/150 lbs.) of OV1 stated in the police accident report that he didn?t see MC1 because of the trees and bushes in the center divider. Visibility from the driveway that OV1 exited is partially obscured by the trees and bushes (photo 0352CS10); however, from the middle of the roadway and into the southbound lanes, they are not a factor. Based on calculations of distance traveled post impact, MC1?s estimated speed at time of impact was 33 mph. The impact of MC1 into OV1 caused the right rear tire of OV1 to lose all of its air pressure. Both vehicles were towed.
RiderInj: The 19 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries listed as a minor concussion, a laceration to the left knee, and multiple abrasions and contusions. He was taken to a local hospital and admitted for one day. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1.	The rider of MC1 had a reaction failure in over braking and losing control.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front end from impacting OV1 and moderate damage from sliding on its? left side plane. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good.
OV1 sustained minor damage to the right rear side. OV1 was not inspected.
Environmental: There are no environmental factors that are considered to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. multiple fixed objects (roadway shoulder, sign and asphalt roadway surface), left side impact crash event.	The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained fatal injuries as a result of multiple impacts with the environment, sign and roadway surface. There were no passengers on the motorcycle.
MV1: 2007 Ducati Sport Classic 1000 Mono SE (sport race replica) motorcycle (992cc), black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. multiple fixed objects, left side impact crash event resulting in fatal injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Sunday, July 2014 at 1112 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed scattered clouds, a SSW wind direction at 9.2 mph, and an ambient temperature of +77.0 degrees F. Sunset was at 2006 hours. The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. On the approach to the crash site there is a 950? left curve (834? radius of curve) for westbound traffic with a 4% uphill grade. At the crash site the roadway straightens out and the uphill grade reduces to 2.6% with a 2.5% crown.
The roadway is an east/west minor arterial in a rural portion of the county. There is one lane for eastbound traffic and one for westbound.	There are also marked bicycle lanes for both directions of travel. These lanes are of asphalt construction and are 8? wide. The east and westbound lanes are separated by one set of painted solid double yellow lane lines and other than the posted (55 mph) speed limit signs there are no regulatory traffic devices in the area.
Parking on both sides of the roadway is allowed.
The roadway environment is bordered on both sides by an 11 foot wide shoulder composed of soft dirt and gravel. There are also uphill embankments leading away from the shoulder areas that have low lying vegetation and trees. At the crash scene there is a 44? wide dirt construction forest service style road that is barricaded with a series of concrete K-Rails to prohibit any access into the wilderness area by vehicles.

MC1 was a 2007 Ducati Sport Classic 1000 Mono SE (sport race replica style) motorcycle being operated by a 28 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a full face DOT approved Bell ?Bullitt?	motorcycle helmet (white) with a double ?D? ring nylon chin strap (mfg. date: 1-2014). The helmet was equipped with a clear plastic face shield and weighed 56.44 ounces.
The rider was traveling westbound at a high rate of speed as he was coming into the uphill left curve. There was no evidence of any pre-impact skids until MC1 crossed over the westbound bicycle lane and left the asphalt portion of the roadway surface. The rider of MC1 continued in the dirt shoulder area paralleling the roadway for a distance of approximately 140 feet until it appears he lost control when the bike struck a shallow ditch. As MC1 collapsed onto the shoulder area the rider was ejected and continued westbound sliding and/or tumbling a distance striking a metal traffic post severing his left foot above the ankle. The rider continued on until coming to rest after traveling an approximate distance of 116? and slightly impacting a parked vehicle.
 
After collapsing onto the shoulder MC1 slid and/or tumbled across the roadway causing a fuel spill and eventually came to rest in the shoulder area adjacent to the east side of the roadway. MC1 had traveled a distance of approximately 185? from where it initially collapsed to its final resting place.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event. There were no apparent roadway design issues at or near the location of the crash site.
RiderInj: The 28 year old male rider of MC1 sustained multiple blunt force traumatic fatal injuries to the head and thoracic areas of the body.	The Coroner?s toxicology report indicated that there was a postmortem presence of cannabinoids in his system.
Human: The 28 year old male rider of MC1 was driving at a speed unsafe for the roadway design and failed to perceive the (left) curvature in the roadway causing the motorcycle to drift off the asphalt roadway surface onto a soft shoulder, losing control. The rider was licensed but not endorsed for the operation of motorcycles.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained major left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in July 2014 at approximately 2338 hours in Southern California.	It was dark with spot illumination.	The temperature was approximately 69 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was stopped traffic.

The crash occurred on a predominately north/south state highway in a commercial/small business area. The northbound roadway has 4 through lanes and a dedicated left turn lane; the southbound roadway has 4 through lanes divided by a 16ft. Wide raised concrete divider, planted with trees and shrubs. The speed limit is 45 mph. The northbound grade is -0.8 % and a crown 4.3%. The Reference Point (RP) is a fire hydrant, that is 3 ft. 10 in. east of the east curb-line of the north/s outh roadway and 323 ft. south of the south curb-line of the east/west roadway.
MC1 is a 2002 Honda VT1100C (1199cc) motorcycle ridden by a 36 year old male (6 ft. and 205 lbs.). The rider was wearing a DOT approved, HCI half helmet. The passenger seated behind the rider of MC1 is a 46 year old female, height and weight unknown, was wearing a DOT approved, Bilt Solar
modular helmet.	OV1 is a 1988 Ford F350 Custom Stake Body driven by a 56 year old male (5 ft. 3 in. and 128 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was northbound in the #3 lane stopped behind other vehicles, waiting for the traffic signal to phase green. OV1 was northbound in the #3 lane approaching MC1 from the rear at approximately 41 mph.	The signal phased green, the traffic ahead of MC1 began to move forward, the rider of MC1 began to release the clutch and was struck in the rear by OV1. The Point of Impact was approximately 31 ft. north and 25 ft. west of the RP, in the #3 lane. OV1 pushed MC1 onto its left side and remained entangled to their Final Rest Positions (FRPs). OV1 had overlapping front and rear, left and right wheel skids.	The left side skid marks were approximately 68 ft. in length, beginning approximately 12 ft. north and 25 ft. west of the RP and ending approximately 79 ft. north and 29 ft. west of the RP. The right side skid marks were approximately 61 ft. in length and began approximately 18 ft. north and 21 ft. west of the RP and ended approximately 81 ft. north and 24 ft. west of the RP. MC1 left approximately 63 ft. of gouges in the roadway beginning approximately 32 ft. north and 23 ft. west of the RP.
 
Both the rider and passenger of MC1 were ejected.	The FRP of the rider is unknown.  The passenger was located face up; her head and feet were positioned approximately 85 ft. and 91 ft. north respectively and both were approximately 34 ft. west of the RP in the #2 lane.

There was approximately 7 in. of crush to the front of OV1, where the front bumper was pushed back against the radiator by the rear fender of MC1. The sissy bar with passenger backrest attached to MC1 was bent backwards approximately 61 degrees from vertical.
RiderInj: The following injuries taken from the police report.	The 36 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained contusions to the left ankle, knee and flank. His Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. The 46 year-old female passenger of MC1 sustained multiple rib fractures, not further specified. Her Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 4.
ODriverInj: The 56 year-old male driver of OV1 sustained no injuries from the crash, but had a BAC of 0.24.
Human: The driver of OV1?s reaction failure due to impairment was the major factor of this crash. The driver of OV1 had a BAC of 0.24.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for crash involved vehicles.
Environmental: There were no crash causal factors relating to the environment.

CrashType: MC1 is westbound in the #2 lane at a high speed negotiating a left curve when the left footboard makes contact with the roadway surface and causes MC1 to lose control. MC1 goes down on its left side, impacting the roadway surface then the curb. MC1 slides to its FRP. The rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway major arterial, mid-block between a T-type intersection and a four-way signal controlled intersection. The roadway has three through lanes in each direction with a painted divider. There are trees and bushes on the north side of the roadway along with a narrow dirt path. The area beyond the pathway is below the roadway grade and has a bike trail through an urban wilderness area. On the south side of the roadway is a concrete sidewalk, trees and greenery, and single family residences. The crash occurred just west of a left curve. The length of curve was measured at 1250? and has a radius of 1667?. The roadway has a slight downgrade measured at -2.3% and a crown of 2.4%. The roadway has an east/west designation, however is in a southwest/northeast orientation at the crash site.	The posted speed limit is 55 mph. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the west. The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and skid/slid to his FRP. The rider sustained major to moderate injuries. There were no permanent or mobile visual obstructions that would be considered contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in July of 2014 at 1910 hrs. The temperature was +75 degrees F. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. MC1 towed.

MC1 was a 2007 Harley Davidson Ultra Classic-FLHTCU touring type motorcycle. The 59 year old male (6?00?/190 lbs.) rider was wearing a partial coverage half helmet that had safety ratings for FMVSS 218 (US DOT). The rider was wearing a tank top type T-shirt, jeans, work style boots, and thin full fingered leather gloves. The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. The rider had been stopped at a red light a block away. When the light phased to green, he accelerated to a stated 40-45 mph. The rider was in the #2 lane ahead of all other traffic. The rider stated that the rear end began to ?feel funny, unstable? and he felt as if he was starting to go into a high speed wobble. He stated that the unstable condition then progressively got worse and also affected the front end of MC1. He stated that the handlebars were violently turning from side to side, commonly referred to as a ?tank slapper.? The rider
 
stated that he had experienced a high speed wobble in the past on the same motorcycle and was able to remedy the situation by applying his brakes. He stated that he did apply both front and rear brakes, at which time he lost control and crashed. There were no pre-crash skid marks from MC1. When the crash scene was inspected, a gouge was located just prior to the out of control front tire marks in the roadway. After MC1 went down on its left side plane, it impacted the curb slid for approximately 431? to its FRP. Using a coefficient of friction of 0.5, this slide alone puts MC1?s speed at approximately 82 mph. This calculation does not take into account the bleeding off of speed caused by 3 gouges; the impact with the curb; the tire friction marks from the wobble; or any braking that the rider may have done. It appears that MC1 was taking the curve at a high speed and was into a low lean angle which caused the left side
footboard and mounting bracket to make a hard contact with the roadway surface and dig into the roadway. This is the First Harmful Event. This caused MC1 to start to go out of control.	MC1 left 2 front tire marks weaving from right to left in rapid succession, showing the unstable condition. The rider stated that he landed somewhere in the roadway, but had no idea where. He stated that his focus was to try and stop himself from impacting the curb.
RiderInj: The 59 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major to moderate injuries listed as a pneumothorax and contusion to his left lung, fractures to his left clavicle, left scapula, and fractures of ribs #2 though #8 on the left side. He also sustained a major abrasion to his left upper arm, and numerous other abrasions. He was taken to a local hospital and admitted for 11 days. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a comprehension failure in not realizing that his lean angle clearance was not sufficient.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate damage to the front end from impacting the curb and moderate damage from sliding on its? left side plane. The pre- crash condition would be labeled as like new.
Environmental: There are no environmental factors that are considered to be contributory to the crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) right front to left side injury crash event. The crash caused a secondary impact and subsequent third impact of the rider onto OV1 and collapsing onto the roadway surface causing serious injuries.
MV1: 2007 Harley Davidson FLSTC Heritage Soft Tail (1584cc), purple
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event. The collision occurred	on Saturday July 2014 at 1345 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1316 hours indicated there was haze, winds from the west at 8.1mph and, an ambient temperature of 75.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed for 6.0 miles in all directions. The motorcyclist was traveling on a two lane principal arterial roadway with grade of +0.3%. The roadway is of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit for north and southbound traffic is 50 mph.
The roadway has an overall travel way width of 37 feet. There is one lane dedicated for northbound traffic and one lane dedicated for southbound traffic and both are ten feet wide. The lanes are separated by a four foot wide painted median strip consisting of two sets of painted solid double yellow lines. There are designated safety lanes on both sides of the roadway.

The northbound lane is seven feet wide and the southbound lane is six feet wide. The roadway is bordered by concrete ?K-Rail? barriers on both the north and southbound sides. Along the northbound side there is an uphill slope or cliff leading to an area of single family residential homes. On the southbound side the concrete barriers separate the roadway from a north/south bicycle and pedestrian pathway and railroad easement. This pathway was not involved with the crash event. The scene of the crash was approximately .36 of a mile (1900 feet) south of the nearest signal controlled intersection and there were no traffic control devices or signs to regulate the flow of traffic in the area of the crash site other than posted speed limit signs.
MC1 was a 2007 Harley Davidson FLSTC cruiser style motorcycle being operated by a 67 year old male rider. MC1 was traveling southbound in the designated painted (solid double yellow lines) median separating both directions of travel.
OV1 was a 2005 Honda Odyssey (automobile) that was being operated by a 40 year old male. The driver was stopped southbound in the #1 lane.
The driver of OV1 was not familiar with the area and had decided to turn around by initiating a U-turn type movement from the southbound #1 lane into the northbound #1 lane. Southbound traffic was heavily congested and stopped at this time however northbound traffic was proceeding at or near the posted
 
50mph speed limit. OVD started his turn at an estimated speed of 8 mph, crossing over the painted median when his vehicle was struck by MC1 at the driver?s side front door.
The rider told officers during his interview that OV1 pulled in front of him so suddenly that he had insufficient time to stop or commit to any type of collision avoidance maneuver. The resulting impact caused the motorcycle to collapse onto the roadway surface, left side down. The rider was ejected off the front of the bike and onto the engine hood of OV1. The rider rolled off the front ofOV1 and collapsed onto the roadway surface with OV1 still moving forward. The rider was subsequently pinned under the front of OV1 and remained there until the arrival of emergency service personnel. He remained conscious during the accident investigation.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 67 year old male operator of MC1 sustained serious injuries as a result of the crash and was transported by ambulance from the scene to a local hospital for treatment. The injuries included but were not limited to multiple lacerations to the arms and hands, a fractured shoulder, ribs and pelvis, with possible injuries to the head and neck. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision.
Human:
The 67 year old male operator of MC1 was traveling outside the lanes of travel in a designated painted traffic median in an attempt to pass congested southbound traffic. The rider was in possession of a valid operator?s license with a motorcycle endorsement.
The operator of OV1 had recently moved to northern California and was unfamiliar with the area and traffic laws as they pertain to driving on divided roadways.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate front end damage and, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. OV1 sustained moderate left front damage and, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Fixed Object (Roadway)
MV1: 2005 Harley Davidson Screamin? Eagle FLHTCSE2 (1690cc) Cruiser motorcycle
Crash:
This single vehicle motorcycle crash occurred in July 2014 at 1740 hours in Southern California.	It was daylight, mostly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 85 degrees F and the winds were light out of the WSW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was no traffic.

The crash occurred southbound, on a left hand curved divided roadway.	The predominately north/south aligned roadway is divided by a 14 ft. wide center median with 8 in. raised concrete curbs and planted with trees and ground cover.	There are 3 travel lanes and a bike lane in each direction, the speed limit of 45 mph and the grade is a southbound grade of less than -0.4 % and a crown +0.8 %.	The curve is 840 ft. in length with a radius of 736 ft. measured from a 100 ft. chord with a 1 ft. 7 in. middle ordinate.
MC1 is a 2005 Harley Davidson Screamin? Eagle FLHTCSE2 (1690cc) Cruiser motorcycle ridden by a 57 year old male (6 ft. 8 in. and 260 lbs.) with a 52 year old female passenger of unknown height and weight. The rider and passenger were wearing unknown makes and models of motorcycle helmets.	MC1 was traveling southbound, negotiating a left hand curve, possibly in the #2 lane at approximately 60 mph.	The rider failed to negotiate the curve and lost control of MC1. MC1 went down with unknown dynamics and slid into the right curb leaving approximately 197 ft. of gouges.	MC1 continued south on the sidewalk for approximately 96 ft.	It then probably tumbled back into the #2 lane to its Final Rest Position (FRP) on its left side facing north.
Overall distance from initial laydown to FRP is approximately 320 ft. with a left offset of approximately 30 ft.	The FRPs of the rider and passenger is unknown.

The rider?s statement to police was that he couldn?t remember what caused the accident, but told the paramedics that he thought a vehicle cut him off. The passenger was unable to give a statement.
RiderInj:
The 57 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report:	numerous areas of abrasions on
his body. The 52 year-old female rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: numerous areas of abrasions on her body and a possible broken ankle/leg.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) for both the rider and passenger was 1. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The rider of MC1 failed to negotiate the curve (reason unknown).
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: MC1 is eastbound in the #1 lane negotiating a left curve approaching a ?T? type intersection. OV1 then pulls out from a side street on the right. The rider first swerves to the right to go behind OV1 at which time OV1 stops, blocking the #2 lane. MC1 swerves back to the left and OV1 accelerates. MC1 brakes hard and loses control, going down on its right side plane and impacting OV1 to the left rear side. Rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway major arterial, at a T-type intersection with no signal controls. There is not a posted stop sign for the side street. The word ?STOP? is painted on the roadway surface along with a limit line. The roadway has two through lanes and a dedicated right turn lane on the rider?s side of the road. There are some trees and bushes on the north side of the roadway along with a narrow dirt path. The area beyond the pathway is below the roadway grade and has a bike trail through an urban wilderness area. On the south side of the roadway is a 4? concrete sidewalk, trees and greenery, and single family residences. The crash occurred just east of a bridge and near the apex of a left curve. The length of curve was measured at 476? and has a radius of 1506?. The roadway is flat and level with a measured grade of +0.2% and a crown of 3.0%. The roadway has an east/west designation, but is in a southwest/northeast orientation at the crash site.	The posted speed limit is 55 mph. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. Visibility was clear at ground level. In the eastbound direction, the approach to the bridge is lower than the peak of the bridge,
which creates a permanent visual obstruction. The left curve in and of itself does not hinder visibility. The weather was clear with a light wind from the west- southwest. The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and skid/slid to his FRP. The rider sustained minor injuries. The left curve on the approach to the intersection is not a visual obstruction that is contributory to the crash. The crash occurred in Southern California in July of 2014 at 1525 hrs. The temperature was +84 degrees F. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. Both MC1 and OV1 were towed.

MC1 was a 2009 Yamaha V-Star Classic (649cc) cruising type motorcycle. The 22 year old male (6?00?/150 lbs.) rider stated he was wearing a full coverage open face helmet with a bubble style smoke/gray face shield that had safety ratings for FMVSS 218 (US DOT). The rider was wearing a thin cotton type T-shirt with a leather vest over it, jeans, high top style canvas tennis shoes, and no gloves. According to the rider, the helmet remained in place to the completion of
 
the crash events. The rider had been riding with a friend in a staggered formation. The rider was the lead MC in the #1 (left) lane. When the rider saw OV1 start to move from the stop sign and cross the eastbound lanes, he stated that he swerved to the right to go behind it. When he did so, OV1 stopped. The rider then swerved back to the left at which time OV1 accelerated. The rider stated that he applied both brakes, locking the rear. The rider stated that the rear of MC1 started to go sideways (CCW yaw) and then impacted OV1 ?straight on? while still in an upright position. The damage that MC1 sustained is inconsistent with his story. The evidence on the roadway shows what appears to be a long rear tire locked wheel skid in a straight line, followed by a short front tire skid that widens near the end, then gouges and scrapes prior to the reported impact area with OV1. MC1 shows evidence of scraping damage on the right side and vehicle impact damage on the left side. The driver of OV1 did not participate in an interview. She stated in the police report that she was stopped for the stop sign, looked both ways, and saw no traffic. OV1 was not inspected. The rider?s friend who was on a motorcycle was not involved in the crash.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions and contusions. He was taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 20 year old female operator of OV1 was not injured and dis not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit her ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a reaction failure in over-braking. The operator of OV1 had a perception failure.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor damage to the right side from sliding on the roadway and moderate damage on the left side from impacting OV1. The pre- crash condition would be labeled as very good.

OV1 is listed in police accident report as having sustained moderate damage and was towed from the scene. OV1 was not inspected.
Environmental: The below grade approach to the intersection is a permanent visual obstruction that is contributory to the crash. The left turn on the approach is very slight and creates no additional visual obstructions.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. an unknown make or model, other vehicle (OV1) only described as an older model blue sedan. This also included MC1 impacting with multiple fixed objects (asphalt roadway surface and roadway shoulder) collapsing left side down. The motorcycle rider was ejected off the bike and sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the crash event. There were no passengers on the motorcycle.
MV1: 2006 Harley Davidson FLHX Street Glide, (1442cc) black
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. multiple fixed objects, left side impact crash event resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Thursday, July 2014 at 0009 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, a SSW wind direction at 5.8 mph, and an ambient temperature of +72.0 degrees F. Sunset was at 1955 hours. The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. On the approach to the crash site there is a 700? left curve (626? radius of curve) for westbound traffic with a 4.6% uphill grade. At the crash site the roadway continues its left curve.
The roadway is an east/west minor arterial roadway in a rural portion of the county. There is one lane for eastbound traffic and one for westbound.	There are also marked bicycle lanes for both directions of travel. These lanes are of asphalt construction and are 8? wide. The east and westbound lanes are separated
by a ten foot wide painted median consisting of two sets of solid double yellow lines. The overall travel way width is 55 feet. On the south side of the roadway in the area preceding the crash site, there is a T-intersection. The intersecting north/south local street is 40 foot wide and is regulated by a posted ?Stop Sign? for northbound traffic approaching the intersection. Other than the stop sign and posted (55 mph) speed limit signs there are no other regulatory traffic devices in the area of the crash site. Parking on both sides of the roadway is allowed.
The roadway environment is bordered on both sides by a wide shoulder composed of soft dirt and gravel. There are also embankments leading away from the shoulder areas that have low lying surface vegetation and trees.

MC1 was a 2006 Harley Davidson FLHX Street Glide motorcycle being operated by a 65 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an unknown style motorcycle helmet.
The rider was traveling westbound approaching a T-intersection prior to the crash event.	There was no evidence of any pre-impact skids that either preceded the approach to or at the intersection.	The rider said he was being followed by an older model blue sedan (OV1) since he had left a freeway interchange. The rider went on to say that OV1 seemed like it was following him too close so he slowed down to indicate to the driver to get off his tail. The rider said he overheard the engine of OV1 ?rev up? and suddenly he was struck from behind causing him to lose control of his bike. OV1 continued westbound, passing both the rider and MC1 without stopping to render aid. Evidence of the motorcycle coming into contact with the roadway surface was approximately 372?3? feet beyond the intersection and confined mostly to the westbound lane of travel. As MC1 collapsed onto the roadway the rider was ejected and continued
 
westbound approximately 37?10? sliding and/or tumbling on to the west shoulder of the roadway. The motorcycle slid off the roadway onto the adjacent shoulder, across an asphalt driveway eventually coming to rest on a wooden log.
MC1 had traveled a distance of approximately 167?7? from where it initially collapsed on to the roadway to its final resting place off the west shoulder. There were no other pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event. There were no apparent roadway design issues at or near the location of the crash site.
RiderInj: The 65 year old male rider of MC1 sustained multiple non-life threatening injuries which included road rash to the left hand, left knee and right forearm, fractured ribs and a complaint of pain to the right shoulder. The rider was treated at the scene and removed by ambulance to a local hospital for treatment.
Human: The 65 year old male rider of MC1 was driving at a speed unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway (OV1) by slowing down and impeding OV1?s speed.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. SUV
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in August 2014 at 1057 hours in Southern California.	There was bright sunlight with clear skies, the temperature was approximately 77 degrees F and the winds were approximately 3.5 mph out of the WSW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was moderate traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial area, on a predominately north/south oriented roadway, passing an uninvolved T intersection on the right side of the roadway. There are four; 11 ft. wide lanes in each direction divided by an 8 in. raised concrete divider planted with ground cover, trees and shrubs and is 24 ft. wide at its widest point.	The southbound grade is -0.8%, the crown is 6.6% and there are no traffic controls.	All measurements were taken from the north/south curb prolongation of the west curb face and the east/west curb prolongation of the north curb face.
MC1 is a 2013 Yamaha Majesty 400 (395cc) step through scooter ridden by a 42 year old male (5 ft. 11 in. and 185 lbs.). The rider was wearing an HJC, CS-R2 full face helmet.	OV1 is a 2005 Land Rover Range Rover driven by a 41 year old male (5 ft. 11 in. and unknown weight).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was southbound in the #3 lane, behind OV1 at approximately 47 mph merging left into the #1 lane, with the expectation of entering the left turn pocket of an intersection ahead.	OV1 was southbound in the #3 lane, ahead of MC1 at approximately 40 mph merging left into the #1 lane.	The driver of OV1 stated that he didn?t see any other vehicles behind him in the #1 or 2 lanes as he started merging to the left and believes that MC1 was in his blind spot.	As MC1 merged from the #2 to the #1 lane, the rider looked over his left shoulder to make sure the lane was clear, as he looked back forward; he saw that he was rapidly overtaking a car that was merging into the #1 lane in front of him.	The rider over braked, causing MC1 to fall onto the roadway on its right side, in the #1 lane and sliding approximately 150 ft., to its Area of Rest (AOR).	OV1 pulled into a parking lot on the right side of the road.

The Area of Impact (AOI) for MC1 was approximately 35 ft. east of the west curb prolongation of the north/south roadway and approximately 10 ft. north of the
 
south curb prolongation of the east/west T intersection. The AOR of the rider was approximately 60 south and 8 ft. east of the AOI, and the AOR of MC1 was approximately 150 ft. south of the AOI. There was no contact with OV1.
RiderInj: The 42 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related during the interview and from the medical staff:	left wrist carpal fracture, a sprained right ankle, bilateral knee abrasions and right lower leg abrasions. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 5. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to perceive MC1, there was a possible blind spot issue.	The rider of MC1 the right of way and blocked MC1?s lane of travel. The rider of MC1?s lack of experience with hard braking was a factor in his losing control of MC1.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for this crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: Both MC1 and OV1 are eastbound in the #1 lane. MC1 attempts to pass heavy traffic by riding in the left double yellow lines. The driver of OV1 got distracted and when he looked forward, traffic was stopped. He braked and swerved left to avoid the vehicle in front of him and was impacted by MC1 who was passing on the left. Rider is fully ejected and sustains injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred mid-block on a non-freeway major arterial, between signal controlled intersections. The roadway has two through lanes in each direction with a painted divider. There is a dedicated left turn lane in each direction at the intersections. There is a 5? sidewalk on both sides of the roadway. There are some trees, grass, and bushes on the north side of the roadway. There is also a non-controlled driveway west of where the crash took place that allows entering/exiting to a commercial area. On the south side of the roadway are some trees and a construction fence where an industrial area is being renovated. The roadway is straight with a slight downgrade of -3.1% in the rider?s direction. The crown was measured at 3.2%.	The roadway has an east/west designation, however it is in a slight southwest/northeast orientation at the crash site.	The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, and has some surface cracking, but in otherwise good repair. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the southwest. The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and skid/slid to his FRP. The rider sustained minor injuries. The crash occurred in Southern California in August of 2014 at 1632 hrs. The temperature was +83 degrees F. Traffic conditions were to moderate to heavy. MC1 towed. OV1 was driven away.

MC1 was a 2004 Honda Shadow VT750C (745cc) cruising type motorcycle. The 40 year old male (5?08?/250 lbs.) rider was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings. It is unknown whether or not the rider was wearing any protective gear other than the helmet. It is unknown if the helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events.	Both the rider and OV1 were westbound in the #1 (left) lane. Traffic was moderate to heavy. The westbound left turn lane had filled up and traffic in the #1 lane had come to a stop. The 44 year old male (5?08?/195 lbs.) operator of OV1 was distracted by his children in the vehicle. He turned his head towards them. When he looked forward again, he saw that traffic in front of him had stopped. He braked and swerved left to avoid hitting the vehicle in front of him. As he did this, the rider of MC1 was passing on the left. He was riding on the double yellow painted
 
lines. MC1 impacted OV1 on the left front side and went down on its left side plane. Based on the damage that MC1 sustained, it appears that the rider of MC1 swerved left just prior to impact and side-slapped OV1. There was no front end damage to MC1. The damage on the right side starts at the foot rest, rear brake lever area that has transfer from the left front tire/wheel of OV1. MC1 then went down on its left side plane. The rider stated that he was passing traffic and saw the left turn signal blinking on OV1. He stated that OV1 made a left lane change in front of him into the center divider. In the police report, the sketch shows that the crash occurred in the wider area of the center divider. When measured, the crash actually took place in the area of the eastbound left turn lane, prior to the center divider. This is consistent with the statements given by the parties involved. No pre or post-impact tire marks were located when the scene was inspected. There were no visible scrapes or gouges either.
RiderInj: The 40 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of a minor laceration to his left knee and a complaint of pain to the same area. He refused any medical treatment at the scene. It is unknown if he went to a medical facility later. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 44 year old male operator of OV1 was not injured and did not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a decision failure in riding on the center divider lane lines passing on the left.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor damage to the right side from impacting OV1, and minor damage on the left side from landing on the roadway. The pre- crash condition would be labeled as fair to good
OV1 sustained minor damage to the left front. OV1 was not inspected.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) broadside type injury crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing minor injuries.
MV1: 2009 Buell Lightning XB 12SS (sport race replica) 1203cc, black
Crash:
This was OV1 vs. MC1 broadside type injury crash event. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight on Wednesday, August 2014 at 1920 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1949 hours. The weather report for 1956 hours indicated overcast skies, with WNW winds at 10.4 mph and, an ambient temperature of 68.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed for 8.0 miles in all directions. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? intersection of a principal arterial roadway with an overall travel-way width of 82 feet. On approach for both drivers the road has a left curve and runs east to west with three lanes dedicated for eastbound and three lanes dedicated for westbound traffic. There are designated left turn lanes to regulate both east and westbound traffic onto the intersecting street at this intersection. On the east side of the intersection the east and westbound lanes are separated by a 4 foot wide raised concrete median containing low lying surface vegetation. West of the intersection the east
& westbound lanes are separated by a 4 foot wide painted median consisting of two sets of solid double yellow lines. The 58 foot wide intersecting minor arterial street has two lanes for north and two lanes for southbound traffic. There are also designated left turn lanes at the intersection. This portion of the roadway was uninvolved in this crash event. The crash site was confined to the area of the intersection only.
The intersection is controlled in all four directions by posted multiphase traffic signals with leading left turn arrows.
The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2009 Buell Lightning XB 12SS motorcycle being operated by a 30 year old male rider.	The rider was traveling at a speed of about 35 mph eastbound splitting between the #1 & #2 lanes while approaching the intersection. Once the rider entered the intersection he increased his speed to 40 mph. Although
the rider claimed he had a green phase light, two independent witnesses who were looking at the same signal for eastbound traffic said the signal was in the red phase.
OV1 was a 2010 Ford Escape (SUV) automobile being operated by a 64 year old female. OV1was westbound in the designated left turn lane, and the driver had
 
initially stopped in first position at the intersection. Upon receiving a green arrow the driver of OV1 waited 1 to 2 seconds before proceeding into the intersection.	The driver used what she called ?normal? acceleration while making the left turn movement however, failed to notice the rider and motorcycle MC1 approaching. She said her view of the opposite side of the intersection was obscured due to the time of day (darkness) and the fact that she was facing five lanes of headlights shined in her direction.
When the rider approached the intersection he felt as though he did not have time to stop and made the decision to continue into the intersection. As he entered the intersection he saw the approach of OV1 and figured he had no time to brake so he decided to swerve to the right, around the front of the vehicle. The rider of MC1 could not negotiate his collision avoidance maneuver in time and was subsequently struck broadside on the left side (in front of his left foot) as the driver continued through the intersection.	The resulting impact caused MC1 to collapse onto the roadway surface, right side down and ejected the rider onto the roadway.
Both MC1 and the rider came to rest inside the intersection. The rider said he came to rest about 15 feet in front of his motorcycle, lying face up with his head facing east.
The driver of OV1 moved her vehicle out of the intersection and parked along the side of the roadway just outside the intersection. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, or animals that caused or contributed to the event
RiderInj: The 30 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were contusions to both knees and a broken left foot. The rider was treated at the scene and taken by ambulance to a local hospital where he was treated and released. There was no evidence of alcohol or drug intoxication.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries.	There was no evidence of alcohol or drug intoxication
Human: The rider of MC1 could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of OV1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major left side damage as a result of being struck by the front portion of OV1 however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained moderate front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in August 2014 at approximately 1855 hours in Southern California. It was daylight with clear skies, the temperature was approximately 74 degrees F and the winds were south at approximately 8 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred on a predominately north/south local roadway in a commercial/small business area. The roadway consists of one 25 ft. travel lane in each direction divided by a 13 ft. continuous left center turn lane.	The northbound grade is 4.2 % and a crown 1.1% and the speed limit is 40 mph. The Reference Point (RP) is a electrical/light pole; that is 2 ft. east of the east curb-line of the north/south roadway and 13 ft. north of the north edge of the involved driveway.
MC1 is a 1990 BMW K75S (740cc) motorcycle ridden by a 54 year old male (6 ft. and 220 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make/model helmet. OV1 is a 2008 Volkswagen Jetta 4 door sedan driven by a 22 year old male (5 ft. 10 in. and 175 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reportedly wearing the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was northbound behind another vehicle.	The vehicle ahead slowed, moved to the right and started making a right turn into the commercial driveway, blocking OV1?s view of MC1.	MC1 continued northbound passing the vehicle as it was making its right turn.	OV1 was westbound and waiting to make a left turn heading south from a commercial driveway.	The driver of OV1 observed the turning vehicle then proceeded to make his left turn across the northbound travel lane.	The rider of MC1 observed OV1 start to make his left turn, tried to swerve to the left in an attempt to avoid the collision but was struck on the right side by OV1 and was pushed into the center turn lane.	The driver of OV1 observed MC1 after starting his left turn but was unable to stop before striking MC1. The OV1 driver stated that he failed to yield the right-of-way to MC1 and was the cause of this collision.	The Area of Impact was approximately 35 ft. south and 18 ft. west of RP.	The Final Rest Position (FRP) of MC1 was approximately 27 ft. south and 40 ft. west of RP on its right side facing roughly north on the west
center turn lane line.	The rider was reported lying on the ground beside MC1, the exact FRP unknown.	The FRP of OV1 was approximately 39 ft. south and 26 ft. west of the RP in the center left turn lane facing west.
RiderInj: The 54 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the medical record:	dislocation of the left 4th and 5th metatarsal phalangeals, minor lacerations of the left knee and right toes and multiple abrasions to the body. The ISS score is 2.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to yield the right-of-way to MC1 and the rider of MC1 failed to perceive OV1.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for crash involved vehicles.
Environmental: OV1?s view of MC1 was obstructed by the vehicle turning right into the same driveway that OV1 was exiting.

CrashType: MC1 reaches the crest of an up-hill approaching a T intersection and is going between 80-100 mph. OV1 nearly completed its left turn when it is impacted by MC1 to the right rear side. The force spins OV1 CW 180 degrees and backwards into OV2 that is stopped at the stop sign. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a ?T? type intersection that is flat and level with no signal controls. The roadway is a non-freeway major arterial. The roadway has three through lanes in each direction. There are no bike lanes. The T intersection side street is on the riders? right and has a stop sign. The rider was southbound.
His approach has a curb high raised center divider with several trees and bushes which could be partially contributory to the crash. The distance from the POI to the lowest point in the sag of the roadway is approximately 958? and is not visible from the intersection. This portion of the roadway is the most contributory to the crash, especially when the speed of MC1 is taken into consideration. On the rider?s approach are single family residences to the right and multi-story apartments on the left. OV1 was going in the opposite direction and making a left turn from a dedicated left turn lane. OV1 also has a raised center divider, but it does not constitute any contribution to the crash. Both sides of the roadway are commercial businesses for OV1.	The roadway has a north/south designation and is in that orientation. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. There was no on-going construction in the immediate area of the crash. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the SSW. The temperature was +73 degrees F. The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and came to rest over 100? south of the POI. The rider sustained moderate injuries. The crash occurred in Southern California in August of 2014 at 1806 hrs. Traffic conditions were to moderate. MC1 and OV1 were towed. OV2 was driven away.

MC1 was a 2005 Honda CBR 1000RR (998cc) sport/racing type motorcycle with modifications. The rear sprocket had been changed to one with fewer teeth so
 
it would have a faster top end speed. The 42 year old male (6?02?/250 lbs.) rider was wearing a Shark full face helmet with a retractable chin bar and a clear face shield. The helmets safety rating is FVMSS 218 (DOT) only. The rider was also wearing a leather jacket, a removable padded spine protector, blue jeans, and slip on leather boots that go just above the ankle. He also had armored leather gloves. The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. MC1 was southbound in the #3 (right) lane. The distance from the lowest part of the sag in the roadway to the approximate middle of the intersection was measured at 958?. Vehicles in the intersection become visible to the rider at approximately 608?. The intersection comes into full view at approximately 458?. The rider stated that he was rapidly accelerating from the green light and was in 4th gear. He stated that he saw one vehicle make a left turn and then saw OV1 in the left turn lane slowing, when all of a sudden OV1 continued with its? left turn and he could not stop in time to avoid hitting it. The rider stated that he applied his brakes several times and skidded, so he released them and re-applied them. He said that he knew he couldn?t stop in time, so he tried to swerve left at the last minute, but impacted the right rear of OV1. The 25 year old female (5?05?/110 lbs.) driver of OV1 said she had entered the left turn lane as another vehicle was making its? turn ahead of her. She stated that she slowed and checked for on-coming traffic. She stated that she saw no vehicles and proceeded with her left turn, when all of a sudden she felt an impact and had no idea what hit her and caused her car to spin around. She stated that as her car was spinning, it impacted another vehicle (OV2) that was stopped at the stop sign. When she exited her car, she saw MC1 lying in the roadway. The72 year old male (6?00?/190 lbs.) driver of OV2 stated that he stopped for the stop sign, and then began inching forward so that he could make a left turn. He stated that he saw OV1 making its left turn, so he stopped again. He looked to his left and saw MC1 approaching fast. He saw the front end of MC1 dip down hard, indicating to him that the rider was braking. He also stated that he saw the rear tire of MC1 come up off the ground. He stated that MC1 impacted OV1 to the right rear side causing the car to spin and impact the front of his vehicle. He saw the rider get ejected and fly across OV1 and slid down the street. After impacting OV1, MC1 side slapped OV1 then went down on its? right side plane and slid to its FRP in the intersection. The rider was vaulted above ride height. While going over OV1, his right leg dragged across the right rear window frame which lacerated his skin in the area of his knee. Blood and flesh was located on this part of OV1. After landing on the ground, the rider skidded/slid to his FRP which was 110? south of the POI
RiderInj: The 42 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major and moderate injuries consisting of femur fracture, lacerations and abrasions. He was taken to a hospital where he was admitted for an unknown number of days. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The female operator of OV1 sustained a minor abrasion to her upper left chest area which was most likely caused by the seatbelt. She refused medical attention at the scene. She did not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit her ability to operate a motor vehicle. She submitted to a blood test which had negative results for alcohol/drugs. The passenger in the right front seat position sustained a minor abrasion to the right elbow and also refused medical attention at the scene.The driver of OV2 was not injured. He did not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle. He submitted to a blood test which had negative results for alcohol/drugs.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a decision failure in riding excessively fast on a public street.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage as a result of the high speed frontal impact. The forks were broken off at the frame head/yoke from being driven rearward into the radiator and engine area. The front rim had pieces missing and the tire was flat. The frame was fractured in several locations and had a complete loss of integrity. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as very good.

OV1 sustained major damage to the right-side-rear area. The impact broke the right rear axle, several windows, and caused the front and side air bags to deploy. The damage on OV1 from impacting OV2 consisted mostly of scratches across the rear bumper. The impact was more of a side-swipe type contact and was bumper to bumper. The pre-crash condition of OV1 would be labeled as new.

OV2 sustained minor damage that consisted of scrapes and paint transfer to the left-front-corner of the plastic bumper. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as near new.
Environmental: The blind crest is a permanent environmental factor that is considered contributory to this crash, primarily because of the speed that MC1 was traveling at. The trees and bushes are present in the center divider, but do not provide any contribution to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. multiple fixed objects (raised concrete curb, sidewalk and, utility light pole) right center side impact crash event. MC1 struck a raised concrete curb and collapsed onto the concrete sidewalk and impacted with a utility pole. Both the rider and MC1 impacted with the utility pole.
