The motorcycle rider sustained fatal injuries as a result of this crash event. There were no passengers on the motorcycle.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. multiple fixed objects, right center impact crash event resulting in fatal injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Monday, August 2014 at 2146 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 2158 hours showed partly cloudy skies, with WNW winds at 4.6 mph. The ambient temperature was +69.8 degrees F and sunset was at 1944 hours. Visibility was clear and unrestricted for 10.0 miles. The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred on the northbound portion of a straight and level principal arterial roadway with a travel way width with of 59 feet. This is a north/south principal arterial roadway with four lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and four lanes for southbound traffic. The southbound portion of this roadway is uninvolved in the crash event. The north and southbound lanes are separated by a 14 foot wide raised concrete median containing low lying surface vegetation.
There are no bicycle lanes on either side of the roadway and parking is prohibited. The posted speed limit for both directions is 45 mph.
On both sides of the roadway there are retail & commercial businesses. Both the east and west sides of this roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks. There is a four way intersection north of the crash site that is regulated by electronic signal controls however it is not involved with this crash event.
The utility pole that was damaged was an Ameron style, 31 foot tall tapered spun-cast concrete pole weighing 1,700 lbs. The diameter of the pole (at the base) is 10 5/16 inches using four 1? x 36? anchor bolts. (spec. sheet attached). The shear strength at the base is 11,000 to 14,000 PSI.

MC1 was a 2009 Suzuki GSX-R600 (sport race replica style) motorcycle being operated by a 29 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a full face FMVSS218 (US DOT) approved motorcycle helmet with a double ?D? ring nylon chin strap and adjustable chin bar, (mfg. date: 12-2013). The adjustable chin bar had been separated from the body of the helmet along with the clear plastic face shield. The helmet weighed 54.5 ounces
The rider was traveling northbound with another rider in the #2 northbound lane prior to the crash event.	Both the rider and his partner had stopped for a red light one block south of what would be the crash scene.
When they received a green light both the rider and his partner both took off at a high rate of speed. Both riders initiated a ?wheelie? through the intersection
 
with the rider pulling well ahead of his partner. During the riders ?wheelie? he dropped the front wheel back down on to the street and lost control going into a high speed wobble drifting across the roadway into the northbound #4 lane. There was no evidence of any pre-impact skid marks leading up to the point where the front tire of MC1 struck the curb face along the east side of the roadway. MC1 continued northbound along curb line for about 24 feet before jumping the curb on to the concrete sidewalk.	MC1 travelled across the sidewalk a distance of about 7 feet until it impacted head-on into a concrete utility light pole. The impact sheared the front tire and forks from MC1 sending them into the northbound left turn lane adjacent to a raised concrete center median. After impacting (and shearing) the pole MC1 continued sliding approximately 137 feet into the signal controlled intersection north of the crash site. The rider was ejected into the pole and onto the concrete sidewalk.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event. There were no apparent roadway design issues at or near the location of the crash site.
RiderInj: The 29 year old male rider of MC1 sustained extreme multiple blunt force traumatic fatal injuries of the head and thoracic areas of the body. The Coroner?s toxicology report indicated that there was a postmortem presence of ethanol (.0023-.003) Phenethylamines, amphetamine and, methamphetamine in his system.
Human: The 29 year old male rider of MC1 was driving at a speed unsafe for the portion of the roadway while attempting a ?wheelie? subsequently lost control and went into a high speed wobble with his motorcycle.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained total damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: MC1 is weaving around traffic while passing other vehicles, using all lanes including the center two-way left turn lane. OV1 entered the roadway from a parking lot attempting to make a left turn before MC1 became visible. Upon seeing MC1, OV1 stopped in traffic blocking both lanes. MC1 attempted collision avoidance by braking and swerving. MC1 had a left frontal impact with OV1 to the left side. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred between two signal controlled intersections, at the intersection of a driveway. The roadway is a non-freeway major arterial. The roadway has two through lanes in each direction with a two-way left turn lane. There is a dedicated left turn lane at each of the intersections for the rider?s direction of travel. There is a 12? sidewalk on both sides of the roadway. There are some large trees on the rider?s right which did not block his view of the roadway or OV1. There is a second driveway for the same parking lot that OV1 exiting. It is located to the left (south) of OV1. There was a vehicle exiting from that driveway which is the one that MC1 went around the rear of in the middle of the roadway. Both sides of the roadway are commercial/retail. The roadway is straight with a slight upgrade of +1.8% in the rider?s direction. The crown was measured at 4.7%. The roadway has a north/south designation and is in that orientation at
the crash site. The posted speed limit is 35 mph. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, and has some surface cracking but in otherwise good repair. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the west. The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and landed within 6? of the POI. The rider sustained minor injuries.	The crash occurred in Southern California in August of 2014 at 1120 hrs. The temperature was +80 degrees F. Traffic conditions were to moderate to heavy. MC1 was towed. OV1 was driven away.

MC1 was a 2011 Suzuki DRZ 400S (398cc) dual sport type motorcycle. The 19 year old male (5?03?/145 lbs.) rider stated that he was wearing a Fly full face helmet with no face shield. He had non-prescription goggles with clear lenses. The helmet?s safety ratings and any damage is unknown. The rider stated that he was wearing an armored jacket, jeans, military style boots, and armored leather gloves. The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash
 
events.	MC1 was northbound from a signal that had just phased to green. He was in the #1 (left) lane and had just passed on the left the lead vehicle ahead of him by going into the two-way left turn lane. There was another vehicle that had just exited the south driveway of a parking lot, north of the intersection that was making a left turn. There are discrepancies in the police report as to whether MC1 went behind or in front of this vehicle. According to the driver of OV1, MC1 went to the rear of that vehicle. In doing this, MC1 wound up in the northbound #2 (right) lane. It was when MC1 was passing the vehicle making the left turn out of the driveway that the driver of OV1 first saw MC1. The driver of OV1 said that MC1 was going so fast he didn?t know what to do. He stopped, blocking both northbound lanes. The driver of OV1 stated that he knew MC1 was going to crash into him, so he turned his head away from the windows. He then felt and heard MC1 impact his vehicle. The driver of OV1 stated that he thought that MC1 might have tried to make a right turn into the same driveway that he had just exited in an attempt to avoid the crash. The driver of OV1 stated that he had open road ahead that would have made it possible to complete his left turn and
not block the roadway. The rider of MC1 stated that he remembered that OV1 pulled out in front of him and that he braked hard to avoid crashing. He stated that he locked up his brake and released it, then re-applied it. He stated that he thought he might have tried to turn into the driveway that the OV came out of because braking wasn?t slowing him down enough, but wasn?t sure. MC1 sustained no reduction in wheelbase. The roadway south of the signal that MC1 had been stopped at has a right curve that ends at the signal. There were no visible tire marks from either vehicle at the crash scene. Only a few minor scrapes on the roadway surface were located at MC1?s FRP. MC1?s FRP was in the northbound #2 lane, approximately at the mid-point of the driveway. Based on the damage to OV1, it does appear that MC1 was attempting a right turn and that the impact angle was less than 90 degrees. The front tire of MC1 was found flat. There were no obvious causes found as to why there was no air pressure. The rear tire air pressure was between 16% and 39% below recommended levels.
The rear tire mark from MC1 was not visible at the time the scene was inspected. Based on the police report measurements for the fluid spill, it appears that MC1 fell over onto its right side plane after impact. MC1 was moved prior to the arrival of the police, so its orientation at its FRP is not known.
RiderInj: The 19 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of a minor laceration to his right knee, an abrasion to his right elbow, and a decreased level of consciousness. When the rider was interviewed, he stated he had very limited memory of the crash and was suffering from short term memory loss. He was taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 83 year old male operator of OV1 was not injured and did not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a decision failure in weaving through traffic and passing other vehicles at a high rate of speed as compared to the rest of the traffic.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate damage to the left side from impacting OV1 then the roadway surface. The left side of the handlebar was broken off. The transmission case had a hole punched into it from the shifter. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.

OV1 sustained moderate damage to the left side, mostly in the area of left rear door, but extends from the left front door rearward to the left rear wheel.
 
Damage was also located below the body on the frame.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) rear-end type injury traffic collision, causing non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider.
MV1: 2013 Yamaha YZF R1 (sport race replica) 998cc, silver in color
OV1: 2007 Chevrolet Avalanche (Sport activity vehicle), blue in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) rear end type injury traffic collision occurring on Tuesday, 08/2013 at 0655 hours in Southern California. The weather report for this region showed clear skies, with calm winds out	and, an ambient temperature of 66.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface was level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred west of a four way multi-phase signal controlled intersection on a straight, multiple lane major arterial. The street has an overall travel-way width of 95 feet. There are a total of six lanes dedicated for vehicular traffic; three for eastbound and three for westbound traffic. The east and westbound lanes of traffic are separated by a raised concrete median that is approximately 4 feet in width from the intersection and extends for 175 until it
expands to 14 feet in width over an additional distance of 165 feet. The remainder of the street is separated by a 14 foot wide two-way left turn lane.	There are two designated left turn lanes for east to northbound traffic.

Environmental and Crash Specifics (continued):
The north side of the street and east side of the signal controlled intersection are uninvolved with this crash event. There are also no designated ?Bike Lanes? on the north and south side of the roadway.

The roadway in the area of the crash site is straight with a slight uphill grade of 1.1%. The crown affecting the eastbound lanes of traffic is 2.0%. There is a posted speed limit of 45 mph for both directions of travel. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.
The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2013 Yamaha YZF R1 (sport race replica) style motorcycle (silver) being operated by a 25 year old male. The rider was wearing a DOT approved Shoei RF1100 full face motorcycle helmet. Prior to the interview the rider claimed he had since disposed of the helmet soon after the crash.
 
OV1 was a 2007 Chevrolet Avalanche (sport activity vehicle) being operated by a 28 year old female with no passengers on board. OVD was returning home travelling eastbound in the #1 lane approaching the intersection intending to enter the #2 left turn lane to proceed northbound on the cross street. Her speed on approach was about 30mph.
MCR was also traveling eastbound in the designated #1 lane of the multi-lane surface street approaching the intersection. The rider had been traveling at an approximate speed of 45 mph and was closing on OV1.
The driver of OV1 started to move her vehicle from the #1 eastbound lane into the	#2 left turn lane. Her speed was still 30 mph however she began to reduce her speed because the signal light ahead at the intersection was in the red phase.
The MCR at first intended to pass OV1 by entering the 14 foot wide two-way left turn lane. He felt that his approach speed to OV1 was too fast (45mph vs 30mph). MCR suddenly realized that the two-way left turn lane terminate at the raised concrete median so he swerved back into the #1 eastbound lane. It had been his intention to also enter the left turn lane however, once he positioned himself back into the #1 lane he was once again closing on OV1 at a higher rate of speed and, OV1 was beginning to slow down.
MCR attempted to avoid colliding with OV1 by briefly applying his brakes and swerving to the left. The riders closing speed was too fast and the right front portion of his motorcycle impacted with the left rear corner of OV1.
The resulting impact caused MC1 to collapse left side down on to the roadway surface and ejected the rider. MC1 slid about 70 feet until coming to rest against the raised center median, facing north. The rider (MCR) rolled and/or tumbled for a distance of about 55 feet from the initial area of impact.
MC1 sustained moderate right front and left side damage to the bumper and fairing as well as scraping along the left side from striking the roadway surface. OV1 sustained minor damage to the rear bumper and left rear quarter panel.
While inspecting the crash scene I located what appeared to be a rear tire scuff about 6 feet in length running parallel to the lanes of travel and lined up just inside the left turn lane area. I also located two scuff marks that appeared to be from the riders clothing. These scuff marks also ran parallel to the lanes of travel and were inside the left turn lane area. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 25 year old rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were abrasions too both arms and legs. He was treated and released at the scene. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries.
Human:
The 25 year old rider of MC1 was travelling at an unsafe speed for the present traffic on the roadway. He further complicated his situation by attempting to maintain his high rate of speed by entering the two-way left turn lane with the intention of passing OV1.
The 28 year old female driver of OV1 had made a reasonably safe lane change to the left without anticipating the presence of a motorcycle coming up from behind her at a high rate of speed.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate right front and left side damage as a result of this crash event however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
OV1 sustained minor left rear damage however, appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition and, was in fact driven home by the OVD.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1), front to right side injury crash event with a low side left lay down impact of the motorcycle on to the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected and sustained minor injuries as a result of impacting the roadway. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2014 Harley Davidson XL883N Sportster (conventional style) motorcycle, red
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event resulting in minor injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Friday, August 2014 at 1826 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, a South wind direction @ 6.9 mph, and an ambient temperature of +80.2 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be sharp, polished and in satisfactory condition. There was a 2.5% uphill grade and 0.4% crown in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred in the southbound #1 lane of a straight six lane principal arterial state highway with and overall travel way width of 102 feet. The north and southbound lanes are divided by a 4 foot wide raised concrete median with no median barrier or fence. There is a 6 foot wide bike lane along the east side and west side of the roadway however the northbound portion of the roadway is not involved with this crash event.
The posted speed limit is 45 mph for both north and southbound traffic. There is a four way signal controlled intersection approximately 200 feet south of the crash site. The intersection was not part of the crash event.

MC1 was a 2014 Harley Davidson XL883N Sportster conventional style motorcycle. MC1 was being operated by a 61 year old male. The rider was traveling southbound in the #1 lane at a speed of about 15 mph prior to the crash event. As the rider was approaching the intersection OV1 moved from a stopped position from the adjacent left turn lane entering the #1 southbound lane directly in front of MC1.	The rider was in such proximity to OV1 that he had insufficient time to stop or commit to any type of collision avoidance maneuver.
OV1 was a 2001 Honda Accord 4 door automobile being operated by a 29 year old male. The driver said prior to moving his vehicle into the southbound #1 lane, he looked over his right shoulder and believed it to be clear of any vehicles. The driver said that as he moved his vehicle into the lane he felt an impact toward the rear of his vehicle, having not seen MC1 on its approach.
MC1 had impacted the roadway surface left side down causing minor damage to the gas tank and components.	The rider was ejected off the bike impacting the roadway surface and came to rest in an area near the area of impact.
RiderInj: The 61 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of impacting the roadway surface. The injuries included an bilateral abrasions to both arms, elbows and knees. The rider was wearing an unknown make/model motorcycle style helmet. The rider was transported to a local area hospital for treatment and released later the same day. There was no evidence of alcohol or drugs present in his system.
Human: The 61 year old rider of MC1 appears to have been operating his motorcycle in a safe manner and, was simply slowing fo traffic in the area. The driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision in moving his vehicle into the adjacent lane in front of MC1.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor left side damage as a result of the crash however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 sustained minor damage in the area of the right rear quarter panel as a result of this crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. SUV
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in August 2014 at 1638 hours in Southern California. There was bright sunlight with scattered clouds, the temperature was approximately 82 degrees F and the winds were light and variable. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn and there was heavy traffic.

The crash occurred in a residential area on a predominately east/west oriented roadway at a 4 way intersection. Eastbound, there is a 10 ft. wide ?protected/permissive? left turn lane and 2 through lanes.	On the westbound side there is a ?protected/permissive? left turn lane and 3 through lanes. The left turn and the #2 lane are both 10 ft. wide and the #1 and #3 lanes are 12 ft. wide. The westbound grade is 0.8% and the crown is 2.1%. The north side of the north/south roadway, there is a 10 ft. wide left turn lane and a 19 ft. wide travel lane in each direction. The south side is uninvolved in this accident.

All measurements were taken using a south running station line with the Reference Point (RP) being a fire hydrant that is 2 ft. west of the west curb of the north/south curb prolongation and 35 ft. 4 in. north of the north curb of the east/west curb prolongation.

MC1 is a 2009 Suzuki GSXR-750 (750cc) cruiser style motorcycle ridden by a 28 year old male (5 ft. 8 in. and 200 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make and model of helmet. OV1 is a 1997 GMC Yukon driven by a 50 year old male (5 ft. 5 in. and 150 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was westbound in the #3 lane at approximately 35 mph approaching the intersection with a green circular traffic signal.	OV1 was eastbound in the left turn lane, stopped in the intersection, partially across the limit line, waiting to make a left turn with a green circular traffic signal.	The rider observed that traffic in the #1 and 2 lanes was backing up but there was no traffic ahead of him in the #3 lane.	The driver observed westbound traffic in the #1 and 2 lanes slowing as it approached the intersection and believed that traffic was slowing to allow him to make his left turn.	MC1 continued forward into the intersection and observed OV1 approaching the left side of MC1 with insufficient time to take evasive action.	OV1 started his left turn as MC1 entered the
 
intersection and stated he was unable to stop before striking MC1.	MC1 and the rider were struck on the left side by OV1 which continued north after completing the left turn.	MC1 pivoted counter clockwise and struck the roadway on its right side POI #2 and MC1 and the rider slid across the intersection in a north/west direction and impacted the traffic signal pole POI #3 where MC1 separated from the rider and continued north/west to its Final Rest Position (FRP).

Point of Impact #1 (POI #1) OV1 into MC1 was approximately 43 ft. south and 26 ft. east of RP.	POI #2, MC1/rider striking the roadway was approximately 42 ft. south and 16 ft. west of RP.	POI #3 and the rider?s FRP, MC1/rider striking the traffic signal pole was approximately 35 ft. south and 27 ft. west of RP. The FRP of MC1 was approximately 26 ft. south and 29 ft. west of RP.
RiderInj: The 28 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the medical report:	grade 3 laceration of the spleen, small left pneumothorax, multiple left posterior rib fractures, left L1 fracture, left closed proximal fibula fracture and a left outer leg abrasion. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 17. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to give MC1 the right of way. The rider of MC1 failed to comprehend the actions of the surrounding traffic and OV1.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 and unable to determine OV1?s crash causal status, unable to view OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: MC1 reaches the crest of an up-hill left curve when he noticed that traffic ahead was stopped and back-up for the signal. The rider over braked, locking the rear wheel, causing MC1 to go into a CCW rotation until MC1 high-sided onto its right side plane. MC1 then skidded/slid to its FRP where it impacted OV1. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
OV1: 2002 GMC 3500 tow-truck towing a 2009 Mercedes Benz C300
Crash:
This crash occurred between two signal controlled intersections, near a ?T? type intersection with no signal controls. The roadway is a non-freeway major arterial. The roadway has two through lanes in each direction with bike lanes. In the rider?s direction, there is a right turn only lane for the T intersection, which is a one-way street at the entrance. The roadway has a curb high raised center divider with several trees and bushes. The roadway surface had recently been completely re-done with new asphalt. Some, but not all, lane markings were in place. The two through lanes were separated by temporary plastic tabs that were imbedded in the asphalt. The approach to the crash site is a 7% up-grade with a left curve. After the crest, the roadway is a 7% down-grade and still has a left curve as it approaches a four-way, signal controlled intersection. Traffic was stopped for the red signal. Both sides of the roadway are commercial/retail. The roadway has a north/south designation; however, it is in an east/west orientation at the crash site. The posted speed limit is 35 mph.
The roadway is made of asphalt composition, and is newly paved. There was no on-going construction in the immediate area of the crash. Visibility was clear
at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the WSW. The temperature was +79 degrees F.	The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and came to rest on the far right side of the roadway. The rider sustained minor injuries.	The crash occurred in Southern California in September of 2014 at 1603 hrs. Traffic conditions were to moderate to heavy. MC1 towed. OV1 was driven away.

MC1 was a 2009 Yamaha Raider S (1854cc) cruiser type motorcycle with modifications. The 32 year old male (6?09?/240 lbs.) rider was wearing a Bilt full face helmet with a retractable chin bar and a clear face shield. He had non-prescription sun glasses with clear gray/smoke lenses. The helmets safety rating is FVMSS 218 (DOT) only. The rider stated that he was wearing a light t-shirt, thin cotton shorts, low cut athletic shoes, and armored leather gloves. The helmet
 
remained in place to the completion of the crash events.	MC1 was southbound in the #1 (left) lane. He stated that he was going between 45-50 mph. He stated that he was going up-hill in a left curve and could not see that traffic was stopped ahead of him. He stated that it wasn?t until he crested the hill and began going down-hill that he noticed that traffic was stopped for a signal up ahead. He braked hard and locked up the rear tire. The rear end of MC1 began to slowly slide out to the front in a CCW rotation until the bike flipped forward. He was fully ejected and skidded/slid to the right curb. MC1 continued in a straight path towards the stopped traffic. MC1 came to rest after impacting the left-front-center of a vehicle that was being towed by OV1. The 34 year old male (5?09?/185 lbs.) operator of OV1 stated that he was southbound in the #1 lane, stopped for a red light. He said that he was about the seventh vehicle back from the limit line. He stated that he felt a light ?bump? to the rear. He said he saw some handlebars in his left side mirror. He said he could see the rider out his right side window, which was lying in the gutter area. When MC1 was inspected, the skid patch on the rear tire was barely visible due to MC1 having been moved several times after the crash. The front tire air pressure was measured to be in the 16%-39% below recommended range. At 30 psi, it is in the lower percentage area and not considered a contributing factor to the crash. There was a fuel leak at MC1?s FRP. The gas was able to leak out of the gas cap/filler area due to a loose fitting press fit cap. MC1 was high-sided on its right side with the gas tank in a downhill position from the rest of the bike. There was little fire danger.
RiderInj: The 32 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of numerous abrasions to his arms, legs, and torso. He refused medical treatment at the scene and stated that he never sought any medical attention later. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 38 year old male operator of OV1 was not injured and did not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a reaction failure in over braking which caused him to lose control.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor damage to the right side from impacting and sliding on the roadway surface. The damage consisted mostly of scratches and scrapes. The most significant damage was to the gas tank, which was dented and scratched by the roadway. The impact with OV1 was very slight and no damage on MC1 could be specifically attributed to it. The right mirror was broken off. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.

OV1 sustained very minor damage to the right-front-center in the lower bumper area. The damage consisted of denting/gouging to the plastic. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as near new.
Environmental: The curvature of the roadway combined with the blind crest, are permanent environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash. This is especially true when their effects are intensified by MC1 exceeding the speed limit.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1), crash event with a low side right lay down impact of the motorcycle on to the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected and sustained minor injuries as a result of impacting the roadway. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2005 Harley Davidson XL1200C (conventional style) motorcycle, red
OV1: 2013 Toyota Tacoma light utility pick-up truck, blue
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle crash event resulting in minor injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Monday, September 2014 at 1624 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed	mostly cloudy skies, a West wind direction of 9.2 mph, and an ambient temperature of +82.0 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be sharp, polished and in satisfactory condition. There was a +4.8% uphill grade and +5.3% crown in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred in the eastbound #1 lane of a right curve three lane principal (non-freeway) arterial roadway with and overall travel way width of 104 feet. The east and westbound lanes are divided by a 14 foot wide raised concrete median containing low lying surface vegetation and no median barrier or fence. There are 8 foot wide bike lanes along both the north and south side of the roadway however the westbound side of this roadway is uninvolved in this crash event. The posted speed limit is 45 mph for both east and westbound traffic.
There is a four way signal controlled intersection east of the crash site with designated left and right turn lanes on the approach. The intersection was not part of the crash event.

MC1 was a 2005 Harley Davidson Sportster XL1200C conventional style motorcycle.	MC1 was being operated by a 62 year old male. The rider was traveling eastbound in the #1 lane at a speed of about 35 mph prior to the crash event. As the rider was approaching the intersection when OV1, a blue Toyota Tacoma light utility pick-up truck made a sudden lane change while both vehicles were adjacent to each other. The OVD had been in the eastbound #2 lane and was unfamiliar with the area. It was his intent to move his vehicle from the eastbound #2 lane across the #1 lane and into the left turn lane to make a U-turn at the intersection. The OVD was also traveling at a speed of about 35 mph (with the flow of traffic) prior to the crash event. Witnesses following OV1 stated to law enforcement that they did not observe any turn signal use from OV1 prior to the lane change. The rider estimated his position to OV1 was to the left just behind the cab,; possibly in the driver?s ?blind spot?. The MCR said that as OV1 moved across the lane it struck the right handle bar of his motorcycle causing the front tire to turn to the right. The MCR said he believed he utilized both front and rear brakes however the motorcycle collapsed right side down onto the
 
roadway surface.	The rider was ejected off the motorcycle and rolled onto the roadway surface.
OV1 continued into the left turn lane and stopped ahead at the intersection. The OVD exited his vehicle and walked back to the crash scene and made the statement that he was sorry and he had not even seen the rider prior to the crash. The driver did not seem to think there was any contact between the two vehicles and the police report indicates no damage to OV1.
MC1 had impacted the roadway surface right side down causing minor damage.	The rider was ejected off the bike impacting the roadway surface and came to rest at an unknown location along the crash area.
RiderInj: The 62 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of impacting the roadway surface. The injuries included superficial abrasions to the right arm left leg and, a puncture wound to the right knee. The MCR was treated at the scene by emergency service personnel and subsequently transported to a local hospital where he was admitted for one day. There was no evidence of alcohol or drugs present in his system.
Human:
The 62 year old rider of MC1 by his own admission appears to have been riding in the ?blind spot? of OV1. Otherwise there was no indication of aggressive behavior.
The driver of OV1 may have been pre-occupied and not paying attention to the presence of traffic behind and adjacent to his vehicle prior to making the lane change.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor right side damage as a result of the crash however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
OV1 sustained no damage as a result of this crash event. Crash scene photos of OV1 show no evidence of damage along any portion of the left side of the vehicle.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: MC1 has frontal impact right side of OV1 after OV1 makes a left turn in front of him. The rider had no time to take any collision avoidance. OV1 goes into a CW rotation. MC1 lands on its right side plane and comes to rest in the intersection. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a four-way, not skewed intersection that had no signal controls. The roadway is a non-freeway major arterial. The roadway has four through lanes in each direction with dedicated left turn lanes and a curb high raised center divider. On the rider?s side of the roadway, the intersection is made up of a driveway to a shopping center. On the side of OV1, the intersection is a two lane side street controlled by a stop sign. Both sides of the roadway are commercial/retail. The roadway has a north/south designation, however; it is in a slight northwest/southeast orientation at the crash site. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. There was no on-going construction in the immediate area of the crash. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the SWW. The temperature was +91 degrees F. The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and came to rest in the #4 lane of travel. The rider sustained moderate to major injuries. The crash occurred in Southern California in September of 2014 at 1603 hrs. Traffic conditions were to moderate to heavy. Both vehicles were towed.

MC1 was a 1985 Honda Aspencade (1182cc) touring type motorcycle. The 53 year old male (6?00?/200 lbs.) rider was wearing a Fuel full face helmet with an integral chin bar and a clear face shield. The helmets safety rating is FVMSS 218 (DOT) only. The rider was wearing unknown clothing. The helmet was ejected during the crash sequence and located approximately 155? south of the POI. The rider was fully ejected and his FRP was approximately 110? south of the POI. MC1 was southbound in the #4 (right) lane. Due to his injuries, he was unable to give any statement. MC1 sustained major damage to the front end as a result of impacting OV1. MC1 landed on its right side plane and skidded/slid to its FRP south of the intersection in the #4 lane. OV1 was being operated by a 52 year old male (5?09?/195 lbs.) He stated that he saw three vehicles approaching the intersection and that he also saw MC1 trailing behind the front three vehicles. When the front three vehicles passed, the driver of OV1 stated that he thought he had time to make his left turn and did so. The driver also stated that he
 
made a sharp, diagonal left turn into the driveway to stay ahead of the on-coming vehicles. The operator stated that as his front end reached the west curb line (driveway), he was impacted by MC1 which caused his vehicle to go into a CW rotation and end up facing in the opposite direction. MC1 sustained a reduction in wheelbase of approximately 11.9?. The front end was pushed rearward into the radiator. The front tire lost all air pressure as a result of the crash. The front rim had pieces missing. The front brake rotors were bent and broken. The rear tire had only 22 psi at the time MC1 was inspected. The front engine guards were also bent and broken. The rear crash bars were scratched from the roadway surface. The rear trunk was dislodged from its mount. The windshield was broken off. It appears that the gas tank was the only thing visible that showed no damage
RiderInj: The 53 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries consisting of unknown head trauma, a mid-back and left arm fracture, and numerous facial, leg and back abrasions. He received medical treatment at the scene and was transported to a hospital where he was admitted for an unknown number of days. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 52 year old male operator of OV1 was not injured and did not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of OV1 had a decision failure in thinking that he could make a safe left turn in front of on-coming traffic.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front end from impacting OV1. It also sustained moderate to major damage on both sides from the impact and contact with the roadway surface. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.

OV1 was not inspected. Its pre-and post-crash condition is unknown.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors found to be contributory to this crash. A traffic control signal at the intersection may have prevented this crash.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) hit & run traffic collision with a secondary lay-down event causing the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface and ejecting the rider causing minor injuries.
OV1: 2014 Ford Fiesta ST (4 door) automobile, blue
Crash:
The collision occurred on Thursday, September 2014 at 1712 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1844 hours. The weather report indicated clear skies, with a west wind at 5.8 mph, and an ambient temperature of 89.1 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface for MC1 was level with a 5.1% crown. The roadway surface was dry, found to be of an asphalt composition worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? 4-way, non-skewed intersection of a principal arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 103 feet. The intersection is controlled in all four directions by multiphase traffic lights with leading left turn arrow signals. The roadway is straight and runs north and south with three lanes dedicated for northbound and three lanes dedicated for southbound traffic. There are two designated left turn lanes to regulate both north and southbound traffic onto the intersecting commercial street at this intersection. There are also designated ?right turn? only lanes in all four directions.
The intersecting east/west principal arterial street has an overall travel-way of 103 feet.	There are three lanes dedicated for westbound traffic and two lanes for eastbound traffic on the west side of the intersection. East of the intersection there are six lanes dedicated for through traffic however, this portion of the roadway was uninvolved in the crash event.
In all four directions the opposing lanes of traffic are separated by 4 foot wide raised concrete median dividers. The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and 8 foot wide adjoining concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for north/south traffic is 45 mph and, 40 mph for east/west traffic.
MC1 was a 2010 Vespa LX150 step through scooter being operated by a 41 year old male. The rider was wearing a FMVSS 218 (US DOT) approved full face motorcycle helmet that was retained in place throughout the entire crash event. The rider was travelling northbound in the designated #2 left turn lane at a speed of about 20 mph. The light for his direction of travel was green phasing to yellow and there is an exclusive leading left turn arrow. Traffic in the area was moderate to heavy. The rider entered the intersection initiating his left turn to continue in a westbound direction.
 
OV1 was a 2014 Ford Fiesta ST (4 door) automobile being operated by a male in his thirties. The operator of OV1 failed to remain at the scene and left prior to the arrival of law enforcement officers. OV1 was approaching the intersection in the southbound #3 lane and had stopped in first position for a red light.
Northbound to westbound traffic was moving at the time however, when the southbound traffic phased to green the vehicles (including MC1) had not cleared the intersection. The driver of OV1 began to proceed southbound into the intersection at a reduced speed of about 2-3 mph.	OV1 continued about 18 feet into the intersection and impacted with the right side of MC1 as it passed in front. The impact caused the rider of MC1 to lose control and the scooter collapsed, left side down with the rider falling down directly adjacent to it. Both MC1 and the rider came to rest in front of the adjacent ?right turn? only lane. The rider attempted to apply his brakes however, was unable to initiate any other type of collision avoidance maneuver.
The OV driver continued through the intersection and initially pulled over and walked back to check on the rider. When he figured that the rider appeared to be OK, he returned to his vehicle and drove away.
RiderInj: The 41year old male rider sustained minor abrasions to his left elbow and knees from impacting the roadway surface as well as a contusion to his left leg. He was treated at the scene and transported to a local hospital where he was treated and released.
ODriverInj: It is unknown if the operator of OV1 sustained any injuries.
Human:
The rider of MC1 could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of OV1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver.
The driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision to continue into the intersection failing to perceive the presence of the approaching scooter making a left turn.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor left and right side damage as a result of impacting with the front portion of OV1.
OV1 sustained minimal front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event. OV1 was located during the police investigation and photographs were made available.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Van based light truck
OV1: 2008 GMC G3500 Van based light truck
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in September 2014 at 2042 hours in Southern California.	It was dark lit with street lights, mostly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 66 degrees F. and the winds were light from the WNW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry; and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred at a T intersection bordered by hotels on the east and west sides and apartments to the south.	The east/west state highway has 2 lanes each way, the #1 lanes are 11 ft. wide and the #2 lanes are 5 ft. wide with painted parallel parking stalls to the right that are 10 ft. wide.	The roadway is divided by a raised 13 ft. wide concrete median with 10 ft. wide un-controlled left turn lanes. The westbound grade is 0.2%, the crown is 6.7% and the posted speed limit is 40 mph.	The north/south roadway forms the base of the T, is undivided with a 20 ft. lane in each direction separated by a painted double yellow
center line with parallel parking on both sides of the roadway. There is a stop sign with limit line that is set back 14 ft. for southbound traffic. The southbound grade is -0.1%, the crown is 2.7% and the posted speed limit is 25 mph.

MC1 is a 2012 Yamaha YZF-R6 (599cc) sport/race replica motorcycle ridden by a 23 year old male (6 ft. 1 in. and 224 lbs.). The rider was wearing an Icon Airframe, full face motorcycle helmet with a clear polycarbonate face-shield that weighs approximately 60 oz.	OV1 is a 2008 GMC G3500 Van based light truck driven by a 59 year old male (5 ft. 10 in. and 220 lbs.). There was 1 passenger riding in OV1. All occupants of OV1 were reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was westbound in the #1 lane at approximately 49 mph. OV1 was southbound crossing the westbound lanes of traffic, making a left turn. The driver of OV1 stopped before starting the left turn.	He stated that he had enough time to complete the turn ahead of approaching vehicular traffic. There is a strong possibility that, due to the shape of the corner building, parked vehicles and poor lighting, the driver of OV1 had difficulty seeing MC1 before starting his turn.
As he pulled across both westbound lanes he observed MC1 approaching and stopped, blocking the #1 and 2 lanes, expecting MC1 to pass either in front or behind OV1. The rider of MC1 applied the brakes of MC1 leaving approximately 73 ft. of rear wheel skid before losing control and causing MC1 and the rider to fall on the roadway on their right side sliding approximately 22 ft. into the left side of OV1. All measurements are approximate and were measured from the
 
west and north curb-lines. The start of the skid was 122 ft. east of the west curb-line and 31 ft. south of the north curb-line, the skid ended at 56 ft. west and
28 ft. south. The gouges and first Point of Impact (POI) #1 was 42 ft. east and 28 ft. south, the gouges ended at 20 ft. east and 26 ft. south.	The POI with the left side of OV1 was 19 ft. east and 26 ft. south.	The Point of Rest (POR) of the rider was 19 ft. east and 24 ft. south.	MC1 slid back and to the left, 2 ft. 8 in. and 7 ft. 4 in. OV1 stayed at POI #2.
RiderInj: The 23 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the coroner?s report:	Bilateral Subpleural lung contusions, bilateral flail chest, multiple right lung lacerations, subdural and subarachnoid brain hemorrhages, inferior vena cava laceration, bilateral jugular lacerations, lacerations to the liver, spleen, kidney and adrenal gland, fractures to C6, C7 and L1, left clavical fracture, multiple lacerations, abrasions and contusions of the outer skin. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 59. Alcohol and drugs were not a factor in this crash.
Human: The OV1 driver?s perception failure and decision to stop instead of continuing past the westbound traffic lanes into the center of the intersection were crash causal factors.	The rider of MC1?s reaction time failure may have contributed to the crash.
Vehicle: Low front tire pressure affected stability and handling of MC1.
Environmental: Poor field of view of the oncoming westbound vehicles, due to the darkness and surrounding buildings and parked vehicles may have been a crash causal factor.

CrashType: MC1 is southbound in the #2 lane in moderate to heavy traffic. The #1 lane had stopped, leaving a gap for OV1 to make a left turn. As OV1 makes its left turn, it impacts MC1 on the left side. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
OV1: 1998 GMC Sierra P/U towing an unloaded boat trailer
Crash:
This crash occurred between two signal controlled intersections at a driveway type intersection with no signal controls. The roadway is a non-freeway minor arterial. The roadway has two through lanes in each direction with a continuous two way left turn lane, and bike lanes. Traffic was moderate to heavy. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. It has a north/south designation however it is in a northeast/southwest orientation at the crash site. It has a 2.6% crown and a -2.7% downgrade for the rider. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. On the rider?s right is a commercial/retail strip mall. On the rider?s left are single family residences. There is a 8? concrete sidewalk on both sides of the roadway. There was no on-going construction in the immediate area of the crash. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the west. The temperature was +76 degrees F.	The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and came to rest on the far right side of the roadway. The rider sustained moderate injuries.	The crash occurred in Southern California in September of 2014 at 1545 hrs. MC1 was towed. OV1 was driven away.

MC1 was a 2013 Harley Davidson Street Bob cruiser (883cc) cruiser type motorcycle with modifications. The 26 year old male (6?02?/200 lbs.) rider was
wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings. It is unknown if the helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events.	MC1 was southbound in the #2 (right) lane. He stated that he was not lane splitting and that the OV turned in front of him. The 54 year old male (6? 02?/200 lbs.) operator of OV1 stated that traffic was heavy and congested. He stated that the vehicles traveling southbound had stopped for him, leaving a gap so that he could make his left turn into the driveway. He stated that MC1 came out of nowhere and must have been splitting lanes. There was no evidence of MC1 skidding in an attempt to avoid impacting OV1. OV1 impacted MC1 on the left side, knocking it over onto its right side plane and fully ejecting the rider. There was evidence that the rider flew across the hood of OV1 as seen in pictures COS12 and COS13. After the crash, the driver of OV1 backed his vehicle into the two-way left turn lane. OV1 was a standard full size pick-up towing an empty boat trailer.
RiderInj: The 26 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of a reported compound fracture to his left leg and a laceration. He was treated at the scene and then taken to a hospital. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 54 year old male operator of OV1 was not injured and did not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The driver of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 before making his left turn.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate to major damage to the left side from the impact with OV1. MC1 also sustained minor to moderate damage to the right side from impacting and sliding on the roadway surface. The damage consisted of bent forks, broken headlight/gauge bracket, dents in the gas tank, scratches and scrapes. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as near new.

OV1 sustained minor damage to the right-front-center of the front bumper area. The damage consisted of denting to the metal bumper and the front license plate being torn off. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.
Environmental: There were no permanent environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash. There was a temporary environmental factor consisting of heavy traffic stopped in the #1 lane which blocked the view of on-coming traffic in the #2 lane.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. fixed objects (roadway surface & raised concrete curb) left side impact crash event. MC1 struck the roadway and slid into his motorcycle before coming to rest. The motorcycle rider sustained moderate injuries as a result of this crash event. There were no passengers on the motorcycle.
MV1: 2007 Honda CBR1000RR (street race, replica) motorcycle (999cc), black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. fixed objects, left side impact crash event resulting in moderate injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Friday, September 2014 at 1750 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed clear skies, with WSW wind conditions at 6.9 mph. The ambient temperature was +73.9 degrees F and sunset was at 1840 hours. Visibility was clear and unrestricted for 10.0 miles. The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. The rider was negotiating a left curve on a 1.1 uphill grade prior to crash event.
The collision occurred on a left curve portion of a multiple lane local street with an approximate radius of 63 feet. The overall length of the curve in this area was 170 feet. The overall travel way width of the roadway is 64 feet. This is a north/south local street with one lane dedicated for northbound traffic and one lane for southbound traffic. The southbound portion of this roadway is uninvolved in the crash event. The roadway design is a ?left curve? with a 12 foot wide painted median (solid double yellow lines) separating the north and southbound lanes of traffic as well as a raised concrete median with surface vegetation south of the crash scene.
There are no bicycle lanes on either side of the roadway and parking is prohibited. The posted speed limit for both directions, through the curve is 30 mph. Other than the posted speed limit signs and the posted traffic advisory signs for the curve, there are no other regulatory traffic control devices in the area. Both the east and west sides of this roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs,	and sidewalks east side of the street has a commercial building and the west side of the street are also occupied by retail/commercial businesses.

MC1 was a 2007 Honda CBR1000RR (street race, replica) motorcycle being operated by a 21 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a full face Bell motorcycle helmet with a double ?D? ring nylon chinstrap which appeared to be in satisfactory condition. The helmet was equipped with a clear face shield and sustained only minor surface abrasions. The helmet remained on the riders head throughout the crash event.
The rider was traveling northbound prior to the crash. As the rider negotiated the left curve he decided to ?apex? the turn along the right edge of the painted two-way left turn lane keeping a constant speed of 25 mph.	As the rider continued northbound along the edge of the lane, he kept his turn tight out of his concern for a vehicle he saw in an adjacent driveway. It was the riders concern that the vehicle might pull out into the street during his turn however, this
 
never occurred. As the rider continued into the turn the rear tire of the motorcycle ?washed out? and collapsed on to the roadway surface, left side down. The rider was ejected off the bike and both slid into a raised concrete curb not before the bike flipped over onto the right side. Both the bike and the rider came to rest in the area of a driveway entrance located along the north side of the street.
The witness sitting in his vehicle, in the driveway, saw the rider approach and remained stopped off the roadway. He estimated the speed of the bike at between 35 & 40 mph.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event. The rider approached the curve at an approximate speed of 35mph yet washed out in the turn; the posted speed limit for this street is 30 mph. There may be an issue with the posted speed vs. critical speed design of the curve.
The rider was treated at the scene by paramedics and transported to a local hospital for treatment and, was admitted.
RiderInj: The most severe injuries sustained by the rider were a compressed fracture of the L2 Lumbar vertebra and fracture of the sacrum. He also sustained minor abrasive injuries to his right knee and buttocks. There was no indication of the presence of drugs and/or alcohol on the rider.
Human: The 21 year old male rider of MC1 was driving at a speed unsafe for the portion of the roadway posted at 30 mph and failed to comprehend the (left) curvature in the roadway and lean angle of his motorcycle causing it to ?wash out? to the right striking the raised concrete curb.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate left and right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Sedan
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in September 2014 at 1755 hours in Southern California. There were clear skies with bright sunlight, the temperature was approximately 71 degrees F. and the winds were approximately 4 mph out of the W. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred in a residential area, on a predominately east/west oriented roadway with two 20 ft. wide undivided lanes, approaching a T intersection. The eastbound grade is -3.3%, the crown is 2.2% and there are no traffic controls. All measurements were taken from the north/south curb prolongation of the west curb face and the east/west curb prolongation of the south curb face.
MC1 is a 2003 Honda CBR600RR (599cc) race replica motorcycle ridden by a 21 year old male (6 ft. 1 in. and 230 lbs.). The rider was wearing a Bilt BLH-2 full-face helmet. OV1 is a 1998 Honda Civic LX 4 door sedan driven by a 32 year old female (5 ft. 5 in. and 180 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was eastbound in the #1 lane at approximately 15 mph. OV1 was eastbound stopped ahead of MC1 on the right side of lane #1 waiting for a westbound vehicle to pass before making a left turn into a residential driveway. MC1 attempted to pass OV1 on the left side, just as OV1 made the left turn. The rider braked and attempted to turn left to avoid the collision, but was unable to stop.	The right front side of MC1 and the right side of the rider struck the left rear quarter panel of OV1 at an impact speed of approximately 10 mph.	MC1 fell on top of the rider at the Area of Impact (AOI). The AOI was approximately 27 ft. north of the south curb line and 90 ft. west of the west curb line.
RiderInj: The 21 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related during the interview: dislocated right shoulder, abrasions to the right knee and a contusion to the right thigh. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 5. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The rider of MC1 attempted to pass OV1 without leaving a safe distance between both vehicles, leaving the rider with insufficient time to react to prevent this accident. The driver of OV1 failed to properly signal her intention of making a left turn.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: MC1 was northbound at a constant speed in the middle lane approaching an intersection when OV1 enters the roadway from a driveway on the right. OV1 drove straight across the lanes of travel and fails to yield to MC1 who impacts OV1 to the left rear side and then goes down. The rider is fully ejected and vaulted above ride height and lands in the roadway. The rider sustained serious injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a driveway type intersection near a signal controlled intersection. MC1 was going northbound in the middle lane at a constant speed when OV1 entered the roadway from the driveway and failed to yield to MC1. There are no signal controls for this driveway. The roadway is a non-freeway major arterial. The roadway has three through lanes in each direction. The right lane is very wide at 22?. There is no designated bike lane or right turn lane at the intersection or in the area of the crash. There is a dedicated left turn lane at the intersection. The roadway has a curb high raised center divider that is 4? wide. The roadway surface is comprised of asphalt, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway is flat and level with a 5% crown and a
-0.1% grade in the direction the rider was going. The roadway has a north/south designation but is in a slight northwest/southeast orientation at the crash site. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the SW. The temperature was +81 degrees F.	The rider of MC1 was fully ejected, vaulted above ride height, and came to rest in the middle of the roadway. The rider sustained major injuries. The crash occurred in Southern California in September of 2014 at 1639 hrs. Traffic conditions were to moderate to heavy. MC1 towed. OV1 fled the scene. The operator of OV1 went home and called the police who went to his residence and subsequently arrested him for felony hit and run involving DUI. His vehicle was located nearby.

MC1 was a 2010 Harley Davidson Street Bob (1200cc) cruising type motorcycle with modifications. The 29 year old male (5?11?/157 lbs.) rider was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings. Per the investigators, the rider was wearing a helmet that remained in place to the completion of the crash events, and went to the hospital with the rider.	MC1 was northbound in the #2 (middle) lane of three lanes. He stated that he was going about 45 mph. He stated that he saw a gray pick-up truck exiting a parking lot on his right. He said that he immediately applied his brakes but was unable to stop and hit the
 
left rear side of the truck. The rider said that he was ejected and lying in the street when a male subject he believes to be the driver of the truck came over to him and apologized for pulling out in front of him. The male subject asked if he was ?OK? to which the rider replied, ?No, I?m hurt.?	The male subject then disappeared. Witnesses said that the truck pulled out into the street crossing the lanes of traffic and failed to yield to MC1, which impacted the truck. After returning to OV1, the driver fled the scene. He parked a few blocks away from his house, which was less than a mile from the crash scene and then a short time later called the police. OV1 was located and the 32 year old male (5?09?/165 lbs.) driver was subsequently arrested for felony DUI and felony Hit & Run. There were no pre or post-impact evidence of braking from either vehicle at the crash scene. There only a few minor gouges in the roadway from MC1. There was a reduction in the wheelbase; however it could not be measured.
RiderInj: The 29 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries consisting of a Grade IV injury to his spleen and left kidney, fractures to his L2 and L3 vertebrae, a fracture of his left hand and one finger, as well as abrasions and contusions to his upper body. He was treated at the scene and then taken to a hospital where he was admitted. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 42 year old male (5?09?/165 lbs.) operator of OV1 was not injured. He was contacted at his residence where he fled to after the crash. He displayed signs of alcohol intoxication and was subsequently arrested. He attempted to take a Preliminary Alcohol Screening test twice, but was not able to complete them. He submitted to a blood test. The results showed a BAC of 0.18%
Human: The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 approaching. He was also deemed to be under the influence of alcohol at the time of the crash.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front end. The front forks were fractured and not static. They were bent in the middle and broken at the axle bolt. There was no evidence of the front tire impacting the frame or engine. A wheelbase measurement was not possible. MC1 also had scratches on the left side from impacting and sliding on the roadway surface. The damage consisted mostly of scratches and scrapes. The most significant damage was to the gas tank, which was dented and scratched by the roadway. The after-market high rise handlebars were bent in and a true width measurement was not possible. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as good.
OV1 sustained minor damage to the left rear side of the truck bed. The damaged area was between the rear tire and the rear bumper. The pre-crash condition would be labeled as near new.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: MC1 was southbound at a constant speed in the #1 lane approaching an intersection when OV1 entered the roadway from a driveway on the right. OV1 drove across the lanes of travel towards the left turn lane and failed to yield to MC1 who impacted OV1 to the left rear side and then goes down. The rider was fully ejected and then run over by OV2 which was northbound. The rider sustained serious injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a driveway type intersection near a signal controlled intersection. MC1 was going southbound in the #1 left lane at a constant speed when OV1 entered the roadway from the driveway and failed to yield to MC1. There are no signal controls for this driveway. The roadway is a non-freeway minor arterial. The roadway has two through lanes and a bicycle lane in each direction, with a two way center lane. There is a dedicated left turn lane at the intersection and in that area the roadway is divided by double yellow painted lines. The roadway surface is comprised of asphalt, is worn and in poor condition showing surface cracking and spalling. There are several areas of bitumen repair from nearby construction, but none of it at the crash site.	The roadway is flat and level with a 6% crown and a +0.1% grade in the direction the rider was travelling. The roadway has a north/south designation but is in a slight northeast/southwest orientation at the crash site. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. There was on-going construction across the street from the crash site with a lane closure, but it had no effect on the crash. There was also construction south of the crash at the corner. It also had no effect on the crash.
Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a light variable wind. The temperature was +73 degrees F.	The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and sustained major injuries. The crash occurred in Southern California in October of 2014 at 1044 hrs. Traffic conditions were to moderate to heavy. MC1 towed. Both OV1 and OV2 were driven away.

MC1 was a 2009 Buell 1125C (1126cc) sport/racing type motorcycle with modifications. The main modifications are the front turn signals and the high performance exhaust. The 34 year old male (6?00?/190 lbs.) rider was wearing a full face helmet with a clear face shield. He was wearing no other eye
 
protection. The helmets safety rating is FVMSS 218 (DOT) only. The rider stated that he was wearing a light t-shirt, thin cotton shorts, low cut athletic shoes, and armored nylon mesh gloves.

The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events.	MC1 was southbound in the #1 (left) lane. He stated that he was going approximately 30 mph when OV1 entered the roadway and came across into his lane. The rider made no mention of the vehicle that was stopped in the #2 lane. He stated that he braked and thought he locked his rear wheel. There was no evidence of a skid. He then stated that he tried to swerve left to avoid hitting OV1. He said that he hit OV1 on the driver?s side, was ejected and slid into the on-coming traffic lanes where he was run over by OV2.	He stated that when everything stopped, he was trapped under OV2.	The 86 year old female driver (5?03?/150 lbs.) of OV1 stated that she was exiting the car wash and wanted to go over into the left turn lane at the signal. There was a car southbound in the #2 lane that stopped at the driveway, allowing her to enter traffic. This vehicle blocked her view as she looked for on-coming traffic while entering the roadway, and she never saw MC1 approaching. The next thing she knew was that she was hit on the driver?s side and saw a motorcycle and its ejected rider ?flying? southbound next to her vehicle. She also stated that she saw the rider get hit by OV2 that was northbound. The 58 year old male (5?07?/160 lbs.) driver of OV2 stated that he was northbound in the #1 lane going between 35-40 mph as he entered the intersection. He saw MC1 collide with OV1, get ejected, and both the bike and rider were sliding across the roadway into his lanes of travel. He braked to
avoid impacting either of them. MC1 slid across his pathway ahead of the rider. The driver of OV2 stated that he was unable to avoid hitting the rider. The driver stated that he felt the right front of his vehicle lift and believed that he had run over the rider. He was finally able to stop and immediately exited his vehicle. He then located the rider under OV1. There were no pre-impact tire marks from any of the vehicles involved in the crash. There were some post- impact tire marks from MC1 and some scrapes made as MC1 slid to its FRP. The marks on MC1 indicate that it was sliding on its right side plane, front end first.
RiderInj: The 34 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries consisting of a fractured pelvis and shoulder. He also sustained numerous abrasions to his upper and lower extremities. He was treated at the scene and taken to a hospital where he was admitted for 8 days. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: Neither OV driver sustained any injuries or displayed any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit their ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 approaching. The unknown vehicle that was stopped adjacent to the driveway that OV1 was exiting partially blocked the driver?s view of approaching traffic made it unsafe to enter the roadway.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor damage to the right side from impacting OV1 and sliding on its right side plane to its FRP. The visible damage consists of scrapes and a broken right turn signal that was mounted to the end of the handlebar, along with the mirror. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered like new.

OV1 sustained minor damage to the left side and consists mostly of scratches and minor denting. It starts at the left rear wheel and ends at the driver?s door.
 
The pre-crash condition of OV1 would be considered like new.OV2 sustained no visible damage other than the front license plate was removed. The pre-crash condition of OV2 would be considered very good.
Environmental: There were no permanent environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) passenger van center front impact causing the motorcycle rider to be ejected off the bike, and vaulting on to the roadway surface. There was a secondary side to side impact involving another vehicle (OV2) automobile and MC1. The third and final event involved the motorcycle impacting with the roadway surface and the adjacent north side curb. The rider (MCR) sustained non-life threatening injuries. There were no passengers on this motorcycle at the time of the collision.
MV1: 2012 Yamaha YZF R6 (sport, race replica) motorcycle, 599cc (white).
Crash:
This was a multiple impact motorcycle vs. other vehicle (OV1) vs. other vehicle (OV2) front to side impact type traffic collision resulting in non-life threatening injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight on Sunday, October 2014 @ 1515 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1453 hours showed clear skies, SSW winds at 11.5mph, an ambient temperature of 75.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unrestricted for 10.0 miles.
The roadway surface has a measured 3.2 uphill grade, is of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred on a straight multiple lane east west principal (non-freeway) arterial roadway with an overall travel-way width of 98 feet. A portion of the crash scene where both MC1 and the rider came to rest leads into a slight left curve with a radius of 1250 feet and an overall length of curve of 650 feet. The roadway has three lanes dedicated for westbound traffic and three lanes for eastbound traffic. The eastbound lanes of this roadway are not involved with this crash event. There are marked 8 foot wide bicycle lanes on both sides of the roadway. The roadway is bordered by both raised concrete curbs and 6 foot wide concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for both east and westbound traffic is 45 mph.
The area of the crash site is about 250 feet west of an ?at grade? four way intersection controlled by multi-phase signal devices for all four directions of travel. There are designated left turn lanes for all approaching traffic as well as designated right turn only lanes however the intersection is not part of this crash event. The north side of the roadway is occupied by commercial businesses. The west side of the street is occupied by multiple family apartment complexes. The opposing lanes of traffic on this roadway are separated by a 13 foot wide raised concrete median with grass ground cover and no median barrier.
There were no roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. Other than the posted speed limit signs there were no traffic control devices in proximity to the crash site.
 
MC1 was a 2012 Yamaha YZF R6 (sport, race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 24 year old male rider.	The rider was wearing a DOT and Snell M2010 approved motorcycle helmet. The helmet manufacturer was an HJC model CL-17 style full face helmet. The rider was initially travelling westbound in the #1 lane at a high rate of speed (45-50mph) and switched into a position where he could split lanes between the #2 and #3 westbound lanes between slower moving vehicles.
OV1 was a 2006 Toyota Sienna passenger van being operated by an 84 year old male. The driver of OV1 was proceeding westbound in the #3 lane at an approximate speed of 40-45 mph.
OV2 was a 2013 Ford Mustang automobile being operated by a 44 year female. The driver of OV2 was proceeding westbound in the #2 lane at an approximate speed of 45mph
While continuing westbound the driver of OV1 felt an impact to his vehicle not realizing that MC1 had just impacted the left rear portion of the vehicle. The driver looked out his side view mirror and saw MC1 impact into the right side of OV2. The driver went on to say that he pulled over to the side of the road and he was not injured.
The driver of OV2 said she saw MC1 attempting to split traffic saw MC1 impact the rear of OV1 and careen into the right side of her vehicle.	The driver of OV2 was not injured.
The initial impact of MC1 to the rear of OV1 ejected the rider vaulting him on to the roadway surface. The rider rolled and tumbled a distance of approximately 160 feet before coming to rest in the #3 westbound lane. The rider said he ended up about 300 feet east of where his motorcycle came to rest.
After impacting OV1 and the rider being ejected off the motorcycle, MC1 careened into the right side of OV2 located in the adjacent #2 westbound lane. After striking OV2 MC1 collapsed onto the roadway surface sliding in a northwest direction for an approximate distance of 128 feet until impacting the raised concrete north curb of that borders the roadway. MC1 continued up and on to the concrete sidewalk area sliding another 64 feet until coming to rest, right side down, about 8 feet north of the roadway.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, or animals that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 24 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were numerous abrasions to the shoulders, right knee, right elbow and posterior portion of the torso. He also sustained a contusion to his left foot. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was uninjured with no evidence of alcohol or drug use. The driver of OV2 was uninjured with no evidence of alcohol or drug use.
Human:
