The 24 year old male rider MC1 was driving at an unsafe speed for the present traffic on the roadway coupled with his intent to split lanes while all traffic was in motion.
The 84 year old male driver of OV1 was proceeding at a speed safe for the surrounding traffic. The 44 year female driver of OV2 was proceeding at a speed safe for the surrounding traffic.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate damage to the front left and right side however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision. OV1 sustained minor left/rear end damage otherwise, was in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
OV2 sustained minor right side damage otherwise appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Sedan
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in October 2014 at approximately 2005 hours in Southern California.	It was dark with clear skies, the temperature was approximately 69 degrees F. and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn with surface cracking. There was medium traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial/small business area, on the eastbound side of a two-way divided roadway that has no median barrier and is posted ?one way, no U-turn and right turn only? for traffic exiting the commercial driveway.	There are 2 eastbound lanes; lane #1 is 12 ft. wide and lane #2 is 22 ft. wide, the center divider is 4 ft. wide and the commercial driveway is 30 ft. wide and is located on the south side of the roadway.	The eastbound grade is 0.1%, the crown is 4.0% and there are no traffic controls. All measurements were taken from the north/south curb prolongation of the east curb face and the east/west curb prolongation of the south curb face.
MC1 is a 2014 Ducati 899 Panigale (898cc) race replica motorcycle ridden by a 24 year old male (5 ft. 6 in. and 154 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make and model helmet. OV1 is a 2014 Dodge Challenger Sedan driven by a 60 year old female (5 ft. 7 in. and 150 lbs.).	There were 3 minor children riding in OV1.	All occupants of OV1 were reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was eastbound in the #1 lane at approximately 40 mph.	OV1 was northbound exiting the commercial driveway, crossing the eastbound lanes to move into the center turn lane just beyond the center median which ends approximately 10 ft. 6 in. east of the east driveway edge, to make an illegal U-turn.	The
rider stated that he only had time to honk his horn before impacting the left front side of OV1.	The driver of OV1 stated that she didn?t see MC1 prior to impact. The Point of Impact (POI) was approximately 234 ft. east and 34 ft. north and the approximate Final Rest Position (FRP) of MC1 was 230 ft. east and 34 ft.
north. OV1?s FRP was the same as the POI.	The rider's FRP was approximately 246 ft. 5 in. east and 37 ft. 4 in. north, from the above mentioned curb reference.
RiderInj: The 24 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: complaint of pain to the right leg. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to perceive MC1 and attempted to make an illegal U-turn, leaving MC1 insufficient time to react to prevent this accident.	The rider of MC1 had a decision failure in his choice of just honking the horn, instead of ?possibly? trying to move towards the #2 lane and going behind OV1.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs motorcycle (MC1) left front to right side, side swipe type impact minor injury crash event. The rider of MC1 maintained control and was not ejected and the motorcycle did not collapse on to the roadway surface.
MV1: 2013 Harley Davidson FXST Deluxe Soft Tail (1449cc), red
Crash:
This was a vehicle vs. motorcycle minor injury crash event. The collision occurred	on Saturday October 2014 at 0919 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 0858 hours indicated that it was partly cloudy, with calm wind conditions and, an ambient temperature of 67.1 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed for 10.0 miles in all directions. The motorcyclist was traveling on a multiple lane principal arterial (state highway) roadway with grade of +0.5%. The roadway is of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit for north and southbound traffic is 45 mph.
The roadway has an overall travel way width of 106 feet. There are four lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and four lanes dedicated for southbound traffic. The lanes are separated by a four foot wide raised concrete and brick median. There are no designated bicycle/safety lanes on either side of the roadway and parking is not allowed.

The northbound lanes have a combined width of 46 feet. The southbound lanes of this roadway are not involved with this crash event. The roadway is bordered by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks approximately 10 feet in width. The eastside of the roadway bordering the northbound lanes is occupied primarily be commercial/retail businesses. The west side of the roadway bordering the southbound lanes is also occupied by commercial/retail businesses. The scene of the crash is an ?at grade? T-intersection. The intersecting local street is approximately 40 feet wide and allows of both east and westbound vehicular traffic. The only regulatory traffic device at this intersection is one posted ?STOP? sign for eastbound traffic approaching the principal arterial roadway. The speed limit on this local street is 25 mph however this street is not part of the crash event.

MC1 was a 2013 Harley Davidson FXST Deluxe Soft Tail cruiser style motorcycle being operated by a 50 year old female rider. MC1 was traveling northbound in the #1 lane at an approximate speed of 40 mph.
OV1 was a 2001 Toyota Camry (automobile) that was being operated by a 22 year old male. The driver was traveling northbound in the #2 lane at an approximate speed of 40 mph. Prior to the precipitating event both vehicles were paralleling each other.
 
As both vehicles were approaching the T-intersection, OV1 initiated a sudden lane change left from the #2 lane into the adjacent #1 lane. The rider of MC1 had initially noticed the sudden lane change of OV1 and applied her brakes to slow down however, noticed that OV1 was still moving to the left encroaching on her position in the #1 lane. OV1 continued moving into the #1 lane and the left front portion of OV1 impacted with the right side of MC1. The impact caused the left front portion of the bumper ofOV1 to become dislodged. For a moment both vehicles were captured and the rider maintained her position on the motorcycle. Both vehicles; now moving together continued to the left, entering the intersection and slowed to a point where they dislodged and both rolled to a stop. The rider of MC1 was not ejected nor did MC1 ever collapse on to the roadway surface.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj:
The 50 year old female rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of the crash and was only treated and released at the scene. The injuries consisted of
a laceration the right knee and a contusion to the right leg. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 50 year old female rider of MC1 was traveling at a safe speed foe the present roadway conditions, within her lane of travel and subsequently did not contribute to the cause or outcome of this crash event.
The 22 year old male operator of OV1 was also traveling at a safe speed for the present traffic on the roadway however, failed to properly scan the environment to check for any vehicles in proximity to his lane changing maneuver. His subsequent actions lead to the primary cause of this crash event.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
OV1 sustained moderate left front damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash..
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: MC1 is northbound negotiating a left curve at a constant speed in the #1 lane approaching an intersection when he drifts to the left and impacts a curb high center divider. MC1 then impacted a break-away metal sign post, then the ground. The rider is fully ejected and sustained serious injuries. He was arrested for DUI. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a ?T? type intersection with no signal controls. MC1 was going northbound in the #1 left lane at a constant speed and negotiating a downhill left curve. The roadway has two lanes in each direction and bike lanes. There is a raised center divider with trees and bushes on the approach to the intersection. There is an island divider in the middle of the intersection with a dedicated left turn lane and a dedicated merging lane. The intersecting roadway is controlled by a stop sign. The roadway is a non-freeway minor arterial. The roadway surface is comprised of asphalt, is worn and polished, but otherwise in good condition. The crown was measured to be 4.1% and the downgrade was measured to be -2.6% in the direction the rider was traveling. The roadway has a north/south designation but is in a slight northwest/southeast orientation at the crash site. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. There was no construction in the area. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The intersection was illuminated by overhead spot lamps that were
illuminated. The weather was partly cloudy with no measurable wind. The temperature was +69 degrees F.	The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and sustained major injuries. The crash occurred in Southern California in October of 2014 at 1051 hrs. Traffic conditions were light. MC1 was towed.

MC1 was a 2009 Yamaha Zuma (1256cc) scooter type motorcycle with modifications. The known modification is the windshield that was missing after the crash. The 21 year old male (5?06?/170 lbs.) rider was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings. It is unknown what, if any, protective apparel the rider may have been wearing. The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events and went to the hospital with the rider.	MC1 was northbound in the #1 (left) lane on his way home from dinner and drinking. He admitted to having three 24 oz. beers between 1830 and 2000 hrs. He stated that he got too close and hit the center diver. There was no evidence of any evasive maneuvers prior to the impact with the center divider. The rider said that no other vehicle was involved in the crash. After impacting the center divider, MC1 rode along the curb edge before mounting the divider and impacting the sign post. The rider was fully ejected. It is unknown when his ejection took place and whether or not he impacted the sign post. The post was
 
bent and had been replaced.	After impacting the sign post, both MC1 and the rider skidded/slid to their FRP in the southbound #1 lane. A passerby found him and called emergency personnel. Damage to MC1 and yellow paint transfer on the curb indicate that MC1 rode the curbing for approximately 15? before mounting the divider. The damage to the exhaust appears to be a combination of curbing/roadway and possibly the post. MC1 had damage on all sides. It is unknown how much of it may have been pre-existing. It does appear that MC1 flipped over from one side to the other before coming to rest. MC1 was found on its right side plane facing east. The rider submitted to a preliminary alcohol screening (PAS) test while at the hospital. He gave two successful breath samples with recorded results of 0.211% and 0.211% BAC. This took place 1 hour and 22 minutes after the crash. He was arrested and released to the care of the hospital.
RiderInj: The 21 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries consisting of a skull fracture (NOS), fractured ribs (NOS), a fractured left hand (NOS), and multiple abrasions. It is unknown if he lost consciousness. He was treated at the scene and taken to a hospital where he was admitted for an unknown number of days. He displayed signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing the center divider as he was drifting into it. His level of intoxication would be considered a major contributing factor.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained major damage to the right side from impacting the curb, post, and roadway surface. The right front fork was broken off at the axle. MC1 had scrapes and dents on both sides. The windshield and left mirror were missing. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered fair.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) broadside type crash event with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface. The rider (MCR) was ejected off of the motorcycle impacting the right side of OV1 and the roadway surface suffering serious injuries.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event. The collision occurred	on Wednesday October 2014 at 1248 hours in Southern California.	The weather report for 1258 hours showed partly cloudy skies, with winds out of the SSW at 6.9 mph. There was an ambient temperature of 81.0 degrees F. Visibility was 10.0 miles and at ground level it was clear and unobstructed in all directions.	The roadway surface for MC1 had a 1.4% uphill grade with a 4.6% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? T-intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 80 feet and commercial shopping center driveway. The driveway was approximately 42 feet wide allowing for ingress and egress of vehicular traffic into the center. The roadway is straight and runs north and south with two lanes dedicated for northbound and two lanes dedicated for southbound traffic.
There is a 10 foot wide painted two way left turn lane separating the north and southbound lanes of traffic. There are no designated ?Bike? lanes, electronic or posted traffic control devices in proximity of the crash site other than a ?stop? sign for eastbound traffic exiting the shopping center. The east and west sides of the minor arterial street are bordered by raised concrete curbs and adjoining 9 foot wide concrete sidewalks.
On the west side of the roadway is a retail/commercial shopping center open to the public. On the east side of the roadway are multiple family two story apartment complexes. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 1996 Triumph Sprint 900 (885cc) cruiser style motorcycle being operated by an unlicensed 50 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a half shell motorcycle helmet with a FMVSS 218 DOT rating. The helmet was black in color, size large and equipped with a nylon strap and double "D" rings. The rider had accelerated to an estimated speed of approximately 40 mph, southbound in the designated #2 lane of the minor arterial street approaching the T-
intersection and OV1.
OV1 was a 2013 Kia Soul (automobile) being operated by an 87 year old male driver. The OVD was initially approaching the intersection in the northbound #1 lane however, changed into the two way left turn lane intending to turn left into the shopping center. OVD had been moving at approximately 20mph and had
 
come to a complete stop prior to making the desired left turn movement once traffic cleared. Once the OVD believed the southbound lanes to be clear of traffic he initiated his left turn movement. OV1 crossed the southbound #1 lane and began to cross the #2 lane when MC1 impacted it along the right side. The OVD was not injured by the crash and completed his left turn driving into the parking lot and parking in a designated stall.
The rider had been southbound in the #2 lane at a speed of about 40mph. The rider said he never saw OV1 until the impact however there was evidence of 78 feet of pre-impact rear wheel locked skid. MC1 struck the right side of OV1in an upright position near the right side B-Pillar. The resulting impact caused the rider to be ejected off the motorcycle and into the side of OV1 causing serious injuries to the rider?s right leg. MC1 collapsed right side down onto the roadway surface within 7 feet of the area of impact.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 50 year old male rider of MC1 sustained serious injuries as a result of the collision. The rider was immediately removed from the scene to a local hospital for treatment. The impact with OV1 caused the riders right leg to be impaled on the metal B-Pillar surface which resulted in an open fracture and loss of bone tissue to the Femur. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The 87 year old male driver of OV1 was not injured. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 50 year old male rider of MC1 did not react in time or conduct a proper collision avoidance maneuver prior to the crash. His efforts in bringing his motorcycle to a stop by utilizing what appeared to be rear braking only was insufficient.	The rider showed no evidence of having the proper license for operation of a motorcycle and may have lacked training and or experience in similar situations.
The 87 year old male driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision having failed to perceive the proximity of the approaching motorcycle while making his left turn.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front and right side damage as a result of impacting with the OV1 and the roadway. The motorcycle otherwise appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained major right side damage however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Fixed Object (Roadway)
MV1: 1997 Harley Davidson Softtail FLSTC (1338cc) Cruiser motorcycle
Crash:
Environmental and Crash Specifics: This single vehicle motorcycle crash occurred in October 2014 at 2005 hours in Southern California.	It was dark, clear, the temperature was approximately 74 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, with surface cracking and spalling.	There was light traffic.

The crash occurred westbound, on an east/west undivided roadway with a center turn lane and railroad tracks crossing the roadway. The predominately east/west aligned roadway has a single set of abandoned railroad tracks crossing north to south with the crossing guards/lights dismantled. The roadway is divided by an 18 ft. wide center turn lane with 8 in. raised concrete islands west & east of the railroad tracks. The island to the west is: 18 ft. wide, 19 ft. long. The island to the east is:	18 ft. wide, 47 ft. long.	There are 2 travel lanes in each direction.	The outside lanes are 21 ft. wide and the inside lanes are 11 ft. wide. The speed limit is 40 mph, the westbound grade is -1.1 % and the crown +2.3 %, the railroad tracks have a 0.26 % crown.
MC1 is a 1997 Harley Davidson Softtail FLSTC (1338cc) Cruiser motorcycle ridden by a 39 year old male (5 ft. 5 in. and 225 lbs.) The rider was wearing a Bell, fullface Qualifier helmet.	MC1 was traveling westbound in the #1 lane at approximately 47 mph. The rider rose up off the seat by pulling on the handlebars as he started over the railroad tracks, felt a sudden deceleration and was launched over the handlebars of MC1. Rider struck the roadway on the front of his helmet and tumbled end over end several times then slid an unknown distance to his Final Rest Position (FRP) straddling the westbound #1 & #2 lanes facing south.	The rider then crawled to the center turn lane.	MC1 went down on its left side and slid for approximately 132 ft. to its FRP facing southeast.
RiderInj: The 39 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related during the interview: right scapula fracture, multiple fractures of the left tibia/fibula, dislocation of right humerus, torn right shoulder ligaments/muscles, bilateral abrasions to posterior forearms and anterior knees.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) for the rider was 5. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The rider of MC1 was traveling at a speed unsafe for the road conditions.
Vehicle: MC1 may have inadvertently down shifted as it crossed over the railroad tracks.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: MC1 rear-ends OV1 who had entered the roadway from a public driveway when making a wide right turn. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. The rider?s helmet was not secured properly and was ejected from the rider?s head during impact.
Crash:
This crash occurred south of an at-grade 4 way type intersection with signal controls. MC1 was going southbound in the #1 left lane at a constant speed. OV1 entered the roadway while making a right turn. OV1 went wide out to the #1 lane and cut off MC1. The roadway has three through lanes in each direction. In the rider?s direction, there are dedicated left and right turn lanes. There is a curb high raised center divider that is 3? wide.	On the rider?s right is the entrance to an urban park, which is where OV1 was exiting. The entrance has a 10? wide curb high shrubbery filled divider. For the exit side, there is a straight/left turn combination lane, and a right turn only lane. There is a crosswalk on three sides of the intersection. On the rider?s left is a commercial/business complex. The roadway is a non-freeway major arterial. The roadway surface is comprised of asphalt, is worn and polished, but otherwise in good condition. The crown was measured to be 4.2% and the grade was measured to be +1.1% in the direction the rider was traveling. The roadway has an east/west designation but is in a slight northwest/southeast orientation at the crash site. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. For the OV, the roadway surface was concrete. It was in good condition. The crown was measured at 0.5% and the grade was measured to be a -6.1%. The driveway is made to simulate a small bridge. There was no construction in the area. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The intersection was illuminated by overhead spot lamps that were
illuminated, with the exception of the one on the NW corner where the crash took place. It was malfunctioning and kept turning on and off. The weather was partly cloudy with no measurable wind. The temperature was +60 degrees F.	The rider of MC1 was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. The crash occurred in Southern California in October of 2014 at 2138 hrs. Traffic conditions were light. MC1 was towed.
 
MC1 was a 2012 Yamaha YZF R6 (599cc) sport/racing type motorcycle with modifications. The modifications were the front turn signals, taillight/stop lamp, exhaust, and the removal of the rear turn signals. The windshield was missing after the crash, along with all the gauges and headlights, and some of the fairing and side covers. The 18 year old male (5?06?/130 lbs.) rider was wearing a full face style helmet with a clear face shield. The helmet had markings indicating that it met FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and ECE-22-05 safety ratings. The rider was wearing a chest/spine protector over a t-shirt, blue jeans, tennis shoes, and armored nylon gloves. The helmet was ejected upon impact with OV1. The rider stated that he only snapped the chin strap and did not put it through the double ?D? rings. MC1 was westbound in the #1 (left) lane on his way from a friend?s house to another friend?s house. He was riding at a stated constant speed of approximately 45 mph. He stated that he saw the OV pulling out from the driveway, but he did not attempt to slow down. He stated that the OV immediately went wide in his turn and went out to the #1 lane. At that time, the rider began to brake hard and stated that he skidded with his rear tire before impacting the left rear of the OV. The rider stated that he was fully ejected and that his helmet flew off his head. The rider stated that he was unconscious and woke up as he was being loaded into the ambulance. He stated that he went unconscious again and woke up in the hospital. The 49 year old male (6?01?/180 lbs.) operator of OV1 stated that he was making a right turn into the #3 lane. He then signaled to move left into the #2 lane, and then into the #1 lane when he
heard the impact. OV1 was moved from its FRP prior to the police arriving. MC1 and the rider were found in the street. MC1 was on its right side plane. MC1 left approximately 33? of rear wheel locked skid prior to impacting OV1. MC1 traveled approximately 43? after impact. The rider was launched above ride height
and then skidded/slid a total of 81?03? from the POI.
RiderInj: The 18 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of numerous lacerations and a concussion. The rider stated that he lost consciousness twice. He was treated at the scene and taken to a hospital where he was treated and released. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 49 year old male operator of OV1 was not injured and did not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human:
The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 approaching the intersection and a decision failure in not properly making a right turn. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
The rider of MC1 had a reaction failure in not slowing down sooner and in poor application of the brakes. The rider has only been riding less than 2 weeks and has very little experience. He completed a basic safety rider course less than a month before buying his crash motorcycle.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front end from impacting OV1. MC1 also sustained major damage to both sides from impacting the roadway surface. It appears that MC1 may have flipped upside down at some point in the crash. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered good.

OV1 was not inspected. The damage was listed as moderate to the left rear area in the police accident report. OV1 was driven away from the scene.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1), right front to left side sideswipe type minor injury crash event with a low side right lay down impact of the motorcycle on to the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected vaulted over the front of the other vehicle and onto the roadway surface. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event resulting in minor injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Saturday, October 2014 at 1456 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed partly cloudy skies, a south wind direction @ 8.1 mph, and an ambient temperature of +90.9 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be sharp, polished and in satisfactory condition. There was a 0.0% grade and 3.4% crown in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred in the southbound #1 lane of a straight eight lane principal arterial (non-freeway) state highway with and overall travel way width of 115 feet. The crash site was located underneath an interstate freeway bridge (overpass). The north and southbound lanes are divided by a 20 foot wide raised concrete median with metal guard rails a series of 13 5? diameter concrete bridge pylons.
There are no bicycle lanes provided on either side of the roadway and parking is prohibited. The northbound portion of the roadway is not involved with this crash event.
The posted speed limit is 45 mph for both north and southbound traffic. There is a four way signal controlled intersection approximately 250 feet south of the crash site which was not part of the crash event.

MC1 was a 2002 Suzuki model SV650S sport race replica style motorcycle. MC1 was being operated by a 25 year old male. The rider was traveling southbound lane splitting between the #1 and #2 through lanes at a speed of about 15-20mph.	The rider was on his way to work and was not in a hurry however was attempting to pass the slower southbound traffic.	When OV1 encroached across the #2 and #1 lane line the rider was in such proximity to OV1 that he had insufficient time to stop or commit to any type of collision avoidance maneuver. The rider attributed this to the lack of clear visibility of the traffic ahead of him. He said that just behind OV1 was a large SUV that obstructed his view of OV1 making the lane change. When asked about braking or departing his position into either the #1 or #2 lanes, thee rider told me that both lanes were occupied by vehicles directly adjacent to him.
OV1 was a 2012 Mini Cooper automobile being operated by a 40 year old male. At the time of the crash event the driver was traveling southbound in the #3
 
lane at a speed of about 10 mph. The driver was also in the process of changing lanes from the #3 lane across the #2 lane with the intent to enter the southbound #1 lane. The driver said that as he moved his vehicle across the lanes he continually looked over his left shoulder to see if it was clear to enter. However, as he entered the #1 lane he felt an impact and observed the rider flying over the hood of his vehicle.
As a result of the impact between the two-vehicles MC1 collapsed onto the roadway surface right side down. The rider was ejected off the bike impacting the roadway surface and came to rest approximately 21 feet south of the original area of impact.
RiderInj: The 25 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of impacting OV1 and the roadway surface. The injuries included	a contusion to the right leg and a contusion to the right ankle. The rider was transported to a local area hospital for treatment and released later the same day. There was no evidence of alcohol or drugs present in his system.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured as a result of this crash event and, there was no evidence of alcohol or drugs present in his system.
Human:
The 25 year old rider of MC1 appears to have been operating his motorcycle at a speed relative to surrounding traffic however, was lane splitting and was unaware of the hazards of moving traffic changing lanes. The rider had a motorcycle permit only, no permanent endorsement, and had not attended any type of recognized training.
The driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision in moving his vehicle into the adjacent lane in front of MC1.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor right front and left side damage as a result of the crash however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 sustained minor damage in the area of the left front quarter panel as a result of this crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile turning left
Crash:
This two-vehicle motorcycle crash occurred in October 2014 at approximately 1705 hours in Southern California.	It was twilight and clear; the temperature was approximately 79 degrees F and the winds were WNW at approximately 8 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred at a 4 way intersection, in a commercial/residential area, on a north/south undivided roadway separated by double yellow painted center lines. There is a bike lane, 2 through lanes and a left turn lane in each direction. The left turn lanes are 10 ft. wide, the #1 lanes are 11 ft. wide and the #2 lanes are 15 ft. wide.	The left turn and through lanes are separated by a 4 ft. wide painted divider.	There is a non-involved 22ft. wide residential driveway on the east side of the intersection and a 4 lane commercial driveway on the west side. The 2 westbound entrance lanes are 12 ft. wide; the 2 eastbound lanes are a left and right turn lanes that are also 12 ft. wide. The east and westbound lanes are separated by a 4 ft. wide 8 in. raised planted divider.	The southbound grade is 0.5 % and the crown 7.7 %, with a speed limit of 45 mph.
MC1 is a 2012 Honda CBR250R (249cc) Sport/race replica motorcycle ridden by a 46 year old male (6 ft. 1 in. and 195 lbs.) and a 15 year old male (5 ft. 7 in. and 160 lbs.) passenger seated directly behind the rider. The rider was wearing an HJC, open-faced IS-33 helmet; the passenger was wearing a full-face Scorpion EXO-70 helmet.	MC1 was traveling southbound in the #1 lane at approximately 35 mph, approaching the intersection.	OV1 was traveling northbound in the left turn lane, stopped north of the limit line waiting for a vehicle to clear the intersection before making a left turn into the commercial driveway. Once the vehicle passed OV1, OV1 began her turn then saw MC1 in the #1 lane. The driver stated that she tried to speed up to clear the intersection, but was struck by MC1. The rider of MC1 observed OV1 starting her turn and braked hard and slowed to approximately 20 mph before striking OV1 in the right rear.	The Point of Impact (POI) was approximately 29 ft. 7 in. east of the south curb-line and approximately 10 ft. south of the north curb-line.

MC1 fell onto its right side within 6 ft. of the POI, the rider landed west of MC1. The passenger of MC1 vaulted over the back of OV1 and landed on his back, an undetermined distance beyond OV1. OV1 continued into the driveway striking and mounting the right curb before continuing into the adjacent parking lot.
RiderInj:
The 46 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the emergency medical record:	abrasions to the
inner thighs, scrotum and 2nd Right finger.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) for the rider was 1. The 15 year-old male passenger of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related by his guardian, during the interview: abrasions to the back of the right hand and a contusion the right thigh. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) for the rider was 1.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured during this collision. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to perceive MC1 prior to starting her left turn.	The rider of MC1 made a decision failure by not attempting to move left behind OV1.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causation factors for this crash.
Environmental: A vehicle ahead of MC1 in the same lane may have blocked OV1?s view of MC1..

CrashType: MC1 was westbound negotiating a left curve at a constant speed in the #2 lane when the throttle began to accelerate. The beginner rider pulled in the clutch and began to brake when MC1 starts to wobble. The rider stated that she laid MC1 down intentionally to avoid impacting the curb. The rider stated that she held onto MC1 for a short distance before letting go. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred mid-block between intersections on a roadway that has a left curve in the rider?s direction. The roadway has two lanes in each direction with bicycle lanes. There is a painted center divider. The roadway is a non-freeway minor arterial made of asphalt composition that is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. The roadway has two lanes in each direction with bike lanes. There is a painted divider. Both sides of the roadway have trees and shrubbery. To the right is an uphill slope and to the left is a downhill slope. The crown was measured at 3.2% and the downgrade was measured at 2.3%.	The roadway has an east/west designation but is in a southwest/northeast orientation at the crash site. The crash took place in a section of roadway that has a
left curve for the rider. The radius of the curve was calculated to be 1250.5. The length of curve was measured at 1460?. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. Visibility was clear at ground level and unrestricted. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the WSW. The temperature was +77 degrees F. The rider held onto the downed motorcycle for a short distance before letting go and being fully ejected. The rider sustained minor injuries. The crash occurred in November of 2014 in Southern California at 1510 hrs.

MC1 was a 2014 Harley Davidson Sportster (1202cc) cruiser type motorcycle. The 50 year old female (5?09?/200 lbs.) rider was wearing a HJC half helmet with a short visor and prescription sun glasses. The helmet had markings indicating that it met FMVSS 218 (US DOT) safety ratings. The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. The rider was wearing a T-shirt, regular denim jeans, and motorcycle oriented boots. The rider was not wearing any gloves. The rider had completed a motorcycle safety course within the past 6 months and was a first time rider. Her motorcycle was purchased new and had 535 miles on it at the time of the crash. MC1 was westbound in the #2 (right) lane on her way home from a day ride with her boyfriend and another rider. The third rider had already left the group when the crash took place. The rider stated that she was riding in the rear position of a staggered formation with her
 
boyfriend cruising at about 35 mph. The crash occurred about two miles from the rider?s home. She stated that suddenly the accelerator started to rev up and she began to gain speed. She pulled in the clutch and applied the brakes. The motorcycle then began to wobble and she lost control. She intentionally laid MC1 down on its left side plane in an effort to avoid crashing into the curb. She stated that she held onto MC1 for a short distance until she realized that MC1 was headed for the curb. She did not want to hit the curb, so she let go. She then skidded/slid to her FRP. MC1 continued sliding away from her, impacted the curb and came to rest further down the road. MC1 was ridden to the rider?s home by one of the firefighters. The investigating officer stated in the accident report that when he checked the throttle it stuck one time. He determined that it was the throttle lock control (cruise control) that was possibly adjusted a little too tight. When MC1 was inspected 17 days after the crash, the throttle worked fine. The air pressure in both tires was below 50% the recommended pressure. This may have been contributory to the crash as the rider was negotiating a left curve and inadvertently accelerating and then braking, which could have caused some unstable conditions. The rider?s inexperience in how to respond to the mechanical failure was also contributory. MC1 skidded/slid on its side for a distance of approximately 109? which calculated to a speed of approximately 40 mph. Damage to MC1 was minimal and consisted of mostly minor scrapes. The rider was treated at the scene and then taken to a local hospital where she was treated and released.
RiderInj: The 50 year old female operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting mostly abrasions and one minor laceration. She displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit her ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a reaction failure of improperly responding to the conditions presented to her which were a combination of mechanical issues combined with speed and over-braking.
Vehicle: MC1 had very low air pressure in both tires which would be considered contributory to the unstable nature of MC1 while negotiating the curve and over-braking. The probable cause of the undesired increase in speed could be attributed to the throttle lock that the new rider was not familiar with. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered new.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Light Truck
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in November 2014 at approximately 1725 hours in Southern California.	It was dark with partly cloudy skies, the temperature was approximately 70 degrees F. and the winds were light from the southwest. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn with surface cracking and spalling. There was light traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial/small business area, on the southbound side of a two-way roadway. There is a two-way continuous left-turn lane approximately 42 ft. north of the Point of Impact (POI) that turns into a southbound left turn lane beyond that point.	North of the POI there is a single through lane in each direction with 2 through lanes on the northbound side south of the POI. The southbound grade is 1.0% and the crown is 2.4%. All measurements were taken from a reference point, a ground utility box, that?s approximately 7 ft. west of the north/south roadway and 160 ft. north of the east/west
roadway.
MC1 is a 2004 Suzuki SV-650S (645cc) Sport, race replica ridden by a 24 year old male (5 ft. 11 in. and 155 lbs.). The rider was wearing a V136 model VCAN full face motorcycle helmet. OV1 is a 2000 Toyota Tacoma SR5 driven by a 34 year old male (5 ft. 6 in. and 160 lbs.).	There was 1 minor child riding in OV1. All occupants of OV1 were reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was southbound at approximately 37 mph passing a vehicle that was merging into the southbound left turn lane as MC1 was merging right into the right turn lane. The rider stated he was in the vehicles blind spot. OV1 was northbound in the #1 lane where the driver stopped before making a left into a commercial driveway. The driver of OV1 stated he saw the headlights of a vehicle southbound about 100 yards away and decided he had enough time to make his turn. OV1 started the left turn and slowed before entering the driveway. The rider of MC1 saw OV1 crossing the southbound lane braked hard and started to slide just before hitting OV1 in the right rear side at the bumper Point of Impact. OV1 continued into the driveway and MC1 fell on its left side and sliding low side to its Final Rest Position (FRP). The rider made contact with the rear bumper of OV1 and came off MC1 when it fell to the roadway and he slid to his FRP.
RiderInj: The 24 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related in the interview: right distal open femur fracture, right proximal fractures of the tibia/fibula and multiple abrasions and contusions of his external skin. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 10. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to perceive MC1 and attempted to make a left turn in front of MC1, leaving MC1 insufficient time to safely stop to prevent this accident.	The rider of MC1 had a reaction failure in braking without attempting to move left around the back of OV1.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) sideswipe type crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact a raised concrete curb and the roadway surface.	The rider (MCR) was ejected off of the motorcycle	and impacted the roadway surface suffering minor injuries.
MV1: 2013 Kawasaki Ninja ZX-6R 636cc (Sport Race, replica), white
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event. The collision occurred during daylight hours on Wednesday October 2014 at 1650 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1809 hours on this day. The weather report for 1658 hours showed scattered clouds, with a SSW wind direction at 6.9 mph. There was an ambient temperature of 77.4 degrees F. Visibility was 10.0 miles and at ground level it was clear and unobstructed in all directions.	The roadway for MC1 had a 0.2% uphill grade with a 5.3% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? T-intersection of a E/W minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 83 feet and a driveway accessing a retail/commercial shopping center that was open to the public. The N/S driveway was approximately 38 feet wide allowing for ingress and egress of vehicular traffic into the shopping center.
The roadway is straight and runs east and west with three lanes dedicated for northbound and three lanes dedicated for southbound traffic. There is a four way signal controlled intersection approximately 138 feet east of the crash site however it is not involved in the crash event.
There is a 10 foot wide painted two way left turn lane separating the east and westbound lanes of traffic. There are no designated ?Bike? lanes, electronic or posted traffic control devices in proximity of the crash site. The north and south sides of the minor arterial roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and adjoining 8 foot wide concrete sidewalks.
Both sides of the roadway are occupied by independent retail/commercial shopping centers open to the public. The posted speed limit for both east and westbound traffic is 45 mph.
MC1 was a 2013 Kawasaki Ninja ZX-6R (636cc) sport race replica motorcycle being operated by a 22 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an AFX model FX-90 DOT/UN/ECE-22-05 approved full face motorcycle helmet. The rider was operating his motorcycle with a Valid California Driver?s license endorsed for the operation of motorcycles. The rider was traveling at an approximate speed of 40-45 mph eastbound in the #3 lane. As he was approaching the T-intersection (driveway) he moved from the #3 lane into the #2 eastbound lane to go around a bus which was stopped in the #3 lane. The rider continued eastbound in the #2 lane.
 
OV1 was a 2006 Toyota Highlander (SUV) being operated by a 72 year old male driver. The OVD was driving northbound towards the roadway intending to exit the shopping center. When the OVD stopped at the driveway he moved his vehicle onto the roadway turning right with the intent of continuing eastbound. The OVD drove onto the roadway crossing the eastbound #3 lane and continued into the #2 lane when his vehicle was struck by MC1 along the left side from the driver?s side door to the left front fender.
The rider had continued eastbound in the #2 lane when OV1 pulled out of the driveway crossing the #3 eastbound lane and encroached into the #2 lane. Seeing this, the rider attempted to brake and move to the left. The rider also attempted using the horn however OV1 continued crossing into the #2 lane. The right front portion of MC1 struck the left side of OV1 causing the rider to be ejected off the bike and onto the roadway surface in front of OV1.
The rider said that his motorcycle somehow remained upright and continued in a southeast direction where it impacted with the raised concrete curb and collapsed left side down onto the roadway.
Although the rider fell onto the roadway in front of OV1 there was no contact between him and the vehicle.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of the collision. The rider was treated at the scene and removed from the scene to a local hospital for treatment. The rider sustained a contusion to his right arm and leg as well as a fractured big toe to his right foot. He also sustained abrasions to his back and a sprain to the neck area. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The 72 year old male driver of OV1 was not injured and there was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 22 year old male rider of MC1 was operating his motorcycle at a speed safe for the present traffic on the roadway and could not react in time or conduct a proper collision avoidance maneuver prior to the crash.
The 72 year old male driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision to enter the roadway having failed to perceive the proximity of the approaching motorcycle while making his right turn.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor right front and left side damage as a result of impacting with	OV1 and the roadway surface.
The impact with the south curb simply stopped the motorcycle and was considered as a harmful event. The motorcycle otherwise appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained minor left side damage however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. SUV
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in November 2014 at 1855 hours in Southern California.	It was dark, mostly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 66 degrees F and the winds were WSW at approximately 3.5 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, with surface cracking and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred in a residential area on a predominately north/south oriented roadway at a T intersection with a left hand curve.	Northbound; there is an 11 ft. wide through lane and a 4 ft. wide bicycle lane.	Southbound there is a 15 ft. wide through lane, a 4 ft. wide bicycle lane and a 10 ft. wide left turn lane. The northbound grade is +1.5%; the crown is 2.8% and there are no traffic controls.	The left hand curve is approximately 370 ft. in length; the radius is approximately 596 ft.	The chord is 100 ft. with a 2 ft. middle ordinate. The east/west oriented roadway forms the base of the T intersection; each lane is 20 ft. wide. The westbound through lane has a stop sign at the limit line.	The downhill grade is approximately -10.7% with a crown of 1.3%.


All measurements were taken using a south running station line with the Reference Point (RP) being the east curb-line of the north/south roadway and the north curb-line of the east/west roadway.
MC1 is a 2014 Honda CBR 1000RR (999cc) sport/race replica style motorcycle ridden by a 42 year old male (5 ft. 10 in. and 200 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make and model of helmet. OV1 is a 2013 Acura MDX driven by a 41 year old female (5 ft. 1 in. and 120 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was northbound at approximately 30 mph approaching the intersection.	OV1 was westbound, where the driver stopped at the limit line, waiting to make a left turn. The driver of OV1 stated that she looked both ways then started her left turn and was struck by MC1 on the left side front tire/wheel.	The rider of MC1 saw OV1 starting her left turn and braked hard leaving approximately 23 ft. 2 in. of rear wheel skid before letting off on the brakes, releasing the skid.	The
 
skid began approximately 81.9 ft. south and 8.4 ft. west of the RP and ended approximately 58.7 ft. south and 8 ft. west of the RP. The Area of Impact (AOI) was approximately 29.10 ft. south and 7.3 ft. west of the RP.	OV1 continued west approximately 11.2 ft. with the rider of MC1 on the hood of OV1 where it came to rest. MC1 came to rest on its right side facing west; its Final Rest Position (FRP) was approximately 23 ft. south and 3 ft. west of the RP.
RiderInj: The 42 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related during a partial interview: right femur fracture (NFS). The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 9. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to give MC1 the right of way.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 and unable to determine OV1?s crash causal status, unable to view OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: MC1 was attempting to pass a vehicle on the right at a high speed and does not see OV1 in the next lane and rear-ends OV1. The rider was fully ejected and sustained moderate injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred mid-block between two 4-way intersections. The intersection that is north of the crash site has no controls for the north or south travel lanes. The cross streets are controlled by stop signs. The intersection that is south of the crash site is signal controlled. The roadway has three lanes in each direction and bike lanes. The roadway is straight and is divided by a solid double yellow line. The roadway is a non-freeway major arterial that bisects a single family residential neighborhood at the crash scene. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The crown was measured to be 7.7% and the grade was measured at 0.5%. The roadway has a north/south designation but is in a slight northeast/southwest orientation at the crash site. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The weather was clear with a slight breeze from the NNE. The temperature was +60 degrees F. The area was illuminated by overhead spot lamps that were illuminated. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. The crash occurred in Southern California in December of 2014 at 2056 hrs. Traffic conditions were light. MC1 was towed.

MC1 was a 1995 Triumph Thunderbird 900 (885cc) conventional type motorcycle with modifications. The known modifications are the passenger foot pegs, handlebars, and removal of the side reflectors. The 28 year old male (5?08?/140 lbs.) rider was wearing an open face helmet with a clear bubble face shield which was missing at the time of the helmet inspection. The helmet had markings indicating that it met FVMSS 218 (US DOT) safety ratings. The rider was wearing a heavy cotton jacket, jeans, heavy work boots, and full fingered leather gloves. The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. The rider gave two different versions of how the crash took place. In the police accident report he stated that the vehicle he was focused on was behind him and during the interview, he stated that it was in front of him. MC1 was southbound in the #2 (middle) lane on his way to a sporting event from home. He stated that there was a vehicle that was next to him a few blocks back at a signal. The rider stated that he had lane split between stopped vehicles at a red
 
light in order to get to the front of the line. The rider stated that he was between the #1 and #2 lanes. There was vehicle on his left in the #1 lane that rapidly accelerated upon receiving the green light. The rider stated that was in the #2 lane and passed that vehicle, then merged into the #1 lane. That other vehicle then passed him and got in front of him in the #1 lane. The rider stated that he then accelerated to pass that vehicle. The rider stated that he started to merge over to his right, into the #2 lane and was doing a head check on that other vehicle. When the rider looked forward, he stated he then saw OV1 just ahead of him in the #2 lane. The rider stated that he attempted to brake and swerve right to avoid the OV, but impacted the right rear of it and went down. The rider stated that he may have been going up to 60 mph just before the impact. The 17 year old male (5?11?/195 lbs.) driver of the Acura stated that he was driving at a constant speed when he was hit from behind. He stated that he was unaware of any other vehicle on the roadway at the time of the crash. In the police accident report the rider stated that just prior to the crash the other vehicle that he was focused on had changed lanes and was behind him. There was no evidence of any evasive maneuvers prior to the impact from either vehicle involved in the crash. The rider was fully ejected. Both the rider and MC1 skidded/slid to their FRPs. MC1 had damage on all sides. From the scrape marks found on MC1, it appears to have been sliding on its right side plane, high side first for the majority of its slide. The broken left side foot peg and damaged shifter appears to have been caused by the initial impact with OV1. It is unknown what MC1?s orientation was at the completion of the crash.
RiderInj: The 28 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor to moderate injuries consisting of a closed fracture of the distal tibia and fibula, and multiple abrasions. He was treated at the scene and taken to a hospital where he was treated and released. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 was distracted and had a perception failure in not seeing OV1 directly in front of him.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate front end and left side damage from rear-ending OV1 to the right rear and moderate damage to the right side from impacting and sliding on the roadway surface.	The foot peg and shifter were broken or damaged as a result of the impact with OV1. The rear brake pedal was ground down as was the right hand grip and handlebar. The mirrors had been removed by the rider prior to the crash. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered fair.

OV1 was not inspected. It would appear based on the police accident report and the damage located on MC1, that OV1 should have damage to the right rear area. The accident report listed the damage as minor and that OV1 was driven away.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a single vehicle motorcycle (MC1) vs. roadway minor injury crash event. MC1 collapsed left side down after the rider over-braked for traffic, causing him to be ejected onto the roadway.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. roadway left side impact crash event resulting in minor injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Tuesday, December 2014 at 0717 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 0653 hours showed overcast skies, calm wind conditions with intermittent rain showers. The ambient temperature was +64.0 degrees F and sunrise was at 0639 hours. Although it was raining, visibility at ground level was clear and unrestricted for 10.0 miles. The roadway surface was found to be wet of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred on the westbound portion of a straight and level principal arterial roadway with a travel way width with of 82 feet. This is a east/west principal arterial roadway with three lanes dedicated for eastbound traffic and three lanes for westbound traffic. The eastbound portion of this roadway is uninvolved in the crash event. The east and westbound lanes are separated by a 3 foot wide raised concrete and brick median. In the area of the crash site the roadway is intersected on the south side by a 28 foot wide driveway allowing for ingress and egress into a commercial/retail shopping center.
There are no traffic controls present at this T-intersection other than a posted ?STOP? sign for northbound traffic exiting the shopping center. Just west of the intersection there is a 10 foot wide ?right turn? only lane allowing eastbound traffic access into the center.
There are no bicycle lanes on either side of the roadway and parking is prohibited. The posted speed limit for both directions is 40 mph.
On both sides of the roadway there are retail & commercial businesses. Both the north and south sides of this roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and 8 foot wide raised concrete sidewalks. The nearest signal controlled intersection to	is a four way intersection east of the crash site that is regulated by electronic signal controls however it is not involved with this crash event.

MC1 was a 2013 Honda PCX150 scooter being operated by a 45 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a ?Seven-Zero-Seven?, Vendetta 3 model, full face FMVSS218 (US DOT) approved motorcycle helmet with a double ?D? ring nylon chin strap (mfg. date: 05-2012). The helmet was equipped with a gray smoke plastic face shield and weighed approximately 61.15 ounces.
The rider was traveling westbound in the #1westbound lane prior to the crash event. Traffic conditions at the time were moderate with no visual obstructions or road work issues at the time.
 
The rider was proceeding westbound and his speed was about 30mph/44fps. The surrounding westbound traffic was at a distance of about 45-60 feet in front of his position. As the rider continued westbound he noticed that the traffic ahead of him was rapidly slowing down. The rider reacted to this sudden slowdown by applying the brakes hard. The result of this application of the brakes caused the scooter to lose control on the wet roadway surface and collapse left side down. When the scooter collapsed, the rider initially stayed with the vehicle however was ejected onto the roadway surface sustaining a puncture style injury to his left leg possibly from the brake lever. The scooter slid for a distance of about 45 feet before coming to rest between the #1 and #2 westbound lanes. The rider rolled or slid a distance of about 25 feet from the initial area of impact, and came to rest inside the #1 westbound lane.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians or, animals	that caused or contributed to the event. The intermittent rain showers created poor surface adhesion to the roadway surface however there were no roadway design issues at or near the location of the crash site.
RiderInj: The 45 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of this crash event. The injuries consisted of a contusion to the left arm, a puncture type injury to the left thigh and, a puncture injury to the left foot. The rider was treated at the scene and transported to a local hospital where he was admitted for treatment. The rider showed no evidence of drug and/or alcohol use.
Human: Although the 45 year old male rider of MC1 was driving at a speed safe for the present traffic and environmental conditions (rain) on the roadway his panic application of the brakes caused him to lose control of the scooter and collapse ontot he roadway surface.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: Intermittent rain showers were determined to have contributed to the cause of the collision however were not the primary issue.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) broadside type crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface.	The rider (MCR) was ejected off of the motorcycle vaulting over the other vehicle and impacting the roadway surface suffering serious injuries.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event. The collision occurred during the hours of darkness on Monday December 2014 at 1815 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1644 hours on this day. The weather report for 1853 hours showed clear skies, with calm wind conditions. There was an ambient temperature of 61.0 degrees F. Visibility was 10.0 miles and at ground level it was clear and unobstructed in all directions.	The roadway surface for MC1 had a 0.7% uphill grade with a 0.8% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? T-intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 101 feet and retail/commercial pool supply store that was open to the public. The driveway was approximately 38 feet wide allowing for ingress and egress of vehicular traffic into the parking area. The roadway is straight and runs north and south with three lanes dedicated for northbound and three lanes dedicated for southbound traffic.
In the area of the crash site the #3 southbound lane incorporates with the #2 lane to create one southbound #2 lane.
There is a 20 foot wide painted two way left turn lane separating the north and southbound lanes of traffic. This opens up to two ?left turn only? lanes north of the crash site. There are no designated ?Bike? lanes, electronic or posted traffic control devices in proximity of the crash site. The east and west sides of the minor arterial street are bordered by raised concrete curbs and adjoining 8 foot wide concrete sidewalks.
On the west side of the roadway is occupied by independent retail/commercial stores. The east side of the roadway is occupied by retail/commercial stores as well as a pet hospital. The posted speed limit for both north and southbound traffic is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2009 Kawasaki Ninja 250R (249cc) sport race replica motorcycle being operated by an 18 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a DOT/Snell M2010 approved full face motorcycle helmet. The rider was operating his bike outside of his license classification which prohibited the operation of a motorcycle after the hours of darkness. The rider had accelerated to an estimated speed of approximately 40-45 mph, southbound in the designated #2 lane of the minor arterial street approaching the T-intersection and OV1.
 
OV1 was a 2006 Mitsubishi Lancer ES (automobile) being operated by a 56 year old female driver. The OVD was initially approaching the intersection in the northbound #1 lane however, changed into the two way left turn lane intending to turn left into the pool supply store. OVD had been moving at approximately 5-10 mph and had continued at this speed throughout the intended left turn movement into the driveway. Once the OVD believed the southbound lanes to be clear of traffic she made her left turn movement. OV1 crossed the southbound #1 lane and began to cross the #2 lane when MC1 impacted it along the right side of the vehicle at the B-Pillar. The OVD was not injured by the crash and completed her left turn driving into the parking lot of the store.
The rider had been southbound in the #2 lane accelerating to a speed of about 40-45mph. The rider saw OV1 in the two-way left turn lane however did not anticipate the left turn movement of the vehicle. When OV1 turned the rider attempted to slow down or stop by using his front brake as this was evident by the discovery of approximately 13 feet of pre-impact locked skid marks. The rider told me he had no other option due to the fact that there vehicles occupying the #1 and #3 lanes on either side of him. MC1 struck the right side of OV1in an upright position at the right side B-Pillar.
The resulting impact vaulted the rider off the motorcycle causing his face & helmet to impact the roof line and pivot over the top of OV1. The rider fell to his feet adjacent to the driver side of OV1. MC1 collapsed left side down onto the roadway surface at the area of impact.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 18 year old male rider of MC1 sustained serious facial injuries as a result of the collision. The rider was immediately removed from the scene to a local hospital for treatment. The impact with the roof area of OV1 caused several facial fractures to the nose and orbital sockets of the skull as well as lacerations to the forehead and bridge of the nose. The rider also complained of pain to his right knee, back and genitals. There was evidence of significant collapse of the gas tank forward of the rider?s seat. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The 56 year old female driver of OV1 was not injured. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 18 year old male rider of MC1 could not react in time or conduct a proper collision avoidance maneuver prior to the crash. His efforts in bringing his motorcycle to a stop by utilizing what appeared to be front braking only was insufficient.	The rider was operating his motorcycle outside of the license restrictions which prohibited operation of the vehicle after the hours of darkness. The rider may have lacked sufficient training and or experience in similar situations that would require the application of proper collision avoidance maneuvers.
The 56 year old female driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision having failed to perceive the proximity of the approaching motorcycle while making her left turn.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front end and left side damage as a result of impacting with the OV1 and the roadway surface. The motorcycle otherwise appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained moderate right side damage however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Roadside environment
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred in December 2014 at 1120 hours in Southern California.	It was daylight with scattered clouds, variable light winds and the temperature was approximately 68 degrees F.	The asphalt roadway surface was dry with surface cracking. There was light traffic.

The crash occurred on an undivided, right hand curving section of predominately east/west local roadway with single-family homes on the north and south sides of the roadway. There are two lanes in each direction separated by a painted double yellow center line.	The #2 lanes are 20 ft. wide and the #1 lanes
are 12 ft. wide.	There is an uphill westbound grade of 2.8% before the first Point of Impact (POI) and a crown of 5.4%.	The speed limit is 40 mph. The Reference Point (RP) is a Man-Hole-Cover that is approximately 820 ft. east of the east curb line of the north/south roadway and approximately 3 ft. south of the
east/west roadway.
MC1 is a 2009 BMW GS-1200 Adventure (1170cc) motorcycle ridden by a 61 year old male (5 ft. 9 in. and 201 lbs.). The rider was wearing an adult x-large XD-4 model full-face motocross Arai helmet with a clear polycarbonate face-shield.

MC1 was westbound negotiating the right hand curve, when witnesses saw the rider slump over the handlebars. MC1 continued straight, crossing the eastbound lanes striking the curb. This caused MC1 and the rider to be launched into the air striking a 6 ft. tall brick wall set back from the curb approximately 7 ft., OV1 traveled approximately 21 ft. west, hitting the wall and then sliding approximately 51 ft. west to its Point of Rest (POR) in the road facing west against the curb on its left side. The rider traveled approximately 36 ft. struck the wall and then traveled another 5 ft. to his POR, adjacent to the west side of the man-hole-cover (RP).
RiderInj:
The 61 year old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related in the medical examiners record:	complete transection of the spine at L1, Subdural hemorrhage at L1, bilateral anterior rib fractures (4 on the right and 3 on the left), abrasions and hematoma to external skin.
 
Although it cannot be determined as a possible cause of death, all coronary arteries were 100 % blocked at the time of the autopsy. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 35. Neither drugs or alcohol were present at the time of the accident.
Human: The rider of MC1 may have had a medical emergency that would have been a crash causal factor. Witnesses observed the rider slumped over the handlebars of MC1 before it crossed the road and impacted the raised curb.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors for MC1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: Solo rider crashes mid-block for no apparent reason. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries.
Crash:
This crash occurred mid-block on a straight roadway that has three lanes in each direction with a continuous two-way left turn lane. The roadway is a non- freeway major arterial. The nearest cross street was measured to be 343? west of the crash site. The roadway has commercial/retail on the north side. The south side has single family residential homes separated by a block wall from the roadway. Both sides of the roadway have concrete sidewalks. The roadway
is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has a crown of 5.3% and a grade of 0.6% The roadway has an east/west designation and is in that orientation at the crash site. MC1 was traveling westbound at an unknown speed in the #1 lane. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The crash took place in Southern California in December of 2014 at 0923 hrs. The weather was clear and the wind was light from the east. The temperature was +59 degrees.
Traffic conditions were light. MC1 was towed.

MC1 was a 2013 Honda CBR 250R (249cc) sport/racing type motorcycle. The 19 year old male (5?10?/145 lbs.) rider was wearing unknown clothing. He was wearing a Bilt full face helmet with face shield and integral chin bar. It had markings that showed it met FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and ECE 22-04 safety ratings. It is unknown if the helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. MC1 was westbound in the #1 lane at an unknown speed when he lost control.
On the rider?s right is commercial/retail. To his left is single family residential. In the police accident report, the rider stated that he was eastbound headed
to an unknown location. He stated that he did not remember how fast he was going or if there was any other traffic on the roadway. Debris was located by the investigating officer in the westbound #1 and #2 lanes. There were no pre-impact tire marks from MC1 that would indicate that he was trying to avoid another vehicle. There were no road or weather conditions that could be considered as contributory to the crash. MC1 had damage that was high to the rear portion which seems to indicate that MC1 was in a position with the front wheel up in the air when the rider lost control. MC1 also had damage to both sides indicating that it was flipping from side to side before coming to rest. MC1 skidded/slid for an unknown distance before coming to rest. A witness saw MC1
 
flipping on the roadway and saw a vehicle driving away very fast. The witness speculated that this car may have been involved in the crash because it drove away fast. There were no other witnesses or evidence that would indicate that another vehicle was involved in the crash. When MC1 was inspected, both tires were severely underinflated. It is unknown if this was a contributing factor in the crash. In the police accident report, the rider is listed as not have a motorcycle endorsement and was not the registered owner. MC1 had only 262 miles on it. Immediately to the right of the crash scene is a motorcycle sales and repair facility. There was speculation on the part of the police that the rider had just exited from the driveway east of the crash site and either intentionally or accidentally raised the front tire up into the air and then lost control. Since there were no witnesses and the rider was not cooperative, this information was not a part of the official accident report.
RiderInj: The 19 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of an abrasion to his left shin and a complaint of pain to his right shoulder. He was treated at the scene and taken to a hospital where he was treated and released. The rider displayed no signs of impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a decision failure in attempting a wheelie and not being able to control MC1. He did not have a motorcycle license, indicating that he most likely had very little riding experience which would be a contributing factor.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate damage to the rear section and both sides from impacting the roadway surface and flipping. MC1 was found on its left side plane, which means that it landed on its right side plane before flipping and sliding to its FRP. The low tire pressure may have been a contributing factor to the crash. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition would be considered new.
Environmental: There are no permanent or temporary environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a vehicle OV1 vs. OV2 rear end type collision resulting in secondary impacts involving one other vehicle: OV3 and a motorcycle: MC1. There was a secondary impact involving OV1 and OV3. There was also a secondary impact involving OV2 and MC1. The resulting primary and secondary impact caused OV1 to overturn and collapse upside down onto the roadway surface. The resulting primary and secondary impact caused OV2 to impact MC1 ejecting the rider and careen off onto a local cross street. The rider of MC1 was ejected off his bike and onto the roadway surface.	MC1 collapsed onto the roadway surface coming to rest across to the south side of the intersection. There was another vehicle: OV4 that was not struck by any of the involved vehicles however did sustain minimal damage from flying debris. The driver of OV1 sustained fatal injuries along with multiple injuries sustained by the driver of OV2, OV3 and the two occupants of OV3 (complaints of pain only). The rider of MC1 sustained no injuries in this crash event. There were no passengers on MC1.
MV1: (MC1) 2001 Honda XR650L (dual purpose) motorcycle (644cc), red in color
OV2:
(OV2) 2013 Nissan Frontier (Pick-up truck), black in color (OV3) 2010 Lexus RX350 (automobile derivative), blue in color
(OV4) 2014 Honda Civic (automobile), black in color (debris damage only)
Crash:
This was a multiple vehicle multiple primary and secondary impact crash event occurring during the daylight hours on Friday, December 2014 at 1052 hours in Southern California.
