The weather report for this region showed partly cloudy skies, with calm wind conditions and an ambient temperature of 62.8 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed for all directions of travel. The roadway surface was dry, level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred on a straight, multi-lane minor arterial roadway with an ?at grade? four leg intersection. The intersection is controlled by a multi- phase traffic control signal. There are two lanes dedicated for southbound traffic and three lanes for northbound traffic.	The opposing lanes are separated by one set of solid double yellow lines painted on the roadway. There are two designated left turn lanes for southbound to eastbound traffic allowing access into to a major shopping mall. There is also a designated left turn lane for northbound traffic to access a residential neighborhood to the west of the intersection. Each side of the minor arterial roadway contains marked 6 foot wide ?Bike Lanes?. The roadway has an overall travel way width of 72 feet. The northbound lanes of the roadway as well as the entire roadway south and east of the intersection are not involved with this crash event.
There is a posted speed limit of 40 mph for both north and southbound traffic. There were no super elevation issues with this roadway. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.
 
OV1 was traveling southbound in the designated #2 lane at a speed of about 31 mph (on board computer data) in a 2002 Toyota Camry. OV1 was being operated by a 73 year old male driver. OV2 was stopped southbound in the designated #2 lane (in second position) in a 2013 Nissan Frontier Pick-up truck and was stopped behind MC1 at the intersection. The case vehicle MC1 was a 2001 Honda XR650L dual purpose motorcycle being operated by a 27 year old male rider. The rider was stopped southbound in the #2 lane at first position at the limit line of the intersection. OV3 was stopped southbound in the designated #1 lane in first position at the limit line. OV3 was being operated by a 63 year old female driver and there were two passengers riding with her. OV4 was stopped southbound in the designated #2 left turn lane in first position at the limit line. OV4 was being operated by a 37 year old female driver. All vehicles (except OV1) were stopped for a red phased signal light for southbound traffic at the intersection.
Engagement:
As OV1 continued southbound in the #2 lane it struck the left rear portion of OV2. The resulting impact between these two-vehicles caused the following chain reaction:
Upon impact, OV2 was thrust into a forced acceleration speed of approximately 22 mph (on board computer data) causing it to impact the rear of MC1 pushing the motorcycle into and across the intersection. The rider was ejected onto the roadway surface however he got up and moved out of the roadway under his own power. OV2 then slid in a southwest direction approximately 72 feet onto the adjacent residential cross street.	This was evident by scuff marks left from the right rear tire.
After hitting OV2, OV1 launched to the left and impacted the right rear portion of OV3 (stopped S/B #1 lane in 1st position). The resulting impact caused OV3 to be thrust into the intersection at a forced acceleration of about 15 mph. OVD3 however was able to control her vehicle and move it to the side of the roadway.
RiderInj: The 27 year old male rider sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.	The rider was wearing an unknown style motorcycle helmet.
ODriverInj:
OVD1: The driver sustained fatal injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries included but were not limited to a transected Aorta, subdural Hematoma and, a hemorrhage to the left ventricle of the heart. The Coroner?s Autopsy indicated that the driver may have suffered a heart attack either prior to or at the time of the crash. The report also indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the driver?s system.

OVD2: The driver sustained a collapsed right lung. He was treated at the scene and taken to a local area hospital where he was later released the same day. The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the driver?s system.OVD3: The driver sustained a complaint of pain to her neck and back area as did her two passengers. All three were taken from the scene to a local area
 
hospital for X-rays and then released.	The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the driver?s system. OVD4: The driver sustained no injuries as a result of this crash event.
Human:
The 73 year old male driver of OV1 had been traveling at a speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway. The driver may have suffered a heart attack prior to the crash.
The 24 year old male driver of OV2 was stopped in traffic at the time of the crash and subsequently did not contribute to the cause or outcome of the event. The 27 year old male rider of MC1 was stopped in traffic at the time of the crash and subsequently did not contribute to the cause or outcome of the event. The 63 year old female driver of OV3 was stopped in traffic at the time of the crash and subsequently did not contribute to the cause or outcome of the event. The 37 year old female driver of OV4 was stopped in traffic at the time of the crash and subsequently did not contribute to the cause or outcome of the event.
Vehicle:
OV1 sustained total damage as a result of the collision but appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
OV2 sustained major rear end damage as a result of the collision but appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. MC1 sustained minor rear and left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
OV3 sustained major right rear damage as a result of the collision but appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV4 sustained minimal right side damage as a result of debris from the collision and was in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. SUV
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in December 2014 at 0906 hours in Southern California. It was clear with bright sunlight, the temperature was approximately 54 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred in a residential/apartment area, westbound on a predominately east/west oriented roadway. There are two 11 ft. travel lanes and a 12 ft. wide bicycle lane in both directions. The westbound pre-crash grade is -2.7% with a crown of 5.3%.	The grade at the crash location is -0.8% with a crown of 5.1%. The south side was uninvolved in this accident. All measurements were taken using an east running station line with the Reference Point (RP) being the east curb-line of the north/south roadway and the north curb-line of east/west roadway.

MC1 is a 2006 Suzuki GSXR-600 (599cc) cruiser style motorcycle ridden by a 23 year old male (5 ft. 10 in. and 190 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown model, full-face Shoei helmet. OV1 is a 2005 Lexus RX 330 driven by a 55 year old female (5 ft. 7 in. and 142 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

OV1 made a right turn into the #2 lane of the east/west roadway heading westbound at an unknown speed. Driver stated she saw no oncoming traffic as she made her right turn. MC1 was westbound in the #2 lane overtaking OV1 at an unknown high rate of speed. MC1 sideswiped the left side of the rear bumper, leaving a black paint transfer on OV1. The rider of MC1 lost control.	This caused MC1 and the rider to fall to the roadway on their left side and slide an unknown distance to their FRPs. The driver of OV1 was unaware of the collision and stopped to render assistance to MC1 which she saw sliding on the roadway to her left. The Area of Impact was determined by the statement of the MC1 rider, as being approximately 100 ft. east of the east curb-line and approximately 6 ft. south of the north curb-line.
RiderInj:
The 23 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as observed from police photographs: left leg laceration and
 multiple anterior/posterior abrasions. A BAC of 0.10 was recorded 15 minutes after crash. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1.
Human: The rider of MC1 was unable to avoid the crash due to alcohol/drug involvement. The rider had a BAC of 0.10, 15 minutes after the crash.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 and OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Roadway
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred in January 2014 at 0856 hrs, in Southern California.	It was daylight, clear, the temperature was approximately 47 degrees F and the winds were approximately 3.5 mph from the ESE. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and noted to be in good condition. There was light traffic.

The crash occurred on the southbound side of a predominately north/south straight roadway that has a 13 ft. wide median planted with trees and ground cover.	The northbound side was not involved in the crash. Southbound, there is a 14 ft. wide shoulder, travel lane #2 is 12 ft. and travel lane #1 is 13 ft. wide. The grade is 0.1%, the crown is 4.0% and there are no traffic controls.
MC1 is a 2007 Suzuki GSXR 1000 (999cc) motorcycle ridden by a 26 year old male (6 ft. 1 in. and 200 lbs.). The rider was wearing an adult XL HJC FG-17 motorcycle helmet.

MC1 was southbound in the #1 lane at approximately 72 mph, when the rider (in his words) ?spaced out? thinking about ?work, money and legal issues? and rode into the center divider. A blood test was performed approximately 32 minutes after the crash; marijuana and cocaine was found in the rider?s system. MC1 impacted the curb face, which caused MC1 to fall onto its left side and slide for approximately 264.5 ft. along the curb-face to its Final Rest Position (FRP). The rider was ejected, tumbled and slid for approximately 81.5 ft. along the center median curb-face to his FRP.	The rider was lying face down in the roadway facing south.
RiderInj: The 26 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related in the medical report:	subdural and subarachnoid hemorrhages, traumatic brain injury with altered level of consciousness and abrasions NFS. Marijuana and cocaine was found during a blood test.
Human: The rider of MC1 had marijuana and cocaine in his system which contributed to his attention failure.	This caused him to drift left into the center median.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: MC1 was eastbound in the #1 lane when OV1 entered the roadway attempting to make a left turn from a shopping center driveway. MC1 impacted the left front side of OV1. The rider was fully ejected and sustained moderate injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a four-way type intersection that had no electronic signal controls during hours of daylight. OV1 was exiting a shopping center driveway on the south side of the intersection. On the north side of the intersection is a public roadway to a residential area. The roadway that MC1 was on is a minor arterial that has two lanes in each direction. In MC1s direction there is a dedicated left turn lane. The roadway has a curb high raised center divider. Both sides of the roadway have bike lanes. Both sides of the roadway have concrete sidewalks. Both the driveway and the other cross street have stop signs. The roadway is straight and level. The crown was measured at 2.0% and the grade was measured at +0.2%. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. The roadway has an east/west designation but is in a slight southeast/northwest orientation at the crash site.
MC1 was eastbound at 80 degrees. The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the SSW. The temperature was +61 degrees F. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The crash took place in Southern California in January of 2015 at 1356 hrs. Traffic conditions were moderate. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passengers. MC1 was towed. OV1 was driven away.

MC1 was a 2003 Kawasaki Vulcan VN800 (805cc) cruiser type motorcycle with modifications. The known modifications are the custom seat, and removal of the side reflectors. The 50 year old male (5?08?/180 lbs.) rider was wearing an unknown style helmet with unknown safety ratings. The rider was wearing unknown upper torso clothing, denim jeans, and over the ankle boots. It is unknown if the rider was wearing gloves. The rider of MC1 stated in the police accident report that he was eastbound in the #1 (left) lane at about 35 mph. He stated that while he was approaching the crash area, he saw OV1 exit the driveway from the shopping center. The rider stated that he was sure that the driver of OV1 saw him because he saw his head move and look in both
directions before pulling out. The rider stated that the driver of OV1 ?just came out? and that he was able to brake before impacting the side of OV1, but didn?t
 
think he was able to bleed off much of his speed. The 25 year old male operator (5?11?/165 lbs.) stated that he was going to make a left turn to go westbound. He said that he pulled out of the driveway and then he saw MC1 approaching eastbound in an unknown lane so he ?hit the brakes.? He stated that it looked as if MC1 was going to go around him but MC1 impacted the side of his car. He stated that the rider was ejected and went ?tumbling? across the hood. The operator of OV1 stated that there was a SUV or car in front of MC1. The rider of MC1 made no mention of a vehicle in front of him. There were no pre-impact skids from either vehicle. In one of the on-scene photos, it appears that MC1 is leaning against OV1. It is unknown if that is the actual FRP position of MC1 or if it was put in that position before being placed onto its side stand. After the crash, the rider was observed to be up and walking around. The driver of OV1 spoke briefly on the phone, but never submitted to an interview. He did provide via email some scene photographs.
RiderInj: The 50 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of an unknown type fracture of the distal forearm. He was treated at the scene and taken to a hospital. It is unknown if the rider was admitted or treated and released. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 approaching. There may have been a temporary view obstruction of an SUV in front of MC1.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front end damage from impacting the left side of OV1. MC1 also had damage to both sides. Damage on the right side was possibly caused by OV1. Damage on the left side would have been caused by the ground. MC1 had pre-existing damage on all sides which was evident from the unfinished repairs on the gas tank in which bondo was used, and numerous scratches with rust. MC1 sustained an approximate 4? reduction in wheelbase.
There was evidence that the front wheel/fender impacted the engine/radiator. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered fair.

OV1 was inspected from photographs provided by the operator. OV1 sustained damage to the left front side area. The damage was minor and OV1 was driven away.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) offset head-on type crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface and become captured underneath OV1. The rider was ejected off of the motorcycle and impacted with the side of OV1 and the roadway surface suffering serious injuries.
MV1: 2004 Yamaha YZF R1 (Sport Race, replica) (998cc), blue
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event. The collision occurred during daylight hours on Friday January 2015 at 0822 hours in Southern California. Sunrise was at 0657 hours on this day. The weather report for 0758 hours showed clear skies, with NNE winds at 2.3 mph. There was an ambient temperature of 38.5 degrees F. Visibility was 10.0 miles at ground level and, it was clear and unobstructed in all directions.	The roadway surface for MC1 had a 0.4% uphill grade with a 7.9% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? T-intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel-way width of 62 feet and commercial gas station that was open to the public. The east driveway for the station was approximately 38 feet wide allowing for ingress and egress of vehicular traffic onto the property.
The minor arterial roadway is straight and runs east and west with two lanes dedicated for eastbound and two lanes dedicated for westbound traffic. The crash site is approximately 200 feet east of a four way signal controlled intersection which was uninvolved in this crash event.
The east and westbound lanes are undivided with only a painted solid double yellow line separating the opposing lanes. For westbound traffic approaching the intersection there is a designated ?left Turn? only lane approximately 200 feet in length which can be used by westbound traffic wanting to turn left either into the east or west driveways of the gas station. There are 6 foot wide designated ?Bike? lanes on both the north and south sides of the roadway. The north and south sides of the minor arterial roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and adjoining 7 foot wide concrete sidewalks. The north side of the roadway is also bordered by residential single family homes. Other than a posted speed limit signs there are no other electronic or posted traffic control devices in proximity of the crash site.
MC1 was a 2004 Yamaha YZFR1 (998cc) sport race replica motorcycle being operated by a 34 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an unknown style motorcycle helmet. The rider was operating his motorcycle with the required license endorsement. Prior to the crash event, the rider was positioned facing north in the west driveway apron of the same gas station OV1 was turning into at the east driveway approximately 141 feet east of his location. Once the rider exited the driveway he turned eastbound and positioned his bike in the eastbound #1 lane and began to accelerate.
OV1 was a 2007 Cadillac Escalade (SUV) being operated by a 67 year old male driver. The OVD was initially approaching the intersection in the westbound #1 lane however, changed into the	left turn lane intending to turn left into the gas station. The OVD had slowed to a stop prior to making his left turn to cross the eastbound lanes of traffic and enter the east driveway. The OVD claimed he was alert; having just left home and indulging in his first cup of coffee. Once the
OVD believed the eastbound lanes to be clear of traffic he made his left turn movement.	As OV1 crossed the eastbound #1 lane MC1 impacted the right front portion of OV1 at the bumper just to the right of the right front headlight assembly. The OVD was not injured by the crash and brought his vehicle to a complete stop straddling the eastbound #2 lane. The OVD claimed he never saw the presence of MC1 on the roadway could not initiate any kind of collision avoidance maneuver.
The rider continued to accelerate out of the driveway into the eastbound #1 lane unaware of OV1 turning into his lane of travel. The rider said he accelerated to a speed of approximately 10-15 mph prior to the crash. As OV1 turned in front of MC1 the rider attempted to brake however could not avoid colliding with the vehicle.
The rider stated that as his bike struck OV1 he was ejected off the bike and vaulted over OV1 and onto the roadway surface adjacent to the left side of the vehicle. Fearing that he might get run over because OV1 was still moving forward, the rider jumped to his feet and moved over to the side of the road. MC1 struck the front of OV1 in an off-set head on type impact which caused the bike to collapse left side down and become captured under the bumper and right front tire of OV1. MC1 was drug underneath OV1 for a distance of about 14 feet before the OVD brought his vehicle to a complete stop.
As a result of the collision the rider suffered numerous	injuries and was treated at the scene by Fire Paramedics and subsequently transported from the scene to a local hospital for treatment.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 34 year old male rider of MC1 sustained a broken wrist, fracture Pelvis as well as an abrasion to his abdomen and his right shin. He was treated and later released at a local area hospital. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The 67 year old male driver of OV1 was not injured. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 34 year old male rider of MC1 could not react in time or conduct a proper collision avoidance maneuver prior to the crash. His efforts in bringing his motorcycle to a stop by utilizing what appeared to be front braking only was insufficient.
The 67 year old male driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision having failed to perceive the proximity of the approaching motorcycle while making his left turn.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front end and left side damage as a result of impacting with the front of OV1 the roadway surface and being dragged underneath the right front tire of VO1. The motorcycle otherwise appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained moderate right front damage however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event. The weather was clear and dry with no precipitation. There was no roadway construction in the area and no traffic advisory for this area.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Roadway
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred in January 2014 at 1818 hrs. in Southern California.	It was dark, with spot illumination; scattered clouds, the temperature was approximately 61 degrees F and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry and noted to be travel worn. There was no traffic.

The crash occurred on the northbound side of a predominately north/south undivided left curving uphill residential roadway.	The curved roadway is 40 ft. wide, the grade is 11.7%, the crown is 5.7% and the radius of the curve is 405 ft.	There are raised concrete curbs and parallel parked vehicles on both sides of the roadway.
MC1 is a 2008 Honda CBR 600 RR (599cc) motorcycle ridden by a 34 year old male (5 ft. 11 in. and 165 lbs.).	The rider was wearing an Arai RX-Q full face motorcycle helmet with a clear polycarbonate face shield.	OV1 is an (unoccupied) 2005 Toyota Corolla CE 4 door sedan parallel parked on the right side of the roadway.

MC1 was northbound, negotiating the left hand curve at approximately 26 mph.	MC1 drifted to the right and the rider lost control.	This caused MC1 to fall on the roadway and slide approximately 28 ft. into the right hand curb, then slide approximately another 7 ft. into the rear undercarriage of OV1, trapping the
rider under OV1 in front of MC1.	OV1 had to be lifted by fire/rescue personnel in order to free MC1 rider.
RiderInj: The 34 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related in the police report/photographs: a minor laceration to the right shoulder, multiple abrasions and contusions to his body. The rider had a BAC of .283 tested 1 hour and 21 minutes after the accident.
Human: The rider of MC1 had alcohol in his system which contributed to his perception failure.	This caused him to drift right towards the curb where he lost control and slid into the curb and (parked) OV1.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors.

CrashType: DUI rider with passenger riding towards a ?T? intersection at a high rate of speed runs out of road and crashes onto the roadway then impacts a curb. Both rider and passenger are fully ejected and sustain serious injuries.
Crash:
This crash occurred at the west dead-end of a roadway at a ?T? type intersection. All directions have posted stop signs. In the rider?s direction, there are two stop signs. One is located to the right on the sidewalk. The other is mounted in the center divider and has a reflective square yellow warning sign mounted below the stop sign. There is another reflective square yellow warning sign along the west curb line with a reflective rectangular yellow sign that has black arrows pointing to the left and right. The roadway leading up to the crash site has one lane in each direction with a continuous two-way left turn lane. The last 200? of the roadway consists of a left turn lane and a right turn lane with a painted 7? wide center divider. The cross street has one lane in each direction. Both roadways have bike lanes on both sides of the street. On the west curb line there is a semi-circular curb high planter with trees and shrubbery. The planter protrudes into the intersection, narrowing the north/south roadway width by approximately 50%. Both streets are straight and level. The roadway that the rider was on has a crown of 0.4% and a grade of 0.1%.	Both roadways are made of asphalt composition, are worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. The lane that MC1 was traveling in has a long (over 300?) bitumen repair strip from an unknown under-ground service repair. The crash took place at night. The area was illuminated by overhead spot lighting that were illuminated. The roadway has an east/west designation. It is in a slight southwest/northeast orientation at the crash site. The rider was westbound at 260 degrees. On the rider?s right is single family residential. On the left is an urban school. The
posted speed limit is 35 mph. The crash occurred in Southern California in December of 2014 at 0346 hrs. The weather was partly cloudy with a light wind from the northeast. The temperature was 54 degrees. Traffic conditions were light. MC1 was towed

MC1 was a 2004 Kawasaki ZX6R Ninja (636cc) sport/racing type motorcycle with minor modifications. The known modifications are the rider foot pegs, shifter and brake lever, and their mounting brackets, and the addition of sliders. All reflectors had been removed. The 28 year old male (5?09?/170 lbs.) rider was wearing an unknown brand full face helmet with integral chin bar and a smoke/gray tinted face shield. The helmet was not inspected and its safety ratings are unknown. The rider was wearing a thin (based on scene photos) cotton jacket, jeans, heavy work boots, and denim pants. It is unknown the chin strap was used or if the helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. The 31 year old female (unknown description) was wearing an Icon full face helmet with integral chin bar that had visible markings indicating that it met FVMSS 218 (US DOT) safety standards, a	black leather armored motorcycle jacket, a thin cotton style dress, and below the ankle athletic shoes. The helmet was not inspected (see scene photos). It is unknown whether or not the chin strap was used or if the helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. MC1 was westbound on a two lane roadway with a continuous two way left turn lane bisecting a single family residential neighborhood and an urban school at approximately 0345 hrs. The area was lit with overhead spot illumination that was illuminated. The roadway terminates into a ?T? intersection that has posted stop signs in all directions. The westbound roadway is striped with left or right turn lanes only. MC1 was traveling at a stated speed of 20 mph. prior to the crash. The rider was quoted in police accident report to say that the last thing he remembered was his passenger requesting that he ?slow down? to which he stated that he ignored. The passenger was also quoted to the same statement. She also stated that she had no idea how fast they were going or what lane they were in. The rider stated that he did not see the posted stop sign as he entered the intersection. When he realized that the road was coming to an end, he applied both brakes in an attempt to stop. The rider stated that when he realized that he was not going to be able to stop, he intentionally laid MC1 down. When the rider was questioned by the police about the crash and whether or not he had consumed any alcoholic beverages, he at first denied that he had any alcohol. He later changed is story and admitted to consuming ?two beers? around 1900 hrs. At the crash scene, a tire friction mark was located in the middle of the intersection prior to some scrape marks leading to the impact with the curb. MC1 was equipped with sliders that did help in minimizing some of the cosmetic type damage. Based on the damage to MC1, it appears that it was on its left side plane sliding front end forward as it impacted the curb, which was painted red. MC1 sustained major damage to the front end. There was a large amount red paint transfer on the top of the broken front fender. The front wheel was fractured and the front tire lost all air pressure. The front forks were forced rearward and the front tire/wheel impacted the radiator/engine. There was a measured reduction in wheelbase of approximately 9?. The impact with the curb also fractured the frame in several locations. Based on additional damage to MC1 and the location of dirt/mud, it appears that after impact MC1 flipped landing on its rear section before coming to rest. MC1 is shown on its right side plane in the curb high planter. It is unknown if that is the true FRP or if it was flipped over to that side when emergency personnel arrived. There was no evidence of MC1 sliding in the dirt on its right side. MC1s FRP was approximately 12? from POI #1 in the street and approximately 4? west of POI #2 which was the curb. The rider and passenger were both located in the same planter. The rider was a few feet south of MC1. The passenger was located approximately 11? southwest of MC1. There are several trees in the planter. It does not appear that MC1 impacted any of them. It is unknown whether or not the rider or passenger impacted a tree. The passenger?s injuries could have been caused by her impacting the ground, curb, or a tree.
RiderInj:
The 28 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of lacerations and abrasions. He complained of pain to his left arm, but no injury was substantiated. He was treated at the scene and taken to a hospital where he was admitted for an unknown number of days. The rider had an odor of an alcoholic beverage on his breath and admitted to consuming two beers earlier. He was unable to perform any standard balance/coordination tests, including checking his eyes for nystagmus or taking a preliminary breath screening test. The rider was asked if he would submit to a voluntary blood test. He did. The investigating officer requested that the rider be charged with felony DUI if the blood test results warranted charges.

The female passenger sustained major injuries consisting of multiple pelvic fractures, a lacerated spleen, and several abrasions. It is unknown whether or not she had consumed any alcoholic beverages.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a perception failure in not recognizing that the roadway was coming to an end. His impairment may have been a substantial contributing factor.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained major front end and left side damage from sliding on the roadway and impacting the curb which resulted in an approximate 9? reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered good.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in January 2015 at 1459 hours in Southern California.	It was day time, light out with clear skies, the temperature was approximately 70 degrees F. and the winds were light and variable. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn with surface cracking and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial/residential area on the southbound side of a north/south roadway separated by a painted double solid yellow center line. There are 6 ft. wide bicycle lanes and 3 through lanes in each direction.	The # 1 and 2 lanes are 10 ft. wide and the #3 lanes are 11 ft. wide, the northbound left turn lane is 10 ft. wide.	There are no traffic signals for the through lanes. The southbound grade is 0.2%, the crown is 6.6% and the posted speed limit is 45 mph.
MC1 is a 2008 Harley Davidson XL-1200N (1199cc) cruiser style motorcycle ridden by a 31 year old male (5 ft. 8 in. and 180 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make/model, full face motorcycle helmet with a blue tinted polycarbonate face-shield.	OV1 is a 1998 Lincoln Continental automobile driven by an 85 year old female (5 ft. 4 in. and 153 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was southbound in the #2 lane at approximately 40 mph. MC1 traveled south approximately 235 ft. from where he had stopped at the southbound limit line of the east/west intersection to the Point of Impact (POI).	OV1 was northbound in the left turn lane making a left turn westbound into a commercial driveway.	OV1 crossed the southbound through lanes in front of MC1, which caused the rider of MC1 to brake hard leaving approximately 62 ft. of skid before impacting the right rear door and right rear wheel of OV1.	The POI was approximately 36 ft. south and approximately 24 ft. east of the Reference Point (RP), power pole.	The RP is approximately 85 ft. south of the south curb-line of the east/west roadway.	OV1 continued the turn and stopped in the driveway, with
the right front/rear tires approximately 29 ft. south of the RP and the front approximately 14 ft. and the rear 3 ft. west of the RP.	MC1 came to rest facing south on its right side, approximately 74 ft. south and 27 ft. east of RP. Rider?s FRP is unknown
RiderInj: The 31 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: a right leg fracture, lacerations to the right hand and above the right eye, and complaint of pain to the right shoulder. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 5.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to perceive MC1 before crossing in front of MC1 was the main contributing factor. MC1 rider?s decision to brake only instead of moving laterally was a contributing factor.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: MC1 was eastbound in the #1 lane when he decided to make a right turn into a gas station driveway. The rider saw OV1 that was eastbound in the #3 (right) lane and thought that it was further back than it actually was. MC1 rode directly into OV1?s path. MC1 was impacted on the right side and knocked over onto its left side plane. The rider was fully ejected and sustained moderate injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a ?T? type driveway intersection that had no signal controls. The crash took place during hours of darkness. The area was illuminated by overhead spot illumination. There was also a fair amount of ambient lighting from nearby signs and parking lot lights. Both involved vehicles were eastbound and slowing for an upcoming signal that was phasing to red. Both sides of the roadway are commercial/retail centers. The roadway is a principal arterial that has three lanes in each direction. At the intersection, the roadway widens to include two left turn lanes and a right turn lane. The roadway has a curb high raised center divider with shrubbery. There are no bike lanes. Both sides of the roadway have a grassy area prior to a concrete sidewalk. The roadway has a downhill left curve where the crash occurred. The crown was measured at 2.0% and the grade was measured at -5.7%. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished and has some minor surface cracking, but in otherwise good repair. The roadway has an east/west designation but is in a slight southeast/northwest orientation at the crash site. MC1 was traveling eastbound at approximately 64 degrees. The weather was clear with no wind. The temperature was +66 degrees F. The posted speed limit is 50 mph. The crash took place in Southern California in January of 2015 at 1810 hrs. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passengers and was towed. OV1 was driven away.

MC1 was a 2014 Yamaha Bolt (942cc) cruiser type motorcycle with modifications. The known modification is the exhaust system. The 24 year old male (5?03?/120 lbs.) rider was wearing a full face Biltwell helmet with integral chin bar and a clear face shield. The helmet had markings that it met FVMSS 218 (US
 
DOT) safety ratings. The rider was wearing and armored sweatshirt under a thin nylon jacket. He was also wearing shin guards under his regular denim jeans. The helmet remained in place to the completion of the crash events. The rider of MC1 stated that he was southbound in the #1 (left) lane at about 5 to 10 mph and thought he was in 2nd gear. He stated that he was planning on making a left turn at the signal but upon seeing the gas station he realized that he would need fuel for the trip home and decided to pull in. The rider stated that this was only his second time in the area and the first time in that direction. The rider stated that he looked before making the turn into the driveway and saw a vehicle. It is unknown if that car was OV1. The rider thought that that the car he saw was further away than it actually was and thought that there was plenty of room for him to proceed. He then made his right turn into towards the driveway when he was hit by OV1. When interviewed by the investigating officer, the rider stated that the crash was his fault. The 51 year old male (5?11?/168 lbs.) operator of OV1 stated that was in the #3 lane and that he never saw MC1 until it was directly in front of him. The driver stated that he was already braking prior to the crash because the signal ahead was phasing to red. The driver of OV1 was unable to estimate his speed. The driver of OV1 had one passenger and did not seem to be distracted. MC1 was impacted on the right side by the front end OV1 which caused minor damage to both vehicles. MC1 was then knocked down onto its left side plane where it slid to its FRP. MC1 sustained mostly cosmetic damage. The gas tank was dented on the left side by the handlebars after impacting the ground. The left hand grip was ground down and the clutch lever was bent. The left foot peg and shifter were bent. There was no evidence of any evasive maneuvers prior to the impact from either vehicle involved in the crash. The rider was fully ejected. Both the rider and MC1 skidded/slid to their FRPs. It is unknown what MC1s orientation was at the completion of the crash.
RiderInj: The 24 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of an open fracture of the right tibia and fibula as stated in the police accident report. He was treated at the scene and taken to a hospital where he was treated and admitted for 10 days. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 was not injured. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 was distracted and had a comprehension failure in not properly judging the distance between him and OV1.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor right side damage from the impact with OV1 and minor to moderate damage to the left side from sliding on the roadway. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be like new.

OV1 was not inspected It would appear based on the police accident report that OV1 should have damage to the left front area. The accident report listed the damage as minor and that OV1 was driven away.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) broadside type crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface.	The rider (MCR) was ejected off of the motorcycle and impacted the roadway surface suffering minor injuries. There were no passengers on the motorcycle.
MV1: 2010 Honda CBR1000 RR (Sport race replica) 954cc, red pattern
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event. The collision occurred during the daylight hours on Friday January 2015 at 0921 hours in Southern California. Sunrise was at 0649 hours on this day. The weather report for 0853 hours showed mostly cloudy skies, with calm wind conditions. There was an ambient temperature of 64.9 degrees F. Visibility was 10.0 miles and at ground level it was clear and unobstructed in all directions.	The roadway for MC1 had a negative 0.8% downhill grade with a positive 2.8% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? T-intersection of a E/W principal arterial (non-freeway) roadway with an overall travel-way width of 107 feet and a driveway accessing a auto service center that was open to the public. The N/S driveway was approximately 24 feet wide allowing for ingress and egress of vehicular traffic into the center.
The roadway is straight and runs east and west with three lanes dedicated for northbound and three lanes dedicated for southbound traffic. There is a four way signal controlled intersection approximately 120 feet east of the crash site however it is not involved in the crash event.
There is a 4 foot wide raised concrete median w/o barrier separating the east and westbound lanes of traffic. Other than posted speed limit signs there are no electronic or posted traffic control devices in proximity of the crash site. The north and south sides of the principal arterial roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and adjoining 9 foot wide concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for both east and westbound traffic is 45 mph.
The south side of the roadway is occupied by a retail/commercial shopping center open to the public. On the north side of the roadway is a multiple family apartment complex.
MC1 was a 2010 Honda CBR1000RR (sport race replica motorcycle) being operated by a 34 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an Icon brand DOT and Snell 2005 approved full face motorcycle helmet. The rider was operating his motorcycle with a Valid California Driver?s license endorsed for the operation of motorcycles. The rider was traveling at an approximate speed of 40 mph eastbound in the #1 lane. As he was approaching the T-intersection (driveway) he
 
saw OV1 moving northbound crossing from the #2 lane into the #1 lane. Due to the proximity of the two-vehicles the rider was only able to apply his front brake for a short distance before striking the left side of OV1.
OV1 was a 2006 Chrysler Crossfire (automobile) being operated by a 68 year old male driver. The OVD had exited the auto service center and was driving northbound crossing the eastbound lanes of travel with the intended purpose of entering the designated left turn lanes west of the intersection. The OVD crossed a designated right turn lane, the #3 lane, the #2 lane and when he crossed the #1 lane he felt an impact along the left side of his vehicle. When the OVD realized his vehicle had been hit by MC1 he moved his vehicle from the crash site into the #1 lane.

The rider applied his brakes however, had insufficient time to conduct any collision avoidance maneuver. The right front portion of MC1 struck the left side of OV1 causing the rider to impact the side of OV1where he was ejected off the bike. The rider vaulted to a location approximately 18? 5? away from the AOI striking the roadway surface with his thigh and buttocks.
MC1 collapsed onto the roadway surface left side down and came to rest in the #2 eastbound left turn lane east of the crash site approximately 15 feet from the area of impact.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 34 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of the collision. The rider was treated at the scene and removed from the scene to a local hospital for treatment. The rider sustained a laceration to his right buttock as well as an abrasion to his left ankle.	He also sustained a closed fracture of the Pelvic ring. The rider was treated at the scene and transported to a local hospital where he was admitted for treatment; remaining two days. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The 68 year old male driver of OV1 was not injured and there was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 34 year old male rider of MC1 was operating his motorcycle at a speed safe for the present traffic on the roadway and could not react in time or conduct a proper collision avoidance maneuver prior to the crash.
The 68 year old male driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision to enter the roadway having failed to perceive the proximity of the approaching motorcycle while making his right turn.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate right front and left side damage as a result of impacting with OV1 and the roadway surface. The motorcycle otherwise appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained moderate left side damage however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in February 2015 at 1732 hours in Southern California.	It was dusk with clear skies, the temperature was approximately 61 degrees F. and the winds were light from the west. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, and there was medium traffic.

The crash occurred on a straight roadway in a residential/apartment area, on the northbound side of a north/south roadway that has two 11 ft. wide through lanes and a 5 ft. wide bicycle lane each way separated by a continuous left-turn lane.	The northbound grade is 0.5%, the crown is 6.8%, the posted speed limit is 40 mph and there are no traffic signals.	A light pole was used as the Reference Point (RP) that is 314 ft. north of the east/west curb prolongation of the north curb face and 2 ft. east of the east curb face of the north/south roadway.

MC1 was a 1999 Custom S & S Modified Hard-tail (1819cc) Cruiser motorcycle ridden by a 36 year old male (5 ft. 10 in. and 225 lbs.). The rider was wearing an Iron Horse, German Gloss Novelty motorcycle helmet. OV1 is a 2011 Toyota Corolla Sedan driven by a 17 year old female (5 ft. 4 in. and 104 lbs.).	There was 1 passenger riding in OV1.	All occupants of OV1 were reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was northbound in the #1 lane at approximately 30 mph. OV1 was eastbound making a left turn from a private driveway, crossing the southbound lanes into the #1 lane. The driver of OV1 waited till southbound traffic passed, then accelerated rapidly into the #1 northbound lane. The southbound traffic blocked both the rider of MC1 and the driver of OV1?s view of the other. The rider of MC1 saw OV1 as she crossed the center turn lane. MC1 swerved to the
right but struck OV1on the right side at the right front wheel. The Point of Impact was 13 ft. north and 17 ft. west of the RP. MC1 went down on the left side and slid approximately 46 ft. to its Final Rest Position (FRP) 56 ft. north and 4.5 ft. west of the RP. The FRP of OV1 is unknown. The FRP of MC1 rider was approximately 19 ft. north and approximately 13 ft. west of the RP.
RiderInj: The 36 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related during the interview: abrasions to the right knee and both elbows, contusions to the lower back and buttocks. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 made her left turn into the #1 lane, in front of oncoming traffic, instead of turning into the continuous center turn lane, causing MC1 inadequate time to avoid the collision. The rider of MC1 was unable to complete his swerve to the right due to a reaction time failure.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were temporary mobile view obstructions which blocked both vehicles view of each other.

CrashType: MC1 was southbound in the #1 lane when OV1 began making a left turn from the stop sign. MC1 braked to avoid the collision. MC1 had a frontal impact to the left rear side of OV1. MC1 went down on its left side plane. The rider was vaulted above ride height and landed in the street. OV1 went into a CCW rotation in excess of 90 degrees. The rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a four way, non-skewed type intersection that had no signal controls. The crash took place during hours of daylight. Both sides of both roadways have single family residential homes in the area of the crash. The roadway that MC1 was traveling on is a non-freeway principal arterial that has three lanes in each direction with a curb high raised center divider. At the intersection, the roadway includes a left turn lane in each direction. There are no designated bike lanes. The rider?s side of the roadway has a grassy area prior to a concrete sidewalk. The roadway is straight with a downgrade that was measured to be 4.4%. The crown was measured at 6.2%. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. The roadway has a north/south designation but is in a slight northeast/southwest orientation at the crash site. MC1 was southbound at approximately 80
degrees. The cross street runs east/west and is controlled by posted stop signs. OV1 was eastbound, making a left turn. The weather was clear with a light wind from the east. The temperature was +60 degrees F. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The crash took place in Southern California in February of 2015 at 0803 hrs. Traffic conditions were light to moderate. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. MC1 had no passengers. MC1 was towed. OV1 was driven away.
MC1 was a 2006 Suzuki Boulevard C50 (819cc) cruiser type motorcycle with modifications. The known modifications include the exhaust system, handlebars, front and rear turn signals, and a performance computer chip. The 20 year old male (5?10?/175 lbs.) rider was wearing a Bell full face motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield that was in the upright position. The helmet had labeling showing that it met FVMSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell M2010 safety standards. The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence. The rider was wearing non-prescription sun glasses. The rider was also wearing an armored
 
leather jacket, full fingered leather gloves, regular denim jeans, and low cut athletic style shoes. The rider of MC1 stated that he was southbound in the #1 (left) lane at a constant speed of 45 mph. He stated that he had just left home and was on his way to school. He stated that he saw OV1 to his right front, stopped over the limit line and that the driver was looking to her right. He said that he never saw her look left towards him. The rider stated that all of a sudden, OV1 pulled out from the side street and appeared to be making a left turn. He stated that he braked hard. He could hear that his rear tire was skidding. He also stated that he was using both brakes in an effort to avoid hitting OV1. The rider stated that he impacted OV1 to the left rear side and was fully ejected from MC1. He said that he thinks he flew over the trunk of OV1 and then landed in the street. He stated that he remembered being south of the sign in the center divider, but close to it. He was afraid of getting hit by another car, so he quickly got onto the center divider and waited for help. The 25 year old female (5?06?/180 lbs.) operator of OV1 stated that she was stopped at the stop sign and had looked to her left (north) and saw several cars north of the train tracks. She then looked to her right to see if it was clear and it was, so she started to make her turn when she was hit in the rear and her car spun around. She stated that she never saw MC1. When the police arrived, both vehicles were at their FRPs. MC1 was facing southbound in the #1 lane on its? left side plane. OV1 was facing in a northwesterly direction in the middle of the intersection. MC1 left approximately 47? of rear locked wheel skid prior to impacting OV1.	The skid is straight. There was no evidence of any front tire skid from MC1. There were no tire marks from OV1. MC1 sustained major damage and was towed to the riders home where it was inspected. OV1 sustained moderate damage and was driven away.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of two toe fractures to his left foot. He was treated at the scene and taken to a hospital where he was treated and released. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 complained of pain to her forehead and neck. She was treated at the scene and then taken to a hospital where she was treated and released. She did not seek additional medical care. She displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit her ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human:
The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 as it approached the intersection. She saw several vehicles behind MC1 but did not identify MC1 in front of the pack of approaching vehicles.

The rider of MC1 had a reaction failure in over-braking and skidding for 47?.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front end damage from the impact with OV1 and minor to moderate damage to the left side from impacting and sliding on the roadway. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be like very good.

OV1 sustained moderate damage to the left rear side. It appeared that the first point of contact was at the left rear wheel, and then went rearward as OV1 went into a CCW rotation and the two-vehicles began to separate. The pre-crash condition of OV1 would be listed as fair to good.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Sedan
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in February 2015 at 0741 hours in Southern California. It was daylight, not bright with haze, the temperature was approximately 59 degrees F. and the winds were light from the east. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, with surface cracking and ripples. Traffic was light.

The crash occurred in a residential-apartment/commercial area, at a T intersection, in the #2 lane of the southbound, right curving north/south roadway. The southbound roadway has a 0.7 % grade and a crown of 3.6%. The #1 lane is 10 ft. wide, the #2 lane is 16 ft. wide, and there is a 5 ft. wide bicycle lane on the right next to the curb. The roadway is divided by a 10 ft. wide, continuous left turn lane. The northbound roadway has 2 through lanes that are 11 ft. wide and
a 5 ft. wide bicycle lane on the right. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The curve is approximately 126 ft. in length, with a radius of approximately 625 ft.; the middle ordinate was approximately .5 ft. measured from a 50 ft. measuring tape. All measurements were taken from the south and west curb faces.

MC1 is a 2001 Honda CBR-600F4i (599cc) sport/race replica motorcycle ridden by a 32 year old male (5 ft. 8 in. and 155 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make/model motorcycle helmet. OV1 is a 2014 Dodge Journey SUV driven by a 32 year old female (5 ft. 7 in. and 150 lbs.). There were 3 passengers riding in OV1. All occupants of OV1 were reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was southbound in the # 2 lane at approximately 34 mph. OV1 was northbound in the left turn lane, stopped to make a left turn at the intersection. The driver of OV1 saw an accident north of the intersection and was waiting for a southbound car to pass.  After the car passed, OV1 started the left turn after the car passed and struck MC1 on the left side. The driver started she never saw MC1. The Point of Impact (POI) was approximately 12 ft. east of the west curb- line and 18 ft. north of the south curb-line. MC1 high sided onto its right side and slid approximately 63 ft. southwest leaving approximately 63 ft. of gouges and fluid on the roadway, sidewalk, grass and onto a private driveway from POI to MC1 Point of Rest (POR). The POR for MC1 was approximately 35 ft. south of the south curb-line and 15 ft. west of the west curb-line. OV1 completed the turn and parked next to the north curb. The rider?s POR was unknown.
RiderInj: The 32 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: a deep laceration to the left knee. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to perceive the approach of MC1.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no Environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: This is a solo MC crash with high speed and a loss of control. MC1 was westbound in the #1 lane at a high speed. After going through a dip in a gutter way, MC1went airborne. Upon landing, MC1 lost control and crashed onto the roadway. MC1 then skidded/slid into a parked vehicle (fixed object). The rider was fully ejected and was ahead of MC1 sliding in the direction of the parked vehicle. MC1 caught up to the rider and pushed him into the parked vehicle. The rider sustained fatal injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a MC vs. fixed object (parked vehicle) solo vehicle type crash. This crash occurred on a single family residential roadway that has one lane in each direction with no divider or painted lines. On street parallel parking is permitted on both sides of the roadway. There were parked vehicles on both sides of the roadway. The roadside has a 5? wide grass strip before a 5? wide sidewalk. There are trees and utility poles along the roadside. The roadway is a local street with a speed limit of 25 mph. It is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has an east/west designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway is in a slight southwest/northeast orientation. The rider was westbound in the #1 lane at 260 degrees. The roadway is straight and level. The grade was measured to be 0.0%. The crown was measured to be 7.2%. The weather was described as ?haze? with light variable wind. The temperature was +71 degrees F. The crash took place in February 2015 in Southern California at 1223 hrs. There was no roadway construction in the area of the crash. Traffic conditions were light. The rider was fully ejected and sustained fatal injuries. MC1 had no passenger. MC1 was towed from the scene.

MC1 was a 2003 Yamaha YZF-R6 (599cc) sport/racing street type motorcycle with modifications. The known modifications include the exhaust system, turn signal lights, brake/clutch levers, and a stand on wheelie bar attached to the rear frame that extends beyond the rear tire. The 30 year old male (5?07?/150 lbs.) rider was wearing a Shoei X-Eleven full face motorcycle helmet. The face shield came off during the crash. It was gray/smoke tint. The helmet had labeling showing that it met FVMSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell M2005 safety ratings. The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence and was removed by paramedics. The rider was not wearing any other type of eye protection. The rider was wearing a T shirt, denim jean type pants, and below the ankle athletic shoes.
The area of the crash is a residential zone that has streets designated as either north/south or east/west. They are in a grid type pattern. Stop signs are used for traffic control at every other intersection for the east/west street. There are posted stop signs at the intersection where the crash occurred for east/west traffic. The north/south street does not have a stop sign at the intersections where the east/west street does. The east/west streets have dips and gutter ways on both sides of the intersections that run north and south. It appears that MC1 was westbound at a very high speed. When going through the intersection that is east of the crash site, MC1 became airborne after going through the gutter ways. Upon landing west of the intersection, MC1 lost control.
The front forks began to violently rotate back and forth in what is commonly referred to as a ?tank slapper.? There were	tire marks from the front tire of MC1 that showed MC1 made very rapid, out of control turns before going down on its right side plane. There were also tire marks from the rear tire, some of which were over-lapping with the front tire marks. During this process, MC1 crossed over into the opposing lane of travel. As MC1 continued out of control in a westerly direction, it nearly impacted a parked full size pick-up that was parked on the south side of the street in the eastbound lane of travel. After passing the truck, MC1 went through another gutter way on the east side of the intersection which is when it went down. MC1 high-sided and was on its right side plane and rotated in an unknown direction, but ultimately was sliding backwards. The rider was fully ejected and sliding ahead of MC1. MC1 caught up to the rider and pushed him into and under a parked vehicle, causing fatal injuries. The rider was found in a prone position with his head under the parked vehicle and his legs extending out from the vehicle. The rider was pronounced deceased at the scene. In the on-scene photos, MC1 and the parked vehicle are at their FRPs. The impact of MC1 into the parked vehicle had enough force to move the parked vehicle backwards approximately 2? and push the right front tire up and over the curb. The helmet had been removed from the rider by paramedics and placed near MC1. When inspected, the chin strap was still intact and looped through the double D rings. The reporting officer stated that no one had touched the strap and that the paramedics removed the helmet in the condition that it was inspected. A witness who is a friend of the rider stated that the rider of MC1 was showing his riding abilities to him. The witness stated that the rider rode eastbound first for about a block, then turned around and came westbound. The witness stated that the rider was going fast and went airborne approximately 60 cm (23.6?) after going through a dip in the roadway. He said that the rear tire landed onto the roadway first followed by the front tire, at which time the rider appeared to lose control as indicated by the handlebars rapidly going back and forth. Another witness stated that she saw the rider leaning to the right and MC1 leaning to the left. Witnesses estimated the speed of MC1 to be around 50 mph. Skid/slide formulas and collinear momentum put the speed of MC1 at approximately 87 mph. The front tire air pressure was low at 29 psi, but within 15% of recommended inflation. The rear tire lost all air pressure as a result of the crash. The rider did not have driver?s license. He had been issued an index number for tracking purposes by the DMV. His status to get a license was listed as ?suspended? because of a prior DUI arrest and citation for no license.
RiderInj: The 31 year old male operator of MC1 sustained fatal injuries consisting of: a transection of the brain stem, lacerations to the brain stem; subdural and subarachnoid brain hemorrhages; a thoracic aortic laceration; bi-lateral flail rib fractures; several internal organ lacerations including the liver and spleen; numerous bone fractures including the pelvis, left femur, left tibia and fibula; and numerous lacerations and abrasions. The toxicology results showed that the rider had a BAC of 0.16%. This level is twice the legal limit and most likely impaired his ability to operate a motor vehicle in a safe manner.
Human: The operator of MC1 had a decision failure in going too fast and riding while legally intoxicated. The rider lives in the neighborhood and should have had known about the dips in the roadway.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained major damage to the right side and rear end. The rear axle arm supports were broken. The rear tire was flat and the rim was fractured. The rear sprocket was bent and the chain dislodged. The modified frame extension which is believed to be used as a wheelie stand for the rider was bent and misshaped. Both the engine case and transmission case were damaged and fluids leaked out. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as good.
Environmental: There are permanent dips in the roadway for drainage which are contributory to this crash only because of the excessive speed that MC1 was going.

CrashType: MC1 was southbound in the #1 lane approaching a 4-way stop. For an unknown reason, MC1 went down on its left side plane in the middle of the intersection and slid to its FRP south of the intersection. The DUI rider was fully ejected and sustained moderate injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a four way, non-skewed type intersection that had stop signs posted in all directions. The crash took place during hours of darkness. The area was illuminated by overhead spot illumination. On the rider?s right there are single family residential homes; on the left is an urban park. The approach
to the intersection is an up-hill right curve. In the rider?s direction, the intersection and the two stop signs are visible at a distance greater than 300?. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The roadway that MC1 was traveling on is a non-freeway minor arterial that has one lane in each direction, bike lanes, and a painted center divider. Parking is allowed during daylight hours. At the intersection, the roadway includes a left turn lane. Both sides of the roadway have concrete sidewalks. Beyond the sidewalk on the right is a landscaped up-slope. On the left is a landscaped down-slope to the park. The intersection was measured to have a crown of 3.5% and a downgrade of -2.0%. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. The roadway has a north/south designation but is in a slight northwest/southeast orientation at the crash site. MC1 was southbound at approximately 190 degrees. The weather was clear with a light wind from the SSE. The temperature was +68 degrees F. The crash took place in Southern California in March of 2015 at 2101 hrs. Traffic conditions were light. The rider was fully ejected and sustained injuries. There was no on-going construction at the time of the crash. MC1 had no passengers. MC1 was towed.

MC1 was a 2003 Suzuki SV650 (645cc) cruiser type motorcycle with minor modifications. The known modifications include the exhaust system and rear turn signals. The 32 year old male (5?10?/195 lbs.) rider was wearing an unknown style of helmet and unknown type clothing/protective apparel. The rider of MC1
 
stated that there was a problem with the brakes that unexpectedly locked up on him and caused the crash. He stated that it happened earlier on the freeway. hen MC1 was inspected, there were no obvious signs of any brake problems.

MC1 was riding in the #1 (only) lane which is 18? wide. There is an 8? bike lane to the right near the intersection. On the approach, the configuration changes to an 8? parking lane with a 5? bike lane adjacent to the travel lane. It appears that the rider may have over-braked and lost control after recognizing that he failed to stop for the stop sign. MC1 went down and the left side of the front tire/rim dug into the roadway causing asphalt to pile up into the tire bead area of the rim. The front tire was measured to have only 19 psi. The rear tire was measured to have 25 psi. Both tires were underinflated and may have contributed to the crash by causing instability while braking and turning. MC1 skidded/slid a distance of approximately 118?. Using a coefficient of friction of 0.40 (nylon sliders and downgrade), MC1 was calculated to be going approximately 38 mph. at the time of the crash, which is below the posted speed limit of 40 mph. In using maximum effective braking calculations, MC1 would only need approximately 59? to safely stop. There were no pre-impact tire marks that would indicate heavy braking/skidding. The POI is in the middle of the intersection, indicating that MC1 never stopped for the posted stop sign. It is unknown if MC1 was traveling much faster than the speed limit and attempted to stop before the stop sign. MC1 was riding to the right side of its lane prior to losing control.
After crashing, MC1 slid at a slight angle across the travel lane. This was most likely due to the curve in the roadway prior to the intersection where it appears that the rider was riding to the inside of the curve. The length of curve was measured at 702?. A 100? chord was used to measure the radius. The mid-ordinate was measured to be 9? (0.75?) which calculates to a radius of 1667?. Based on the direction of travel and location of the crash, it appears that the rider may have been on his way home. The rider stated that he was coming from a bar and that he had consumed two 8 ounce beers. During the crash investigation, officers could smell the odor of alcoholic beverages on the rider. After conducting a DUI investigation, the rider was arrested. He was given a breath test which produced results of 0.15% BAC.
RiderInj: The 32 year old male operator of MC1 sustained moderate injuries consisting of an open fracture to the left lower leg, a laceration to his left foot, and abrasions to both arms and back. He was treated at the scene and taken to a hospital. It is unknown if he was admitted. He displayed signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle and was arrested.
Human: The operator of MC1was under the influence of alcohol which caused a perception error of him not recognizing the stop sign at the intersection, combined with a reaction error which caused MC1 to go down. There may have been some type of mechanical problem with the brakes per the rider, but that is doubtful based on the inspection. The rider?s BAC level was measured to be 0.15% on a breath test that was taken 1 hour and 15 minutes after the crash.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor damage to the left side plane. MC1 was equipped with aftermarket sliders which protected MC1 from more serious damage. MC1 had damage on both sides, some of which appears to be old.	The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as fair.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that are considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) broadside type injury crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface ejecting the rider causing minor injuries. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2013 Harley Davidson FXDB ?Street Bob? cruiser (1573cc), black in color
OV1: 2005 Toyota Tundra pick-up truck, white in color
Crash:
This was an OV1 vs. MC1 broadside type injury crash event. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight on Friday, March 2015 at 1155 hours in Southern California. Sunrise was at 0702 hours. The weather report for 1152 hours indicated cloudy skies, with NE winds at 8.1 mph and, an ambient temperature of
89.1 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed for 10.0 miles in all directions.	The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? intersection of a principal arterial roadway (non-freeway) with an overall travel-way width of 53 feet. For the motorcycle rider there is a left curve on the approach to the intersection with a -3.3% downhill grade. For the other driver the roadway is straight on the approach to the intersection. The roadway runs north and south with two through lanes for each direction of travel.	There are designated left turn lanes to regulate both north and southbound traffic onto the intersecting local street at this intersection.
The north and southbound lanes are separated by a painted solid double yellow line.	The local street on the east side of the intersection is 50 feet wide with two through lanes for eastbound traffic and three regulated westbound lanes for left, right and, through traffic. There are marked painted arrows to indicate this. The local street on the west side of the intersection is 40 feet wide with one lane for westbound traffic and two lanes for eastbound traffic. The eastbound #2 lane also allows for right turns and is marked with a painted arrow. Both local streets on either side of this intersection are separated with a painted solid double yellow line. Both local street east and west of the intersection are uninvolved with this crash event. The crash scene was confined to the area of the intersection. The intersection is controlled in all four directions by posted electronic traffic signals with no designated left turn arrow signal devices.
All four sides of the intersection are bordered by commercial/retail businesses. The roadway is bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks and there no marked or designated ?Bike? lanes. Parallel parking is regulated and not allowed in proximity or at the intersection. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 30 mph.

MC1 was a 2013 Harley Davidson FXDB cruiser style motorcycle being operated by a 28 year old male rider. The rider was traveling at a speed of about 30-35
 
mph northbound in the #1 lane while approaching the intersection.	The rider was wearing a Z1R DOT and ECE-2205 approved full face motorcycle helmet with a smoke colored visor.
OV1 was a 2005 Toyota Tundra pick-up truck being operated by a 53 year old male driver. OV1 was traveling southbound and moved into the left turn lane with other traffic. The driver followed two-vehicles into the intersection mistakenly thinking that he was entering on a solid green arrow light. This intersection is not equipped with a left turn arrow for any of the four directions of travel.
As the rider approached the intersection the signal controlling his direction of travel phased from green to yellow. The rider estimated his distance from the intersection at about one and a half car lengths at the time of the phase. The rider also noticed OV1 moving into the intersection making a left turn. The rider immediately applied his front brake, down shifted and, started to move to the right. The rider could not stop in time or move around OV1 and subsequently impacted the right side of the truck near the cab and bed. MC1 collapsed onto the roadway surface as well as the rider.
Both MC1 and the rider came to rest inside the intersection. The rider said he was about 3 feet away from his motorcycle, lying face up with his head facing south.
The driver of OV1 continued moving forward and stopped his vehicle near the north crosswalk. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, or animals that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 28 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were an abrasion to his forehead, chest and a laceration to his lower right leg. The rider was taken to a local area hospital and was treat and released the same day.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. There was no evidence of alcohol or drug intoxication
Human: The rider of MC1 could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of OV1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate front end and left side damage as a result of impacting the right side of OV1 however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained minor right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This is a solo MC crash with MC1 falling onto the roadway.	MC1 was eastbound in the #1 lane negotiating an uphill right curve after making a right turn at a ?T? type intersection that was controlled by signals. The rider did not see a significant amount of loose sand in his lane. When MC1 hit the sand, the front tire washed out and MC1 went down on its right side plane. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred after the rider had gone through a signal controlled ?T? type intersection during daylight hours. The roadway has two lanes in each direction, divided by a double yellow painted line. There is a bike lane on each side. The roadside has guardrails. A 5? concrete sidewalk is on the same side of the road as the rider?s direction of travel. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial businesses on both sides of the roadway. The roadway is a non- freeway minor arterial. It is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has an east/west designation.
