In the area of the crash, the roadway has a nearly 180 degree curve, much like a freeway on-ramp. The rider was headed eastbound in the #1 lane of travel while negotiating the uphill right curve. The rider?s direction of travel would take him in a westbound direction after completing the curve. The curved roadway is similar to a freeway on/off ramp and is landscaped in the middle. In the rider?s direction, the roadway has an upgrade of +3.0%. The crown was measured to be 1.6%. No parking or stopping is allowed on either side of the roadway. The weather was cloudy/partly cloudy with a moderate wind from the SSW. The temperature was +66 degrees F. The crash took place in March 2015 in Southern California at 1552 hrs. There was no roadway construction in the immediate area of the crash. It is unknown if the sand in the roadway came from one of two construction areas near the crash or from some other unrelated source.
Traffic conditions were moderate. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger. MC1 was towed from the scene. 
MC1 was a 2013 Triumph Bonneville (865cc) conventional street type motorcycle with minor modifications. The known modifications include the exhaust system, slightly oversized tires, and the handlebars. The 49 year old male (5?11?/220 lbs.) rider was wearing a Lance Monaco GT/2 full face motorcycle helmet with a retractable chin bar that was in the down position. The face shield is a ?transition? or ?photo chromatic? type that automatically goes from clear to
 
tinted, depending on the amount of light exposed to it. At the time of the crash, it was at full tint. The helmet had labeling showing that it met FVMSS 218 (US DOT). The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence.	The rider was not wearing any other type of eye protection. The rider was also wearing an armored leather jacket, full fingered leather gloves, thin cotton type pants, and motorcycle oriented over the ankle boots.	The rider of MC1 stated that he had just gone through a construction zone where work was being done on a bridge overpass. He was in the #1 left lane. The #2 lane was coned off due to the construction. The #1 lane that the rider was in was an option lane. He could either go straight or make a right turn. He was on his way home from work and made a right turn. After making his right turn he stayed in the #1 lane and had accelerated to ?around 20-25 mph.? He stated that he was now negotiating an uphill right curve. He was behind a standard full size pick-up and ?looking through his turn.? He stated that all of a sudden his front tire washed out from under him and that he had no idea why. He was fully ejected from MC1. After the crash, the rider said that there was a lot of sand or cat litter in the middle of the lane he was riding in and that he never saw it until after the crash. The sand type debris was an oval shaped patch approximately 8? long and 1? deep. The source of the sand is unknown. The front tire was slightly over-inflated and the rear tire was slightly under-inflated, but both were within 16%-39% of recommended PSI. The rider stated that he was riding in the middle of his lane because he wanted to have some ?cushion? space in case a vehicle might come into his lane of travel from either direction. The rider said that when he was ejected, he landed on his right knee and he suffered an abrasion. He also landed
on his right elbow/forearm causing a contusion. He said that he believed that the contusion to his inner left thigh was cause by his right foot in the course him tumbling in the roadway. He stated that his helmet never made contact with the roadway surface. The rider said that witnesses stopped and moved MC1 to the side of the road before and photos or measurements could be taken. He said that he saw his bike on its right side facing in a northeasterly direction and
that the front tire was partially over the double yellow lines. He also said that after the crash, he immediately got up and moved to the side of the road.	A 100? chord was used to measure the radius. The mid-ordinate was measured to be 9?. The radius was calculated to be 143?. The length of curve was 208?. MC1 sustained minor damage and was towed.
RiderInj: The 49 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of an abrasion to his right knee and contusions to his right forearm and left inner thigh. The rider refused medical treatment at the scene and stated that he would seek his own medical attention later. He went to a walk-in medical clinic the next day. No X-rays were taken. He was given a prescription for pain and muscle relaxers which he never had filled. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of MC1 had a perception failure in not seeing the hazard in the roadway while negotiating the right curve.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor damage to the lower right side. The bottom of the right front fork, the exhaust system, and the engine side case sustained minor to moderate scrapes. The right hand grip also sustained minor damage. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as like new.
Environmental: There was sand like substance in the roadway that was a temporary environmental condition that is a contributory causation factor to this crash.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Pickup truck
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in March 2015 at 0640 hours in Southern California.	It was dark with spot lighting, clear, the temperature was approximately 63 degrees F. and the winds were calm. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn with surface cracking and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial area at a 4 way intersection bordered by raised concrete curbs and concrete sidewalks.	The north/south roadway has 2 through lanes and a permissive left turn lane in each direction. The # 1 lanes are 11 ft. wide, the #2 lanes are 12 ft. wide and the left turn lanes are 10 ft. wide. The roadway is separated by a painted double yellow center line. There are traffic signals for the through lanes; this gives the left turn lane permissive only status.	The southbound grade is 0.7%, the crown is 8.3% and the posted speed limit is 35 mph.	The east/west roadway has 1 through lane and a left turn lane in each direction.	The west side of the intersection has a 10 ft. wide left turn lane, a westbound 14 ft. lane and a 12 ft. eastbound lane.	There are traffic signals on all 4 street corners for the east/west roadway.	The posted speed limit is 25 mph.

MC1 is a 2007 Suzuki GSXR 600 (599cc) sport/race replica motorcycle ridden by a 29 year old male (5 ft. 7 in. and 180 lbs.). The rider was wearing an Icon Airmada, full face motorcycle helmet with a grey/smoke tinted polycarbonate face-shield that weighed approximately 61 oz.	OV1 is a 2008 Chevrolet Silverado truck driven by a 28 year old male (6 ft. 4 in. and 210 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was southbound in the #1 lane approaching the intersection at approximately 25 mph. The rider stated that he had a green light. The operator of OV1stated that he was eastbound stopped in the left turn lane at the intersection for a red signal.	OV1 entered the intersection after the signal phased green to make his left turn and was struck in the area of the left front wheel by MC1. The Area of Impact (AOI) was approximately 24 ft. east of the west curb-line and approximately 18 ft. south of the north curb-line.	The rider of MC1 vaulted over the hood of OV1 and came to rest approximately 35 ft. south of the AOI in the south crosswalk.	The Points of Rest of MC1 and OV1 are unknown as both were moved prior to the arrival of the police.	The rider of MC1 was riding on an expired license and had no motorcycle endorsements.
RiderInj: The 29 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the hospital medical record:	a right side comminuted, displaced tibia/fibula fracture, a right proximal fibula shaft fracture, a documented loss of consciousness, a right side adrenal gland hematoma, lacerations to the left hand and right elbow, multiple hand abrasions NFS and multiple ligament injuries to the left knee.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 14. The rider of MC1 had marijuana in his system, discovered during the hospital blood work.
Human: It is unknown which operator had the perception error in not seeing the red light or had a decision error in running the red light. The rider of 1 may have had drug involvement since he tested positive for THC.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1), rear end type injury crash event. The motorcycle rider sustained minor injuries as a result of impacting the rear portion of OV1. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2009 Harley Davidson XR1200 Sportster conventional (1203cc), orange in color
OV1: 2006 Toyota Sienna automobile (station wagon), white in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle rear impact crash event resulting in serious injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Sunday, March 2015 at 0758 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed partly cloudy skies, with calm wind conditions and an ambient temperature of +61.0 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a	-5.2 % downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred in a portion of the northbound lanes of a straight divided six lane principal arterial roadway with an overall travel way width of 99 feet. There is a left curve downhill portion of the roadway south of the crash site that has an overall radius of 1250 feet and a length of curve of 693 feet. There were no super elevation issues with this roadway. The north and southbound lanes are separated by a 4 foot wide raised concrete median with low lying
vegetation. There is a designated 8 foot wide bike lane on the west side of the roadway and the same on the east side south of the intersection.
There are no traffic control devices, either posted or marked in proximity of the crash scene. The speed limit for both north and southbound traffic is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2009 Harley Davidson XR1200 Sportster (conventional) motorcycle being operated by a 35 year old male. The rider was wearing a DOT approved half shell motorcycle helmet at the time of the crash event.
The rider was traveling northbound in the #1 lane at an approximate speed of 35 mph prior to the crash event. The rider was following traffic and just prior to the crash he was scanning the adjacent #2 lane for other vehicles. As the rider continued northbound he directed his attention back to his lane of travel and suddenly realized that traffic was coming to a stop. The MCR reacted by applying his front brake and attempted to depart the #1 lane into the #2 lane. The MCR locked the front brake leaving about 27 feet of skid marks however could not avoid striking the rear right portion of OV1. The resulting impact caused MC1 to collapse right side down onto the roadway surface. The MCR was ejected off the bike and rolled onto the roadway surface. Both the motorcycle and rider came to rest in the #2 northbound lane. To the best of the rider?s knowledge he came to rest about 30 feet ahead of the motorcycle but got up and walked off the roadway. His motorcycle was moved away from the crash scene.
OV1 was a 2006 Toyota Sienna (automobile) being operated by a 33 year old female.	The OVD was northbound in the #1 lane and had to come to an abrupt stop for the traffic in her lane. The OVD said as soon as she brought her vehicle to a stop she felt a ?bump? to the rear however at first only saw the traffic
 
behind her coming to a stop. It wasn?t until she saw the MCR standing up holding his wrist that he may have been the source of the impact she felt. The driver of OV1 had moved her vehicle away from the crash scene as well, prior to the arrival of law enforcement officers.
RiderInj: The 35 year old male rider of MC1 sustained an unspecified fracture to his left wrist as well as abrasions to his left arm and leg. He was treated at the scene, transported to a local area hospital and released later the same day. There was no evidence of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of this crash event. There was no evidence of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human: The 35 year old rider of MC1 had simply directed his attention away from the traffic in front of him to scan the adjacent lane. The resulting action provided him with insufficient time to react to the traffic slowing and stopping.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate right side damage as a result of the crash however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 sustained minor damage to the rear bumper and right rear quarter panel however was otherwise in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Sedan
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in April 2015 at 1725 hours in Southern California. It was dark with spot lighting, there were scattered clouds, the temperature was approximately 69 degrees F. and the winds were between 8 and 10 mph. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn with surface cracking and there was moderate to heavy traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial/residential area at a 4 way intersection bordered by raised concrete curbs and concrete sidewalks.	The north side of the intersection has 2 northbound through lanes, one southbound through lane, one right turn only lane and one left turn lane.	The south side of the intersection has 2 northbound through lanes, one southbound through lane and one left turn lane.	The northbound grade is 0.7% and the crown is 3.8%.	The east/west sides of the intersection have 2 through lanes and a left turn lane in each direction.	The posted speed limit is 35 mph.	All directions of travel are controlled by tri-phase traffic signals, posted signs and painted roadway markings, for both vehicles and pedestrians.	There are delineated pedestrian crosswalks
connecting all four corners of the intersection.

MC1 is a 1993 Kawasaki Ninja ZX-7R (748cc) modified sport/race replica motorcycle ridden by a 23 year old male (5 ft. 7 in. and 170 lbs.). The rider was wearing a Scorpian EXO 700, full face motorcycle helmet with a clear polycarbonate face-shield that weighed approximately 61 oz. The rider had no formal training and had purchased the motorcycle and helmet 3 days prior to the crash. OV1 is a 2013 Hyundai Sonata 4 door sedan driven by an 88 year old female (5 ft. 7 in. and 160 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints. MC1 had been modified by the removal of entire front fairing.

MC1 was northbound in the #1 lane approaching the intersection at approximately 37 mph on a green signal that phased to amber.	OV1 was southbound in the left turn lane, stopped in the intersection on a green signal that phased amber while waiting for traffic to clear before making a left turn. The rider of MC1 observed OV1 with the front left turn signal blinking as he approached the intersection, observed OV1 begin her left turn, over braked leaving approximately
34 ft. of tire friction mark on the roadway before losing control and falling onto its left side on the roadway at the Area of Impact #1 (AOI #1).	MC1 and the rider continued northbound with MC1 leaving approximately 26 ft. of gouges from AOI #1 to the impact with OV1, AOI #2.	The impact of MC1 into the right side of OV1
 
at the front wheel/bumper area lifted OV1 enough to allow the rider to slide under OV1 near the right side ?B? pillar. MC1 deflected approximately 30 ft. northwest to its Point of Rest (POR). OV1?s driver?s airbag deployed and the driver continued her left turn and continued eastbound, dragging the rider under OV1 for approximately 100 ft. before stopping near the south curb.

AOI #1 was located approximately 53 ft. south of the north curb-line and 13 ft. west of the east curb-line. AOI #2 was approximately 28 ft. south of the north curb-line and 12 ft. west of the east curb-line. The POR of MC1 was approximately 7 ft. south of the north curb-line and 38 ft. west of the east curb-line for the front wheel; and 6 ft. south of the north curb-line and 33 ft. west of the east curb-line for the rear wheel.	The POR of OV1 was approximately 42 ft. south of the north curb-line and 101 ft. west of the east curb-line for the left front wheel, 48 ft. south of the north curb-line and 103 ft. west of the east curb-line for the right front wheel, 46 ft. south of the north curb-line and 92 ft. west of the east curb-line for the left rear wheel, and 46 ft. south of the north curb-line and 92 ft. west of the east curb-line for the right rear wheel.
RiderInj: The 23 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: a traumatic diaphragm rupture, multiple spine injuries, open lower right leg fracture, lacerated spleen, collapsed left lung and multiple abrasions to back. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 29.
ODriverInj: The 88 year-old female driver of OV1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report:	bilateral abrasions and contusions to forearms, from airbag deployment; abdominal contusion from the seatbelt and a left knee contusion from the steering column. The ISS was 1. Drugs and alcohol were not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to yield to oncoming traffic before making her left turn on an amber signal.	The rider of MC1 failed to stop for the phasing traffic signal and assumed that OV1 would wait for him to pass. The driver of OV1 also had a perception failure.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: MC1 was eastbound in the two-way left turn lane and had just changed lanes to the right into the #1 lane when he was rear-ended by OV1. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. OV1 fled the scene MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred after the rider had made a left turn from a side street at a ?T? type intersection, and then made a lane change into the #1 lane. The intersection has a stop sign only for the side street. It is a local street with no divider. The roadway where the crash occurred is a non-freeway minor arterial that has two lanes in each direction. West of the intersection, the westbound lanes have a dedicated left turn lane and is divided by double yellow painted lines. East of the intersection the roadway has a two-way left turn lane. The crash occurred during daylight hours. The surrounding area is comprised of commercial businesses on both sides of the roadway. The roadway has 12? concrete sidewalk on the rider?s right and a 6? grass strip on the left and then a 5? concrete sidewalk. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has an east/west designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway is in a slight southwest/northeast orientation with eastbound being at 80 degrees on a compass reading. In the rider?s direction, the roadway has a downgrade of -1.0%. The crown was measured to be 5.5%. Parking is allowed on either side of the roadway with some restrictions (red curb areas). The weather was clear with a moderate wind from the SSW. The temperature was +63 degrees F. The crash took place in April of 2015 in Southern California at 1803 hrs. There was no roadway construction in the immediate area of the crash. Traffic conditions were moderate to heavy, but flowing. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger. MC1 was taken from the scene to a friend?s house nearby.

MC1 was a 1983 Honda Nighthawk (655cc) that is categorized as a sport-touring type motorcycle with no modifications. The 69 year old male (5?10?/160 lbs.) rider purchased MC1 brand new from a dealership. MC1 had only 4,573 miles on it. The helmet that the rider was wearing was purchased at the same time. The helmet was a Shoei ER-7 full face motorcycle helmet with integral chin bar and a clear face shield. The helmet had labeling showing that it met FVMSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell 1980. The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence.	The rider was wearing clear prescription glasses. The rider stated
 
that he was wearing a leather jacket that was motorcycle oriented. He was not wearing any other motorcycle oriented protective clothing or gear. He stated that he wore denim jeans and below the ankle athletic shoes and no gloves. The rider had just finished a meal at a fast food restaurant and was headed home. The rider stated that he exited the parking lot and made a left turn onto the side street where the stop sign is. He said that he then stopped at the stop sign and was waiting for traffic to clear. He said that westbound traffic was fairly heavy and that there was an eastbound vehicle waiting to make a left turn. When there was a break in the westbound lanes and the left turning vehicle made its turn, the rider stated that he looked both ways and saw no vehicles approaching that would be a hazard to him. He then made his left turn into the two-way left turn lane. He was still accelerating and signaled to make a lane change to his right into the #1 lane. The rider believed that he was in second gear and going about 30 miles an hour. The posted speed limit on this street is 40 mph. After making the lane change the rider stated that he was impacted from behind and ejected off his bike. The rider said that he never saw the vehicle that hit him. The rider said that several people stopped to help him and that they moved MC1 to the side of the road and assisted him in getting out of the roadway before the police arrived. The POI was estimated by the police in the accident report based on statements. No physical evidence such as scrapes or gouges was listed in the report. A gouge was located in the street when the scene was inspected. It was located over 50? east of the stated POI. It is unknown whether or not it is related to this crash and not included in the diagram. A piece of the front grill from OV1 was found and collected as evidence by the police
at the time of the crash. No one was able to get the license plate number from OV1.	At least one witness said they thought they could recognize OV1 and the driver if seen again. A search for OV1 had negative results. MC1 landed on its left side plane and slid to its FRP. The rider pointed out on my diagram the approximate location as to where he thought he and MC1 ended up in relation to the POI. The rider sustained several abrasions and refused medical treatment at the scene. He never went to a doctor.
RiderInj: The 69 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions to his extremities and hands. The rider refused medical treatment at the scene. He never followed up with a doctor at a later date for his injuries. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 fled the scene with OV1. His impairment if any is unknown.
Human: The operator of MC1 had a perception failure in not seeing OV1 prior to making his lane change. The driver of OV1 may have had a reaction failure if the lane change by MC1 allowed sufficient time for one.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate damage to the rear portion as a result of OV1 impacting it. The rear taillight assembly and turn signals were broken off and the rear portion of the frame affecting the passenger seat area was bent. The left side of MC1 sustained minor damage from the roadway surface. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as like new.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) fatal crash event. The resulting impact between the two-vehicles caused motorcycle rider to be ejected on to the roadway surface, causing the fatal injuries.
MV1: 2005 Harley Davidson FLHTCUI Electra Glide Ultra Classic (Touring) 1449cc, red
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle fatal traffic collision. The collision occurred	on Thursday, April 2015 at 0942 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 0953 hours showed clear skies, with calm wind conditions.	The temperature was 73.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The overall unobstructed visibility for the area was 10.0 miles. The motorcyclist was traveling on a multi-lane minor arterial roadway surface with a downhill grade of 1.6%. The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be sharp and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit is 55 mph.
The collision occurred at a local street T-intersection on a right (2800? radius) curve downhill grade minor arterial roadway with an overall travel way width of 130 feet. The street although curved, runs primarily north and south with three lanes dedicated for northbound and three lanes dedicated for southbound traffic. North of the intersection the lanes are separated by a 20 foot wide raised concrete divider. South of the intersection the lanes are separated by a 3 foot wide raised concrete divider.	There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The local street runs east and west into both single family and multiple family residential areas. This street has an overall travel way of 54 feet. The There are two eastbound lanes on this street. The #1 lane is designated ?left turn only? for traffic entering the intersection and proceeding north onto the minor arterial roadway. The #2 lane is a right curve designed lane that feeds traffic directly onto the southbound lanes of the minor arterial roadway. The only designated traffic control device at this intersection is a posted ?STOP? sign regulating eastbound (left turn) traffic. The speed limit for the local street is 25 mph. There are no marked, posted or electronic signal devices to regulate the north and southbound lanes of traffic at the intersection.

MC1 was a 2005 Harley Davidson touring style motorcycle being operated by a 70 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a FMVSS-218 US DOT approved Harley Davidson brand ?Titanium Chrome? half shell style (37.5 ounce) motorcycle helmet equipped with a double ?D? ring chin fastener. The rider was in possession of a suspended California license. MC1 was traveling southbound in the #3 lane of the minor arterial roadway approaching the intersection at an approximate speed of 40 mph.
OV1 was a 2014 Toyota Corolla sedan type automobile being operated by a 48 year old male. OV1 was approaching the intersection eastbound in the #1 left
 
turn lane of the local street. The driver had stopped for the posted stop sign at the limit line prior to entering the intersection. When the driver thought it was safe he accelerated into the intersection and started his left turn towards the northbound traffic lanes. The driver of OV1 did not see the presence of MC1 approaching the intersection in the southbound #3 lane.
OV1 had moved a distance of about 26 feet into the intersection when it impacted with the right side front portion of MC1.	The rider had no time to react or conduct a collision avoidance maneuver. This was apparent due to the lack of any evidence of pre impact skids. The resulting impact ejected the rider off the motorcycle; vaulting him an approximate distance of	45? 10? until he impacted with the roadway surface sliding another 40 feet to his final resting place just south of the intersection. MC1 collapsed onto the roadway surface, left side down and was pushed or captured by the front of OV1 moving it approximately 39? 4? to its final resting place in the intersection. After the impact OV1 rolled a distance of approximately 46 feet until stopping inside the intersection adjacent
to MC1.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 70 year old male rider of MC1was treated at the scene and transported to a local emergency hospital however, he succumbed to the injuries sustained in this crash event. The injuries included but were not limited to: Subarachnoid hemorrhaging of the Midbrain, Basal skull fracture and, multiple parasternal rib fractures.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision.
Human:
The 70 year old male rider of MC1 was traveling at a speed safe for the present traffic on the roadway however may have employed poor lane position approaching the intersection.
The 48 year old male driver of OV1 failed to notice the presence of MC1 and made an unsafe decision to enter the intersection.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major right side damage as a result of the impact with OV1and minor left side damage after impacting with the roadway surface. MC1 appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
OV1 sustained major front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental:
Traffic on the local street is regulated by a maximum speed limit of 25 mph and a posted stop sign at the intersection. This provides the motorist the option to enter the intersection at their discretion. The minor arterial roadway has one regulation that being the posted speed limit of 55 mph (80.85 fps). At a normal acceleration rate it takes an eastbound vehicle leaving the limit line from a stopped position approximately 8 seconds to traverse across the southbound traffic lanes and safely enter the northbound lanes.

Providing southbound traffic adheres to the 55 mph speed limit, any traffic from the local street moving into the intersection could affect approaching traffic within 300 to 400 feet of the location. Considering the disparity in the two traffic regulations this intersection would be better suited with traffic signals.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in April 2015 at 1816 hours in Southern California. It was daylight, clear, the temperature was approximately 76 degrees F. and the winds were light. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn with heavy traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial area on the westbound side of an east/west state highway with 3 through lanes and a dedicated left and a dedicated right
turn lanes. The roadway is divided by a 4 ft. wide, 8 in. high center divider with no median barrier. The grade is 0.7% and the crown is 3.4%. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

MC1 is a 2013 Harley Davidson Soft-tail Deluxe (1868cc) cruiser style motorcycle ridden by a 51 year old female (4 ft. 11 in. and 232 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make and model motorcycle helmet. OV1 is a 1999 Jaguar XK8 driven by a 17 year old female (5 ft. 5 in. and 118 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was westbound in the #1 lane, stopped behind OV1 in heavy traffic. OV1 started moving forward but stopped suddenly as traffic ahead stopped. MC1 started forward at the same time as OV1.	MC1 attempted to swerve to the right in order to pass OV1 on the right side, lost control, fell on its right side and slid into the right underside and rear of OV1.
RiderInj: The 51 year-old female rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report:	a left wrist sprain and a contusion to the inner left leg. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 2.
Human: The rider of MC1 failed to stop when the traffic ahead stopped suddenly.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: This was a non-contact hit and run crash in which the rider over-braked with the rear brake and laid MC1 down on its left side plane. MC1 was westbound approaching an intersection when the crash occurred. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred as the rider was approaching a four-way, not skewed, signal controlled intersection. The roadway where the crash occurred is a non- freeway major arterial that has three lanes in each direction. Prior to and after the intersection, there is a 14? wide painted divider. In the area of the crash, the divider narrows down to 4? in both directions making room for dedicated left turn lanes. The crash occurred during hours of darkness. The area was illuminated by overhead spot illumination. The surrounding area is comprised of rural open space on the rider?s right and single family residential homes on the left. The roadway has 5? concrete sidewalk on the rider?s right that starts at the crash site and an 8? concrete sidewalk on the left. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. It had some surface cracking. The windy roadway has an east/west designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway is in a southwest/northeast orientation with westbound being at 190 degrees on a compass reading in the rider?s
direction. The roadway has a downgrade of -1.7%. The crown was measured to be 2.7%. No parking is allowed on either side of the roadway. The weather was clear with no wind. The temperature was +69 degrees F. The crash took place in April of 2015 in Southern California at 2039 hrs. There was no roadway construction in the area of the crash. Traffic conditions were light. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger. MC1 was towed. OV1 fled the scene.
MC1 was a 2007 Honda Shadow (745cc) cruising type motorcycle with aftermarket soft-sided saddle bags. The 21 year old male (6?02?/150 lbs.) rider was wearing a Cyber U-6 open face helmet with a snap on visor. The helmet had labeling showing that it met FVMSS 218 (US DOT). The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence.	The rider was not wearing any type of eye protection. The rider stated that he was wearing a leather jacket that was motorcycle oriented. He was not wearing any other motorcycle oriented protective clothing or gear. He stated that he wore denim jeans, below the ankle
 
athletic shoes, and no gloves.

The rider was on his way to his grandmother?s house which would be about a 20 mile ride. He stated that he had already ridden about 15 miles. He said that was originally in the middle (#2) lane and was approaching an intersection that had a red light for his direction of travel. He was cruising at a constant speed of approximately 50-55 mph. He saw that there were stopped vehicles in the #1 and #2 lanes of travel and that the #3 lane had no cars. He decided to change lanes to the #3 lane when he was about 2-3 blocks away. He stated that he anticipated that by the time he arrived at the signal, it would change to green and he could proceed without stopping. He said that he had let off on the throttle and was coasting once he changed lanes. As he neared the intersection, the light did change to green for his direction. As he started to accelerate, he stated that there was a car that came from the side street on his right. He said that the car came to the intersection and briefly stopped, then quickly made a right turn, cutting him off. In his opinion, the driver of the other vehicle did not see him even though he was riding with his hi-beams on. The rider stated that he panic braked and locked up the rear tire causing it to skid. He felt that he would not be able to stop without crashing into the other vehicle, so he intentionally laid MC1 down on its left side. He stated that he probably should have used more
front brake, but was afraid of losing control and crashing. He stated that he ?threw? MC1 down hard to the left so that it would go down. After MC1 was sliding on the roadway, the rider stated that he was fully ejected. The rider said that he tumbled several times on the roadway while in a fetal like position with his hands mostly up around his face. The rider stated that when he began to slow down from tumbling, he was able to roll up onto his feet and walk out of the street. He stated that he was never stopped, lying in the street after being ejected. There was one skid that was approximately 9? long in the #3 lane that was made by MC1. After going down, MC1 skidded/slid approximately 208? before coming to a stop near the curb. At one point prior to coming to rest, MC1 brushed up against the curb face causing minor scrapes to the seat and top of the rear fender. That POI is unknown. While sliding on the roadway, MC1 rotated in an unknown direction and was sliding rear end first. There was a witness that supported the rider?s statement of the OV.
RiderInj: The 21 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions to his extremities, hip, and buttocks. The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was admitted for one day. The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 fled the scene. It is unknown if there was any impairment or intoxication that contributed to the crash.
Human: The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 approaching the intersection. The operator of MC1 had a reaction failure in over-braking with the rear brake and poor braking overall.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor to moderate damage to the left side as a result of sliding on the roadway surface. The foot peg, shifter, and gas tank sustained the most damage. There was no fuel leak from the damaged area of the gas tank.	The top of the seat and fender sustained minor damage from impacting the curb face. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as good.

OV1 was not contacted and fled the scene. Its condition is unknown.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) sideswipe type crash event causing a secondary impact of MC1 into a raised concrete median and tree. The rider (MCR) was ejected off MC1 and also struck a tree in the center median causing fatal injuries.
MV1: 2005 Honda CBR600RR (Sport race replica) 599cc, red in color
OV1: 2009 Toyota Venza (Automobile) 4 door sedan, silver in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle fatal traffic collision. The collision occurred	on Monday April 2015 @ 1026 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1023 hours showed mostly cloudy skies, with calm wind conditions and an ambient temperature of 62.6 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The motorcyclist was traveling on a straight and level roadway surface (+0.1%). The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise was in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.
The collision occurred on a east/west multiple lane principal arterial roadway with an overall travel way width of 100 feet. There are three through lanes of traffic for both eastbound and westbound traffic.	The opposing lanes are separated by a 12 foot wide raised concrete median containing trees and low lying surface vegetation. On both the north and south sides of the roadway are designated 8 foot wide bicycle lanes. There are no designated traffic control devices to regulate the east/westbound traffic lanes other than the posted 45 mph speed limit signs.
The location of the crash scene was at an at grade ?T? style intersection with a 27 foot wide public driveway for traffic exiting a U.S. Post Office parking lot. The driveway allows for the exiting of vehicular traffic only and requires a right turn only on to the westbound lanes of traffic. There were no apparent super- elevation issues with this roadway.
The north side of the roadway is occupied by commercial and retail businesses including a U.S. Post Office. The Post Office and the businesses are open to public access throughout the day. There is also a multiple unit residential apartment complex a seven high cinder block wall facing the roadway. The south side of the roadway is occupied by numerous multiple unit residential apartment complexes as well. Both north and south sides of the roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks. The eastbound lanes of travel are not involved in this crash event.

MC1 was a 2005 Honda CBR600RR (sport race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 27 year old male rider.	MC1 was traveling westbound in the #2 lane of the three lane principal arterial roadway approaching the T-intersection driveway. Per witnesses at the scene, MC1 was traveling at an extremely high rate of speed (+70 mph), having started from an intersection 1350 feet east of the crash site.
OV1 was a 2009 Toyota Venza (automobile) being operated by an 80 year old female. The driver had initially stopped at the limit line prior to entering the
 
roadway. OV1 was exiting the driveway traveling in a southwest (right turn) direction as required by the traffic regulations. OV1 crossed the #3 and #2 lanes of the westbound lanes and was moving into the #1 lane at the time of the crash event.
As MC1 approached the driveway exit the rider, having noticed OV1 crossing the westbound lanes, started moving towards the westbound # 1 lane in an attempt to avoid the vehicle. As OV1 crossed into the #1 lane the rider of MC1 applied his brakes however failed to avoid a collision and struck the left side driver door and left front quarter panel of OV1. The resulting impact caused MC1 to collide with the raised concrete curb of the raised median strip. MC1 eventually vaulted over the top of the curb and both bike and rider collided with a tree which was positioned close to the center of the raised median strip. MC1 came to rest left side down on top of the raised median strip facing east adjacent to the same tree it had struck. The rider had vaulted off the bike impacting the same tree and was ejected a distance off approximately 31? 6? and an overall distance of 77? 9? from the original impact with OV1.
The rider was located lying face up along the south side of the raised median strip with his head positioned to the north	The resulting impact of the rider and the tree caused his helmet to eject off his head and it came to rest approximately 165? further down the street near the eastbound bicycle lane.
The driver of OV1 continued a short distance, westbound in the #1 lane and eventually brought her vehicle to a rolling stop in that lane, west of the crash site. There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj:
The 27 year old male rider of MC1 succumbed to the injuries he sustained in this crash event. His injuries included but were not limited to a transection of the brain stem, Basal skull fracture and a severe laceration to the Cerebellum. There was a presence of cannabinoids in the riders system.
The rider was wearing an FMVSS 218 (US DOT) approved full face motorcycle helmet with a clear face shield that sustained only minor abrasive damage however was ejected off his head during the crash event. This may have been attributed to a loose fitting strap at the time.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 27 year old male rider of MC1 was traveling at a speed considered unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway and failed to perceive the danger of a vehicle entering the roadway from a public driveway.
The 80 year old female operator of OV1 failed to perceive the presence of approaching traffic while entering the roadway.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major right front and left side damage as a result of impacting with OV1 and the tree. MC1 appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained moderate left side damage to the driver side door and left front quarter panel however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. 4 Door Sedan
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in March 2015 at 1930 hours in Southern California.	The skies were partly cloudy, dark with spot illumination, the temperature was approximately 64 degrees F and the winds were approximately 5 mph out of the southwest. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be in good condition, and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred at a T intersection, in a commercial area, on a predominately east/west oriented roadway (per the police report).	There are two 12 ft.
wide travel lanes and a 7 ft. wide bike lane in both directions. Westbound has a 9 ft. wide right turn lane and eastbound has a 10 ft. wide left turn lane. There is a 14 ft. wide raised center median, planted with grass and trees that divides the roadway.	The westbound grade is -4.1% and the crown is 4.5%.	There are no traffic controls for east/west traffic.	The base of the T is a commercial driveway with one 18 ft. wide southbound right turn lane and two 15 ft. northbound lanes separated by a 14 ft. wide, raised planted divider. There is a painted limit line set back approximately 9 ft. for the southbound lane with stop painted on the ground behind it.

MC1 is a 2005 Honda CBR-600-RR (599cc) sport, race replica motorcycle ridden by a 28 year old male (5 ft. 5 in. and 145 lbs.). The rider was wearing an HJC CS-R2 full face helmet.	OV1 is a 2008 Volkswagen Jetta 4 door sedan driven by a 22 year old male (5 ft. 11 in. and unknown weight).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was westbound in the #2 lane, traveling at approximately 40 mph. MC1 had just started to move into the #1 lane when the rider saw OV1 start to make a left turn across the westbound lanes into the commercial driveway. The rider stated that he applied both the front and rear brakes and then stood up on the foot pegs just before impacting OV1 behind the right rear door.	The Point of Impact (POI) was approximately 29 ft. west of the east curb-line and 22 ft. south of the north curb-line.	OV1 was eastbound in the left turn lane waiting to make a left turn into the commercial driveway.	The driver stated he was looking in the direction of westbound traffic but didn?t see MC1.	OV1 started the left turn and was traveling approximately 19 mph at the POI then continued into the driveway before stopping at its Point of Rest (POR) which was approximately 7 ft. west and 37 ft. north of the curb-lines.	The rider of MC1 was launched over the rear of OV1 and came to his POR approximately 62 ft. west and 21 ft. south of the curb-lines, while MC1 had an Area of Rest roughly 12 ft. west and 18 ft.
RiderInj: The 28 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the medical records:	right trapezium fracture, closed nasal bone fracture, chipped tooth, bilateral knee abrasions, abrasion and hematoma to the forehead. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 6. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to perceive MC1.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for this crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causation factors for this crash.

CrashType: This was a solo motorcycle (MC1) vs. multiple fixed objects; pick-up truck, garage wall, brick pilaster and fence. The impacts caused the rider to be ejected over the front of the bike impacting the garage wall and ground.	MC1 continued through a wooden fence prior to collapsing left side down onto a concrete patio. The rider sustained fatal injuries and was pronounced dead at the scene.
MV1: 1987 Harley Davidson FLSTC (chopper style) Soft Tail motorcycle, 1337cc
Crash:
This was MC1 vs. multiple fixed objects head-on crash event resulting in fatal injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Saturday, April 2015 at 2212 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed overcast skies, a SSW wind condition at 5.8 mph, and an ambient temperature of +60.6 degrees F. Sunset was at 1930 hours. MC1 was traveling eastbound on a 40 foot wide east/west straight and level local residential street that was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition and appeared to be worn otherwise was in satisfactory condition. The local street makes a 90 degree turn at the crash site and continues so as to facilitate north and southbound traffic. The speed limit in this area is not posted but would be recognized as 25 mph. There are no bicycle lanes on either side of the street however it is bordered by raised concrete curbs, a five foot wide grass parkway and four foot wide concrete sidewalks. The area on both sides of the street is occupied by two story single family residential dwellings that have driveways accessing this street. There were no crown or grade issues with this portion of the roadway. Visibility at ground level was clear and unrestricted.
The collision occurred when the rider failed to negotiate the turn to proceed north and departed the roadway driving onto an 18 foot wide private driveway, sideswiping a parked vehicle (pick-up truck). MC1 proceeded another 13 feet until impacting with the corner of a garage wall.
The garage is of a wood and stucco construction, single story 20 foot square to facilitate the parking of two-vehicles. The garage is attached to a two story single family home and faces the street. MC1 impacted the northwest corner of the structure careened through a wooden fence striking a brick pilaster before collapsing right side down onto a concrete patio. The rider was ejected off of MC1, striking the garage wall and the ground about 12 feet away.

MC1 was a 1987 Harley Davidson FLSTC Soft Tail (chopper style) motorcycle being operated by a 51 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a Soaring Mfg. FMVSS 218 (DOT) approved motorcycle (partial coverage) helmet with a double ?D? ring nylon chin strap. The helmet had no manufacturing date and weighed
38.45 ounces. The helmet had no face shield and was retained on the riders head throughout the crash event.
The rider resides in the neighborhood where the crash occurred. The rider?s residence is directly west of the location of the crash site. When I interviewed the owner of the property where the crash occurred he told me the rider was preparing to sell MC1 and wanted to start it up and get it ready for sale. The rider had allowed MC1 to sit idle without use for a period of about two years and made no effort to conduct safety or maintenance checks to it. During the inspection of MC1 it was discovered that the front tire had 13 psi and the rear tire 11psi. The rear tire was bald and without tread. There were no witnesses to the crash however the neighbor who also rides a similar make and model of motorcycle said he heard MC1 approaching his residence at a high rate of speed and
 
thought it to be in 3rd or 4th gear prior to the crash.
The rider had left his residence however it was unknown how long he was on the motorcycle until he returned eastbound approaching the 90 degree turn in the street. There was no apparent attempt to turn left up the local street, or brake prior to the crash. MC1 continued eastbound, departing the roadway onto his neighbor?s driveway. MC1 proceeded 30 feet into the driveway where the high rise left handle bar grip struck the left rear quarter panel of a full sized Ford F-150 4WD 4 door pick-up truck parked unattended in the driveway. MC1 and rider continued eastbound up the driveway another 13 feet until impacting with the northwest corner of the garage structure. The resulting impact caused the rider to be ejected over the top and head first into the garage wall. MC1 continued off the structure impacting a wooden fence and brick pilaster. MC1 finally collapsed right side down inside the property on a concrete pad. After impacting the garage wall the rider fell to the ground 12 feet away on grass turf.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event. There were no apparent roadway design issues at or near the location of the crash site.
RiderInj:
The 51 year old male rider of MC1 sustained fatal injuries as a result of this crash event. The rider was pronounced dead at the scene.	His injuries included but were not limited to a lacerated Liver, Spleen, and Aortic Wall. There was also hemorrhaging of both Kidneys as well as the Pericardial Sac.
Although there was no evidence of alcohol in his system, the deceased tested positive for the presence of Cannabinoids, Amphetamines as well as Methamphetamines.
Human:
The 51 year old male rider of MC1 was operating a motorcycle while under the presumptive intoxication of drugs as well as a motorcycle that had not been properly checked or serviced prior to it?s operation on the roadway.
The rider was licensed for the operation of motorcycles.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained major front end and left side damage. MC1 was in poor condition however due to the damage sustained items such as the throttle and front brakes could not be adequately inspected.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in May 2015 at 1730 hours in Southern California.	It was daylight, partly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 79 degrees F. and the winds were light from the WNW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry; and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred at a 4 way intersection, in a commercial/residential-apartment area.

bordered by hotels on the east and west sides and apartments to the south.	The east/west state highway has 2 lanes each way, the #1 lanes are 11 ft. wide and the #2 lanes are s5 ft. wide with painted parallel parking stalls to the right that are 10 ft. wide.	The roadway is divided by a raised 13 ft. wide concrete median with 10 ft. wide un-controlled left turn lanes.	The westbound grade is 0.2%, the crown is 3.8% and the posted speed limit is 45 mph. The north/south roadway forms the base of the T, is undivided with a 20 ft. lane in each direction separated by a painted double yellow center line with parallel parking on
both sides of the roadway. There is a stop sign with limit line that is set back 14 ft. for southbound traffic. The southbound grade is 0.4%, the crown is 3.6% and the posted speed limit is 25 mph.

MC1 is a 2012 Harley Davidson XL-1200C (1201cc) sport/race replica motorcycle ridden by a 21 year old female (5 ft. 7 in. and 145 lbs.). The rider was wearing an Icon Alliance, full face motorcycle helmet with a clear polycarbonate face-shield that weighs approximately 61 oz.	OV1 is a 2004 Toyota Corolla driven by a 19 year old male (5 ft. 5 in. and 115 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was westbound in the #1 lane at approximately 49 mph. OV1 was southbound crossing the westbound lanes of traffic, making a left turn.	The driver of OV1 stopped before starting the left turn. He stated; he looked at westbound traffic and it was clear. The driver of OV1 started his left turn across the westbound lanes and was struck in the left driver?s door by MC1. The rider of MC1 applied the brakes of MC1 and stated that she didn?t have enough time to swerve before striking OV1. The Point of Impact (POI) was approximately 26 ft. south of the north curb-line and 18 ft. west of the east curb-line.		MC1 was on its
 
left side in the #1 lane with major front crush damage facing southwest at its Point of Rest (POR), approximately 8 ft. west and 6.5 ft. north of the POI. The rider of MC1 was on her left side approximately 6.3 ft. north and 2 ft. west of the POI.	OV1 pivoted left and came to rest facing west in the #1 lane, the left front and rear tires were approximately 25 ft. south of the north curb-line, with the rear tire approximately 5.8 ft. west of the east curb-line and the front tire approximately 3.6 ft. east of the east curb-line.	OV1 sustained major damage to the left side front and rear doors.	The airbags did not deploy, both left door windows were shattered.
RiderInj: The 21 year-old female rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the medical report:	left elbow fracture, right 1-4 displaced tow fractures, left forearm puncture and scrapes to left eyebrow/forehead from eyeglasses.		The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 5.
ODriverInj: The 19 year-old driver of OV1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: forehead laceration. The ISS was 1. Alcohol and drugs were not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1 made his left turn in front of oncoming traffic, causing MC1 inadequate time to avoid the collision.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.

CrashType: MC1 was northbound in the #2 lane at a stated speed of 40 mph. He was attempting to untangle a wire from his wrist when he lost control and went down. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This is a solo loss of control MC crash. The crash occurred as the rider was riding on a straight and level roadway at a constant speed. The roadway has 3 through lanes in each direction that are separated by a curb high raised 10? wide divider. The crash occurred on the approach to a ?T? type intersection that is controlled by overhead electronic signal lights. The roadway where the crash occurred is a non-freeway minor arterial. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The intersecting roadway forms the ?T?. It has a total of 4 lanes and a curb high raised divider. It has one lane for an entrance and three lanes for exiting. There is a right and left turn only lane and a center lane that allows either a right or left turn. The surrounding area is comprised of large multi-story senior apartment complexes on both sides of the roadway. The roadway has 10? concrete sidewalk on both sides. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has a north/south designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway is in a slight northwest/southeast orientation. MC1 was traveling northwest at 340 degrees on a compass reading. In the rider?s direction, the roadway has an upgrade of
+3.0%. The crown was measured to be 4.6%. No parking is allowed on either side of the roadway. According to the police accident report, the weather was cloudy and the roadway surface was dry. Weather Underground makes no mention of precipitation. The rider stated that there was a ?heavy drizzle? and the roadway surface was wet. The wind was calm. The temperature was +57 degrees F. The crash took place in May of 2015 in Southern California at 0615 hrs.
There was no roadway construction in the immediate area of the crash. Traffic conditions were light. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger. MC1 was towed. The rider was taken to a nearby hospital for treatment and then released.

MC1 was a 2009 Yamaha TMAX step-through (499cc) type motorcycle with no modifications. The 47 year old male (6?00?/205 lbs.) rider purchased MC1 used from a dealership. The rider was wearing a HJC CL16 full face motorcycle helmet with integral chin bar and a clear face shield. The helmet had labeling showing that it met FVMSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell 2010. The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence.	The rider was wearing clear
 
prescription glasses. The rider stated that he was wearing a cotton sweat shirt, denim jeans, and below the ankle athletic shoes. He was wearing full fingered leather motorcycle oriented gloves.

The rider had just left his residence and was on his way to work. He stated that he was wearing his I-Pod ear buds under his helmet and that the I-Pod was in the forward glove box. The wire to the ear buds had somehow wrapped around his left wrist. The rider stated that he was approaching the intersection when he noticed this. He stated that he removed his right hand from the throttle and attempted to untangle the wire. As he did so, MC1 began to veer left. The rider said that he immediately put his right hand back on the handlebars and ?counter steered? to the right. In doing this, he stated that MC1 started to go ?out of control.? He stated that he then applied front brake in an attempt to slow MC1 down and regain control. He said that he applied too much pressure on the front brake and locked up the front tire. The rider said that because of the wet and slippery roadway surface, the front tire washed out and he crashed. When MC1 was inspected, both tire air pressures were low. The front tire had only 14 lbs. psi. It is rated to have 33psi. The rear tire had 25 lbs. psi. It is rated to have 41 psi. MC1 had not been ridden since the day of the crash and was stored in the rider?s garage. The rider said that his FRP was south of the intersection straddling the #2 and #3 lanes. He said that MC1 was ahead of him in the #2 lane. Both the rider and MC1 had moved from the roadway prior to the police arriving. While inspecting MC1, the scrapes and markings indicate that it mostly slid on its right side plane, front end forward. The rider pointed out the approximate location as to where he thought he and MC1 ended up in relation to the POI.
RiderInj: The 47 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions and contusions to his extremities and hip. He was treated at the scene, and then taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of MC1 was distracted as a precursor to his reaction failure in over steering and over braking.
Vehicle: The low tire pressure in both tires would be considered a contributing factor in crash causation. MC1 sustained minor damage consisting mostly of scrapes to the right side as a result of impacting the roadway surface. There was some very minor pre-existing damage to the left side. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as good.
Environmental: The wet or dry condition of the roadway surface could make a difference in whether or not any environmental would be considered as a contributing factor to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. another vehicle rear end type crash event. The motorcycle rider lost control causing the motorcycle to collapse onto the roadway surface prior to impacting with the other vehicle. The rider sustained minor injuries as a result of impacting the rear portion of OV1 while it was stopped in traffic. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2008 Kawasaki EX250J (sport race, replica) 249cc, white in color
OV1: 2005 Honda Odyssey automobile derivative (mini-van), blue in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) rear impact crash event resulting in minor injuries to the motorcycle rider. The collision occurred on Saturday, May 2015 at 1040 hours in Southern California. The weather report showed mostly cloudy skies, with variable wind conditions at 6.9 mph. The temperature was +63.0 degrees F. The roadway surface was found to be dry, level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There was a -1.1% downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred in the eastbound lanes of a divided four lane minor arterial roadway with an overall travel way width of 84 feet and at T style intersection with a 40 foot wide local street. The local street is not involved with this crash event. The east and westbound lanes are separated by an 8 foot wide raised concrete median containing low lying vegetation. There are mark and designated bike lanes on either side of the roadway. There is a slight right curve in the roadway proceeding and beyond the intersection however in the area of the intersection the roadway straightens out.
The intersection is controlled in all directions by a by multiphase electronic traffic control signals. The speed limit for both north and southbound traffic is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2008 Kawasaki EX250J motorcycle being operated by a 23 year old male. The rider was wearing an unknown make or model type motorcycle helmet.
The rider (MCR) was traveling eastbound in the #1 lane at an approximate speed of 25 to 30 mph prior to the crash event. MCR was in the company of one other rider (witness) and speaking with him on a Bluetooth helmet mount communications device.	As the MCR continued eastbound he advised the other rider that he wanted to turn left at the next intersection they were approaching. The other rider was just ahead and to the left of the MCR and felt as though they were approaching the intersection too fast to make a sudden lane change into the designated left turn lane. The MCR moved in behind the other rider and transitioned into the left turn lane continuing at his present speed. The MCR continued eastbound in the left turn lane however realized that traffic in front of him was stopped for a red phase light at the intersection. The MCR attempted to stop however applied too much front brake locking the tire and causing the rear tire to wash out to the left. MC1 collapsed left side down and both rider and bike slid into the rear of OV1. The overall distance from braking to mpact was approximately 56 feet.
 
OV1 was a 2005 Honda Odyssey mini-van being operated by a 50 year old female.	The OVD was eastbound stopped in first position of the left turn lane for a red phased signal light. The OVD said she had been stopped for a period of about 30 seconds when she felt an impact to the rear of her vehicle. The OVD exited her vehicle and went around to the rear to find the MCR lying on the ground and MC1 on its side.
RiderInj:
The 23 year old male rider of MC1 sustained a laceration to his chin and an undisclosed injury to his right hand (ring finger).
The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of this crash event. There was no evidence of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human: The 23 year old rider of was traveling at a speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway.	The MCR?s speed prevented him from having sufficient time to stop safely for traffic in front of him.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate left side damage as a result of the crash however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 sustained minor damage to the rear bumper however was otherwise in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in April 2015 at 1838 hours in Southern California.	It was dark, mostly cloudy, the temperature was approximately 66 degrees F. and the winds were light from the WNW. The asphalt roadway surface was dry; and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred at a T intersection with residential apartments on the north, south and east sides of the roadway and single family homes on the west side of the roadway.	The north/south roadway has three 12 ft. through lanes and a 7 ft. bicycle lane in each direction, separated by a 16 ft. wide center divider planted with trees and shrubs.	On the southbound side of the roadway there is an 11 ft. wide left turn lane for eastbound traffic and an 11 ft. wide merging
lane for westbound-southbound traffic. The east/west roadway is a 40 ft. wide residential street with 20 ft. wide through lanes. This roadway forms the base of the T intersection. The northbound lanes have a -5.5% grade with a crown of 4.1% and the speed limit is 50 mph. The westbound lanes have a -6.8% grade with a crown of 8.0% and the speed limit is 25 mph. There is a stop sign with limit line that is set back 12 ft. for westbound traffic.

MC1 is a 2014 Harley Davidson Ultra Limited FLHTK (1690cc) touring motorcycle ridden by a 63 year old male (6 ft. 1 in. and 300 lbs.).	The rider was wearing a Shoei St. Cruz half motorcycle helmet without a face-shield.	Helmet weighs 40.16 oz.	OV1 is a 2015 Dodge Charger driven by a 66 year old male (6 ft. 2 in. and 238 lbs.).	There was 1 passenger riding in OV1, seated in the #3 position.	All occupants of OV1 were reported to be using the available three- point manual lap and shoulder restraints.		MC1 was northbound in the #1 lane at approximately 40 mph.	As MC1 approached the intersection, the rider observed OV1 stopped at the stop sign.		OV1 was westbound crossing the northbound lanes of traffic, making a left turn to head south.	The driver of OV1 stopped before starting the left turn.	He stated that he looked both ways but didn?t see any vehicular traffic.	OV1 started across the northbound lanes when
the driver of OV1 observed MC1 approaching from the left.	MC1 braked and slowed to approximately 10 mph, but was unable to avoid OV1.	MC1 struck OV1 on the left side, at the drivers and rear passenger doors near the B pillar.	The Point of Impact was approximately 6 ft. north of the south curb-line and
approximately 36 ft. west of the east curb-line.	OV1?s left side tires Point of Rest (POI) were approximately 1.5 ft. north and 37 ft. west for the front tire and
10.5 ft. north and 34.5 ft. west for the rear tire.	MC1?s POI was approximately 10.5 ft. north and 32 ft. west for the front wheel and 5 ft. north and 33 ft. west for the rear wheel.	MC1 was on its right side. The rider of MC1 did not separate from MC1.
RiderInj: The 63 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related during the interview: minor laceration on the right elbow, right knee abrasion and right lower leg contusion.	The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1. Alcohol and drugs were not a factor in this crash.
Human: The driver of OV1?s perception failure, led to him making a left turn across the northbound lanes of traffic, in front of MC1, causing MC1 inadequate time to avoid the collision.
Vehicle: There were no crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash factors for MC1 or OV1.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. another vehicle broadside type crash event. The motorcycle collapsed onto the roadway surface sliding into the side of the other vehicle. The rider was ejected off of the motorcycle and impacted the roadway surface suffering minor injuries.
MV1: 2014 Harley Davidson XL883N Sportster (conventional) 883cc, brown n color
OV1: 2011 Audi Q7 (automobile derivative) white in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury crash event. The collision occurred on Saturday May 2015 at 1820 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1943 hours on this day. The weather report for 1756 hours showed partly cloudy skies, with winds from the south at 11.5 mph. There was an ambient temperature of 64.0 degrees F. Visibility was 7.0 miles and at ground level it was clear and unobstructed in all directions.	The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred beyond an ?at grade? T-intersection of a N/S minor arterial roadway with an overall travel way width of 60 feet and a local commercial street. The E/W local street was approximately 44 feet wide allowing for ingress and egress of vehicular traffic into local shopping areas.
The roadway runs with a right curve design for north and southbound traffic. There are two southbound lanes north and south of the T-intersection. There are two northbound lanes south of the intersection however this tapers down to one northbound lane north of the intersection.
Most of the eastside of the roadway north of the intersection allows for a safety lane and a bicycle/pedestrian access lane. The T-intersection is controlled by electronic traffic control signals however was not part of this crash event.
There is a 4 foot wide set of painted solid double yellow lines separating the north and southbound lanes of traffic north of the intersection. South of the intersection the lanes are simply divided by one set of solid double yellow lines. There are designated ?Bike? lanes on both sides of the roadway. The east and west sides of the principal arterial roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and adjoining 6 foot wide concrete sidewalks.
The west side of the roadway is occupied by independent retail/commercial businesses open to the public. The east side of the roadway is currently an open land development currently under construction. The posted speed limit for both north and southbound traffic is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2014 Harley Davidson XL883N conventional motorcycle (883cc)	being operated by a 19 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an unknown style motorcycle helmet. The rider was operating his motorcycle with a Valid California Driver?s license however it is not endorsed for the operation of motorcycles. The rider was traveling at an approximate speed of 20-25 mph northbound in the #1 lane. Both the MCR and the OVD had just passed through a signal controlled T-intersection with OV1 just ahead of MC1 at a reduced speed.
 
OV1 was a 2011 Audi Q7 (SUV) being operated by a 46 year old male driver. The OVD was driving northbound having just passed through the signal controlled T- intersection.	The OVD was attempting to locate a restaurant believed to be in the area and had reduced his speed to look for the business.	The OVD reduced his speed further and moved towards the right shoulder of the roadway however decided to make a U-Turn type movement to return to the area he had just drove through. The OVD said when he looked back from where he came his vehicle was struck along the left side by MC1.
The MCR had initially slowed his speed for OV1 when he saw it slow down. As OV1 moved towards the right shoulder the MCR regained his speed to continue northbound. The MCR said OV1 made a sudden U-Turn type movement and stopped in the roadway blocking his path. The MCR said he locked up his brakes and the motorcycle collapsed left side down and slid into the left side of OV1.
The front portion of MC1 struck the left side of OV1 causing minor damage. The MCR fell onto the roadway sustained an undisclosed injury to the right side of his pelvis.
The MCR, motorcycle and OV1 moved off the roadway prior to the arrival of law enforcement.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 19 year old male rider of MC1 sustained an undisclosed injury to the right side of his pelvis as a result of the collision. The rider was treated at the scene and removed from the scene to a local hospital for treatment. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The 46 year old male driver of OV1 was not injured and there was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 19 year old male rider of MC1 was operating his motorcycle at a speed safe for the present traffic on the roadway and could not react in time or conduct a proper collision avoidance maneuver prior to the crash.
The 46 year old male driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision to initiate a U-turn movement on the roadway having failed to perceive the proximity of the approaching motorcycle while making the turn.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate front and left side damage as a result of impacting with	the roadway surface and the side of OV1. The motorcycle otherwise appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event. OV1 sustained minor left side damage however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. 4 Door Sedan
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in March 2015 at 1930 hours in Southern California.	The skies were mostly cloudy, it was dark with spot illumination, the temperature was approximately 61 degrees F and the winds were approximately 7 mph out of the south-southwest. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn, and there was heavy traffic.

The crash occurred at a 4 way intersection, in a commercial area, on a predominately east/west oriented roadway with a solid double yellow painted center line.	The eastbound roadway has a 10 ft. wide left turn lane which is separated from the #1 lane by a white painted divider that is 6 ft. wide at the intersection crosswalk. The #1 lane is 12 ft. wide and the #2 lane is 13 ft. wide at the intersection crosswalk. The westbound lanes were not involved. The grade is 0.5%
and the crown is 4.8%.	Police and fire/rescue vehicles were present in the intersection for a different accident.

MC1 is a 2008 Kawasaki 650R Ninja (649cc) sport, race replica motorcycle ridden by a 61 year old male (5 ft. 6 in. and 160 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make/model helmet. OV1 is a 1999 Acura sedan driven by a 36 year old male (5 ft. 8 in. and 150 lbs.). The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

OV1 was eastbound ahead of MC1 in the #2 lane slowing before entering the intersection due to the flashing lights on the police and fire vehicles that were partially blocking the intersection. MC1 was eastbound behind OV1 approaching the intersection.	As OV1 entered the intersection, MC1 failed to slow or stop and collided with the rear of OV1. The rider of MC1 stated that he didn?t see OV1 slow or stop in the intersection.

The Point of Impact (POI) was approximately 9 ft. east of the west curb-line and 15 ft. north of the south curb-line. MC1 came to rest on its right side facing north just west of the POI. The rider stayed with MC1. After the collision, OV1 pulled across the intersection and stopped in the parking lot on the south/east corner.
RiderInj: The 61 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: fractured left tibia and fibula, NFS. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 4. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The rider of MC1 failed to perceive that OV1 was stopped.
