Vehicle: The gas cap on MC1 was missing and there was an allen wrench stuck in the broken ignition switch.
Environmental: There were emergency vehicles in the intersection that had responded to a prior accident that contributed to the crash.

CrashType: This was a solo MC crash in which the rider lost control just before entering a left curve. MC1 went down on its left side plane. MC1 was southbound approaching an offset intersection with an ?S? curve when the crash occurred. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred as the southbound rider was proceeding straight at a constant speed approaching a four-way, skewed, signal controlled intersection. The roadway where the crash occurred is a non-freeway minor arterial that has two through lanes in each direction and dedicated left turn lanes. In the rider?s direction there is also a dedicated right turn lane and an island. Prior to and after the intersection, there is a 14? wide painted divider. In the area of the crash, the divider narrows down to a pair of solid yellow lines in both directions making room for dedicated left turn lanes. The crash occurred during hours of daylight. The surrounding area is comprised commercial/industrial on the right and single family residential homes on the left. The roadway has 8? concrete sidewalk on both sides. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has a north/south designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway is in a southwest/northeast orientation with southbound being at 170 degrees on a compass reading in the rider?s direction. The straight transition in the middle of the ?S? curve has a compass reading of 150 degrees. The roadway has an upgrade of 1.0%. The crown was measured to be 1.7%. No parking is allowed on either side of the roadway. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. The weather was partly cloudy with a moderate wind from the south. The temperature was +65 degrees F. The crash took place in May of 2015 in Southern California at 0950 hrs. There was no roadway construction in the area of the crash. Traffic conditions were light. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger. MC1 was towed.

MC1 was a 2014 Kawasaki Ninja EX300B (296cc) sport/racing type motorcycle with minor modifications. The 20 year old male (5?06?/125 lbs.) rider was wearing an unknown make, model, or style of helmet. The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence.	It is unknown what safety gear if any the rider was wearing.
 
The rider stated that he was southbound in the #1 lane at an unknown speed approaching the intersection when he hit a ?bump? and lost control. He said that he tried to counter steer to regain control but it didn?t work.	There was no obvious ?bump? in the roadway	when the scene was inspected. Officers noted in the police report that the only ?bump? they could find was a pair of metal triangular water line access lids. These were inspected and no significant ?bump? could be detected. Tire striation marks were located in the southbound #2 lane, south of the intersection. The tire marks were right, left, and right in rapid succession indicating the front forks were out of control. This is commonly referred to as a ?tank slapper?. Immediately following the tire marks, scrapes and minor gouges in the roadway were visible. MC1 slid on its left side plane across the roadway into the northbound #1 lane for a total distance of 201?.
Calculations put MC1?s speed at approximately 50 mph at the time of impact. It is unknown how much faster the rider may have been going on his approach, or whether or not he had both wheels on the ground prior to losing control. The rider stated that after hitting the bump in the roadway, he attempted to counter steer. It is unknown which direction he tried to turn to first and whether or not it may have made a difference in preventing the crash. Approximately 5? of tire marks were located prior to the POI spanning a distance of a little over 23?. They appear to be made from the front tire rapidly rotating left and right out of control, commonly referred to as a tank slapper. After going down on its left side plane, MC1 slid approximately 201? to its FRP in the northbound lanes of the roadway. It is unknown where the rider?s FRP is. MC1 was inspected a few hours after the crash. The rear tire had very low air pressure that was measured to be 20 psi. This could be considered a contributing factor in why MC1 went out of control. The bump in the roadway that the rider mentioned and was inspected is not significant enough to have caused this crash by itself. In the police accident report, the rider stated that he was in the #1 lane. The tire marks and POI do not support the rider?s statement. The transition from the #1 lane to the #2 lane (headed right) where the crash sequence begins would be too sharp of an angle for MC1 to re-direct (headed left) and proceed in the direction it did without other external forces being applied. The rider contributed to this crash with a combination of errors which include high speed, poor maintenance, poor or incorrect reaction, and possibly a lack of experience.
RiderInj: The 20 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of abrasions to his extremities. The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released. The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of MC1 had a decision failure in riding at an excessive speed and possibly choosing the wrong reaction for his situation.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor damage to the left side as a result of sliding on the roadway surface. The over-sized ?sliders? prevented much more damage from occurring. The left mirror was broken off and there were some minor scrapes to the lower left side cover. The shifter, side stand, and left rear axle nut also sustained some minor scratches. When inspected, the rear tire had a low air pressure reading of 20 psi which could have been contributory for MC1 losing control while negotiating a curve. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as like new.
Environmental: The bump in the roadway is only considered a minimal contributing factor due to the excessive speed of MC1.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. roadway vs.parked vehicle (OV1) rear-end type injury crash event causing MC1 to collapse onto the roadway, ejecting the rider and causing non-life threatening injuries.
MV1: 1982 Harley Davidson FXR (shovelhead chopper) 1337cc, black in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. parked vehicle minor injury rear end traffic collision occurring on Thursday, May 2015 at 2125 hours in Southern California. The weather report at 2158 hours showed clear skies, with WNW winds at 5.8 mph and, an ambient temperature of 61.7 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions for 10.0 miles.
The collision occurred on a straight east/west two lane local residential surface street with a posted speed limit of 25 mph for both directions of travel. The roadway surface was dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There is a 2.9% downhill grade for eastbound traffic near the crash site. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. There were no significant roadway crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.
There is one lane for eastbound traffic and one lane for westbound traffic. The two opposing lanes are separated by one painted set of double yellow lines. Both lanes measure 20 feet wide and are bordered by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. There were no cross-streets in proximity of the crash site and no posted or electronic traffic control devices. The neighborhood is occupied by several two story multiple family apartment complexes which provide open driveway access to the street and each complex.

MC1 was a 1982 Harley Davidson (Shovelhead chopper) type motorcycle being operated by a 46 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an unknown style motorcycle helmet. The rider was traveling eastbound on the local street prior to the crash event.
OV1 was a 2007 Chevrolet Suburban (SUV) which was legally parallel parked (within 18 inches) and unoccupied facing east along the south side of the roadway.
Prior to the crash event the rider of MC1 was traveling eastbound at a speed of approximately 25-30 mph. As he continued driving east he drew his attention away from his operation of MC1 in order to check the status of his back pack which was secured to a rear ?sissy? bar. When he did this the rider failed to notice that MC1 was drifting to the right towards the south side of the street. Both the rider and MC1 continued drifting until he realized he was heading towards a parked vehicle (OV1). The rider attempted to brake however MC1 collapsed onto the roadway surface and struck the right rear portion of OV1 causing severe
 
damage to the front tire of MC1. The rider was ejected off of MC1 and sustained a minor injury to his lower back. OV1 sustained minor damage to the right rear portion of the bumper
RiderInj:
The 46 year old male rider of MC1 sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of this crash event. The injuries sustained were a	sprain to the Lumbar area of the spine. The rider was treated at the scene by emergency service personnel and subsequently transported to a local area hospital for treatment.
There was no evidence of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human: The 46 year old male rider of MC1 was operating his vehicle at a safe speed for the roadway and traffic however, failed to maintain his attention towards the safe operation of MC1 prior to the crash event.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front end damage as a result of impacting with the rear of OV1 however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained minor damage to the right rear portion of the rear bumper and appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a MC right frontal impact into OV left side crash type crash. Both vehicles were originally in the same direction in the same lane. MC1 went down on its left side plane after impact. The rider was fully ejected and sustained moderate injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a residential collector roadway at a ?T? type intersection. The side street intersects from the right. The roadway is a windy, up-hill in which both vehicles were negotiating a left curve just prior to the crash. There is one lane in each direction with a curb high raised divider that has several mature pine trees in it. There is a 4? concrete sidewalk on the right side of the roadway. On the left is grass and shrubbery. On the right is a small up-slope to the single family homes. On the left is a down-slope. The intersecting side street is on the right and is controlled by a posted stop sign.	There are no controls for the rider or OV, other than a posted ?NO U-TURN? sign in the center divider. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has a east/west designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway is in a northeast/southwest orientation with eastbound being at 50 degrees on a compass reading in the rider?s direction. The roadway has an upgrade of +9.4% at the crash site. The crown was measured to be 4.4%. No parking is allowed on either side of the roadway. The posted speed limit is 35 mph. The weather was overcast with a light variable wind. The temperature was +63 degrees F. The crash took place in May of 2015 in Southern California at 2015 hrs. There was no roadway construction in the area of the crash. Traffic conditions were light. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor to moderate injuries. MC1 had no passenger. Both vehicles were towed.
MC1 was a 2005 Yamaha V-Star (1063cc) cruising type motorcycle with minor modifications. The 22 year old male (6? 01?/170 lbs.) rider was wearing an unknown make, model, or style of helmet. It is unknown what safety ratings the helmet has. The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence. On-scene photos show that the rider had been wearing a black leather jacket, tan/brown over the ankle work style leather boots, and armored black and white leather gloves. It is unknown what if any, other safety gear the rider was wearing.
 
The rider stated that he was traveling between 45-50 mph and that he knew the speed limit was only 35. He said that he did not see OV1 until he was about ?2 car lengths? away from it. He said that he was not trying to pass OV1 on the left. The rider stated that when he saw OV1, it was stopped and appeared to be making a U-Turn. He said that he slammed on his brakes and down shifted, then impacted into the side of OV1. MC1 left approximately 52?03? of rear tire skid marks. When inspected, MC1 was unable to be moved and the skid patch could not be located on the tire. The 35 year old male (6? 01?/215 lbs.) operator of OV1 was visiting from out of state and driving a rental vehicle. He said that the GPS unit told he was going in the wrong direction for his location and to make a U-Turn. He said that he saw the opening in the center divider and began to turn around. He stated that he did not see or hear MC1 until the impact. He also said that he did not see the posted no U-Turn sign. The roadway has one lane in each direction and has no painted markings. In the direction of travel for both vehicles, it is a fairly steep up-hill with a left curve. The radius of the curve was calculated to be 1251?. The length of curve was measured at 1154?. The overall length and radius of the curve, combined with the trees in the center divider create a permanent view obstruction as a contributing factor to this crash, especially when excessive speed is added in. By MC1 rider?s own statement, he was going 10-15 mph faster that the posted limit, which is unsafe. The part of OV1 making an illegal U-Turn is also contributory to this crash, but is not as significant a contributing factor as is the speed of MC1. After impact, OV1 continued to move forward a short distance before coming to a stop. Following the initial impact, MC1 side-slapped OV1, causing damage from the driver?s
door reward to the left rear quarter panel. MC1 then went down on its left side plane and was under OV1. Some of the post-crash scrape marks were from MC1 being dragged across the roadway surface onto the tow truck. The rider appears to have been vaulted above ride height and flew over the engine hood. This was determined by a clothing scuff mark on the top of the left fender area and the riders FRP as indicated in the police accident report. The impact activated numerous air bags inside OV1. First, second, and third row side air bags were deployed on both sides of OV1 as well as the drivers? seat side and interior side
air bags. A passenger in seating position #3 sustained minor lacerations and contusions to the face.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of bi-lateral abrasions to his lower extremities. In the police accident report, multiple fractures were listed as possible, but were not able to be verified. The rider was taken to a local hospital. It is unknown if he was admitted or treated and released. The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 complained of pain to his left side. He was not transported to a medical facility. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to safely operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of MC1 had a decision failure in riding at an unsafe speed for the roadway. Because of his speed, he had a perception failure. The rider also had a reaction failure in poor braking. The operator of OV1 also had a perception failure in not seeing the posted no U-Turn sign.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front and right side as a result of impacting OV1. The front suspension, windscreen, handlebars, gas tank, crash bars, foot boards, exhaust system, and right saddle bag all had significant damage. MC1 also sustained moderate damage to the left side from sliding on the roadway surface. The left mirror, crash bar, gas tank, footboard, battery box, and saddlebag sustained damage. When inspected, the front tire had a low air pressure reading of 24 psi. This is not considered contributory to this crash. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as fair.
 
OV1 sustained moderate damage to the left side. Damage was located from the initial impact near the ?B? pillar to both the forward and rear doors. MC1 then side slapped OV1 as both vehicles continued their forward movement. Damage to OV1 continued to the left rear quarter panel. The left running board also sustained damage. The pre-crash condition of OV1 would be considered like new.
Environmental: The curvature in the roadway along with the tree lined center divider is considered contributory to this crash as a permanent view obstruction primarily due to the excessive speed on the part of MC1. At the posted speed, a stopped vehicle would clearly visible at a safe distance allowing plenty of time and space for a safe stop.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. SUV
Crash:
This single vehicle crash occurred in June 2015 at 0713 hours in Southern California.	There was light rain, the temperature was approximately 68 degrees F and the winds were light and variable. The asphalt roadway surface was wet, noted to be travel worn and there was heavy traffic.

The crash occurred in a residential area on a predominately east/west oriented roadway at a T intersection.	There are two 11 ft. wide through lanes, a bike lane with parallel parking against the right hand curb and a 14 ft. wide center median that is planted with grass and trees.		The eastbound grade is -1.9% and the crown is 2.6%. The base of the T is a predominately north/south roadway with a single 20 ft. lane in each direction.	A limit line with stop painted on the roadway was south of the limit line and a stop sign on the right side was approximately 6 ft. south of the limit line.

All measurements were taken using a east running station line with the Reference Point (RP) being east/south curb prolongations.

MC1 is a 2006 Harley Davidson FLSTFI Fatboy (1450cc) cruiser style motorcycle ridden by a 55 year old male (6 ft. 3 in. and 282 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make and model of helmet.

MC1 was eastbound in the #2 lane at approximately 25 mph approaching stopped traffic. As MC1 approached the T intersection the rider observed a vehicle roll past the limit line in the northbound lane. The rider panicked when he thought the vehicle wouldn?t stop and would collide with MC1.	He aggressively applied both the front and rear brakes, skidded for approximately 11ft. MC1 low-sided onto the right side and slid in the #2 lane for approximately 11 ft. to its Point of Rest. Both the front and rear tires were grossly underinflated, there was approximately 18 psi. in the front tire and approximately 14 psi in the rear, which contributed to the loss of control.
RiderInj: The 55 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: fractured right leg, NFS. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 4. Alcohol was not a factor in this crash.
Human: The rider of MC1 panicked and over braked, causing MC1 to low-side on the wet roadway.
Vehicle: Both the front and rear tires were grossly underinflated.
Environmental: Light rain and slippery roadway were contributing crash causal factors.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. automobile (OV1) broadside type crash event with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface. The rider (MCR) was ejected off of the motorcycle impacting the roadway surface and suffering serious injuries.
MV1: 2009 Suzuki 1300RH ?Hayabusa (sport race replica) 1340cc, white & blue custom
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. automobile injury crash event. The collision occurred on Monday June 2015 at 2043 hours in Southern California.	The weather report for 2053 hours showed scattered clouds, with winds out of the west at 3.5 mph. There was an ambient temperature of 66.0 degrees F. Visibility was
10.0 miles and at ground level it was clear and unobstructed in all directions.	The roadway surface for MC1 was a left curve, uphill grade of 2.1% with a 5.1% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? offset (skewed) four way intersection of a minor arterial surface street with an overall travel way width of 82 feet. There is a commercial shopping center along the west side of the roadway and a single family residential neighborhood to the east. The driveway was approximately 41 feet wide allowing for ingress and egress of vehicular traffic into the center. There is a 20 foot long triangular center raised concrete divider separating the entry and exit lanes.
The roadway is curved to the right for MC1 and runs north and south with two lanes dedicated for northbound and two lanes dedicated for southbound traffic. There is a 14 foot wide painted two way left turn lane separating the north and southbound lanes of traffic on the south side of the intersection and a designated left turn lane on the north side of the intersection to allow traffic into the residential neighborhood. There are designated ?Bike? lanes along both sides of the roadway. There are no electronic or posted traffic control devices at the intersection or in proximity of the crash site other than posted ?stop? signs for east and westbound traffic exiting the shopping center and the residential neighborhood. The east and west sides of the roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and adjoining 7 foot wide concrete sidewalks.	The retail/commercial shopping center was open for public access. The posted speed limit for both directions of travel is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2009 Suzuki RH1300 Hayabusa sport race replica style motorcycle being operated by 48 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a Scorpion model KDT-10 full face motorcycle helmet with a FMVSS 218 DOT and Snell 2005 rating. The helmet was blue and white in color, size large equipped with a smoke colored plastic adjustable visor nylon straps and double ?D? ring fasteners. The rider was southbound in the #2 lane approaching the intersection an
 
approximate speed of 50 mph.
OV1 was a 1997 Nissan Maxima (automobile) being operated by an unlicensed 25 year old female driver. The OVD was initially traveling in the northbound #1 lane however, at the last moment made a sudden left turn movement towards an entrance to a shopping center along the west side of the roadway. During the left turn movement the OVD crossed the southbound #1 lane and started crossing the southbound #2 lane when she suddenly stopped her vehicle. The MCR saw the OVD from the time she started her left turn however failed to anticipate her stopping in the roadway. The MCR attempted to avoid hitting OV1 by applying both front and rear brakes however this caused the motorcycle to fishtail. The MCR had no time to swerve away from OV1 and subsequently struck the vehicle along the right side just in front of the B-Pillar injuring a passenger seated in the right front passenger seat. The resulting impact caused the motorcycle to collapse left side down adjacent to OV1 and ejected the rider into the right side of the vehicle and onto the roadway surface. The MCR could not provide any information regarding where he came to rest on the roadway as well as the position of his motorcycle.

At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 48 year old male rider of MC1 sustained serious injuries as a result of the collision. The rider was immediately removed from the scene and admitted to a local hospital for treatment. The MCR sustained a series of fractures to the C3 through C6 Cervical vertebra as well as a dislocated C7 vertebra. The rider also sustained a cerebral hemorrhage and was bleeding from his mouth and nose. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The 25 year old female driver of OV1 was not injured. A 22 year old female seated in the right front passenger seat sustained a laceration above the right eyebrow as well as a complaint of pain to her head. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 48 year old male rider of MC1 was traveling at a speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway. The rider could not react in time or conduct a proper collision avoidance maneuver prior to the crash. The rider could not bring his motorcycle to a stop by utilizing front and rear braking only due to the proximity of OV1. The rider was properly licensed for operation of a motorcycle.
The unlicensed 25 year old female driver of OV1 made an unsafe turning movement towards a shopping center driveway entrance.	Her decision to turn and then suddenly stop in the roadway was the proximate cause of the crash event. She was not properly licensed for the operation of her vehicle.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front and minor left side damage as a result of impacting with the right side of OV1 and the roadway. The motorcycle otherwise appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained major right side impact damage in the area at or near the B-Pillar however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) broadside type injury crash with a primary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle rider to lose control and impact the roadway. The rider fell to the roadway surface sustaining minor injuries. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash.
MV1: 2000 Harley Davidson Soft tail FXSTD (modified chopper) 1488cc, black in color
OV1: 2010 Mercedes Benz S550 (Automobile) silver in color
Crash:
This was an MC1 vs. OV1 broadside type injury crash event. The collision occurred during evening hours on Saturday, June 2015 at 2107 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 2003 hours. The weather report for 2058 hours indicated clear skies, with SSW winds at 4.6 mph and, an ambient temperature of
63.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed for 10.0 miles in all directions.	The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred on a straight ?at grade? T-intersection of a multiple lane Principal Arterial (State Highway) that has an overall travel way width of 80 feet. The roadway runs east and west with two lanes for each direction of travel. The opposing lanes are separated by a 16 foot wide painted divider. There are 8 foot wide designated ?bike lanes? for each direction of travel on this roadway. Speed limit is 50mph.
The intersecting north/south roadway is an 82 foot wide multiple lane minor arterial providing two lanes for each direction of travel. On the southbound approach to the intersection there are two lanes designated for left turn only and one lane designated as right turn only. There is also an 8 foot wide ?bike lane? provided for northbound bicycle traffic. There are also raised concrete sidewalks and marked crosswalks provided to allow access to both a public beach area south of the intersection and residential neighborhoods to the north of the intersection. The intersection is controlled by electronic multiphase traffic signals.
MC1 was westbound on approach to the intersection with a -1.2% downhill grade. The rider was traveling at a speed of 45 mph splitting lanes between the #1 and #2 northbound lanes of travel prior to the crash event.
OV1 was westbound in the #1 lane on the approach to the intersection. The driver was slowing on his approach due to an accident being investigated by law enforcement. West of the intersection both the through lanes of traffic were blocked by police vehicles and all westbound traffic was being redirected north onto the minor arterial roadway.

MC1 was a 2000 Harley Davidson FXSTD (chopper style) motorcycle being operated by a 32 year licensed male rider. The rider was traveling at a speed of about 45 mph westbound on the Principal Arterial splitting the #1 and #2 lanes while approaching the intersection.	The rider was wearing an unknown style
 
motorcycle helmet at the time of the crash.
OV1 was a 2010 Mercedes Benz S550 (automobile) being operated by a licensed 51 year old male driver. OV1 was traveling westbound in the #1 lane of the Principal Arterial roadway slowing down as he approached the intersection. The driver was slowing in response to the police vehicles west of the intersection and traffic being diverted north. There were vehicles occupying both westbound lanes of traffic at the time and all westbound traffic was moving north at the intersection.
As the rider of MC1 continued his approach and lane splitting, he attempted to turn right as directed however, he struck the right side of OV1 which caused his motorcycle to collapse right side down and onto the roadway surface, sliding into the intersection. The rider was ejected off of MC1 and sustained minor injuries.
As the driver of OV1 initiated his right turn at the intersection his vehicle was struck on the right side by MC1. The driver of OV1 did not sustain any injuries.
RiderInj: The 32 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries was treated at the scene by paramedics and subsequently transported to a local area hospital. The injuries sustained were an undisclosed injury to the left wrist (possible fracture) and an undisclosed injury to the left lower leg. There no was evidence of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries. There was no evidence of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The rider of MC1 could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of OV1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver.
The driver of OV1 slowed to make a required turning movement as directed by law enforcement and did not contribute to the cause or outcome of this crash event.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate left and right side damage as a result of impacting the right side of OV1 and the roadway surface however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained minor right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a solo MC running off the roadway type crash. MC1 went wide while negotiating a right curve and impacted the center divider and a sign post before going down on its left side plane. The rider was fully ejected and sustained moderate injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a private residential collector roadway just prior to a ?T? type intersection. Traffic exiting may only make a right turn. The roadway has a right curve and is uphill as it approaches the posted stop sign. The intersecting minor arterial with two lanes in each direction has a curb high raised center divider. The crash roadway has one lane in each direction with a curb high raised divider that has grass, two mature trees and a non-breakaway metal sign post that has three different metal signs on it. The signs face towards in-coming traffic. The top sign is black and white and indicates that there is a divider.
The other two signs indicate that the area is private property and lists some rules and regulations. Both sides of the roadway have a 3? strip of grass followed by a 4? concrete sidewalk. The area is comprised of duplex style single family homes.	The roadway on the approach to the crash site is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, has a slurry coat with numerous tar snakes, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway where the crash occurred is made
up of stamped concrete and the majority of it is dyed red to resemble terra cotta tiles. This portion of the roadway is free of cracks or any other deformity.	The roadway has a north/south designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway is in a southwest/northeast orientation with southbound being at 220 degrees
on a compass reading in the rider?s direction. The roadway has an upgrade of +5.1% at the crash site. The crown was measured to be 1.9%. Parking is allowed on either side of the roadway on the approach of the crash scene but is prohibited in the immediate area of the crash site. The posted speed limit is 15 mph. The weather was clear with no wind. The temperature was +65 degrees F. The crash took place in June of 2015 in Southern California at 1928 hrs. The lighting was described as dusk/dawn in the police report. There was no roadway construction in the area of the crash. Traffic conditions were light. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor to moderate injuries. MC1 had no passenger and was towed.
 MC1 was a 2014 KTM 69 Duke (690cc) dual purpose on-road, off-road type motorcycle with no modifications. The 21 year old male (6? 02?/205 lbs.) rider was wearing a T-shirt, gym shorts, slippers, and no gloves. The rider was wearing an AVG full face helmet with integral chin bar and clear face shield. The helmet had labeling that indicated it met FMVSS 218 (DOT) and ECE-22-05 safety ratings. The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence.

The rider stated that he had just left his residence and was headed to the store to maybe get something to eat. He said that he made the right turn from his street to the collector street in his complex that led to the exit. The rider stated that after he completed the turn, he began to accelerate towards the stop sign. At that time he experienced rapid acceleration that was uncontrollable. The front tire rose up off the ground and he was unable to control MC1. He said that he pulled in the clutch lever in an attempt to stop or slow down the bike, but that it didn?t work.	The rider stated that the rear tire of MC1 impacted the curb high center divider while the front tire was still up in the air. MC1 continued forward and impacted the metal sign posted at the west end of the divider. The rider said that as he and MC1 were passing the sign, his left lower leg was severely lacerated by one of the three signs mounted to the metal post. The entire post was knocked over from the impact. The metal post was set in concrete that was approximately 12?x24?. The rider said that he was fully ejected at that point and fell off to the right, landing in the street. MC1 continued in its southwest direction and came to rest along the center divider. In the police accident report, the rider said he wasn?t sure if he was ?hit by a car or if he was doing a wheelie.? The rider stated that he has been riding dirt bikes for approximately 14 years. He said that he is very experienced at riding motorcycles but this is his first ever street bike. He has never taken a rider safety course. The rider has owned MC1 for only three months and it has 651 miles. By the rider?s own admission, MC1 has a lot of power. When MC1 was inspected, no issue could be detected with the clutch or throttle. Both appeared to be in normal working order. Based on the rider's statements and comparing his riding experience along with the condition of MC1, it is still unknown if the wheelie was intentional or accidental. Either way, the rider lost control of the wheelie and crashed. He stated that he pulled in the clutch and that MC1 kept accelerating. It would appear that instead of pulling in the clutch, the rider stayed on the throttle until the he was ejected.

Additional Information: The day the controls were being conducted, the rider for Control Motorcycle #1 left immediately after his interview. He refused to allow us to photograph his MC or helmet. His motorcycle was fully inspected during his interview. His motorcycle appeared in the background of two photographs of another Control MC. His MC was cropped out of the original photograph, sanitized, and added to the Control section in the Images File.
RiderInj: The 21 year old male operator of MC1 sustained a major laceration to his lower left leg with unspecified nerve damage, a minor laceration to his lower lip, and numerous abrasions. The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was admitted for two days.	The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of MC1 had a reaction failure in attempting to apply the clutch when he should have released the throttle. The rider may have also had a comprehension failure in not realizing how much power MC1 truly has and the differences between dirt riding and street riding.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate to minor damage to the forks and left side as a result of impacting the curb, sign, and sliding across the roadway surface. The front suspension, handlebars, gas tank, and foot pegs were all damaged. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as new.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors, permanent or temporary, that were considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a vehicle (OV1) vs. vehicle (OV2) vs. motorcycle (MC1) multiple impact rear-end type minor injury traffic collision causing MC1 to collapse on to the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider sustained non-life threatening injuries and was treated and released at the scene. There were no passengers on MC1 at the time of this crash event.
MV1: 2005 BMW R1200GS Dual Purpose (1170cc) blue & black in color
Crash:
This was vehicle (OV1) vs. vehicle (OV2) vs. motorcycle (MC1) multiple impact minor injury traffic collision occurring during the daylight hours on Monday, June 2015 at 1745 hours in Southern California. The weather report for this region showed overcast skies, with winds out of the WSW at 5.8 mph and, an ambient temperature of 66.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions for 9.0 miles. The roadway surface was dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There is a -4.4% downhill grade in the area of the crash site.
The collision occurred on a left curve multiple lane principal arterial roadway with an ?at grade? four leg intersection. The intersection is controlled by multi- phase traffic control signals with four lanes dedicated for westbound traffic and four lanes for eastbound traffic.	The opposing lanes are separated by a 2 foot wide raised concrete median.
There are two designated left turn lanes for westbound to southbound traffic as well as two designated left turn lanes for eastbound to northbound traffic. There are no designated ?Bike Lanes? on either side of the roadway and the overall travel-way width of this street is 116 feet. There are commercial and retail shopping centers in all four quadrants.
There is a posted speed limit of 45 mph for both east and westbound traffic. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway. There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.

The case vehicle (MC1) was a 2005 BMW R1200GS (dual purpose) motorcycle being operated by a 56 year old male rider. The rider had been travelling westbound in the designated #1 lane of the multi-lane surface street and was stopped behind a white Jeep SUV for a red phased traffic light.
OV2 (2011 Toyota Camry automobile) was being operated by a 28 year old female. The driver of OV2 was stopped behind MC1 prior to the crash event. OV1 (2008 Volkswagen Jetta automobile) was being operated by a 22 year old female. The driver of OV1 was traveling westbound in the #1 lane at an approximate speed of 5-10 mph (off throttle) approaching OV2 from behind prior to the crash event.
 
As the rider was stopped waiting for the light to phase he noticed the signal for his direction of travel phase to green and the white Jeep SUV started to move forward. The MCR was still at a standing stop when his bike was struck from behind by OV2.	MC1 was pushed forward a few feet and collapsed left side down with OV2 on top of it.	MC1 did not come into contact with the white Jeep SUV. The MCR was ejected off of MC1 on to the roadway surface within six feet of the bikes FRP. The impact of OV2 and MC1 were as a direct result of the initial rear end collision of OV1 striking the rear of OV2 as it was stopped in traffic behind
MC1. The motorcycle sustained minor damage to the rear fender and the left side once it collapsed onto the roadway surface. While inspecting the scene I found no evidence of pre or post impact skid marks from any of the involved vehicles.	At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
No scene photos were taken by law enforcement at the time of their investigation.
RiderInj:
The 56 year old male rider sustained non-life threatening injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were a contusion to the left forearm, an abrasion to the right elbow and a 2nd degree burn injury to the right forearm as a result of coming into contact with the exhaust manifold of the motorcycle. The rider was treated and released at the scene and none of the other parties OVD1 & OVD2 sustained injuries as a result of this crash event.
The police report indicated that there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system as well as the other drivers.
Human:
The 22 year old female driver of OV1 had been traveling at a speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway.
The 28 year old female driver of OV2 was stopped in traffic and did not contribute anything to the cause or outcome of this crash event. The 56 year old male rider of MC1 was stopped in traffic and did not contribute to the cause or outcome of this crash event.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor rear and left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision. MC1 was towed to the rider?s residence at his request.
OV2 sustained minor rear and front end damage however, was in satisfactory operating condition. OV2 was driven away. OV1 sustained minor front end damage however, was in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 was driven away.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: MC1 was westbound approaching a four-way, not skewed intersection when the rider attempted a stunt and fell off. The riderless MC1 veered to the left and impacted OV1 that was making a left turn. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a four-way, not skewed type intersection that is controlled by overhead signals. The signals had no part in the crash causation. Both MC1 and OV1 were on the same roadway going in the same direction. The roadway in their direction of travel is straight and has three through lanes, two dedicated left turn only lanes, and a bike lane. The roadway has a curb high center divider that is landscaped with small greenery and grass. The roadway is a minor arterial. The roadway has concrete sidewalks on both sides and some trees. The surrounding area is single family residential on both sides with the exception of the right corner which is a commercial business. The intersecting roadway is also a minor arterial. No on-street parking is allowed. The crown for the roadway was measured to be 4.1% and the grade was measured to be 1.0%. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. The roadway is designated as north/south however at the crash site is in an east/west orientation. Both vehicles were westbound at 270 degrees. The speed limit is posted at 45 mph. The weather was listed as clear with a temperature of +77 degrees F. There was a light wind from the SSW. The crash occurred in Southern California in June of 2015 during hours of daylight at 1632 hrs. There was no construction in the area of the crash. MC1 was towed and OV1 was driven away after the accident report.

MC1 was a 2009 Honda VT750C (745cc) cruising type motorcycle with minor modifications. The known modifications include the removal of the front fender, exhaust system, and the rear turn signals. The 22 year old male (6? 08?/150 lbs.) rider was wearing unknown clothing and an unknown brand or style helmet.

The rider stated in the police report that he was northbound in the #2 lane going approximately 40 mph. He stated that he was ahead of ?most of the traffic.? He stated that he decide to stand up on his motorcycle and perform a trick. He said that he went from sitting to kneeling, and then attempted to stand up. The rider admitted that his upper body and most of his legs were almost extended while standing on the seat. It is not known if he still had his hands on the handlebars or not. He the lost control and ?went down.? MC1 continued rolling under its own power, veering left and impacting OV1 on the left side. MC1 then
 
crashed onto the roadway. A witness to the crash saw the rider attempting to stand on the seat and crash. The witness stated that after the rider stopped rolling in the roadway, he got up and began to run after his motorcycle. The witness stated that it was too late and that MC1 had already entered the intersection and impacted OV1. The 49 year old female (5? 04?/125 lbs.) operator of OV1 stated that she had been stopped for a red left arrow in the #1 left turn lane. She stated that upon receiving the green arrow she proceeded forward into the intersection making her left turn. Somewhere in the middle of the intersection she heard a loud impact and saw that the riderless MC1 had impacted her left rear door. She stated that she completed turning maneuver and parked to the right curb. From there she could see the rider moving his motorcycle from the roadway.
RiderInj: The 22 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of strains the cervical and lumbar regions, and an unspecified injury to his right ankle. The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released. The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 49 year old operator of OV1 was not injured. She did not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit her ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The rider of MC1 had a decision failure in attempting to perform a stunt of standing on the seat and losing control, causing the crash. The operator of OV1 had no contribution to the crash.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained minor damage to the right side from impacting OV1 and minor damage to the left side from impacting the roadway surface. On the right side, the front turn signal was broken, the foot peg and brake lever were bent and non-functional. The single small saddle bad and exhaust pipes sustained some scratches. On the left side, the handlebars, clutch lever, battery side case, foot peg, and rear axle minor scratches from impacting the roadway. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered as good.

OV1 sustained minor damage to the left rear door and handle as a result of MC1 impacting it. There was also damage to the left rear wheel where the foot peg/brake lever made contact.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a solo MC running off the roadway type crash. MC1was riding in the painted divider passing other vehicles when the painted divider became a raised divider.	MC1 impacted the center divider. The rider was fully ejected and sustained major injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a non-freeway principle arterial. The roadway has a 14? wide, paved curb high center divider that begins at the crash site. The crash roadway has two lanes in each direction. Both sides of the roadway are bordered by an emergency lane/bike trail that varies in width but averages approximately 8?. The area off the roadway is comprised of sand and some ground cover. The surrounding area is comprised of a nature preserve on the right and a public beach on the left. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has an overall north/south designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway is in a northwest/southeast orientation and is designated as an east/west roadway in the police accident report with westbound being at 310 degrees on a compass reading in the rider?s direction. The roadway is level with a grade of +1.6% at the crash site. The crown was measured to be 2.1%. No parking is allowed on either side. The posted speed limit is 60 mph. The weather was overcast with a light wind from the east. The temperature was +64 degrees F. The crash took place in June of 2015 in Southern California at 0719 hrs. There was no roadway construction in the area of the crash. Traffic conditions were light. The rider was fully ejected and sustained major injuries. MC1 had no passenger and was towed

MC1 was a 2014 BMW S1000RR (999cc) sport/racing type motorcycle with minor modifications which included engine guards and lighting. The 25 year old male (5? 08?/190 lbs.) was wearing a thin long sleeve shirt, slip on tennis shoes, and armored nylon gloves. The rider was wearing a Scorpion EXO-R410 Slinger full face helmet with integral chin bar and gray/smoke face shield. The helmet had labeling that indicated it met FMVSS 218 (DOT) and Snell 2010 safety ratings. The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence.
 
The rider was northbound in the #1 (left) lane at a high speed. Witnesses stated that MC1 was going in excess of 80 mph. Speed calculations show MC1 traveling at 96 mph. He was passing other vehicles while riding in the painted divider area.	At the point of impact, the painted divider terminates and becomes a 14? wide curb high raised center divider. MC1 impacted the right corner of the center divider at about four or five o?clock on a clock face orientation. The impact caused both rims to fracture, deflating both tires and send MC1 tumbling out of control. The rider was fully ejected off of MC1 and flew above ride height before landing in the left lane and skidding/sliding to his FRP. MC1 rode the curb of the divider for approximately 93? scraping the transmission case and other components on the left side plane of MC1 before landing on one of its sides. Which side MC1 landed on first is unknown. MC1 slid a distance of approximately 766? before coming to rest at its FRP. During this distance, MC1 flipped at least one time, possibly more, and rotated in and unknown direction. MC1 was found on its right side plane. MC1 was facing in a northeast direction. The rear tire area at the axle was on the paved surface of
the roadway and the rest of MC1 was in the sand on the side of the road. The rider slid an unknown distance. One scuff mark appears to be that of the rider and his clothing. This scuff mark terminates at the rider's FRP and is approximately 105? in length. The rider?s FRP is 461? from the POI.	The helmet that the rider was wearing had several impacts and major abrasions. This would indicate that the rider was initially tumbling before sliding. The rider was found by
witnesses to be unconscious and non-responsive. He was bleeding from several areas of his body. While officers were investigating the crash, the rider had an odor of an alcoholic beverage on his breath and person. He was arrested at the hospital for suspicion of DUI and released pending the blood test results. A blood sample was taken at 0952 hrs. The results of the blood test were 0.192% BAC.
RiderInj: The 25 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries consisting of fractures to his pelvis, left femur, and left foot. He also sustained a dislocated hip. The rider had several avulsions and numerous abrasions. The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was admitted for an unknown number of days.	The rider displayed signs of intoxication that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle. The rider was legally intoxicated at more than twice the legal limit.
Human: The operator of MC1 had a perception failure in not seeing the raised divider.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained major damage to all sides. Both rims were fractured from impacting the raised center divider causing immediate loss of air pressure in the tires. MC1 tumbled, flipped, and skidded/slid to its FRP. MC1 ended up on its right side plane facing northeast. It was straddling the roadway edge and the sand. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as new.
Environmental: The raised center divider is considered a permanent environmental factor in this case only because of the rider?s excessive speed and impairment.

CrashType: This was a vehicle (OV1) vs motorcycle (MC1) left front to right side, side swipe type impact minor injury crash event causing MC1 to collapse onto the roadway surface, left side down ejecting the rider. There were no passengers with the rider at the time of the crash. The other driver (OVD) fled the scene failing to stop and identify or render aid.
Crash:
This was a vehicle vs. motorcycle minor injury hit & run crash event. The collision occurred on Friday June 2015 at 1806 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1758 hours indicated that it was clear, with	winds out of the southwest at 9.2 mph. There was an ambient temperature of 75.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed for 9.2 miles in all directions. Sunset was at 2004 hours on this day.
The motorcyclist was traveling southbound in the #2 lane due to road construction in the area that had closed off the southbound #3 lane.	The roadway is a multiple lane principal arterial with a downhill grade of -0.7%. The roadway is of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The posted speed limit for north and southbound traffic is 45 mph.
The roadway has an overall travel way width of 102 feet. There are three lanes dedicated for northbound traffic and thee lanes dedicated for southbound traffic.
The lanes are separated by a four foot wide raised concrete and brick median on both sides of the intersection. There are also designated 7 foot wide bicycle lanes on either side of the roadway and parking is not allowed.
The southbound lanes have a combined width of 44 feet. The northbound lanes of this roadway are not involved with this crash event. The roadway is bordered by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks approximately 7 feet in width. The eastside of the roadway bordering the northbound lanes is occupied primarily be commercial/retail businesses. The west side of the roadway bordering the southbound lanes is also occupied by commercial/retail businesses. The scene of the crash is an ?at grade? four way non-skewed intersection. The intersecting minor arterial roadway is approximately 93 feet wide overall and allows of both east and westbound vehicular traffic. The entire intersection is regulation by multi-phase four way electronic traffic control devices. The speed limit is 45 mph. The westbound portion of the roadway west of the intersection is part of this crash event. The eastbound portion of the roadway is not involved and is separated from the westbound lanes by a raised concrete and brick median approximately 14 feet in width. The east and westbound lanes of the roadway east of the intersection are reduced to an overall width of 43 feet and are not involved in this crash event.
 
MC1 was a 2000 Titan Gecko RM2000 cruiser style motorcycle being operated by a 43 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a FMVSS-218 DOT and ECE- 2205 rated full face motorcycle helmet. MC1 was initially traveling southbound in the #2 of the principal arterial north of the intersection due to the road construction. The rider was traveling at a reduced speed of about 10 mph preparing to make a right turn at the intersection and continue westbound onto the local street.
OV1 was an unknown year Dodge challenger (automobile) that was being operated by a male subject with no further description. The driver was also traveling southbound in the #2 lane at an unknown rate of speed behind MC1.
As both vehicles were approaching the intersection the rider set up to make his right turn from the southbound #2 lane and swung wide in an attempt to align his position with the westbound #1 lane. The rider decided in order to be safe he would swing wide with his right turn so as not to get to close to the road construction. As the rider initiated his right turn, the driver of OV1 decided to make the same right turn however he initiated a tighter turn inside the path of MC1. During the turn MC1 was moving into the westbound #1 lane at about 10 mph. At the same time OV1 was moving into the westbound #2 lane and for some reason continued merging left into the #1 lane.
The rider of MC1 said that he felt an impact on his right leg and looked over to see OV1 pushing into the side of his motorcycle. The resulting impact between the two-vehicles caused MC1 to collapse left side down. The bike came to rest in the #1	lane facing in a north direction. The MCR was ejected off the bike and rolled or tumbled approximately 15 feet onto the raised concrete median coming to rest about 10 feet away from MC1. The driver of OV1 continued
westbound away from the crash scene failing to stop and identify or render aid to the rider.
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 43 year old male rider of MC1 sustained minor injuries as a result of the crash and was only treated and released at the scene. The injuries consisted of a abrasions to his left shoulder, elbow, knee and foot. The rider also claimed to have blacked out after impacting with the ground however he refused any further medical assistance at the scene. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: It is unknown whether or not the driver of OV1 sustained any injuries or was experiencing any degree of impairment.
Human:
The 43 year old male rider of MC1 was traveling at a safe speed for the negotiation of the right turn movement and the present roadway conditions, within his lane of travel and subsequently did not contribute to the cause or outcome of this crash event.
The male driver of OV1 was also traveling at a safe speed for the present traffic on the roadway however, failed to properly scan the environment to check for any vehicles in proximity to his lane changing maneuver. His subsequent actions lead to the primary cause of this crash event.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. OV1 sustained an unknown amount of damage a a result of this crash event and the driver failed to remain at the scene.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Light Truck. Hit & Run
OV1: Unknown year, Ford F-250 Extended Cab
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in June 2015 at 1721 hours in Southern California. It was daytime, with clear skies, the temperature was approximately 86 degrees F. and the winds were light with a left crosswind. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be travel worn and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred in a commercial area on the westbound side of an east/west roadway separated by a painted center median that varies from 3 ft. to 15 ft. wide with double solid yellow lines. The eastbound side has construction with heavy traffic; the eastbound lanes mirror the westbound lanes.	The westbound side has commercial driveways on the right, 2 travel lanes and a left turn lane.	The left turn lane is 10 ft. wide, the #1 travel lane is 12 ft. wide and the #2 lane is 19 ft. wide. There are no traffic signals for the through lanes and there is an uncontrolled intersection approximately 98 ft. west of the Point of Impact (POI) with OV1. The westbound grade is -0.4%, the crown is 7.4%. The posted speed limit is 40 mph.

MC1 is a 2000 Suzuki SV 650 (654cc) naked style motorcycle ridden by a 29 year old male (6 ft. and 160 lbs.). The rider was wearing a Bilt, full face motorcycle helmet with a reflective polycarbonate face-shield. OV1 is an unknown year Ford F250 extended cab light truck driven by an unknown male (unknown height and weight). It is unknown whether the driver of OV1 was using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was westbound in the #1 lane at approximately 35 mph. OV1 pulled into the westbound traffic from a commercial driveway on the right and immediately merged into the #1 lane in front of MC1 and then came to a sudden stop. The rider forced MC1 onto its left side to keep from riding into the back of OV1, which he believed might have caused more severe injuries. MC1 slid on its left side approximately 38 ft. facing south and slid under the rear of OV1.	MC1 and OV1 didn?t separate. The 2nd POI and Point of Rest are the same approximately 112 ft. east of the east curb-line of the uncontrolled intersection and
approximately 25 ft. south of the north curb-line.
 
The driver of OV1 helped the rider move MC1 to the right curb, then got back into OV1 and departed the scene westbound.
RiderInj: The 29 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related during the interview: abrasions to both arms and the lower left leg. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 1.
Human: The driver of OV1?s decision to unsafely merge into traffic is a contributing factor.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: Construction eastbound caused congestion in the #1 westbound lane of traffic.

CrashType: MC1 was westbound in the left lane when OV1 enters the road from a driveway on the right and makes a wide right turn into the path of MC1. MC1 has right frontal impact with OV1 left front side. MC1 then goes down on its right side plane and slides for approximately 114? to its FRP. The rider was fully ejected and sustained moderate injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a minor arterial roadway with 2 through lanes in each direction and a 2 way left turn lane at the crash site. The crash occurred just beyond a ?T? type intersection involving a driveway that OV1 had just exited. The roadway is straight with a minor up-hill grade that was measured to be 2.7%. The crown was measured at 7.4%. The surrounding area is comprised of retail/commercial businesses. Both sides of the roadway have a concrete sidewalk.
The sidewalk on the north side is 8? wide and the one on the south side is 12?. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has an east/west designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway is in a southeast/northwest orientation with westbound being at 265 degrees on a compass reading in the rider?s direction. Parallel parking is allowed on either side of the roadway. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The weather was listed as ?haze? with no wind. The temperature was +79 degrees F. The crash took place in June of 2015 in Southern California at 1120 hrs. There was no roadway construction in the immediate area of the crash. There was construction a couple blocks east of the crash site
which caused the #2 lane in the opposite direction of travel to be coned off, but it had no effect on crash causation. Traffic conditions were light to moderate in the westbound lanes. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor to moderate injuries. MC1 had no passenger and both vehicles were towed.
MC1 was a 2006 Harley Davidson Street Glide (1442cc) cruising type motorcycle with modifications. The known modifications include the exhaust, crash bars, some engine parts, and motor power enhancement device. The 47 year old male (6? 03?/230 lbs.) rider was wearing unknown type clothing other than a pair of blue thin cotton type pants. The rider was wearing novelty type partial coverage helmet that had a fake ?DOT? sticker on the back. The helmet was
constructed of a thin fiberglass shell with most all of the thin foam padding worn out. It did not have any other impact absorbing materials. The helmet
 
remained in place to the end of the crash sequence.

The rider stated that he was westbound in the #1 (left) lane going approximately 40 mph and was to the left side of the lane. He said that the OV was next to him in the #2 (right) lane. The rider said that he was near the rear quarter panel of OV1 when the driver ?suddenly? put on his left turn signal, then immediately turned left. The rider thought that the OV might be trying to make a U-turn. He said that he had no time to react and impacted OV1 on the left front side. He was ejected from MC1 and flew across the hood of the car. He stated that he ?went right? and that OV1 went to the left and somehow ran him over. The driver of OV1 stated that he had just exited a driveway from a fast food location after looking and saw that the roadway was ?clear.? He then heard a loud ?boom? and saw MC1 ?flying.? Witnesses saw the crash but were not sure where OV1 came from. After impacting OV1, MC1 went down on its right side plane and skidded/slid for approximately 114? diagonally across the roadway and intersection coming to rest at the south side curb line. MC1 was still at its FRP when the police arrived. OV1 had been moved. There was a post impact tire mark made by MC1 prior to the scrapes and gouges. This was most likely from the front tire as it was redirected from the impact. The left front tire from OV1 lost all air pressure as a result of the crash.
RiderInj: The 47 year old male operator of MC1 sustained unknown type nerve damage in his neck region. In the police accident report the rider stated that this was a pre-existing injury that the crash aggravated. He also sustained a separated right shoulder, a laceration to his right heel, and numerous abrasions. The rider was taken to a local hospital. It is unknown if he was admitted. The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 41 year old male (5?09?/190 lbs.) operator of OV1 was not injured. He displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit the safe operation of a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 ahead of other traffic approaching when he entered the roadway. Had the driver of OV1 stayed in the right lane as the law requires when entering the roadway, there would not have been a crash. The operator of MC1 could possibly have done a better job of anticipating the actions of OV1 and taken some pre-crash precautions which may not have prevented the crash, but could have lessened the impact and injuries
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate damage to the entire right side from impacting OV1 and sliding on the roadway. The front suspension, fairing, gas tank, right side crash bar, foot board, brake pedal, saddle bag, and exhaust all sustained damage. The seat was broken off as a result of the crash. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as very good.

OV1 sustained moderate damage starting at the leading edge of the driver?s door and proceeding forward, ultimately pulling off the front bumper. The left front tire sustained a puncture causing it to lose all air pressure. The impact also broke some steering components to the left side of the vehicle.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors, permanent or temporary, that were considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: MC1 has frontal impact with OV1 right front side, which is making a left turn in front of MC1. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a five lane roadway that is a minor arterial at a driveway type ?T? intersection. There are two through lanes in each direction and a two way left turn lane at the crash site. The crash occurred mid-block between intersections. The intersection to the west is signal controlled. The intersection to the east is not. Both are ?T? type intersections. The roadway is straight and level. The crown was measured to be 8.1% and the grade at +1.5%. On-street parallel parking is normally allowed on both sides of the street. There is roadway construction further east from the crash site and 40? delineator orange cones have been positioned in the gutter to prevent parking in the eastbound lanes. This is the advance warning construction area. The area is comprised of commercial/retail on either side of the roadway. Both sides of the roadway have concrete sidewalks. In the area of the crash, the sidewalk is 11? wide and abuts to commercial buildings. The driveway where the crash occurred forms a narrow alley between two commercial buildings that leads to a small apartment complex in the back where the owner of OV1 resides. The roadway is made of asphalt composition, worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has an east/west designation. In the area of the crash, the roadway is in a northeast/southwest orientation with eastbound being at 60 degrees on a compass reading in the rider?s direction. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The weather was clear with a light wind from the SSW. The temperature was +82 degrees F. The crash took place in July of 2015 in Southern California at 1447 hrs. There was no roadway construction in the area of the crash. Traffic conditions were heavy and backed up due to lane closures ahead. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger and was towed. OV1 was also towed.
 
MC1 was a 2007 Yamaha Royal Star Tour Deluxe (1294cc) cruising type motorcycle with minor modifications. The 60 year old male (5? 08?/210 lbs.) rider was wearing a thin cotton short sleeved shirt, regular denim jeans, over the ankle hiking style boots and no gloves. The rider was wearing an HCI half helmet with no face shield. The helmet had labeling that indicated it met FMVSS 218 (DOT). The rider was wearing non-prescription sun glasses with a gray/smoke colored lens. The helmet remained in place to the end of the crash sequence.

The rider stated that he had just left his mother?s residence and was headed to the store. He stated that traffic was very heavy due to the construction up ahead. He said that he was eastbound in the #2 (curb) lane at 30-35 mph. He said that the #1 (left) lane was stopped. In the police accident report, the rider stated that he came upon stopped cars and passed them on the right, between the cars in the #2 lane and the curb. He said that as he approached the area of the driveway, he saw OV1 making its left turn in front of him. He stated that he applied the rear brake and tried to swerve right. The skid mark from the rear tire shows a straight line skid that is angled to the right. The tire mark starts approximately 5? north of the SCL and terminates near the POI at approximately 3? north of the SCL. Based on the tire mark, it would appear that the rider was able to make a slight swerve to the right before applying and locking up the rear
brake. The rider could not remember if he applied any front brake or not. The rider remembered impacting the right front of OV1 and then flying over the hood and landing on the sidewalk. The driver of OV1 stated that he was attempting to make a left turn into the driveway and traffic was very heavy and backed up. He stated that the cars in both eastbound lanes stopped and left a gap for him to make his turn. He said that as he slowly made his way across the eastbound lanes, MC1 appeared traveling eastbound along the curb and impacted the right front of his car. The driver stated that he never saw MC1 prior to the crash.
After the crash, MC1 landed on its right side plane facing northeast. The front tire was in the roadway and the rear tire was on the apron of the driveway. OV1 was pushed slightly east with its front tires ending up just south of the SCL. The front tire of MC1 was forced rearward and impacted the frame/radiator.
RiderInj: The 60 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of an abrasion to his right bicep and bi-lateral abrasions to his hands. The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was treated and then released.	The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 37 year old male (5?09?/175 lbs.) operator of OV1 displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human:
The operator of MC1 had a decision failure in attempting to unsafely pass stopped traffic on the right side at an unsafe speed. The rider also had a reaction failure in improperly applying his brakes.
The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 because of all the stopped vehicles in front of him, yielding their right of way. In defense of this driver, MC1 was operating on a portion of the roadway not usually traveled upon and was at an unusually high rate of speed for the current conditions (all traffic stopped).
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front end from impacting OV1. The forks sustained an approximate 9.5? reduction in wheelbase. The left
 
frontal area of MC1 sustained minor damage from side-slapping OV1. The right side sustained numerous scratches as a result of impacting the roadway surface. The front suspension, front fender, handlebars, gas tank, rear parcel rack, seat, and foot pegs were all damaged. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be listed as good.

OV1 sustained minor to moderate denting to the right front side, hood, and a broken steering linkage.
Environmental: The construction zone east of the crash location that caused heavy, backed up traffic is considered a contributing factor only because of the rider?s actions.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. other vehicle (OV1) broadside type injury crash with a primary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle rider to lose control and impact the roadway surface prior to impacting OV1. Both the rider and MC1 impacted the side of OV1. The rider fell to the roadway surface sustaining critical injuries. There were no passengers on the motorcycle at the time of the crash.
OV1: 2004 Ford Ranger XLT pick-up truck, silver/gray in color
Crash:
This was an MC1 vs. OV1 broadside type injury crash event. The collision occurred during daylight hours on Thursday, July 2015 at 1652 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1959 hours. The weather report for 1152 hours indicated clear skies, with SSW winds at 10.4 mph and, an ambient temperature of
80.6 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed for 10.0 miles in all directions.	The roadway surface was found to be dry, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at a straight ?at grade? T-intersection of a Local street with an overall travel-way width of 40 feet. The roadway runs north and south with one	20 foot wide portion for each direction of travel. There are no lane lines or delineators on approach to or at the area of the crash site. The motorcycle rider was northbound on approach to the intersection with a +1.4% uphill grade. The other driver was southbound on the approach to the intersection.
There are no designated left turn lanes to regulate both north and southbound traffic onto the intersecting local street at this intersection. There are no posted traffic control devices at the intersection.
The north and southbound lanes are not separated from each other by painted or raised medians.	The intersecting east/west local street of the T- intersection is 40 feet wide with a 20 foot portion for eastbound traffic and the same for westbound		traffic. Both intersecting local streets are bordered by the same raised concrete curbs a 5 foot wide grass parkway with adjoining 5 foot wide concrete sidewalks. The area in and around the crash site is made up of single family residential homes that face the street with open driveway aprons allowing for ingress and egress to each home. Parallel parking is allowed on
all sides of the streets and the unposted speed regulation for these streets is 25 mph.

MC1 was a stolen 2013 Triumph Thruxton conventional style motorcycle being operated by a 30 year old unlicensed male rider.	The rider was traveling at a speed of about 30-35 mph northbound on the local street while approaching the intersection.	The rider was wearing a HJC model CS-R2 FMVSS 218 DOT approved (black) full face motorcycle helmet with a clear colored visor. The status of MC1 at the time of this crash event was it had been reported stolen from
 
a neighboring city.
OV1 was a 2004 Ford Ranger XLT pick-up truck being operated by a licenced 30 year old male driver. OV1 was traveling southbound on the local street and was in the process of making a U-turn type movement at the intersection in order to continue northbound through the neighborhood.	There was no other traffic in proximity of the intersection and there were no special conditions such as roadwork or obstructions on the roadway or at the intersection.
As the rider was traveling at an approximate speed of 30-35 mph as he approached the intersection. At the same time the driver of OV1 was approaching the intersection and starting his U-turn. As the rider approached OV1 he initiated a collision avoidance maneuver in an attempt to avoid hitting the vehicle. The rider first applied and locked up his rear brake. This was evident by the 33? 9? long skid mark left on the roadway. The rider also applied and locked up his front brake. This was also evident by a 26? 8? mark left on the roadway. The termination of the rear brake and start of the locked front brake over lapped each other by about 5 feet.
