By the appearance of the relatively straight skid marks it does not appear as though the rider attempted to steer away from the impending collision.
At or near the termination of the front brake skid, the rider lost control of MC1 and it collapsed right side down on to the roadway sliding about 11 feet just prior to impacting near the right side of OV1. As MC1 collapsed onto the roadway, the rider was ejected and either slid or tumbled into right front quarter panel of OV1.
Both MC1 and the rider came to rest just inside the intersection at or near the area of impact between the two-vehicles.
The driver of OV1 continued moving forward and stopped his vehicle just east of the area of impact about 23 feet away.	At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, or animals that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 30 year old male rider of MC1 sustained critical injuries was treated at the scene by paramedics and subsequently transported to a local area hospital. The injuries sustained were a Cerebral Hemorrhage, open fracture to the left knee as well as closed fractures to the left Femur, and the left	wrist. The MCR tested positive for Amphetamine, Methamphetamine and, Morphine (Heroin).
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries.	The driver was determined to have been under the influence of drugs (Cannabis) prior to the crash event testing positive .140/.138. The driver was subsequently arrested at the scene.
Human:
The rider of MC1 could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of OV1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver. The rider was also sufficiently impaired by a depressant type narcotic, and was operating a stolen vehicle at the time of the crash event.
The driver of OV1 failed to comprehend the presence of MC1 while initiating his U-turn at the intersection. The driver was also affected by his impairment.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major right side and front end damage as a result of impacting the roadway surface and the side of OV1 however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained moderate right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: MC1 has frontal impact with OV1 right rear side. MC1 was going at a high rate of speed in the #1 lane. OV1 was making a left turn into a driveway. The rider was fully ejected and sustained major injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a four lane roadway that is a minor arterial at a driveway type ?T? intersection. There are two through lanes in each direction and a dedicated left turn lane at the crash site. The crash occurred south of a signal controlled intersection. The roadway is straight and level. The crown was measured to be 5.1% and the grade at +0.9%. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has 8? concrete sidewalks on both sides. There are utility poles and some trees along the roadside. The area is commercial/retail on both sides of the roadway at the crash site. The roadway has a north/south designation. At the crash site the roadway is in a slight northeast/southwest orientation with southbound being at 164 degrees for the rider's direction. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The weather was partly cloudy and the temperature was +88
degrees F. There was a light wind from the SSW. The crash took place in August 2015 in Southern California at 1449 hrs. There was no construction in the area of the crash. Traffic conditions were moderate. Both vehicles were towed.

MC1 was a 2000 Yamaha YZFR6 (599cc) sport/racing type motorcycle with minor modifications which included lighting, exhaust, sliders, seat, and slightly oversized tires. None of the modifications had any contribution to the crash. The 25 year old male (5? 06?/180 lbs.) rider was wearing a thin cotton short sleeved shirt, thin cotton shorts, low cut athletic shoes and no gloves. The rider was wearing an ICON Airmada full face helmet with integral chin bar and a smoke colored face shield. The helmet had labeling that indicated it met FMVSS 218 (DOT) and ECE-2205 safety ratings. The helmet was ejected from the rider?s head during the crash. Its location after the crash is unknown. There was no evidence of a helmet strap failure. When inspected, the helmet straps were in good condition and undone. There were no excessive wear marks or burn/stretch markings. Inside the helmet cracks and denting of the Styrofoam liner was visible.
 
The rider said that he had left his apartment and was on his way to a store. He stated that he had no specific memory of the crash. He had no idea what lane he was in or how fast he was going. When he spoke of OV1 making a left turn in front of him, it was because he had heard it from either the police or friends who had told him since the crash. When the rider spoke about the pre-ride safety check, he stated it was out of habit that he does it every time on the first ride of the day, not that he had any specific memory of doing it. He stated that prior to the crash, there were no issues or problems with MC1, the weather, visibility, the roadway or traffic conditions, family or friends, or anything that was distracting him. The 48 year old male (5?06?/200 lbs.) operator of OV1 participated over the phone for the interview. He stated that he was in California on vacation with his family. He stated that he was stopped in the northbound left turn lane long before the signal. He stated that there were no vehicles in front of him that he could remember. He wanted to make a turn into the drive-thru mini market. He said that he looked for on-coming vehicles and saw none. He started to make his left turn and then saw MC1 approaching very fast. He said that he accelerated to try and get out of the way when he felt an impact to the right rear of his vehicle. He said that he stopped as quickly as he could, which was in the driveway area. He stated that he had seven passengers in his vehicle and that two of them sustained minor injuries. There were no pre-impact tire marks from either vehicle. OV1 had been moved slightly prior to the arrival of the police. MC1 and the rider were at their FRPs. The silver Nissan pick-up seen in some of the photographs just south of MC1 was legally parked at the time of the crash and not involved. Several witnesses said that they had seen MC1 prior to the crash or at the time of the crash and estimated its speed to be anywhere from 50 mph to 90 mph, but definitely exceeding the speed limit. One witness stated that she was southbound stopping for a red light when MC1 passed her on the right. MC1 made a right turn at the intersection and then immediately made a left U-turn followed by a right turn and continued southbound. This behavior displays some aggressive riding habits. One witness saw MC1 changing lanes to the right at or near the intersection just before the crash.	He stated that he was wondering why since there were no obstructions in that area. He then saw OV1 turning left south of the intersection and surmised that the rider had seen this too and changed lanes in an effort
to avoid a crash. This indicates that that the rider saw OV1 and made an evasive maneuver. His decision to move to the right and not brake was incorrect. MC1 sustained major front end damage as a result of the crash. The forks and frame were broken. A small piece of the frame was found embedded in the side of OV1. The frame also bowed outward in the middle over the engine. No static measurement of the wheelbase could be done due to the damage. It was obvious that the front end had been pushed rearward into the radiator and engine area. It appears that the lacerations to the rider?s body occurred when he was ejected and flew over the rear of OV1 which had sharp deformed sheet metal as a result of the impact. The other injuries sustained were caused by blunt force trauma that would include the vehicle side and the ground.
RiderInj: The 25 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries consisting of a skull fracture with a brain hemorrhage, lacerations to his liver and spleen, and a bruised kidney. He also had fractures to the thoracic vertebrae (T2), and his right wrist. He also sustained numerous lacerations which included his neck and the carotid artery, his left shoulder, right arm, and abdomen. He stated that he lost approximately 5 pints of blood. The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was admitted for 10 days. The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle. The rider stated that he had smoked illegal marijuana the night before the crash.
ODriverInj: The 48 year old male (5?06?/200 lbs.) operator of OV1 was not injured and displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.	Two passengers sustained minor injuries.
Human:
The operator of MC1 had a decision failure in riding faster than the posted speed limit. He also had a reaction failure in swerving to the right instead of left and/or not braking.

The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 approaching, possibly because of MC1?s high speed.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major damage to the front fork area. There was a maximum reduction in wheelbase as the forks were forced rearward into the engine area as MC1 impacted OV1 causing damage to the radiator and exhaust. The impact also fractured the frame at the yoke separating the forks from the rest of the bike and bent the side portions of the frame outward. The front rim was bent, but the tire still held pressure. The rear tire lost all pressure during the crash. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered good to fair.

OV1 sustained major damage to the right rear side. There was significant intrusion into the passenger area. The right rear window and rear hatch window were broken. The rear hatch was crumpled and misaligned. A broken piece of the frame from MC1 was imbedded into the metal side panel of OV1.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury crash event that included a secondary collapse of the motorcycle on to the roadway surface. The rider impacted the side of OV1 and the roadway surface sustaining critical injuries. There were no passengers riding on the motorcycle at the time.
MV1: 2012 Yamaha FZ-1 (sport race replica) 998cc, white in color
Crash:
This was an injury crash event involving MC1 impacting the right side of OV1 causing critical injuries to the rider. The crash occurred on Sunday August 2015 @1530 hours in Southern California. The weather report for this region showed partly cloudy skies with winds out of the west at 8.1 mph with occasional gusts of up to 17.3 mph. There was an ambient temperature of 73.9 degrees F. Visibility was 10.0 miles at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions. The roadway surface was dry level, of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition.
The collision occurred at the location of a four way multi-phase signal controlled intersection on a straight, multiple lane principal (non-freeway) arterial roadway. The street has an overall travel way width of 102 feet. There are a total of six lanes dedicated for vehicular traffic; three for eastbound and three for westbound traffic. There are designated left turn lanes for east to northbound and west to southbound traffic at the intersection. There are no designated ?Bike Lanes? on the north or south side of the roadway. The opposing lanes of traffic west of the intersection are divided by a 4 foot wide raised concrete divider without a barrier. East of the intersection the opposing lanes are divided by a shortened raised concrete divider about 20 feet in length (w/o a barrier) and two sets of solid double yellow lines spaced about 4 feet apart.
The cross street north of the roadway is a multiple lane minor arterial roadway approximately 63 feet in width with two lanes for northbound traffic as well as two lanes for southbound traffic. The opposing lanes are separated by a painted double solid yellow set of lines. This portion of the intersection and roadway were uninvolved. The cross street south of the intersection is approximately 87 feet in width with two lanes each for both north and southbound traffic. There are two designated left turn lanes to facilitate northbound to westbound traffic and one right turn only lane for northbound to eastbound traffic. This portion of the roadway and intersection was also uninvolved. There is a posted speed limit of 45 mph for both east and westbound directions of travel.	The roadways up to and through the intersection are straight and there are no super elevation issues.	There were no significant roadway grade or, crown issues with the roadway surface, in the area preceding, at or, beyond the crash site.

MC1 was a 2012 Yamaha FZ-1 sport race replica style motorcycle, white in color being operated by a 51 year old male who was properly licensed and endorsed for the operation of motorcycles. The rider was wearing a FMVSS 218 US DOT and Snell 2010 approved Shoei RF1100 full face motorcycle helmet.
 
OV1 was a 2007 Chevrolet Equinox SUV operated by a 31 year old unlicensed female driver. OV1 was traveling eastbound on the principal arterial roadway and had entered the designated left turn lane on approach to the same intersection. OV1 was stopped in first position facing a red phased light.
The rider was traveling westbound in the designated #2 lane of the roadway approaching the intersection on an existing green light. The rider continued into the intersection and was traveling at a speed of about 40-45 mph (58.8 fps).
The driver of OV1 suddenly entered the intersection from the left turn lane against a red phased light to initiate a left U-Turn type movement. OV1 accelerated to an approximate speed of 19 mph over a distance of 40 feet just prior to the crash event.
As MC1 entered the intersection, the rider had insufficient time to initiate any type of collision avoidance maneuver and could only try to apply his front and rear brakes. MC1 struck the right side of OV1 just at the front portion of the right side rear passenger door behind the B-pillar.
The rider was ejected from the bike into the side of OV1 and onto the roadway surface in proximity of the area of impact.	MC1 collapsed onto the roadway left side down sliding approximately 20 feet to the final resting place.
MC1 sustained moderate left side damage to the fairing as well as minor scraping along the left side from striking the roadway surface. The windshield was detached from MC1 as well as a portion of a rear luggage compartment.
OV1 sustained moderate right side damage starting at the right rear quarter panel, right rear passenger door, B-Pillar and, right front passenger door. While inspecting the ?area of impact? and ?final resting place?, there was evidence of a skid mark approximately 3 feet in length directly east of the area of impact and was more than likely from the front tire. At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the event.
RiderInj: The 51 year old rider of MC1 sustained critical injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries included but were not limited to a broken left ankle, multiple rib fractures to the left side, a lacerated pancreas and ruptured spleen which was subsequently removed. The rider was wearing upper body protective clothing and sustained only a minor contusion to his left forearm. There was no other evidence of soft tissue damage. He was admitted to a local hospital for treatment of his injuries. The police report indicated there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the rider?s system.
ODriverInj: The driver and passengers of OV1 sustained no injuries. The police report indicated there was no presence of alcohol or drugs in the driver?s system.
Human: The 31 year old unlicensed female driver of OV1 had made an unsafe decision to initiate a left U-turn type movement against a red phased arrow. The rider of MC1 was determined not to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the collision. OV1 sustained moderate right side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Automobile
Crash:
This two-vehicle crash occurred in August 2015 at 1852 hours in Southern California.	It was daylight, clear, the temperature was approximately 70 degrees F. and the winds were light from the west. The asphalt roadway surface was dry, noted to be good condition and there was light traffic.

The crash occurred in a residential area on a predominately east/west roadway with a slight left hand curve, at a T intersection bordered by apartments on the north side and single family homes on the south. There is a predominately north/south roadway forming the base of the T that intersects on the south side of the roadway, with a 25 ft. travel lane in each direction and a white painted limit line and the word ?stop? painted in white behind it on the northbound side. The roadway is boarded by raised concrete curbs and sidewalks with a stop sign on the east side of the roadway at the curb return.	The eastbound roadway has three 12 ft. through lanes and a 9 ft. bicycle lane; the westbound roadway has three 12 ft. through lanes, a 9 ft. bicycle lane and a 10ft. left turn lane. The roadway is divided by a 14 ft. wide raised center median planted with shrubs and trees.	The eastbound grade is 0.8%, the crown is 5.0% and the speed limit is 45 mph.

MC1 is a 2006 Yamaha FZ6 (599cc) motorcycle ridden by a 16 year old male (5 ft. 6 in. and 140 lbs.). The rider was wearing an unknown make and model, full face motorcycle helmet with a clear polycarbonate face-shield. OV1 is a 1993 Honda Civic LX driven by a 20 year old male (6 ft. 3 in. and 160 lbs.).	The driver of OV1 was reported to be using the available three-point manual lap and shoulder restraints.

MC1 was eastbound in the #2 lane approaching the intersection at approximately 45 mph. OV1 was westbound stopped in the left turn lane at the intersection prepared to make a left turn. OV1 entered the intersection crossing the eastbound lanes traveling at approximately 17 mph and was struck in the right front wheel/fender area by MC1. MC1 struck OV1 after braking hard and leaving approximately 137 ft. of dry pavement skid that curved into the #3
lane.	The Point of Impact (POI) was approximately 15 ft. east of the west curb-line and 7 ft. north of the south curb-line.	The rider of MC1 was launched over the hood of OV1 onto the roadway approximately 25 ft. east of the POI, with his Point of Rest (POR) approximately 1 ft. north of the south curb-line.	MC1 continued forward approximately 3 ft. pushing OV1 east as OV1 continued southbound, causing OV1 to leave a right front tire scuff mark approximately 2 ft.
 
long. This caused MC1 to pivot into the right side of OV1 before disengaging and falling onto the roadway on its left side facing north; its POR was approximately 23 ft. east of the west curb-line and 15 ft. south of the south curb-line.	OV1 rolled on its tires to its POR facing northeast approximately 37 ft. east of the west curb-line and 11 ft. south of the south curb-line.
RiderInj: The 16 year-old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the police report: a fractured knee (NFS), bilateral leg abrasions and abrasions to the right foot. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 5.
Human: The driver of OV1 failed to perceive MC1 before entering the intersection.	MC1?s speed was higher than what was safe for the situation and his evasive action was not properly executed.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors for MC1 or OV1.
Environmental: There were no environmental crash causal factors.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle vs. another vehicle broadside type injury crash event.	The front of the motorcycle struck the left rear portion of the other vehicle and collapsed onto the roadway surface. The rider was ejected off the motorcycle into the side of the other vehicle and onto the roadway surface suffering serious injuries.
MV1: 2014 Honda CB500F (sport race replica) 471cc, black in color
OV1: 2013 International Navistar/Maxx Force (twin axel, heavy utility) white in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) injury crash event. The collision occurred on Sunday August 2015 at 1145 hours in Southern California. Sunrise was at 0618 hours on this day. The weather report for 1153 hours showed scattered clouds, with winds from the south at 8.1mph. There was an ambient temperature of 78.1 degrees F. Visibility was 10.0 miles and at ground level it was clear and unobstructed in all directions.	The roadway surface was of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? T-intersection of a driveway allowing access to a north/south county bike trail. The overall width of the driveway was approximately 39 feet allowing for both ingress and egress of both bicycle and/or pedestrian traffic. The trail cuts through largely rural wilderness areas of the region. There are no residential or commercial structures in the immediate area.
The collision occurred on a straight section of an east/west principal arterial roadway with a 2% downhill grade. The overall width of this roadway is 48 feet with a 12 foot lane for eastbound traffic and one for westbound traffic. The two opposing lanes are separated one painted set of solid double yellow lines. On the north side of the roadway there is a designated ?Bike Lane? approximately 8 feet in width. The bike lanes are separated from the traffic lanes by one painted solid white lane line. There is also an 8 foot wide raised concrete sidewalk that parallels the roadway. On the south side of the roadway there is another designated ?Bike Lane? approximately 16 feet in width.
The surrounding environment north and south of the roadway is rural wilderness and other than posted speed limit signs there are no traffic control devices present in the area of the crash site. The posted speed limit for both east and westbound traffic is 45 mph.

MC1 was a 2014 Honda CB500F motorcycle (471cc) being operated by a 54 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an unknown style motorcycle helmet. The rider was operating his motorcycle with a Valid California Driver?s license which was endorsed for the operation of motorcycles. The rider was traveling at an approximate speed of 40 mph eastbound on the principal arterial roadway approaching the bike trail driveway entrance.
 
OV1 was a 2013 International Navistar Maxx Force (twin axel heavy utility) telephone maintenance truck being operated by a 39 year old male driver. OV1 was also traveling eastbound on the principal arterial roadway, approaching the same bike trail driveway entrance. The OVD was slowing his vehicle as he approached the driveway and was moving to the right side of the roadway. The OVD continued to move to the right eventually slowing to a stop and signaling for a left turn. It was the driver?s intent to turn left into the bike trail driveway and he had to initially move the truck to the right in order to negotiate the left turn movement.
The MCR had noticed OV1 pulling to the right side of the roadway as well as another vehicle (witness #1) which was slowing as well. The MCR maintained his speed and moved towards the center of the road way initially passing the witness vehicle on the left and continuing eastbound with the intent to pass OV1on the left. As MC1 approached OV1, OV1 started the left turn movement crossing the eastbound and westbound lanes of traffic. The MCR applied his brakes laying down a combined length of skid approximately 43 feet in length.

The MCR could not avoid OV1, striking the vehicle near the left rear tire and quarter panel. The right front portion of MC1 impacted OV1 sending the rider into the side of OV1. Both MC1 and the rider collapsed onto the roadway surface after impacting with OV1.
The MCR, motorcycle and OV1 moved off the roadway prior to the arrival of law enforcement.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 54 year old male rider of MC1 sustained serious injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries included but were not limited to a Pneumothorax (punctured) left lung, fractures to the ribs, clavicle and scapula along his right side and soft tissue abrasions to his body.	The rider was treated at the scene and removed from the scene to a local hospital for treatment. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The 46 year old male driver of OV1 was not injured and there was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 54 year old male rider of MC1 was attempting to make an unsafe passing maneuver to the left of traffic.
Due to the size of OV1 the 46 year old male driver positioned the vehicle near the right side of the roadway to negotiate the left turn movement and signaled prior to initiating the turn.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate front and right side damage as a result of impacting with the left side of OV1 and the roadway surface. The motorcycle otherwise appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained minor left side damage in the area of the left rear quarter panel however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Motorcycle vs. Object on roadway
Crash:
This single motorcycle crash occurred in August 2015 at 2057 hours in Southern California.	It was night, clear, the temperature was approximately 70 degrees F. and the winds were light from the WNW.	The asphalt roadway surface was dry with sand along the east/west roadway edges and a north/south aligned ridge in the painted center divider.	There was light traffic.	There was a single street light on the west side of the road approximately 67 ft. west of the Point of Impact (POI).

The crash occurred on a straight section of predominately north/south state highway with urban industrial on the east side and a state park on the west. There is a 9 ft. wide concrete shoulder and two 12 ft. wide travel lanes in both directions divided by a 12 ft. wide painted divider with double painted yellow lines on both sides. The northbound grade is -0.4%, the crown is 5.6% and the speed limit is 60 mph.

MC1 is a 2000 Harley Davidson FXST (1449cc) motorcycle ridden by a 46 year old male (5 ft. 9 in. and 165 lbs.). The rider was wearing an adult large unknown model full-face Bell helmet with a smoked colored polycarbonate face-shield. The passenger behind the rider was a 43 year old female (4 ft. 11 in. and 108 lbs.).	The passenger of MC1 was wearing an adult small Shoei TZR helmet.

MC1 was northbound in the #1 lane following a van at approximately 55 mph when the van swerved into the #2 lane.	MC1 was unable to follow the van before striking the 6 ft. round spa cover that was folded in half.	The rider of MC1 lost control of MC1.	Both rider and passenger were launched over the cover landing on the painted line between the #1 and #2 lanes facing west.	MC1 came to rest on the right shoulder. The POI was approximately 2166 ft. north of curb prolongation of the east/west roadway and 38 ft. west of the east curb-line of the north/south roadway. The Areas of Rest are estimated due to lack of remembered information available from the parties involved.
RiderInj:
The 46 year old male rider of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the hospital record:	a right pneumothorax, small bladder hematoma, avulsion fracture to the right side of L5 transverse process, right distal radius fracture, diastasis of pubic symphysis; abrasions to: lower
 
back, left knee, left elbow and right buttocks; right thigh contusion. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 17. The 43 year old female passenger of MC1 sustained the following injuries as related on the hospital record:	acute left hemisacrum fracture and bilateral pubic ramus fracture, left distal radius fracture with volar dislocation of distal fracture fragments, right pneumothorax, left elbow subluxation; contusions to: upper left arm, upper right thigh and left posterior upper thigh; abrasions to:	right forearm, right hand, right buttocks and bilateral knee abrasions. The Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 21.
Human: The rider of MC1 was following to close behind the vehicle in front of MC1, this caused there to be insufficient distance to allow MC1 to avoid the debris in the roadway.
Vehicle: There were no vehicle crash causal factors for MC1.
Environmental: Poor light conditions and a spa cover dropped from another vehicle were crash causal factors.

CrashType: Solo MC fails to negotiate a left curve and impacts the curb. The rider is fully ejected and sustains major injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a four lane roadway that is divided by a curb high center median that is 17? wide and has several trees and other greenery. The roadway was straight before leading into the gentle left curve. No parking is allowed on the roadway. The crown was measured to be 4.8% and the grade at - 2.9%. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has standard concrete curbs. In the rider's direction there is a rural wilderness with an asphalt bike trail on the right and an apartment complex on the left. The bike trail is approximately 10? lower elevation than the roadway. The distance between the bike trail and the roadway varies. In the area of the crash, the distance varies from approximately 20? to 30?. Between the roadway and bike trail are several mature eucalyptus trees.	Just to the right of the roadway are several metal reflector signs that are approximately 36? tall. On the left side of the roadway is a meandering concrete sidewalk that sometimes meets the curb. Otherwise, there is grass adjacent to the roadway. The roadway has an east/west designation. At the crash site the roadway is a southwest/northeast orientation. The rider was headed southwest at 255 degrees at the crash location. The posted speed limit is 55 mph. The weather was listed as cloudy/partly cloudy with a light wind from the SSW. The temperature was +71 degrees. The crash took place in September 2015 in Southern California on a Tuesday at 1800 hrs. There was no construction in the area of the crash. The rider was part of a group of five riders. Other than the riders in the group, there was no other traffic at the time of the crash. MC1 was towed.

MC1 was a 2007 Harley Davidson (1584cc) cruising type motorcycle with modifications which included the exhaust, and handlebars. The 25 year old male (5? 09?/175 lbs.) rider was wearing a Simpson ?Street Bandit? full face helmet with integral chin bar and clear face shield. The helmet was matte black in color. The helmet had markings that indicated it met FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and Snell M2015 safety standards. He was wearing a thin cotton short sleeved shirt, regular denim jeans, below the ankle tennis type shoes and no gloves.

The rider was part of a group of five riders. The first four were riding in pairs, side by side. The fifth rider was riding to the right side of the lane behind them. The crash rider was reportedly riding in the middle on the right side. They all had just left a bar in which they stated that no one had been drinking and that they
 
were on their way to another unknown bar. All the riders were originally in the #1 (left) lane at a constant speed of a stated 50 mph. The first two riders changed lanes to the right, followed by the next two, and then the last rider. The last rider stated that he saw MC1 drift to the right and his front wheel was ?shuttering.? MC1 then brushed up against the right asphalt curb. It continued straight and then went into a storm drain opening. The storm drain deviation in the curb line opens to the right of the roadway approximately 5?. MC1 went into this opening and impacted the west portion of the storm drain which is at a 90 degree angle to the curb line. It does not jut out into the roadway. Upon impacting the curb, MC1's front rim was severely deformed and the front tire lost all air pressure. MC1 continued forward, and the under carriage/frame of MC1 scrapped over the top of the curb. MC1 continued in a westerly direction and impacted two 36? reflector road signs. Both signs were bent to nearly a 90 degree angle and the reflector portion was broken off. MC1 continued in a westbound direction hitting several objects before coming to its FRP. The rider was fully ejected. His helmet sustained major damage, including a fracture through the full thickness of the shell in the chin bar area on the left side. A portion of the chin bar is missing. It is unknown if the damage was caused by impacting one of the several trees on the roadside or some other object. When the police arrived, MC1 was found resting in a partially upright position, reportedly on its side stand, in the dirt south of bike trail below the roadway grade. In the on-scene photos, MC1 can be seen leaning against a dirt embankment. The side stand is not visible. It is unknown how much MC1 was moved prior to the arrival of the police. After impacting the curb and two road signs, MC1 tumbled end over end and flipped side over side to its FRP. Several parts of MC1 broke off and were found at the scene. There were no pre-impact skid marks. The rider?s FRP was not documented because he had been taken from the scene by the paramedics. In looking at the scene photos, it would appear that the rider?s FRP was not far from MC1 as bloody clothing and paramedic trash can be seen in the background. The rider was taken to a hospital where he was admitted. When MC1 was inspected, damage was located on all sides. In a brief interview of the rider at the hospital by the police, the rider stated that he had no memory of the crash. He stated that he had not consumed any alcohol or taken any drugs. The rider stated that he has been riding for between 12-15 years. He also stated that his MC is well maintained and had no mechanical issues. Witnesses not part of the group saw the group leaving the bar and stated that they were going very fast. Another witness came upon the crash after it occurred and found the rider?s friends removing objects from the rider?s pockets. He did not know what was being removed. While at the hospital, the rider submitted to a blood test to determine if he was DUI. The test results came back with a BAC of 0.01% alcohol and positive for Lidocaine. It is believed by the police that the Lidocaine might have been introduced to the rider?s system at the hospital rather than having been used as an illegal drug, but it is not certain. In the police accident report, the rider is listed on page #2
as ?HBD-Not Under Influence.?
RiderInj: The 25 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries listed in the police accident report as consisting of fractures to his right tibia, fibula, and ankle. He also sustained a fractured T-7 in his spine along with nerve damage to his right arm. The rider sustained internal injuries consisting of a pneumothorax to his right lung and contused ribs. There was also listed a major laceration starting in the rider?s neck area and terminating in the chest area. The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was admitted for an unknown number of days. The rider apparently displayed some signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle, however, he was deemed not under the influence. He was admitted to a local hospital for an unknown number of days.
Human: The operator of MC1 had a perception failure in not seeing the left curve in the roadway.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained major damage to all sides. The front rim was broken. The aftermarket hi-rise handlebars were bent and not functional. The gas gauge was knocked out from its placement on the top left side of the gas tank. The rear suspension, seat, foot pegs, rear brake foot lever, shift lever and lighting were also broken. There was not a reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered as fair.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was a vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) broadside type injury crash event with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface and impact another vehicle (OV2) in the roadway. The motorcycle rider was ejected off of MC1 onto OV1 and onto the roadway surface.
Crash:
This was a multiple vehicle (OV1 vs. MC1 vs. OV2) broadside type injury crash event resulting in injuries to the MCR. The collision occurred during the hours of daylight on Friday, August 2015 at 1739 hours in Southern California. Sunset was at 1922 hours. The weather report for 1753 hours indicated clear skies, with WSW winds at 6.9 mph and, an ambient temperature of 93.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed for 10.0 miles in all directions.
The roadway surface was found to be dry of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred on a straight ?at grade? intersection of a minor arterial roadway with an overall travel way width of 65 feet.	MC1 was traveling southbound on a local street approaching the signal controlled intersection.
The MCR stopped for a red phased signal on arrival to the intersection.	North of the intersection the local street has an overall travel way width of 40 feet with one 20 foot lane running north and the other 20 foot lane running south. South of the intersection the local street has an overall travel way width of 45 feet. The northbound lane is 20 feet wide and the southbound lane is 25 feet wide. OV1 was traveling westbound in the #1 lane on the minor arterial roadway approaching the intersection at 30-35 mph.	The roadway has two lanes designated for westbound traffic and two lanes for eastbound traffic. The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by one set of solid double yellow lines painted to the roadway surface. There are marked and designated left turn lanes for both directions of travel to access the local street north and south of the intersection. There are also designated ?Bike Lanes? on both the north and south side of the roadway. The intersection is controlled by a set of multiphase electronic traffic control signals that regulate the flow of traffic for all four directions including the left turn lanes for east and westbound traffic.
The roadway is also bordered on all sides by raised concrete curbs and adjoining concrete sidewalks. The posted speed limit for the minor arterial roadway is 40 mph. The local street north and south of the intersection has a posted speed limit of 25 mph.
 
MC1 was a 2003 Kawasaki 500R Ninja motorcycle being operated by a 33 year old female rider (MCR).	MCR was stopped at the intersection for a red light at first position in the southbound lane of a local street. OV1 was a 2014 Hyundai Elantra (automobile) being operated by a 30 year old female driver (OVD1).
OVD1 was traveling westbound in the #1 lane approaching the intersection at a speed of approximately 30-35 mph. OV2 was a 1998 Mercedes Benz E320 (automobile) being operated by a 17 year old juvenile female driver (OVD2). OVD2 was stopped at the intersection for a red light at first position in the northbound lane of the local street.
When the MCR received a green light she moved MC1 into the intersection at a speed of 5-10 mph. It was her intent to make a left turn onto the eastbound lanes of the minor arterial roadway. At the same time on the south side of the intersection OVD2 moved OV2 into the intersection at about 5-10 mph intending to turn left into the westbound lanes of the minor arterial roadway. OVD1 had maintained her speed of 30-35 mph on her approach to the intersection in the westbound #1 lane. Witnesses at the scene reported that OV1 continued into the intersection against a red phased traffic signal for westbound traffic.
OVD1 entered the intersection and did not see MC1 at the time claiming that there was sun glare blocking a clear view of the intersection.
As OV1 entered the intersection it impacted the left front of MC1 as it was moving in front of the westbound lanes. The area of impact appeared to be approximately 19 feet east of the prolongation of the west curb of the street and 20 feet south of the prolongation of the minor arterial roadway. There was evidence of light scraping approximately 14 feet in length from MC1 sliding along the roadway surface. There was no evidence of pre or post impact skid marks from either vehicle. The MCR and OVD1 said they did not use any type of collision avoidance maneuver prior to the impact. The resulting impact ejected the MCR up and onto the front hood of OV1 causing the rider to impact the windshield. The MCR fell off of OV1 and onto the roadway surface. MC1 collapsed right side down and slid along the roadway surface, striking OV2 and coming to rest 52 feet west of the intersection adjacent to the north curb of the minor arterial roadway. MC1 had slid an approximate distance of 72? 9? prior to coming to rest. During the crash event OV2 had also moved into the intersection and was starting to turn left much the same as MC1 when it was struck near the right rear corner by MC1 while it was sliding right side down with no rider westbound away from the initial crash event.	Both OV1 and OV2 moved off the lanes of travel from their final resting places.
RiderInj: The 33 year old female rider of MC1 sustained injuries as a result of the collision. The injuries sustained were a fracture of the left foot, contusions to the left ankle, left knee and undisclosed pain to her hip and back. The rider was treated at the scene and taken by ambulance to a local hospital where she was treated and released. There was no evidence of alcohol or drug intoxication.
ODriverInj:
The driver of OV1 sustained an undisclosed abrasion to her left forearm from deployment of the driver side air bag. OVD1 refused any treatment at the scene. There was no evidence of alcohol and/or drug intoxication.
The driver and passengers of OV2 sustained no injuries and there was no evidence of alcohol and/or drug intoxication.
Human:
OVD1 had failed to stop for a red light claiming a visibility impairment caused by sun glare. Sunset for this day in August was at 1922 hours and the crash was reported at or about 1739 hours. OVD1 would have been driving in the direction of the Sun, approximately 1 hour and 43 minutes prior to sunset.
MCR could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of OV1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver. OVD2 could not sufficiently react in time given the proximity and position of MC1 to initiate a collision avoidance maneuver.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major left side damage as a result of being struck by the front portion of OV1 however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained moderate front end damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. another vehicle (OV1) broadside type crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to collapse onto the roadway surface. The rider (MCR) impacted the side of OV1 and the roadway surface suffering serious injuries.
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. other vehicle injury crash event occurring during evening hours on Saturday, September 2015 at 1938 hours.	Sunset was at 1911 hours on this day. The weather report for 1953 hours showed clear skies, with a WSW wind direction at 4.6 mph. There was an ambient temperature of 71.1 degrees F. Visibility was 9.0 miles and at ground level it was clear and unobstructed in all directions.	The roadway is a local street and has a 3.1% uphill grade with a 2.1% crown for southbound traffic. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? intersection with a east/west commercial/retail driveway that was 50 feet wide at the apron. The driveway was located along the north side of the street and allowed for ingress and egress of motor vehicles using the adjacent shopping center. Across the roadway on the south side there are two 10 foot wide vehicle lanes separated by a 14 foot wide raised concrete median. These two lanes allow for exiting traffic only from an adjacent shopping area onto either the north or southbound lanes of the local street.
The roadway is straight and runs north and south with two lanes dedicated for southbound and one lane dedicated for northbound traffic. The overall width of the local street is 36 feet and the opposing lanes of traffic are separated by a painted set of solid double yellow lines. There are no traffic control devices regulating vehicles on the local street in the area of the crash site however there is one posted stop sign regulating eastbound traffic as they exit the
shopping center along the north side of the local street and another regulating traffic exiting from the south side to the northbound lane. There is a four way signal controlled intersection approximately 360 feet north of the crash site however it is not involved in the crash event.
There are no designated ?Bike? lanes in proximity of the crash site and parking is prohibited on both sides of the street. The north and south sides of the local street roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and adjoining 5 foot wide concrete sidewalks.
Both sides of the roadway are occupied by independent retail/commercial shopping centers open to the public. The posted speed limit for both north and southbound traffic is 35 mph.

MC1 was a 2007 Yamaha FZ-1 (sport race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 44 year old male rider. The rider was wearing an unknown style motorcycle helmet. The rider was operating his motorcycle with a Valid California Driver?s license endorsed for the operation of motorcycles. The rider was traveling at an
 
approximate speed of 35-40 mph southbound in the #2 lane. As he was approaching the intersection OV1 was entering the roadway from the driveway along the north side of the street, intending to turn left into the northbound lane of traffic.
OV1 was a 2006 Chrysler 300 (sedan type automobile) being operated by a 25 year old male driver. The OVD was driving eastbound towards the roadway intending to exit the shopping center turning left into northbound lane of the local street. When the OVD stopped at the driveway he moved his vehicle approximately 33 feet into the roadway crossing the #2 southbound lane and moving towards crossing the #1 lane.
MC1 was continuing southbound in the #2 lane approaching OV1?s position. There is a southbound uphill grade that limits the view of the intersection on approach. The rider of MC1 acted on the presence of OV1 crossing his lane of travel by applying his rear brake and steering to the left towards the #1 southbound lane.
The rider continued his collision avoidance maneuver by continued braking and moving towards the direction of OV1. The rider could not avoid OV1 and the front of his motorcycle struck OV1 along the left front quarter panel. The subsequent impact of the two-vehicles caused the rider to impact the side of OV1 and MC1 collapsed onto the roadway surface. The rider vaulted and rolled across the front engine hood of OV1 and fell onto the roadway surface.
Both the rider and MC1 had been moved from the scene prior to the arrival of law enforcement.
RiderInj: The 44 year old male rider of MC1 sustained serious injuries as a result of the collision. The rider was treated at the scene and removed from the scene to a local hospital for treatment. The injuries included and were not limited to a spinal fracture, fracture of the left ankle, as well as numerous abrasions to his left arm and leg as well as a laceration to the left leg. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The 25 year old male driver of OV1 was not injured and there was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 44 year old male rider of MC1 was operating his motorcycle at a speed safe for the present traffic on the roadway however did not react in time to conduct a proper collision avoidance maneuver prior to the crash. The application of the rider's collision avoidance maneuver was improper because he essentially turned into the path of OV1.
The 25 year old male driver of OV1 made an unsafe decision to enter the roadway having failed to perceive the proximity of the approaching motorcycle while making his left turn.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate front and right side damage as a result of impacting with	OV1 and the roadway surface. MC1 appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.

OV1 sustained minor left side damage in the area of the left front quarter panel however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: Solo out of control MC impacts curb, then goes airborne over a landscaped slope landing approximately 30? below, impacting the ground and a block wall. The rider was fully ejected and sustained major injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a two lane, undivided roadway that is adjacent to marked parking stalls in a townhome complex. There are no markings on the roadway surface, other than the parking stalls. The roadway is straight and level, and leads directly into the parking area. No parking is allowed on the roadway other than in marked stalls. The crown was measured to be -0.4% and the grade at -1.4%. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good condition. The roadway has standard concrete curbs where applicable. The roadway has concrete driveways to the right and some ground cover/shrubbery. To the left are ground cover and a residence. At the end of the roadway are the marked parking stalls. There is a guardrail and shrubbery just north of the north curb to prevent vehicles from driving over the cliff. There is approximately 15? of flat ground between the residence and the beginning of the slope where MC1 went over. There is an approximate 30? elevation difference from the top of the slope to the bottom. The slope is at an approximate 45 degree angle. At the bottom of the slope is a block wall for other residences in the complex. The slope has ground cover and some trees. The area is single family residential on both sides of the roadway at the crash site. The roadway has a north/south designation. At the crash site the roadway is in a northwest orientation with northbound being at 330 degrees for the rider?s direction. There is no posted speed limit. The weather was listed as ?haze.? The temperature was +74 degrees. The crash took place in September 2015 in Southern California at 0725 hrs. There was no construction in the area of the crash. There was no other traffic at the time of the crash. MC1 was towed.

MC1 was a 2001 Suzuki GSXR 600 (599cc) sport/racing type motorcycle with minor modifications which included lighting, exhaust, and sliders. The 35 year old male (5? 09?/220 lbs.) rider was wearing not wearing a helmet. He was wearing a thin cotton short sleeved shirt, thin cotton shorts, sandals (flip flops), and no gloves.
 
The rider stated that he was moving MC1 out of the garage. He said that he was attempting to shift MC1 into first gear when he suddenly lost control. It would appear that the rider was able to shift into first gear and upon releasing (popping) the clutch MC1 rapidly accelerated and the rider immediately lost control.
It is unknown if the front tire/wheel lifted off the ground.	MC1 proceeded in a northwesterly direction gaining speed. It is unknown if the rider had any influence on the direction of MC1 which barely missed impacting a parked vehicle. MC1 impacted and mounted the curb on the rider's left. There was a small tree at this POI that the rider did not impact. The parked vehicle that MC1 missed was parked in the western most parking stall adjacent to the curb that MC1 impacted. MC1 continued in a north-west direction across the flat area to the rear of the residence on the left before becoming air born. MC1 then flew approximately 28? to its FRP. It is unknown if MC1 impacted the block wall before or after impacting the ground. There was yellow paint transfer on the wall, but no damage. Where MC1 landed at the base of the block wall there is a concrete gutter way for drainage. The rider landed approximately 4? west from MC1. It is unknown at which point the rider was ejected from MC1. The rider had recently purchased MC1 from an unknown source. It was his first MC and he had no prior experience or training.
RiderInj: The 35 year old male operator of MC1 sustained major injuries consisting of a fractured neck (NFS), a fractured back (NFS), a hip fracture (NFS), and a fractured right ankle (NFS). The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was admitted for an unknown number of days. The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human: The operator of MC1 had a reaction failure in not being able to stop MC1 before crashing. The rider also had no experience/training.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained minor damage to the left side of the front rim after impacting the curb. MC1 sustained major damage to the front end and fork area as a result of impacting the ground at the bottom of the slope. There was a severe reduction in wheelbase as the forks were forced rearward into the engine area. There was a measured reduction in wheelbase of 6.1 inches from factory specification. The entire front end was damaged beyond repair, as well as the gauges and numerous components such as lighting, mirrors, radiator, engine guards, frame, and foot pegs. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered as very good.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) (broadside) left front to left side impact injury crash event causing a secondary impact of MC1 with the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected onto the hood and into the windshield of the other vehicle sustaining non-life threatening injuries.
MV1: 2003 Honda CBR600RR (sport, race replica) motorcycle, black in color
Crash:
This was a vehicle (OV1) vs. motorcycle (MC1) broadside type injury crash event. The collision occurred on Monday, September 2015 @ 0950 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 0956 hours showed hazy skies, with WSW winds at 5.8 mph and an ambient temperature of 77.0 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed for 5.0 miles. The collision occurred on a downhill grade section (10.5%) of a local street with a right curve at intersection with a multiple unit apartment complex driveway. There is one designated through lane of travel for both north and southbound traffic. These lanes are separated by a painted solid double yellow lane line divider north of the driveway intersection. South of the intersection the through lanes of travel are separated by a painted two-way left turn lane 10 feet in width. There are also designated 7 foot wide bike lanes on both sides of the roadway. There is a single designated left turn lane for southbound traffic approaching the driveway intersection to turn left into the apartment complex. The edges of the roadway are bordered by raised concrete curbs and there is a 5 foot wide concrete sidewalk along the east side of the roadway.
The overall travel way of the southbound lanes is 44 feet and the speed limit for both directions of travel is posted at 35 mph. There are no posted or
electronic traffic control devices in the area.	The driveway has one lane dedicated for entry and one dedicated for exiting traffic. Both lanes are separated by a raised concrete planter.
The environment of the crash scene is bordered by the apartment complex along the east side of the roadway. West of the roadway is a semi-rural wilderness area.

MC1 was a 2003 Honda CBR600 RR (sport, race replica) motorcycle being operated by a 23 year old male rider. The rider was leaving the apartment complex and approaching the local street intending to proceed north. The MCR only slowed down when he entered the local street. At the same time OV1 was traveling northbound and struck the left side of MC1, ejecting the rider onto the hood and windshield of MC1 and onto the roadway surface. MC1 slid or tumbled from the area of impact to the east curb area north of the intersection.
OV1 was a 2013 Honda Fit compact automobile that was being operated by a 55 year old male driver. The driver was traveling northbound on the local street approaching the driveway entrance when MC1 pulled out in front of him. The OVD attempted to avoid striking MC1 by swerving to the right however there was insufficient time and OV1 struck the left side of MC1 causing it to collapse onto the roadway surface.
 
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The 23 year old male rider of MC1 sustained a dislocated left shoulder and a cerebral concussion. There were no apparent broken bones or internal injuries. The rider was treated at the scene and later transported to a local hospital where he was treated for his injuries. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The driver of OV1 sustained no injuries as a result of the collision. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 23 year old rider of MC1 was being unsafe in the operation his motorcycle while attempting to enter a local street.
The rider failed to stop prior to looking and did not see or ignored the presence of the approaching northbound traffic OV1 to his left.
The 55 year old male driver of OV1 was traveling at a reasonable speed for the traffic environment and was unable to react in sufficient time to the presence of MC1 crossing into his lane of travel.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate left side damage however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash. MC1 was towed from the scene.
OV1 sustained major left front damage to the areas of the hood and windshield however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition. OV1 was driven from the scene.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: This was a motorcycle (MC1) vs. automobile (OV1) broadside type crash with a secondary lay-down event that caused the motorcycle to impact the roadway surface.	The rider (MCR) was ejected off of the motorcycle impacting the roadway surface and suffering critical injuries.
MV1: 2006 Ducati Superbike (sport race replica) 998cc, red in color
Crash:
This was a motorcycle vs. automobile injury crash event. The collision occurred on Friday September 2015 at 1713 hours in Southern California.	The weather report for 1653 hours showed clear skies, with winds out of the SSW at 9.2 mph. There was an ambient temperature of 80.1 degrees F. Visibility was 10.0 miles and at ground level it was clear and unobstructed in all directions.	The roadway surface for MC1 was a right curve, uphill grade of 10.2% with a 4.8% crown. The roadway surface was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be dry, worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. There were no super-elevation issues with this roadway.
The collision occurred at an ?at grade? T-intersection of a north/south multiple lane principal (non-freeway) arterial surface street with an overall travel way width of 99 feet. The roadway employs three lanes for northbound traffic and three lanes for southbound traffic. There are also marked ?Bike? lanes on both the east and west side of the roadway. The opposing lanes of traffic are separated by 16 foot wide raised concrete median with no barrier.
At the T-intersection there is a designated left turn lane allowing for northbound traffic to turn westbound into the residential area. There is also a designated merging lane for traffic leaving the residential area to proceed north into traffic. Both the east and west sides of this roadway are bordered by residential single family homes. The posted speed limit for the roadway is 45 mph. The east/west local street that intersects this roadway is 40 feet in width with one lane for eastbound traffic and one lane for westbound traffic. The street allows for traffic to enter or exit the residential neighborhood along the west side of the principal arterial roadway. There is one posted stop sign for eastbound traffic at the T-intersection regulating traffic preparing to turn north or southbound. The posted speed limit for the local street is 25 mph. Other than the posted stop sign, there are no posted or electronic regulatory devices at this intersection.

MC1 was a red 2006 Ducati Superbike 998cc (sport race replica) style motorcycle being operated by an unlicensed 53 year old male rider. The rider was wearing a Shoei X-Eleven model full face motorcycle helmet with a FMVSS 218 DOT and Snell 2000 rating. The helmet had no dominating color was a size adult large equipped with a clear colored plastic adjustable visor nylon straps and double ?D? ring fasteners. At the time of the crash event the rider was southbound in the #3 lane approaching the intersection at 50 mph.
 
OV1 was a blue 2009 Ford Focus (automobile) being operated by a licensed 75 year old male driver and a 74 year old female passenger (3rd position). The OVD was initially traveling northbound on the principal arterial roadway and had entered the left turn lane in order to continue westbound into the residential
area at the T-intersection. The OVD stopped his vehicle prior to entering the intersection and proceeded only when the passenger told him it was clear to cross.
During the left turn movement into the intersection the OVD crossed the southbound #1 and #2 lanes and as his vehicle crossed the southbound #3 lane it was struck on the right side near the rear passenger door and quarter panel by MC1 after traveling about 50 feet. The resulting impact spun OV1 out of the intersection into a position where it was facing east just behind the stop line of the local street.
As OV1 was entering the intersection MC1 was proceeding southbound in the #3 lane at a speed of 50mph. The MCR was pre-occupied with directing his attention to a leg cramp he was suffering just prior to the crash event. The MCR did however try to avoid the crash by applying his brakes. There was evidence of heavy braking on the rear tire due to a visible skid patch however, little evidence of front wheel braking.
The resulting impact caused the motorcycle to collapse left side down and spin to a position facing north inside the southbound #3 lane,, inside the intersection. During the impact between the two-vehicles the MCR was ejected off of MC1 and vaulted to a location adjacent to the west curb line just south of the intersection.
At the time of the collision there were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj:
The 53 year old male rider of MC1 sustained critical injuries as a result of the collision. The rider was immediately removed from the scene and admitted to a local hospital for treatment. The injuries sustained were a series of fractures to the T5 through T7 Thoracic vertebra with spinal shock as well as a traumatic brain injury. The rider also sustained numerous rib fractures as well as fractures to the sternum and hands. There were also numerous lacerations as well as a de gloving of the right chest area and a right hemopneumothorax.
There was an evidence of drug use (Cocaine) documented on the medical report.
ODriverInj: The 75 year old male driver of OV1 was not injured. The 74 year old female seated in the right front passenger seat was also uninjured. There was no indication of drug and/or alcohol involvement.
Human:
The 53 year old male rider of MC1 was traveling at a speed that was unsafe for the present traffic on the roadway. The rider could not react in time or conduct a proper collision avoidance maneuver prior to the crash. The rider could not bring his motorcycle to a stop by utilizing front and rear braking due to the proximity of OV1. The rider was unlicensed for the operation of a motorcycle and there was evidence of an illegal stimulant (Cocaine) drug in his system.
The licensed 75 year old male driver of OV1 made an unsafe (left) turning movement at the T-intersection.	His decision to turn was the proximate cause of this crash event. The driver of OV1 properly licensed for the operation of his vehicle.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained major front and moderate left side damage as a result of impacting with the right side of OV1 and the roadway. The motorcycle otherwise appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
OV1 sustained major right side impact damage in the area at or near the right rear passenger door and quarter panel however appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash event.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType: MC1 was westbound in #1 lane approaching a ?T? type intersection when OV1 made a left turn in front of it. MC1 impacted the left front side of OV1. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred at a ?T? type intersection that has no signal controls. The rider was on a four lane, minor arterial roadway that has a painted divider on the rider?s left as he approaches the intersection. There is a bicycle lane on the right edge of the roadway. There are two through lanes in each direction. In the opposing direction, there is a dedicated left turn lane. The intersecting side street on the rider?s right is a single family residential collector road and is controlled by a posted stop sign. Both roadways are straight. No parking is allowed on the roadway that MC1 traveled on. On street parallel parking is allowed
on the intersecting street. The crown for roadway that MC1 was on was measured to be 5.0% and the grade was measured to be -1.2%. The crown for the side street was measured to be 5.7% and a down grade of -3.9%. Both roadways are made of an asphalt composition, are worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair. Both roadways are bordered by concrete curbs, sidewalks, and block walls. Both roadways are designated as north/south. The roadway that MC1 traveled on is in a northwest/southeast orientation at the crash site. MC1 was in a westerly direction at 280 degrees. The intersecting street is in a northeast/southwest orientation. The speed limit for MC1 is posted at 45 mph. The speed limit for OV1 is 25 mph. The surrounding area for both roadways is comprised of single family residential homes. The weather was listed as clear with a temperature of +78 degrees F. There was a light wind from the WSW. The crash occurred in Southern California in September of 2015 during hours of daylight at 1815 hrs. There was no construction in the area of the crash. Both MC1 and OV1 were towed.

MC1 was a 2009 Yamaha YZF R6 (599cc) sport/racing type motorcycle with minor modifications which was the rear tail light and turn signals. The 21 year old male (5? 07?/160 lbs.) rider was wearing an adult large Fulmer AF M2B Blue Strategy full face modular helmet that had a clear face shield and gray/smoke tinted internal sun screen that was in the down position. According to the rider, the helmet was damaged in the chin bar and face shield areas. He stated that
 
he threw it away after the crash. The rider could not remember the brand, but was able to provide one picture of him wearing the helmet which was enough to identify the helmet and locate additional information. The helmet was identified as a Fulmer brand modular full face helmet. According to the Fulmer
website, this helmet meets FMVSS 218 (US DOT) and UN/ECE-22-05 safety standards. The helmet weighs 63 ounces in the rider?s size. The rider was wearing thin cotton military tan camouflage long sleeved shirt and pants, over the ankle military issued style boots, and armored nylon mesh gloves.

The rider was on his way home from work. He stated that he was in the left lane going approximately 40 mph. He said that there were no other vehicles near him. The rider said that the driver of OV1 failed to stop at the posted stop sign and started to make a left in front of him. He stated that he swerved to the left. He then saw traffic approaching from the opposite direction and could not continue with his plan of going around the front of OV1. At the same time, OV1 came to a stop blocking his path. He then braked hard with the front brake, after which he then applied the rear brake causing it to lock and skid just before impacting OV1.	The rider said that he impacted the left front side of OV1. He said that was fully ejected and flew over the hood of OV1, then landed in the roadway. He said that he landed on his right shoulder and then tumbled/slid to his FRP. In the police accident report, the driver of OV1 stated that she was stopped at the stop sign and looked in both directions and did not see any vehicles approaching. She also stated that the signal to her left at the intersection south of her was red for both north and southbound traffic and that there were vehicles stopped in the southbound lanes. The driver stated that she entered the intersection making a left turn, crossing the northbound lanes. She said that as she was entering the southbound lanes she felt the impact of MC1
colliding with the left side of her vehicle. She saw the rider of MC1 get fully ejected and land on the roof of her vehicle. The POI is in the intersection and approximately 32? S of the North Curb Line (NCL). The limit line for OV1 is 19? N of the NCL.	When a vehicle is stopped with the entire vehicle behind the limit line, the driver would have a permanent view obstruction with the block wall and could not see a safe distance to check for on-coming traffic before entering the roadway. The driver of OV1 had to have moved forward for visibility in order to make the above statements about the nearby intersection. This would reduce the travel distance of OV1 down to approximately 41?to the POI.	Using normal rates of acceleration (4.8 f/s/s) for OV1, MC1 had approximately 4.14 seconds to react and avoid the crash. In the accident report, the POI is listed as having occurred in the northbound #1 lane of MC1. This is not supported by the tire mark left by MC1 which crosses right to left over the double yellow painted lines for the center divider as depicted in the diagram. Witness #2 listed in the accident report was behind OV1 and his statement supports the physical evidence and the statement of the rider.
RiderInj: The 21 year old male operator of MC1 sustained minor injuries consisting of a brief loss of consciousness, a minor laceration to his chin, contused ribs, hyperextension of the neck and lower thoracic back area, along with abrasions and contusions. The rider was taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released. The rider displayed no signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit his ability to operate a motor vehicle.
ODriverInj: The 48 year old female operator of OV1 was not injured. She did not display any signs of intoxication or impairment that would inhibit her ability to operate a motor vehicle.
Human:
The operator of OV1 had a perception failure in not seeing MC1 approaching.
The rider of MC1 had a decision failure in swerving left into the path of OV1 that was still moving across his path of travel.
Vehicle: MC1 sustained moderate damage to the front and both sides. Most of the damage appears to be cosmetic in nature, consisting of a broken faring, headlight assembly, gauge assembly, side cover parts, a broken left handlebar, and both mirrors. There were some minor scratches to the left side plane. There was no reduction in wheelbase. The pre-crash condition of MC1 would be considered as good.OV1 was not inspected.
Environmental: There were no permanent or temporary environmental factors that would be considered contributory to this crash.

CrashType: This was another vehicle (OV1) vs. scooter (MC1) right to left side impact crash event causing a secondary impact of MC1 with the roadway surface. The motorcycle rider was ejected onto the roadway surface sustaining critical head injuries.
MV1: 2008 Vespa LX50 Piaggio (scooter) 49.40cc, silver in color
OV1: 1998 Chevrolet Silverado utility Pick-up truck, white in color
Crash:
This was another vehicle vs. motorcycle side swipe type injury crash event. The collision occurred on Saturday September 2015 @ 1500 hours in Southern California. The weather report for 1453 hours showed clear skies, a SSW wind direction at 12.7 mph, and an ambient temperature of 82.9 degrees F. Visibility at ground level was clear and unobstructed in all directions for up to 10.0 miles. Both vehicles were traveling southbound on a left curve 90 foot wide multiple
lane principal (non-freeway) arterial roadway with a -1.9% grade and +1.8% crown.	The roadway was found to be of an asphalt composition which appeared to be worn and polished otherwise in satisfactory condition. The principal arterial roadway has three lanes designated for southbound traffic as well as three lanes for northbound traffic. The opposing lanes are separated by a 12 foot wide raised concrete median containing low lying surface vegetation and trees.
Both sides of the roadway have 7 foot wide marked ?Bike Lanes? and 5 foot wide raised concrete sidewalks. The environment surrounding the crash site is rural wilderness. Other than the posted 50mph speed limit signs there were no electronic, posted or marked traffic control devices regulating the flow of traffic in the area of the crash site.

MC1 was a 2008 Vespa LX50 Piaggio (step through style) scooter being operated by a 58 year old unlicensed male rider. MC1 was traveling southbound in the 5 foot wide designated ?Bike Lane? along the west side of the principal arterial roadway with the flow of traffic. The rider was traveling at a speed of about 35- 40 mph.
OV1 was a 1998 Chevrolet Silverado utility pick-up truck, white in color, being operated by a 42 year old unlicensed male driver.	The driver was traveling southbound in the #3 lane of the principal arterial roadway at about 40 mph approaching MC1.
As the rider continued southbound still in the ?Bike Lane? OV1 was continuing to approaching from behind in the #3 lane. As OV1 came up adjacent to MC1 the driver drifted over just enough to capture the left side of MC1 while it was still inside the bike lane. The resulting impact caused the rider of MC1 to lose
control of the scooter.	The rider and scooter continued southbound for another 60 feet with the rider attempting to gain control through braking and swerving however the scooter collapsed right side down ejecting the rider onto the roadway surface.	The rider either rolled or tumbled another 8 feet before coming
to rest adjacent to the raised concrete curb along the west side of the road.
OV1 sustained minor scuff type damage along the right side of the vehicle and the driver was uninjured.
 
There were no other vehicles, pedestrians, animals or, environmental conditions that caused or contributed to the crash event.
RiderInj: The unlicensed 58 year old male rider of MC1 sustained abrasions to the left leg and an unspecified traumatic head injury. He was treated at the scene and transported to a local hospital for admission and treatment. There was no evidence of drug or alcohol involvement.
ODriverInj: The unlicensed 42 year old male driver of OV1 was uninjured.
Human:
Although the unlicensed 58 year old male rider of MC1 was operating his vehicle with reasonable safety he was traveling outside the lanes of travel for motor vehicles well inside a designated ?Bike Lane? reserved for pedal cycle traffic.
The unlicensed 42 year old male driver of OV1 failed to notice his position on the roadway; drifting to the right and entering the bike lane. The driver had insufficient time to react before his vehicle impacted with MC1.
Vehicle:
MC1 sustained moderate left and right side damage as a result of impacting with OV1 and the roadway surface however, appeared to have been in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
OV1 sustained minor right side scuff type damage however appeared to be in satisfactory operating condition prior to the crash.
Environmental: There were no environmental factors that were determined to have contributed to the cause or outcome of this crash event.

CrashType:
MC1 was northbound in #2 lane when OV1 made a lane change to the right, in front of MC1. OV1 was going slower than the posted speed limit. MC1 Tried to steer left and brake, but still impacted OV1 to the rear and went down. The rider was fully ejected and sustained minor injuries. MC1 had no
passenger.
Crash:
This crash occurred on a six lane major arterial, north of a signal controlled intersection. There are three through lanes in each direction. The roadway has a left curve in the rider?s direction. The roadway has a curb high raised center divider that is 4? wide. No on-street parking is allowed. The crown of the roadway was measured to be 1.8%. The grade was measured to be +1.6%. Both sides of the roadway are commercial/retail. The roadway is made of an asphalt composition, is worn and polished, but in otherwise good repair.
